He has a notable history of atrial fibrillation on dabigatran as well as numerous vascular risk factors including prior myocardial infarction, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, hypothyroidism, and current tobacco use. He awoke feeling well but while talking to his daughter at 9: 45 AM his speech started to slur. He felt that it was "difficult to get the words out" which he describes as his speech "stuttering." He looked in the mirror and tried to smile and noticed that the right side of his face did not move but the left side of his face did. Of note, his daughter reports that she thought it was the left side of his face that was not moving correctly. He thought there might be some sensory disturbance on his face initially. The symptoms all resolved within 20 minutes and prior to his arrival at this emergency department. A code stroke was called for question of transient ischemic attack. Currently, he only feels lightheadedness and a dull frontal headache. He denies any other symptoms but does not yet feel back to normal. On neurologic review of systems, the patient endorses headache and lightheadedness. Denies confusion. Endorses difficulty with producing or comprehending speech. Endorses dysarthria. Denies loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, vertigo, tinnitus, hearing difficulty, or dysphagia. Denies muscle weakness. Denies loss of sensation. Denies bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait. On general review of systems, the patient denies fevers, rigors, night sweats, or noticeable weight loss. Denies chest pain, palpitations, dyspnea, or cough. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or abdominal pain. Denies dysuria or hematuria. Denies myalgias, arthralgias, or rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH/PSH: [] Cardiovascular - Afib/Aflutter (on dabigatran), MI (s/p PCI in ___, HTN, mixed dyslipidemia [] Endocrine - Hypothyroidism [] Pulmonary - COPD, OSA [] Renal - Membranous nephropathy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> <FAMILY HISTORY> There is no history of neurologic disease including strokes, seizures, or intracranial hemorrhages. Motor leg, left - 0 6b. Motor leg, right - 0 7. Limb Ataxia - 0 8. Sensory - 0 9. Language - 0 10. Dysarthria - 0 11. Structure of speech demonstrates fluency with full sentences, intact repetition, and intact verbal comprehension. Normal reading. Content of speech demonstrates intact naming (high and low frequency) and no paraphasias. Normal prosody. No dysarthria. No apraxia. No evidence of hemineglect. [VII] No facial movement asymmetry (forced eyelid closure, volitional smile), but intermittently the right nasolabial fold is noted to be slightly flat at rest. [VIII] Hearing intact to finger rub bilaterally. (Left ear hearing aid) [IX, X] Palate elevation symmetric. [XI] SCM/Trapezius strength ___ bilaterally. Outpatient Lab Work <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnosis: TIA Secondary diagnoses: atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, hypertension, membranous glomerulonephritis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted with symptoms of transient difficulty speaking and a facial droop. By the time you reached the hospital, your symptoms had resolved, and your neurological exam was normal. We obtained an MRI, which did not show a stroke. We therefore diagnosed you with a "mini-stroke" or TIA (transient ischemic attack). Strokes and TIAs are conditions where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: - Atrial fibrillation: we will change your medications for this (see below) - SMOKING: you absolutely need to quit smoking. - High blood pressure: please continue taking your blood pressure medications. Your blood pressure was not significantly elevated while you were in the hospital. - Cholesterol: your "bad" cholesterol (LDL) is 88, which is in a good range. You should contine taking your rosuvastatin (Crestor) at the same dose. Your "good" cholesterol (HDL) is 28, which is too low. It should be over 40. You can raise your good cholesterol by losing weight, increasing your exercise, and watching your diet (limiting calories and limiting the fat and sugar in your diet). Your triglycerides are still very elevated at 436. Please continue to take your fenofibrate medication for this. - Sleep apnea has been shown to increase the risk of stroke. Please continue to use your CPAP machine at night. We are changing your medications as follows: - After discussions with you, Dr. ___ PCP), Dr. ___ cardiologist) and Dr. ___ nephrologist), we decided that you should switch from dabigatran (Pradaxa) back to warfarin (Coumadin). You were on that medication before. You will get your first dose of warfarin in the hospital, and will need to fill the prescription before tomorrow. Your INR will need to be checked at the ___ lab in ___. You should have your first check on ___ or ___. This can be done by the ___, or you can go to the lab on ___. It is very important that your INR is checked either on Sundary or ___. Dr. ___ will follow up that result on ___. The next check should be 1 or 2 days after that. The manufacturer of Pradaxa recommends that you continue to take Pradaxa for three days whilst starting warfarin, so we will provide you with 5 more tablets to take. During the time when you are taking both warfarin and Pradaxa you should not take aspirin. On ___, you can start taking a baby aspirin (81 mg) daily. This is recommended by Dr. ___ to decrease the risk of further heart problems. We discussed the increased risk of bleeding on the combination of warfarin and aspirin with you, Dr. ___ Dr. ___. Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please follow up with Dr. ___ in stroke neurology clinic. Please also follow up in cardiology clinic with Dr. ___ and in ___ clinic with Dr. ___, as listed below. Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. ___ as soon as possible. Your nephrologist recommend that you continue your blood pressure and diuretic (water pill) regimen, and your fluid restricted diet. You should limit salt intake. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - sudden partial or complete loss of vision - sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - sudden weakness of one side of the body - sudden drooping of one side of the face - sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body - sudden difficulty pronouncing words (slurring of speech) - sudden blurring or doubling of vision - sudden onset of vertigo (sensation of your environment spinning around you) - sudden clumsiness of the arm and leg on one side or sudden tendency to fall to one side (left or right) - sudden severe headache accompanied by the inability to stay awake It was a pleasure providing you with care during this hospitalization.
target: ___ man who presents with 20 minutes of facial weakness, dysarthria, and possibly motor aphasia. He has a history of atrial fibrillation on dabigatran, myocardial infarction, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, obstructive sleep apnea, and membranous nephropathy. His symptoms began at 9:45 the morning of admission when talking to his daughter when he noticed that his speech was stuttering and slurred. He noticed while looking in a mirror that's the right side of his mouth did not move when he tried to smile. This resolved completely. Exam is not at baseline. MRI does not demonstrate a CVA but story is strongly suggestive of TIA. [] Assessment for Acute Cerebral Ischemia - Localization - NCHCT negative, Carotid US w/o stenosis, NC MRI do not demonstrate CVA, MRA Neck ok - Etiology - likely cardioembolic given atrial fibrillation - Neurologic Status Monitoring - neurologically stable throughout admission - Swallowing Status - passed bedside dysphagia screen - Antithrombotic Therapy - Pt's home medication of dabigatran 150 BID can likely be considered a failure at this point, so after discussing this extensively with the patient as well as his cardiologist and nephrologist, we decided to switch to warfarin, with 3-day overlap with dabigatran (as recommended by the manufacturer of Pradaxa); ASA 81 mg can be resumed after the pt is off dabigatran. INR will be managed at ___. Risk Factor Assessment/Management - HgbA1c 6.2, FLP TChol 165 HDL 28 LDL 88 ___ 436, smoking cessation counseling given (active smoker), TTE w/o significant findings & negative bubble urine/serum toxicology neg, TSH re: AF risk: 2. Sleep apnea has been shown to increase the risk of stroke. Pt was advised to continue to use his CPAP machine at night. Extensive smoking cessation counseling was provided, and pt agreed to quit smoking. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for complaints of arm pain and found to have a heart attack. You underwent a cardiac catheterization which revealed a blockage in your right coronary artery. A stent was placed in the area of the blockage opening it up and restoring flow to the heart muscle. In addition to the medicaitons and lab work you will need to quit smoking as this increases your risk of having another heart attack. You have made a good recovery following your heart attack. You have a follow up as detailed below with your cardiologist. Please make sure you keep this appointment. We have also recommended that you have pulmonary funciton tests as an outpatient. Please discuss this with your primary care doctor after discharge. It has been a pleasure taking care of you this admission. Please do not hesitate to contact us if you have any questions related to your care or stay. You have been started on a number of medications to protect your heart following the heart attack and to help preserve its funcitoning. Please see your medication list. Plavix and Aspirin must be taken daily to prevent clot reformation in the area of the stent. No one except for your cardiologist can tell you to stop taking Plavix. Failure to take this medication as directed could result in a lifethreatening heart attack. In additon to these new medications we also changed your dose of Levothroxine from 300mg daily to 100mg daily based on your thyroid function lab work. You will need to have labs drawn in 6 weeks to determine your thyroid function following this change. You will also need liver function tests and a cholesterol panel in 6 weeks as you have been started on atorvastatin a drug to prevent worsening of your cholesterol and stabilize existing cholesterol plaques. In addition on ___ you need to have your electrolytes checked since we started you on Lisinopril.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted for chest pain and were found to have a heart attack. This was treated with placement of a bare metal stent into the right coronary artery of your heart. It is very important that you take several steps in order to improve your health and help prevent future heart attacks. This includes taking your prescribed medications everyday, especially aspirin and plavix. You should also stop smoking and we have set you up with a program called Quitworks which will help provide you with resources to do this. Eating a healthy diet low in saturated fats and simple carbohydrates, and instead eating a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, nuts, and whole grains is an important part of improving your health. Lastly, after recovery from your heart attack in 3 weeks, you should begin an exercise program building up to 30 minutes of physical activity 5 days a week. Your cholesterol is also too high and you have diabetes. Both your cholesterol and diabetes can be controlled by healthy diet and exercise. Your cholesterol also requires the medication Atorvastatin which we have prescribed for you. You should follow up with your PCP regarding your diabetes, who can redraw a lab to confirm your measurement here. The following changes were made to your medications: START Aspirin 325 mg START Clopidogrel 75 mg START Atorvastatin 80mg STOP Simvastatin START Nicotine patch 14mg
target: Patient is a ___ y/o woman with H/O hypertension, hyperlipidemia, hypothyroidism, stroke, smoking and non-adherence with prescribed medication who was admitted after receiving a bare metal stent to her proximal RCA. # Vasospasm vs Aborted STEMI: Patient complained of severe chest pressure as though someone were sitting on her chest which led to her coming to the ED. In the ED, initial EKG was within normal limits and troponin-T negative x 2. However, she noted acute worsening of chest pain and felt as though her chest was about to "explode" and "pop." EKG at this time revealed STE in II, III, aVF with reciprocal ST depressions in I and aVL. These findings disappeared on a subsequent EKG minutes later. A code STEMI was called, and the patient was given a prasugrel load and transferred to the catheterization laboratory. The patient was found to have an 80% focal proximal stenosis of her RCA with TIMI 3 flow through the artery. Upon engagement of the RCA, the patient became bradycardic and this corrected with atropine. The stenosis did not respond to intracoronary nitroglycerin. The patient was subsequently bolused and infused with Integrilin. An Integrity 2.5 x 12 mm bare metal stent was placed to the RCA lesion with 0% residual stenosis. The patient was also found to have a 20% proximal stenosis of the LMCA. The patient noted resolution of chest pain after the procedure. The patient's cardiac biomarkers were negative throughout hospitalization. Most likely, the patient had vasospasm associated with her RCA stenosis leading to the ST elevations in inferior leads. Although it is possible that the patient had an acute thrombosis that resolved by the time the patient reached the cath lab, the rapidity with which these EKG findings presented and resolved is more suggestive of vasospasm. The lack of cardiac biomarker eleavtion is consistent with an acute occlusion that rapidly resolved before frank infarction could occur. The patient was treated with Integrilin for nearly 18 hours. She will continue with aspirin 325 mgs daily for 3 months, then 162 mgs daily indefinitely, Plavix 75 mg daily for at least a month, and Atorvastatin 80 mg daily indefinitely. The patient was initially started on a beta blocker, but this was discontinued since her nly flow-limiting coronary artery stenosis was intervened on and there was no other clinically significant coronary artery disease present (LMCA stenosis only 20%). She also did not have biomarker evidence of infarction or echocardiographic evidence of LV systolic heart failure to mandate beta-blockade. Prasugrel was initially given but switched to Plavix because the patient had past history of stroke. The patient will continue on her home blood pressure medications with goal <130/80. The importance of dual anti-platelet therapy to prevent stent thrombosis was reviewed with the patient, along with the importance of smoking cessation and enrollment in a cardiac rehabilitation program. # Pump: The patient had echo after stent placement. This revealed normal EF with no wall motion abnormalities. The patient had no clinical signs of diastolic heart failure. # Chronic DOE: The patient complained of dyspnea on exertion and waking up in the middle of the night coughing. Given the normal echo findings, this may be secondary to a pulmonary process from her years of smoking. Because the patient was not taking her levothyroxine, it may also be that her fatigue was from hypothyroidism (and worsening of any underlying sleep apnea). She may also have post nasal drip contributing to her night time coughing. She was advised to quit smoking and was set up with Quitworks by social work. We recommend PFTs as an outpatient. She was advised to continue taking her thyroid pill. # Smoking: The patient was counseled against smoking and was seen by social work who assisted in setting the patient up with Quitworks. The patient does want to stop smoking. She was placed on a nicotine patch in the hospital. # RUQ pain: Patient initially complained of RUQ pain. This resolved on the second day of hospitalization. Her alkaline phosphatase was mildly elevated but the GGT was normal. No imaging or intervention was performed. This can be followed up as an outpatient for resolution. # Hypertension: The patient will continue her home HCTZ-Lisinopril. # Hypothyroidism: The patient was maintained on her levothyoxine which she was not taking at home. Thyroid repletion should improve her lipid profile. # Hyperlipidemia: The patient was not taking her simvastatin. She was placed on atorvastatin 80 mg. Her LDL was 141. Goal is <100, and ideally <70. She was advised of lifestyle changes including healthy eating habits and exercise. The patient was counseled on healthy eating by nutrition. # H/o Stroke: Patient on aspirin 325 mg and started on a short course of Plavix for her new bare metal stent. # Diabetes mellitus, type II: Patient's hemoglobin A1c was elevated to 6.6%, consistent with DM. She should have a repeat HbA1c drawn as an outpatient to confirm. The patient was advised on healthy eating habits and exercise to lower her blood sugars. She will follow up with her PCP. # GERD: Continued home ranitidine # Skin: Pt complained of recurrent vesicles which burst on their own every few weeks releasing foul smelling contents in the area of her abdomen, breast, and axilla. Although there were no active lesions during her hospitalization there were residual scars. The patient was advised to follow up with dermatology as an outpatient. CODE: Full EMERGENCY CONTACT: Name of health care proxy: ___ Relationship: daughter Phone number: ___ Cell phone: ___ Transitional: 1) Follow up with cardiology to ensure patient is taking medications 2) Needs close follow up for healthy lifestyle habits including nutrition and exercise 3) Repeat HgbA1c to diagnose with DM II 4) Follow up on alkaline phosphatase elevation 5) Quitworks to stop smoking 6) PFTs 7) Dermatology for recurrent vesicles

target: [] BRIEF CLINICAL COURSE: ___ w/ H/O CAD s/p multiple PCIs including rotational atherectomy, stenting and balloon angioplasty of the proximal RCA, RPDA, LCx and LAD, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, moderate aortic insufficiency, moderate tricuspid and mitral regurgitation, moderate pulmonary arterial systolic hypertension, cerebrovascular disease with transient ischemic attacks s/p left carotid endarterectomy and stage 4 chronic kidney disease presenting with left arm and neck pain, c/f TIA. The patient underwent a thorough TIA workup which was non revealing and was catheterized with placement of DES in LAD after failing his stress test. . [] ACTIVE ISSUES: # UNSTABLE ANGINA: Patient has an extensive history of CAD with multiple PCIs, including rotational artherectomy, stunting and balloon angioplasty of the proximal RCA, RPDA, LCx, and LAD. Most recently, the patient had a cath on ___ with BMS to the RCA; the procedure was complicated by dissection, necessitating placement of two further bare metal stents. On this admission, the patient had atypical chest pain with the epicenter in the left armpit that initially radiated upward and to the left towards the right jaw; this pain was different from prior anginal episodes and EKGs were largely unremarkable. His presentation, with a transient expressive aphasia was more concerning for TIA on admission. Cardiac enzymes were negative X 3 and his chest pain waned. After concern for TIA had diminished after consulting with neurology, the patient underwent a stress test in which he exercised for total 6 minutes on Gervino Protocol with an estimated maximum MET capacity of ___ METS with the test being stopped due to drop in systolic blood pressure. Given this outcome, the patient was prepped for cardiac catheterization with pre/post contrast hydration. During the cardiac catheterization, a ___ ___ was placed to the LAD, ffr normal after. Medical management for circ and left main disease was recommended, and the patient was maintained on integrillin for 18hrs, got 300 plavix, with close urine output monitoring. We also optimized the patient's anti-anginal meds: Isosorbide Dinitrate was increased to 40 mg PO/NG TID then switched to 120mg imdur. At discharge, the patient was chest pain free and cleared by physical therapy for return to home. . # Transient Expressive Aphasia: Patient with h/o TIA's ___ years prior. Presentation for this admission c/f TIA given expressive aphasia for 1.5 minutes. Neurology notified of patient once on the floor and came to bedside for eval. Non contrast CT head, no evidence of intracranial bleed and the patient was allowed to have permissive HTN to BP < 180 systolic. Neuro followed the patient during this admission; MRA final read no evidence of acute stroke, chronic small vessel ischemia apparent, no findings to suggest acute or subacute ischemia and patent bilateral carotid arteries. TTE, compared to prior study from ___, mild to mod AS now present. We continued the patient on ASA, plavix. The patient will be closely followed as an outpatient. . []CHRONIC ISSUES: # : PUMP: TTE on ___ compared to prior study from ___, mild to mod AS now present, pulm artery diastolic HTN is new. . # HTN: On admission, given concern for a TIA, the patient was allowed to have permissive HTN to 180 systolic. His systolic pressures were in the 150-170 range for the first 2 days of this admission and by discharge, pressures were 110-140 systolic. The patient was given hydralazine PRN, continued on metoprolol, furosemide, and isosorbide as above for angina. The patient's home dose of valsartan was restarted at discharge. . # HLD: We continued atorvastatin 80mg daily . # CKD: Cr 2.2 on admission. Known Stage 4 CKD, Cr baseline ~2.0. We trended his creatinine throughout this admission. Creatinine remained stable throughout this hospitalization. He received pre/post-contrast IVF hydration, gentle given cardiac disease. He will have close monitoring of his serum chemistries as an outpatient. . []TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -The patient was discharged with a holter event monitor that will be managed by his outpatient cardiologist. -The patient had a significant contrast load given his CKD and will require outpatient monitoring of his creatinine post cath.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - gait unsteady, needs supervision <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had chest pain and collapsed in a bar. You were unresponsive but it is unclear why. You were defibrillated and brought to ___ ___, then transferred to ___. A cardiac catheterization showed that you have blockages in your heart arteries but they did not appear to cause your collapse. We did not place any stents at this time. An Electrophysiology doctor team saw you here and did not think that you need to have any further workup for an irregular heart rhythm. You did have a heart attack and we started many new medicines to help your heart recover from the heart attack. It is very important that you take these medicines every day and go to the scheduled doctor's appointments. You also need to stop drinking and smoking to prevent another similar incident and to help the medicines work. A neurology team evaluated you and thought that your forgetfulness and unsteadiness is due to your collapse and possible lack of oxygen to your brain. They do not think that more tests are necessary and they feel that you will improve gradually. . Start taking the following medicines: 1. Aspirin 325 mg daily to prevent another heart attack 2. Plavix 75 mg daily to prevent another hear attack 3. Atorvastatin 80 mg daily to prevent further blockages in your arteries. 4. Metoprolol 50 mg daily to slow your heart rate and prevent another heart attack 5. Lisinopril 10 mg daily to lower your blood pressure 6. Nitroglycerin under your tongue as directed for chest pain 7. Folic acid 1 mg daily and thiamine 100 mg daily for nutritional reasons as you were drinking heavily 8. Nicotine patch one daily to help you quit smoking.
target: ___ male with alcohol abuse and no other significant past medical history became unconscious at a bar with resultant CPR for ventricular fibrillation arrest. He was taken to an OSH where he was thought to have ventricular fibrillation arrest s/p shock x1 and transferred to ___ for further care with cardiac cath showing recent RCA occlusion suggestive of ischemic mechanism for arrest and aortic stenosis. Hospital course complicated by femoral groin site bleed, alcohol withdrawal, severe systemic hypertension, and encephalopathy. # One vessel coronary artery disease with cardiac arrest The patient arrived intubated for airway protection in setting of cardiac arrest. Etiology of cardiac arrest may be related to RCA occlusion; however, complete data are not available especially from EMS to state whether or not this was a true cardiac arrest as no rhythm strips are available from EMS. The OSH documented ventricular fibrillation; however, only one strip available in the chart and per electrophysiology review, uncertain if represents such arrest. No further work-up for abnormal heart rhythm was advised by EP. Initial ECG on admission showed ST-elevation in V1, III, and aVF with j-point depression in V2 and non-specific ST-T abnormalities. Cardiac biomarkers peaked with troponinT peak of 1.51 and CK-MB 214 and trended down with some component likely attributable to CPR and electrical shock during resuscitation. Therapeutic hypothermia was not initiated in the ___ emergency department as mental status was not impaired. He was started on empiric treatment for ACS including nitroglycerin infusion secondary to high systemic hypertension in setting of alcohol withdrawal and underwent c. cath showing one-vessel coronary artery disease with peaked appearance of RCA suggestive of recent occlusion. There was no intervention performed as there appeared to be collaterals to PDA and right-sided vessels from LCx, the lesion appeared to be acute-on-chronic with LCx-dominant anatomy, and RCA did not supply a significant amount of myocardium at baseline LVEF > 55 %) After extubation, patient reported several day history of chest discomfort supporting likely possible ischemic etiology of arrest. Cardiac cath was complicated by left femoral groin site bleed secondary to patient leg movement despite instructions. Pressure was held for 20 minutes. Bedside US did not indicate pseudoaneurysm. On discharge, there was a soft hematoma measuring at least 2 cm x 2 cm around the area with no femoral bruit. The patient continued to report severe chest pain consistent with MSK etiologies especially in setting of recent CPR with serial ECGs and cardiac biomarkers not suggestive of acute ischemic event. His pain was treated with oxycodone. CXR was not suggestive of rib fractures. He remained in NSR throughout hospitalization. Labs indicated A1c 5.6 and cholesterol panel of total cholesterol 182, ___ 90, HDL 67, LDL 97. He was discharged on aspirin 325 mg PO qD, atorvastatin 80 mg PO qD, clopidogrel 75 mg PO qD, lisinopril 10 mg PO qD, and metoprolol succinate 50 mg PO qD. He will ___ with cardiology after discharge for aggressive medical optimization. # Mild aortic stenosis Patient endorses family history of aortic stenosis with possible bicuspid valve in family member. C. cath indicated peak-to-peak gradient of 30 mmHg suggestive of mild aortic stenosis. He will ___ with cardiology as above. # Probable peripheral vascular disease Patient reported symptoms of claudication and exam significant for disparate pulses notably in femoral area. He will ___ with cardiology for further evaluation. # Alcohol abuse with alcohol withdrawal and tobacco abuse The patient was actively drinking about ___ drinks per day. It is uncertain what "a drink" constitutes for the patient, so his effective alcohol intake may be much higher than ___ days. He was given a banana bag and nutritional supplementation in addition to other supportive measures. He has had withdrawal symptoms in the past without a history of seizures or DTs. He also has concurrent substance abuse with marijuana. Urine tox was negative for other substances such as cocaine. He was placed on a CIWA scale and treated for withdrawal. He had not seizures or adverse events related to alcohol withdrawal during hospitalization. Social work was consulted and discussed substance abuse. Patient plans to schedule outpatient evaluation including mental health appointment for treatment of anxiety symptoms. # Transaminitis Admission LFTs significant for ALT 45, AST 74 and CPK in ___ supporting a potential muscular etiology in setting of CPR and electrical shocks. LFTs trended down to ALT 49, AST 60 with no disturbances in synthetic markers such as Tbili or INR. Given concurrent alcohol abuse, it is uncertain if another process such as a primary liver process is contributing somewhat to elevation. Repeat LFTs and CK are advised at PCP ___. He was discharged on a multivitamin, folate, and thiamine. # Acute toxic-metabolic encephalopathy The patient seemed to be inattentive. Occupational therapy evaluation noted severe short term memory deficits, decreased safety awareness, and issues with functional mobility and balance. His function was below baseline level and required verbal cues to be safe. Cognitive rehab secondary to impulsiveness, cognitive impairments, and poor insight was recommended. Exam was significant for positive romberg, nystagmus, and ataxia. Given concern for ___'s encephalopathy, neurology was consulted with impression of subtle cerebellar deficits and mild ataxia on finger to nose. These findings were thought to be due to combination of pre-existing cerebellar atrophy secondary to alcohol abuse as well as possible mild anoxic brain injury due to cardiac arrest. It was also thought that the component of inattentiveness may be secondary to resolving encephalopathy due to alcohol withdrawal. ___'s encephalopathy was unlikely given that he lacked ophthalmoplegia. Overall, it was felt that the patient will likely improve over time. He should ___ in the cognitive neurology clinic if cognition remains problematic in ___ weeks. He was discharged home with 24-hour supervision by family. CODE: full COMM: ___ ___, girlfriend. Father - HCP - ___ - ___, cell ___.

Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY RX *lisinopril 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *1 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> # Non-ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction with # Multivessel Coronary Artery Disease # Hypertension # History of Transient Ischaemic Attack # Cocaine Use Disorder # Tobacco/nicotine addiction (cigarettes) <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain. You were found to have very high blood pressure, and lab tests (specifically, cardiac enzymes) showed us that you had a heart attack. We controlled your pain and blood pressure with medications through the IV (specifically, morphine and nitroglycerine). You underwent a procedure called a cardiac catheterization, which allowed us to look at the blood vessels in your heart. We saw that you had a blockage in one of them (specifically, at the far end of the left circumflex artery, also known as the distal LCx), which was opened with a small balloon. A metal tube, called a stent, was placed in this artery to help keep it open. You tolerated this procedure well, and did not have any further chest pain after this procedure. You then had an echocardiogram, or an ultrasound picture of your heart. This picture showed us that your heart's ability to squeeze and pump blood was still within the normal range. In addition, we monitored your heart during this hospital stay, and it showed slow heart rates with normal heart rhythm (also called sinus bradycardia). Due to this heart attack, you received several medications that you shall need to continue after leaving the hospital. Most importantly, you were started on aspirin at a dose of 81 mg every day (also known as a "baby aspirin") and clopidogrel (also called Plavix) at a dose of 75 mg every day. These medications help to keep your stent open. Missing even a single dose of either of these medications could cause a massive heart attack and/or death. It is very important that you do not stop taking these two medications without first speaking with a cardiologist. In addition, you were started on a medication called atorvastatin (also called Lipitor) at a dose of 80 mg every evening. This medication is to keep your heart arteries healthy, to prevent future heart attacks, and to lower your cholesterol. This medication has specifically been proven to help patients live longer after a heart attack. For your high blood pressure, you were started on a new medication called amlodipine (also called Norvasc) at a dose of 10 mg every day. We continued your old high blood pressure medication, called lisinopril, still at the same dose of 10 mg every day. We would like you to continue using both of these medications for high blood pressure. We discussed at length the importance of quitting smoking to keep your heart healthy, to prevent future heart attacks, and for your overall health. You are leaving the hospital with a prescription for nicotine patches, which ought to help curb cravings for tobacco. In addition, we discussed the importance of quitting cocaine to keep your heart healthy, to prevent future heart attacks, to control your blood pressure, and for your overall health. It is very important that you keep your follow-up appointments with both your new primary care physician and with your new Cardiologist (heart doctor). Please do not stop or skip any doses of your medications without first speaking with these doctors. ___ was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___ ___. Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish you all the best! Your ___ Healthcare Team
target: Mr ___ is a ___ yo M with H/O multiple TIAs, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cocaine use disorder who presents as a transfer from ___ with chest pain and elevated troponins consistent with NSTEMI. CTA at ___ failed to demonstrate evidence of pulmonary embolus or or aortic dissection. At ___, he underwent PCI with DES x1 to distal LCx with improvement in flow and resolution of symptoms. TTE demonstrated preserved EF. He endorsed no signs or symptoms of heart failure. ACUTE ISSUES: # NSTEMI / CAD: Mr. ___ presented with ___ chest pain at rest with positive cardiac biomarkers without definitive ischemic changes on ECG (no ST depressions, no ST elevations > 1 mm, no T wave changes), all consistent with a NSTEMI. Right-sided ECG did not demonstrate any evidence of RV infarction. His CAD risk factors included hypertension, hyperlipidemia, ongoing cigarette smoker, and intermittent cocaine use. He was initially started on nitroglycerine gtt without change in chest pain and then received morphine 4 mg IV with resolution of chest pain. He was started on heparin gtt and was taken for cardiac catheterization on ___. This demonstrated Right dominance, subtotal occlusion of the distal LCx and 70 % mid RCA stenosis. He received DES x1 to the distal LCx with improvement in flow and resolution of symptoms. TTE demonstrated LVEF = 62 % with preserved biventricular regional and global systolic function, indeterminate LV diastolic function, mild aortic stenosis (valve area 1.2-1.9 cm2) and mild symmetric LVH. Troponin-T peaked at 1.53 and CK-MB peaked at 43. HbA1c = 5.5 %. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin 81 mg PO daily and clopidogrel 75 mg PO daily, for a planned 30 months following a clopidogrel load of 600mg. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily was also started, which Mr ___ tolerated well. Given asymptomatic bradycardia with rates as low as mid-30s and Mr. ___ history of cocaine use, beta-blockade was not initiated. As described below, Mr. ___ was discharged on amlodipine 10 mg PO daily for his residual CAD and lisinopril 10 mg PO daily for hypertension and post-MI secondary prevention. We discussed at length the importance of smoking cessation, and Mr ___ agreed to trying nicotine patches. # Hypertension: Mr. ___ was initially hypertensive with SBP = 176 mm Hg on presentation to ___. He was started on nitroglycerine gtt which, along with analgesics, brought his SBP to the 150s. He reported being prescribed lisinopril 10 mg PO daily, though he stated that he had not been taking this for approximately 1 week prior to admission as he ran out. Later he reported that he had not received a prescription for lisinopril in "years." In the ___ period, he was started on amlodipine 10 mg PO daily, which he tolerated well. On discharge, lisinopril 10 mg PO daily was restarted. CHRONIC PROBLEMS: # History of TIA: Mr. ___ reports 4 TIA-like episodes, last ___ years ago, characterized by L sided weakness (face, arm and leg) and slurred speech. These occurred in the context of arguing with his then-girlfriend. He stated that no cause had been found. He reported being told by a Neurologist to take full-dose aspirin and a statin, though he stated that he had been non-compliant with the statin. He denied any persistent symptoms, and neurologic exam remained unremarkable during this hospital stay. He was discharged on DAPT (aspirin and clopidogrel) and atorvastatin. # Cocaine Use Disorder: Mr. ___ reported using cocaine "a few times a year," last approximately 4 weeks prior to admission. We discussed cocaine use as a risk factor for MI, and he stated that he understood. He did not endorse plans to continue using cocaine. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: MEDICATIONS STARTED: amLODIPine 10 mg PO/NG DAILY, Atorvastatin 80 mg PO/NG QPM, Clopidogrel 75 mg PO/NG DAILY, Nicotine Patch 14 mg TD DAILY - Patient hypertensive to SBP 160-180s while inpatient but improved to 110-130s after being started on amlodipine (home lisinopril continued but unclear as to how reliably he was taking this). Repeat BP as outpatient for potential adjustment of his antihypertensives. - Consider rechecking kidney function/electrolytes for patient restarting ACE-I - Patient counseled as to the importance of smoking cessation and discharged with nicotine patches. - Patient counseled as to the importance of abstaining from cocaine use and seen by social work prior to discharge. - Patient will be on lifetime aspirin 81 mg daily and clopidogrel 75 mg daily for at least one year after ___ ___. - Patient had f/u w/ new PCP (Dr. ___ at ___ ___ and cardiology (Dr. ___ at ___). Cardiology f/u not until next month but patient provided with instructions to call next week to see if any sooner appointments available.

He denies radiation, dyspnea, n/v, visual changes, no diaphoresis. He did not take anything for it. His sister called ___. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. . No atrial septal defect or patent foramen ovale is seen by 2D, color Doppler or saline contrast with maneuvers (cannot definitively exclude). Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets are mildly thickened. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no pericardial effusion. Exercise MIBI performed on ___ demonstrated: The image quality is good. Left ventricular cavity size is normal. Resting and stress perfusion images reveal partially reversible perfusion defect in the inferior wall. Gated images reveal normal wall motion. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 55%. No prior studies. IMPRESSION: Partially reversible perfusion defect in the inferior wall. CARDIAC CATH performed on ___ demonstrated: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed multi-vessel native disease. The ___ was without angiographically-apparent disease. The LAD had a 60% proximal lesion with good competitive flow from the LIMA. The LCX had mild diffuse disease. The RCA had a long proximal 90% lesion extending to the mid-vessel. 2. Graft angiography revealed a patent SVG-D1 and LIMA-LAD. The SVG-RCA was occluded. 3. Left ventriculography revealed normal ejection fraction calculated at 58% with no wall motion abnormalities. 4. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed an elevated LVEDP of 26mmHg. 5. Successful PTCA and stenting of the proximal and mid RCA was performed with overlapping 2.5x28 mm and 3.0x33 mm Cypher stents which were postdilated to 3.0 and 3.5 mm respectively. Final angiography revealed 0% residual stenosis, no dissection, and TIMI 3 flow. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Normal ventricular function. 3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the proximal and mid RCA. Admission CXR: No acute intrathoracic pathology is noted including no pneumonia or heart fail ___ Cardiac Cath: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system revealed three vessel disease. The LMCA had no angiographically-apparent disease. The LAD had mild luminal irregularities, a proximal 60% stenosis, and a mid-vessel 50% stenosis. The LCx had a 60% stenosis at its origin. The RCA had a proximal 50% ISR with mid vessel 90% stenosis. 2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed widely patent LIMA-LAD. The SVG-D1 had a mid vessel 90% stenosis with diffuse noncritical disease. 3. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed mild systemic systolic arterial hypertension with SBP of 154 mmHg and DBP of 68 mmHg. 4. Left ventriculography was deferred. 5. Successful stenting of the mid RCA ISRS with a 3.0 x 16 mm TAXUS DES. Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and TIMI II flow (See ___ comments) 5. Successful stenting of teh mid SVG to the diagonal with two overlapping 3.5 x 18 and 3.5 x 13 proximal to distal CYPHER DES. Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and TIMI III flow (see ___ comments) FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Systemic arterial hypertension. 3. Successful stenting of the mid RCA with a DES. 4.Successful stenting of the mid SVG to the diagonal with two overlapping DES. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Metformin 1500 mg qam and 1000 mg pm Glyburide 10 mg BID Metoprolol 150 mg BID Plavix 75mg QD Protonix 40 mg QD Lisinopril 40 mg QAM Simvastatin 40 mg QAM Aspirin 325 mg QD HCTZ 25 mg QD <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Disp: *30 Tablet, Sublingual(s)* Refills: *0* 6. Amlodipine 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 7. Protonix 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day. 8. Simvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 9. Chantix 0.5(11)-1(3X14) mg Tablets, Dose Pack Sig: as instructed Tablets, Dose Pack PO as instructed: Days 1 - 3: 0.5 mg once daily Days 4 - 7: 0.5 mg twice daily Day 8 - End of treatment: 1 mg twice daily . Disp: *1 dose pack* Refills: *0* 10. Metformin 1500mg QAM daily and 1000mg QPM daily 11. Glyburide 10mg twice daily Home diabetic regimen initially omitted from discharge paperwork. Patient called at home and instructed to continue. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Unstable Angina Coronary Artery Disease In-stent coronary artery occlusion Hypertension, uncontrolled Diabetes Mellitus, type II uncontrolled Dyslipidemia Tobacco Dependence <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Vital Signs stable, ambulating, chest pain free without any shortness of breath. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You have been evaluated for chest pain during this admission and found to have two heart vessels occluded during cardiac catheterization. You underwent new stent placement in your right coronary artery and your diagonal artery. It is essential that you continue to take your daily aspirin and plavix for atleast one year and that you do not stop these medications without discussing this with your doctor. We have also made changes to your home blood pressure medications. Please note that your home lisinopril has been changed to include a second medication, hydrochlorothiazide. Also, norvasc has been added daily. Your cholesterol was found to not be completely controlled. We increased your simvastatin dose to 40mg daily to 80mg daily. You may double up on the pills you have at home until you fill your new prescription. If you develop any new myalgias, please return to the 40mg dose. It was also noted during your stay that your blood sugars and triglycerides are not well controlled. Please follow-up with your primary care physician to discuss optimal management in the next ___ weeks. In the meantime, please continue your home regimen. Please also stop smoking. This, in addition to optimizing your medical regimen, will help prevent further chest pain and future risk of heart attack. You have been given a prescription for chantix to assist you in quiting smoking. Please call you physician if you experience any depression or suicide thoughts while taking this medication. Please call your doctor or return to the emergency department if you experience any chest pain, shortness of breath, worsening leg swelling, or any other concerning new problems.
target: Patient is a ___ yo male w/CAD s/p CABG in ___ (LIMA-LAD; SVG-RCA and SVG-D1) and PTCA in ___ with stenting of the proximal and mid RCA, HTN, DM2 tobacco use who presented with ___onsistent with prior anginal pain, currently CP free. #. Chest pain - Presentation was consistent with anginal symptoms in a patient s/p CABG and PTCA ___. In the ED, after 3 SL nitroglycerin tablets, the patient was CP free. EKG showed new lateral lead ST depressions. Enzymes were negative. The decision was made for cardiac catheterization in this patient with a story of unstable angina. Left heart catheterization revealed 90% in-stent restenosis in the mid RCA and a 90% stenosis in the mid SVG to the diagonal which were treated with three drug eluting stents. Patient had no complicates from the procedure and was ambulating on the unit, chest pain free on the following morning. Medical management was optimized with ASA 325 mg QD, Plavix 75 mg QD, Metoprolol 150 mg BID, Lisinopril 40 mg QD, simvastatin 80 mg QD, HCTZ 25 mg QD, and Amlodipine 5mg QD. Patient was counselled on smoking cessation and requested Chantix to aid him in quitting. Further optimization of blood pressure and diabetes are recommended during outpatient follow up. #. Pump - EF from ___ ___ showed EF 55% without Left Ventricular dysfunction. Patient remained euvolemic without signs or symptoms of fluid overload. #. Rhythm - NSR, monitored on telemetry without arrhythmia event. #. Diabetes Mellitus, non-insulin dependent, uncontrolled - Patient treated with metformin 1500mg/1000mg BID and glipizide 10mg BID with inadequate control. Patient was covered with an insulin sliding scale during this admission. Patient was informed to return to his current outpatient regimen on discharge and instructed to follow up with his primary care physician within the week for better control. An HbA1c was checked prior to discharge to aid in this. #. HTN- Patient was found to be hypertensive in the 160-180s on admission. Norvasc 5mg daily was added to his regimen with improvement in systolic blood pressures to 140 on discharge. It is recommended that the patient have further tightening of blood pressure control as an outpatient. #. Hypercholesterolemia- Patient was discharge on simvastatin 80mg QD as lipid profile during this admission revealed LDL of 99, not at goal for a diabetic with coronary disease. #. Tobacco dependence - Baseline CXR w/o abnormalities. Patient was advised on the importance of smoking cessation. He requested a prescription for Chantix on discharge. He was given a one month starter pack supply and it is recommended that he follow up with his primary care physician for monthly maintenance packs if the patient is successful with Chantix. He was provided with patient information about the drug and instructed to call his physician if he notices any depressive symptoms. #. h/o stroke - Aspirin and Plavix for secondary prevention were continued and his antihypertensive regimen was optimized. #. FEN Patient instructed on a heart-health, low salt cardiac diet. Electrolytes were monitored and replete during his stay. # GERD - Patient continued on PPI during this admission and discharge home on his home regimen. #. Access: PIV #. PPx: heparin sc, PPI, bowel regimen #. Code: Full . #. Dispo: to home with primary care and cardiology follow up.

Right groin dressing clean, dry and intact; right groin nontender to palpation; 2+ distal pulses <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 53AM WBC-10.7 RBC-4.70 HGB-14.9 HCT-44.2 MCV-94 MCH-31.6 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.0 ___ 07: 53AM NEUTS-82.3* LYMPHS-11.2* MONOS-5.7 EOS-0.5 BASOS-0.3 ___ 07: 53AM PLT COUNT-283 ___ 07: 53AM ___ PTT-31.0 ___ ___ 07: 53AM GLUCOSE-109* UREA N-15 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.3 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-26 ANION GAP-13 ___ 07: 53AM cTropnT-1.23* ___ 04: 20PM CK(CPK)-985* CK-MB-77* MB INDX-7.8* cTropnT-1.55* ___ 06: 45AM BLOOD CK-MB-26* cTropnT-3.13* ___ 04: 20PM CHOLEST-192 HDL CHOL-58 CHOL/HDL-3.3 ___ ECG ___ Sinus rhythm. Inferior wall myocardial infarction of indeterminate age. Early R wave progression. Consider posterior myocardial infarction. Since the previous tracing of ___ inferior T wave abnormalities are now more prominent. R wave progression earlier. Lateral precordial Q wave persists. Clinical correlation is suggested. CXR ___ PA and lateral views of the chest were provided demonstrating no focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax. The heart and mediastinal contours are normal. A fat pad is noted along the right heart border. Bony structures are intact. Cardiac Catheterization ___ - Hemodynamics (see above): Normal systemic arterial BP - Coronary angiography: right dominant - LMCA: Patent, relatively short - LAD: Calcified system throughout with serial focal lesions including 70%. The large diag has 80% focal at its origin. A calcified 70% lesion is noted at and just beyond the takeoff of a relatively large septal branch. A small diag originates from this lesion is totally occluded. There is a second relatively large septal branch that takes off distally (proximal to a small diagonal branch). Both septals have 60% stenosis at origins. Both septals provide collaterals to the distal RCA branches. The apical LAD also provides RCA collaterals. - LCX: Calcified throughout with mild luminal irregularities. The OM1 is subtotally occluded proximally. The OM2 is stump occluded (dye stain noted at the origin indicating recent thrombus) with distal filling via L-L collaterals. This is likely the culprit. - RCA: Diffusely diseased throughout and occludes distally. The distal branches are diminutive and receive R-R (via AM) and L-R (LAD system) collaterals. Interventional details - Change for ___ R CFA sheath. AC with UFH and Integrilin. Therapeutic ACT confirmed. ___ XB guide 3.5 provided adequate support throughout the case. Decision to treat the culprit lesion (occluded OM2) and the subtotally occluded OM1. - Starting with the OM2: Crossed with Prowater wire with ease. Intraluminal position confirmed with distal injection. Predilated with 2.0x12 mm balloon performing 3 overlapping inflations ___ ATM). Noted intraluminal defect in distal vessel. Therefore, performed Export thrombectomy (4 passess). Additional predilatations with 2.5x20 mm balloon (2 overlapping inflations to ___ ATM). Vessel recoil developed rapidly, therefore, stented with 2 overlapping Promus Element drug-eluting stent (2.5x28 distally and 2.75x20 mm proximally). Postdilated the overlap zone with the stent balloon inflated to 16 ATM. Final angiography showed excellent result with 0% residual stenosis within the stents and no apparent dissection or distal emboli. - We then directed our attention to the OM1 lesion. Predilated with 2.0x12 mm balloon at 8 ATM then deployed 2.25x16 mm Promus Element drug-eluting stent at 10 ATM with full balloon expansion. Final angiography showed excellent result with 0% residual stenosis and no apparent dissection or distal emboli. - The R CF arteriotomy was then closed with ___ angioseal with adequate hemostasis. - Patient became pain free by end of procedure. He left the cath lab free from angina and in stable condition. Echocardiogram ___ The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is mildly dilated. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal to mid infero-lateral hypokinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, LV regional systolic dysfunction is now present. The degree of MR seen has decreased. (EF 50%) ECG ___ Sinus rhythm. Consider infero-posterolateral myocardial infarction of indeterminate age. Since the previous tracing probably no significant change. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Amlodipine 10 mg PO DAILY 2. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you while you were here at ___. You were admitted to the hospital after you had a heart attack. You ha a cardiac catheterization and we saw a blockage in the artery that gives blood to your heart. This was opened up with a stent and you were then pain free and are safe to go home. You were seen by physical therapy and they instructed you to not exert yourself too much prior to your follow-up appointment with Dr. ___ new cardiologist. You were started on multiple new medications to help your heart heal, keep that stent open and prevent further heart attacks. It is critically important that you take your prasugrel every single day and do not miss any doses to make sure your stent stays open. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with history of hyperlipidemia, hypertension, 40 pack-year smoking history admitted for NSTEMI, now s/p coronary angiography and DES to OM1 and OM2. # CAD/NSTEMI: Patient presented with 1 week h/o progressive chest pain concerning for unstable angina, elevated troponin-T of 1.23 and EKG changes concerning for cardiac ischemia, all consistent with a NSTEMI. Chest pain was resistant to nitro drip. He underwent coronary angiography showing 3 vessel CAD and was treated with DES to the culprit lesions of OM1 and OM2. He received a clopidogral load in the cath lab and was placed on Integrilin drip x 6 hours. Troponin rose to 3.13, but CK-MB trended down 77->26. Patient was subsequently chest pain free. He was continued on ASA, changed from clopidogrel to prasugrel given body habitus and ongoing PPI use for GERD, statin and beta blocker and was discharged home with plan for close outpatient cardiology follow up and referral to outpatient cardiac rehabilitation. # Tobacco use: Patient appeared motivated to quit, stated that he would benefit from nicotine replacement therapy. He was started on nicotine patch and had no adverse symptoms. # Hypertension: Continued beta blocker and ACE-I with good blood pressure control (100s-120s/40s-70s). # Shellfish allergy: Patient reported h/o anaphylaxis to shrimp. This allergy was updated in OMR. He tolerated the iodinated contrast without difficulties. # Hyperlipidemia: Last lipid panel ___ ___ 45 HDL 55 LDL 100. Increased home atorvastatin from 20 mg to 80 mg in the setting of NSTEMI.

Your imdur dose was increased from 30mg daily to 60mg daily. Your lasix was restarted at 20mg daily. . Please take all medications as prescribed. Please go to all follow up appointments. . Patient had continued intermittent CP which was responsive to nitroglycerin IV drip over the first night of admission. She was taken to cath on ___. Cath demonstrated native 3V disease with progression of native vessel diffuse atherosclerosis and collateral insufficiency. Grafts/stents were patent with known occluded SVG-RCA. No intervention was performed. She was therefore managed medically as followed: The heparin drip was discontinued. Nitro gtt was weaned off on ___. Imdur was increased to 60mg daily. The patient remained CP free for >24hrs. She tolerated walking with physical therapy well, without shortness of breath or CP. She was continue on statin, ASA, Plavix, ACE, metoprolol, and imdur was increased as above. No further up-titration of her medications were made as her SBP remained ~100. . # Hypotension- The patient had a vasovagal episode when the sheath was pulled after cath. Her BP responded to fluids. The episode was associated with CP and lateral ST depressions. The patient has severe collateral insufficiency efforts were made to keep her BPs adequate, >90. . # Anemia- HCT was 27.2 after the cath. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ diagnostic coronary angiogram via right femoral access. ___ percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty and drug eluting stent placement to in stent restenosis of sapheonous vein graft to the posterior descending coronary artery via right radial artery. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of CAD s/p CABG, hypertension, hyperlipidemia who presented to the ___ ___ with chest pain. The patient states that two nights ago he had an episode of chest pain that started while he was watching TV. He described the pain as severe, occurring on the left side of his chest, radiating to his left arm with associated shortness of breath. He took a nitroglycerin at home which relieved his symptoms. He denied chest pain on exertion but did feel short of breath on exertion. This morning he had another episode of chest pain while he was driving his son to school and reported the same symptoms with left sided chest pain radiating to his left arm, in addition to diaphoresis. His pain was again relieved by nitroglycerin. His last heart attack was ___ years ago in ___ and his symptoms at that time were chest pain in the middle of his chest radiating to his neck. He had a cardiac cath at that time which showed patent CABG grafts, severe stent restenosis of distal SVG-RPDA. He was transferred to ___ and had a drug eluting stent placed to the SVG to the PDA. The patient was placed on aspirin and plavix and has been compliant with his medication including his antihypertensive medication. He smokes ten cigarettes daily. The patient states he hasn't been exercising much in the ___ time but in the ___ he has been active with yard-work. ER course: the patient presented with a BP of 221/139 initially. He ruled in for non-ST elevation MI by EKG and troponin. His EKG showed inferior Q waves biphasic T waves in 1 aVL V4 and inverted T waves in V5 and 6. R radial access site CDI, soft, without bleeding or hematoma, +CSM. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You went to ___ for chest pain. Your blood work and EKG showed you had a heart attack. You were transferred to ___ for a cardiac catheterization in which a drug coated stent was placed to open a blockage in the stent that is in your bypass graft of your posterior descending coronary artery. Instructions regarding the care of the access sites are included with your discharge information. An echocardiogram showed your heart's pumping function is still normal. Please continue your current medications with the following changes: - Continue Aspirin 81 mg daily, lifelong. - Continue Plavix (clopidogrel) 75 mg daily, you should take this for a minimum of one year and ONLY stop when told by a cardiologist specifically. - Start Atorvastatin 80 mg nightly for high cholesterol. - Stop lovastatin - Increase lisinopril to 30 mg daily for your high blood pressure Quitting smoking is one of the most important things you can do for your health. It can be very difficult to quit smoking. Don't give up! Please discuss quitting smoking at your follow up appointment with your primary care doctor if you were not ready to discuss a quitting plan before leaving the hospital. It is very important to take all of your heart healthy medications. In particular, aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) keep the stents in the vessels of the heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. If you stop these medications or miss ___ dose, you risk causing a blood clot to form in your heart stents, which can be life threatening. Please do not stop taking either medication without taking to your heart doctor, even if another doctor tells you to stop the medications. It is strongly recommended that you attend a cardiac rehab program. A referral form was provided to you that lists the locations of these programs. Please bring this with you to your follow up visit with your cardiologist, and they will inform you when it is safe to begin a program. If you have any urgent questions that are related to your recovery from your hospitalization or are experiencing any symptoms that are concerning to you and you think you may need to return to the hospital, please call ___ (___) Cardiology at ___. It has been a pleasure to have participated in your care and we wish you the best with your health! -Your ___ Cardiac Care Team

We strongly suggest that you go to the diabetes clinic at ___ ___ to help improve your blood sugars. . We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. target: ___ y/oF with PMH of CAD s/p multiple PCI p/w NSTEMI. . # Chest pain: given her hx of prior PCI, stable angina and uptrending CE, coronary ischemia/ NSTEMI was thought to be the likely cause of her chest pain/pressure. This is further supported by nitroglycerin gtt relieving her symptoms. EKG was stable without any significant ST changes. She had a high TIMI score and was thought to benefit from early intervention. Her nitro gtt was weaned and stopped over the first night. She underwent a TTE in the am that showed EF55% with mild AS and mild Mitral regurg and a cath that reveal stable disease that could not be intervened on. She was managed medically with ASA 325, heparin gtt, plavix 75mg, metoprolol 12.5 mg TID and atorvastatin 80mg daily. She did well overnight and was transferred to the general cardiology floor. She was seen by physical therapy and she will go home with home ___ services and cardiac Rehab as well as the medications listed above. . # DM: chronic issue, found to have a A1c of 8.7. We continued her OSH insulin regimen (aspart SS with glargine 10U at night). Her sugars continued to be high and we increased her sliding scale. She was on glyburide 5mg PO BID at home, but given her persistently high FSG we started her on glargine 10 units at night in addition to her glyburide 5mg PO BID. She will follow up in the outpatient setting for further management of her diabetes. . # HTN : 144/64 on admission, we continued home lisinopril, amlodipine and changed atenolol to metoprolol in hospital. # HLD : chronic stable issue.Trig 271, HDL 42, LDLcalc 96. Pt started on atorvastatin 80mg daily. . # Anemia: iron deficiency anemia, we continued home dose of ferrous sulfate

There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the mid to distal septum and hypokinesis of the apex. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted for an interventional cardiac procedure to open-up a partially blocked blood vessel to your heart. This blockage had been causing you chest pain. A drug eluting stent was placed in this blood vessel. These stents require that you take aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) for at least one year or possibly longer. Do not stop taking aspirin and clopidogrel for any reason unless Dr. ___ you this is OK. You risk clotting off the stent and causing another heart attack if you do not continue these medicines. Because aspirin is an important blood thinner, and you were allergic to it, you had aspirin desensitization. This was successful and you can now take aspirin and should take this medicine every day for the rest of your life. The following changes were made to your medications: ** STOP nexium, take pantoprazole instead for your heartburn. ** START aspirin 325mg by mouth once daily for at least one year to prevent the stent from clotting off. ** START Plavix (clopidogrel) 75mg by mouth once daily for at least one year to prevent the stent from clotting off ** START lisinopril 5mg by mouth once daily to lower your blood pressure ** STOP taking simvastatin, start atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily to lower your cholesterol ** START nicotine patch every day to help you quit smoking. This is the most important thing you can do for your health. ** STOP taking metoprolol for now, Dr. ___ restart this medicine next week if your blood pressure has improved
target: ___ with GERD, COPD with unstable angina with negative cardiac enzymes found to have 95-99% bifucating LAD lesion now s/p cath with ___ in proximal LAD, admitted to CCU for aspirin desensitization, chest pain free. . # Unstable angina: Presented to OSH with chest pain, negative enzymes, found to have 80% bifurcating lesion to LAD. Transferred to ___ for intervention. A DES was placed in the LAD, with jailing of diagonal branch. She remained chest pain free after the procedure, although cardiac enzymes did rise (consistent with jailing). Because she has a allergy to aspirin, she was then transferred to the CCU for aspirin desensitization, which was successful. She was started on ASA 325mg PO daily, plavix 75mg PO daily, lisinopril 5mg daily. Metoprolol not started for the time being as her pressures were in 90's on lisinopril. PCP or cardiologist can consider starting beta-blocker in the future. Repeat TTE showed EF45-50% with akinesis of the mid to distal septum and hypokinesis of the apex. . # ASPIRIN DESENSITIZATION: Reported hives/mouth sensation with prior use. Transferred briefly to CCU for asa desensitization, which was successfully completed without incident. She was started on ASA 325mg PO daily. . # COPD - chronic, breathing at baseline throughout admission. Continued on spiriva and advair-diskus (substituted from symbicort as that is non-formulary) . # SMOKING History - nicotine patch while in-house. Smoking cessation councelling provided at length. Nicotine patch prescription given for outpatient setting. She should follow closely with her PCP regarding smoking cessation.

Patient was in her normal state of health until this am when she developed acute onset chest pressure that awoke her from sleep at 6am. Describes retrosternal chest pressure accompanied by tachycardia and headache. No associated dyspnea, diaphoresis, N/V or any other associated symptoms. Per patient recording, systolic blood pressure was in 200s. When symptoms did not after approx ___ hrs, patient called PCP who told her to ___ to the ED. EKG showed old LBBB with no other evident ST changes, CXR wnl. Initial labs remarkable for Cr of 1.3, trop 0.04. Due to uniterpretable EKG in the setting of elevated cardiac enzymes, patient taking emergently to cardiac catheterization. Prior to cath, started on heparin gtt and plavix loaded. Catheterization showed diffuse atherosclerosis with likely acute occlusion of left circumflex OM2, and significant stenoses in distal LAD and Diag 1. Angioplasty of OM2 branch was complicated by dissection (no evidence of perforation) and attemts to stent thrombosed area were aborted. Following catheterization, patient had residual ___ chest discomfort with unchanged EKG. She was admitted to the CCU for further observation. On review of systems, she complains of intermittent uncontrolled blood pressure for the for the past ___ yrs with BP as high as 200s. These episodes are accompanied by flushing, headaches and tachycardia. Thorough evaluation revealed renal artery stenosis with normal urinary metanephrines and aldosterone. She is currently followed by a nephrologist with no planned intervention. Of note, despite hyperlipidemia, patient is not maintained on a statin. She previously tolerated atorvostatin but when she was changed to simvastatin for insurance purposes, she developed dark urine. As this was a listed side effect on the back of the bottle, patient decided to see d/c meds. Otherwise, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Has old healed lesions on bilat knees ___ fall NEURO: Extremeties: right Groin with no hematoma, ecchymosis Pulses: Right: DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: DP 2+ ___ 2+ Skin: intact <PERTINENT RESULTS> Hematology: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD WBC-6.8 RBC-4.02* Hgb-12.0 Hct-33.9* MCV-84 MCH-30.0 MCHC-35.6* RDW-14.3 Plt ___ ___ 04: 15PM BLOOD Hct-36.0 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD WBC-7.5 RBC-4.25 Hgb-12.7 Hct-35.2* MCV-83 MCH-30.0 MCHC-36.1* RDW-14.1 Plt ___ ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD WBC-7.7 RBC-4.96 Hgb-14.7 Hct-41.1 MCV-83 MCH-29.6 MCHC-35.7* RDW-14.3 Plt ___ ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD Neuts-81.3* Lymphs-14.4* Monos-2.7 Eos-1.3 Baso-0.3 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD ___ PTT-22.9 ___ ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD ___ PTT-22.2 ___ Chemistries: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-154* UreaN-25* Creat-1.3* Na-139 K-3.8 Cl-104 HCO3-24 AnGap-15 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-181* UreaN-25* Creat-1.3* Na-138 K-3.7 Cl-104 HCO3-21* AnGap-17 ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-196* UreaN-27* Creat-1.3* Na-136 K-3.3 Cl-98 HCO3-24 AnGap-17 Cardiac Biomarkers: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-469* ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1052* ___ 10: 01PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1025* ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD CK-MB-17* MB Indx-3.6 cTropnT-2.95* ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD CK-MB-109* MB Indx-10.4* cTropnT-2.80* ___ 10: 01PM BLOOD CK-MB-129* MB Indx-12.6* cTropnT-1.77* ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.04* LFTS: ___ 09: 05AM BLOOD ALT-13 AST-24 LD(LDH)-191 CK(CPK)-166 AlkPhos-56 Other: ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD %HbA1c-6.5* eAG-140* ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD Triglyc-226* HDL-33 CHOL/HD-7.3 LDLcalc-162* ECG ___: Sinus rhythm. Borderline P-R interval prolongation. Left bundle-branch block. CXR ___: FINDINGS: Single frontal view of the chest was obtained. Right infrahilar/perihilar opacity most likely relates to slight prominence of the vasculature, although an underlying minimal consolidation cannot be entirely excluded. Lingular atelectasis/scarring is noted. The remainder of the left lung is clear. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. Cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable. There is a twin LAD system wtih a 90% lesion in the mid-portion of hte vessl. The first diagonal goes to the apex and has an 80% lesion. The circumflex artery is free of angiographically apparent flow limiting disease but a small OM2 branch is totally occluded. 2. ASA indefinitely; plavix (clopidogrel) 600 mg bolus given in cath lab and 75 mg daily with plan for LAD and DIAG revascularization to be pursued by Dr. ___, interventional cardiology attending. 5. Plan for CCU observation/medical management at this time ECHO ___: The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with mild basal inferolateral hypokinesis. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 55%). The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Minimal regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, c/w CAD. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. metoprolol tartrate 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 5. hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY (Daily). 6. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 7. lisinopril 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and needed a cardiac catheterization to assess your heart arteries for blockages. One artery was thought to have caused the heart attack and was opened with a balloon. There was a small tear called a dissection that has not caused any complications. No stents were placed. You had some chest pain after the procedure and a medicine called isosorbide mononitrate was started to prevent more chest pain. This will cause a headache but you should speak to Dr. ___ the headache is not relieved by tylenol. The plan is for you to return for another procedure to fix additional blockages in your coronary arteries. . We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. Start Isosorbide mononitrate to prevent chest pain. 2. Start nitroglycerin under your tongue if you have chest pain similar to the pain during your heart attack. You can take up to 2 tablets 5 minutes apart but please call Dr. ___ away if you have any chest pain and take nitroglycerin. Call ___ if you take two nitroglycerin tablets and you still have chest pain. 3. Start taking Atorvastatin 80 mg to lower your cholesterol 4. Start taking Plavix to prevent blood clot formation in your coronary arteries 5. Continue to take Lisinopril, aspirin, hydrochlorothiazide and metoprolol as before.
target: Patient is a ___ y/oF with type 2 DM, ___ transferred to the CCU following NSTEMI c/b carotid dissection of OM2 during attempted angioplasty. # CORONARIES: Patient presented with chest pressure. EKG showed NSEMI. She was sent to the cath lab and then admitted to the CCU s/p NSTEMI c/b OM2 dissection during attempted angioplasty. Cardiac catheterization revealed diffuse 3-vessel disease with significant stenoses in the distal LAD and diag. Patient had peristent low-grade chest discomfort after cath but no signs of significant complication from dissection including perforation. On discharge, she was chest pain free. She was treated with aspirin, plavix, metoprolol, and was started on atorvastatin. She was not given heparin in the setting of her dissection. Her CK peaked at 1052 on the am of ___. Patient plans to undergo elective PCI for treatment of her LAD lesion although at the time of discharge, she was still considering the possibility of CABG. # PUMP: Patient remained euvolemic with no signs of congestive heart failure. Her echo showed mild basal inferolateral hypokinesis with EF >55%. # Renal Artery Stenosis: appears to be etiology of episodic uncontrolled blood pressure with no planned intervention per outpatient nephrologist. Was previously tolerated high-dose ACEI although Cr elevated to 1.3 from unknown baseline (1.1 in ___ upon admission. Her creatinine remained stable and she was restarted on her home dose of lisinopril 40 mg po daily. . # Hypertension: Patient presented to the ED with hypertensive emergency with BP 200/120, MI and headache. Her chest pressure improved with improvement in her BP. She was continued on metoprolol, hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril. # Type 2 DM: Patient's A1C was 6.5, close to baseline. She was only using metformin intermittently. She will discuss restarting this medication with her PCP. She was continued on a diabetic diet and humalog sliding scale while admitted. #Anemia: Patient was admitted with normal HCT at 41.1 which then trended as follows: 41.1->35.2-> 36-> 33.9. There were also decreases in her other cell counts (platelets, WBC). She should have a repeat CBC done as an outpatient. CODE: Full (confirmed with patient)
