She states that shortly after awaking at 0800 the morning of admission she experienced sudden onset nausea, vomiting and non-bloody non melanotic diarrhea with associated diaphoresis. She called her PCP, who urged her to go to the ___, where she was found to have ST elevations in II/III/AVF and reciprocal ST depressions in V2. VS at the time were: T 97.4 BP 131/61 HR 61 RR 18 O2 Sat 100% RA. She was given ASA 325, Heparin 60U/kg, Atorvastatin 80 and Plavix 600 and transferred to ___ for PCI. Cardiac cath showed total mid RCA occulsion (R dominant) and a DES was placed with restoration of flow to the distal RCA and PDA. Labs on arrival were CKMB 61 Trop 1.81 and Cr 1.7 (baseline unknown). On arrival to the CCU she denied CP/SOB/N/V/HA, palpitations or lightheadedness. She has had no sick contacts and states she can walk ~30 minutes before becoming SOB. She does not frequently climb stairs due to degenerative disc disease. She denies PND/orthopnea and states that she has noticed occasional swelling in her ankles over the past few months. On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: None 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - cataracts - GERD - osteoporosis - spinal stenosis - gastric ulcer - asthma - hysterectomy - cholecystectomy - multiple back surgeries <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death. - Mother: Died at age ___, unclear history of CAD - Father: ___ at age ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION EXAM: VS: T 98 BP 93/48 HR 63 RR 17 O2 Sat 97% 2L NC Wt 153 lbs GENERAL: NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. NECK: Supple, JVP 3cm above the clavicle, thyroid non tender, mobile. No LAD. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. II/VI harsh holosystolic murmur best heard at the apex. Normal S1/S2, no S3/S4. No lifts of heaves. No carotid bruits. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTA anteriorly. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: WWP, scant pedal edema to the medial malleolus. 2+ pulses bilaterally. Cath site c/d/i, no hematoma or femoral bruits. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ DISCHARGE EXAM: GEN: NAD CV: RRR, III/VI holosystolic murmur heart throughout the precordium, JVP flat. Normal S1/S2, no S3/S4 PULM: Crackles in dependent lung fields L>R, no increased WOB, no cyanosis. ABD: NTND, NABS, no rigidity or rebound. EXT: WWP, no c/c/e, pulses 2+ NEURO: A/Ox3, non focal. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 27PM GLUCOSE-131* UREA N-44* CREAT-1.6* SODIUM-131* POTASSIUM-3.9 CHLORIDE-88* TOTAL CO2-28 ANION GAP-19 ___ 12: 22PM CK-MB-102* cTropnT-5.04* ___ 05: 48AM CK-MB-120* cTropnT-5.18* ___ 05: 48AM TRIGLYCER-77 HDL CHOL-54 CHOL/HDL-2.9 LDL(CALC)-90 ___ 01: 00AM CK-MB-61* MB INDX-7.5* cTropnT-1.81* ___ 01: 00AM WBC-11.0 RBC-4.12* HGB-12.2 HCT-34.4* MCV-84 MCH-29.5 MCHC-35.3* RDW-15.5 ___ 01: 00AM NEUTS-86.8* LYMPHS-9.8* MONOS-3.1 EOS-0.1 BASOS-0.1 RELEVANT STUDIES: Cardiac Cath (___): 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated single vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA, LAD, and LCx were free of angiographically significant disease. There was a thrombotic total occlusion of the mid-RCA with no collateralization. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal resting systemic arterial pressure. ___ (___): The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls. There is a focal defect in the basal inferior septum on 2D and color Doppler with continuous left-to-right flow c/w a post infarction ventricular septal defect (VSD). The remaining left ventricular segments contract normally. (LVEF 50%). Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function may be more depressed given the interventricular flow). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. CXR (___): Current study demonstrates top normal heart as well as bilateral hilar enlargement and pulmonary edema. The findings might potentially represent a new acute mitral regurgitation with increasing pulmonary venous pressure and presence of newly developed pulmonary edema. Small bilateral pleural effusions are noted. There is no pneumothorax. ___ (___): The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal half of the inferior and inferolateral walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 50-55 %). There is a ~1cm basal inferoseptal post infarction ventricular septal defect (VSD) with prominent left-to-right flow. Right ventricular cavity size is normal with free wall hypokinesis. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. ___ (___): The left atrium is normal in size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinsis of the basal and mid inferior and inferolateral segmets . There is a post infarction ventricular septal defect (VSD). Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. An eccentric, posteriorly directed jet of Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. MRI (___) 1. Normal left ventricular cavity size with normal global LVEF of 65% albeit severely depressed effective forward LVEF of 20%. Severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the mid to basal inferoseptal and inferior walls. 2. Transmural of late gadolinium enhancement in the inferoseptal wall, and 45% non-transmural late gadolinium enhancement in the inferior wall extending into the inferolateral wall, consistent with myocardial infarction and low (inferoseptal wall) to intermediate (inferior wall) likelihood of functional recovery after revascularization. The late gadolinium enhancement demonstrates a microvascular obstruction-type pattern. The infarct size was quantified at 18.2 g, which represents 21% of the total myocardial mass. 3. Increased T2 signal in these segments, consistent with edema/inflammation and acute/subacute timing of infarction (within 2 weeks). 4. Myocardial salvage index, representing the difference between the area at risk (T2) and the infarct size (late gadolinium enhancement) divided by the area at risk, calculated at 53%. 5. Infarct-related muscular ventricular septal defect in the mid to basal inferoseptal wall measuring 7 mm in the long-axis direction, and 6-9 mm in the short-axis direction (9 mm at the mouth on the left ventricular size of the septum, and slightly tapering to 6 mm on the right ventricular side of the septum). 6. Ischemic mitral regurgitation with mild posterior leaflet tethering. 7. Normal right ventricular cavity size with depressed RVEF of 39%. Global right ventricular hypokinesis with dyskinesis of the distal segments. Late gadolinium enhancement in the inferior right ventricular wall, consistent with right ventricular myocardial infarction. Systolic flattening of the interventricular septum, consistent with elevated right ventricular systolic pressure. 8. The indexed diameters of the ascending and descending thoracic aorta were normal. The indexed diameter of the main pulmonary artery was normal. 9. Left atrial enlargement. 10. A note is made of dependent patchy areas of consolidation are identified in the lung bases, right greater than left, with a focal area of nodularity in the right mid lung measuring 2 cm in craniocaudal dimension. However, there is no correlate on prior chest radiograph. Findings are likely the sequelae of pulmonary edema, though aspiration or pneumonia should be considered in the appropriate clinical circumstance. Recommend follow-up chest radiograph after acute illness to document resolution. A note is also made of punctate non-enhancing lesions in both kidneys, likely small simple cysts. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> - Vit D 50,000U every other ___ - Verapamil 240mg qday - Omeprazole 20mg qday - Clonazepam 0.5mg po qhs - Pioglitizone 30mg qday - Pregalbin 25mg qday - Ultram 50mg prn back pain <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Acute Myocardial Infarction 2. Ventricular-Septal Rupture SECONDARY: 1. Hypertension 2. Diabetes 3. Asthma <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure participating in your care during your admission to ___. You were transferred to our hospital for treatment of a heart attack. The blockage in your arteries was opened and a stent was placed in one of your coronary arteries to help keep it open. We also treated you with several medications to reduce the risk of both another heart attack and of your heart becoming weak from having had a heart attack. Your heart also suffered a complication from your heart attack in which one of the walls between the different chambers of your heart ruptured, allowing blood to flow in a direction it normally would not flow. This is a serious complication and requires repair. You were evaluated by our interventional cardiologists as well as our cardiac surgeons who felt that it would be best to postpone correcting this problem until you have had a bit more time to recover from your heart attack. We have changed some of your medications and started you on several new medications. Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed. In terms of new medications, we have started you on the following medications: -Aspirin, 325mg daily to prevent another heart attack -Plavix, 75mg daily to keep the stent open. Do not stop taking your aspirin and plavix together unless Dr. ___ you it is OK. -Lisinopril, 5mg daily to lower your blood pressure -Atorvastatin, 40 mg daily to lower your cholesterol -Amiodarone, 200mg once daily to keep your heart in a regular rhythm. -Furosemide (Lasix), 80mg daily to prevent fluid overload -Metoprolol 25mg twice daily to lower your heart rate and help your heart recover from the heart attack. -Ranitidine, 150mg, at bedtime to prevent stomach upset You should STOP taking the following medications: -Omeprazole (instead you should take the Ranitidine listed above) -Verapamil (this is no longer necessary because of the other medications we have started you on) . Weigh yourself every day, Call Dr. ___ you notice your weight increase more than 3 pounds in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days.
target: ___ y/o woman with STEMI and total RCA occlusion s/p DES complicated by post-infarct ventricular septal perforation. # STEMI: Pt had 100% RCA occlusion just distal to the acute marginal takeoff, now s/p DES with restoration of flow to the distal RCA and PDA (R dominant). She was started on ASA, Plavix, Atorvastatin, metoprolol and lisinopril during her hospital course. ___ showed mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal half of the inferior and inferolateral walls. Immediately following PCI she was in 2:1 heart block, which subsequently evolved to Wenckebach and 1:1 conduction. She remained hemodynamically stable throughout and was discharged home with cardiology and PCP follow up. # VSD: Physical exam on admission to the CCU revealed a new III/VI systolic murmur heard thoughout the precordium concerning for new VSD/MR. ___ showed VSD, cardiac MRI later showed 3:1 shunt fraction, normal RV size with free wall hypokinesis and elevated PA pressures. Her O2 sat remained >93% on RA throughout her course and she was given diuresis for reducing pulmonary edema and shunt, and minimizing pulmonary hypertension. Blood pressure was also optimized to decrease afterload and maximize forward flow. The definite treatment will require surgical repair of the interventricular septum defect. Percutaneous VSD closure may also be an option. OUTPATIENT ISSUES: - F/U WITH CT SURGERY/INTERVENTIONAL CARDIOLOGY - Adjust lasix 80 mg po qd - Should have RHC to assess shunt function which could help decide whether patient needs to have her shunt fixed # A-fib: Pt was found to have a period of unsustained symptomatic A-fib, lasting ~30 mins. This could be a result of changes in RA volume and dynamics. Given patient's already compromised CO, atrial kick is necessary to maintain adequate MAP. Amiodarone was started for rhythm control. She was continued on metoprolol for rate control. CHRONIC DIAGNOSES: DM: Pt has documented hx of diabetes, controlled by Pioglitizone prior to admission. She was covered with ISS during this hospitalization. She was restarted on pioglitizone prior to discharge. # HTN - Her home Verapamil was held and she was started on Metoprolol and Lisinopril with SBP goal in the ___ given the lack of mortality benefit of CCB (especially verapamil) # GERD - Patient has a documented history of GERD, and takes omeprazole at home. Omeprazole was stopped in setting of plavix while ranitidine was started at 150 mg po qhs. # HLD: She was started on atorvastatin 80 mg po qdaily (PROVE trial) but it was decreased to 40 mg po qdaily given she was on multiple medications (amiodarone) which would uptitrate her statin dose putting her at risk for rhabdomyolysis. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Pt maintained a full code during this admission - Pt has follow up with Dr. ___ in one week and CT surgery in 2 weeks

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac catheterization with thrombectomy and angioplasty <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo M with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, CAD s/p DES to the left circumflex in ___ noncompliant with all medications due to cost who presents with STEMI. The patient went to work as usual at 7AM working as a ___. Around 8: 30AM the patient began to experience severe left-sided chest tightness. He denies associated SOB, DOE, diaphoresis, radiation, lightheadedness or presyncope. This chest tightness was different than his prior MI symptom which was left subscapular pain. The pain was unrelieved with rest and the patient called ___. Of note, the patient was prescribed multiple cardiovascular medications in ___ (the last time he saw an MD) after his previous MI cared for at ___. He was not taking any medications for greater than ___ years due to cost. Also of note, the patient describes intermittent episodes of similar chest tightness for 1 month occurring at rest and with activity though not reproducible with exertion. In the field, the patient appears to have ST-elevations on EKG strip. A code STEMI was called enroute to the ED. In the ED, the patient received aspirin 325mg, plavix 600mg, metoprolol 5mg IV, nitoglycerin gtt, heparin gtt and integrilin gtt. In the cath lab, the patient was found to have a 100% left circ lesion near his previous stent with thrombosis involving his prior stent. The patient had thrombectomy with multiple passes through his previous stent and placement of a DES to the left circ lesion proximal to his prior stent. The patient became chest pain free with near normalization of his ST elevations around noon. The catheterization procedure was complicated by blood loss of 150cc. The patient developed relative hypotension to sbp 80's thought in part due to blood loss and in part due to vagal response to urinary retention relieved with foley catheter placement. With IVF bolus, the patient's pressure improved to 120/70 while in the post-cath holding area. On review of symptoms, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypertension Hypercholesterolemia CAD s/p Taxus stent to the L Cx in ___ Medication noncompliance due to cost of medications Low back pain <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Family history remarkable for father with MI requiring CABG at age ___. No other premature CAD and no history of sudden death. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: HR 64 BP 119/77 RR 18 97% RA. Gen: Well-appearing. NAD. HEENT: Dry mucus membranes. No carotid bruits. EOMI CV: Distant heart sounds. Normal S1 and S2, no M/R/G, RRR Pulm: CTA bilaterally, no wheezes crakles or ronchi Abd: Soft, nontender, no palpable masses or organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Palpable 2+ bilateral tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses. Right groin cath site with clean, dry dressing in place. No hematoma or bruit, Left femoral pulse 2+ Neuro: A&Ox3. Skin: no rashes <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD WBC-14.1* RBC-4.93 Hgb-14.9 Hct-43.0 MCV-87 MCH-30.2 MCHC-34.6 RDW-13.2 Plt ___ ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD WBC-8.5 RBC-4.29* Hgb-12.9* Hct-38.4* MCV-90 MCH-30.1 MCHC-33.6 RDW-12.8 Plt ___ ___ 08: 15AM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.7 ___ ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD Glucose-105 UreaN-12 Creat-1.1 Na-141 K-3.7 Cl-100 HCO3-28 AnGap-17 ___ 07: 05AM BLOOD Glucose-92 UreaN-12 Creat-0.8 Na-139 K-4.8 Cl-102 HCO3-29 AnGap-13 ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-211* ___ 08: 59PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1493* ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1184* ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD CK-MB-4 ___ 08: 59PM BLOOD CK-MB-163* MB Indx-10.9* ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD CK-MB-101* MB Indx-8.5* cTropnT-2.15* ___ 08: 15AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-3.4 Mg-2.2 ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD Triglyc-88 HDL-65 CHOL/HD-3.1 LDLcalc-119 LDLmeas-118 ___ 10: 30AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.9 EKG ___: In the field at 09: 47AM, sinus rhythm at 100, normal axis, 3mm ST elevations in II, III, aVF and V6, ST depressions in I, aVL, V2 and V4. At 12: 06, sinus rhythm at a rate of 60, normal axis, approximately ___levations in II, III, aVF and V6, right bundloid pattern in precordial leads. No prior for comparison. TTE ___: Mild concentric LVF, EF 65% with minor apical contraction abnormalities, diastolic dysfunction, trivial TR with normal right sided pressures. The patient underwent thrombectomy down his prior stent and OM1 with several passes as well as placement of a stent to the left circumflex lesion. ECHO ___: The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinesis of the basal to mid inferior wall and inferior septum . Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Inferior lateral STEMI Tobacco abuse <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable, Chest pain free <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted with a heart attack called an ST elevation myocardial infarction. You had an echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) which showed some damage to the heart muscle which is causing a condition called congestive heart failure. You have a mild case. You are being started on several new medications for this. We have worked out getting you these medications for free from PharmaCare. You must take these medications as prescribed every day. The aspirin is absolutely necessary to help thin the blood. The plavix is also used to thin the blood. The lisinopril and metoprolol are used to help the heart muscle and for blood pressure control. The lipitor medication is used to help with cholesterol and also for anti-inflammatory actions. You ABSOLUTELY MUST stop smoking. You are being given a nicotine patch to help with this. You should consider nicotine gum to help with times of intense cravings. There are also support groups online and by phone you can join to help you quit smoking. Please call your doctor or go to the emergency room if you have fevers >101, chills, bleeding, chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, lightheadedness or any other symptoms which are concerning to you.
target: This is a ___ year old male with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, CAD s/p DES to the left circumflex in ___ noncompliant with all medications due to cost who presents with STEMI found to have 100% left circumflex lesion and thrombus burden s/p thrombectomy. # CAD/Ischemia. Mr. ___ has not taken his medications for a few years. He was restarted on Aspirin 325mg daily, plavix 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg, Toprol 25mg daily and lisinopril 10mg daily. Social work was consulted for assistance with obtaining affordable or free prescriptions. He was given assistance and received a free one month supply of medications with chance for renewal. He is also enrolling in medical insurance. He was told to follow up with myself in clinic and with Dr. ___ in Cardiology. However, since he lives in ___ - he stated that he would rather find care in his area. He was told to call my clinic with any questions or concerns. # Pump. He is to continue on his BB and ACEi as above. # NSVT - Patient with ectopy and NSVT s/p STEMI. Likely due to recent STEMI and will resolve on its own. Telemetry was without events on his discharge. # Hypercholesterolemia. He is to continue on high dose statin as above # Tobacco abuse - Mr. ___ was strongly encouraged to stop smoking. He was prescribed a Nicotine patch. # Code: Full Code

Your EKGs and bloodwork were concerning for a heart attack, and you underwent a cardiac catheterization that showed almost complete blockage of one artery and complete blockage of another artery. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with HTN and inconsistent medical care who presented with chest pain to ___, where he was found to have elevated troponins and EKGs concerning for ongoing ischemia. He was transferred to ___ and found to have an NSTEMI: # NSTEMI s/p cath with PCI: Presented with chest pain, elevated troponins (uptrending) and EKG changes without ST elevations. Pt has a TIMI risk score of 4 based off known risk factors (early family hx, multiple cardiac risk factors, episode of STE on one EKG and recent severe angina). He was initially started on a heparin gtt, and a nitro gtt to make him chest-pain free. In addition, he was started on ASA 325, low-dose metoprolol, atorvastatin 80mg. He underwent cardiac catheterization via R femoral approach on ___ with BMS x2 to RCA and LCx. Following the procedure, he was started on prasugrel which was transitioned to plavix on discharge (for insurance issues). Cardiac enzymes noted to be downtrending post-procedure. An echo showed preserved global systolic function and no focal wall motion abnormalities. # HTN: Noted to have systolic blood pressures in the 140s-150s on and off nitro gtt. Metoprolol uptitrated, low dose lisinopril started with good effect of systolic BP in 120s-130s. # HLD: Workup for cardiac risk factors showed Hb A1C 5.7; LDL 111. Discharged on atorvastatin 80mg daily. # Otitis: Continued amoxicillin 500mg po q8h (started ___ until ___, thereafter discontinued given no symptoms and completion of 5-day course. # Tobacco abuse: Counseled on smoking cessation. Provided with nicotine patches in appropriate taper.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Cardiac catheterization with deployment of drug-eluting stent in the RCA <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with CAD s/p multiple stents, s/p CABG, DM, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, recent normal stress echo (no inducible wall motion abnormality on echo but had late EKG changes into recovery) in ___ for atypical chest pain (at that time it was retrosternal chest pain lasting a few seconds, with no radiation and no associated symptoms) comes with chest pain all day long. He tried 2 tabs of TNG without relief. He was given full dose ASA prior to arrival. He takes ASA, lisinopril, omerpazole, atorvastatin, amlodipine, Wellbutrin, citalopram at home. Lipids and BP well controlled per cardiology note in ___. He has Viagra at home but doesn't use it. He denied PND, orthopnea, ___ swelling, lightheadedness, LOC, blurred vision. In the ED, initial vitals were T 98.2 HR 90 BP 140/70 RR 16 SaO2 100% on RA. He rated his chest pain at severity ___. Patient received IV morphine, SL TNG x 3, however his pain was refractory. He was then placed on a heparin gtt and nitroglycerin gtt and given IV Dilaudid. He was loaded with clopidogrel 600 mg po x 1. On arrival to the floor, patient was without complaints, however he briefly had a vasovagal episode and had pre-sycnope as a result. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. Coronary artery bypass graft ___. 2. Laparoscopic adjustable gastric band, ___ (Allergan Vanguard band). <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died of an MI at ___, brother with CAD s/p stent at age ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> On admission General: Young Hispanic man in NAD, comfortable, pleasant VS: T 97 BP 107/71 HR 79 RR 16 SaO2 95% on RA Chest pain ___ HEENT: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI Neck: supple, no JVD CV: regular rhythml no murmurs, rubs or gallops Lungs: CTAB--no wheezes, rales or rhonchi Abdomen: soft, non-tender, not distended, BS+ Ext: warm and well perfused; no clubbing, cyanosis or edema; 2+ distal pulses bilaterally Neuro: moving all extremities grossly At discharge GEN: well-appearing, in NAD VS: T 98.4 SBP 92-104 HR ___ sinus RR 18 Sa02 96% on RA HEENT: neck veins flat, no LAD, no oral lesions CV: RRR; no murmurs, rubs or gallops LUNGS: CTAB ABD: soft, non-tender, not distended GU: no Foley EXT: warm, 2+ DP, femoral, radial pulses; no hematoma at radial puncture site NEURO: A&Ox3, CN2-12 intact, walking, no motor deficits <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD WBC-15.1* RBC-4.69 Hgb-14.4 Hct-44.6 MCV-95 MCH-30.6 MCHC-32.2 RDW-13.0 Plt ___ ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD Neuts-62.2 ___ Monos-6.6 Eos-2.7 Baso-1.1 ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD ___ PTT-32.9 ___ ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD Glucose-87 UreaN-11 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-3.8 Cl-103 HCO3-24 AnGap-15 ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-501* ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-3.5 Mg-1.9 ___ 05: 43PM BLOOD Lactate-1.0 ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD CK-MB-49* ___ 05: 32PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.34* ___ 01: 57AM BLOOD CK-MB-38* cTropnT-0.45* ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.52* DISCHARGE LABS -------------- ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD WBC-14.4* RBC-4.37* Hgb-13.5* Hct-42.6 MCV-98 MCH-30.9 MCHC-31.7 RDW-12.9 Plt ___ ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD ___ PTT-30.6 ___ ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD Glucose-116* UreaN-10 Creat-0.9 Na-138 K-4.3 Cl-103 HCO3-29 AnGap-10 ___ 05: 35AM BLOOD Mg-1.9 ECG ___ 4: 39: 42 ___ Sinus rhythm. Small Q waves in lead III of unknown significance. Poor R wave progression across the precordium. ST segment depression in leads I, aVL, and V5 of unknown significance. However, may represent myocardial ischemia. These changes are new compared to the previous tracings. CXR ___ The patient is status post median sternotomy and CABG. Cardiac, mediastinal and hilar contours are unchanged, with the heart size within normal limits. The pulmonary vasculature is not engorged. Lungs are clear. No focal consolidation, pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. There are no acute osseous abnormalities. Echocardiogram ___ The left atrial volume is moderately increased. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with near akinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF= 40%). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function may be more depressed given the severity of mitral regurgitaiton.]There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate to severe (3+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is borderline increased. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with regional systolic dysfunction c/w CAD (PDA territory). Moderate to severe mitral regurgitation most likely due to papillary muscle dysfunction. Borderline pulmonary artery hypertension. Compared with the prior stress-echo study (images reviewed) of ___, the wall motion abnormalities are new and the mitral regurgitation is markedly worse. Cardiac Catheterization ___ Catheter placement via left radial artery, 5 ___ performed ___ angiography using 5 ___ Preformed ___, JR4, JL4 Coronary angiography: right dominant LMCA: No distal 50% unchanged LAD: Diffuse proximal disease with competitive flow after touchdown site. The mid diagonal has eccentric 40-50% stenosis at the SVG touchdown site. The origin is unchanged from prior. The LAD after the ___ touchdown has mild luminal irregularities and supplies collaterals to the RCA LCX: mid vessel 50% into OM1. Chronic total occlusion of prior stent to OM2 RCA: Thrombotic subtotal occlusion of the RCA with TIMI 0 flow into the PL and collaterals from LCA supplying the PL. SVG-Diagonal-OM: Occluded SVG-OM: Occluded LIMA-LAD: Widely patent Interventional details Change for 5 ___ JR4 guide after the 6 ___ guide could not be torque because of severe spasm in the left arm. Crossed with ChoICE ___ XS wire into the PL but a distal injection was ambiguous as to whether the wire was intraluminal. Exchanged for a Prowater wire and directed into the distal PL. Still, distal injection was ambiguous as to whether the wire was intraluminal. There was no flow in the RCA antegrade. Dilation was performed using a 2.5 mm balloon at the lesion. Antegrade flow was restored but the distal vessels were severely spasmodic with minimal antegrade flow. This was relieved with IC vasodilators somewhat. Over time the distal vessels vasodilated. A 2.5 x 15 mm Promus Element Plus stent was deployed and post dilated with a 2.75 mm balloon. Final angiography revealed normal flow, no dissection and 0% residual stenosis. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Lisinopril 40 mg PO DAILY 2. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 150 mg PO BID 3. Amlodipine 10 mg PO DAILY 4. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY 5. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY 6. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN chest pain 7. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 9. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 10. TraZODone 100 mg PO HS: PRN insomnia <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY 3. BuPROPion (Sustained Release) 150 mg PO BID 4. Citalopram 40 mg PO DAILY 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H RX *pantoprazole 40 mg 1 tablet,delayed release (___) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *3 6. Nicotine Patch 14 mg TD DAILY RX *nicotine 14 mg/24 hour 1 patch to skin daily Disp #*14 Transdermal Patch Refills: *0 7. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 8. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY 9. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN chest pain 10. TraZODone 100 mg PO HS: PRN insomnia 11. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY RX *metoprolol succinate 25 mg 1 tablet extended release 24 hr(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *3 12. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY RX *clopidogrel 75 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *5 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> # Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction # Coronary artery disease with occlusion of both venous bypass grafts # Mild left ventricular systolic dysfunction # Diabetes mellitus, controlled # Hypertension # Tobacco abuse # Hyperlipidemia # Gastroesophageal reflux disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___ you were admitted for chest pain that was found to be from a heart attack. You were treated with anticoagulants, aspirin, and a cholesterol lowering drug called a statin. Cardiac catheterization on ___ showed that two of the vein grafts from your bypass surgery in ___ were occluded. These could not be fixed in the catheterization procedure. However, your right coronary artery, which formerly had been OK, showed no flow, meaning there was a blockage from atherosclerosis there. This was opened and a drug-eluting stent was placed to keep this area open. There was good blood flow through the right coronary artery afterward. You will need to continue taking a medication called clopidogrel (Plavix) for ___ year, in combination with aspirin for the rest of your life. An echocardiogram (ultrasound of the heart) showed that you had new areas of heart muscle dysfunction compared to ___, likely from this heart attack. You also had worsening valve function of the mitral valve, causing a small amount of blood to flow backward in the heart instead of pumping forward. This will need to be monitored by your cardiologist. The most important step you can take for your health right now is to stop smoking. We will discharge you with nicotine patches and you explained that you already have Chantix (___). Smoking raises your risk for repeated heart attacks, and because of your prior procedures and surgeries, any new heart damage becomes harder to repair. MEDICATION CHANGES: -stop taking amlodipine -start taking metoprolol succinate 25mg daily -start taking lisinopril 20mg daily (you may cut your home 40mg pills in half until you are out, and then fill the 20mg prescription) -you have to take clopidogrel (Plavix) every day
target: Mr ___ is a ___ yo man with H/O CAD s/p multiple stents and s/p CABG ___, DM, hypertension, hyperlipidemia presenting with 1 day of chest pain, found to have NSTEMI due to new RCA lesion as well as totally occluded SVG grafts. # NSTEMI/CAD: S/P CABG here in ___ (LAD-LIMA, SVG-ramus with vein graft to the diagonal was taken off the ramus graft in Y-fashion, SVG-marginal). Unfortunately, he continued smoking prior to admission. Patient presented with chest pain unresponsive to NTG. CK-MB peaked at 49 and TnT 0.52. He had a few episodes of angina at rest since starting heparin drip, ASA, and clopidogrel in house, but these were responsive to nitroglycerin within minutes. GPIIb/IIIa not used because ischemic symptoms thought to be likely secondary to vein graft occlusion. Coronary angiography showed occlusion of both saphenous vein grafts, thrombotic subtotal occlusion of the RCA with TIMI 0 flow into the PL and collaterals from LCA supplying the PL. The RCA lesion was stented with a DES. There was also a mid vessel 50% stenosis of OM1. Chronic total occlusion of prior stent to OM2 was confirmed. TTE showed LVEF 40% (decreased from 45-50% from ___ stress TTE), worsened mitral regurgitation (3+ relative to 1+ previously), and new inferior & inferolateral hypo/akinesis. He was continued on ASA, clopidogrel, atorvastatin and lisinopril. His home lisinopril dose was decreased from 40 to 20 mg as he had borderline systolic BPs here in the ___. A beta blocker was started (metoprolol succinate 25 mg), and home amlodipine was discontinued in favor of the beta-blocker for CAD and LVSD. Smoking cessation was recommended. PPI was changed from omeprazole to pantoprazole to minimize drug-drug interactions with clopidogrel. # DM: Patient does not use medications since lap band ___ now diet controlled. Last A1c was 6.1 in ___. # Hypertension: Well controlled with SBPs 100-110s, though occasionally was in ___ on lisinopril 40 mg + metoprolol tartrate 12.5 BID. His home amlodipine was held, and upon discharge this was discontinued in favor of metoprolol. # Hyperlipidemia: Continued home atorvastatin 80 mg. # Tobacco abuse: Treated with nicotine 14 mg transdermal patch while here. Patient was set up with his PCP to restart ___ (Chantix) as outpatient. He was discharged with 2 week supply of nicotine patches. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ------------------- -TOBACCO CESSATION -FOLLOW UP BP CONTROL ON NEW REGIMEN

The recalls being in his usual state of health yesterday when he felt a fleeting moment of burning right-sided chest pain for ___ minutes while walking that self-resolved. He went to bed feeling fine but was awoken by severe right sided chest pain, bilateral shoulder pain, and teeth pain. His wife noted him to be diaphoretic and gray in color. He felt nausea, and severe weakness. He went to the bathroom and had some "diarrhea". His pain resolved for 2 minutes and he went back to bed when the pain suddenly returned again just as severe. He believed his pain was due to his "lungs" as it was on his right side. He recalls his NSTEMI in ___ felt different with a squeezing left sided chest pain that was milder than today's chest pain. After the pain returned, his wife called EMS who promptly arrived and transported him to the ___ ED. . In the ED, initial vitals were 57 144/92 18 99%RA. He was given Plavix 600mg PO ONCE, Heparin bolus 6000 units IV ONCE, Integrillin 18mg IV ONCE. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. . Discharge Labs ___ 06: 29AM BLOOD WBC-9.7 RBC-5.21 Hgb-15.4 Hct-44.3 MCV-85 MCH-29.5 MCHC-34.7 RDW-14.0 Plt ___ ___ 10: 43AM BLOOD Hct-40.9 Plt ___ ___ 06: 29AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 10: 43AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD ___ PTT-33.0 ___ ___ 02: 15AM BLOOD ___ PTT-22.1 ___ ___ 06: 29AM BLOOD Glucose-111* UreaN-9 Creat-0.8 Na-141 K-4.0 Cl-104 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD Glucose-137* UreaN-13 Creat-0.8 Na-137 K-3.7 Cl-106 HCO3-23 AnGap-12 ___ 08: 43PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1559* ___ 10: 43AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-2205* ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-2525* ___ 08: 43PM BLOOD CK-MB-42* MB Indx-2.7 cTropnT-3.31* ___ 10: 43AM BLOOD CK-MB-103* MB Indx-4.7 ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD CK-MB-114* MB Indx-4.5 cTropnT-3.68* ___ 02: 15AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 29AM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-2.4* Mg-2.2 ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5 Phos-2.2* Mg-2.0 Cholest-179 ___ 10: 43AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.8 eAG-120 ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.8 eAG-120 ___ 06: 03AM BLOOD Triglyc-154* HDL-42 CHOL/HD-4.3 LDLcalc-106 . Microbiology -MRSA negative . Reports Cardiac Catherization ___ INDICATIONS FOR CATHETERIZATION: Inferoposterolateral STEMI. PROCEDURE: Left Heart Catheterization: was performed by percutaneous entry of the right femoral artery, using a 5 ___ left ___ catheter, advanced to the ascending aorta through a 6 ___ introducing sheath. Coronary Angiography: was performed in multiple projections using a 5 ___ JL4 and a 5 ___ JR4 catheter, with manual contrast injections. Percutaneous coronary revascularization was performed using placement of drug-eluting stent(s). HEMODYNAMICS RESULTS BODY SURFACE AREA: 2.22 m2 HEMOGLOBIN: 15.2 gms % REST **PRESSURES AORTA {s/d/m} ___ **CARDIAC OUTPUT HEART RATE {beats/min} 52 RHYTHM SINUS, AIVR **ARTERIOGRAPHY RESULTS MORPHOLOGY % STENOSIS COLLAT. FROM **RIGHT CORONARY 1) PROXIMAL RCA NORMAL 2) MID RCA NORMAL 2A) ACUTE MARGINAL NORMAL 3) DISTAL RCA NORMAL 4) R-PDA NORMAL 4A) R-POST-LAT NORMAL **ARTERIOGRAPHY RESULTS MORPHOLOGY % STENOSIS COLLAT. FROM **LEFT CORONARY 5) LEFT MAIN NORMAL 6) PROXIMAL LAD NORMAL 6A) SEPTAL-1 NORMAL 7) MID-LAD NORMAL 8) DISTAL LAD NORMAL 9) DIAGONAL-1 NORMAL 10) DIAGONAL-2 NORMAL 12) PROXIMAL CX DISCRETE 100 **PTCA RESULTS CX PTCA COMMENTS: Initial angiography revealed a proximal circumflex total occlusion. We planned to treat this occlusion with aspiration/PTCA/stenting and integrilin was started prophylactically. A ___ sheath was exchanged in for access and a ___ JL4 guiding catheter provided excellent support for the procedure. A Prowater wire was used to cross the occlusion with minimal difficulty. An Apex OTW 2.0mm balloon was used to pre-dilate at 4atm for 10sec to restore flow. An Export XT catheter was then used to aspirate the lesion with minimal difficulty. A Promus OTW 3.0x15mm drug-eluting stent (DES) was deployed at 14atm for 34sec. The stent was post-dilated with an NC Quantum Apex MR 3.25x12mm balloon at 12atm for 7secs. Final angiography revealed 0% residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and TIMI 3 flow. The patient left the cath lab angina-free and in hemodynamically stable condition. TECHNICAL FACTORS: Total time (Lidocaine to test complete) = 42 minutes. Arterial time = 40 minutes. Fluoro time = 13.1 minutes. IRP dose = 1495 mGy. Contrast injected: Non-ionic low osmolar (isovue, optiray...), vol 170 ml Premedications: Midazolam 0.5 mg IV Fentanyl 25 mcg IV ASA 325 mg P.O. Clopidogrel 600 mg PO Anesthesia: 1% Lidocaine subq. Anticoagulation: Heparin 6000 units IV, ___ units IV Other medication: Eptifibatide 19 mg IV bolus x2, 16.6 ml/hr (75mg/100ml) IV gtt Cardiac Cath Supplies Used: - ___, PROWATER 300CM 2.0MM ___ 15MM 3.25MM ___, QUANTUM MAVERICK 12MM ___ CORDIS, JL 4.0 ___ SAINT ___, ANGIOSEAL VIP - ___, EXPORT ASPIRATION CATHETER - ALLEGIANCE, CUSTOM STERILE PACK - MERIT, LEFT HEART KIT - ___, RIGHT HEART KIT - ___, PRIORITY PACK ___ 3.0MM ___, PROMUS OTW 15MM COMMENTS: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated acute thrombotic occlusion of the proximal LCx. The LMCA and RCA had no significant disease. The LAD prior stent was patent without significant stenosis. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed mild systemic arterial systolic hypertension with SBP 141 mmHg. Following reperfusion the patient developed transient accelerated idioventricular rhythm without hemodynamic compromise that reverted to sinus rhythm. 3. Successful PTCA/aspiration/stenting of a proximal totally occluded circumflex with a Promus OTW 3.0x15mm drug-eluting stent (DES) which was post-dilated with an NC Quantum Apex MR 3.25x12mm balloon. Final angiography revealed 0% residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and TIMI 3 flow. 4. R FA ___ access was closed with an angioseal closure device without complications. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Acute inferoposterolateral ST elevation myocardial infarction due to thrombotic LCx occlusion. 2. Mild systemic arterial hypertension. 3. Successful PTCA/aspiration/stenting of a proximal total circumflex occlusion with a Promus OTW 3.0x15mm drug-eluting stent (DES) post-dilated to 3.25mm. 4. Patient to recieve integrilin for six hours post procedure. 5. ASA 325mg daily indefinitely; clopidogrel 75mg daily for at least 12months 6. High dose statin and other management per CCU team . ___ ECHO The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the inferolateral wall. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 45-50 %). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Transmitral and tissue Doppler imaging suggests normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with focal hypokinesis of the apical free wall. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The ascending aorta and aortic arch are mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction c/w CAD (proximal RCA distribution). Dilated thoracic aorta. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: Based on ___ AHA endocarditis prophylaxis recommendations, the echo findings indicate prophylaxis is NOT recommended. Clinical decisions regarding the need for prophylaxis should be based on clinical and echocardiographic data. . EKG ___ . Sinus rhythm with increase in rate as compared with prior tracing of ___. The previously recorded ST segment changes have improved. The ST segment elevation in the inferior leads has resolved. Otherwise, no diagnostic interim change. Rule out myocardial infarction. . ___ CXR SINGLE BEDSIDE FRONTAL RADIOGRAPH OF THE CHEST: Cardiac, mediastinal, and hilar contours are stable, specifically re-demonstrating a tortuous course of the descending aorta. The lungs are clear. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic abnormality. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None Of note, he self-discontinued aspirin and a statin a few years ago as he was told his cholesterol was normal and he prefers not to take medications. <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. The underlying etiology of his progressive CAD is multifactorial including aspirin and statin non-adherence, tobacco abuse, and sedentary lifestyle. Conitnued Aspirin, Plavix, Atorvastatin and commenced low dose metoprolol succinate, and lisinopril. Intense smoking cessation counseling was given along with lifestyle modification counselling. A Nutrition consult for cardiac diet was carried out as well. Lastly medication adherence counselling was accomplished by briefly stressing necessity to continue all his meds that we prescribe especially aspirin and clopidogrel and statin or he may have a fatal MI. Further stressed by resident on ___. Cardiology follow-up in Dr ___ clinic . #) Mild acute diastolic heart failure: Most probably secondary to acute ischemia. No hypoxia. Was not clinically fluid overloaded.Treated underlying ischemia per above . #) Leukocytosis: Mild without left shift. No infiltrates on CXR. Almost certainly was reactive to stress. . #) Mild hyperglycemia: Patient is overweight, sedentary, and at risk for DM. Checked HgA1C  5.8% . #) OSA: Continued CPAP

Patient was at a neighbour's place, help to fell trees when he experienced sub-sternal chest pressure. He paused, considering that this might be an AMI, decided not to work on another tree, collected his things, walked over the road to his house and called ___. He sat down, the pain improved, then worsened again. En route he developed diaphoresis, palor and began vomiting. He developed ventricular fibrillation and was shocked out of this rhythm with re-establishment of sinus rhythm, also notable for 5-___epression and t-wave inversion in V2-4, ST depression of 1 mm in I and large t-waves in III. En route he was given 162 mg ASA. He was briefly at ___ where ST-segment depression seen on EMS was again noted. He described sub-sternal chest pain, weakness and nausea. He was given aspirin 162 for a total of 324 mg, plavix 600 mg, SLN x 2, lidocaine 100 mg IV, 50 mcg fentanyl, heparin bolus 3600 units IV. Chest pain improved. He continued to vomit and likely lost some medication, so another 600 mg of Plavix was given. He was given Zofran (8 mg) prior to MedFlight arrival for evacuation to ___. Given a question of torsades (unclear but seen on beginning four inches of EMS strip EKG) he was sent on MedFlight with magnesium, but this was not given in the ED. On Medflight, Mr. ___ vomited again, was given 100 mcg more of fentanyl with chest pain dropping from ___ to ___. He arrived at ___ and was taken directly to the cath lab where one bare metal stent was placed in the almost completely occluded proximal left circumflex. RCA was approximately 50 % stenosed at its narrowest point and branches of the left anterior descending, septal perforators and diagonals, were tightly stenosed. Throughout this period from home until arrival in the cath lab, he was hemodynamically stable with pressures slightly elevated from 130s to 150s. Opening blood pressure was 124 mmHg systolic, but decreased by the end of the procedure to ___ systolic. Dopamine drip was started and a baloon pump placed. Given that atrial fibrillation was thought to be new and was likely contributing to hypotension, the patient was further sedated with successful electrical cardioversion. He received 4.5 L of IV fluids in total. On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. BRIEF HISTORY: ___ year old man with hypertension presented with chest pain, nausea/vomiting and ventricular fibrillation to an outside hospital. The V fib was successfully cardioverted, and an ECG was consistent with inferoposterior ___. He was transferred emergently to the ___ cardiac catheterization lab for right and left heart cath. INDICATIONS FOR CATHETERIZATION: inferoposterior ___ cad chest pain ventricular fibrillation PROCEDURE: Right Heart Catheterization: was performed by percutaneous entry of the right femoral vein, using a 7 ___ pulmonary wedge pressure catheter, advanced to the PCW position through an 8 ___ introducing sheath. Cardiac output was measured by the Fick method. Left Heart Catheterization: was performed by percutaneous entry of the right femoral artery, using a 6 XB 3.5 guide, advanced to the ascending aorta through a 6 ___ introducing sheath. Coronary Angiography: was performed in multiple projections using a 5 ___ JL3.5 and a 5 ___ JR4 catheter, with manual contrast injections. Intra-aortic balloon counterpulsation: was initiated with an introducer sheath using a Cardiac Assist 9 ___ 40cc wire guided catheter, inserted via the right femoral artery. Percutaneous coronary revascularization was performed using placement of bare-metal stent(s). Conscious Sedation: was provided with appropriate monitoring performed by a member of the nursing staff. FROM **LEFT CORONARY 5) LEFT MAIN NORMAL 6) PROXIMAL LAD NORMAL 6A) SEPTAL-1 NORMAL 7) MID-LAD DISCRETE 90 8) DISTAL LAD NORMAL 9) DIAGONAL-1 DISCRETE 10) DIAGONAL-2 NORMAL 12) PROXIMAL CX DISCRETE 100 **PTCA RESULTS CX PTCA COMMENTS: Initial angiography revealed a proximally occluded LCx. We planned to treat this with PTCA and stenting. Heparin and Integrillin were given prophylactically. A ___ XB3.5 guide provided good support. A Prowater wire crossed the wire without difficulty. Thrombectomy was performed with an Export catheter followed by predilation with a 2.0x15mm Voyager balloon. A 3.0x18mm Vision bare metal stent was then deployed at 16atm. Post-dilation was performed with 3.25x15mm and 3.5x15mm Quantum Maverick balloons at 21 and 20atm, respectively. Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, TIMI 3 flow, and no apparent dissection. TECHNICAL FACTORS: Total time (Lidocaine to test complete) = 1 hour 14 minutes. Arterial time = 1 hour 12 minutes. Fluoro time = 13.0 minutes. IRP dose = 879 mGy. Contrast injected: Non-ionic low osmolar (isovue, optiray...), vol 140 ml Premedications: ASA 325 mg P.O. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated two vessel coronary artery disease. The ___ was free of angiographically apparent flow limiting stenosis. The LAD had a complex trifurcating lesion in the mid vessel that was 80-90%. There was an 80% stenosis in the mid LAD that involved the origin of a major diagonal branch. That diagonal branch also had a 90% stenosis. The LCx had a 100% proximal stenosis. The RCA had a long 50% stenosis in the mid vessel. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed elevated right and left sided filling pressures with RVEDP 16mmHg, and mean PCWP 25mmHg. There was mild pulmonary arterial hypertension with PASP 38mmHg on dopamine gtt. The cardiac index on dopamine was preserved at 3.17 l/min/m2, it declined to 1.58 l/min/m2 when dopamine was weaned off because of continued ventricular ectopy. Following the placement of the IABP the cardiac index improved to 2.3 l/min/m2. 3. Left ventriculography was deferred. 4. An intra-aortic balloon pump was placed sheathed via the right femoral artery, with MAP 77 mmHg on ___ counterpulsation. 5. Successful PCI of the proximal LCx occlusion with a 3.0x18mm Vision BMS, post-dilated to 3.5mm. 6. Because of low blood pressure in the presence of rapid atrial fibrillation, cardioversion to NSR was performed with a single shock of 360 joules after the patient was sedated with the help of a member of the anesthesia department. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Mildly elevated right and left sided filling pressures. 3. Mild pulmonary arterial hypertension. 4. Successful placement of intra-aortic balloon pump. 5. Successful PCI of the LCx with BMS. 6. Successful cardioversion of atrial fibrillation. ATTENDING PHYSICIAN: ___. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with lateral akinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a large heart attack and a bare metal stent was placed in your left circumflex artery. You had some heart arrhythmias including atrial fibrillation and ventricular fibrillation that required cardioversion (shock) to fix, and short runs of ventricular tachycardia. All of this irregular rhythms were thought to be due to your heart attack and have now resolved. Your echocardiogram showed some wall motion abnormalities and your heart function is not as strong as it was before but we think this will improve over time. For now, you will need to exercise accoring to your exercise prescription, take all of your medicines and follow up with your new cardiologists. A bypass operation will be scheduled in the future. . target: Mr ___ presented with ___ in the context of a 'cold' and dyslipidemia. A bare mental stent was placed in the proximal left circumflex culprit lesion. The patient will take Plavix and other CAD regimen for one month, allowing for endothelium to appear within stent, before elective CABG, given extensive CAD. Coronary Artery Disease The patient underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed significant RCA, LAD (including diagonal)and LCx disease and had a stent placed to the LCx. Symptomatic ischemia and EKG changes were likely derived from the occluded LCx. CAD is a new diagnosis for this patient. LDL 121 and HbA1c 5.4 suggesting he does not have diabetes. He was given integrillin for 18 hrs. Given extensive coronary disease, the patient is a candidate for CABG. Cardiac surgery was consulted and it was decided to defer this surgery by one month, allowing endothelium to appear within the LCx stent. The patient was given a dose of prasugrel for rapid onset of purine receptor block, followed by Plavix. He is being discharged on plavix BID for one week then Q day, atorvastatin, metoprolol, lisinopril, and full dose aspirin. He will follow up with Dr. ___ cardiac surgery and with Dr. ___ for cardiology. Atrial Fibrillation, Ventricular Tachycardia, Torsades de Pointes Although atypical, AF appears to be an ischemic rhythm in this case (concern for new onset MR, possibly consistent with echo, and atrial stretch). It appeared responsible for hypotension, but hypotension continued despite resolution of AF  however, each of the above rhythms is also associated with lowered pressure. Cardioversion was desirable and successful in the cath. lab (sedated, electrical) and a baloon pump was placed. Over the night following catheterization, the patient had frequent bouts of ventricular ectopy with PVCs, VT, AIVR, and one 14 second episode of self-limited torsades de ___. Due to low blood pressures, beta-blocker was initially avoided and patient was loaded with amiodarone and started on an amiodarone gtt. Swan-Ganz catheter was removed to prevent triggering arrhythmias. The ventricular ectopy decreased, and after discussion with EP, low dose metoprolol was initiated and amidarone was stopped. K and Mg were aggressively repleted. Ectopy was very substantially decreased about 24 hours after the event, suggestive of extended reperfusion ectopy. He had very few to no ectopy at discharge. Hypertension/Hypotension Balloon pump was used for the first 24 hours to support cardiac function and blood pressure. He was also briefly on dopamine in the cath. lab., which was discontinued upon arrival on the floor. Systolic blood pressures were initially in the ___, lower during VT, even after having 4.5L of fluid. His pressures spontaneously increased on the day following admission. HCTZ was held. Leukocytosis Likely stress demargination in ACS and resolved with time. Supported by diff with minimal bands and evening cortisol of 26 at presentation.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Metoclopramide / Haldol / morphine / ibuprofen / Iodinated Contrast- Oral and IV Dye <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with systolic heart failure (LVEF 35%), coronary artery disease s/p NSTEMI ___ with diffuse disease and inferior STEMI in ___ (no intervention), valvular heart disease (2+MR, 2+TR), peripheral vascular disease s/p L BKA, current 3 cig/day smoker who presents as an ED-ED transfer from ___ for dyspnea and lower extremity edema for the last 2 days. She reports that she noticed swelling in RLE ___ days ago as well as progressive shortness of breath and orthopnea. Shortness of breath is at rest as she resides in a wheelchair and is not physically active. She describes sleeping in a hospital bed with incline at baseline but progressive orthopnea and PND since ___. She had wanted to delay evaluation until after family's ___ dinner (corned beef). She has also has abdominal bloating "I feel six months pregnant". She has PRN Lasix 20mg at home which she has not taken in years but did trial yesterday and today. She denies chest pain. She reports L shoulder/scapula pain which is reproducible and associated with back pain. She denies LH/dizziness/syncope. She reports that she has not had anything similar in many years. Per her last cardiology outpatient note with Dr. ___ ___, her "coronary disease is widespread enough to favor surgical repair but unfortunately her anatomy makes appropriate targets difficult. She was previously evaluated by cardiac surgery but unfortunately was deemed a poor CABG candidate given diffuse CAD with poor distal targets ("small targets would likely prevent bypasses from maturing"). We referred her to back to interventional cardiology for re-evaluation for high risk PCI of the left main coronary artery (unlikely in setting of recent CVA, asymptomatic status)." Current plans for medical optimization. At presentation to the ED, her vitals were T: 98 HR: 95 BP: 167/87 RR: 22 SO2: 94% RA . She was assessed by the cardiology fellow in the ED. BiPAP initiated in the ED for symptomatic improvement (no hypoxia noted). She was given Lasix 40 mg IV and nitro gtt started with at least 300 cc urine output by the time of cardiology fellow's exam with improvement in dyspnea. A foley catheter was placed. She also received IV fentanyl 50 mcg, ASA 324, heparin drip for NSTEMI although her back pain was reproducible. EKG changes and trop were through to be demand in the setting of known unrevascularized multivessel disease versus acute coronary syndrome. She was admitted for consideration of PCI depending on anemia, ___ and multivessel disease. She was recently admitted from ___ for dysphagia and twitching as well as word finding difficulties without evidence of new CVA nor seizure activity with improvement during hospitalization. Back pain was also present during this hospital stay. She also had early DKA on that hospital stay. In ___ she presented to the CCU intubated for AMS. She was found to have an inferior STEMI and left MCA CVA. She did not undergo cath for STEMI due to bleeding risk in setting of stroke. She also has known 3VD with poor surgical targets. She was medically managed with ASA, Plavix, Statin, and beta blocker. She did not get started on ___ due to ___. For her stroke, she had a work up for etiology. Did not show evidence of PFO. CT-A did not show evidence of carotid stenosis. Etiology was thought to be cardioembolic from transient myocardial stunning in setting of MI. She was admitted from ___ to the neurology service. What happened when you were in the hospital? - In the emergency room, you were placed on BIPAP, which is a way to help you breath without using a breathing machine. - You were admitted to the cardiology service where you received IV Lasix (furosemide) to make you pee out the extra fluid. - Your medications were changed around to make them better for your high blood pressure and heart failure. - You were found to have a mini-heart attack. - Your kidney level was elevated (creatinine) and this was monitored. - The chronic pain service recommended we add Lyrica to your pain regimen, which you declined. - We offered to consult psychiatry to assist with management of depressed mood and coping of your medical issues but you declined their evaluation. - We had extensive discussions with you along with your sister ___ (healthcare proxy), your husband, and your mother. To this end, we also signed a form (called a MOLST) that you will NOT be hospitalized. What should you do when you leave the hospital? - You elected to follow up with only palliative care and primary care for now to limit your coming back to medical providers. - Please take all your medications as prescribed. There have been changes to your medication list as described below. - Your discharge weight is 49.8 kg (109.79 lb). If you are able to weigh yourself at home, please check your weights daily and let your primary care doctor know if you are gaining more than 3 lbs in a day. This may affect your torsemide dosing plan. It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. Sincerely, Your ___ care team
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with systolic heart failure (LVEF 45%), coronary artery disease s/p NSTEMI ___ with diffuse disease and inferior STEMI in ___ (no intervention), L MCA CVA with residual hemirparesis and word-finding diffculties, valvular heart disease (2+MR, 2+TR), peripheral vascular disease s/p L BKA, current smoker who presents as an ED-ED transfer from ___ for dyspnea and lower extremity edema for the last 2 days, felt to be HFrEF exacerbation with NSTEMI, anemia, and ___. #GOC: brief hospital course predominated by ___ conversations. Patient repeatedly expressed that she wants leave the hospital and was felt to have the capacity to do so. Her specific goals were to go home, smoke, drink CocaCola, and eat whatever she wants. She requested to be DNR/DNI, and a family meeting was held with HCP/sister and patient's mother at which time she was made DNR/DNI. Patient also repeatedly expressed a desire to be DNH stating that she was tired of multiple admissions. Family meeting was had to discuss this as well and palliative care was consulted for consideration of hospice. It is difficult to predict her life expectancy; however, it was felt that given her multiple comorbidities, home hospice ___ would be a reasonable consideration. MOLST signed with DNR/DNI/DNH/no noninvasive ventilation/no artificial nutrition/no artificial hydration/no dialysis. Patient's husband and oldest daughter were also aware of the change in ___ and were supportive of patient's choice. This change in code status was communicated to PCP. Given concern for depression affecting patient's decision-making, psychiatry consultation and initiation of antidepressants were encouraged by primary team but patient declined. Finally, patient does not wish to maintain follow up with specialist providers but is willing to return to PCP with whom she has an established relationship and with palliative care for now. She wishes to continue medications as well for now. # Acute exacerbation of chronic systolic heart failure (EF 45%): ___ class III, stage C; warm and wet on admission to ___ service. Patient presented with SOB and orthopnea with CXR consistent with pulmonary edema, elevated JVP and BNP. She was notably not hypoxic but placed on BIPAP in the ED which improved her dyspnea and orthopnea. The etiology of her HF exacerbation was felt to be due to NSTEMI vs dietary indiscretion vs hypertensive urgency with flash pulmonary edema vs underdiuresis (not consistently on Lasix 20 po daily at home). She was diuresed with IV Lasix 40 during hospital course, including on day of discharge when she appeared to flash again ___ hypertension with SBP 170s. She was transitioned to new home diuretic plan of torsemide 20 mg daily to ensure euvolemia. In addition, her ischemic HFrEF regimen was optimized during this hospital course with the addition of metoprolol (changed from home labetalol), as well as imdur 90 mg daily and hydralazine 50 mg TID. ACE and ___ were not pursued given renal function but may be considered as outpatient. TTE this admission showed normal left ventricular cavity size with mild regional systolic dysfunction most c/w CAD (PDA distribution). Moderate mitral regurgitation; increased PCWP; EF 45%. In sum: -Diuretics: torsemide 20 daily -Preload: imdur 90 mg daily -Afterload: hydral 50 mg TID; amlodipine 5 mg daily -NHBK: Metoprolol XL 50 mg daily -Aldactone not pursued given hyperK+ hx -Devices: not candidate for ICD; not within GOC -Discharge (bed) weight is 49.8 kg (109.79 lb). #NSTEMI #CAD s/p NSTEMI ___ with diffuse disease and inferior STEMI in ___ (without revascularization) This admission, patient had increased STD laterally from baseline, and positive troponin (negative CK-MB) for which she was placed on heparin gtt initially (subsequently discontinued due to anemia as below). She continued on home aspirin 325, atorva 80, and initiated on metoprolol as above. Troponins downtrended without further intervention. Ultimately, she will go home on aspirin 81 mg daily due to concern for ongoing anemia. #Acute on chronic iron deficiency anemia: patient has known baseline anemia which is felt to be mixed etiology (normocytic with wide RDW raises suspicion for B12 and iron deficiency and ACD). Her home ferric gluconate was held and she received IV Fe repletion according to FAIR-HF trial. She received 1U pRBC during admission with appropriate improvement in Hct/Hgb. Etiology of acute on chronic anemia felt to be due to occult bleeding in setting of heparin gtt (?GI given dark stool vs GYN given hx of menorrhagia, although neither seen in hospital). ___ on CKD: Cr elevated to 1.8 from baseline ~1.3-1.7, with suspicion for cardiorenal etiology. FeUrea this admission was 35%, borderline instrinsic vs prerenal etiology. Cr remained stable over brief admission. #Depressed mood: this was addressed at length with primary team and patient given the concern that her depressed mood was affecting her coping and possibly decision making. However, patient attributed depressed mood to the fact of being in the hospital and states that she's happy when she's at home doing the things she likes. To this end, she declined psychiatry evaluation and antidepressants while admitted. #Somnolence: patient noted to be more lethargic upon initial evaluation, which was felt to be due to medication effect with IV Ativan given overnight as well as her home sedating medications (mirtazapine at 45 mg qHS and qHS po Ativan). Ativan was held over admission and mirtazapine decreased to 15 mg qHS. Her mental status improved and she was alert and oriented on ___ afternoon and ___. CHRONIC ISSUES: ================ #Type I DM: continued home insulin dosing and ISS; glargine increased to 14U qAM and 14U qPM given hyperglycemia to 400s on the day of discharge. Her insulin regimen may be further adjusted as an outpatient. #Back/shoulder pain: Patient follows with chronic pain as an outpatient and this pain is felt to be due to ___ etiology. Primary team discussed regimen with CPS who recommended Lyrica and titration off gabapentin. Patient declined Lyrica and strongly wished to pursue gabapentin. She was continued on baclofen, lidocaine patch, and standing Tylenol. #h/o seizure disorder: continued home lacosamide #Current smoker: continued on nicotine patch while inpatient; discontinued at discharge as patient is a current smoker. Notably, smoking was a primary motivator for her decision to go home. We did discuss the option of her going outside to smoke then returning for ongoing care but patient declined this too. #h/o L MCA CVA with residual R sided hemiparesis and word finding difficulty: patient was continued on aspirin 325 while admitted as well as Plavix 75 and atorvastatin 80 mg qHS. Aspirin was decreased to 81 mg on discharge due to change in GOC and concern that she would continue to have worsening anemia if she were to continue on asa 325 at home. #Hypothyroidism: continued home levothyroxine #HTN: patient placed on amlodipine, imdur, and hydralazine as above #GERD: continued home omeprazole 40 mg PO BID TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Patient was insistent on leaving on ___ despite primary team concern that her medications would need further titration and monitoring. Please watch BP, glucose, and CBC, chem10 to ensure appropriate dosing. - see GOC above as patient is now DNR/DNI/Do not hospitalize. MOLST signed with HCP and patient on ___ - Please consider further clarification if patient wishes to receive outpatient care. At the time of discharge, she wished to attend follow up with PCP and palliative care only and so no other appointments were arranged (e.g. cardiology). She notably DOES want to continue medications and is ok with further lab checks to confirm proper doses of medications. However, she would not want inpatient-level care if management of abnormal labs or symptoms were to warrant hospitalization. - Please consider cancelling any appointments that are not with PCP or palliative care per patient preference - Please discuss ongoing consideration of antidepressants. Patient declined psychiatry evaluation which may be re-addressed in follow up PCP ___. - Please clarify indication for omeprazole 40 mg BID and decrease if able - Discharge weight 49.8 kg (109.79 lb). Please note the following changes: MEDICATIONS INITIATED: --torsemide 20 mg daily --metoprolol XL 50 mg daily --imdur 90 mg daily --hydralazine 50 mg TID --amlodipine 5 mg daily MEDICATIONS DISCONTINUED: --labetalol changed to metoprolol XL 50 mg daily --Tylenol with codeine discontinued due to somnolence MEDICATIONS ADJUSTED: --aspirin 325 mg daily decreased to 81 mg daily given anemia requiring blood transfusion this admission --glargine increased to 14U qAM and 14U qPM --mirtazapine decresed from 45 to 15 mg qHS due to increased somnolence

Pain felt like heart was being "squeezed " for several minutes with alternating pressure sensation at his sternal area. Patient describes pain lasted for 5 minutes, affected left chest and radiated to both arms with a "pins and needles" sensation. Patient did not take nitroglycerin because he has not obtained relief from this in the past. He states that since his last cardiac surgery in ___ he has essentially been chest pain free, and denies any other anginal pains over past ___ years. Prior MIs have tended to cause more back and neck area pains, per patient. Of note, patient had prolonged admission after STEMI in ___, which was complicated by subsequent VT arrest and cardiogenic shock. Patient required intra-aortic balloon pump support as well as ventilator support. . Patient reports that approximately 30 minutes after onset of his first chest pain episode, he went up the stairs to shave, and while in the bathroom began having the same sensations of pressure/squeezing over his left chest, although less intense and which lasted less time. Patient denies palpitations, but reports a feeling of "difficulty getting air in" with chest pain. He also reports paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea for the last 6 months. He now has equivalent of 3 pillow orthopnea and reports frequent episodes of waking up and needing to go outside to "get some air". He denies skipping medications, and he has not discontinued his Plavix. Still smokes approximately one pack per day. . Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2 Occluded SVG-->OM2. 3. Cardiogenic shock. 4. Succesful Stenting of SVG-OM2 5. Intraaortic ballon pump placement. . . ___ TTE: The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. LV systolic function appears mildly-to-moderately depressed (ejection fraction 40 percent) secondary to hypokinesis/akinesis of the inferior and posterior walls. There is no ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with borderline normal free wall function. There are complex (>4mm) atheroma in the aortic arch. There are focal calcifications in the aortic arch. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. LVEF =40%. Compared with the findings of the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the left ventricular ejection fraction is increased. . . ___ PA AND LATERAL CHEST: Heart size is at the upper limits of normal. The lungs are clear without effusion, consolidation, or pneumothorax. There is no overt CHF. Post- median sternotomy and CABG changes are stable. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. . ___ CARDIAC CATH: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed native 3 vessel and left main CAD. The LMCA had a calcified ostial 85% stenosis. The LAD was heavily calcified, with ostial 30% stenosis and diffuse disease throughout up to 50% stenosis in the mid-LAD just before a major D2. The mid LAD was tortuous at the LIMA anastomosis, with competitive flow seen. There was stump occlusion of the previously stented D3 and a small high D1. The LCX was heavily calcified, with mild diffuse disease proximally and supplying a large branching OM1. The AV groove CX was occluded after OM1, with late filling of a distal LPL via left to left collaterals. The RCA was heavily calcified, with diffuse disease and ectasia throughout. There was a proximal 80% stenosis, a mid 80% stenosis and a distal 90% stenosis before the RPDA. There was competitive flow in the RPDA. There were 2 long RPLs. There was a distal AV groove RCA that supplied collaterals to OM2. 2. Vein graft angiography demonstrated a stump occluded SVG-OM (~10 mm proximal to prior stents). 3. Radial-rPDA angiography demonstrated patent a radial graft with an origin 30% stenosis. There was antegrade filling of the large RPDA and retrograde filling into the RPLs and distal AV groove (with collaterals to OM2). Arterial conduit angiography also demonstrated a patent LIMA-LAD with collateral filling of the stented diagonal. There was were serial heavily calcified eccentric 30% stenoses in the proximal left subclavian artery. 4. Successful PTCA and stenting of protected LMCA was performed with a 3.0x13 mm Cypher ___ using a 3.25 mm NC balloon. Final angiography revealed a 5% residual stenosis and no dissection or distal emboli (see PTCA Comments). 5. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated mildly elevated systemic arterial pressures (145/77 mmHg), mildly elevated left sided filling pressures (LVEDP 18 mmHg, with respiratory variation from ___ mmHg). There was no transaortic gradient on pullback of catheter from LV to aorta. 6. Left ventriculography was deferred. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel and left main native coronary artery disease. 2. Patent LIMA-LAD and radial-rPDA but stump occluded SVG-OM. 3. Mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 4. Mild systemic systolic arterial hypertension. 5. Successful stenting of protected LMCA with a Cypher DES. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Metoprolol XL 100mg Aspirin 325mg Crestor 40mg Lisinopril 5mg Plavix 75mg Neurontin 900mg QAM, 1200QPM Seroquel 150mg QHS <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Tablet, Sublingual Sublingual PRN (as needed) as needed for chest pain: Please take sublingually for chest pain relief and repeat x2 cycles at 5 minute intervals. ___ call M.D. if chest pain continues . Disp: *15 Tablet, Sublingual(s)* Refills: *0* 3. Toprol XL 100 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day.
