Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *3* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Unstable Angina Coronary Artery Disease Hypertension Mild Congestive Heart Failure/Systolic Dysfunction (EF 40%) Hyperlipidemia Osteoarthritis . <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Good. At time of discharge the patient had stable vital signs and appeared to be in no distress. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___ ___. . You were admitted after complaints of chest pain and discomfort. Additional lab studies showed that you had negative cardiac enzyme markers which indicates you did not suffer an acute heart attack. Your cardiac monitoring tests (EKG, telemetry monitoring)also showed no evidence of a new heart attack. Follow up cardiac catheterization discovered that you had a narrowing of your left main coronary artery (___) which was stented and opened up to allow for better blood flow to your heart. Some of your older heart grafts were also noted to be occluded. A repeated ultrasound of your heart, called an echocardiogram, showed you still have mildly decreased heart pumping function as a result of prior heart attacks and damage to your heart muscles. Overall, however, your heart pumping function (also called ejection fraction) appears slightly better than it did in ___. . It is important that you weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight > 3 lbs. Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet per day. Also, please stop smoking. Information was given to you on admission regarding smoking cessation. . It is very important that you follow-up with your physicians as outlined below. . If you experience any additional chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, confusion, new weakness, bleeding/swelling/redness in your right groin at the catheterization entry location, or any other concerning symptoms please return to the emergency room or call your primary cardiologist as soon as possible. . MEDICATION INSTRUCTIONS: -Please start taking 20mg Lasix daily for blood pressure control and for mild systolic heart dysfunction -Continue to take nitroglycerin sublingual tablets as needed and as prescribed for additional chest pains / angina -Continue taking 100mg Toprol XL once daily -Otherwise, please continue taking your usual home medications as previously prescribed .
target: In summary,Mr. ___ is a ___ male with PMH significant for CABG ___, PCI ___, STEMI and subsequent VT arrest in ___ requiring additional stenting/PCI who presented with 24 hours of unstable angina. . # Chest Pains /Angina: Initially the patient's sudden onset of chest pain after ___ years of essentially no chest pains at baseline was very concerning for ACS given known premature CAD and recent graft failure. Fortunately, he had negative cardiac biomarkers. Given symptoms at rest, stent re-stenosis was felt to be less likely. Mr. ___ has a longstanding history of cardiac events, including CABG ___ (LIMA-LAD, radial PDA, SVG-OM2), PTCA and stenting to D1 in ___, and he had a STEMI/VT arrest ___ which required IABP support, and a thrombotic occlusion of SVG-OM2 was discovered and stented. At that time, back in ___, cardiac catheterization also noted 50% ostial LMCA, 50% LAD, 80% dRCA, 60% pRCA lesions and occluded LCX. On this admission, he was continued on heparin drip, and had been Plavix loaded at OSH prior to arrival in anticipation of a cardiac catheterization. He remained chest pain free after admission to ___ and he was continued on aspirin, plavix, statin therapy and Toprol XL. Repeat lipid profile showed LDLs 82, total cholesterol of 140, HDLs 36 and TGs 111. He was taken to cardiac catheterization lab and angiography revealed native 3 vessel and left main coronary artery disease. There was a patent LIMA-LAD and radial-rPDA but stump occluded at SVG-->OM3. Mild left ventricular diastolic dysfunction noted along with some mild systemic systolic arterial hypertension as well. He underwent successful stenting of protected LMCA with a Cypher drug-eluting stent with no post-procedure complications. At time of discharge he was chest pain free with stable vital signs. He was discharged on his usual Toprol XL, statin, aspirin, plavix, SL NTG as needed and he was started on 20mg Lasix daily for blood pressure control and for mild systolic heart dysfunction. He was also advised to continue close-follow up with his primary cardiologist, Dr. ___. . . # Pump function / Chronic systolic and diastolic heart failure: Last LVEF prior to this hospitalization was noted at 40-45%, however his history was suggestive of deterioration of systolic function with his complaints of some orthopnea, PND, and some mild bibasilar crackles on exam. Chest x-ray fairly unremarkable for any large amounts of fluid overload and read as being WNL. Team initially held off on diuresis given anticipated cardiac catheterization. Beta blocker and lisinopril continued daily. A repeat ECHO was reassuring as it showed the left ventricular ejection fraction was slightly better that his last study ___ (LVEF=40%). However, given his clinical symptoms and the notice of additional left ventricular diastolic dysfunction and mild systemic systolic arterial hypertension on cardiac catheterization he was started on Lasix 20mg daily prior to discharge alongside his usual beta-blocker and daily lisinopril. He was asked to weigh himself every morning, call MD if weight > 3 lbs, and he was also advised to adhere to 2 gm sodium diet per day. . #Rhythm: Predominantly normal sinus rhythm with no new significant ectopy noticed on continuous telemetry monitoring or serial EKGs. Heart rates typically in the 60-80s range. No subjective complaints of palpitations. . #Osteoarthritis: Predominantly in hips and knees, sometimes has "aches" in his lower back area as well. He was continued on his usual daily Neurontin therapy for joint aches while inpatient. . # Insomnia : Per history, it appears heart failure symptoms account for most of his sleep disturbance as he awakens secondary to PND and orthopnea. As above, his regimen was changed and Lasix added for additional CHF therapy. However, he continued on his Seroquel for now to avoid withdrawal, and given that he describes some overlapping anxiety that he feels makes his sleeping worse at night. . #Smoking: He is still smoking 1PPD, and he has been using tobacco for about ___ years. Smoking cessation counseling provided and health risks outlined clearly. He was given a Nicotine Patch 21 mg TD DAILY. . # Fluids, Electrolytes and Nutrition: He was initially NPO in anticipation of cardiac catheterization but ___ placed on a regular cardiac healthy diet post-procedure. Electrolytes were monitored and repleted daily as needed. . # Prophylaxis: He was continued on a heparin drip which also served as DVT protection, and Colace/Senna given PRN for bowel regimen. . # Code Status: The patient was maintained as a full code status for the entirety of his hospital course. .

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> STEMI <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac catheterization an placement of Bare Metal Stent in LAD. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with h/o current tobacco abuse, hypertension, ___ transferred from OSH with STEMI. Patient reports that she was in her USOH was standing outside talking to her neighbor when she developed localized substernal chest pressure that gradually worsened to feel like a sharp, knife like pain, ___ in severity. In addition, she also had dyspnea, nausea and light headedness. She went into her house and lay down with no improvement in her symptoms so she called her PCP who told her to go to the hosptial and she arrived at ___ about 3.5 hours after her initial symptom onset. She does not remember what she got in ___ but reports that her pain has been persistant and is still a ___ on admission to the floor post cath. At ___ she was found to have ST elevations inferiorly, was started on heparin gtt and transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. . Of note she does report having episodes of chest pain, similar to her current pain for about ___ years, but never as bad as the current episode. In addition, she has reported worsening dyspnea with exertion such as running or walking recently. . In the cath lab she was found to have single vessel CAD with large thrombus mid vessel. He had thrombectomy, intracoronary nipride and integrilin. Also found to have distal apical LAD embolic occlusion removed with restoration of normal flow no residual stenosis. On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. *** Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypertension Hyperlipidemia Depression patient reports brain damage since birth ?hormone problem - with chronic diaphoresis and flushing <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> There is no family history of premature coronary artery disease or sudden death. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS T98.5 BP121/75 (110-121/72/88) HR 71 RR 16 100% RA Gen: diaphoretic and flushed appearing, resting comfortably, in NAD HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Neck: Supple with JVP flat CV: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB anteriorly, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. BS + Ext: No lower extremity edema, DP's 2+bilaterally, right groin with pressure dressing in place, no evidence of hematoma or bruit Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ Renal U/S: Normal kidneys bilaterally. No renal masses identified. ___ ECHO: The left atrium is elongated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Normal regional and global biventricular systolic function. No pathologic valvular abnormality seen. ___ CTA Chest: 1. No pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection. The stent in the left anterior descending coronary artery cannot be assessed as this examination is not tailored towards that. 2. Scattered mediastinal lymph nodes with the largest measuring 15 x 13 mm at the right hilum are of uncertain clinical significance. 3 Incompletely evaluated prominence of the anterior interpolar cortex of the left kidney, a renal ultrasound is advised for furter assesment. ___ C.Cath: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated single vessel coronary artery disease. There was a large thrombus in the mid-LAD with slow flow at its apex. The LMCA, LCx, and RCA did not have any angiographically apparent CAD. 2. Resting hemodyanmic measurement demonstrated elevated filling pressures with a PCWP of 18 mmHg and an RVEDP of 18 mmHg. The mean PAP was within normal limits at 26 mmHg. The calculated fick cardiac index was preserved at 2.9 l/min/m2. 3. Successful thrombectomy and stenting of the mid left anterior descending artery with a Driver (3.5x12mm) bare metal stent. Final angiography demonstrated no angiographically apparent dissection, no residual stenosis and TIMI III flow throughout the majority of the vessel. The very distal portion of the vessel demonstrated slow flow (See ___ comments). FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Elevated bi-ventricular filling pressures. 3. Successful thrombectomy and PCI of mid-LAD with a bare metal stent. ___ ECG: Sinus rhythm. There is ST segment elevation in the inferior and anterolateral leads consistent with acute myocardial infarction. Reciprocal ST segment depression offers additional evidence of myocardial infarction. No previous tracing available for comparison. Clinical correlation is advised. TRACING #1 Labs: ___ 05: 15PM WBC-12.5* RBC-3.56* HGB-9.1* HCT-27.9* MCV-78* MCH-25.6* MCHC-32.8 RDW-17.8* ___ 05: 15PM PLT COUNT-505* ___ 05: 15PM ___ PTT-150* ___ ___ 05: 15PM TRIGLYCER-262* HDL CHOL-21 CHOL/HDL-7.9 LDL(CALC)-92 ___ 05: 15PM IRON-38 CHOLEST-165 ___ 05: 15PM calTIBC-421 FERRITIN-15 TRF-324 ___ 05: 15PM GLUCOSE-113* UREA N-14 CREAT-0.6 SODIUM-126* POTASSIUM-3.1* CHLORIDE-91* TOTAL CO2-21* ANION GAP-17 ___ 05: 15PM ALT(SGPT)-22 AST(SGOT)-27 LD(LDH)-181 ALK PHOS-65 TOT BILI-0.2 ___ 05: 15PM RET MAN-1.4 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Atenolol 50mg daily Diovan 80mg daily HCTZ 25mg daily Seroquel 200mg BId lamictal 100mg daily Protonix 40mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Quetiapine 100 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 5. Lamotrigine 100 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. Pantoprazole 40 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO Q24H (every 24 hours). 7. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ ___: ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) Coronary artery disease Hyperlipidemia Hypertension Tobacco Abuse Depression <DISCHARGE CONDITION> fair <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital because you were having a heart attack. You had cardiac catheterization and removal of a blood clot from one of the arteries that supplies blood to your heart. You also had a stent placed in this artery to keep it open. Your other heart arteries did not show any evidence of significant blood clot. You also had a cat scan which did not show any evidence of blood clot in your lungs. You had an ultrasound of your kidney to follow up on a nonspecific finding on cat scan. The kidney ultrasound was normal. Medications: 1) You were started on a medication called ___ which you will need to take every day until your doctor tells you that you can stop. This medication is very important to prevent a blood clot from forming in your heart. Missing doses of this medication could cause you to have another heart attack. 2)Your atenolol, hydrochlorothiazide and diovan were stopped. 3)You were started on metoprolol xl 50mg daily to protect your heart and your blood pressure. 4)You were started on lipitor 80mg daily for your cholesterol. 5) You were started on ferrous sulfate which you should take because your red blood cell count is slightly low which is most likely due to your menstrual periods. This pill can cause constipation. Please call your doctor if you do not have a bowel movement in greater than 3 days. It is very important that you quit smoking to help protect your heart and decrease the risk of having another heart attack. You were started on the nicotine patch which you should continue to take. The dose will be decreased to a lower nicotine level in 6 weeks by your primary care doctor. Please continue to follow a low fat diet. You should try to eat fresh fruits and vegetables and avoid high fat foods and fast foods which have a lot of cholesterol. Please follow up as below. Please call your doctor or return to the hospital if you have any concerning symptoms including chest pain, light headedness, dizziness, fever >101, trouble breathing or any other worrisome symptoms. Please try to quit smoking after you leave the hospital. Information was given to you about smoking cessation.
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ yo F with h/o current tobacco abuse, hypertension, ___ transferred from OSH with STEMI s/p LAD thrombectomy and BMS placement. 1)STEMI: She was transferred from OSH directly to the cardiac catheterization lab with STEMI with ST elevations in II, III and aVF. She had PCI with removal of large thrombus in LAD with placement of a BMS. She was also noted to have a distal LAD embolus. She did not have any recurrance of her chest pain during the remainder of her admission. Echocardiogram with preserved systolic function, EF 55%, no significant valvular abnormalities. She was discharged on ___ 325m atorvastatin ___ and metoprolol xl 50mg daily. She was counseled on smoking cessation and given a prescription for a nicotine patch on discharge. 2)Sinus tachycardia - she had persistant sinus tachycardia to 130's following her cardiac catheterization of unclear etiology. In addition, she was borderline hypotensive with SBP 90-100, while at baseline she is on 3 antihypertensives as an outpatient. She had a CTA to evaluate for pulmonary embolus that did not show any evidence of pulmonary embolus. There was no evidence of pericardial effusion on her echocardiogram. She may have been slightly dehydrated given that her tachycardia did respond to IVF. Anxiety and nicotine withdrawal was also a likely contributing factor to her tachycardia. 3) Anemia - unknown baseline with HCT 27.9 on admission. Iron studies consistent with iron deficiency anemia with low reticulocyte index. Her HCT remained stable with no evidence of acute bleeding. She was started on ferrous sulfate. 4)Leukocytosis - She had elevated WBC on admission likely ___ acute stress response in setting of STEMI, no symptoms of infection on ROS, UA negative. WBC normalized with no evidence of infection. 5)Thrombocytosis - most likely ___ acute stress response due to STEMI versus iron deficiency anemia. PLT stable in 500's. 6)Hypertension - borderline hypotensive post cath, unclear etiology as discussed above. She was changed from atenolol to metoprolol during her admission. Her diovan and HCTZ were discontinued. 7)Depression - She was continued on her outpatient regimen of seroquel and lamictal.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> doxycycline / Codeine / orphenadrine / Victoza <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Treadmill echo stress test ___ Left heart catheterization with coronary angiogram ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ year old woman with CAD s/p CABG in ___ (single vessel graft to RCA after multiple stents to RCA with intractable restenosis), DES to mLAD in ___ at ___, and DES to mid and distal OM at ___ one week prior to presentation who presents with generalized weakness and fatigue since her cardiac catheterization. She presented to ___ one week ago with her typical angina pain (L chest pain radiating to shoulder) and she reports that when having these last two stents placed last week, she did not experience the same sense of relief that she usually does when she has a stent placed. Since the PCI and stent placement, she has been feeling an overall sense of malaise, fatigue, exercise intolerance, mild SOB, lightheadedness, and continues to experience L chest pain/pressure going to the shoulder. This pain worsened over the last two days, prompting her to present to the ED. She says that her daughter was worried about her, she reports being pale, diaphoretic, and lightheaded. She has been taking 3 SL NG per day. She denies missing ASA or Plavix, which she takes at night. In the ED: - Initial vitals: 98.7 HR87 BP109/68 RR18 100% RA - EKG: NSR 79, LAD, NSST changes - Labs/studies notable for: 139 / 100 / 15 ---------------< 237 AGap=19 5.5 / 20 / 0.9 WBC 9.4 Hgb 14.2 plt 180 17: 30 CK: 45 MB: <1 Trop-T: <0.01 23: 39 Trop-T: <0.01 ___: 11.0 PTT: 41.1 INR: 1.0 - Patient was given: 17: 37 IV Ondansetron 4 mg 18: 34 SL Nitroglycerin SL .4 mg 20: 18 SL Nitroglycerin SL .4 mg ___ 21: 47 IV Morphine Sulfate 2 mg ___ 22: 53 TD Nicotine Patch 21 mg ___ 23: 06 IV Ondansetron 4 mg CXR: IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic process ED Course: treated symptomatically for nausea; became hypotensive with administration of SL nitro and was subsequently given 1L NS. She received full dose ASA prior to arrival. - Vitals on transfer: HR69 BP110/80 RR18 98% RA On the floor the patient relates the above. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope, or presyncope. On further review of systems, denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. Denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CAD s/p 13 stents per report and CABG -Diabetes Mellitus -PVD s/p multiple lower extremity procedures -H/o prior DVT -HLD -HTN -Anxiety -GERD, h/o PUD -Chronic pain -Glaucoma <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - Mother: AAA, MI, Carotid stenosis, cervical Ca, CAD - Cousin: cervical CA - maternal grandmother: MI - ___ grandfather with MI, HTN, HLD <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: -==== VS: T97.4 BP 127 / 83 HR 64 RR 18 98% Ra GENERAL: NAD HEENT: AT/NC, anicteric sclera, MMM NECK: supple, no LAD CV: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs PULM: CTAB, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi, breathing comfortably without use of accessory muscles GI: abdomen soft, nondistended, nontender in all quadrants, no rebound/guarding, no hepatosplenomegaly EXTREMITIES: no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. L groin access site is without hematoma or bruit. PULSES: 2+ radial pulses bilaterally NEURO: Alert, moving all 4 extremities with purpose, face symmetric DERM: warm and well perfused, no excoriations or lesions, no rashes DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: -==== VS: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 1127) Temp: 98.2 (Tm 98.5), BP: 102/62 (97-118/59-68), HR: 58 (54-78), RR: 18 (___), O2 sat: 97% (94-97), O2 delivery: Ra, Wt: 206.79 lb/93.8 kg Fluid Balance (last updated ___ @ 1327) Last 8 hours Total cumulative 600ml IN: Total 600ml, PO Amt 600ml OUT: Total 0ml Last 24 hours Total cumulative -180ml IN: Total 820ml, PO Amt 820ml OUT: Total 1000ml, Urine Amt 1000ml GENERAL: NAD HEENT: AT/NC, anicteric sclera, MMM NECK: supple, no LAD CV: RRR, S1/S2, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs PULM: CTAB, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi, breathing comfortably without use of accessory muscles GI: abdomen soft, nondistended, nontender in all quadrants, no rebound/guarding, no hepatosplenomegaly EXTREMITIES: no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. R groin access site is without hematoma or bruit. PULSES: 2+ DP pulses bilaterally NEURO: Alert, moving all 4 extremities with purpose, face symmetric DERM: warm and well perfused, no excoriations or lesions, no rashes <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS ___ 05: 30PM BLOOD WBC-9.4 RBC-4.78 Hgb-14.2 Hct-41.4 MCV-87 MCH-29.7 MCHC-34.3 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-40.7 Plt ___ ___ 05: 30PM BLOOD Neuts-66.2 ___ Monos-4.3* Eos-2.1 Baso-0.5 Im ___ AbsNeut-6.20* AbsLymp-2.48 AbsMono-0.40 AbsEos-0.20 AbsBaso-0.05 ___ 05: 30PM BLOOD Glucose-237* UreaN-15 Creat-0.9 Na-139 K-5.5* Cl-100 HCO3-20* AnGap-19* ___ 05: 30PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 11: 39PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 13PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 45AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.9 Stress Echo ___ Indication: This ___ year-old female with hypertension, diabetes, smoking, hyperlipidemia, family history of premature coronary artery disease, obesity, sedentary lifestyle, coronary artery disease onangiography, prior intracoronary stent, prior coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and peripheral vascular disease was referred for a stress test for evaluation of anginal pain and fatigue. Medications: metoprolol 25 mg QD, lisinopril 10 mg QD, isordil dinitrite 10 mg TID, rosuvastatin 40 mg QD clopidogrel 75 mg QD Type of stress/symptoms: The patient had no symptoms at rest/prior to stress. The patient exercised on a Gervino treadmill (3 min stages) protocol for 13 min 0 sec ___ METS) representing a fair exercise capacity for age and gender. The test was stopped due to claudication and leg fatigue. In response to stress, the patient had ___ left shoulder pain beginning at 12.5 min of exercise (heart rate 106bpm; systolic blood pressure 188mmHg)that resolved at 3.0 min (heart rate 83bpm; systolic blood pressure (152mmHg) of recovery. Hemodynamics: In response to stress, the heart rate increased to 109 bpm (65 % APMHR) with a peak systolic blood pressure of 188 mmHg (peak rate-pressure product = ___. ECG: The resting ECG showed sinus rhythm and non-specific STT wave changes. The stress ECG showed showed no change from baseline at peak exercise. More pronounced biphasic T waves were noted in recovery. During stress there was one isolated ventricular premature beats. Rest echo: Resting echo images demonstrated mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. There is normal regional left ventricular systolic function and normal global systolic function. Diastolic parameters are indeterminate. The right ventricular cavity size is normal with normal free wall motion. There is no pericardial effusion. Doppler demonstrates no aortic valve stenosis, trace aortic regurgitation, trivial mitral regurgitation and no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. The resting estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. Stress echo: Echo images were acquired within 54 sec post stress at heart rates of 105 to 93 bpm. These demonstrated appropriate augmentation of all left ventricular segments. The E/e' was 13 at seconds after exercise and similar to baseline. This suggests no abnormal increase in left ventricular filling pressure with exercise. There was appropriate augmentation of right ventricular free wall motion. Exercise conclusion: Fair functional exercise capacity for age and gender. Non-specific ECG changes, with anginal pain, and no 2D echocardiographic evidence of inducible ischemia to achieved treadmill stress. No Doppler evidence for a change in left ventricular filling pressure with exercise. Normal resting blood pressure with a normal blood pressure and a blunted heart rate (beta blocker) response to achieved treadmill stress. Normal pulmonary artery systolic pressure at rest. Left heart cath coronary angiogram ___ Results Hemodynamics Pressure (in mmHg) Label Phase Systolic Diastolic End diastolic Mean AO 0 113 63 0 76 Coronary Description The coronary circulation is right dominant. LM: The left main, arising from the left cup, is a large caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into the left anterior descending and leftcicumflex systems. LAD: The left anterior descending artery, which arises from the left main, is a large caliber vessel. There is mild tortuosity beginning in the proximal segment. There is a stent in the proximal segment. The Diagonal, arising from the proximal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The septal perforator, arising from the proximal segment, is a small caliber vessel. Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the left main, is a large caliber vessel. The obtuse marginal, arising from the mid segment, is a medium caliber vessel. There is a stent in the mid and distal segments. The superior lateral of the OM, arising from the distal segment, is a small caliber vessel. RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 100% stenosis in the ostium on prior angiosaphy There is a stent in the proximal, mid, and distal segments. Bypass Grafts: SVG: A medium caliber saphenous vein graft connects to the distal segment of the RCA. This graft is patent. Findings - Severe single-vessel coronary artery disease (RCA). Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear ___, ___ was a pleasure caring for you at ___. WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? -========= - You were admitted because you had chest pain in the setting of recently placed stents one week ago. WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL? -- - You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain. Based on our evaluation, there was no indication that you had a heart attack. During an exercise stress test, you had anginal chest pain, so the decision was made to proceed with a coronary angiogram to look at the coronary arteries. Based on the findings, the recommendation was made to manage your coronary artery disease and chest pain with medications. You were started on a new medication called Imdur to help with the chest pain, and your dose of Lisinopril was decreased from 10 mg daily to 5 mg daily. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? --== - It is very important to take your aspirin and clopidogrel (also known as Plavix) every day. These two medications keep the stents in the vessels of the heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. If you stop these medications or miss ___ dose, you risk causing a blood clot forming in your heart stents and having another heart attack. Please do not stop taking either medication without talking to your heart doctor. - You are also on other medications to help your heart: Rosuvastatin, Metoprolol, Imdur, and Lisinopril. Make sure to take these and all your other medications exactly as prescribed. - If you have severe anginal chest pain that does not improve with rest, your daily Imdur, and sublingual nitroglycerin, please go to the emergency department. - Continue to not smoke cigarettes, as cigarettes significantly increase your risk of coronary artery disease, heart attacks, and stroke. By quitting, you have decreased your risk of experiencing such events in the future. Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish you all the best! Your ___ Team

The patient was continued on medical management upon transfer to ___, with no further anginal symptoms even with ambulation since admission. The patient was taken for cardiac catheterization on ___, during which time a DES was placed to the LAD at the location of a 90% stenosis. There was also a 60% LCx stenosis noted, where no intervention was done. The patient tolerated the procedure well. He was monitored on telemetry with no significant events. He was continued on aspirin, plavix (to be continued x 12 months), metoprolol, and pravastatin. He was set-up to see a new cardiologist, Dr. ___ follow-up. . #. The patient was discharged on ___ in good condition, ambulating well, CP-free with cardiology follow-up in place.

ECG and cardiac enzymes were positive which signified that she had a second ___ while in the hospital. She was stabilized and taken to the cath lab on ___. She is now s/p two Cypher stents to LAD. She is currently chest pain free and doing well. She will be dishcharged on ASA 325 mg, ___, statin, beta-blocker and ace-inhibitor. She had no further symptoms during her stay, and her telemetry was unremarkable. # Respiratory distress: Patient went into respiratory distress secondary to ___ as above. Durint the episode she was also noted to be in atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular rate which likely contributed to her respiratory decompensation. Shortly after being intubated she became febrile and hypotensive. She wsa started on Vanco/Zosyn for treatment of possible sepsis/PNA. She was transitioned to Cipro/Zosyn and was treated for a 10 day course. She remained on the ventilator for > 1 week and was successfully extubated. She is to continue on Furosemide 40mg BID. #C Diff - Patient tested positive for C diff on ___. She was started on Flagyl and will complete a 14 day course. On day of discharge, she was day 7 of treatment. Her abdomen examination remained benign, and her diarrhea improved. # Hypertension: Patient was hypotensive during respiratory distress which likely contributed to respiratory decompensation. Blood pressures are now controlled on a regimen of Lisinopril 20mg daily and Metoprolol 100mg TID. . # Pump: Echocardiogram shows EF 40%. She is to continue on Lasix, ACE-inhibitor and BB. She appeared euvolemic at time of discharge. . # Rhythm: Patient had atrial fibrillation with RVR s/p ___ as above. Rhythm converted to NSR with diltiazem. She has had no repeat episodes while in the hospital. Anti-coagulation has been held as A-fib was likely in setting of MI. Patient is to continue on Beta-blocker. # Acute renal failure: Patient had acute renal failure likely due to atrial fibrillation and ___ resulting in poor forward flow. At time of discharge her creatinine was 1.0 and her renal failure had resolved. # Valves: No known pathology # COPD: Patient with history of COPD. Her home COPD medications were restarted and she continued to have good oxygen saturation on room air (95%) and no reported difficulties breathing. # Diabetes Mellitus: Patient has a history of diabetes on Lantus and Sliding scale at home. At time of discharge, she was on lantus 30 units, and a sliding scale of humalog on discharge. # Vulvar cancer: There was concern during patient's stay that she had developed a recto-vaginal fistula during the time she had the c. difficile diarrhea. A fistulogram was completed that did not demonstrate any evidence of fistula. Her primary outpatient oncology team was contacted and she will have further treatment as directed by them once she returns home to ___.

target: ___ female with complex cardiac history with multiple interventions presenting with angina. . 1. CORONARIES: Her presenting symptoms were concerning for unstable angina. The patient proceed to catheterization on ___. Given her creatinine elevation at 1.5 at time of admission, we prehydrated her along with sodium bicarbonate and N-acetylcysteine. In the holding area, just prior to catheterization, the patient developed some respiratory distress, with O2 sats dropping to low 80 % on 2 L O2. She was re-started on IV heparin, a nitroglycerin drip, and received IV lasix, with only 100 ccs of urine output. Her O2 saturation improved after received a nebulizer treatment. Cardiac catheterization was performed which revealed vein grafts to be patent and no intervention was performed. LVEDP was mildly elevated at 15 - 20 mm Hg. Medical management was encouraged. During the hospitalization, the patient had multiple episodes of chest pain following cardiac catheterization, resolving within minutes after administration of sublingual nitroglycerin. It's likely that the patient will continue to have these episodes and will need to use nitroglycerin as needed. We continued her on aspirin, statin, plavix, beta blocker, and ACEI. . 2. Congestive Heart Failure The patient was volume overloaded during the majority of the hospitalization. This is likely because on admission, we decreased the patient's home regimen of torsemide from 20 mg TID to 20 mg BID because of the creatinine elevation, as well as prehydrating her with 1 L before catheterization. On exam, she had rales and 1+ pitting edema, and required 2 L of oxygen to maintain saturations in the ___. We attempted multiple diuretic regimens, including using furosemide, metolazone, and torsemide. She had very little output following furosemide. The most effective was 5 mg of metolazone followed by 60 mg of torsemide. Towards the end of hospitalization, she developed acute renal failure, likely secondary to overdiuresis, and her torsemide was held for two days while her creatinine resolved. By the end of hospitalization, her rales had improved considerably, her pitting edema resolved, and she was able to saturate normally on room air. On ambulation, she was saturating at 97% on RA. She was discharged on 20 mg of torsemide PO BID. . 3. Acute Renal Failure As a consequence of diuresis and possibly contrast dye, the patient's creatinine rose from baseline to 2.3. We stopped her torsemide regimen and encouraged PO intake of fluids. Towards the end of hospitalization, her creatinine trended back down to baseline. She was restarted on torsemide twice a day. She will have her creatinine checked within 1 wk outpatient. . 4. Atrial Fibrillation Near the end of hospitalization, probably as a consequence of diuresis and likely volume depletion along with renal failure, the patient went into atrial fibrillation with HR 100 - 140. Her BP at the time was stable at 102/70. She received PO metoprolol with conversion back into sinus rhythm. She was symptomatic with chest pressure at the time of atrial fibrillation; she received a nitroglycerin with resolution of this pain. We increased her home metoprolol dose from 37.5 mg PO BID to 50 mg PO BID. She remained in normal sinus rhythm. . 5. Type II Diabetes Mellitus The patient's sugars were difficult to control throughout hospitalization. Initially, metformin and glyburide were held due to creatinine elevation. She was maintained on a sliding scale. However, when sugars started to > 400 regularly, she was restarted on glyburide at half her normal dose. Lantus was started at night in addition and metformin continued being held. The combination of 8 U lantus at night and glyburide along with sliding scale provided her good coverage. As her creatinine trended back down, we restarted her on metformin and her home dose of glyburide. . 6. COPD We continued her advair and spiriva and her albuterol as needed. Was stable during hospitalization. . 7. GERD We continued her H2 blocker. . 8. Dispo: The patient was discharged to home with home O2. She was transported by ambulance given her oxygen requirement. We set her up with ___ services.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure to care for you as your doctor. You were brought to the hospital because of shortness of breath which you experienced at home. During your hospitalization you had several tests done which ruled out a lung clot. However you were found to have a clot in one of your CABG vein grafts on your heart. This clot was cleared by cardiac catherization, where two stents were placed in this area. Another test also revealed your heart is not pumping as affectively as it should. We feel like your shortness of breath is therefore caused by disease in your heart which is also causing fluid to collect in your lungs. Your weight prior to leaving was 190 pounds. It is essential you weigh yourself every morning, call your primary care doctor if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. So, you should call your doctor if you weigh more than 193 pounds. You should continue the following medications with the following important changes: 1. DECREASE Lantus to 16 units daily as your blood sugars were quite low on your previous 23 units daily. 2. STOP: Isorsorbide Mononitrate as you had no evidence of chest pain after your procedure. 3. STOP: Amlodipine 4. STOP: Clonidine 5. STOP Furosemide 6. CONTINUE: Sevelmer 2400 mg with meals 7. CONTINUE: Nephrocaps, 1 capsule daily ****Your kidney doctors ___ monitor your blood pressure in dialysis and re-adjust your blood pressure regimen as needed. You did not have high blood pressure in the hospital, so we did not re-start some of your home medications.**** ****It is very important you remain compliant with your medications*** ***It is very important that you keep all of your doctor's apointments.***
target: ___ male with multiple medical problems including chronic systolic heart failure with diastolic dysfunction, atrial fibrilliation(age unknown, thought to be in last 2 ___ triple vessel CABG, ESRD ,DM, HTN and peripheral vascular disease presenting with worsening dyspnea over the last 6 weeks and with acute episode SOB on ___ which required hospitalization at ___ transferred to BID for NSTEMI cardiac catherization. . # NSTEMI- He denied any chest pain but had a prolonged history of SOB. ECG showed an old inferior infarct and seemingly new lateral ST depression. At ___ they ruled in for NSTEMI and was started on a heparin drip, plavix, lipitor, and metoprolol and serial ECGs were taken. His troponin increased from 0.23 to to 1.14 and peaked at 2.09 on ___. Echo showed left ventricular cavity enlargement with regional systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD and new changes included a smaller left ventricular cavity with more extensive regional dysfunction now involving the septum and right ventricular free wall. Cardiac catherization on ___ showed venous conduit arteriography demonstrated a SVG to OM2 that was free of angiographically significant disease. A second SVG to the R-PDA was 90% occluded in its mid segment by thrombus. There was competative flow to the anterograde limb. Furthermore arterial conduit angiography demonstrated a 60% stenosis in the mid segment of a LIMA graft to a large D1 at the site of a kink in the vessel. It was felt that his occluded PDA should be targeted and at a second caridac catherization (___) he had 2 BMS placed in his second SVG to the R-PDA. Post-procedure, he was initially managed with an IV heparin infusion and this was later changed to s/c for DVT prophylaxis. We continued Atorvastatin, Aspirin and Clopidogrel. Lipid panel showed a LDL 35 HDL 34. Commenced Metoprolol for rate control. . # Chronic systolic heart failure with diastolic dysfunction- Most probably ischemic in nature given his extensive CAD disease. 6 weeks dyspnea prior to admission was felkt likely due to exacerbation of congestive cardiac failure in the context of new AF. His most recent cath showed near equalization of diastolic pressures with o obvious signs suggestive of constrictive disease. A restrictive process is still possible, however there was no clear evidence of a pulsus paradoxus within the limits imposed by his atrial fibrillation, and overall it was felt that these findings were consistent with potential constrictive/restrictive pericardial process which could be affecting his heart function. His EF was depressed at 35-40%. There were minimal valvular abnormalities but there was evidence of pulmonary artery systolic hypertension with a dilated thoracic aorta. A CXR on ___ showed moderately severe cardiomegaly but no radiographic evidence of acute pulmonary edema following dialysis. He continued in AF and it was not deemed safe to warfarinise due to falls risk and it was felt that cardioversion would likely not be successful if attempted. He was diuresed with good urine output and Metoprolol and Lisinopril were started . His shortness of breath improved and he was discharged home. . # Atrial Fibrilliation- The patient's first documentated case is ___, his EKG before that on ___ showed normal sinus rhythm. Possible causes include thyroid disease but his TSH was normal, PE was ruled out with a negative CTA at ___ and it was felt that this was likely secondary to his left atrial enlargement. ___ score is 3 points.TSH was normal. He was started on Metoprolol for rate control. He qualified for coumadin however due to falls risk and medication compliance issues the decision was made not to start warfarin. Cardioversion was considered but it was felt that given his left and right atrial enlargement that the chances of success would be low. His AF is rate-controlled with Metoprolol. . # ESRD- ___ year history, felt likely secondary to hypertension and DM. At ___, he was was given insulin and kayexalate for hyperkalemia.At ___, we continued his dialysis regimen with a UF goal of 3.5L and this improved his cardiac failure. We continued renagel, sevelamer and ferrous sulfate. . #Possible Bacteremia- Positive blood cultures set from ___ at ___ which showed gram positive cocci in clusters and was started on Vancomycin. He remained afebrile with no signs of infections. Infectious diseases at ___ suggested 3 more doses of Vancomycin 1 gram after each hemodialysis session for next 3 times.After reviewing the records only ___ bottles grew gram positive cocci in clusters on ___ discontinued Vancomycin regimen given the absence of any clinical signs of infection.Blood cultures taken on ___ and ___, have no growth to date. These should be followed up. . #Metabolic Acidosis- According to our records, the ABG's done at ___ and the current labs in house showed a increased anion gap metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.Possible etiologies include uremia. The patient is currently recieving dialysis three times a week, with the last being on ___. Salicylate toxicity remains unlikely after speaking with the patient.We touched base with renal about dialysis regimen as it seems to have recently been inadequate, renal has been made aware of this and felt like his current regimen is adequate. They do suspect thar he has not been compliant with his medications given his short term memory issues and that this may be intefering with his fluid status. . # Type 2 Diabetes- Adjusted Insulin SC with 16 units lantus at ___. . # Potential Dementia/ Depression- has exhibited more short term memory loss according to his family since his wife died 6 months ago. This appears to be a more chronic progressive dementia taht has now been picked up in the context of his wife's death and him not being able to hide his symptoms. During this admission he has exhibited mild confusion at times at night, when he forgets why he is in the hospital but will still remain oriented to time and place in these episodes. Continued home dose Fluoxetine. Lorazepam PRN was given for anxiety. Mini Mental on ___ was ___ with significant impairment in short-term memory. . #Hypertension Held BP meds amlodipine, Imdur, clonidine. Given systolic blood pressures in 90'-120, BP currently being well controlled with metoprolol and lisinopril.

Study is mildly degraded by motion. 2. No acute intracranial abnormality. 3. Atrophy and extensive probable small vessel ischemic changes as described. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of left leg numbness and weakness resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: Diabetes High blood pressure High cholesterol We are not changing your medications. Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician as listed below. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - sudden partial or complete loss of vision - sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - sudden weakness of one side of the body - sudden drooping of one side of the face - sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body It was a pleasure meeting you! Your ___ Neurology Team AHA/ASA Core Measures for Ischemic Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack 1. Dysphagia screening before any PO intake? () Yes [performed and documented by admitting resident]  (x) No 2. DVT Prophylaxis administered by the end of hospital day 2? (x) Yes - () No 3. Smoking cessation counseling given? () Yes - (x) No [if no, reason: (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 7. Stroke education given (written form in the discharge worksheet)? (x) Yes - () No (stroke education = personal modifiable risk factors, how to activate EMS for stroke, stroke warning signs and symptoms, prescribed medications, need for followup) 8. Assessment for rehabilitation or rehab services considered? (x) Yes - () No [if no, reason not assessed: ____ ] 9. Discharged on statin therapy? (x) Yes - () No [if LDL >= 100 or on a statin prior to hospitalization, reason not discharged on statin: ____ ] 10. Discharged on antithrombotic therapy? (x) Yes [Type: aspirin Antiplatelet - () Anticoagulation] - () No 11. Discharged on oral anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter? () Yes - () No [if no, reason not discharge on anticoagulation: ____ ] - (x) N/A
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with DM2, HTN, CHF, MI s/p CABG, HLD, and CKD who presented with acute onset L lower extremity numbness and weakness and persistent nausea. Given acute onset of symptoms, she was admitted for stroke workup. ED COURSE: In the ED, a code stroke was called. NIHSS 1 for L sided sensory loss to pin prick. tPA was not administered given minimal symptoms and that she was >3 hours from last known normal state. Vital signs were stable. Her exam was notable for decreased strength (4+/5) of the left interphalangeal, hamstring, and tibialis anterior muscles. She had decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch on her LLE. A non-contrast head CT showed no intracranial abnormalities. She had a normal ECG, chest X-ray, and an MRI which showed no acute intracranial abnormalities. Her lab work was significant for CBC WNL, chem 7 WNL with her BUN/creatinine (40/2.1) at baseline. Nml coags, LFTs, lipids, serum tox. HbA1c was 8.1, TSH was 1.3, LDL 45. She was transferred to the floor for further work-up and monitoring. HOSPITAL COURSE: Her exam on the floor was notable for new left-sided dysmetria on finger-to-nose test as well as mild left-sided weakness and sensory deficits, which improved by hospital day 3. Our impression that her presentation was due to an MRI-negative lacunar stroke resulting in ataxic hemiparesis. Her echocardiogram was unremarkable. Her hospital course was complicated by hyperglycemia; her insulin regimen was adjusted after the ___ was consulted, and her fingersticks improved. On hospital day 3, Ms. ___ had an isolated fever to 101.6, and her WBC count rose to 13.4 from 9.0. UA was negative for nitrites, WBC 1, but showed 100 protein and glucose. Urine and blood cultures were drawn. A repeat chest X-ray was negative. Her temperature then fell to normal range the rest of her hospital course, and her WBC count the next day fell to 8.2. Also, on hospital day 3, her creatinine rose from 2.2--> 3.3 and BUN from 46-->77-->82. This was thought to be prerenal ___ due to decreased PO intake due to nausea in the setting of hyperglycemia. Her PO intake improved as her nausea subsided, her urine output improved, and her creatinine and BUN were downtrending on discharge. The patient was seen by ___, who felt that she would be stable for home discharge within ___ ___ visits in hospital, with home ___ and ___ services. Transitional issues: 1. She has had longstanding orthostatic hypotension, which we have documented here. 2. Follow-up creatinine ___ on CKD, improving) 3. Follow-up of incidental findings: 1.5 mm right cavernous carotid aneurysm versus atherosclerotic irregularity versus infundibulum, 1.5 mm left supra clinoid internal carotid artery aneurysm versus infundibulum 4. Diabetes management; HbA1c was 8.1

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Codeine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o M CAD (s/p CABG (___) and RCA PCI w/ BMS ___, HLD, HTN, s/p Aortic Aneurysm repair (___) and COPD, presents with chest pain that began at 6AM today. He had just finished walking up the stairs before it happened. He described the pain as a pressure, located on the left side of his chest, with radiation to left shoulder but not to jaw or back. No increased SOB. Pain not exacerbated by movement or inspiration. No nausea/vomitting/abdominal pain. No diaphoresis. Relieved after given morphine in ED. Refuses to take Nitroglycerin because it gives him a headache. Patient took all of his medications today including aspirin. Received Plavix in ED. . Importantly, the patient was recently hospitalized (discharge ___ from ___ for crushing chest pain. Initally he did not have ECG changes, but one day after admission had significant ST changes, however, cardiac enzymes were negative and continued to be negative 24 hours after ECG changes occurred. The patient was diagnosed with a COPD exacerbation and discharged on a prednisone taper and antibiotics. He had sats as low as 70% with walking during his admission and does not use his oxygen during the day, which he often requires. . At baseline patient walks 2 blocks or ___ flight of stairs before becoming short of breath. He has been having angina ___ times/day over the past few weeks, occurring with no particular pattern - at times when he sleeps and other times when walking. Mild increased shortness of breath with the hot weather recently. The pain he experienced today was more of a "pressure" and different than his baseline anginal pain in that it radiated to his left shoulder. Upon admission on floor, patient was chest pain free. . On review of systems, he has significant back pain s/p lower back surgery and treated with chronic opiates. He has +cough. He has bilateral calf pain when walking, relieved by rest. He denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias. No hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CAD s/p MI and CABG (___) with patent LIMA to the LAD, RIMA to the RCA, PCI in ___ with BMS in the RCA just distal to his RIMA touchdown, status post MI ___ years ago. Repeat PCI in ___ showed widely patent LIMA and RIMA grafts; patent distal RCA stent and known occluded native LAD and RCA. ___ stress test showed no anginal symptoms or ischemic ST segment changes. -chronic small vessel angina -Alcohol abuse -Tobacco abuse -Hypercholesterolemia -Hypertension -COPD on 2L home O2 overnight -History of head trauma in ___ from MVA with post-traumatic grand mal seizure was on Dilantin, last seizure four to ___ years ago -aortic anuerysm s/p repair ___ -neurogenic claudication <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> positive for early CAD Mother - died of MI at ___. Father - died at ___ of "MI and cancer." Cousin with MI at ___, died of MI at ___. Sister with borderline diabetes. Brother died of throat cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS - 97.4 158/68 78 20 95% RA Gen: NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Neck: Supple with flat JVP. CV: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. Chest: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Breath sounds distant and decreased I/E ratio, occasional wheezes, no crackles. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers. Large scar inner right thigh - occured during past MVA. . Pulses: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> LABS UPON ADMISSION: . ___ 11: 54AM BLOOD WBC-7.9 RBC-5.20 Hgb-13.0* Hct-39.0* MCV-75* MCH-24.9* MCHC-33.2 RDW-14.8 Plt ___ ___ 11: 54AM BLOOD Neuts-76.0* Lymphs-17.3* Monos-4.1 Eos-1.8 Baso-0.8 ___ 11: 54AM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.2 ___ ___ 11: 54AM BLOOD Glucose-96 UreaN-10 Creat-0.5 Na-136 K-4.3 Cl-98 HCO3-27 AnGap-15 ___ 08: 50AM BLOOD Calcium-9.6 Phos-4.3 Mg-2.0 . CARDIAC ENZYMES: . ___ 05: 50PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-55 ___ 02: 20AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-41* ___ 08: 50AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-41* ___ 11: 54AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.01 ___ 05: 50PM BLOOD CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 02: 20AM BLOOD CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 08: 50AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.01 . LABS UPON DISCHARGE: . ___ 06: 45AM BLOOD WBC-6.9 RBC-4.58* Hgb-11.6* Hct-34.5* MCV-75* MCH-25.3* MCHC-33.5 RDW-14.4 Plt ___ ___ 06: 45AM BLOOD Glucose-87 UreaN-12 Creat-0.6 Na-134 K-4.9 Cl-97 HCO3-29 AnGap-13 ___ 06: 45AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5 Phos-3.5 Mg-1.8 . EKG: ___ Sinus rhythm. Anteroseptal myocardial infarction of undetermined age. Non-specific lateral T wave inversions. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ the rate has increased. The biphasic precordial T waves are no longer seen. . CXR: ___: Single AP upright portable view of the chest was obtained. The lungs are clear without focal consolidation. No large pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. The patient is status post median sternotomy. Surgical clips are again noted projecting over the right infraclavicular region. The aorta remains calcified and tortuous. The mediastinal and cardiac silhouettes are stable in this patient with known history of descending thoracic aortic aneurysm. . CARDIAC STRESS TEST: ___: This ___ year old male with PMH of CAD s/p CABG ___, PCI ___. Asymptomatic at time of testing. The patient was given 0.142mg/kg/min of Dipyridamole over 4 minutes. The patient reported no anginal symptoms during the infusion or in recovery. There were no ST segment changes throughout the study. They rhythm was sinus with poor R wave progression and 1 vpb late in recovery. Dipyridamole was reversed with 125mg Aminophylline IV. Appropriate hemodynamic response; of note pt had blunted heart rate response as he is beta blocked. Of note, patient had low resting blood pressure of 110/50 to begin study, as low as 95/42 during infusion. Following the study patient had a brief syncopal episode without ECG changes noted. Pt fell on to his right arm with no complaints or apparent injuries after fall. Pt recovered quickly repeat blood pressure 110/50. Pt had no neurologic deficits following incident. . The fixed apical defect, however, is stable from prior study. 2. Unchanced apical hypokinesis. 3. It is important you continue to take all of your medications as perscribed in order to prevent a future heart attack. We also advise you to wear your oxygen at home when needed and stop smoking. Please weigh yourself every morning and call your doctor if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs for 3 consecutive days. We made NO changes to your medications. Please follow up with your physicians. target: ___ is a ___ year old man with coronary artery disease, history of CABG (patent LIMA and RIMA grafts and patent distal RCA stent), hypertension, hyperlipidemia, COPD with extensive smoking history and recent exacerbation, perhipheral vascular disease, who presented with chest pain. Three sets of cardiac enzymes were negative and the patient did not have any new ECG changes suggestive of acute myocardial ischemia. The patient is known to have small vessel coronary artery disease and refractory angina at baseline. This presentation was thought to be similar to his baseline angina. The patient refused to take nitroglycerin for chest pain as it causes headaches. He also refused to wear oxygen and refused inhaled steroids and tiotropium nebulizer treatments during his hospital stay. . The patient had a nuclear stress test which showed no anginal type symptoms or ischemic ECG changes during exercise. The perfusion study showed a small reversible perfusion abnormality involving the distal anterior wall at the margin of the prior moderate to severe fixed apical defect. His fixed apical defect was stable. . However, following completion of the study, the patient syncopized transiently most likely due to orthostatic hypotension. He had a low resting blood pressure of 110/50 when the study began, and as low as 95/42 during infusion. The patient fell on to his right arm with no complaints or apparent injuries after fall. He recovered quickly repeat blood pressure 110/50. He had no neurologic deficits following incident. . It was decided by Dr. ___ the team that the patient did not have any intervenable disease from his images on previous cardiac angiography. His aspirin, statin, lisinopril and Toprol XL was continued. . His other medical problems including COPD, chronic low back pain, and peripheral vascular disease were medically managed. . He was full code for this admission.

The native coronary circulation was not engaged due to known proximal occlusion and need to conserve contrast use in light of severe renal insufficiency. 2. The arterial conduit (LIMA) was not engaged as it is known to be atretic per recent cath. 3. Selective coronary angiography of the 4 vein grafts revealed occlude RSVG-dRCA and RSVG-OM1. The RSVG-D1 and the RSVG-OM2 were patent. The RSVG-OM2 had moderate disease throughout similar to the findings of the cardiac catheterization from ___. 4. Limited resting hemodynamic assessment revealed normal systemic arterial pressure (127/65 mmHg) and borderline elevated pulmonary arterial pressure ___ mmHg). The left- and right-sided filling pressures were normal (mean PCWP 9 mmHg and RVEDP 8 mmHg). The cardiac output and cardiac index were normal at 5.7 l/min and 3.5 l/min/m2 respectively. 5. Left ventriculography was deferred due to renal insufficiency. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Known severe obstructive three vessel coronary artery disease. The native coronary arteries were not engaged. 2. Ocluded RSVG-OM1 and RSVG-RCA. 3. Patent RSVG-OM2 and RSVG-D1. 4. The LIMA was not engaged as it is known to be atretic. 5. Normal left and right ventricular filling pressures. 6. Left ventriculography was deferred. . RENAL U.S. ___ 2: 45 ___ FINDINGS: The right kidney measures 9.5 cm. Normal color vascularity is seen throughout the right kidney. The left kidney measures 7.9 cm. A simple cyst measuring 1.6 x 0.8 cm is seen in the interpolar region of the left kidney. Normal color vascularity is seen throughout the left kidney. In the main renal artery, peak systolic velocity is 40 cm/sec with sharp systolic upstroke. Normal waveforms are visualized in the left renal vein. IMPRESSION: 1. Normal waveform in the left renal artery. In comparison with the examination of ___, the left renal artery is better visualized but probably not significantly changed. 2. Left renal cyst. . Mediastinal surgical clips are again noted. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is unchanged. There is no pneumothorax, consolidation, or pleural effusion. The pulmonary vasculature is normal. The osseous structures are unchanged. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. . Carotid U/S ___: pending as of this discharge summary. .
