input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> v fib cardiac arrest <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Left heart catheterization Drug eluting stent to left anterior descending artery <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ man with a history of coronary artery disease (s/p stenting LCx ___, on ASA and Plavix), presenting after collapsing during the ___. . Mr. ___ stopped smoking in ___, as ___ resolution, and started running shortly thereafter. He ate poorly, but became good at running. He started running with his son in ___. In ___ he had some exertional chest pain which led to nuclear stress test and catheterization, with placement of a bare metal stent in left circumflex. Since that time he had been free of symptoms, with his most recent stress test in ___ this year not revealing any concerning ischemia, per the patient. He had received this care in ___, where he lives with his wife. He most recently completed a marathon two months ago without chest pain. . Mr. ___ was running the ___ Marathon today, with his son, without having taken his ASA and Plavix for the last two days. His doctor had previously told him to hold these for two days prior to racing to reduce bruising. He got to mile 25 before witnessed callapse, earlier increasing shortness of breath and fatigue, followed by loss of consciousness. Bystander provided CPR until AED arrived. No strips, but AED determined shockable rhythm, likely VF. Sinus rhythm was re-established after two shocks and he was brought to ___ and directly into the cath lab. En route he received 100 mg lidocaine. In the ED he was noted to have ST elevation in V3 with biphasic t-waves. ST depression was also commented upon there. Code STEMI was called. He received Integrillin, IVFs (~ 2L), ASA 325 mg, Plavix (loaded with 600 mg), vitals were 151/87, HR 86, RR 23, 97% NC. Cardiology was consulted and recommended direct transfer to the cath. lab. On coronary agiography, LCx stent was appreciated and open, LAD disease was noted ~ 90%. Unlikely STEMI, infact unlikely ACS, but Dr. ___ describes as likely angina/ischemia with consequent VF and arrest. Possible that ischemic changes on EKG are secondary to demand and shocks. A long stent drug-eluting stent was placed in the LAD. He received 20 mg IV Lasix. EKG had partly normalized after cath. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for (+) shortness of breath, fatigue and notable for the absence of (-) chest pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Dyslipidemia, Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: Former cath. and stent. (LCx) (___) -CABG: None. -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: Once, ___. -PACING/ICD: No. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of early MI, but heart disease in many relatives, typically noted in ___. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: T = 98.7, HR = 74, BP = 129/75, RR = 15, O2Sat = 97 RA GENERAL: In NAD. Tanned slim man. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP visible while lying flat, s/p cath. CARDIAC: RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Some crackles upon initial deep breaths anteriorly, only ausculatated anteriorly and laterally. No wheezes or rhonchi given these limtis. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. NEUROPSYCHIATRIC: Alert. Oriented to person, place (time not asked), context. Mood, affect appropriate. Jocular and more dissappointed about not finishing race that myocardial ischemia. Very pleasant and cooperative. CN II grossly intact, EOM WNLs, ___, speech normal - no errors, dysphonia, aphasia. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> labs on admission: CBC ___ 02: 05PM BLOOD WBC-13.3* RBC-3.89* Hgb-12.2* Hct-36.2* MCV-93 MCH-31.2 MCHC-33.6 RDW-13.6 Plt ___ Coags ___ 02: 05PM BLOOD ___ PTT-21.6* ___ Chem 7 ___ 02: 05PM BLOOD UreaN-16 Creat-1.5* ___ 07: 42PM BLOOD Glucose-100 UreaN-15 Creat-1.1 Na-135 K-4.0 Cl-98 HCO3-26 AnGap-15 Cardiac biomarkers ___ 02: 05PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-391* ___ 02: 05PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.05* ___ 07: 42PM BLOOD CK-MB-41* MB Indx-4.1 cTropnT-0.44* ___ 04: 47AM BLOOD CK-MB-45* MB Indx-3.3 cTropnT-0.64* ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD CK-MB-29* MB Indx-2.2 cTropnT-0.37* Other labs ___ 07: 42PM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-4.0 Mg-2.1 ___ 04: 47AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.6 eAG-114 ___ 04: 47AM BLOOD Triglyc-25 HDL-79 CHOL/HD-2.3 LDLcalc-98 ___ 02: 07PM BLOOD Glucose-126* Lactate-8.1* Na-140 K-4.6 Cl-103 calHCO3-18* ___ 05: 13PM BLOOD Lactate-2.6* Labs on discharge: CBC ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD WBC-6.3 RBC-3.65* Hgb-11.1* Hct-32.5* MCV-89 MCH-30.3 MCHC-34.0 RDW-13.5 Plt ___ ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD Plt ___ Chem 7 ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-13 Creat-0.9 Na-140 K-4.2 Cl-104 HCO3-27 AnGap-13 LFTs ___ 04: 27PM BLOOD ALT-386* AST-264* LD(LDH)-346* CK(CPK)-1326* AlkPhos-63 TotBili-0.6 Other chem ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.9 Cardiac cath ___: COMMENTS: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated two vessel disease. The LMCA was without angiographically apparent disease. The LAD had a long diffusely disease mid vessel 90% stenosis. The LCx had a widely patent stent. The RCA had an 80% stenosis of a small PL branch. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed elevated right and left heart filling pressures with RVEDP 18 mmHg and PCWP 24 mmHg. There was mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension with PASP 38 mmHg. The cardiac index was preserved at 2.7 L/min/m2. The systemic and pulmonary vascular resistances were normal. There was systemic arterial normotension. 3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid LAD with a 3.0 x 33mm Cypher drug eluting stent which was postdilated to 3.0mm. Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection, and TIMI 3 flow. (see ___ comments for details) FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Status post VT/VF cardiac arrest, STEMI. 3. Elevated ventricular filling pressures. 4. Mild pulmonary arterial hypertension. 5. Successful PTCA and stenting of the mid LAD. Echo ___: The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal hypokinesis of the mid to distal anterior wall, anterior septum, and apex. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 40-45 %). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired relaxation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is a very small pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild regional left ventricular hypokinesis c/w mid LAD disease. Mild aortic regurgitation. Impaired left ventricular relaxation. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> ASA: stopped on advice of cardiologist Plavix: stopped on advice of cardiologist <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills: *2* 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *11* 3. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 5. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> 1) Cardiac arrest 2) Ventricular fibrillation 3) Ischemic cardiomyopathy 4) Coronary artery disease 5) ST elevation myocardial infarction <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure to take care of you here at ___. You were admitted for cardiac arrest, or failure of your heart to beat. You were rescued with CPR and shocked, which restored your heart rhythm and saved your life. You were then brought to the ___ for further management, where you went to the cardiac catheterization laboratory. In the lab they found that the left anterior descending or LAD artery was 90% blocked. A long drug eluting stent was placed to keep the artery open. You underwent an echocardiogram which showed mild to moderate reduction of your heart function. This may be temporary or permanent, it will become clear once you repeat an echocardiogram or ultrasound in your heart in about a month. We also obtained a cardiac MRI to be sure that there was no other cause of the cardiac arrest other than the 90% blocked LAD artery, which was confirmed to be correct according to the MRI. Now that this blockage was corrected, your chances of another cardiac arrest will be very low. . Medication changes: 1. You will need to take a full dose aspirin and Plavix every day for at least one year and possibly longer. Do not stop taking Plavix or Aspirin or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ ___ says that it is OK. You risk having heart attack if you stop these medicines. 2. Start Atorvastatin (Lipitor) to lower your cholesterol and help your heart recover. 3. Start Metoprolol daily to lower your heart rate and help your heart recover 4. Start Lisinopril daily to lower your blood pressure and help your heart recover.
target: # Coronary Artery Disease/v fib arrest: The patient had previous diagnosis of coronary artery disease with a stent placed to the left circumflex in ___. Rhythm strips obtained from the AED in the field after his fall showed ventricular fibrillation prior to shocking the patient back into normal sinus rhythm. He was brought to ___ where he underwent cardiac catheterization. This revealed two vessel disease with long diffuse disease in the mid LAD with 90% stenosis and 80% stenosis of a small PL branch from the RCA. The LMCA did not have disease and the left circumflex stent was widely patent. The patient received a 3.0 x 33mm Cypher drug eluting stent to the LAD without complications. It was thought that the cause of his ventricular fibrilation was due to ischemia in the LAD distribution from increased demand during the marathon. He had an echo which showed mild regional left ventricular hypokinesis consistent with mid LAD disease and impaired left ventricular relaxation. His EF was 40-45%. Previous records were obtained which showed in ___ the patient had an LVEF of 60% on echo and no perfusion defects on nuclear ETT, indicating an interval insult to the LAD, which most likely was from an ischemic event during the marathon. The patient had a cardiac MRI to rule out any other areas of cardiac abnormalities that may have contributed to the arrhythmia. The final report is pending, but the preliminary report showed subendocardial gadolinium uptake in the LAD territory which was likely from his recent ischemic event. There were no other abnormalities. Therefore it was decided that an ICD for secondary prevention was not indicated in this patient. He was started on aspirin 325 mg, plavix 75mg, and atorvastain 80 mg, as well as metoprolol 12.5 mg TID. He tolerated this well and was discharged on metoprolol succinate 50 mg Q day. He was also started on lisinopril 5 mg for the decreased ejection fraction and anterior MI. He should continue on this medication and have his electrolytes checked in one week. He was instructed to decrease his physical activity, mainly his running, over the next month and undergo an exercise stress test at that time before resuming more vigorous running. He will see his cardiologist in ___ in 1 - 2 weeks when he returns home. He should remain on his plavix for at least ___ year and his aspirin indefinitely. # coping: The patient exprtessed disappointment in not finishing the race and dealing with his diagnosis of myocardial infarction. He was visited by social work to provide support. # Hypercholesterolemia Total cholesterol was previously noted to be 194, per the patient, but he was not taking a statin. Labs show presently his LDL is 98 and t cholesterol is 182. He was discharged on 80 mg atorvastatin a day. # Renal Failure: The patient initially presented with a creatinine of 1.5. This was thought to be pre-renal from his marathon. His creatinine was trended and was 0.9 the day of discharge. # Leukocytosis: The patient initially presented with a white count of 13.3. This resolved over the next to days and was likley from the stress of the marathon and cardiac arest. His white count was 6.3 at discharge. # Mental Status: The patient's family noted some subtle changes in his short-term memory. Over time this seemed to have improved. The patient denied any defecits in memory.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Sulfonamides / Iodine; Iodine Containing / Ticlid <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization without stenting on ___. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo M with history of CAD s/p MI in ___ with multiple stents placed previously (see below for details), severe mixed dyslipidemia, Hepatitis C, h/o complicated epistaxis on ASA/Plavix, and other medical issues presents today with dull chest pain that has been persistent. Patient reports that he has been having CP associated with exertion over the last 6 months, usually when he walks uphill or stairs. It resolves upon rest at times and sometimes with more gradual increase of activities. The chest pain usually lasts about 3 minutes. He had a nuclear stress test done in ___ during which he did 9 mins of ___, with ___ METS (excellent) and was found to have reversible flow in OM1 region. He deferred cath at the time and it was decided he would have medical management. However, on ___, 2 days prior to admission, patient was out camping. He woke up with a mild dull sub-sternal chest pain, about ___, non-radiating. He denies any SOB, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, and diaphoresis. He initially attributed it to sleeping on damp ground overnight. However, this persisted. He went to ___ in ___ where an AMI work up was done and lab studies (troponin, EKG) were negative, per patient. On the day of admission, he called Dr. ___ the persistent CP which he thinks is similar to his acute heart attack in the past, and he was referred to come into the ED. In the ED, VS T 99.0, HR 59, BP 137/83, RR 16, O2Sat 98%. He received 325 mg ASA, 1x 0.4 mg SL NTG, 1x Tylenol, and was started on heparin gtt. EKG was noted to be unchanged from prior. Troponin was neg 1x in the ED. His CP was slightly over the right upper sternal border, improved with SL NTG to pain ___. HR was as low as in the ___. He was asymptomatic otherwise. Upon arriving the floor, patient reports a ___ chest dullness slightly over the right upper sternal border, radiating to the mid-upper back, not sharp. He admits that he takes ___ of the 325 mg aspirin daily and ___ to ___ of the 75 mg plavix given his history of epistaxis that once took 2 weeks to resolve. He also stopped his pravastatin about 5 days ago due to leg cramps. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - CAD s/p MI in ___, s/p ___ LAD stent in ___, s/p RCA stents x4 in ___ and ___, s/p POBA to RCA lesion between the previous 2 stents c/b embolism to PDA on ___, then repeat cath in ___ with PTCA and DES to distal RCA between 2 previously placed stents - Hepatitis C - h/o complicated epistaxis while on ASA and Plavix, requiring ___ embolization and repeated packings by ENT. Per notes, it appears he intermittently does not take his ASA/Plavix at full doses due to fear of bleeding. Followed by Plastic Surgery ___ for intranasal stenosis - h/o anxiety and panic attacks, not on med - h/o ruptured urethra, s/p surgical repair ~ ___ years ago - h/o BCC - s/p bilateral hernia repairs - s/p tonsillectomy - ? herpes zoster, which patient denies - HSV, per patient <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> - His father died at ___ of heart failure, s/p several MIs. - His mother passed away from ALS <PHYSICAL EXAM> Physical exam upon discharge: VS: T97 (98), BP 118/72 (112-140/63-78), 55 (50-58), 18 (___), 96% (92-99%) RA, I/O ___+ General: A&Ox3, NAD HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Mucous membrane moist. Neck: Supple. JVP at the level of the clavicles. CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. Difficult to hear heart sound, best at apex. Regular rate. No murmur, rub, or gallop appreciated. Respiratory: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. BS present. + scar from biopsy of BCC above the umbilicus. Ext: No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. DP and ___ 2+ bilaterally. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ - BMP: GLUCOSE-118* UREA N-17 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-138 POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-104 TOTAL CO2-25 ANION GAP-13 - CBC with diff: WBC-8.9 RBC-5.34 HGB-16.6 HCT-47.8 PLT COUNT-213 MCV-90 MCH-31.1 MCHC-34.8 RDW-15.0 NEUTS-59.0 ___ MONOS-3.8 EOS-1.6 BASOS-0.3 - Cardiac enzyme @ 1: 15PM: cTropnT-<0.01 - Cardiac enzymes @ 9: 29PM: CK(CPK)-67 CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01 - Coagulation: ___ PTT-27.6 ___ ___ - Cardiac enzyme @ 6: 55AM: CK(CPK)-54 CK-MB-2, cTropnT-<0.01 - LFT: ALT-45* AST-40 AlkPhos-58 TotBili-0.5 Albumin-4.4 - Lipid Panl: total cholesterol 175, triglyceride 163, HDL 40, LDL 102 - HgbA1C: 6.2%* Images & Procedures: ___ Cardiac catheterization: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system revealed 3 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA showed a 25% ostial lesion. The LAD had a proximal Bard stent with 25% tubular in stent restensosis; mild disease mid LAD 35% at D4; distal LAD is somewhat small in caliber with slow flow consistent with microvascular; high D1 (arising before Bard stent) with mild diffuse disease. The LCx had focal heavy calcification; ostial 20%; AV groove Cx absent after atrial branches and modest caliber OM1. The RCA showed proximal 20%; patent stent proximal-mid RCA with 30% distal edge stenosis; mild in-stent restenosis distal RCA; 50% slightly hazy difficult to visualize stenosis in the distal RCA spanning the origin of the twin RPDA and extending just beyond into the distal AV groove RCA; more rightward RPDA is smaller than the ___ larger RDPA; the ___ RPDA is diffusely diseased to 35%; mild diffuse in-stent restenosis in distal AV groove RCA leading to large RPL2, with jailed very distal AV groove RCA supplying small RPL3 and modest long RPL4; AM1 mid 50%; RPL2 50%. We decided to do FFR for RCA stenosis. Change for ___ F guide catheter. Heparin given. Therapeutic ACT confirmed. Rx Radi pressure wire equalized at 10 atm Hg abd delivered after some effort into RPL2. baseline Pd/Pa 0.94 with 6 mm hg gradient with the guiding catheter disengaged from RCA. With the maximal hyperemia induced by IV adenosine, the FFR was 0.71. Upon pullback of the transducer into the distal RCA before the RPDA, the FFR was 0.93. Upon pullback of the transducer into the guiding catheter, FFR was 1.00. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Moderate single vessel coronary artery disease with mild diffuse in stent restenosis. 2. Normal LV disastolic function. 3. Positive pressure wire of the complex stenosis in the ___ RCA spanning the origins of both RPDAs. 4. Findings discussed with Dr. ___. Current presneting symptoms atypical for angina (biomarkers negative for necrosis), and the distal RCA lesion should not cause rest pain. Distal RCA trifurcation lesion is complex. PCI would require jailing of a significant and diffusely disease RPDA2. DES would be preferable but patient has problems with significant epistaxis while of dual antiplatelet therapy. Would therefore ___ medical management as benefits of PCI do not clearly outweigh the risks. 5. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against CAD. Consider addition of amlodipine 2.5 mg as third antianginal agent, along with the use of prophylactic TNG (patient reports of headaches with nitrates) prior to activities that provoke angina. 6. F/U with Dr. ___. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> - Metoprolol 25 mg p.o. b.i.d. - pravastatin 20 mg p.o. daily, which patient stopped ~ 5 days ago - ___ of 325 mg ASA po daily - ___ to ___ of 75 mg plavix daily - multivitamin - nitroglycerin SL, prn, although patient has never taken on his own <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Rosuvastatin 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 2. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day): Please hold if systolic blood pressure < 100 or if heart rate < 50. 3. Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Tablet, Sublingual Sublingual PRN (as needed) as needed for chest pain: Place 1 pill under the tongue for chest pain. ___ repeat after 5 minutes if pain not relieved, for a total of 3 pills. Contact your doctor or call ___ if not relieved after 3 pill.s. 4. Multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 5. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. Lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): Please hold if systolic blood pressure is < 100. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnosis: - Unstable Angina Secondary diagnosis: - Severe mixed dyslipidemia - Hypertension - History of epistaxis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain. You underwent cardiac catheterization on ___, during which no additional intervention was performed due to the anatomy of your right coronary artery. Therefore, your coronary artery disease was managed medically with some medication changes. Please note the following changes to your medication: - Please START rosuvastatin (Crestor) 10 mg, 1 tab, by mouth, once at bed time. - Please START lisinopril 10 mg, 1 tab, by mouth, once daily. - Please DECREASE aspirin to 81 mg, 1 tab, by mouth, once daily. - You can STOP taking plavix 75 mg, 1 tab, by mouth, once daily. Please follow up with your primary care physician and your cardiologist.
target: He was admitted on ___ for persistent chest pain and discharged on ___. 1. Unstable Angina, secondary to coronary artery disease. Given the change in his chest pain from exertional to rest chest pain a few days prior to admission and his significant coronary artery disease, patient underwent cardiac catheterization. However, due to his RCA anatomy, no additional stent was placed. Amlodipine was considered but it was thought that his HR was already borderline low and lisinopril was just added during this hospitalization. This could be reconsidered later. Plavix was held during hospitalization given his significant history of epistaxis and reluctance. However, the medical team had a discussion with patient regarding the benefit and risk of being on Plavix. He understands and prefers to take the lower dosage as he had been prior to admission. It is advised that he discuss with his cardiologist regarding the use of Plavix. His unstable angina and coronary disease was optimized medically with metoprolol, lisinopril, rosuvastatin (given myalgia from pravastatin), aspirin (as agreed by patient), and prn SL nitroglycerin prior to discharge. He will need to follow up with his primary care physician and cardiologist. 2. Severe mixed dyslipidemia. This has been a chronic issue for him per outpatient record. He had been on pravastatin but self-discontinued for myalgia few days prior to admission, despite normal CK. His goal LDL should be < 70 given his coronary artery disease, and he is still not at goal. A discussion was carried out with patient regarding rosuvastatin, its potency, and potentially less myalgic profile with the lipophilic property. He agreed with the plan. This should be followed up by his primary care physician and cardiologist. 3. Hypertension. Patient had mildly elevated SBP in the 140s during this admission. 10 mg of lisinopril was initiated for better blood pressure in additional to metoprolol. Metoprolol was not up-titrated given mild sinus bradycardia on home dose. Amiodarone can be considered for the future if BP uncontrolled with ACE inhibitor and if angina continues to be an persistent issue. 4. History of Epistaxis. Non-active during this hospital course.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is ___ male with a history of coronary artery disease (three vessel branch disease, RCA stent) who presents from home with chest pain. He was in his normal state of health until the evening of ___ when he developed sub-sternal chest pain at rest. He describes it as located in the ___ his chest, radiating to the back, having a compression like quality. It was not associated with nausea, vomitting, shortness of breath, or diaphoresis. He took SLNG without effect. He describes the pain as similar to his previous MI but worse. . He has coronary artery disease going back to ___ when he presented with an inferior MI and catheterization revealed 80% OM1, 90% OM2 and 99% OM3 with mild RCA disease. He was well until ___ when he developed recurrent angina. Cardiac catheterization on ___ revealed diffuse severe disease of the three OM vessels and a 95% mid RCA stenosis, which was treated with a total of three PS1530 and one 3.0 x 25mm ACS ML proximally. Then in ___ he developed recurrent exertional angina and underwent angiography, which revealed diffuse disease of the OM1, OM2 and a 99% stenosis of OM3, D1 with 90% proximal stenosis and the RCA had 90% in-stent restenotic lesion in the distal PS stent, with successful rotational atherectomy of the RCA. Since that time he has been relatively free of chest pain, has RX of SLNG but has not used in some time. . In the ED, initial vitals were 80 150/70 16 100%. On exam, brown guiaic positive. EKG with ST depressions I/AVL, V3-6 that improved following NTG gtt. CTA chest negative for aortic dissection or PE. He was started on heparin and nitro gtt. He was given zofran for nausea. He continued to have chest pain despite multiple doses of morphine and dilaudid. Cardiology evaluated, after increasing nitro gtt to max rate allowed on floor, currently pain free. Access 2 18G. Vitals on transfer 109/52 57 16 92%2L sleeping. . On the floor, the patient vomitted, EKG unchanged. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> # CAD -- s/p multiple PCI -- (___) s/p inferior MI no intervention -- (___) mid and distal RCA stenting with three PS1530 -- (___) Diag and multiple OM branch disease on cath -- (___) rotational atherectomy of RCA after exertional angina # Diabetes # Dyslipidemia # Hypertension # Glaucoma <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> # Brother: MI in his mid ___ # Sister: hypertension Physical ___: Physical Exam On Admission: VS: T 97.3, BP 107/53, HR 61, RR 20, SpO2 99% on 2L, Wt 82.2 kg Gen: NAD. Alert and oriented x3. Mood and affect appropriate. Pleasant and cooperative. Resting in bed. HEENT: NCAT. PERRL, EOMI, anicteric sclera. MMM, OP benign. Neck: Supple. JVP at clavicle while lying at 45 degrees. No carotid bruits noted. No cervical lymphadenopathy. CV: RRR. Normal S1, S2. Soft systolic murmur at RUSB without radiation. No rubs or gallops appreciated. Chest: Respiration unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Lungs CTAB. No wheezes, rhonchi, or rales. Abd: BS present. Soft, obese, NT, ND. No HSM detected. HEENT: NCAT. PERRL, EOMI, anicteric sclera. MMM, OP benign. Neck: Supple. JVP not elevated. No cervical lymphadenopathy. CV: RRR. Normal S1, S2. Soft systolic murmur at RUSB without radiation. Ext: WWP, no cyanosis or clubbing. No significant ___ edema, resolved from admission. Digital cap refill <2 sec. Distal pulses radial 2+, DP 2+, ___ 2+. Skin: No rashes, ecchymoses, or other lesions noted. Neuro: CN II-XII grossly intact. Moving all four limbs. <PERTINENT RESULTS> LABS ON ADMISSION: ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-3.42*# Hgb-10.8*# Hct-32.7* MCV-96 MCH-31.7 MCHC-33.1 RDW-14.5 Plt ___ ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Neuts-81.9* Lymphs-13.1* Monos-3.6 Eos-0.8 Baso-0.5 ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD ___ PTT-21.6* ___ ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Glucose-339* UreaN-37* Creat-1.5* Na-133 K-5.7* Cl-100 HCO3-20* AnGap-19 ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Calcium-9.8 Phos-3.6 Mg-1.7 ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD ALT-29 AST-48* AlkPhos-40 TotBili-0.4 Albumin-4.6 ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Lipase-34 . CARDIAC BIOMARKERS: ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-113 CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 03: 43AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-378* CK-MB-45* cTropnT-0.37* ___ 10: 40AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-850* CK-MB-101* cTropnT-1.14* ___ 06: 45AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-653* CK-MB-42* cTropnT-1.73* ___ 03: 30PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-449* CK-MB-23* cTropnT-1.49* ___ 07: 20AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-239 CK-MB-9 cTropnT-1.76* . OTHER RELEVANT LABS: ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Cholest-125 Triglyc-140 HDL-37 LDLcalc-60 ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD %HbA1c-6.6* eAG-143* ___ 03: 43AM BLOOD calTIBC-406 Ferritn-48 TRF-312 ___ 03: 43AM BLOOD VitB12-176* Folate-10.1 ___ 03: 43AM BLOOD TSH-0.99 . URINALYSIS: ___ 11: 05PM URINE Color-Straw Appear-Clear Sp ___ ___ 11: 05PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-NEG Glucose-1000 Ketone-50 Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.0 Leuks-NEG ___ 11: 15PM URINE Hours-RANDOM Creat-44 Na-94 K-21 Cl-91 . LABS ON DISCHARGE: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD WBC-5.9 RBC-3.85* Hgb-12.0* Hct-35.1* MCV-91 MCH-31.2 MCHC-34.2 RDW-14.0 Plt ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-25* Creat-1.2 Na-140 K-4.2 Cl-107 HCO3-23 AnGap-14 ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.5 Phos-2.9 Mg-1.9 . IMAGING / STUDIES: # CHEST (PORTABLE AP) ___ at 9: 43 ___: FINDINGS: There are no pleural effusions or pneumothorax. The cardiac and mediastinal contours are unremarkable. There is moderate cardiomegaly. Pulmonary vascularity is normal. There is minimal bibasilar atelectasis, but the lungs are otherwise being clear. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. . # CTA CHEST ___ at 10: 23 ___: FINDINGS: Visualized portion of the thyroid appears unremarkable. There is no axillary, hilar, or mediastinal lymphadenopathy. The aorta is of a normal caliber along its course. There is no evidence of intramural hematoma or aortic dissection. The pulmonary arterial trunk is of normal caliber. There is no filling defect down the subsegmental level. There is no pericardial or pleural effusion. Calcified atherosclerotic disease is seen in the coronary arteries. Additionally, abnormal calcification is seen in the chordae tendineae of the left ventricle along with hypodensity in the inferior left ventricular wall may represent prior NSTEMI. The lungs are clear with mild bibasilar atelectasis. While this exam is not specifically designed for subdiaphragmatic evaluation, the superior pole of right kidney demonstrates a 6 cm hypodensity that is incompletely characterized but may represent a simple cyst. No comparison is available at the time of dictation. BONES: Moderate degenerative changes are seen throughout the thoracic spine, primarily in the form of prominent anterior osteophytes. No aggressive-appearing lytic or sclerotic lesion is seen. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute aortic syndrome or PE. 2. Cardiac findings suggesting prior inferior wall NSTEMI. . # TTE ___ at 11: 46: 49 AM): The left atrium is mildly dilated. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with mild hypokinesis of the inferolateral wall and distal inferior wall. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 50-55 %). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be quantified. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with mild regional systolic dysfunction c/w CAD. Mild mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology. Increased PCWP. . # CHEST (PRE-OP PA & LAT) ___ at 8: 44 AM): FINDINGS: In comparison with the study of ___, there is little change and no evidence of acute cardiopulmonary disease. Mild enlargement of the cardiac silhouette without vascular congestion, pleural effusion, or acute focal pneumonia. . # CAROTID SERIES ___ at 8: 54 AM): FINDINGS: There is a heterogeneous calcific plaque at the origin of both internal carotid arteries. However, the peak systolic velocities bilaterally were normal as are the ICA/CCA ratios. There is also normal antegrade flow involving both vertebral arteries. IMPRESSION: Heterogeneous calcified plaque at the origin of both internal carotid arteries, no significant associated stenosis, however (graded as less than 40% bilaterally). . <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Aspirin 81 mg PO daily Metoprolol succinate 50 mg PO daily Lisinopril 40 mg PO daily Rosuvastatin 20 mg PO daily Fenofibrate 160 mg PO daily Glyburide/Metformin ___ mg) 2 tab PO BID Actos 30 mg PO daily Doxazosin 2 mg PO daily Travatan Z 0.004% 1 drop QHS Nitroglycerin SL (but does not use) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 2. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. lisinopril 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 4. omeprazole 40 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO once a day. Disp: *30 Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.)(s)* Refills: *0* 5. metoprolol succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. 6. glyburide-metformin ___ mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO twice a day. 7. Actos 30 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 8. doxazosin 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime. 9. Travatan Z 0.004 % Drops Sig: One (1) drop Ophthalmic at bedtime. 10. cyanocobalamin (vitamin B-12) 250 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnoses: Non ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction Coronary Artery Disease Chronic Gastrointestinal Bleeding Chronic Kidney Disease Secondary Diagnoses: Diabetes Mellitus Hypertension Dyslipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain. In the hospital, you had EKG changes concerning for a heart attack and lab tests indicated new injury to your heart muscle. You were taken for cardiac catheterization, which showed diffuse coronary artery disease. You were seen by Cardiac Surgery and evaluated for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). Several changes were made to your medications in order to better protect your heart. You were increased to a full dose Aspirin, and you were changed from Crestor to Atorvastatin. Your Fenofibrate was also stopped. Because your blood pressure was elevated while in the hospital, you were started on Amlodipine, another blood pressure medication. START: Aspirin 325 mg by mouth daily START: Atorvastatin 80 mg by mouth daily STOP: Rosuvastatin (Crestor) 20 mg by mouth daily STOP: Fenofibrate 160 mg by mouth daily Because of the recent bleeding found from your digestive tract, you were started on Omeprazole to reduce the amount of acid produced. You were also found to have low levels of Vitamin B12 in your body and were started on a Vitamin B12 supplement. You should continue taking this until told to stop by your PCP. START: Omeprazole 40 mg by mouth daily START: Vitamin B12 250 mcg by mouth daily You will need a followup appointment with your PCP, Dr ___ ___. Appointment details are below. Because of your anemia and the bleeding detected in your gastrointestinal tract, you will also need to schedule an appointment with a Gastroenterologist to have this evaluated. You should discuss this with Dr. ___.
target: The patient is an ___ year old male with a history of CAD, diabetes, hypertension, and dyslipidemia who presented with chest pain and lateral ST depressions on EKG. His chest pain resolved on Nitro gtt and he ruled in with positive CEs. He was noted to have anemia and guaiac positive stools. Cardiac cath showed 3VD, and CABG evaluation was initiated. . # Coronaries: He has known CAD with inferior MI in ___, mid/distal RCA stent placement in ___, known disease in the Diag and multiple OM branches on prior cath in ___, and RCA atherectomy in ___. He has not had a cardiac cath since ___. He had significant chest pain on admission with lateral ST depression, and ruled in on his second set of CEs. CTA on admission did not show evidence of an acute process. Heparin was discontinued on ___ due to his low Hct and apparent GI bleeding. He initially required a relatively high rate Nitro drip and Morphine to become chest pain free, but remained CP free after the Nitro drip was stopped on ___. He had cardiac cath on ___ which showed 3VD and he was referred to CT Surgery to be evaluated for CABG. During his stay, he was continued on a cardiac regimen of Aspirin 325 mg PO daily, Clopidogrel 75 mg PO daily, Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily (home Rosuvastatin 20 mg), Metoprolol tartrate 25 mg PO BID, and Lisinopril 40 mg PO daily. In preparation for possible CABG, studies were carried out per CT Surgery recs including TTE, carotid US, and CXR PA+L. . # Pump: He does not have a known history of CHF, but did show signs of mild volume overload on admission. These largely resolved soon after admission and likely represented mild acute diastolic heat failure. TTE on ___ showed LVEF 50-55% with mild hypokinesis of the inferolateral and distal inferior walls. . # Rhythm: He had multiple runs of NSVT up to 18 beats shortly after admission, but remained asymptomatic during these episodes. His ectopy decreased significantly later in his stay. His electrolytes were repleted with goal K>4 and Mg>2. . # Creatinine Elevation: His baseline creatinine was initially unknown (last OMR record 0.8 in ___. He had Cr 1.5 on admission, and it was unclear whether this represented ___ or ___. His BUN/Cr ratio was >20 but urine electrolytes showed urine Na 94 and FENa 2.34%. PCP records obtained on ___ showed a recent baseline Cr ~1.4-1.6, most recently 1.4 on ___, indicating that he was near his baseline with ___. His Cr remained stable during his admission. . # Anemia: His Hct on admission was 32.7 and dropped to 28.8 when repeated several hours later. His Hct was 42.7 in ___, the last value recorded in OMR. PCP records were obtained on ___ and showed that his baseline Hct had been 33-35 over the last ___ years. His stool guaiac positive on admission and he had several guaiac positive stools afterward without grossly visible blood. He received 2 units of PRBCs with an appropriate increase in Hct from 25.9 to 31.4. His Hct then remained stable in the low ___. His iron studies were unremarkable, but his B12 was low at 176, and he was started on Cyanocobalamin 250 mg PO daily. . # Hypertension: He has a history of hypertension treated with Lisinopril 40 mg PO daily and Metoprolol succinate 50 mg PO daily. His Lisinopril was held initially in the setting of ARF and his high dose Nitro drip. His Lisinopril was restarted at 20 mg PO daily on ___ for better BP control. His Nitro drip was stopped on ___, and he was increased back to his home dose of Lisinopril 40 mg PO daily. . # Hyperlipidemia: He was on Rosuvastatin 20 mg PO daily and Fenofibrate 160 mg PO daily at home. His lipid panel on admission showed TC 125, ___ 140, HDL 37, and LDL 60. He is currently at his goal LDL. He was switched to Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily on admission in the setting of ACS, and Fenofibrate was held. . # Diabetes: He was on a home regimen of Glyburide/Metformin ___ mg) 2 tabs PO BID and Actos 30 mg PO daily. His HgbA1c was sent on admission and was 6.6%. His oral diabetes meds were held while in hospital, and he was placed on a Regular Insulin sliding scale. His home regimen was restarted on discharge. . # BPH: His home Doxazosin 2 mg PO daily was held during his stay. . # GI Prophylaxis: He was placed on a bowel regimen of Colace. Ondansetron was provided PRN for nausea. He was started on Pantoprazole 40 mg IV Q12H given the initial concern for significant GI bleeding. He was kept on Omeprazole 40 mg PO daily on discharge. . # DVT Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots . # Followup -- Patient instructed to call for PCP followup appointment -- Scheduled for CABG on ___ .

This was accompanied by dizziness and a cold sweat. He felt that he would pass out, but did not lose consciousness. His coworkers observed him to be pale and shaky. EMS was called. . The patient presented to ___ ___ this morning reporting crampy abdominal pain and this pre-syncopal episode. He denied chest pain, arm or jaw pain, palpitations, LOC. He was found by EMS to be hypotensive to the SBP ___. In the ___ he was given 1L NS for hypotension, recovered to SBP 90-120s. He was given ASA 325mg and started on a heparin gtt. Plavix was not given, nor was a beta blocker given initial hypotension. He continued to deny chest pain or dyspnea. FSBS 387 (not covered as no PO intake). No EKG changes per report, but tropI 0.57. Given the troponin elevation and acute hypotension, the patient was transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. . Of note, the patient is ___ week s/p TURP at ___. Since the procedure he reports mild hematuria, now resolved, and decreased urinary frequency. He has had intermittent episodes of dull suprapubic abdominal pain, relieved with urination. He is particularly pleased that he has experienced no nocturia for the last two days. He continued his ASA 81mg daily, but held Plavix for the procedure and has not restarted it. . By report, the catheterization did not reveal any additional stenosis to explain his recent symptoms. Heparin gtt stopped. On arrival to the floor, patient reported ___ dull suprapubic abdominal pain. The patient notes that he has never had chest pain with his prior MI, but rather experienced shallow breathing. He states that he is familiar with his typical MI breathing, and that he is not experiencing this pattern on this occasion. He denies dyspnea on exertion. . target: ___ with Hx CAD s/p stenting to the ostial and mid LAD in ___, LCx in ___, and OM in ___, known total occlusion of the RCA, hypertension, dyslipidemia, diabetes, and current tobacco use who presented with nausea, vomiting, and weakness with new lower abdominal pain, found to have elevated tropI, now s/p cath with no new stenosis. . # CORONARIES / type II MI: History of 3VD on cath in ___, R dominant with diffuse LAD, totally occluded RCA. s/p OM1 stent in ___, DES to LCx in ___, DES to mid-LAD and DES to ostium/proximal LAD in ___. Cardiac cath ___ showed no new stenosis. This appeared to be a type 2 MI (NSTEMI), with decreased blood supply due to hypotension and hypovolemia. This was most likely ___ nausea and vomiting and/or UTI. TropT the morning following admission was 0.20, down from tropI at OSH 0.57 (although these are not directly comparable measurements). The patient was already on appropriate medical management with aspirin, statin, metoprolol, ACE inhibitor, and nitrate. These were continued. Cholesterol panel showed good control with LDL < 50. Following discussion with the patient's Urology office, Plavix was restarted. # PUMP: No history of CHF, LVEF preserved in ___ despite multiple MIs. TTE on this admission showed LVEF 45-50% with increased wall motion abnormalities. # RHYTHM: No history of Afib or arrhythmia, none seen on telemetry during this admission. # HLD: Continued statin. Cholesterol panel showed good control. # Hypotension: Hypertensive at baseline with multiple medications, presented with hypotension, which is the likely cause of his presyncope and ischemia. This could be due to poor PO intake in the 3 days prior to admission due to nausea and vomiting. Medications were initially held due to hypotension, then restarted successfully with good SBP control. # BPH, recurrent cystitis one week s/p TURP, UTI: Patient complained of suprapubic tenderness, although his post-operative hematuria had resolved. Denied urinary symptoms, had substantially reduced frequency. UA showed sign of infection, which may be the cause of the patient's symptoms. Terazosin was continued and Cipro started for UTI per Urology input. On one measurement, the patient had a post-void residual of 570cc, but then had good output that resolved this transient retention. Urology follow-up appointment already in place, documented for patient. # T2DM: FSBS elevated at ___ and here up to 300-450. The patient did not develop an anion gap acidosis, but clearly was not in good control. Oral agents were held in favor of ISS. This was uptitrated several times and Lantus added for basal control. As the patient's PCP is in the midst of adjusting his outpatient regimen, no changes were made on discharge. Inactive Issues: # Nausea/vomiting: Patient presented with history of nausea and vomiting 3 days PTA, may be ___ UTI. No symptoms during admission. # COPD: continued inhalers (albuterol and Advair) # Tobacco abuse: prefers not to use patch; encouraged to do so prior to discharge to aid smoking cessation. Prescription provided. # Back pain: not currently active, does not use cyclobenzaprine or other medication CODE: FULL EMERGENCY CONTACT: ___ (wife, ___ Transitional Issues: - Consider switching statin given the 80mg dose of simvastatin is now discouraged; the patient has been on this dose for more than a year, so its use is reasonable - We restarted Plavix; ensure this is not held without Cardiology input - The patient was started on Cipro for UTI, but sensitivity information was still pending at the time of discharge. It would be helpful to follow-up to ensure that this is appropriate treatment. - Provided Rx for nicotine patch to aid in smoking cessation

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old male with risk factors for CAD (HTN, DM) who presented to OSH with 1 week chest pain after URI with a productive cough for the past ten days. During that time, he had some diffuse pain through out the precordium which he did not think much of. It was not associated with N/V/E diaphoresis, arm or neck pain. He also did not notice an association with food. . ROS is negative for fevers, chills, angina, claudication, h/o MI, or PND, ___, or othopnea. The patient's history was obtained in the Cath waiting area prior to procedure. . Per the old notes at the OSH, he presented to his PCP ___ ___ with URI and chest pain. He was found to have chest pain radiating to the left arm, and a productive cough with dark sputum. An ECG showed anterior ST elevations and he was sent to the ED at ___. He was treated with 5 mg IV IV lopressor, 325 mg ASA, and was give a heparin drip at 1000 units. He had a CK that peaked at 992 and a troponin that was 2.25. He has been persistently tachycardic throughout his hospital stay. He had a cath which showed a 98% occluded LAD. He spiked a temp to 102.5 and was started on azithromycin. . His labs at the OSH were remarkable for the following: Troponin T 1.14 -> 1.8 with an admission CK-MB of 18.2 now 11.6. Total cholesterol 183, Triglycerides 138, HDL 54, LDL 101. HgBA1C 8.1. The lung bases did not show a focal infiltrate (although the left side could not be viewed well). . On arrival to the floor, he was tachycardic and was febrile to 101 (see below for VS). He had urine culture, blood cultures, and a repeat CXR. He was asymptomatic and denied chest pain, or shortness of breath. He had used his pro-air a few times. Otherwise he did not feel warm and he was not coughing. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: (+)Diabetes, (+)Dyslipidemia, (+) Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: None -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: None -PACING/ICD: None 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: DM II, diagnosed last year on oral medications, HgbA1C 8.7 Asthma: Medication controlled HTN Diabetes Dyslipidemia Status Post Tosillectomy Renal Calculi PNA/Bronchitis recently given Azithromycin 250 mg PO daily (last dose ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of MI or CVA. No history of PE, DVT or blood diathesis. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: T=99.1 BP=140/95 HR=111 RR=20 O2 sat= 100, 4L NC. GENERAL: NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. The patient is comfortable. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP of 0 cm. CARDIAC: PMI located lateral to ___ intercostal space, faint at 30 degrees Faint, but normal S1 and S2. No S3 or S4. No R ventricular heave. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored. Patient was able to speak in complete sentences. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. target: ___ year old male with h/o DM, HTN, and dyslipidemia who presented to OSH with a STEMI who was transferred to ___ with ECG concerning for STEMI and fever who was subsequently diagnosed with a PE/DVT, PNA, pericarditis, STEMI and an SVT/Atrial Tachycardia. . Summary & Formulation: # s/p STEMI: The patient presented to ___ for an intervention for a known LAD lesion, after having chest pain for several days. The OSH did not send the patient to the Cath lab immediately after presentation as they believed that the infarct had occured several days prior to his prsentation to the OSH ED. He was medically managed for two days over the holiday weekend prior to having a catheterization, and then transferred for an intervention. He had a ___ placed to the mid LAD, and was subsequently chest pain free. He had an ECHO which demonstrated an EF 25% with a dilated left ventricle and severe hypokinesis/akinesis of the anterior septum, anterior free wall, and apex, with focal apical dyskinesis; the lateral wall appears hypokinetic as well. He was continued on plavix, aspirin, and atorvastatin. His ECHO was also suggestive of Pericarditis which was confirmed with a rub on physical exam. . # Asthma exacerbation: He presented with out complaints of SOB, but he continued to require his albuterol inhaler. His heart rate was noted to be high, and he had a peak flow in the 200's. He was also given Metoprolol to help control his HR to reduce the risk of adverse remodeling ___. However, his breathing continued to worsen, and he began to require O2. His beta-blocker was stopped and his peak flow was measured to be 200. He was started on his Flovent inhaler, and continued on ipratropium nebulizers. He was not started on steroids for an asthma exacerbation due to concern that it would precipitate a ventricular aneurysm or septal rupture. His peak flow prior to discharge was 425. . # SVT: The patient had three runs of SVT of 220. He report symptoms of flushing, but was never hypotensive or unresponsive. He only noted flushing on the second and third round of SVT. The rhythm was noted to be accelerated, and the DDx included AT, MAT, versus AVNRT. The latter was thought to be unlikely, with AT as the most likely diagnosis. He was treated with IV diltiazem to break the episodes of SVT and then started on a low dose diltiazem which was 60 mg QID. We had tried 30 mg QID, but continued to have an elevated HR. He was not given a beta-blocker due to his concomitant asthma exacerbation ___ beta blockade. . # Pericarditis: After his admission, he had evidence on his ECG of pericarditis. Due to his recent STEMI it was thought to be secondary to inflammation, and unlikely to be a ___ syndrome given the timing of pericarditis ___. His INR was allowed to increase slowly due to concern about development of a pericardial effusion, but his ECHO did not show an effusion. . # DVT/PE: He has a known Factor V Leiden mutation (heterozygous) and he had a superficial femoral vein clot that was not completely occlusive. He had been treated for a DVT in the past, and therefore will require life long anti-coagulation. Due to his persistent sinus tachycardia both at the time of presentation, transfer to ___ and his hospital stay, it was presumed that he had a pulmonary embolus. He did not undergo a V/Q scan due to his history of asthma, and he did not undergo a CTA due to his ___. He was started on warfarin empirically for his apical hypokinesis, and his INR prior to discharge was 1.4. He was sent home with Lovenox. . # L sided Pleural Effusion/Retrocardiac opacity/PNA: After a discussion with radiology, and concomitant fever, he was diagnosed with HCAP and empirically started on Levaquin. He then spiked an additional fever, and was transitioned to Vancomycin, Cefepime, and Ciprofloxacin. He was then transitioned to oral antibiotics, and discharged home with oral cefpodoxime to complete an 8 day course. . # ___ on CKD: His creatinine was elevated at the OSH. He is listed as having known CKD. His creatine peaked at 1.8 and improved with mild IV hydration. The elevation in his creatinine was thought to be secondary to contrast nephropathy. Prior to discharge his was 1.4. . # Decreased TSH: Due to his persistent sinus tachycardia, his TSH was checked. He had a slightly abnormal TSH, and a T3 was normal and his T4 was only slightly above normal. . # Sinus Tachycardia: In the setting of his STEMI and recent DVT, his sinus tachycardia was multi-factorial. His sinus rate prior to decreased into the 90's while he was on diltiazem. . Chronic Issues: . # DM II (uncontrolled). He was diagnosed last year and started on oral medications, with a HgbA1C of 7.5. While he was admitted to the hospital he was kept on an ISS with lantus to help control his blood sugars. . # HTN: He presented with mild hypertension, that resolved. . # Dyslipidemia: His lipids were checked while he was hospitalized and his total cholesterol was 183 with an LDL of 101. He was started on high dose Atorvastatin 80 mg per-MI. . TRANSITION OF CARE: Disposition: Home Follow up: PCP and ___ status: Full ADDENDUM - THE PATIENT WAS RE-ADMITTED A FEW DAYS AFTER DISCHARGE WITH A PERICARDIAL EFFUSION AND TAMPONADE PHYSIOLOGY. FULL DISCHARGE SUMMARY TO FOLLOW.

Stage IV chronic kidney disease 4. Hyperlipidemia 5. Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear ___, ___ were admitted to the hospital for catheterization to open several blockages that were found in the arteries around your heart during your last admission. ___ received stents to two of these arteries, though your symptoms of chest pressure and shortness of breath on exertion persisted. ___ underwent a repeat catheterization to evaluate a third blockage that was thought to be contributing to your symptoms, but it did not appear severe enough to require stenting. Your exertional symptoms are likely caused by your coronary disease, your COPD, and some fluid in your lungs from all the fluids ___ needed for these catheterizations. Your symptoms finally did improve enough to be discharged from the hospital. The following changes were made to your medications: 1. START AMLODIPINE 2.5mg twice a day 2. START XOPONEX inhaler, 2 puffs every ___ hours as needed for shortness of breath 3. CONTINUE PLAVIX 75mg daily for the next ___ months 4. DECREASE ISOSORBIDE MONONITRATE to 120mg IN THE MORNING 5. STOP COUMADIN- ___ do not need this medicine anymore 6. STOP OMEPRAZOLE. 7. START PANTOPRAZOLE 20mg daily to control your reflux It is very important that ___ continue to take your clopidogrel every day to prevent your stents from clogging and causing a large heart attack. Also, please continue to take your aspirin every day. If ___ miss your dose for 48 hours or more, ___ will not be able to safely continue taking aspirin without undergoing desensitization again. Please continue your other previously prescribed medications It truly was a pleasure taking care of ___, Mrs. ___ ___ Instructions: ___
target: Mrs. ___ is an ___ with a history of severe CAD, COPD, CKD stage IV, HTN, HLD, PVD, who was re-admitted for a planned stenting of a severely diseased LMCA, but who experienced continued exertional chest pain and pressure following DES to LAD and LMCA, likely secondary to a combination of diffuse CAD, COPD, and pulmonary edema. ACTIVE PROBLEMS: 1. CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: She has experienced persistent exertional angina over the past few weeks which has been functionally limiting. Severe left main coronary artery disease was discovered during her last hospitalization in ___ with a distal 70% stenosis. She underwent aspirin desensitization in the ICU during that admission and eventually declined CABG, so she returned for LMCA stenting. She presented early for pre-procedural hydration with NS, bicarbonate, and mucomyst given her severe chronic kidney disease (GFR 17). She underwent uncomplicated catheterization with DES placed to the LMCA and LAD. She continued to experience exertional chest pressure and shortness of breath after taking only a few steps. . She demonstrated transient anterolateral T wave inversions during these episodes, which quickly resolved with rest or nitrogylcerin SL. Of note, a 60% LCX lesion was noted on her previous cath, and the ostia was jailed by the new LAD stent. Due to suspicion that her LCx disease was driving these symptoms, she underwent repeat cath on ___, again with pre-procedural hydration protocol for renal protection. Pressure wire analysis failed to demonstrate significantly severe disease to merit intervention of the LCx lesion, which was not felt to be a likely culprit behind her chest symptoms. Furthermore, LCx stenting would likely jail and jeopardize collaterals to the RCA. Her medical regimen was expanded to include amplodipine 2.5mg BID for additional anti-anginal effect and her isosorbide was decreased to 120mg QD to allow an evening holiday with the hope of preventing tolerance. She continued aspirin, plavix x 12months, metoprolol, atorvastatin. 2. EXERTIONAL DYSPNEA/CHEST PRESSURE: She continued to note substernal chest pressure and dyspnea with minimal exertion following her first catheterization. As mentioned, repeat catheterization failed to demonstrate a probable epicardial source. Small vessel disease may be at fault, and her medical anti-anginal regimen was optimized as above. Her chest XR demonstrated pulmonary edema and effusion from preprocedural hydration. Her symptoms improved somewhat with diuresis, as well as sheduled albuterol nebs for suspected severe COPD. She received bronchodilators and occasional sublingual nitroglycerin prior to exertion with some improvement. While her functional tolerance did improve, she was discharged to acute rehab for more intensive physical therapy. She will most likely continue to experience chest pressure and dyspnea on mild exertion, which occurred frequently in house. These symptoms should preferentially be treated with rest, and use sublingual nitroglycerin if symptoms do not resolve after 5 minutes of rest. Would not recommend ED referral unless her symptoms are particularly severe or fail to respond to rest and nitroglycerin. 3. STAGE IV CHRONIC KIDNEY DISEASE: She presented in stage IV renal disease with an estimated GFR of 17. She received saline, bicarbonaate, and mucomyst prior to catheterization. She developed acute on chronic kidney injury following her second catheterization, which was likely a combination of contrast nephropathy and pre-renal azotemia from lasix. Creatinine was stable at 2.8 at discharge. 4. COPD: She has moderate to severe COPD based on recent PFTs, currently controlled on tiotropium. She never tolerated advair or inhaled steroids due to hoarseness. She experienced some relief with scheduled albuterol nebs. She was discharged with levalbuterol inhaler to prevent some of the tachycardia associated with beta agonism due to her severe coronary disease. 5. EXERTIONAL LOWER EXTREMITY PAIN: She complains of bilateral posterior thigh pain with ambulation that radiates to the buttock. It improves with rest. Per her report, she had balloon angioplasty of bilateral lower extremity PVD at ___ in years past without stents. She underwent lower extremity arterial dopplers at rest, demonstrating only mild-to moderate occlusive disase with ABI of about 0.8 bilaterally. Her symptoms may therefore be related to general deconditioning, and she did note some improvement with physical therapy. 6. PREVIOUS PE: She had a suspected pulmonary embolus several years ago which was never fully established due to her refusal to undergo CTA. She had been on coumadin since that time, which was stopped prior to her catheterization. After discussion with her PCP, coumadin was not restarted. 7. ASPIRIN INDUCED BRONCHOSPASM: She was desensitized during her last hospitalization and continued daily full-dose aspirin without complication. 8. HYPERCHOLESTEROLEMIA: Her lipid panel was checked during hospitalization with Cholesterol 142, ___ 114, HDL 44, and LDL 75. Atorvastatin 80mg daily was continued due to severe coronary disease. 9. HYPERTENSION: She continued metorpolol succinate, and amlodipine 2.5mg BID was added for anti-anginal effect. BP was well controlled. 10. ?HIT: She carries a likely diagnosis of HIT. Heparin products were avoided. 11. PULMONARY HYPERTENSION: She has a history pulmonary hypertension with peak TR velocity of 45-75 on ___ echo. Uncertain WHO classification given prior PE, COPD. 12. IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA: continue iron supplementation PENDING TESTS AT DISCHARGE: none TRANSITIONAL CARE ISSUES: - ___ rehab for increasing functional capacity

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Lisinopril <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> substernal chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ yo Male with a history of CAD and bladder cancer s/p urostomy presents with substernal chest pain starting this morning. The pateint states he had a cough for the last 2 days which he thought was similar to his COPD, he took albuterol neb and then had crushing substernal chest pain which felt like something heavy was sitting on his chest. This pain was ___. This pain was similar to his previous heart attack pain. He took nitroglycerin and the pain improved, he called EMS, who gave him another 3 nitroglycerin and a full dose of aspirin. With resolution of chest pain. In the ED, initial vitals were 111 156/82 23 98%. He reported that his pain had resolved. He denied any chest pain or shortness of breath and states he feels no discomfort. He denies any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, changes in his bowel or bladder habits. Initial labs, revealed a negative trop. A chem 7 reveal a BUN/Cr of 52/2.2, other electrolytes (initially hemolyzed) were normal. proBNP was 2183. CBC revealed macrocytic anemia of Hct of 37.4, normal WBC and plt count. Coag wnl. CXR was obtained an final read was pending. He was started on heparin gtt and admitted for r/o ACS. On review of systems, he reports a prior TIA, but denies deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors.He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> DM - A1c 7% ___ Asthma, COPD, smoker - PNA in ___ CKD - Cr 1.4 CAD s/p CABG ___, multiple stents to LAD, cath ___, subclavian bare metal stent, EF 56% by MIBI Hyperlipid HTN H/o small stroke ___ ago: right parietal lobe w/ left arm affected Obesity GERD Anxiety Chronic back pain Partial blindness Invasive bladder Cancer <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mom with heart attack @ ___, Dad HTN and heart attack at 36. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Admission Exam: VS: T=97.9 BP=168/78 HR=73 RR=20 O2 sat= 98% GENERAL: WDWN male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: Supple with JVP of 6 cm. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. systolic murmur heard along sternum. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. urostomy in place, C/D/I EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. Discharge Exam: vitals: 66 110/63 18 97% RA unchanged. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 11: 40AM BLOOD WBC-8.4 RBC-3.76* Hgb-12.9*# Hct-37.4* MCV-100*# MCH-34.2*# MCHC-34.4# RDW-14.9 Plt ___ ___ 11: 40AM BLOOD ___ PTT-30.7 ___ ___ 11: 40AM BLOOD Glucose-184* UreaN-52* Creat-2.2* Na-136 K-6.1* Cl-108 HCO3-16* AnGap-18 ___ 11: 40AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.01 ___ 07: 05PM BLOOD CK-MB-11* MB Indx-8.3 cTropnT-0.24* ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD CK-MB-10 MB Indx-4.3 cTropnT-0.22* ___ 11: 40AM BLOOD proBNP-2183* Discharge labs: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD WBC-7.7 RBC-4.07* Hgb-13.6* Hct-41.3 MCV-102* MCH-33.4* MCHC-32.9 RDW-14.9 Plt ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-80 UreaN-38* Creat-2.0* Na-138 K-4.8 Cl-106 HCO3-20* AnGap-17 Cath Report: Coronary angiography: LEFT dominant LMCA: The LMCA was short but patent. LAD: The LAD tended to be selectively engaged with the JL4 and AL2 catheters with significant pressure dampening. Views with the AL2 in the LMCA showed a 40-50% near-ostial stenosis. There was a 50% stenosis in the proximal LAD prior to the first diagonal branch that appeared similar to the appearance in the prior angiogram from ___. The proximal LAD was calcified. D1 was of moderate caliber with a proximal 50% stenosis. A larger D2 had a moderate origin stenosis, a proximal 50% stenosis and diffuse plaquing throughout; its small medial pole had a significant origin stenosis (also seen on the prior angiogram). The major distal D3 ran parallel to the distal/apical LAD. The apical LAD either wrapped around the apex or supplied a modest caliber collateral to the LPDA. LCX: The LCX had a proximal 30% stenosis after a high modest OM1 followed by a large atrial branch. There was a large branching OM2 with mild plaquing throughout that arose from a 35% stenosis in the AV groove CX. The AV groove CX was severely narrowed just after OM2 and then totally occluded prior to the several stents seen in the mid-distal AV groove CX (without contrast filling). The atrial branch provided faint collaterals to the posterolateral wall. RCA: The RCA could not be engaged selectively with the JR4. Non-selective angiography confirmed the proximal tapering and proximal-mid vessel diffuse occlusion seen on the prior angiogram with delayed filling of a small caliber long RV branch. SVG-LPDA: The SVG proper was patent with minimal luminal irregularities. There was a 40% stenosis in the LPDA distal (antegrade) from the anastomosis. The LPDA gave off several laterally oriented sidebranches. There was retrograde perfusion of several LPL branches. There was also a tortuous apical collateral to the RV. Assessment & Recommendations 1. Three vessel native coronary artery disease with moderate LAD stenoses unlikely to cause rest angina, but continued small vessel disease too small for PCI. 2. Patent SVG-LPDA with mild distal native disease. 3. Severe, poorly controlled systemic systolic arterial hypertension suggestive of malignant hypertension in the setting of acute NSTEMI. 4. No hemodynamic evidence of significant right subclavian artery in-stent restenosis. 5. No lesions conducive to PCI. 6. Suggest aggressive secondary preventative measures against CAD, hypertension, NSTEMI, and LV diastolic dysfunction, including continued clopidogrel for ___ year for post-MI secondary prevention, addition of amlodipine or other dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, maximal statin therapy, and referral to outpatient cardiac rehabilitation. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___. You were admitted for chest pain, which we found to be related to your heart. You underwent a cardiac catheterization, which revealed that the blood vessel that supply oxygen to your heart are unchanged from ___. It is very important to control your blood pressure to prevent this type of chest pain in the future. We have started a new medication and increase an already existing medication to better control your blood pressure. (see below for details) Please follow up with Dr. ___ to re-establish care with him. Please also follow up with ___ clinic (see below for details). Please also follow up with your cardiologist (see below, they will call with an appointment), kidney/bladder doctor. Medication Changes: Start taking amlodipine 5mg daily Increase metoprolol XL to 100mg daily

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Lactose / Sulfa (Sulfonamide Antibiotics) / Codeine / Penicillins / prednisone / clindamycin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Presented to ___ complaining chest pressure, nausea and vomiting. Transferred to ___ for percutaneous intervention of NSTEMI(non-ST myocardial infarction). <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac ___. Central line placement on right femoral ___. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year old female with a past medical history notable for nonobstructive coronary artery disease, prior history of atrial fibrillation (not on coumadin), hyperlipidemia, and cutaneous lupus who was transferred from ___ for catheterization following an NSTEMI. . Patient initially presented to ___ on ___ with several hours of indigestion, nausea, and chest pressure with ECG demonstrating 1mm ST depressions in V3-V6. Troponin I has trended as follows: 0.06.> 1.99 -> 0.94. CK: 128-> 137. CKMB: 3.4-> 11.1. She was transferred to ___ for further workup and catheterization. . Here at ___, she underwent BMS(Bare metal stent) deployment in the mid-distal LCx but with no reflow following stenting. She was given IC nicardipine bolus 400 mcg and intracoronary nitroglycerine 700 mcg X 1 with improved distal flow. target: ___ year old female with a PMH notable for nonobstructive coronary artery disease, prior history of atrial fibrillation (not on coumadin), hyperlipidemia, and lupus who was transferred from ___ for catheterization following an NSTEMI. S/p DES to ___ and admitted to the CCU for hemodynamic monitoring after an episode of hypotension in the cath lab requiring dopamine. . # Hypotension: Broad differential, but clinical presentation initially was most likely consistent with vagal episode. Patient found to have >1L CC of urine output once foley placed. Patient briefly required peripheral dopamine in cath lab in response to BP with systolics in the ___ but dopamine was quickly weaned without problems and pt was transported to CCU. At that time, TTE without evidence of tamponade, depressed LVEF, or perforation. REPEAT TTE ___ showed very mild focal left ventricular dysfunction c/w CAD and borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Patient did not complain of abdominal or back pain following the procedure which argued against RP bleed. Pt did state she felt extremely thirsty and had not had anything to eat or drink since 9pm the evening prior. Her BPs responded to gentle hydration and remained stable in the ___ systolic overnight following the procedure. Home beta blocker was held. HCT remained relatively stable overnight so less concern for bleed, although on ___ AM pt was noted to have had a 3 point HCT drop from midnight labs, see abdominal wall hematoma below. In the setting of acute bleed BP dropped to as low as ___ systolic. Pt was started on dopamine and levophed and transfused with good effect on BP (up as high as 150s systolic) and quickly weaned from these medications. Patient is being discharged with stable blood pressure. #abdominal wall hematoma - the morning after admission it was noted that the pt had a HCT drop from 33.7 at midnight to 30.5. Pt had been on an integrillin drip since cardiac cath and intervention ___. Overnight pt had remained stable with BP in the low ___, received gentle hydration with IVF, and denied significant pain anywhere in the abdominal, back, or groin regions. pt had bilateral femoral catheterizations as she had become hypotensive following the initial catheterization and there was anticipation of possible need for intra-aortic balloon pump, although her pressures reponded quickly to dopamine and pump was never placed. The night following the procedure, frequent groin checks performed which showed present pulses, no hematoma, masses, evidence of bleeding, or audible bruits. Early morning after admission pt was noted to have some minor bleeding through the dressing of the left femoral catheter site but remained HDS and without complaints. Shortly after discovering this she suddenly developed large swelling over the area of the left groin catheter site and somewhat more proximally partially over the left pelvic and lower abdominal region. She became very pale and was crying out in pain with BPs down to the ___ systolic. Deep pressure was held over the site, pt had right wrist A-line and right femoral central line placed. With dopamine and levophed her BP responded with systolics as high as 150s, and pressors were quickly weaned. Pt recieved a total of 3 units pRBCs. Pt was alert and oriented throughout this episode. Patient was stable during the rest of the hospital stay. . # NSTEMI: Troponin elevation at OSH in the setting of precordial ST depressions. Now asymptomatic. S/p BMS to the LCX, initially with no reflow with response to IC vasodilatory medications. Now asymptomatic. Will continue at home with medical management as below. - aspirin 325mg PO daily - prasugrel 10mg PO daily - metoprolol 12.5mg PO BID - Atorvastatin 10mg PO daily Patient should follow up with PCP and cardiologist. . #UTI: Patient had UTI symptoms and had a culture positive for ESCHERICHIA COLI pan-sensitive. Should complete a course of 7 days of ciprofloxacin 500mg PO Q12h(last day is ___. . #Atrial fibrillation - pt not on coumadin, question of whether or not it was paroxysmal, history unclear. Pt was not started on coumadin for Afib during this hospitalization. . # HLD: Patient was started on Atorvastatin 10 mg PO/NG HS and should continue it at home . # SLE: Patient was continued on home plaquenil. On ___ pt did complain of facial flushing and appeared to have erythematous facial rash in malar distribution, ESR and CRP were sent which were within normal limits.

target: In brief, this is a ___ year old man with hypertension, dyslipidemia, ongoing cigarette use, CAD S/P CABG, and asthma presenting with chest pain and dyspnea. # CAD: Onset of pain at rest was concerning for UA. There was no ECG or biomarker evidence of myocardial infarction. Dobutamine echo (given his difficulty walking due to knee arthritis) was limited by asthma exacerbation, but his chest discomfort was not reproduced, and there was no objective evidence of ischemia. Initially, he was placed on Plavix, which was discontinued when stress test was negative for ischemia (arguing against an ischemic etiology of his chest pain). He remained chest pain free throughout this admission. Continued ASA, beta-blocker (as he had been on this prior to his respiratory deterioration) and statin. # SOB: Asthma exacerbation. Improved with steroids and nebulizers. Discharged on steroid ___ (q2 days) and inhalers (albuterol, fluticasone). # Hypertension: Remained controlled on amlodipine and beta-blocker. # Hyperlipidemia: This admission with HDL 37, LDL 96. Increased Lipitor (given initial concerns for crescendo angina) and continued Tricor. # Nicotine addiction: Advised abstinence. Nicotine patch.
