Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms ___, You were admitted to the hospital for evaluation of chest pain. You had a stress test that was concerning for a clot in one of the arteries of your heart. You underwent cardiac catheterization which showed that you had a new clot in one of your arteries. A new stent was placed to open this area. It is very important to continue taking your medications regularly, especially Clopidogrel (Plavix), Aspirin, and Rosuvostatin (Crestor) in order to prevent your stents from closing and to protect your heart. We stopped one of your medications, Metoprolol, because we were concerned that it might make your heart rate too slow. Please follow up with you cardiologist to determine whether you should restart this at some point. Please avoid vigorous exercise for the next 7 days. After this time it is safe to engage in greater physical activity. It is also important to lead a healthy lifestyle and control your high blood pressure and Diabetes in order to prevent worsening heart disease. It is especially important to stop smoking. Cigarette smoking doubles your risk of coronary heart disease, and one year after you stop smoking the risk of dying from a heart attack decreases by about one-half! I have provided you with a prescription for nicotine patches if you would like to continue to use these once you leave the hospital. Please follow up with your primary care doctor for more help with quitting smoking. Medication changes STOP Metoprolol START Nicotine patch
target: The patient is a ___ y/o female with history of CAD s/p DES to RCA ___, DM II, HTN, HCV, and neuropathy, who presents with several days of substernal chest pain and found to have a positive stress test. . # CORONARIES: Patient has a significant h/o CAD with inferior MI in the past and at the time of presentation was 6 months post DES to RCA for similar for angina. Following this procedure the patient's symptoms had completely resolved. However, one month prior to current presentation she had begun noticing exertional chest heaviness responsive to nitroglycerin, that acutely worsened within a few days of this hospitalization. In the ED EKG was notable only for slight bradycardia and non-specific ST/TW changes. Cardiac enzymes were negative and the patient underwent stress testing. This revealed reversible ischemic changes in the inferior and lateral leads in correlation with patient's symptoms. She underwent coronary angiography which revealed 70% ulcerated plaque in mid RCA, which was stented with a 2.75x15mm Promus ___ stent. The previous distal RCA stent was patent. The patient was continued on a cardioprotective medication regimen, including Plavix 75mg qd, aspirin 325mg qd and crestor 20mg daily. Her metoprolol was held due to sinus bradycardia. She remained hemodynamically stable and was chest pain free at the time of discharge. The importance of risk factor management including control of DM, HTN, HLP, and tobacco cessation was stressed prior to discharge. She will follow up with her cardiologist and PCP following discharge. . # RHYTHM: Patient was noted to be in sinus bradycardia on telemetry and EKGs with rate ranging from 34-56 with no associated symptoms. Given h/o inferior MI and disease of the RCA it is possible that she has suffered some ischemia to vessels of the conduction system. The patient does report h/o bradycardia to ___ noted in previous hospitalizations, and prior EKG in ___ also notes bradycardia, so that this could represent her baseline. Nonetheless it was felt safest to hold her metoprolol in this setting. . # Diabetes Mellitus II Poorly controlled with A1C 9.2 in ___. Maintained on home dose of 24U glargine QHS and humalog sliding scale started during her inpatient course. Her metformin was resumed upon discharge. . # HTN Continued on home regimen of clonidine and isosorbide. Metoprolol was discontinued due to bradycardia. . # HLP Fasting lipids at goal with LDL of 45. She was continued on crestor 20mg daily. . # Tobacco abuse Tobacco cessation counseling provided. Patient was receptive. She was maintained on transdermal nicotine supplementation during her course. She was discharged with a two week supply of nicotine patches with instructions to follow up with her PCP for further support with smoking cessation. . # GERD Continued ranitidine 150mg BID. . # COPD Continued on atrovent BID and albuterol neb prn. . # Anxiety Continued on Benedryl, celexa, and clonazepam. Continued on suboxone for substance abuse treatment. . # Social Issues Letter provided to ___ confirming patient's hospitalization. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - she will f/u with cardiology for further management, including decision regarding resumption of beta blocker - the patient maintained full code status throughout her course.

Lantus 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: ___ (42) unit Subcutaneous at bedtime. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Non ST-elevation myocardial infarction with bare metal stent placement <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for chest pain. We found that you had had a small heart attack. Cardiac catheterization showed that this had happened because narrowing in a blood vessel that supplies your heart with blood. You were treated with a baloon and a stent was placed to help keep the blood vessel open. After the procedure you felt better and had no complications. . You will need to get a post-MI echocardiogram. Please call ___ to schedule this in the next week. You will follow up on this with Dr. ___ at your appointment that you will need to schedule. . We also noted that your blood sugar levels were poorly controlled and your blood cholesterol and fat levels were high. This may put you at risk for further blood vessel disase and you will need close follow up and treatment with your PCP to get these risk factors under control. . The following changes were made to your medications: . 1. Metoprolol Succinate 50mg tablet twice daily was changed to 100mg tablet once daily for control of your blood pressure and pulse. 2. Lisinopril 20mg was increased to Lisinopril 40mg and you should take one tablet once daily for control of your blood pressure. 3. Ranitidine 150mg tablet was decreased from twice daily to once daily. 4. Bactrim was stopped . . You mentioned ongoing right shoulder pain after a fall 2 months ago. We recommened that you discuss getting x-rays and an orthopedic consultation with your PCP.
target: Mrs. ___ is a ___ y/o F with PMHx significant for CAD s/p BMS in ___ and CABG (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM, SVG-RPDA) in ___ who presented to the ED with bilateral flank pain and CP and was found to have elevated troponins on labs. . # CORONARIES: Mrs. ___ has known CAD with prior PCI and is s/p CABG w/LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM, SVG-RPDA in ___. She was admitted with NSTEMI per symptoms and positive troponin to 0.28. Her EKG was minimally changed from baseline mainly showing mildly progressed ST depression and deeper TWI in V4. While demand ischemia d/t high BPs (198/70 in the ED) at presentation was initially considered in the differential diagnosis of her positive cardiac enzymes the patient's symptoms, EKG changes and rich coronary history warranted management as per NSTEMI. She was treated with Aspirin, BB, ACE-I, high dose Statin, IV Heparin and Plavix was loaded. Her pain resolved with IV Morphine and NG ___. Her high TIMI risk score indicated pursuit of an early catheterization strategy which on ___ demonstrated multiple coronary lesions (see report above). She had successful PCI to SVG to RCA with 2 bare metal stents in the mid portion of the graft. She was completely pain free after the procedure and the rest of her course was uncomplicated. She is discharged with Aspirin 325mg daily and Plavix 75mg for a minimum of 3 months. Of note on this admission Metoprolol Succinate was increased from 50 to 100mg daily, Lisinopril was increased from 20mg to 40mg daily and Simvastatin was increased from 40mg to 80mg daily. . # PUMP: Mrs. ___ has known LVH with normal systolic function per echo report of ___. She does not have chronic symptoms of CHF. On admission she had mild clinical and radiological signs of fluid overload perhaps related to IVF therapy in the ED. She did not however have SOB or desaturation and did not require diuresis. She was completely symptom-free on discharge and was able to ambulate comfortably without desaturation. Repeat echocardiography may be considered in the outpatient setting. . # DM: Mrs. ___ has poorly controlled insulin dependent type II diabetes as indicated by HbA1c 11.7% measured on admission. Treatment with Lantus + ISS was continued. Referral to diabetic clinic for optimization of diabetes control is advised. . # HTN: As noted Mrs. ___ presented with high BP to 198/70, this may have been secondary to pain and stress. Her SBP, however remained in the 160s and her metoprolol and lisinopril dosed were increased as mentioned above. HCTZ and Amlodipine were continued at home doses. Close follow-up and optimal BP control in the out-patient setting is advised. . # Dyslipidemia: Mrs. ___ has severe uncontrolled dyslipidemia with lipid profile obtained during this admission demonstration T. Chol 454* ___ 984*1 HDL 40 and LDL 293*. Repeated fasting ___ were 1095. She had no symptoms of pancreatitis and her Lipase was normal. She was on Simvastatin 40mg daily and Niacin 500mg daily prior to the current admission. We increased Simvastatin to 80mg daily. The severity of her lipid disorder may warrant referral for specialist evaluation. An appointments for the ___ at the ___ Outpatient Cardiology Services can be arranged at tel: ___. . # Flank pain and Dysuria: Mrs. ___ reported several days of Flank Pain and dysuria prior to presentation. She had received Bactrim for 3 days prior to her admission. Her UA on admission was negative for signs of inflammation or infection and she had no further complaints. No further Abx therapy was offered. . # Asthma: This was stable and Mrs. ___ had no respiratory complaints during this admission. Inhaled steroid was continued at home dose. . # GERD: Mrs. ___ has history of GERD. She was asymptomatic during this admission. Ranitidine was adjusted to her renal function and decreased from 150 mg BID to ___ QD. . # Right Shoulder Pain: Mrs. ___ reported right shoulder pain of two week duration following a fall. Physical examination did not reveal evidence of significant bone or joint injury. Further evaluation and managment is advised in the outpatient setting.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Tylenol-Codeine #3 <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> - Percutaneous Coronary Intervention w/ Drug-Eluting Stent Placement (x2) in Right Coronary Artery. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old male with PMH of hypercholesterolemia admitted with chief complaint of chest pain. Pt reports that this afternoon he had substernal chest pain and diaphoresis. Previously he was in good health and denies any h/o angina. . In the ED EKG revealed STE in inferior leads and in V5/V6. Pt was loaded with 600mg of plavix, given 325 ASA and given heparin bolus. . Cath revealed 70% mid-RCA lesion and occlusion of PDA. Thrombectomy of RCA and PCI placed in RCA and PDA lesions. Was given fentanyl for CP. . On transfer to CCU pt was in sinus rhythm, SBP 160 and vitals were otherwise unremarkable. Venous sheath was still in place. Pt still complaining of chest pain and STE have not yet resolved, but improved. . On review of systems, s/he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. he denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. he denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. DISCHARGE LABS ___ 07: 15AM BLOOD WBC-8.0 RBC-4.70 Hgb-14.6 Hct-40.6 MCV-86 MCH-31.0 MCHC-35.9* RDW-13.4 Plt ___ ___ 05: 12AM BLOOD ___ PTT-36.4* ___ ___ 07: 15AM BLOOD Glucose-134* UreaN-19 Creat-0.8 Na-141 K-4.1 Cl-104 HCO3-28 AnGap-13 . IMAGING ___ Cardiac Cath: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated two vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA was normal. The LAD was patent. The LCx had less than 50% stenosis. The RCA had a 70% mid-vessel lesion and a subtotal occlusion before the bifurcation with complete occlusion of the PDA. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed systolic and diastolic arterial hypertension. 3. Successful aspiration thrombectomy, PTCA and stenting of the distal RCA into the PDA with a 3.0 x 18 mm Promus DES (see ___ comments). 4. Successful direct stenting of the mid RCA with a 3.5 x 28 mm Promus DES (see ___ comments). 5. Successful RFA AngioSeal (see ___ comments) FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Normal ventricular function. 3. Successful aspiration thrombectomy and PCI fo the distal RCA into the PDA with a 3.0 x 18 mm Promus DES. 4. Successful PCI of the mid RCA with a 3.5 x 28 mm Promus DES. ___ TTE: The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. The estimated right atrial pressure is at least 15 mmHg. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal ___ of the inferior and inferolateral walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 40-45 %). Transmitral and tissue Doppler imaging suggests normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size is normal with focal basal free wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Normal left ventricular cavity size with regional biventricular systolic dysfunction c/w CAD ___ RCA distribution). Mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None. <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *11* 3. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 5. metoprolol succinate 50 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 6. Nitrostat 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tablet Sublingual as directed as needed for chest pain. Disp: *25 tablets* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> ST Elevation myocardial infarction Acute Systolic dysfunction Dyslipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Medically Stable. Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization at ___. You were admitted because you had a heart attack. Images of your heart (catheterization) showed that critical vessels that supply blood to your heart were blocked, and so 2 stents (drug-eluting) were placed in order to keep the blood vessels open. Echocardiogram (which is an ultrasound of your heart) after the catheterization procedure showed impaired heart function. These findings predispose you to future heart problems, including fluid backup in your lower extremities and lungs. Please START taking the following medications in addition to your home medications: 1. Metoprolol - to lower your heart rate, control your blood pressure and help your heart pump better. 2. Atorvastatin - to lower your cholesterol and prevent future plaque build-up in your heart's arteries. 3. Plavix - to prevent re-occlusion of your stented arteries or blockage of the drug-eluting stent that was placed. 4. Aspirin - to prevent platelet blockage of the drug-eluting stent that was placed. 5. Lisinopril - to control your blood pressure and help your heart pump better. 6. Nitroglycerin - to alleviate heart-related chest pain. Please take this medication if you have chest pain at home that is similar to the chest pain that brought you to the hospital. Take one tablet, wait 5 minutes, then take another tablet. Please call ___ if you still have chest pain after 2 tablets, and please call Dr. ___ you use nitroglyerin at all. It is very important that you are compliant with these medications, especially Plavix (Clopidogrel) and Aspirin. Skipping or changing doses of these medications can result in life-threatening blockage of the arteries that were blocked during this heart attack. Do not stop unless your cardiologist, Dr. ___ you that it is ok. In addition, please: 1. Weigh yourself every morning, and call your primary care physician if your weight goes up by more than 3 lbs (total). 2. Continue the exercise plan that the physical therapist discussed with you during this admission. 3. Involve your family and friends in your lifestyle modifications (including low-salt/low-fat diet, aerobic exercise and new medication regimen) in order to facilitate the long-term maintenance of this care. Thank you for entrusting your health to our staff. Please contact the Heartline (___) if you have chest pain again or any other concerning symptoms.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo male with PMH of hyperlipidemia who presented with chest pain and found to have STEMI s/p 2 drug-eluting stent placement. . # Acute Inferior Myocardial Infarction (STEMI): Initial EKG showed ST elevation in II, III, aVF, V5 and V6, as well as ST depression in I, aVL, aVR, V1 and V2. Pt underwent emergent catheterization, which revealed 70% stenosis of RCA, and 100% occlusion of PDA. Aspiration thrombectomy was performed, and 2 Drug-Eluting Stents were placed (distal-RCA into PDA, mid-RCA). Post-PCI echocardiogram performed on HD 2 was notable for mild LV dysfunction, w/ EF of 40-45%, and severe hypokinesis of basal ___ inferior/inferolateral walls and mild pulmonary hypertension. His post-cath course was complicated by right groin hematoma at the site of access on HD 2, but resolved without intervention. He also developed low-grade temps to Tmax of 100.5, but was without other concerning signs or symptoms for infection or acute thromboembolic event. He was started Aspirin, Plavix, Atorvastatin, Lisinopril, and Metoprolol. He tolerated these medications well, and at time of discharge, pt had experienced no observed arrhythmias on telemetry, and was asymptomatic, feeling well and ready to go home. . # Hypertension: Pt was previously on HCTZ/lisinopril, stopped secondary to side-effects (lightheadedness). He was started on Metropolol and Lisinopril for long-term improved cardiac outcome. . # Hyperlipidemia: At time of admission, pt was not on any lipid-lowering medications, and lipid panel on this admission revealed LDL of 150, borderline low HDL and ___ 155. As pt is status-post acute myocardial infarction, he was started on atorvastatin, which will require long-term continuation. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Will have follow-up with NP ___ on ___, previous outpatient Cardiology (Dr. ___ on ___, and Dr. ___ on ___ - Will recommend CBC + BMP check-up at first outpatient consultation. - Dry weight estimated at 89kg. Will aim for healthy weight reduction via low-salt/low-fat cardiac diet.

target: ___ yo F with CAD s/p PCI to D1/LAD, DM2, HTN, HLP p/w atypical chest pain, completed ___, s/p cath with LAD DESx2 continuing to have non-exertional atypical chest pain no EKG changes. . # completed ___ . # s/p cath with LAD DESx2 - Per cath report, restenosis of the previous stent was seen and two additional stents were placed. If the patient has anginal exertional symptoms in the future, the patient should consider CABG. Cath was done despite atypical nature of chest pain. . # Atypical chest pain: Given her CAD could be cardiac. Patient has two bare metal stents placed in ___ and patient is compliant with medications. There are no EKG changes at rest and the atypical nature could be consistent with GI eitology. Patient completed ___ and ___ exercise MIBI prior to discharge. Patient was continued on ASA 325mg PO daily, plavix 75 mg PO daily and simvastatin 80mg PO daily. Beta blocker was stopped due to bradycardia. Episodes of atypical chest pain were not effected by nitroglycerin. The chest pain continued, described as burning lasting one minute coming every 15 mins, not related to exercise. Symptoms could be consistent with dissection but no difference in bilateral blood pressues and no widened mediastium per CXR. Patient was observed for an additional day and there were resolution of symptoms. . # PUMP: no signs of fluid overload . # RHYTHM: NSR . # GERD - patient is home omeprezole 20mg PO daily but continues to have some symptoms that could be consistent with GERD. Switched to H2 blocker and PRN maalox. Switched from PPI to reduce interaction with Plavix. . # HTN - Per previous notes: She was found to be hypertensive as both her Toprol and Lisinopril had been halved due to complaints of fatigue. She was also complaining of dry cough. Therefore, Lisinopril was switched to an ___, and hydrochlortiazide was added to her regimen. target: ___ with HTN, HLP, CAD s/p CABG ___, DM2 (10.9% in ___, obesity, heavy cigarette smoking, presented with inferior STEMI, taken to cath lab which showed 2-vessel CAD and now s/p ___ ___. # ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION s/p 2 DES. Patient presented with chest pain and was found to have ECG with inferior ST elevations and was taken emergently to cath lab and now s/p ___. His ___ graft has 90% thrombotic stenosis, but other grafts looked stable. He was given Integrillin and nitroprusside in the cath lab. An aspiration thrombectomy was performed although only a small amount of material was removed. The patient was also loaded with plavix and aspirin. He was started on 75 mg plavix and 81 aspirin. A post-cath TTE showed an EF of 35%. Beta blockade was accomplished with metoprolol, and he was discharged on an increased dose (100mg) of metoprolol daily and nitroglycerin SL PRN. Lisinopril was held due to concern about renal function after angiography, and then a concern for hypotension. outpatient. The patient refused statin therapy due to a history of intolerance. On discharge, he was chest pain free. # DM2. The patient was initially placed on sliding scale insuling, but he had adverse reactions to insulin while inpatient, consisting of chest pressure and warmth. This was changed to his home glipizide as the patient refused insulin due to this reaction. A HgbA1C measured during this hospitalization was 9.7%. # HYPERTENSION. Continued metoprolol as above. Lisinopril was not started due to concern for renal function and hypotension. # HYPERLIPIDEMIA. Patient reported a history of intolerance to statins and was unwilling to initiate therapy during this hospitalization. # DEPRESSION, ANXIETY. Stable at present. Homeless but currently living in friend's basement. His home amitryptyline and clonazepam were continued. He was seen by social work who assisted patient in coping with his diagnosis and helped arrange for home ___. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - restart lisinopril when blood pressure tolerates - consider spironolactone - encourage adherence to high-dose statin

target: Primary Reason for Hospitalization: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a PMH significant for unilateral kidney, ADHD, and hyperlipidemia who presents with chest pain and concern for NSTEMI who converted to STEMI, now s/p cardiac catheterization with 2DES to RPL. Active Diagnoses: # STEMI: Patient is obese, has hyperlipidemia, and had some classic signs of MI on presentation (chest pain at rest, diaphoresis) with continued rise in troponins. Pt was started on a heparin drip. He was also placed on a nitro drip for pain control. He was taken urgently to cath ___ ___levations in inferior leads. Has found to have tight stenosis in RPL, CTO of the RPDA. 2 drug eluting stents were placed in the RPL. Post-procedure, patient had no further CP. He was started on Toprol XL 50mg daily, ASA 325, atorvastatin 80mg daily and prasugrel. Peak CK's 815 with trop 2.45. A1C nl and lipid panel with LDL at 127, <70 is goal. Mr. ___ did not have recurrence of chest pain after the procedure. # Fever: Two days prior to discharge, patient spiked fever, as high as 102.4F. He felt myalgias, but denied headache, dyspnea, cough, sputum production, dysuria. Fever responded to tylenol, but patient continued to spike over next day. Developed some diarrhea, but was C. diff negative. Rapid flu was negative at time of discharge. He was started on levofloxacin and will continue on discharge for 1 week course given questionable infiltrate on CXR which is concerning for pneumonia. He was afebrile at the time of discharge. # Mild tranaminitis: No abdominal pain to suggest acute etiology, has had elevated ALT in past but not elevated AST, most recently checked ___. RUQ ultrasound showed fatty infiltration, no acute changes, possible cyst vs granuloma, suggest repeat in 3 months. Hep serologies negative for acute infection. Patient will follow-up ultrasound with PCP. # ADD/Depression: He was continued on Wellbutrin and Prozac per home regimen. Ritalin was held in the setting of ACS. TRANSITION OF CARE ISSUES: -Repeat US will be required in 3 months (or MRI immediately) to evaluate 2.1 hypoecoic liver mass. RUQ U/S findings IMPRESSION: 1. Echogenic liver consistent with fatty infiltration. Other forms of liver disease, including more significant hepatic fibrosis or cirrhosis, cannot be excluded on the basis of this examination. 2. 2.1-cm hypoechoic region in left lobe of liver is favored to represent focal fatty sparing, although a solid liver nodule cannot be excluded. This could be further evaluated with MRI. If MRI is not performed, then short interval followup with repeat ultrasound in three months is recommended. 3. Simple cyst in right hepatic lobe and probable granuloma in left lateral segment (versus biliary hamartoma). 4. Absent right kidney. Parapelvic cyst in upper pole of left kidney. 5. Fundal adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder without evidence of gallstones.

target: In summary, the patient is a ___ male with PMH significant for HTN, hyperlipidemia, CAD, s/p MI x 4 ( CABG x 4 in ___, s/p SVG-OM2 stenting in ___ and re-stenting in ___ (DES), & known occluded SVG-RCA, severe PVD with multiple stents, and s/p renal artery and carotid artery stenting who presents now with history consistent with stable angina. . #. Unstable Angina /Coronary Artery Disease: Mr. ___ has multiple risk factors including multiple prior MIs, hyperlipidemia, extensive CAD, widespread peripheral vascular disease and current tobacco abuse. Per history, he claimed he had not had active anginal symptoms in ~ ___ years. However, his family and spouse claimed he had more frequent episodes that occured so this timeline was questioned and his presentation was more fitting for stable angina vs. unstable angina. Given his complex cardiac anatomy with multiple stents and grafts, a new blockage in a coronary graft or a stent re-occlusion was initially questioned. Fortunately, his EKG showed no ST-elevations or ST-depressions and overall, his EKG was largely unchanged when compared to prior EKG from ___. His CAD history is notable for four prior myocardial infarctions, and a quadruple CABG in ___. He is also status-post SVG-OM2 graft stenting in ___ and again in ___. He has a known occluded SVG-RCA. Mr. ___ cardiac enzymes were trended and were all negative for an acute event. Telemetry showed no new concerning ectopy. He was continued on medical management with daily 325mg aspirin, Plavix, statin therapy with lipitor, and Toprol XL. Repeat lipid profile showed good control with LDL 51, total cholesterol 119, and HDLs also 51. He was also ordered for additional PRN SL NTG but he had no significant repeat chest pains after transfer to ___. Because his pain subsided, no IV anticoagulation was started overnight. He was set up for a stress MIBI in the morning to assess perfusion defects/ischemia. Stress ECHO showed no significant ECG changes during dobutamine infusion. 2D echocardiographic evidence of prior myocardial infarction was present without any new inducible ischemia. He had a normal hemodynamic response to dobutamine infusion. Thus, he was not felt to have any new occlusions and no additional interventions were planned. Instead his medical management was adjusted for better symptomatic relief of his stable angina, and at time of discharge his Isosorbide Dinitrate was uptitrated to 40mg PO TID. He was also transfused with one unit of blood for his underlying anemia (Hct 26) which was also likely contributing to his frequent angina. . #. Grade I/II Systolic and Grade I Diastolic Heart Failure: Last ECHO ___ showed some mild diastolic dysfunction and mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal hypokinesis of basal to mid-inferolateral wall and some hypokinesis of the mid-to- distal septum. The remaining segments contracted normally and his LVEF was 45-50 %. Clinically, the patient seemed euvolemic on this admission with no signs of acute decompensation. He had a normal range JVP, and no crackles on lung exam. No pedal edema and no prominent dyspnea complaints at rest. Repeat ECHO on this admission showed similar results to prior ECHO with no new regional wall motion abnormalities and no new significant valve disease. LVEF was also about the same at 45-50%. Mr. ___ was continued on his ACE-inhibitor/lisinopril and Toprol XL therapy. He was also reminded to limit his daily sodium intake and to weigh himself daily and notify his doctor if he gained more than 3 lbs. . #. Rhythm: The patient has a known history of first degree A-V delay and bradycardia in the aftermath of his prior inferior MI. On this admission his heart rate was mostly in the 6Os, NSR, ___ degree AV prolongation remained. Continuous telemetry monitoring picked up only rare PVCs, and repeat EKGs did not reveal any new concerning arrhythmias. . #Hypertension: On arrival to the cardiology floor his blood pressures were in the 130s/60s range but he had missed some of his usual home medications per family. Later, repeat measures showed lower normotensive ranges. Thus, he was continued on the same daily regimen of his usual Norvasc, Lisinopril, and Toprol XL. . # Smoking: Smoking cessation counseling was re-emphasized on admission and throughout his hospital course. . #Chronic Renal Insufficiency: Unclear etiology, likely related to his long-term hypertension. Baseline creatinine ___ range per OSH records. On transfer creatinine was 2.29 and it improved to 2.0 at time of discharge. Team monitored daily BUN/Cr trend closely. . #Hyperkalemia: Just prior to transfer his potassium was elevated to 5.4 at outside hospital. He was given some kayexalate and repeat potassium levels after arrival to ___ were improved to 4.7 and 4.6. This rise was likely due to his constipation which had been worsened by recent high dose iron infusions. He was placed on a bowel regimen as outlined below. Otherwise, he is on an ACE-I and he has some underlying chronic renal insufficiency at baseline which both predispose him to some high-normal range potassium levels. . #. Peripheral Vascular Disease: He has a history of severe PVD with multiple stents in place. He is status-post left iliac stenting, which was then re-stented for restenosis. He also had a prior fem-fem bypass for right iliac occlusion. He has been followed closely by Dr. ___ for ___ years. He continues to have mild to moderate claudication symptoms at baseline. He was continued on his usual daily 325mg aspirin and Plavix. . # Anemia: Per patient's daughter his last colonoscopy was a little over year ago and he is due for a repeat colonoscopy later this month which will be set-up over this next week per family. He was diagnosed with colon cancer in ___ and he is status-post colectomy, also done in ___. Currently, he denies bloody stool on history. Last Hematocrit in OMR was in ___ and was in the ___ range. Now he presents with a Hct in the 26 range. MCV of 73 is consistent with microcytic anemia which was recently diagnosed according to the patient's family. He was given IV iron infusions 2 days prior to this admission in light of this new diagnosis. This explains his current iron level of 582. Otherwise, his B12 and folate levels were in normal ranges and his TIBC, ferritin, and transferrin were all normal as well. Patient was asked to follow-up with his primary care M.D. within 2 weeks of discharge for ongoing evaluation of his anemia, particularly with his colon cancer history. CEA was checked and was WNL and LFTs all WNL as well. Mr. ___ anemia was likely contributing to some of his more frequent anemia as well. Thus, he was consented and transfused with 1 unit of blood prior to his discharge. He was also asked to continue oral iron tablets with additional Colace for constipation prevention. . #. Fluids, Electrolytes and Nutrition: Mr. ___ was continued on a cardiac healthy diet and was briefly kept NPO for stress testing. Team monitored electrolytes and he was repleted daily as needed. . #. Prophylaxis: The patient was continued on SCDs/pneumoboots for DVT prevention, and Colace/Senna were given for bowel regimen in setting of recent iron infusion and constipation. . #.Code Status: The patient was maintained as a full code status for the entirety of his hospital stay, this was confirmed with the patient. . .

You were transferred from ___ with concerns for unstable angina and heart issues. You were medically optimized with Aspirin, Plavix, beta-blocker, and heparin before proceeding to the cardiac catheterization lab. Your cardiac catheterization showed evidence of an occluded branch off of the left anterior descending artery which was not intervened upon; it also showed stenosis of a the right coronary artery which was stented with a single drug-eluting stent. You also had an exercise stress test prior to discharge which showed no EKG changes of concern and you had no pain symptoms. You were discharged in stable condition. . Please call your doctor or go to the emergency department if: * You experience new chest pain, pressure, squeezing or tightness. * Worsening swelling in your legs or a weight gain of 3 lbs or more, fatigue or excessive weakness. * You develop new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheezing. * You are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids, or your medications. * If you are getting dehydrated due to continued vomiting, diarrhea, or other reasons. Signs of dehydration include: dry mouth, rapid heartbeat, or feeling dizzy or faint when standing. * You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit, or have a bowel movement. * You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your urine, or experience an unusual discharge. * Your pain is not improving within 12 hours or is not under control within 24 hours. * Your pain worsens or changes location. * You have shaking chills, or fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit or 38 degrees Celsius. * You develop any other concerning symptoms. . CHANGES IN YOUR MEDICATION RECONCILIATION: * Upon admission, we ADDED the following medications: You should START: Aspirin 325 mg PO daily You should START: Metoprolol 50 mg XL PO once daily You should START: Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily You should START: Amlodipine 10 mg PO daily You should CHANGE: increase your Lisinopril from 20 mg to 40 mg PO daily You should START: Nicotine 14 mg TD patch daily You should START: Imdur 30 mg PO daily You should START: Colace and Senna for a bowel regimen . * The following medications were DISCONTINUED on admission and you should NOT resume: DISCONTINUE: Atenolol . YOU SHOULD STOP SMOKING, AS THIS IS CONTRIBUTING TO THE WORSENING OF YOUR CARDIAC DISEASE. . * You should continue all of your other home medications as prescribed, unless otherwise directed above.
target: IMPRESSION: ___ with a PMH significant for CAD (s/p MI ___ without intervention), CVA/stroke (___), L carotid stenosis, recurrent DVT (on Coumadin, INR 1.6 on admission), who presented to ___ with unstable angina, who was medically optimized and transferred to ___ for further management . PLAN: # CORONARIES - The patinet has no history of cardiac catheterization procedures, but pharmacologic-stress with perfusion at the outside hospital (___) showed anterior and anteroapical ischemia with no fixed deficits. The EKG demonstrated sinus bradycardia at 49, NA, TWI lead aVL, with no acute ST-changes. The patient's troponins were negative times three-sets at the outside hospital. The patient was started on Aspirin, Plavix, beta-blocker, and heparin gtt as the outside hospital before transfer. The patient went for cardiac catheterization on ___ which showed evidence of right-sided coronary artery stenosis and a single drug-eluting stent was placed in this area; there was also an occluded diagonal branch off the LAD which was not intervened upon. Following her cardiac cath, the patient developed an episode of substernal chest pain and jaw pain with associated hypertensive urgency requiring a Nitroglycerin gtt for control of her systolic blood pressure. Serial EKGs were concerning for areas of ST-elevation in leads II, III and ST changes in leads V1-3. She was re-loaded with Plavix 300 mg PO, received an Aspirin 325 mg PO and was restarted on a heparin gtt, all on the evening of ___ (into the early morning hours of ___ following her cardiac cath procedure. Her CK-MBs were trended and were normal and reassuring. With the above medical optimization, her chest and jaw pain subsided without further issue. There was concern that the RCA stent was not treating her symptoms and that the occluded diagonal lesion may be the culprit. On ___, a low intensity exercise stress test was performed to assess for residual pain and showed a hypertensive response to exercise with no anginal type symptoms or ST-changes at a high cardiac demand and a poor functional capacity. We added Imdur 30 mg PO daily for better BP control and to improve her anginal symptoms. The patient had no further issues with chest pain and serial EKGs were reassuring. She was discharged in stable condition. . # PUMP - The patient had a 2D-Echo in ___ showing that ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function were normal (LVEF >55%) and on recent perfusion study her LVEF was 55%. There is no evidence of CHF, as she has no volume overload (stable left leg swelling, no crackles or elevated JVD). She was continued on her home dose of Lisinopril, was started on Metoprolol and her daily weights were monitored, her I/Os were monitored and she was assessed daily for volume overload. . # RHYTHM - The patient was noted to be in sinus bradycardia on admission with some ___ second pauses on telemetry. She was asymptomatic (no syncope, lightheadedness or dizziness). We continued to monitor her and performed electrolyte optimization with continuous telemetry monitoring. . # DIABETES MELLITUS, TYPE 2 - The patient has a known history of NIDDM, has been on Levemir in the past, but has discontinued Insulin in the last 6-months. She is currently on Metformin at home and has been on Actos previously. Her HbA1c is unknown and was noted to be 10.7% this admission. She has no evidence of retinopathy or nephropathy; but she does have evidence of left leg neuropathy (has been on Tramadol PRN). We discussed that she should consider starting Gabapentin or another neuropathic pain medication for LLE neuropathy as an outpatient. We monitored her blood glucose Q6 hours and continued her on an insulin sliding scale. Her oral hypoglycemics were held until she resumed diet and following her cardiac catheterization procedure. . # HYPERTENSION - The patient has a history of hypertension controlled with ACEI, beta-blocker (Atenolol on admission) with Imdur, and we continued her on the above regimen, with the addition of Amlodipine for further control; her goal SBP was < 130/80. She was weaned from the Nitroglycerin infusion as noted above with transition to an oral anti-hypertensive regmien, without issues. . # HISTORY OF DEEP VENOUS THROMBOSIS - The patient has a history of recurrent DVTs of the LLE, but without pulmonary embolus history. The patient has been on Coumadin with regular INR checks and her three DVT events were when she was not anticoagulated. She arrived heparinized given the concern for ACS. Once heparin was discontinued on ___, her Coumadin dose of 5 mg PO daily was re-initiated with good effect. . # TOBACCO USE - The patient is a current 1-PPD smoker with over 30 pack-year; patient has a desire to quit and realizes the implications of continued smoking on her heart disease. She was prescribed a Nicotine patch 14 mg TD daily patch this admission, and we provided smoking cessation counseling provided. . TRANISTION OF CARE ISSUES: 1. Please follow-up with your primary care physician as an outpatient. 2. You should continue regular follow-up with Cardiology. 3. There were no pending laboratory studies, radiology reports or microbiology studies at the time of discharge. 4. The patient was discharged on Atorvastatin 80 mg PO daily and prior authorization forms were completed and faxed to Mass Health before her discharge.

The heart size is within normal limits. The mediastinal contours demonstrate a tortuous descending aortic contour with calcified atherosclerotic disease of the aortic knob. The hila are normal appearing bilaterally. The lungs are hyperinflated with flattening of both hemidiaphragms suggestive of COPD. There is no consolidation or mass noted. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Again, clips are noted in the right infraclavicular region. IMPRESSION: COPD without evidence for acute cardiopulmonary process - CTA Chest: Non-contrast images demonstrate coronary artery, atherosclerotic aortic, aortic valvular calcifications. There is no pericardial effusion. There is no intramural hematoma mediastinal hemorrhage. Contrast-enhanced images demonstrate an ascending aortic graft, cross-sectional dimension of the ascending aorta measuring 3.9x4.6 cm, unchanged. The aortic valve is tricuspid with small aortic valvular calcification. There is no evidence of aortic dissection. The descending aorta is dilated and unchanged in size, measuring 4.4 X 4.1 X 4.7 cm on AP, TRV, OBL ___ with an abrupt transition at the diaphragmatic hiatus and turbuluant flow causing a ___ appearace. Coronary artery calcifications are present. The pulmonary artery is normally opacified without evidence of pulmonary embolism. The patient is s/p CABG with patent LIMA and RIMA grafts. There are numerous prominent mediastinal nodes that measure up to 1.1 cm in short axis. Most of them are unchanged with the exception of a left paratracheal node that measures 1.1 x 1.4 cm compared to prior 1.1 x 0.5 cm (3: 43). There is no hilar or axillary adenopathy. There is no supraclavicular adenopathy. There is bilateral severe centrilobular and paraseptal emphysema. The tracheobronchial tree is patent to subsegmental level. Another right lower lobe pulmonary nodule (3: 47), less than 2 mm in size is also unchanged. There are no new or worrisome pulmonary nodules. There is mild reflux of contrast into the hepatic veins suggesting underlying right heart failure. Limited evaluation of the imaged upper abdomen is grossly unremarkable. There are no suspicious intraosseous lesions. IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic syndrome. 2. Toprol XL 200 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnoses: - Chest pain, not otherwise specified, likely musculoskeletal in etiology - Syncope Secondary Diagnoses: - Coronary artery disease, with small vessel coronary artery disease and associated angina - Hyperlipidemia - Hypertension - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Primary Diagnoses: - Chest pain, not otherwise specified, likely musculoskeletal in etiology - Syncope Secondary Diagnoses: - Coronary artery disease, with small vessel coronary artery disease and associated angina - Hyperlipidemia - Hypertension - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ for a chest pain that is unlike your usual anginal symptom. The CT scan of your chest showed no lung clots or aortic aneurysm but it did show stable small lung nodules compared to the past. The EKG for your heart did not show concerning changes compared to the past, and the lab studies did not signs of injury in your heart. The chest pain you are experiencing is less likely from the heart. However, you have had recent events when you passed out. It is less likely that this is from low blood pressure with positional changes. Your blood pressure and heart rate actually remained stable with positional changes. It is possible that the fainting is due to arrythmia in your heart. You were offered to have ___ of Heart to monitor the rhythm of your heart to look for causes of these fainting spells. However, you decided not to wear it because you don't have a land line to call in if you were to be informed of arrhythmias. Please note that there is NO change in your medication list. You should continue to take your current medications as prescribed by your health care providers. Please follow up with your primary care physician and your cardiologist as scheduled. - Your primary care provider ___ need to help you to monitor the small stable lung nodules found on the CT scan of your chest as well manage your coronary artery disease and other chronic illness. - You can discuss with your cardiologist about the potential of using ___ of Heart during your appointment with him. Even though you have not had a acute episode of heart failure, you should weight yourself regularly to know what your normal weight is. Signs of heart failure include fatigue, worsening shortness of breath, swelling in your lower extremities and/or belly, and discomfort in your chest. You should let your doctor know if your weight increased more than 3 lbs and with the above mentioned symptoms.
target: This is a ___ yo M with history of MI s/p CABG and stent admitted for chest pain on ___ and discharged on ___. 1. Chest pain, likely musculoskeletal. Patient reported this chest pain felt different than the one that brought him into the hospital last month, as this one is more throbbing in nature after changing a tire. Given his significant cardiac history, he was evaluated for ACS. His cardiac biomarkers remained negative 3x and EKG without much change during hospital stay despite the fact that the chest pain started the day PTA. Of note, d-dimer was elevated. A CTA was done to evaluate for possible pulmonary embolism or aortic aneurysm/dissection; however, no pulmonary embolism or aortic aneurysm/dissection was found. Last hospital course was reviewed along with the previous cardiac catheterization report and stress test, it is thought that he most likely have small vessel CAD that cannot be intervened by cardiac catheterization. His chest pain was also atypical for ACS with relief mostly from percocet and morphine. Patient refused to use nitroglycerin for chest pain during the hospital course as it causes him headache. No new antianginal medication was started at this time. His medications were unchanged during this hospital course. This should be followed up closely with his primary care physician as well as his cardiologist. Additional antianginal medication, such as ranolazine, could be considered for the future. 2. Syncope. It was noted that patient had history of seizure and has been off of Dilantin for some time. He experienced 1x syncope after the nuclear stress test during his last hospital stay. At that time, it was thought this could be due to orthostatic hypotension. He had another episode on the day of admission. Patient was unable to elaborate much about the event as he did not remember, but he did not recall feeling warm or nauseous prior to passing out. Orthostatic blood pressure was obtained during this hospital course, and it was found to be BP 102/44 and HR 44 (lying), 100/40 and HR 52 (sitting), 96/50 and 48 (standing). He was asymptomatic throughout the process. When he was walking in the hall way, no concerning abnormal rhythm was observed on telemetry. Patient was initially open to wearing ___ of Heart monitor to monitor for concerning arrhythmia that could be potentially the cause of his syncope, but he later declined because he does not have a land line phone for communication. This should be followed up by his primary care physician and cardiologist. If cardiac causes can be ruled out in the outpatient setting, may need to consider a neurological cause for these syncopes. 3. Small vessel CAD. He continued on home rosuvastatin 40 mg, lisinopril 20 mg, ASA 325 mg, and metoprolol XL 200 mg upon discharge to home. This should be followed up again by his primary care physician and cardiologist. See #1 for details. 4. COPD, chronic. Patient was in no acute respiratory distress during the hospital course. Per patient, he has been cutting down on the amount of tobacco smoking. Albuterol was initially held during the work up for ACS. However, as he ruled out for an ACS, he was restarted on albuterol. He refused his other COPD medications, such as Advair. Patient was discharged on home medications. This can be followed up again by his primary care physician. 5. Hypertension. BP remained within acceptable range while in house. Patient was continued and discharged on home medication. This can be followed up again by his primary care physician. 6. Hyperlipidemia. Lipid profile with elevated LDL. No change was made. He was discharged on home Crestor. This should be followed up by his primary care physician.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Codeine / Pork Derived (Porcine) <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr ___ is a ___ with hx of CAD s/p CABG and PCI x3, COPD, tobacco abuse and recent spinal fusion surgery who p/w chest pain and sob x6 days. The patient states that last ___ (___) he began feeling "like garbage" and developed chest pain that felt like pressure. The pain was not associated with exertion and was occasionally pleuritic. On ___ he developed shortness of breath as well, and could not walk up five steps without having to stop to catch his breath. He has a baseline cough due to smoking but had increased cough and production of sputum that was white or yellow, without blood. He also notes vomiting after eating for several days, though has been able to hold down food for the last 24h and is regaining an appetite. He noted a fever to 101 a few days ago and ___ yesterday. He was unsure if he had chills or sweats. The patient denies sick contacts but was recently hospitalized for spinal fusion surgery. Of note, on that admission he developed a slightly increased oxygen requirement thought to be due to mucous plugging or aspiration. He also has been a 30pack year smoker and recently increased from smoking ___ to 1ppd since he's been sitting around after surgery. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. . In the ED, initial vitals were afebrile, 89, 166/68, 16, 98%2L. The patient had a CXR showing right middle lobe consolidation and was given azithro 500 mg and cetriaxone. He also was felt to be in a copd exacerbation and was given prednisone 60 mg x1, and duonebs. He got 0.4 SL NTG x 1 here, 1 at home which made him feel nauseous, and morphine 12 mg total with some relief of pain.He also noted some decreased chest pressure with nebs. . On the floor the patient remained afebrile with stable vital signs. He continued to complain of ___ chest pain and back and abdominal pain from his recent surgery. He was comfortable on room air and denied significant shortness of breath. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CAD s/p MI and CABG (___) with patent LIMA to the LAD, RIMA to the RCA, PCI in ___ with BMS in the RCA just distal to his RIMA touchdown, status post MI ___ years ago. Repeat PCI in ___ showed widely patent LIMA and RIMA grafts; patent distal RCA stent and known occluded native LAD and RCA. ___ nuclear stress test showed no anginal symptoms or ischemic ST segment changes. -chronic small vessel angina -Alcohol abuse- couple beers/3 weeks -Tobacco abuse- 1ppd/3 days since age ___ -Hypercholesterolemia -Hypertension -COPD on 2L home O2 overnight -History of head trauma in ___ from MVA with post-traumatic grand mal seizure was on Dilantin, off on Dilantin. Has not had a seizure for years -Thoracic aortic anuerysm s/p repair ___ -neurogenic claudication -s/p spinal stenosis surgery ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> positive for early CAD Mother - died of MI at ___. Father - died at ___ of "MI and cancer." Cousin with MI at ___. Paternal uncle died with MI @ ___ Sister with borderline diabetes. Brother died of throat cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 98.___.5 128/55 59 20 95%RA GENERAL: thin man in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple without jvd CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No ___ mid peaking systolic murmur radiating to the carotids. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: Medial sternotomy scar, right upper chest scars (one iatrogenic, one from being stabbed). No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. tight air movement, no crackles or wheezes. ABDOMEN: Soft, mildly tender around midline scar, well approximated, nonerythematous. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 45PM CK-MB-2 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 10: 35AM GLUCOSE-120* UREA N-9 CREAT-0.5 SODIUM-136 POTASSIUM-4.6 CHLORIDE-96 TOTAL CO2-27 ANION GAP-18 ___ 10: 35AM estGFR-Using this ___ 10: 35AM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 10: 35AM WBC-7.1 RBC-4.90 HGB-12.4* HCT-37.5* MCV-77* MCH-25.3* MCHC-33.0 RDW-14.0 ___ 10: 35AM NEUTS-75.8* ___ MONOS-3.3 EOS-1.6 BASOS-1.3 ___ 10: 35AM PLT COUNT-292 ___ 10: 35AM ___ PTT-27.6 ___ 2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM: ___ The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. A patent foramen ovale is present. A right-to-left shunt across the interatrial septum is seen at rest. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinesis of the anterior septum and apex. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic valve. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. No mass or vegetation is seen on the mitral valve. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Bubbles are seen to pass across the interatrial septum on release of the Valsalva maneuver. Normal regional and global biventricular sysotlic function. Mild aortic regurgitation. If clinically suggested, the absence of a vegetation by 2D echocardiography does not exclude endocarditis. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, a bubble study was performed and is positive. . ETT: ___ This ___ year old male with PMH of CAD s/p CABG ___, PCI ___. Asymptomatic at time of testing. The patient was given 0.142mg/kg/min of Dipyridamole over 4 minutes. The patient reported no anginal symptoms during the infusion or in recovery. There were no ST segment changes throughout the study. They rhythm was sinus with poor R wave progression and 1 vpb late in recovery. Dipyridamole was reversed with 125mg Aminophylline IV. Appropriate hemodynamic response; of note pt had blunted heart rate response as he is beta blocked. Of note, patient had low resting blood pressure of 110/50 to begin study, as low as 95/42 during infusion. Following the study patient had a brief syncopal episode without ECG changes noted. Pt fell on to his right arm with no complaints or apparent injuries after fall. Pt recovered quickly repeat blood pressure 110/50. Pt had no neurologic deficits following incident. IMPRESSION: No anginal type symptoms or ischemic ECG changes with transient orthostatic hypotension in late recovery. Nuclear report sent seperately. . CARDIAC CATH: cath x8 PCI x3, most recent cath ___, not logged ___ FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel native CAD. 2. Patent LIMA with distal 90% lesion of RIMA-RCA touchdown. 3. Stenting of RCA with bare metal stent via RIMA. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet ___ Tablets q4h prn albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler ___ puff q4h prn diazepam 5 mg Tablet 1 tab q6h prn spasm docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule BID fluticasone-salmeterol 250-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device One (1) Disk with Device Inhalation twice a day. fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension One (1) Spray Nasal twice a day. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet daily metoprolol succinate 200 mg daily omeprazole 40 mg Capsule daily rosuvastatin 40 mg daily sennosides 8.6 mg Tablet BID tiotropium bromide 18 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device daily percocet ___ tabs q6h prn pain asa 325mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. albuterol sulfate 90 mcg/Actuation HFA Aerosol Inhaler Sig: Two (2) puffs Inhalation four times a day. Disp: *1 inhaler* Refills: *2* 2. diazepam 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for spasm. 3. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). 4. fluticasone-salmeterol 250-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: One (1) Disk with Device Inhalation BID (2 times a day). Disp: *1 month supply* Refills: *2* 5. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. fluticasone 50 mcg/Actuation Spray, Suspension Sig: One (1) Spray Nasal BID (2 times a day). 7. metoprolol succinate 200 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. 8. omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 9. rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 10. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 11. tiotropium bromide 18 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device Sig: One (1) capsule Inhalation once a day. Disp: *1 month supply* Refills: *2* 12. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO q6h: prn as needed for back pain. 13. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 14. cefpodoxime 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day for 2 days. Disp: *4 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 15. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO every four (4) hours as needed for pain. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Pneumonia COPD exacerbation <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure participating in your care. You were admitted because of chest pain and shortness of breath. You were found to have a pneumonia and COPD exacerbation. You were treated with antibiotics and breathing treatments. Cardiac enzymes and ekgs showed that you were not having a heart attack. It is very important that you quit smoking tobacco. This pneumonia likely occurred because your smoking made it difficult for your lungs to clear an infection. Continuing smoking will worsen your respiratory status as well as your heart. You should also take all the medications prescribed to you. This includes tiotropium inhaler and advair inhaler as well as albuterol inhaler as needed for shortness of breath and wheezing. These are important for improving your breathing. If you do not take these medications you will be at increased risk for COPD exacerbations. Please call if you develop increasing shortness of breath, lightheadedness, dizziness, worsening chest pain not resolved with pain medication, or any other symptoms that concern you. *************** Please START the following medications: -Cefpodoxime 200mg to be taken every 12h x2 days Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.
target: Mr ___ is a ___ with hx CAD s/p cabg, s/p c. cath x8 and pci x3, with poorly managed copd, persistent tobacco abuse and recent hospitalization for spinal fusion surgery who presents with sob and cp x6 days. Given the patient's symptoms, his fever, presence of infiltrate in RML and flat cardiac enzymes, it appears that he is most likely suffering from pna with component of copd exacerbation. He was ruled out for ACS. . # PNA: started on ceftriaxone/azithro in the ED for RML infiltrate. Given recent hospitalization, could be concerned for HAP however remained afebrile on CAP regimen. Also on previous admission there was concern for aspiration. Patient remained afebrile throughout admission. He completed a 5 day course of azithromycin and was discharged with cefpodoxime to complete a 7day course. # COPD: The patient presented with increased O2 requirement, increased sputum production, and wheezes/poor air movement on exam. It was felt that a component of his sob/cp was ___ COPD. He received prednisone 60mg x3 days, ipratroprium nebs q6h, albuterol q2h prn wheezing/sob. His sats and O2 requirement improved to home levels, room air during the day with 2L at night while sleeping. Of note the patient was refusing advair during admission, stating, "I only use the marroon one at home", it was thought he was referring to an albuterol inhaler. He was counseled that it is important to utilize all of his copd medications and discharged with prescriptions in case he does not have them at home. He was also counseled regarding smoking cessation and explained the role smoking can play in decreasing respiratory status and cardiac disease. However, he expressed no interest in stopping, stating that he had stopped smoking and drinking once and attributed it to causing his heart attack. He has recently increased tobacco use from ___ to 1ppd. . # CORONARIES: hx of CAD s/p cabg ___ ago (unclear why had MI at such a young age, denies cocaine) and multiple caths and pcis since. ___ stress shows small area of reversibility in the distal anterior wall adjacent to his infarct and angiogram/cardiac catheterization from ___ has been reviewed by our interventional cardiologists multiple times and it has been determined that there are no revascularizable vessels. Given he was ruled out for ce, this CP does not seem to be ___ cardiac pain. Continued home statin, asa, lisinopril, metoprolol. Morphine ___ q4h prn chest pain initially, when ruled out, treated CP with home percocet. . # PUMP: Last ECHO shows normal regional and global biventricular systolic function. Mild aortic regurgitation. LVEF 40-50%. Appears euvolemic at present. . # RHYTHM: no hx of arrhythmia. Followed on tele. . # tobacco abuse: counseled patient about dangers of tobacco abuse as above. Pt stated he did not require nicotine patch as an inpatient. . # hx alcohol abuse: not currently drinking, no need for CIWA scale. . # s/p spinal fusion surgery: no evidence of infection. Continued home percocet ___ q6h prn back pain. . # PROPHYLAXIS: DVT ppx with subq heparin

Interventional Details Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on an ad hoc basis based on the coronary angiographic findings from the diagnostic portion of this procedure. A 6 ___ EBU3.5 guide provided adequate support. Crossed with a Prowater wire into the distal LAD. Predilated with a 2.0 mm balloon, then 2.5 predil balloon. We then wired the D2 using a Sion Blue supported by a Twinplass. An intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) imaging catheter was passed over the coronary wire distal to the region of interest. Coronary IVUS images were acquired by automated catheter pullback. We further predilated the LAD with a 3.0 cutting balloon. We placed a 3.0 x 22 Onyx DES in the mid LAD across D2. Post-dilated with a 3.5 NC balloon throughout. IVUS confirmed good stent expansion. There is an area of malapposition due to positive remodelling of the mid vessel. TIMI III flow, 0% residual stenosis in region of interest. Complications: There were no clinically significant complications. Findings - Two vessel coronary artery disease. Occluded mid LAD. The pain radiated to the LUE and was associated with diaphoresis and dyspnea. The persistence of the pain prompted him to present to the ED. Otherwise, he notes no recent changes in his health. He denies dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, or swelling. Has not had other recent chest pain. No residual chest pain. R femoral access. Echo as above - echo with Lumason negative for LV clot - Aspirin 81 daily - Continue Ticagrelor 90 BID ___ year min): PA completed and approved - Atorvastatin 80mg daily - Lisinopril 5mg daily - Metoprolol succinate 50mg daily - Outpatient cardiac rehab: referral given pending clearance at ___ follow-up appointment - Outpatient stress to evaluate further residual severe disease in a diag and OM1 branch # Hypertension: No formal prior diagnosis. SBPs 140's-150's initially, now improved to 102/55 on Ace inhibitor and Beta blocker. -Continue Metoprolol and Lisinopril -F/U with PCP # ___ contact: would like HCP to be his son ___ (___) # Family/HCP updated? yes: pt's wife and children at bedside and all questions answered to their apparent satisfaction Transitional: F/U apt made with PCP and cardiologist at ___ ___ Dispo: discharge home without services Anticipate: [x] d/c home [] d/c home with services [] d/c to rehab/LTC ****Above plan reviewed and discussed with Dr. ___. Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ because you had a heart attack. Because of this, you had a cardiac catheterization in which a drug coated stent was placed to open a blockage in your left anterior descending coronary artery. You have some residual blockages that were not intervened upon. You were started on medications to prevent them from progressing and will need a stress test in the near future to determine if they need to be treated with a stent at that time. This should be coordinated at your follow-up appointment with your cardiologist at ___ and ___. If at any point between now and your appointment you develop chest pain, please go to hospital for urgent medical evaluation. Instructions regarding care of the right radial/wrist access site and right femoral/groin access site have been included with your discharge information. Please continue your current medications with the following changes: - Start Aspirin 81mg daily, lifelong. - Start Ticagrelor 90mg twice a day, you should take this for a minimum of one year and ONLY stop when told by a cardiologist specifically. - Start Metoprolol XL 50mg daily, which helps relax your heart and lowers your blood pressure. - Start Lisinopril 5mg daily, which lowers your blood pressure and improves survival after a heart attack. - Start Atorvastatin 80mg daily, which lowers cholesterol and inflammation in your arteries. - A nitroglycerin prescription has been provided to take as needed for chest pain. Place one under your tongue at onset of chest pain. This can be repeated every five minutes times three doses. If you continue to have chest pain after three doses, call ___ for urgent medical evaluation. It is very important to take all of your heart healthy medications. In particular, aspirin and ticagrelor keep the stents in the vessels of the heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. If you stop these medications or miss ___ dose, you risk causing a blood clot forming in your heart stents, and you may die from a massive heart attack. Please do not stop taking either medication without taking to your heart doctor, even if another doctor tells you to stop the medications. It is recommended that you attend a cardiac rehab program in the near future. A referral form was provided to you that lists the locations of these programs. Please bring this with you to your follow up visit with your cardiologist, and they will inform you when it is safe to begin a program. If you have any urgent questions that are related to your recovery from your hospitalization or are experiencing any symptoms that are concerning to you and you think you may need to return to the hospital, please call the ___ HeartLine ___ at ___ to speak to a cardiologist or cardiac nurse practitioner. It has been a pleasure to have participated in your care and we wish you the best with your health! Your ___ Cardiac Care Team
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old with no medical history, taking no medication at time of admission, with exception of occasional Motrin for knee pain, who presented with STEMI V1-V4 and underwent urgent cardiac catheterization; initial attempt via right radial, then proceeded via right femoral artery reevealing the following coronary artery disease: 30% LM, LAD 60% proximal + thrombus 100% distal, D1 90%, D2 50%, Ramus 70%, DES to CTO of LAD with jailed D2. Occluded mid LAD 3.0 x 22 Onyx DES in the mid LAD across D2. Post-dilated with a 3.5 NC balloon throughout. IVUS confirmed good stent expansion. There is an area of malapposition due to positive remodelling of the mid vessel. TIMI III flow, 0% residual stenosis in region of interest. There were no clinically significant complications. He was started on ASA, Brilinta, metoprolol, Atorvastatin and Lisinopril. His Brilinta required PA which was approved. He had a TTE which showed and EF of 35-40% with concern initially of LV clot, repeat (limited) with contrast was negative for thrombus. He remained hemodynamically stable throughout his admission. He remains in SR in ___. He was seen by ___ per STEMI protocol. Per patient request, he will establish cardiology care at ___ ___ and ___ and should have a stress test to determine if residual CAD requires intervention versus current medical management. An appointment has been scheduled for follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___ at 10:30am at ___. A referral for Cardiac Rehabilitation was provided at time of discharge and patient was instructed to wait for clearance from his cardiologist at follow-up before initiating program. He was provided with the ___ Heartline ___ phone number, as well as contact information at ___ ___ and ___. He was instructed if anytime between now and his scheduled appointment should he develop chest pain or any concerning symptoms, that he is to be seen for urgent medical evaluation. A NTG prescription was also provided. Daughter, sons and extended family at bedside and updated in detail.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Morphine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with h/o CAD s/p MI x3 (IMI ___ treated with thrombolytics), s/p PCI of RCA and LAD ___, EF 34% in ___, HTN, hyperlipidemia, presenting with chest pain. Per the pt he developed CP, "burning", starting in the epigastrium and radiating to lt shoulder, ___, lasting for 45 minutes, while driving on ___. Since then the CP recurred when the patient was walking to the mall on the morning of ___, similar to pain while driving, and then recurred at night at bedtime. The pain is associated w/ nausea, wanting to throw up, diaphoresis, radiation to left shoulder and upper abdomen. Says its similar to GERD pain but stronger. Denies SOB or cough. The pt states that it is not similar in nature or intensity to CP before previous MI. Last stress ___ y ago. Denies recent surgeries, travel, hx blood clots, current smoking. Denies diarrhea, bloody or black stools, dysuria. In ___, pt had IMI with s/p RCA PTCA followed by a repeat IMI in ___ with LCX PTCA. Cardiac catheterization in ___ revealed 90% proximal RCA and 80% mid RCA with 40-50% LAD lesion. He received staents that spanned across the two RCA lesions but was complicated by recurrent Cp post-PCI. A re-look revealed 70% LAD thrombosis as well as RCA plaqueing through the RCA stent leading to repeat RCA stenting. In ___ he underwent nuclear stress study that revealed fixed inferior wall defect and reversible basal and mid inferolateral defect. The LV function was depressed at 34% with global hypokinesis. He underwent cath which revelaed patnet stents and non-obstructive disease. CP was thought to be non-cardiac in nature. He has had no cardiac events or workup since. In the ED initial VS were Tc 98.1, BP 107/69, HR 64, RR 14, Satting 96% on RA. He had an EKG which showed sinus 72, IVCD, T wace flattening. His troponin came back <0.01 and he had an unremarkable Chem 7, CBC, LFTs and UA. His CXR showed no acute pulmonary process. He got an aspirin GI cocktail which alleviated his pain and he became pain free. He was admitted to the cards floor for presumed unstable angina. On arrival to the floor, patient VS were Tc 97.7 BP 130/75 HR 73 RR 18 Satting 100% on RA. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS On review of systems, s/he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. S/he denies recent fevers, or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Coronary artery disease- s/p MI x3 (IMI ___ treated with thrombolytics), s/p PCI of RCA and LAD ___ Hypertension Hyperlipidemia Ischemic cardiomyopathy - EF 34% by MIBI in ___ GERD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Sister with h/o congenital heart disease. His brother died at age ___ of myocardial infarction. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PHYSICAL EXAMINATION OJN ADMIT: VS: Tc 97.7 BP 130/75 HR 73 RR 18 Satting 100% on RA GENERAL: middle aged man in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP not visualised. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. The patient exercised for 9 minutes of a Modified ___ protocol and was stopped for fatigue. The peak estimated MET capacity was 7, which represents a fair exercise tolerance for his age. There were no reports of chest, back, neck, or arm discomforts during the study. In the setting of IVCD, at peak exercise, there was 0.5-1 mm horizontal ST segment depression in the inferolateral leads that resolved by 1 minute of recovery. However, at 2 minutes of recovery, there was up to 1 mm downsloping/horizontal ST segment depression in leads V3-6, resolving back to baseline by 3 minutes of recovery. Rhythm was sinus with rare isolated APBs and VPBs during exercise. In recovery, frequent isolated VPBs were noted with occasional ventricular trigeminy. The heart rate response was appropriate during exercise and recovery. There was a mild asymptomatic drop in blood pressure at peak exercise with an appropriate response during recovery. IMPRESSION: Possible ischemic EKG changes in the setting of IVCD with no anginal type symptoms. Mild asymptomatic drop in blood pressure at peak exercise. Frequent low-grade VEA in recovery. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a history of CAD s/p CABG x2, hypertension, type II diabetes and hyperlipidemia who presented to ___ with unresponsiveness at home found to have acute pulmonary edema and elevated cardiac enzymes.
