He is now s/p NSTEMI which likely occurred between ___ to ___ associated with acute pulmonary edema. On admission to ___ there was concern that he had LBBB on EKG but he has had rate dependent LBBB with stress testing here in the past. On arrival to this hospital he was chest pain free and reported feeling well. Given his previous cateterizations which revealed diffuse disease it was felt that there was no indication for repeat evaluation. He was continued on aspirin, plavix, ranolazine and imdur. His atenolol was changed to metoprolol and titrated up as tolerated. He recently was noted to have myalgias and elevated CKs and his statin was subsequently held. He was monitored on telemetry during this admission and found to be in atrial tachycardia with rates in the ___ but without further arrhythmias. He will follow up with his primary cardiologist Dr. ___. Acute on Chronic Systolic Heart Failure: The patient presented to ___ with acute pulmonary edema and subsequently had an elevation of his cardiac enzymes. Echocardiogram at ___ ___ estimated his ejection fraction at 30%. On presentation to this hospital he had mild lower extremity edema and trace crackles in his lungs. He was treated with IV lasix with good effect. As above his atenolol was switched to metoprolol and titrated up as tolerated. During this admission he was noted to be in atrial tachycardia with rates in the ___. There was concern that given his extremely poor systolic function he was not tolerating this faster rhythm well. He underwent transesophageal echocardiogram with subsequent EP ablation of his atrial tachycardia with subsequent maintanance of sinus rhythm. He tolerated this well. He was felt to be euvolemic at the time of discharge. Atrial Tachycardia: As above, the patient was noted to be in atrial tachycardia with rates in the ___ on telemetry. He underwent transesophageal echocardiogram with subsequent EP ablation of atrial tachycardia with resulting sinus rhythm. He was anticoagulated with heparin ___ and subsequently transitioned to coumadin which he will take for one month for stroke prevention. On discharge he was placed on lovenox which he will take until his INR his therapeutic. Hypertension: His blood pressures were well controlled on this admission. He was continued on Imdur and Nifedipine. His atenolol was transitioned to metoprolol which he tolerated well. He was found to have elevated CKs as well as liver function tests. His atorvastatin and zetia were subsequently discontinued with improvement in his CKs. His liver function tests remained elevated which is likely secondary to hepatic venous congestion from right sided heart failure. He underwent right upper quadrant ultrasound during this admission which showed a normal liver contour but confirmed hepatic venous congestion. He will follow up with his cardiologist for consideration of rechallenge with lipid agents. Diabetes mellitus Type 2: His Last HgA1c 5.9% in ___. He has recently had episodes of hypoglycemia on his 70/30 regimen in the setting of poor PO intake. His 70/30 was decreased with good effect. Stage IV Chronic Kidney Disease: The patient's baseline creatinine ranges from 1.9-2.5. His creatinine was at baseline during this admission. His medications were renally dosed. Peripheral Vascular Disease: The patient is s/p aortobifemoral bypass. He had evidence of good distal perfusion on exam. He was continued on aspirin and plavix. Depression/Anxiety: No active inpatient issues. He was continued on celexa. Tobacco Use: Counselled regarding the importance of smoking cessation. He was given a prescription for a nicotine patch.

Family is not available at the bedside and the patient is aphasic, so history was gleaned from bedside charts. The patient was eating dinner with her neice around 5 ___ when she suddenly started choking on food. Her niece noted R sided weakness and difficulty speaking, so called ___. Cardiology saw the patient stat and felt she either had a STEMI, or demand ischemia which causes ST elevations in the setting of prior CABG. Repeat EKG was checked in the ED and was mostly normalized. Trop T was elevated only to 0.03. The patient denied chest pain. Cardiology felt that the patient was very high risk for cardiac cath and would defer procedure in the setting of TPA, unless she became hemodynamically unstable. They recommended aspirin, statin, and beta blocker (when able from a neurologic perspective). <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - CABG x 4 in ___ at ___ (Dr. ___ - Left pleural effusion postoperative s/p CABG, s/p thoracocentesis - left upper lobe lung nodule, followed at ___ - s/p MI - DM2 - CVA - B12 deficiency - ___ Neuropathy - DJD/LS - dementia - HLD - Asthma - ___ disease <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother had breast cancer and died from this; father died of an MI; brother had a myocardial infarction but is alive and well. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ON ADMISSION: General: NAD, lying in bed comfortably. Limb Ataxia: 0 8. Sensory: 1 9. Language: 2 10. Dysarthria: 1 11. Extinction and Neglect: 0 - Mental Status - Awake, alert, follows simple commands. Incomprehensible speech: overall with a paucity of speech, but she likely has a mixed aphasia since she is babbling somewhat with syllables without meaning, but at other times appears frustrated and unable to communicate. ++ dysarhtria as well. - Cranial Nerves - Equal and reactive pupils. + blink to threat bilaterally. Able to look at examiner fully to the R and to the L. R facial droop. Symmetric palate elevation and tongue protrusion. - Motor - Muscule bulk and tone were normal. No drift. No tremor or asterixis. Delt Bic Tri ECR IP Quad Ham TA Gas L 5 5 ___ 5 5 5 5 R 5 5 ___ 5 5 5 5 - Sensation - The patient indicates there may be a sensory change on the R arm compared to the L but is unable to further describe it - DTRs - ___ throughout. - Cerebellar - FNF intact. DISCHARGE EXAM: Neurologic: Mental Status: Awake, alert. Minimal verbal output with mumbled syllables but no clear spontaneous speech. Does not repeat. Oriented to place (able to choose "hospital" from a list, but not the year). Follows midline commands. Mimics well. Cranial Nerves: Decreased blink to threat on the right side. Right nasolabial fold flattening. Motor: Tone is symmetric bilaterally. Moves all extremities antigravity. Right side is slower to activate and can be overcome; on confrontation testing right-sided deltoids, triceps and biceps were at least ___, wrist extensors ___ and finger extensors ___. Lower extremity moves at least antigravity. Differential showed 84% neutrophils but no left shift. Patient was afebrile. This triggered an infectious workup. CXR showed no pneumonia. MICROBIOLOGY: ___ URINE CULTURE-FINAL NEGATIVE ___ BLOOD CULTURE x2 - NO GROWTH TO DATE CARDIAC ENZYMES: ___ 09: 15PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.03* ___ 08: 50AM BLOOD CK-MB-21* MB Indx-14.3* cTropnT-0.50* ___ 06: 25PM BLOOD CK-MB-16* cTropnT-0.56* ___ 04: 59AM BLOOD CK-MB-10 cTropnT-0.55* ___ 03: 37PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.47* IMAGING: CTA head/neck ___: 1. No evidence of definite acute intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect. Subtle hyperdensity along the left tentorium could be due to partial volume averaging or early hemorrhage. 2. Brain parenchymal volume loss, sequelae of chronic microangiopathy, and prior infarcts. 3. No evidence of aneurysm, vascular malformation, or occlusion within the vasculature of the head and neck. 4. Scattered atheromatous disease including calcification of the bilateral proximal internal carotid arteries without evidence of significant stenosis by NASCET criteria. 5. Focal areas of narrowing within more distal branches of intracranial vasculature, likely representing atheromatous disease. 6. Ground-glass right upper lobe pulmonary nodules, as described above. RECOMMENDATION(S): Recommended dedicated chest CT imaging for further valuation pulmonary nodules. Head CT ___: 1. No change to acute intracranial hemorrhage within the medial left temporal lobe. No new areas of hemorrhage. 2. Hypodensity involving the left parietal lobe, compatible with developing infarct. 3. Stable right frontal encephalomalacia. Echo ___: The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls and distal septum. The remaining segments contract normally (biplane LVEF = 38 %). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). No intraventricular thrombus is seen. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with regional systolic dysfunction c/w CAD. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Moderate pulmonary artery hypertension. Fish Oil (Omega 3) 1000 mg PO DAILY 11. Klor-Con 10 (potassium chloride) 20 mEq ORAL DAILY 12. Polyethylene Glycol 17 g PO DAILY 13. Vitamin D 1000 UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> acute ischemic stroke ST-elevation myocardial infarction <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Confused - always. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of difficulty speaking resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: - high blood pressure - high cholesterol We are changing your medications as follows: - starting aspirin 81 mg - starting atorvastatin 80 mg - starting metoprolol - starting lisinopril Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician. Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team
target: ___ year old woman with a history of MI s/p CABG x 4 in ___, who presented with acute onset of aphasia and R sided weaknesss as well as STEMI, s/p TPA at an OSH for acute stroke, who was transferred to ___ for post TPA management. # Left MCA Ischemic Strokes (parietal and frontal): MRI confirms left MCA stroke of the inferior division as well as distal superior division branch. Her course has been complicated by worsening of right sided weakness after presentation as well as a small left medial temporal lobe hemorrhage which is likely from the tPA. On exam she has profound aphasia and right sided weakness. Stroke workup revealed HBA1c 6, LDL 220. She was started on ASA 81mg and atorvastatin 80mg daily. SBP was maintained under 160 given the hemorrhage. She was monitored on tele for afib as a cardioembolic source is the most likely etiology of her stroke. There were frequent PVCs but no atrial fibrillation on her telemetry. She was discharged with ___ of Hearts monitor for 30 days monitoring. # ST Elevation Myocardia Infarction and acute systolic heart failure: Upon arrival to the ___ ED after receiving tPA at ___ ___, the patient developed ST elevations in her inferior and septal leads. She was seen by cardiology and was not taken to the cath lab since the recent tPA bolus would make this procedure too high risk. The tPA given for stroke likely helped treat her STEMI as well. Given the concurrent STEMI with stroke, she may have a cardioembolic source for both (with the most likely etiology being afib, although this has not been caputured). Alternatively, her STEMI may be neurogenic, particularly as she infarcted her insula. She developed hypoxia from pulmonary edema ___ requiring IV lasix. Echo revealed an EF of 38%, worsened from recent echo ___ with EF 50-55%. She was unable to be anticoagulated acutely after the STEMI given her IPH. Cardiology was consulted. She was started on lisinopril, aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol. Her blood pressure has been elevated and so her lisinopril has been increased to 20 mg daily and her metoprolol has been advanced to goal metoprolol succinate 100 mg daily. # Leukocytosis: Developed elevated WBC count ___ but without meeting other SIRS and had no other sign of infection. CXR, UA, and cultures were unrevealing of an infectious source and her WBC count trended down. # Hyperglycemia: During her hospitalization she had elevated blood sugars to the 200s. Her A1c was 6.0% as an outpatient. In conjunction with her leukocytosis this was thought to be secondary to a stress reaction after her stroke and her STEMI. She was started on lantus and an insulin sliding scale rather than an oral diabetes medication in anticipation that her elevated blood sugars would resolve over time. TRANSITION OF CARE: - Cardiology: Will require cardiac catheterization when she is able to be anticoagulated, two weeks after her hemorrhagic transformation (___). - Should receive metoprolol tartrate 25 mg tonight, then start metoprolol succinate 100 mg daily tomorrow. - Fluid status and electrolytes: was on furosemide 20 mg daily and KCl 10 mg BID at home; here after acute pulmonary edema required furosemide 20 mg IV daily. After transitioning to oral diet, developed electrolyte abnormalities consistent with dehydration so her lasix was held. Her electrolytes should be monitored daily to determine the appropriate diuretic regimen. AHA/ASA Core Measures for Ischemic Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack 1. Antithrombotic therapy administered by end of hospital day 2? () Yes - (x) No (hemorrhagic transformation) 4. LDL documented? (x) Yes (LDL = ) - () No 5. Intensive statin therapy administered? (simvastatin 80mg, simvastatin 80mg/ezetemibe 10mg, atorvastatin 40mg or 80 mg, rosuvastatin 20mg or 40mg, for LDL > 100) (x) Yes - () No [if LDL >100, reason not given: ] 6. Smoking cessation counseling given? () Yes - (x) No [reason (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 7. Stroke education (personal modifiable risk factors, how to activate EMS for stroke, stroke warning signs and symptoms, prescribed medications, need for followup) given (verbally or written)? (x) Yes - () No 8. Assessment for rehabilitation or rehab services considered? (x) Yes - () No 9. Discharged on statin therapy? (x) Yes - () No [if LDL >100, reason not given: ] 10. Discharged on antithrombotic therapy? (x) Yes [Type: (x) Antiplatelet - () Anticoagulation] - () No 11. Discharged on oral anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter? () Yes - () No - (x) N/A

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Iodine; Iodine Containing / Bactrim / Beta-Adrenergic Blocking Agents / Heparin Agents <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Urosepsis, stroke and UGIB <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ year-old male with a history ___, PVD s/p L ___, h/o of TIA, CAD s/p stent in ___, s/p PPM for asystole, HTN, HLD, neurogenic bladder with self catherization, peripheral neuropathy initially presented to ___ with urospesis and c/b stroke and coffee ground emesis. . Please see admission note for full details. Briefly, the patient resides at a nursing for the last year after right hip fracture. He was scheduled catheterization for neurogenic bladder at baseline. He reportly had r eye pain w/ discharge, + coffee ground emesis and fevers to 102, a foley placed that returned "puss" and was given CTX 1g x2 and transferred to the ___ ED. In the ED he was guaiac negative, delerious (AAOx2) and combative. A CT a/p was negative for an acute process. Hct was 37.8 and 11.0. On the floor the patient continued to have nausea and vomiting. Then at 5: 35pm the patient's wife noticed that he had new onset of L-sided neglect and L facial weakness. A code stroke was called and CT-head did not show any acute process. He was evaluated by neurology and neuro exam improved. They were concerned of an embolic event given his frequent episodes of TIA. They recommended starting plavix and remaining on the medicine service. . The patient triggered twice in 1 hour for coffee ground emesis, fevers to 101.4 and SBP >200 and nursing concern. CE negative x3. Antibiotics were changed from po cipro back to IV CTX, IV PPI was started and transferred to the ICU for closer management. . On arrive the patient was AAOx3. He had complaints of nausea. He denied NSAID use, h/o GI bleed or varices. An NG-tube was placed lavaged with 1L that was initially coffee ground that cleared after 800cc. Patient's Hct was 32.2 (32.8 at 6pm, but 37.8 on admission). . ROS: The patient denies any chills, weight change, abdominal pain, diarrhea, constipation, melena, hematochezia, chest pain, shortness of breath, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema, cough, rash or skin changes. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -Diabetes, last A1c 6.8 -PVD s/p bypass and amputations w/ ___ ___ -CAD s/p proximal and mid-RCA stent in ___ (prior ___ states pt had CABG, but unclear if patient actually had surgery) -s/p pacemaker placement for asystole x 18seconds (___) -hypertension -presumed TIA with nonfluent aphasia ___ yrs ago -Episode of slurred speech with facial droop several months ago -hyperlipidemia -hypothyroidism -HIT -neurogenic bladder, self catheterizes -peripheral neuropathy -gastroparesis -diabetic retinopathy -syncope -colonic polyps and mild diverticulosis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father had MI. No strokes <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 102.2 BP: 160/70 HR: 78 RR: 15 O2Sat: 100% 2L GEN: chronically ill appearing, no acute distress, mildly confused and slightly combative HEENT: pupils 3mm on left, reactive to light. r cornea is clouded and 2mm and minimally reactive. pt would not cooperate with EOM. anicteric, no epistaxis or rhinorrhea, dry MM NECK: No JVD, lymphadenopathy, trachea midline COR: RRR, no M/G/R, normal S1 S2 PULM: Lungs CTAB, no W/R/R ABD: Soft, NT, ND, +BS, no HSM, no masses EXT: No C/C/E, No edema or calf pain, ___ - wound clean/dry/intact NEURO: alert, oriented to person, place, but thought it was ___. Pt with right ptosis, otherwise CN intake and non-focal. Moves all 4 extremities. Strength ___ in upper and lower extremities, but limited cooperation. SKIN: No jaundice, cyanosis, or gross dermatitis. No ecchymoses. DISCHARGE <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T: 98 BP: 160/90 (114-160/53-90)P: 70's R: 18 O2: 99 RA General: Sleeping; Alert, oriented, no acute distress; plethoric facies. Hands are tremulous HEENT: pupils 3mm on left, reactive to light. r cornea is clouded and 2mm and minimally reactive. anicteric, no epistaxis or rhinorrhea, MMM Neck: supple, JVP not elevated, no LAD Lungs: (while sleeping) Loud/Obstructive type upperway sounds that transmit throughout otherwise clear lungs with occ. wheezes. FROM **LEFT CORONARY 5) LEFT MAIN NORMAL 6) PROXIMAL LAD DIFFUSELY DISEASED 50 6A) SEPTAL-1 NORMAL 7) MID-LAD DIFFUSELY DISEASED 8) DISTAL LAD DIFFUSELY DISEASED 60 9) DIAGONAL-1 NORMAL 10) DIAGONAL-2 NORMAL 11) INTERMEDIUS NORMAL 12) PROXIMAL CX DISCRETE 60 13) MID CX DIFFUSELY DISEASED 13A) DISTAL CX DIFFUSELY DISEASED 14) OBTUSE MARGINAL-1 NORMAL 15) OBTUSE MARGINAL-2 DIFFUSELY DISEASED 70 **ARTERIOGRAPHY RESULTS TO SEGMENTS MORPHOLOGY % STENOSIS LOCATION **BYPASS GRAFT 28) SVBG #1 DIFFUSELY DISEASED 99 32) LIMA NORMAL **PTCA RESULTS SVBG PTCA COMMENTS: Initial angiography revealed a massive thrombus burden in the SVG-OM2. We planned to treat this with local thrombolytics, followed by thrombectomy and PTCA +/- stenting. A ___ Hockey stick guide provided modest support. A Prowater wire was advanced into the graft proximal to the thrombus and a 2.0mm balloon was delivered. We injected 3mg tPA through the distal lumen of the balloon x2. Interval angiography revealed no change in antegrade flow. Attempts to deliver an Export catheter were unsuccessful due to lack of guide support. We then performed PTCA with the 2.09x12mm Voyager balloon at 8, 10, and 15atm but again were unsuccessful at restoring antegrade flow. At this point the wire was removed and we exchange for a ___ AL-1 guide which provided much better support. The Prowater wire was again advanced into the native OM vessel. After intra-luminal position was confirmed, we performed at more PTCA with the 2.0mm balloon at 8atm x5 inflations. This improved antegrade flow and revealed some residual thrombus in the mid/distal graft, as well as a stenosis at the distal graft which also involved the previously placed stent (which extended from the distal graft into the native OM. Export thrombectomy was performed x2 runs, followed by PTCA with a 3.5x12mm Voyager balloon at 5 and 8atm. A 3.0x15mm Endeavor was then positioned in overlapping fashion with the prior stent and deployed at 8atm. We post-dilated with the 3.5mm Voyager at 16atm and then with a 3.5x12mm Quantum Maverick at 12atm. Final angiography revealed a 10% residual stenosis, TIMI 3 flow, and no apparent dissection. Selective coronary angiography in this right-dominant system demonstrated native three-vessel disease. The ___ had no angiographically apparent stenosis. The LAD was diffusely diseased with serial 40-50% lesions in its proximal portion and serial 60% lesions in its distal portion. The LCx had a proximal 60% stenosis and a diffusely disease second obtuse marginal with a subtotal occlusion and diffuse disease in its upper pole and serial 70% stenoses in its lower pole. The RCA had diffuse disease with serial 70-80% stenoses. 2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed the LIMA->LAD to be widely patent. 3. Venous conduit angiography revealed the SVG->OM2 to have a 99% stenosis with diffuse thrombus. The SVG->RCA was not engaged as it was 4. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal systemic arterial blood pressure. 5. Successful PCI of the SVG-OM2 with a 3.0x15mm Endeavor DES, post-dilated to 3.5mm. 6. Successful closure of the right femoral arteriotomy site with a ___ Perclose device. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel native coronary artery disease. 2. Widely patent LIMA->LAD. 3. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old ___ gentleman with HTN, HL, DM2, CAD s/p CABG in ___ and NSTEMI s/p DES in ___ who comes with chest pain. #. NSTEMI- His positive enzymes and ST depressions classified him as having a NSTEMI. He is chest pain free after the night of admission, and medically managed with integrillin, plavix, heparin, aspirin, statin, beta blocker, ___ and Imdur while awaiting cardiac catheterization. He was found to have native 3 vessel disease and severe thrombus in the SVG-OM2 that was evacuated and then successfully stented with an Endeavor stent. He developed some chest pain right after the procedure which quickly resolved. #. Pump - Patient was euvolemic on exam without signs of heart failure. He is scheduled to have an echocardiogram done later this week at his cardiologist's office. #. Rhythm - Normal sinus rhythm. #. Hypertension - His blood pressures widely varied throughout his hospital stay. He was continued on his home amlodipine and valsartan, and his metoprolol was increased. He was also started on low dose HCTZ. #. Hyperlipidemia - LDL 99 with ___ 96 on admission panel in the setting of holding his statin for 6 weeks as he had myalgias. He was restarted on full dose statin without myalgias. #. Diabetes mellitus type II on insulin - His A1c on admission was 9% showing his poor control. He was continued on his home Lantus 70 QHS with insulin sliding scale for breakthrough. His metformin was restarted at discharge. #. Bronchitis - Stable without wheezing or exacerbation. He was continued on his inhalers. #. GERD - His PPI was switched to H2 blocker to decrease interaction with plavix. #. Sleep apnea - He was continued on CPAP.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pressure <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac catheterization with Bare metal stents x7 (3 BMS to OM, 2 BMS to LAD and 2 BMS to LCX) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of HTN, hypothyroidism, and GERD, who presents from OSH with history of worsening chest pressure, with concern for ACS, sent to ___ for cardiac cath. Pt states that for the past year, she has had shortness of breath and chest pressure with ambulation. She describes the chest pressure as central, substernal, non-radiating pressure, relieved by rest. She was at her ophthalmologist's office this ___, and was noted to have a high blood pressure. She then spoke with the her PCP regarding her high BP and SOB, and he recommended she come to the ___ this morning, so he could evaluate her. She said that for at least the last few weeks to months, her chest pressure has remained the same: associated with exertion, walking or doing household chores. In fact, she walked on the treadmill for 3 mins yesterday, and had to stop because of chest pressure ___, that was relieved after 5 minutes of rest. She has had occasional nausea, but denied vomiting, diaphoresis, presyncope, syncope, palpitations with this. She has only had one episode of rest pain, which occurred ___ nights ago, while she was sitting on her couch watching a movie. The pressure lasted for 5mins and went away completely. Today, at the OSH ___, her initial VS were 202/73, 57, 14, 100% 2LNC. Her BP went up to 232/86. At OSH, pt was found to have ST depressions II, III, aVF, V4-V6, and ST elevations in aVR, V1, V2. Trop I 0.23 with normal Cr. CXR at OSH read as no acute process. She was started on ASA 325mg, nitro patch, plavix load 600mg, Atorvastatin 80mg x1, and Lovenox at OSH. Presented to ___ for cardiac cath. . During her cardiac catheterization, she was found to have XXX stenosis of LCx, and had initially XXX stents to XXXX. However, she continued to have chest pain, and repeat ECG's showed ST depressions in II, III, aVF, with II>III, and depressions in V4-V6, with STE in aVR, and V1-V3. Pt then had XXX stents to LAD and LCx. Subsequently, she was chest pain free and repeat ECG showed resolution of ST depressions in II, III, aVF, and lessened depressions in V4-V6, with mild continued elevation in aVR. She required nitro gtt for BP control, but was otherwise hemodynamically stable and chest pain free on transfer to the CCU for monitoring. . On presentation to the CCU, her VS were temp 96.9, BP 120/91, HR 80, RR 19, 96% on 2LNC. She was completely chest pain free and without complaints. . On review of systems, she reports occasional GERD and anxiety. But otherwise, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, - Dyslipidemia, + Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: none -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: as below -PACING/ICD: none 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Hypothyroidism HTN TAH for fibroids GERD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Brother with CABG at ___, Mother with history of angina. No family history of early MI, arrhythmia, cardiomyopathies, or sudden cardiac death; otherwise non-contributory. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL: VS: 96.9 80 120/91 19 96% 2LNC GENERAL: WDWN pleasant, elderly female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP non-elevated CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RRR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs, no S3 or S4 LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB anteriorly, without appreciated crackles or wheezes though limited given pt lying down ABDOMEN: +BS, Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. No abdominal bruits. EXTREMITIES: no edema, dressing in place on left groin without bleeding or evidence of hematoma. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Neuro: alert and oriented, CN II-XII intact, intact to light sensation throughout . DISCHARGE PHYSICAL: Temp Max: 98.4 Temp current: 97.7 HR: 55-60 RR: ___ BP: ___ O2 Sat: 99% RA Gen: alert, anxious, walking around room HEENT: supple, no JVD CV: RRR, +S1 S2, no M/R/G RESP: CTAB without wheezes or crackles ABD: +BS, soft, NT/ND EXTR: no peripheral edema, 2+ DP pulses bilaterally; right groin with ecchymoses, but without bruit NEURO: Alert, oriented, no halluciations Skin: ecchymoses on right groin and abdomen Access: PIV Tubes: none <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: Hct 37 WBC 7.1 Plt 269 Na 134 K 4.3 Cl 103 HCO3 25 BUN 14 Cr 0.8 . DISCHARGE LABS: Hct 37.5 WBC 8.4 Plt 269 Na 143 K 3.9 Cl 108 HCO3 23 BUN 17 Cr 0.8 . PERTINENT LABS: CE'S: ___: CK-MB 5 Trop ___ 4am: CK-MB ___ MBI 12.8 Trop ___ 2pm: CK-MB ___ MBI 10.8 Trop ___ 10pm: CK-MB ___ MBI 7.7 Trop 0.40 A1C: 5.9 LIPID PANEL: Total 222 LDL 145 HDL 58 ___ 93 . STUDIES: CARDIAC CATH ___: PRELIM COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated two vessel disease. The LMCA had a 30% ostial stenosis. The LAD had a 70% proximal stenosis. The Cx had a 90% long mid vessel stenosis as well as a distal 80% stenosis. The RCA had a very posterior origin and was difficult to engage but had only minimal plaquing throughout. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed a central aortic pressure of 157/62 mmHg. There was elevated left sided filling pressures with an LVEDP of 30 mmHg. 3. Careful pullback of the catheter from the LV to the aorta revealed no transvalvular gradient. 4. Successful stenting of the mid LCx with a MiniVision OTW 2.0x23 mm bare-metal stent (BMS) overlapped with a Minivision OTW 2.0x12 mm BMS (distally). Successful stenting of the LCx distal to new stents with two overlapping MiniVision OTW 2.0x12 mm bare-metal stents. Successful stenting of the distal LCx/OM1 with a MiniVision 2.0x8 mm BMS. Final angiography revealed normal TIMI 3 flow, no angiographically apparent dissection and 0% residual stenosis in the new stents deployed. (see ___ comments) 5. Successful stenting of the proximal-mid LAD with two separated MiniVision OTW 2.0x12 mm bare-metal stent (BMS). Final angiography revealed normal TIMI 3 flow, no angiographically apparent dissection and 0% residual stenosis in the new stents. (see ___ comments) 6. R ___ femoral artery angioseal closure deviced deployed without complications. (see ___ comments) FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 3. Successful stenting of the ___ LAD and mid-distal LCx/OM1 with multiple bare-metal stents. (see ___ comments) 4. Dynamic changes in the diameter of the ostium of the left main and catheter dampening consfor 18 hours post procedure 4. ASA indefinitely; plavix (clopidogrel) 75 mg daily for at least one month for bare-metal stents (see ___ comments) 5. R ___ femoral artery angioseal closure device deployed without complications (see ___ comments) . TTE ___: PRELIM Conclusions The left and right atria are normal in size. Lefft ventricular wall thickness, cavity size and regional/global systolic function are normal (LVEF >55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. No mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. IMPRESSION: nomal biventricular systolic function. . CXR ___: FINDINGS: The lung volumes are normal. Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette without pulmonary edema. No pleural effusions. Minimal bilateral symmetrical apical thickening. Normal appearance of the hilar and mediastinal structures. . Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 3. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. levothyroxine 25 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO EVERY OTHER DAY (Every Other Day). 5. ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 7. coenzyme Q10 Oral 8. nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tablet Sublingual every 5 min for total of 2 doses: call ___ or Dr. ___ any chest pain. Disp: *25 tablets* Refills: *0* 9. lisinopril 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Non St Elevation Myocardial Infarction Hypertension Delerium <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you during this admission. You had a small heart attack and needed a cardiac catheterization. We found many blockages in your heart arteries and you received a total of 7 stents during the course of 2 catheterizations. An echocardiogram showed that your heart is functioning well. Your blood pressure was high so we gave you some intravenous medicine to help lower it. You were confused overnight, perhaps from a sleeping pill called trazadone. Do not take this medicine again. You received a large dose of dye during the catheterizations so we are concerned that your kidney function will worsen. So far, that has not happenend but we will need to follow your kidney function closely after you leave. You will follow up with Dr. ___ on ___. We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. Start taking aspirin and Plavix (clopidogrel) daily to keep all the stents open. This is extremely important to prevent another heart attack or even death if the stents suddenly closed. Do not stop taking aspirin and Plavix unless Dr. ___ ___ you it is OK. 2.Start using nitroglycerin if you have any chest pain or trouble breathing similar to the symptoms that preceded your hospitalization. You can take 2 nitroglycerin tablets under your tongue 5 minutes apart. Please call ___ for any pain or severe trouble breathing. 3. Start taking Atorvastatin to lower your cholesterol 4. Start taking Metoprolol to lower your heart rate and blood pressure 5. Start taking Ranitidine to prevent stomach upset from the Plavix and aspirin 6. We increased the dose of your lisinopril from 20mg daily to 40mg daily to help control your blood pressure. **Again, it is very important to have your blood checked on ___ with Dr. ___ to check for your kidney function and electrolytes now that we increased the Lisinopril. You may also need additional blood pressure medication or increased doses. Please discuss this with Dr. ___.
target: HOSPITAL COURSE: Ms. ___ is a ___ female with history of HTN, hypothyroidism, and GERD, who presents from OSH with history of worsening chest pain, concern for ACS, transferred to ___ for cardiac cath, now s/p 7 BMS to LCx and LAD. Pt is hemodynamically stable, and transferred to CCU for close monitoring. . ACTIVE ISSUES: . # CORONARIES: Differential included ACS vs. demand ischemia ___ uncontrolled HTN. Pt's anginal symptoms seemed to be stable in nature rather than increasing or crescendo in nature to suggest unstable plaque. Pt had been severely hypertensive with LVH findings suggested on ECG. Pt went to cardiac cath with 2 stents initially to LCx; however, pain continued post-procedure, with concern for spasm of left main given elevations in aVR. Pt subsequently had 3 more stents placed to LCx and 2 to LAD. Cardiac enzymes were cycled and peaked post-procedure and down-trended. She was started on ASA 325, Plavix 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, and Integrilin for 18hrs. She was started on metoprolol for beta blockade. ACEI was initially held given large dye load and concern for contrast-induced nephropathy. This was restarted as below. TTE demonstrated preserved biventricular systolic function. A1c was sent for risk factor stratification and was 5.9. Lipid panel was sent and showed LDL of 145. She was continued on Atorvstatin 80mg daily. ___ consult was placed. She remained completely chest pain free. She was discharged to continue ASA, Plavix, Atorvastatin, Lisinopril and Metoprolol succinate. . # PUMP: No history of heart failure. Pt appeared euvolemic with elevation of JVP and clear lungs. CXR demonstrated no evidence of pulmonary edema. As above, TTE demonstrated preserved systolic function. . # RHYTHM: Initial ECG at OSH and prior to cardiac cath demonstrated shortened PR interval, with question of possible junction rhythm. Repeat ECG's demonstrated sinus rhythm. She was monitored on telemetry without events. . # HTN: Pt presented with hypertensive urgency with SBP to 230 at OSH. On transfer, blood pressure improved from cath, on nitro gtt. She required titration of nitro gtt for control. We were able to wean off the nitro. As above, ACEI was initially held given large dye load and concern for development of contrast-induced nephropathy. She was started on metoprolol succinate 25mg daily. Lisinopril dose was increased to 40mg daily. She was instructed to follow-up with her PCP for further BP management. . # Large dye load: Received 440cc of contrast. Pt was started on IVF due to concern for contrast-induced nephropathy. Cr and lytes were monitored and remained stable without Cr bump. Pt had dark urine on hospital day 2, with RBC's in urine attributed to foley placement, and negative UCx. Urine output remained normal and discoloration resolved. Cr remained normal. As above, ACEI was initially held and restarted prior to discharge. . # Nausea/HA: likely ___ nitro and relatively low BP, and nausea likely also ___ GERD. Resolved after BP better control. Started on H2 blocker for GERD with improved. symptoms. . INACTIVE ISSUES: . # Hypothyroidism: continue home regimen of levothyroxine 25mcg qod. . # GERD: Pt had symptoms prior to admission. She was started Ranitidine 150mg po bid, with improvement of her symptoms. . TRANSITIONAL CARE: 1. CODE: FULL 2. FOLLOW-UP: PCP ___ 3. MEDICAL MANAGEMENT: - Started ASA 325mg, Plavix 75mg daily, Atorvastatin 80mg daily, Metoprolol XL 25mg daily; Increased dose of Lisinopril from 20mg daily to 40mg daily - Pt instructed to have f/u labs to monitor Cr/lytes on increased dose of ACEI with PCP; also to discuss further uptitration of BP meds as needed

While you were here we looked at the blood vessels in your heart (with a procedure called coronary catheterization) and placed a stent to hold one of the vessels open. We have started some new medicines for your heart: aspirin, plavix, toprol and lipitor. It is important that you take all of these medicines and follow up with your cardiologist and primary care doctors ___ this month. T-wave flattening in III and normalized T-waves in inferior leads, which is new compared with ___ at which time there were ST elevations and T-wave inversions in inferior leads. The estimated peak MET capacity was 7.5 which represents a good physical working capacity for her age. No progressive arm, neck, back or chest discomfort was reported by the patient throughout the study. She did note shortness of breath which was appropriate for the task. At peak exercise, there was 0.5 mm of ST segment flattening over baseline changes seen in the inferolateral leads. This resolved with rest by minute 1 of recovery. The rhythm was sinus with rare isolated apbs. In the absence of beta blocker therapy there was a blunted HR response with an appropriate increase in BP. Resting and stress perfusion images reveal a mild, fixed defect of the base and mid inferior wall. Gated images reveal hypokinesis of the inferior wall. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 51%. CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION ___ 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed 2 vessel coronary artery disease. The ___ had no angiographically apparent flow limiting epicardial coronary artery disease. The LAD had a proximal 70% and a mid 50% stenosis. The LCx had mild luminal irregularities. The RCA had patent stents with a mid-vessel 50% stenosis. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed severe systemic arterial systolic hypertension with SBP 183 mmHg. 3. The initial angiography revealed a 70% and a 50% sequential proximal and mid LAD lesions. The FFR dropped from baseline of 0.89 to below 0.75 at 30 seconds of adenosine infusion indicating a significant lesion. Take every 5min for up to 3 times. Disp: *6 tablet* Refills: *0* 13. Disp: *14 patch* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnosis: 1. Coronary Artery Disease 2. Marker negative crescendo angina 3. Deployment of 2 bare metal stents in the left anterior descending artery. 4. Dyspnea 5. Nicotine dependence, tobacco use 6. Hypertension. 7. Dyslipidemia Secondary Diagnosis: 8. Depression 9. Gastroesophageal reflux <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable,chest pain free. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mrs. ___ you were admitted to the hospital because of chest pain with shortness of breath while you were walking during your hospitalization you did NOT have a myocardial infarction or heart attack. You had an abnormal, but unchanged nuclear stress test that showed some non-reversible inferior wall motion abnoralities. You had a cardiac cath which showed a 50% and 70% LAD coronary artery stenosis. You had two bare metal stents placed in your LAD. You were started on a medication called plavix. This medication helps prevents blood clots from forming in your stent. You absolutely must take this medication for the next 3 months otherwise you could develop a clot in your stent. You must also continue to take aspirin. Two other medications were modified while you were in the hospital your simvastatin was increased from 40mg to 80mg daily for better cholesterol management. Your amlodipine was also increased to 10mg to aid with your blood pressure control. It is our recommendation that you stop smoking. You have a higher risk of a heart attack or worsened heart disease if you continue to smoke. You have been given nicotine patches, take one 21mg patch daily for 4 weeks, then one 14mg patch daily for 2wks, then 7mg patch daily for 2wks. You were also prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin. If you develop chest pain you can take a tab and place it under your tongue. After doing this call ___. You may do every five minutes for a total of 3 times. Please call ___ or go to an emergency room if you develop chest pain, shortness of breath or any other worsening of your medical condition.
target: Patient is a ___ y.o. female with h/o inferior MI, S/P 2 RCA stents who presented with 1 week of exertional palpitations and dyspnea, with waxing and waning chest pain. During this hospital stay, she had MIBI which showed mild, fixed defect of the base and mid inferior wall, hypokinesis of the inferior wall and mildly dilated left ventricle (139ml) and LVEF 51%. Patient's complaints were felt to be anginal equivalent, although her biomarkers showed no evidence of myonecrosis despite days of ongoing smptoms. Decision made to repeat cardiac catheterization, and she was found to have 50% and 70% LAD lesions with an abnormal pressure wire study (including flow-limitation despite lack of a corresponding defect on the ETT-MIBI). Two bare metal stents were placed. Patient was instructed to take aspirin indefinitely and Plavix for at least three months. She was to follow up with her primary cardiologist for final determination of Plavix duration. Tobacco Cessation: Patient still reports smoking one pack per day. She was advised that she was at high risk of worsening cardiac disease if she continued to smoke. She agreed she would like to quit smoking. She was discharged on a typical nicotine patch weaning protocol starting with 21mg patch. Hyperlipidemia - Patient was continued on ezetimibe. Patient's simvastatin was increased from 40 mg to 80 mg daily for better lipid control given her current presentation with marker negative crescendo unstable angina. Hypertension - Patient was continued on lisinopril 30 mg BID. Patient's amlodipine was increased from 5 mg to 10 mg for better blood pressure control. Depression - Patient was continued on home fluoxetine and trazodone.

Initially he was placed on IV heparin drip and increased the dose of statin, however after the results of the nuclear exercise stress test, heparin drip was discontinued and statin dose was reduced back to home dose. He was in sinus rhythm throughout his stay with no lightheadedness, chest pain, shortness of breath palpitation or other symptoms. . # Lightheadedness: Given resemblance to prior angina episode, initial thought was that it might have been secondary to acute coronary syndrome. However, cardiac enzymes were cycled and were normal. He also had similar episode of lightheadedness and clamminess in ___. No evidence of being dehydrated. no ear complaints. no weakness or numbness to suggest stroke. Tremulous, could be secondary to alcohol withdrawal. His CIWA score on admission was normal. target: Mr. ___ is ___ year old man with known CAD who presented to OSH with one day of chest pain and dyspnea who was found to have new Q-waves anteriorly with newly depressed EF and wall motion abnormalities along with positive troponins concerning for NSTEMI. Transferred for cath, complicated by flash pulmonary edema prior to transfer. # Non ST elevation myocardial infarction: Known CAD, with prior stent to RCA and known left circumflex disease. Had progressing ___ q-waves and downtrending cardiac enzymes, from NSTEMI at OSH. Troponins continued to downtrend at OSH as well as at ___. The patient was started on a heparin drip, aspirin, pravastatin 80, was loaded with Plavix and continued with 75mg daily thereafter. His beta blocker and ACEi were initially held due to low blood pressures but were restarted once BPs stabilized. He underwent catheterization which showed severe native LAD and Lcx disease, moderate RCA disease, moderate aortic stenosis, and the recommendation was made to consider AVRcabg. He developed increased shortness of breath and chest pain during the post-cath check. EKG was unchanged and the chest pain responded to SL nitroglycerin and morphine. He got 20 mg IV furosemide for increasing SOB with good effect. Cardiac surgery was asked to evaluate the patient for possible CABG given extensive disease. They saw the patient and determined that he is not a candidate for surgery. He underwent a dobutamine stress ECHO which showed no myocardial viability. The decision was made to medically manage his CAD. He was started on Plavix and continued on aspirin, metoprolol and statin therapy. He was discharged on furosemide 10mg PO daily. He was chest pain free at discharge. # Aortic stenosis: Significant AS (Aortic Valve - Valve Area: *0.6 cm2, Aortic Valve - Peak Gradient: *63 mm Hg). Patient is a ___ candidate and will undergo this workup as an outpatient. # Acute systolic HF: TTE in ___ with LVEF 55-60% and no wall motion abnormalities. TTE at OSH showed LVEF 35-40% with moderate ___ and mid- to distal septal hypokinesis and marked apical hypokinesis. The patient developed flash pulmonary edema prior to transfer to ___ and received a furosemide bolus and nitroglycerin drip. The nitroglycerin drip was weaned prior to arrival. He was noted to have worsening AS on TTE ___. He was initially started on furosemide 20mg PO daily to keep his fluid balance even however developed hypotension and a 1L volume deficit on this dose. He was restarted on lisinopril after stabilization of BPs. He appeared euvolemic at discharge with a weight of 154 pounds. He was discharged on furosemide 10 mg daily, lisinopril 2.5 mg daily and metoprolol succinate XL 25mg daily. # RHYTHM: The patient remained in sinus rhythm and was monitored on telemetry. # CKD: Unknown baseline Cr, but Stage 3 per report. Cr currently 1.4 with eGFR of 47. His creatinine continued to improve and was 1.2 on discharge. # Hypothyroidism: Continued on Synthroid 50mcg daily # Hypertension: Beta blocker and lisinopril were initially held but were added back once blood pressures stabilized. # Hyperlipidemia: Continued pravastatin 80mg # GERD: Omeprazole 20mg daily TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ******************* -___ workup as an outpatient

target: Summary: ___ yo male with a history of CAD (2 DES placed into LAD on ___, hyperlipidemia, HTN, and smoking history presenting with left chest tightness. CORONARIES: The patient has known CAD with a cath report from ___ and an intervention with placement of 2 DES into the proximal and distal LAD (lesions were hazy though FFR showed pressure gradient difference). At that time, he only had single vessel disease. The patient presents with a different type of discomfort than his previous anginal pain. Cardiac enzymes x 3 were normal and there were no EKG changes. The patient did not experience any discomfort during the hospitalization. He was continued on Plavix, high dose aspirin, lisinopril and a statin. A beta blocker was held because he had an adverse reaction to it in the past. Since his discomfort was different than his prior and his last cath was only 2 months ago, it was decided to perform a stress echo on the patient. The stress echo was normal revealing excellent physical endurance and a very good functional exercise capacity without ECG of 2D echo evidence of inducible ischemia. On discharge, the patient was given a prescription for sublingual nitroglycerin. He has a PCP appointment on ___ and ___ planned to have his PCP organize cardiology followup. -follow cardiac enzymes . # Dyslipidemia: From ___ his lipid panel showed LDL calc: 75, HDL: 41, ___: 122, Total choleterol: 122. He was advised to increase his simvastatin 10 mg dose for a goal of LDL<70. On discharge, the patient was given a prescription for pravastatin 20 mg daily because it will provide cost savings. # Left foot drop and associated numbness: The patient complains of difficulty pushing on the ball of his left foot. The physical exam revealed ___ dorsiflexion of the foot and sensory loss on the lateral aspect of the calf wrapping on the the arch of the foot. He did not have any back or neck pain. The remainder of his neurological exam was normal. Since his symptoms are only distal, they might be due to compression of a nerve. He was given an appointment at the neurology urgent clinic for further evaluation. Outpatient followup: 1. Check LDL if at goal 2. Neurology for left foot weakness

You should seek treatment for your alcohol abuse. The following changes were made to your medications: STOPPED simvastatin STARTED amlodipine 5mg by mouth daily STARTED lipitor 40mg by mouth daily STARTED thiamine 100mg by mouth daily STARTED plavix 75mg by mouth daily Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.
target: ___ yo M with past medical history of CAD s/p STEMI ___ and NSTEMI ___ w/ 2 DES to ___ RCA, thrombectomy, BMS to distal RCA (cocaine-related MIs), OM1, 2 and RCA stents, CM EF 25%, VTach s/p ablation ___, afib, cocaine use, HTN, HLD p/w chest pain found to have myocardial infarction. # CP/NSTEMI: pt has significant CAD with h/o multiple stents as well as known inferior wall akinesis c/w distal occlusion of RCA seen on echo in ___. He presented with persistent left-sided CP in the setting of medication non-compliance. In the ED he received 600mg plavix, 325mg ASA, and was started on a nitro gtt but no heparin due to concerns over previous reports of HIT (though pt was negative for HIT antibody). Troponins were elevated to 0.11 so patient was admitted for cardiac catheterization which showed "right dominant system demonstrates two vessel coronary disease. The left main and left anterior descending are free of angiographically apparent disease. The right coronary artery is proximally occluded. The circumflex system is involved, with the previously placed stent into the first obtuse marginal upper pole widely patent, which jails a lower pole small vessel (2mm side branch), which is partially occluded with TIMI 1 flow." There was an "unsuccessful attempt at PCI of occluded inferior division of first obtuse marginal branch." Pt's medications were optimized by starting plavix 75mg po daily, starting amlodipine 5mg po daily, and switching simvastatin to lipitor 40mg po daily due to concerns over increased risk of rhabdomyolysis on simvastatin when amlodipine is also used. Continued home aspirin, carvedilol, lisinopril. Cath site was stable and there was no pain, swelling, bruit, or bleeding noted at site. He was satting well on room air on discharge. # ETOH intoxication: pt has a h/o severe etoh abuse and last had drink 14 hours prior to admission to floor consisting of 1L of southern comfort. He was intoxicated on admission to ED with ethanol level of 218. He was placed on a CIWA scale while in house but did not score. Social work was consulted. He was continued on his home magnesium oxide, folic acid, and MVI and also started on thiamine 100mg po daily. On discharge he was recommended to seek treatment for his alcohol abuse. # Mixed cardiomyopathy with EF 25%: likely secondary chronic alcohol abuse. Pt has a h/o V-fib and would likely benefit from an ICD, however, cardiologist has discussed ICD placement with patient and it was determined that pt is a poor candidate due to his continued alcohol abuse and the risk of frequent shocks during etoh withdrawal. He was continued on his home lasix dose in house because he was euvolemic on admission. Cardioprotective regimen optimized as above. # PAF: pt has h/o PAF but was in sinus rhythm on admission and remained in sinus rhythm throughout hospital course. He was monitored on telemetry. He did have frequent PVCs and occasional 3 beat runs of non-sustained v-tach. He remained hemodynamically stable. Not on coumadin - pt has poor medication compliance - but was on aspirin on admission. If patient's medication compliance improves, he would benefit from coumadin due to his CHADS2 score of 2. # HTN: continued patient's current regimen of carvedilol, lasix, lisinopril # HLD: continued simvastatin in house, but due to addition of amlodipine to cardiac regimen, he was switched to lipitor 40mg po daily on discharge to avoid increased risk of rhabdomyolysis when combining these meds. # tobacco abuse: applied nicotine patch

Coronary CTA ___: Coronary Imaging CT coronary angiography was limited due to significant motion artifcat. There was a right dominant system with normal origins and orientations of the left main and right coronary arteries. The left main bifurcated normally into the LAD and LCx with calcified plaque in the distal left main with possible significant stenosis. The LAD had a single large diagonal branch. There was predominantly calcified plaque involving the proximal and mid LAD, as well as the diagonal branch with probable significant stenosis. The LCx had a single large OM branch. There was predominantly calcified plaque involving the distal LCx and the OM branch with probable significant stenosis. The RCA was dominant and difficult to evaluate due to significant motion artifact. There was diffuse predominantly calcified plaque involving the entire vessel and the PDA with probable total occlusion of the RCA. The calcium score was 2646, which is >99th percentile for his age and gender. . Impression: 1. Increased left ventricular cavity size with normal regional left ventricular systolic function. The LVEF was normal at 58%. 2. The diameters of the ascending thoracic aorta was increased. The main pulmonary artery diameter was increased. 3. Mild left atrial enlargement. 4. Normal coronary artery origins with no evidence of anomalous coronary arteries. Probable severe three-vessel disease with significant stenosis of the LAD and LCx with probable total occlusion of the RCA. . Cath Report ___ (prelim report): 1. 2 vessel CAD 2. Unsuccessful attempt at PCI of CTO in mid RCA 3. ASA alone no need for plavix 4. Recommend: trial of medical therapy. If refractory symptoms, can make more aggressive attempt at PCI of RCA. Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 10. omega-3 fatty acids Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY (Daily). 11. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO once a day. 12. lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 13. metoprolol succinate 50 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). 14. Januvia 50 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: - Coronary Artery Disease Secondary: - Type 2 Diabetes - Tobacco abuse - Hypertension - Hyperlipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___. You were admitted because of chest pain. An EKG and lab tests were performed that showed you were NOT having a heart attack. You did have a CT scan that showed narrowings in the arteries in your heart (the coronary arteries). For this reason you underwent a cardiac catheterization. This provided more detail about your coronary arteries. You had a total blockage in one of your coronary arteries that was not able to be opened. You also had some lesser narrowings in your other coronary arteries. You will need intensive medical therapy to prevent you from having a heart attack in the future. The most important thing that you can do for your health is to quit smoking. Other important factors are controlling your blood pressure, diabetes and cholesterol, which you are doing a good job with currently with your existing medications. No changes were made to your medications at this time. No heavy lifting with the arm used for the catheterization for 7 days. It is important that you go to all follow-up appointments as described below.
target: Primary Reason for Hospitalization: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male with obesity, DM, HLD, HTN, and tobacco use who p/w left sided chest pain, with coronary CTA showing 3-vessel disease (calcium score 2646). . ACTIVE ISSUES: # Chest Pain/Coronary Artery Disease: In the ED the patient was ruled out for acute MI with EKG and biomarkers. He was then enrolled in the ROMICAT II study and received coronary CTA. CTA showed 3-vessel disease (calcium score 2646). He then underwent cardiac cath which showed chronic total occlusion of RCA that could not be opened. The current plan is for maximal medical therapy including smoking cessation. 20 minutes were spent with patient and wife counseling about smoking cessation. He will continue aspirin 81mg, metoprolol succinate 50mg daily, lisinopril 10mg daily, and simvastatin 40mg. There was no room to uptitrate BB or ACEi with current blood pressures. He will follow-up with ___ in cardiology in ___. He was chest pain free for over 48 hours prior to discharge. If he develops refractory symptoms on maximal medical therapy a more aggressive attempt at PCI of RCA could be considered in the future. . CHRONIC ISSUES: # T2DM (HbA1C 6.0): He will continue his current outpatient regimen which includes metformin, actos, glyburide, and januvia. . # HTN: He will continue BB, ACEi . # HLD: His LDL is 65 which is at goal. He will continue Simvastatin 40mg and omega 3 fatty acids . # B12 deficiency: He will continue previous dose of cyanocobalamin . # GERD: He will continue home dose of ranitidine and omeprazole . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - CODE STATUS: Confirmed full code during this admission - Studies still pending at time of discharge: Final cardiac cath report

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> codeine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Left heart catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with history of MI x 2 (s/p LAD bare metal stent at ___ ___ in ___), ___'s, emphysema, who presented with chest pain. For the past several weeks, has had intermittent sharp chest pain, lasting 5 seconds maximum but increasing in frequency, Denies any radiation up the jaw or down the left arm, although experiences radiation to the back. Chest pain isn't associated with exertion, would occur randomly. Endorses recent increasing dyspnea on exertion, nausea and diaphoresis for the past several weeks. Extensive and severe calcification of the coronary arteries, mainly of the LAD found on a recent CT chest that was performed to evaluate his thyroid. Because of increasing frequency of symptoms, patient presented in the ED for evaluation. He took full dose ASA at home which is his home regimen. In the ED, initial VS were: 97.2 57 136/85 18 97%. Labs were remarkable for normal Tpn x1, normal chem 7 (Cr 1.1, K 4.3) and CBC. EKG was within normal limits showing sinus bradycardia at 53 bpm with normal axis and no ischemic changes. CXR PA/LAT showed increased AP diameter (known to have emphysema), no cardiomegaly, no pleural effusion or lung infiltrate or increased pulmonary interstitial markings. Pt was seen by cardiology, who recommended admission for unstable angina. In the ED, pt was given his home diazepam dose in addition to IV heparin bolus followed by heparin ggt. VS on transfer were: 54 106/67 16 100% RA On the floor, patient does not endorse current chest pain, palpitations, nausea or diaphoresis. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia, Obesity BMI 31 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: CAD s/p MI and PCI in ___ with bare metal stent in left anterior descending artery 3. OTHER MEDICAL HISTORY: GERD Asthma Tobacco Use Congenital single kidney Diverticulitis and Partial Colectomy ___ Memory Loss Anxiety Psoriasis-not on steroids currently <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father: deceased ___, RCC with mets, MI Mother: deceased ___, multiple myeloma, CHF, COPD, and DM Sister: ___ cancer (unknown type) ___: Murdered ___, ___ (?OD) ___, sis-OD, meds, and EtOH ___ Children: 1 daughter, ___, healthy <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 97.8, BP 122/84, HR 59, RR 12, 97% RA, 99.79kg General- Alert, oriented, no acute distress HEENT- Sclera anicteric, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck- supple, JVP ~2cm above sternal angle at 45 degress, no LAD Lungs- Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, ronchi CV- Distant heart sounds, no appreciable murmurs, rubs, gallops Abdomen- soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present, no rebound tenderness or guarding, no organomegaly GU- no foley Ext- warm, well perfused, 2+ pulses, no clubbing, cyanosis or edema; no femoral bruit appreciated bilaterally Neuro- CNs2-12 intact, motor function grossly normal DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 97.7, BP 98/62 (98-134/62-87), HR 51 (48-68), RR 18, 94% RA, Wt 98.6kg Unchanged from admission physical exam <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 08: 40AM BLOOD WBC-8.0 RBC-4.91 Hgb-15.9 Hct-46.0 MCV-94 MCH-32.3* MCHC-34.5 RDW-12.3 Plt ___ ___ 08: 40AM BLOOD Glucose-106* UreaN-14 Creat-1.0 Na-141 K-4.1 Cl-104 HCO3-25 AnGap-16 ___ 08: 40AM BLOOD Calcium-9.2 Phos-3.4 Mg-2.1 ___ 01: 10PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 24PM BLOOD CK-MB-4 cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 08: 30AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 cTropnT-<0.01 CXR PA & LATERAL ___: Linear opacity within the peripheral left lung base likely reflects subsegmental atelectasis due to an a large epicardial fat pad. No confluent consolidation is identified. There is no pulmonary edema or pleural effusion. Cardiomediastinal and hilar contours are within normal limits. There is no pneumothorax. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION ___: Coronary angiography: right dominant LMCA: The LMCA was long but patent. LAD: The LAD was calcified proximally and had mild plaquing just before D1. There was a patent stent in the mid LAD just after D1. There was 40% stenosis just after the stent and prior to an intramyocardial segment with slightly slow flow. The distal LAD wrapped around the apex. LCX: There was a proximal 40% CX lesion followed by a 70% stenosis just before the large OM1. The AV groove CX was small after OM1. There were serial 70% stenoses in OM2 into two bifurcating LPL terminal branches. RCA: The RCA had diffuse plaquing throughout to 35% with mild calcification and mildly slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. Assessment & Recommendations 1. Moderate single vessel CAD with diffuse atherosclerosis and diffuse slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. 2. Iatrogenic systemic arterial hypotension without obvious evidence of anaphylactoid reaction after IA TNG and diltiazem with low normal LVEDP and no reported use of PDE-5 inhibitors. Patient's SBP seemed very sensitive to IA and IC TNG. 3. Negative pressure wire evaluation of the serial moderate stenoses in the proximal LCX into OM2 using IC adenosine (measurement obtained twice with identical results, and IV adenosine strongly relatively contraindicated given daily use of inhaled bronchodilators). 4. Routine post-TR Band care. 5. Given symptoms not typical for ischemia and negative pressure wire evaluation of the LCX, would favor aggressive medical therapy with ASA, high dose statin, smoking cessation and long-acting anti-ischemic medication rather than PCI. This is especially true given slow flow consistent with microvascular disease that would not be addressed with PCI of epicardial vessels. 6. D/C cigarettes. 7. F/U with Dr. ___. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q6H: PRN Anxiety 2. Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (100/50) 1 INH IH BID 3. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 4. Ramipril 5 mg PO DAILY 5. Sertraline 75 mg PO HS 6. Simvastatin 40 mg PO HS 7. Aspirin EC 325 mg PO DAILY 8. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 325 mg PO DAILY 2. Diazepam 5 mg PO Q6H: PRN Anxiety 3. Fluticasone-Salmeterol Diskus (100/50) 1 INH IH BID 4. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO BID 5. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY 6. Ramipril 5 mg PO DAILY 7. Sertraline 75 mg PO HS 8. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 9. Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 30 mg PO DAILY RX *isosorbide mononitrate [Imdur] 30 mg 1 tablet extended release 24 hr(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Atypical chest pain <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure to take care of you during your time at ___. You were admitted to the hospital for cardiac catheterization after experiencing chest pain. We found diffuse atherosclerotic disease in the coronary arteries but no vessel that could be intervened on with a stent. You do have a stent in your left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery that was done in ___. We recommend that your coronary artery disease is controlled with medications. You will start a new medication called Imdur (isosorbide mononitrate) which is a long-acting anti-ischemic medication. We also changed your cholesterol-lowering medication to Atorvastatin (stop Simvastatin). You will continue taking Aspirin 325mg daily, Metoprolol tartrate 50mg twice a day, and Ramipril 5mg daily. In addition, stopping smoking would be most beneficial for your heart and overall health. Please discuss with your cardiologist (Dr. ___ about whether or not you should restart Plavix. You did well after cardiac cathterization and you also had no pain, numbness or tingling in your right wrist. Please follow up with your Primary Care Provider and ___ within two weeks of discharge.
target: ___ male with CAD s/p MI and PCI with bare metal stent placement in LAD in ___ at ___ in ___, current 1.5 ppd smoker, emphysema, and Hashimoto's disease who presented with atypical chest pain symptoms of intermittent sharp substernal chest pain that radiates posteriorly to upper back and lasting 5 seconds maximum but increasing in frequency. Patient endorsed increasing dyspnea on exertion, nausea, and diaphoresis. Extensive coronary artery calcification, mainly involving the LAD, found incidentally on CT trachea on ___. While patient had atypical chest pain symptoms and negative troponin x3, he is high-risk (CAD, current smoker, hypertension, hyperlipidemia) and reported that prodrome of nausea, diaphoresis, and dyspnea on exertion were similar to prior presentation for MI. Therefore, decision made to proceed with cardiac catheterization. Catheterization done through right radial approach. There were serial moderate stenoses in the LCX; pressure wire evaluation negative. Single vessel CAD with diffuse atherosclerosis and diffuse slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. Given that patient's symptoms not typical for ischemia and negative pressure wire evaluation of the LCX, aggressive medical therapy was indicated rather than PCI, especially given slow flow consistent with microvascular disease that would not be addressed with PCI of epicardial vessels. Patient was therefore continued on high-dose ASA, high-dose statin, ACEI, beta-blocker, and addition of long-acting anti-ischemic medication. Patient was also counseled on smoking cessation to decrease his cardiac risk factors. Patient was clinically stable for discharge on HD#2 with close follow up by Primary Care Provider and ___ (Dr. ___. We switched his statin to Atorvastatin 80mg daily to optimize cholesterol lowering efficacy. We also added Isosorbide mononitrate 30mg daily for coronary artery disease. He will continue taking ASA 325mg daily, Metoprolol tartrate 50mg BID, and Ramipril 5mg daily. Of note, CT trachea on ___ showed solid nodule in the left kidney space of unknown significance. Patient has congenital single kidney. Creatinine stable post-catheterization.

You were admitted to ___ ___ for evaluation and treatment of chest pain. You were found to have had a recent major heart attack with a decrease in your heart function as well as a blood clot in your heart. You underwent coronary catheterization with placement of a stent in the artery of your heart to open it up. You were started on several new medications to help decrease your risk of further heart attacks. After your heart attack and after the stent was placed, you suffered a cardiac arrest twice. Your heart started beating very fast and irregularly, which caused loss of blood pressure for a few minutes and you required chest compressions and shock to get your heart back into normal rhythm. This is an occasional complication of large heart attacks called ventricular arrhythmia. You were cared for in the ICU for a few days and you had an ICD (defibrillator) placed in your heart to help treat this arrhythmias if they were to happen again. The following changes were made to your medications: START TAKING THE FOLLOWING: Aspirin 81 mg daily Clopidogrel (Plavix) 75 mg daily for your stent Atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80 mg daily for your cholesterol Lisinopril 2.5 mg daily for high blood pressure Metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily for your heart Mexiletine 150 mg PO Q12H for your irregular heart beat Warfarin 5 mg daily to break down the clot in your heart. Dr. ___ adjust this dose at follow-up you should get you blood drawn on ___ to check the level of warfarin. It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital!
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of untreated hypertension and tobacco use previously discharged from the ED 2 weeks ago for chest pain with an exercise stress test that reproduced his angina but was without ischemic changes who was admitted with anterior STEMI. He underwent cath with placement of ___ 1 to proximal LAD but post-cath course complicated by vfib arrest x2 with successful resuscitation and systolic heart failuer w/ EF of 30% now s/p single chamber ICD placement. ACTIVE DIAGNOSES: ----------------- #Vfib Arrest: Patient underwent stenting for STEMI with one DES placed to the proximal LAD on ___. Post-cath he remained chest pain free. However, on the evening of ___ he suffered a vfib arrest on the floor. He underwent 3 cycles of CPR and was defibrillated with return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC). He was bradycardic in the new perfusing rhythm and recieved epinephrine and atropine. Within 5 mintues, he then again converted to polymorphic vtach and underwent 2 additional shocks. Between these shocks, he was given a loading dose of amiodarone 150 mg x1 and then after the repeated vtach he was also started on a lidocaine drip at 1 mg/min without loading dose. After ROSC a second time, he was bradycardic and hypotensive with blood pressures down to ___. He was started on norepinephrine for hypotension and phenylephrine was added when he was still hypotensive. He was transferred to the CCU. In the CCU, he was further loaded with amiodarone for a total loading dose of 450 mg and started on an amiodarone drip with 1 mg/min for the first 6 hours then decreased to 0.5 mg/min for ___ hours and then amiodarone was discontinued completely. His lidocaine drip was continued at the same dosing for 36 hours. The 2 pressors were able to be weaned off within 8 hours. He underwent cardiac cath which was negative for in-stent restenosis or other significant lesions. Ultimately, it was decided that he suffered reperfusion arrhthymia and thus placement of an ICD was not indicated during this hospitalization. Once his blood pressure recovered, his lidocaine drop was stopped and he was restarted on his lisinopril and metoprolol for new onset heart failure post-MI. On the evening of ___, he again suffered ventricular fibrillation arrest. He again received 3 direct cardioversions and returned to sinus rhythm with frequent ectopy. He was placed back on lidocaine drip with resolution of ectopy. Mexilitine was started and he continued to have some ectopy but was monitored for 48 hours off of lidocaine and had no additional episodes of Vtach. He had a repeat TTE on ___ which showed persistent depressed EF of 30% and given his vfib arrest outside of the 48hrs post MI it was felt that he would benefit from an ICD placement, which was placed on ___ without complications. . # Anterior STEMI s/p ___ 1 to Proximal LAD: Patient was admitted with 3 weeks of intermittent anginal chest pain with recent ED observation with ___ with enzymes, serial EKG's, and a moderate risk exercise EKG stress test. He presented to his PCP with ___ in his precordial leads and was sent to the ED where code STEMI was called and patient went to cath lab with ___ 1 placed due to 95% proximal LAD lesion. Per history, it seemed that the worst of his symptoms occurred 5 days PTA and he remained with ___ in V1-V3 following the cath lab. He underwent TTE which showed LV thrombus, LVEF of 35% and mid anterior, mid anteroseptal, distal LV and apical akinesis. His persistent ___ were felt to be c/w aneurysm. His peak trop was 1.42 although during this hospitalization he did not ___ suggesting his insult occurred days prior to his hospitalization. On the floor he was chest pain free and managed post-cath with aspirin 325mg PO daily, prasugrel 10mg PO daily which was switched to clopidogrel 75mg daily given need for warfarin for LV thrombus (see below), metoprolol 12.5mg PO BID, atorvastatin 80mg PO daily, and lisinopril 2.5mg PO daily. # LV Thrombus: Newly diagnosed following recent anterior/apical STEMI. He was started on a heparin drip as well as coumadin with plan to bridge for 24 hours once therapeutic. He will need to be on coumadin for at least ___ months. # Alcohol Dependence: Patient with ___ drinks of hard whiskey daily. Denies history of withdrawal. Did not score on CIWA while in-house and did not require valium. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -Smoking and alcohol cessation -Medication compliance -f/u in ___ clinic in 1 week for ICD interogation -Coumadin for ___ months for LV thrombus, goal INR ___. Recheck INR on ___, Dr. ___ to monitor
