You were admitted to ___ for evaluation and treatment of a heart attack. Your course was complicated by an abnormal heart rhythm and cardiac arrest. You were successfully resuscitated. A cardiac catheterization was performed which showed multi-vessel disease with acute blockage of one of the arteries of your heart which cause your heart attack. The blockage was removed and a bare metal stent was placed to keep the vessel open. . Your blood pressure were a little low during this admission but you did not have significant symptoms and were able to walk with the nurses and physical therapy without significant difficutly. . Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs. . The following changes have been made to your medications: - STOP Tamsulosin as this can lower your blood pressure - STOP Ibuprofen as this can increase your risk of bleeding when getting aspirin and plavix - START Metoprolol Succinate 12.5mg by mouth once daily (take this at night) - START Lisinopril 2.5mg by mouth once daily (take this in the morning) - START Plavix 75mg by mouth once daily (Do not stop taking this medication unless told by a cardiologist) - START Atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily - CHANGE Aspirin to 325mg by mouth once daily . Please follow-up with the appointments below.
target: ___ yo male with CHF/CAD, moderate MR, and HLD presents with inferior/lateral STEMI who coded for vfib arrest in the OSH ED, rec'd chest compressions, and vfib resolved s/p export thrombectomy and BMS to mid RCA admitted to the CCU for hypotension following the procedure. . ACTIVE DIAGNOSES: . # CAD/STEMI/Vfib Arrest c Resuscitation: Mr. ___ presented to an OSH ED 2 days following development of epigastric pain after a period of exertion. Per report he suffered from a vfib arrest, had chest compressions, and reverted to afib with RVR on monitor. He was given a lidocaine bolus and started on lidocaine, heparin, and integrillin drips, given an ASA and transferred to ___ for further evaluation and treatment. He was taken to the cath lab where he received a loading dose of plavix and found was noted to have 2 vessel disease with a thrombotically occluded RCA and a 60% diffusely occluded LAD. He had export thrombectomy and BMS to RCA. He was given dilt in the cath lab for a wide complex tachycardia which broke. He was transferred to the CCU with hypotension and required gentle dopamine pressor support and IV fluid boluses to maintain a MAP >50 which was weaned and discontinued after 2 days. He was monitored on telemetry and evidence of ectopy ceased 72 hours following cath. He had a TTE which showed LVEF 30% secondary to extensive severe inferior posterior and lateral wall hypokinesis/akinesis and RV with free wall hypokinesis. He was started on 2.5mg lisinopril daily (should be given in the morning), 12.5mg metoprolol succinate (which should be given in the evening), 80mg atorvastatin daily, and continued on plavix 75mg and ASA 325mg. We would consider adding spironolactone as a part of his CHF regimen but defer this until later assessment of recovery of LV/RV function by TTE in ___ weeks. . # Afib with RVR: Pt with new afib, likely related to the ___ period. CHADS score 3. On aspirin and plavix and has history of recent falls without intracranial hemorrhage. We deferred initiation of coumadin anti-coagulation in favor of monitoring for resolution of afib following the ___ period. . CHRONIC DIAGNOSES: . # HLD: Stable. Continued on atorvastatin 890mg PO daily . # BPH: Stable. We held his tamsulosin given his relative hypotension but continued his home finasteride. He did not have issues with urinary obstruction during his hospitalization. . # Hypothyroidism: Per report, not on synthroid, thyroid studies wnls. This should be followed as an outpatient. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: . # He is relatively hypotensive with blood pressure ranges of 70's-100's/40's-50's. Unclear if this is new for him and related to decreased cardiac output from his MI. He denies symptoms such as light-headedness, chest pain, shortness of breath, or orthostatic symptoms even while at these pressures and was able to walk with physical therapy without significant issues. . # He could likely benefit from some fine-tuning of his CHF regimen as an outpatient but this must be balances against his relative hypotension and his advanced age. This may require repeat TTE in ___ weeks to assess recovery of his LVEF and myocardial function. . # He was full code during this admission . # He was discharged to rehab for continue working on his strength and physical conditioning.

The had a good day, went to lunch and shopped with no issues. On the way home in the car, around 5: 30pm, she was in the passenger seat trying to talk to her step daughter when she noticed that she wasn't making words that she wanted to say. She was trying to talk but thinks only nonsensical sounds were coming out. They made it home and she was able to carry one of the shopping bags into the house. She continued to have decreased verbal output but started to be able to make some words. Her step daughter became concerned and asked "what is wrong" to which she replied "i don't know." She then was able to ask her stepdaughter for a glass of orange juice at which point she feels that all her symptoms resolved. She did not have any numbness, tingling, weakness, vertigo. She reports that she did have her typical headache all day long but it was similar in character and severity as her normal tension headaches. At the OSH, her blood pressure ranged from 166/81 - 213/82. She has had previous high blood pressure readings but has never taken any medications for that (apparently, she was prescribed lisinopril 2.5 in the past but never stared taking that medication). At a recent appointment with her vascular surgeon, the nurse thought she palpated an irregular heartbeat but this was not reproducible on later checks and was never documented on EKG or heart monitor. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of difficultly speaking that were likely due to a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK (TIA), a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. Damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. TIA can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: Atrial Fibrillation (Irregular Heart Beat) High Cholesterol We are changing your medications as follows: 1. CONTINUE Aspirin 81 mg daily 2. START Ezetimibe (Zetia) 10mg daily Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please follow up with Neurology, Cardiology and your primary care physician. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - sudden partial or complete loss of vision - sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - sudden weakness of one side of the body - sudden drooping of one side of the face - sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team

Hemodynamics (see above): Normal LVEDP of 4 mm Hg. Coronary angiography: right dominant system LMCA: There were minimal luminal irregularities in the LMCA with mild proximal plaquing to 25% at its origin. LAD: The branching S3 had a proximal 50% stenosis. The mid LAD had a 40% stenosis at D1. There was a 40% bifurcation lesion just after the origin of the tortuous branching D2. The distal LAD was tortuous with a corkscrew configuration with TIMI 2 slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. LCX: The LCX supplied a small high branching OM1 and a branching OM2 that arose in the proximal-mid portion of the LCX. The proximal CX had a 25% stenosis. There was no LCX perfusion of the basal posterolateral left ventricle. RCA: The RCA was a large vessel with a proximal calcified 40% stenosis at its first bend. There was diffuse plaquing to 20% in the mid RCA. There was TIMI 2 flow in the RCA proper. All the terminal branches were serpiginous, consistent with hypertensive heart disease. There were twin RPDAs, with a larger first RPDA with a distal bifurcation followed by a ___ RPDA with a proximal bifurciation. RPL1 was of modest caliber but long. RPL2 was a large tortuous vessel. RPL3 was large at its origin, but had an abrupt reduction in size proximally with a 75% stenosis and slow flow in the small caliber vessel beyond with TIMI 1 flow. RPL4 was tortuous with its distal branch perfusing the high lateral left ventricle. Interventional details Given the ongoing chest pain at the start of the procedure, it was elected to proceed with balloon angioplasty of the RPL3 (although there was clearly insufficient run-off to accommodate a stent). A 6 ___ JR4 guide was substituted, with provided adequate support. Bivalirudin was given with confirmation of a therapeutic ACT. A Prowater wire was manipulated after some effort into RPL3 and after slight additional effort into the distal portion of RPL3. The wire was occlusive across the culprit lesion. The proximal RPL3 was dilated with a 1.5x10 mm Sprinter balloon at 8 atms twice for 60 seconds each. Final angiography showed a 60% stenosis in the proximal RPL3, improved/larger caliber of the mid portion of RPL3, with a distal wire-induced grade C deep dissection/contained perforation at the terminal end of RPL3, without angiographic evidence of free flow into the pericardium. There was TIMI 2 flow into both the RCA proper and RPL. Bivaluridin was discontinued. The angiograms were reviewed with Dr. ___ Dr. ___, as well as with Dr. ___ ___ Dr. ___ the ___. The patient was pain free at the conclusion of the procedure. A Terumo Radial Band was applied to the right radial artery with good hemostasis. Potential for Radiation Injury This patient underwent a procedure performed under fluoroscopic (X-ray) guidance. Procedures involving lengthy exposures to X-rays may cause damage to the skin and/or hair. These adverse effects may be increased if one has had previous (especially recent) radiation exposure to the same skin area. Radiation injury to the skin can take many forms, including an area of redness, blistering, hair loss, or ulceration. These effects may appear after a few weeks or even after several months. If an of these occur on the side and back of the torso (or elsewhere), please contact the Interventional Cardiology Section at ___ to arrange further evaluation. Assessment & Recommendations 1. Two vessel branch coronary artery disease with diffuse atherosclerosis and diffuse slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction in a system with a hyperdominant RCA. 2. Tortuous terminal vessels consistent with hypertensive heart disease. 3. Normal left ventricular diastolic function. 4. Unsuccessful balloon angioplasty of the RPL3 with residual stenosis of 60% and a distal guide-wire induced grade C dissection vs. contained perforation. 5. Routine post-TR Band care. 6. D/C bivalirudin. 7. Cycle CKMB, platelets. 8. Low threshold for bedside TTE and consideration of pericardiocentesis for tamponade if patient becomes hypotensive tonight. Recurrent chest pain could represent abrupt closure of RPL3 or pericardial hemorrhage. Despite poor angioplasty result, would not treat with GP IIb/IIIa or heparin given distal wire dissection vs. contained perforation. 9. Reassess benefits vs. risks of clopidogrel as medical therapy for NSTEMI after unsuccessful balloon angioplasty tomorrow. 10. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against hypertension, CAD and NSTEMI Attending Electronic Signature attests that the attending physician was physically present during the key components of the procedure and in compliance with the CMS regulations. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. You were admitted for a heart attack, which was small and although injuring the heart muscle did not reduce the function of your heart to pump. The chest pain that you felt after the catheterization is likely due to inflammation of the sack around the heart, the pericardium. It is important that you take the medications prescribed to prevent further events/ heart attacks from happening in the future.
target: ___ with hypertension presents with intermittent substernal chest pressure for the last 3 days concerning for NSTEMI. # NSTEMI: Chest pressure with initial trop 0.53. Started on heparin gtt. Fasting lipids (LDL 143, HDL 65). A1C of 6.2. Troponins peaked at 0.88. Found to have two vessel branch coronary artery disease with diffuse atherosclerosis and diffuse slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction in a system with a hyperdominant RCA. Per report following POBA: Unsuccessful balloon angioplasty of the RPL3 with residual stenosis of 60% and a distal guide-wire induced grade C dissection vs. contained perforation. Was on integrelin post cath. Also had episode of blurry vision post cath that resolved within a few hours. Patient was started and continued on, atorvastatin 80mg daily, aspirin po 325mg daily, metoprolol 25mg qd. Patient was set up with ___ outpatient cardology follow up. # PUMP: No hx of heart failure. EF>60%. Reassuring echo x2 during hospitalization (was repeated given concern for effusion). Echo was: Normal study. Normal biventricular cavity sizes with preserved regional and global biventricular systolic function. No structural heart disease or pathologic flow identified. Patient was started on beta blockade. # RHYTHM: Currently sinus rhythm. # HTN: formerly on propranolol for BP control and headaches. Patient started on metoprolol in place of metoprolol and 5mg lisinopril with excellent blood pressures at discharge without orthostasis. # DM type 2: monitor on humalog insulin sliding scale. A1C 6.2. Was on HISS while in house. Patient encouraged to continue diet and exercise. # Transitional: - ASA 325mg x1 month, then 81mg - Diet and exercise.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> STEMI <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> cardiac catheterization with bare metal stents x2 to the right coronary artery. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male smoker (___ yr)with a history of GERD who presents with chest pain since 9pm ___ and was found to have an inferior STEMI. He was transferred to the CCU after cardiac catheterization for further management. . He was in his usual state until three days ago when he noted an increase in his symptoms of GERD, which usually occur twice a week, but were now occuring multiple times each day. He described the discomfort as "chest burning" and it was not associated with dyspnea or worsened by exertion. He used over the counter zantac and tums, and felt that these medications helped for a few minutes, but that his symptoms recurred rapidly. He also noted that his symptoms were increasingly unrelated to food intake. They were worst at night, though they did not prevent him from falling asleep and sx abated 1hr after taking prilosec. On the evening of admission, he noted acute worsening of his GERD-like symptoms with associated with severe, sharp substernal chest pain, which was new, radiating into his R arm to elbow a/w numbness in R arm as well. He also felt as though "an elephant was sitting on my chest", ___ on pain scale" and had dyspnea, nausea and diaphoresis. His wife and brother-in-law activated EMS. . On arrival to ED, initial VS were: 98 84 152/80 19 97%ra. EKG demonstrated inferior TWIs and he later developed ___levations in the inferior leads, with ST depressions in I and avL. He was started on a nitro gtt, plavix loaded, given aspirin, and taken to cardiac cath emergently, where anatomy demonstrated 80-90% distal RCA lesion and 50-60% proximal RCA lesion, both of which were stented with DESs. He was transferred to the CCU and chest pain free on arrival. . Review of symptoms is notable for increased stress over the past several months, during which his wife was diagnosed with liver cancer and has been ill. He denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. . Of note, pt is physically active - walks dog daily, built a deck 3 days ago w/o complaint. No history of exertional chest pain or SOB. Normal stress test ___ ago. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - GERD <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father ___, living with CAD and CABG, ___ MI at ___, ___ MI ___. Coronary angiography in this right-dominant system demonstrated one-vessel disease. The LMCA had no angiographically apparent disease. The LAD and LCX had mild luminal irregularities. The RCA had a proximal 40% stenosis and a distal 90% stenosis that was preceded by a 50-60% inflow stenosis. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal systemic arterial blood pressure. 3. You had chest pain and 2 blockages in your right coronary artery. These arteries were opened in the cardiac catheterization lab and 2 drug eluting stents were placed to keep the arteries open. There does not seem to be any damage to your heart muscle. You will need to take new medicines to minimize the risk of another blockage in your arteries. new Medicines: 1. Start taking Aspirin 325 mg (not baby) and Clopidogrel (Plavix) 75 mg every day for at least one year to prevent the stents from clotting off. ___ not stop taking these medicines or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ tells you to. This is extremely important to prevent any heart damage. 2. Start taking Simvastatin to lower your cholesterol. You will need to have a cholesterol level and liver function tests done in about 6 weeks to check the response to this medicine. 3. Start taking Lisinopril for your high blood pressure. This medicine may make your potassium higher and cause you to feel dizzy. You should get your labs checked next week and take your blood pressure every day so the medicine can be adjusted. 4. continue to take Zantac as needed for your heartburn. ___ not take any medicines like Prilosec as these can interfere with the function of the Plavix. 5. Nitroglycerin: to take if you have chest pain at home, take one tablet under your tongue, wait 5 minutes and take one more tablet. If you still have chest pain call ___. Also call Dr ___ you have any chest pain at home, even if you didn't take nitroglycerin. 6. Nicotine patch: use daily to help you quit smoking. This is the single most important thing you can ___ for your health. . No lifting more than 10 pounds for one week to prevent any complications in your groin area. No swimming or baths for one week, you may shower. . Please check labs on ___ with results to Dr. ___ ___ Instructions: ___

target: This is a ___ female with history of HTN, HL, DMII, CAD s/p multiple stents (RCA, LCX, OM1, D1) with last cath ___ demonstrating no obstructive disease, PAD s/p PTCA, pulmonary hypertension, CKD (baseline creatinine 1.5-1.6), GERD who is admitted for pre-syncopal episode and chest pressure. ACTIVE ISSUES: # chest pain: patient admitted with episode of chest pressure which sounded typical and relieved by nitroglycerin. Her ECG was non ischemic. trop neg x2. Nothing on exam to suggest DVT/PE. No mediastinal widening on CXR. No evidence of pneumonia. Attempted to obtain dobutamine stress echo but exam limited by hypertension with dobutamine infusion - no obvious ischemia seen with data that was obtained, however. Pt refused P-MIBI because she did not like the way it made her feel last time. Monitored on telemetry with no significant events. Optimized patient's cardiac regimen: continued Aspirin 325mg daily, home carvedilol, pravastatin. # chronic diastolic heart failure: Lungs and CXR relatively clear and respiratory status good on admission. no symptoms suggestive of an acute heart failure exacerbation, such as ___ edema, elevated JVD, or rales on lung exam. Held lasix and diovan in the setting of renal failure as below. Held diltiazem in the setting of orthostatic hypotension. Restarted all on discharge, but lasix at a lower dose. # acute on chronic renal failure: baseline creatinine 1.7. pt presented with acute on chronic renal failure with creatinine of 2.4 on admission. thought to be pre-renal etiology per FeNa = 0.85%, FeUrea = 29%, secondary to volume depletion from recently increased furosamide dosage over past month and diarrhea at home. Held valsartan and lasix in the setting of acute renal failure and volume depletion. Gave IV fluids and pt's creatinine was back to her baseline by hospital day 3. # orthostatic hypotension: thought to be multifactorial from medications that block compensatory mechanisms (diltiazem) in the setting of volume depletion (from higher lasix dose and diarrhea). Gave 1L IV fluids and decreased lasix to every other day dosing. Home with ___ and ___. CHRONIC ISSUES: # HTN: held valsartan, lasix, and diltiazem as above. Continued carvedilol. restarted valsartan and diltiazem at home dose and lasix at half of home dose on discharge. # Hyperlipidemia: Continued home statin # DMII: held oral hypoglycemics in house and maintained on SSI. restarted home meds on discharge # Hypothyroidism: Continued home levothyroxine. # GERD: Continued home H2 blocker

Zantac 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day: take instead of prilosec while on plavix to prevent interaction. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Left ischemic toes with peripheral vascular disease PMH: Hypertension Diabettes TIA ___ ago and ?___ Asthma CAD 3V Diastolic dysfunction Angina, NSTEMI ___ PSH: TAH, T&A <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Division of Vascular and Endovascular Surgery Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions What to expect when you go home: 1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks -You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase your activity each day -Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: you may walk and you may go up and down stairs -Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too much right away! 2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated on: -Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at night -Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated 3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time -You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some weight -Eat small frequent meals -It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing -To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication What activities you can and cannot do: -No driving until post-op visit and you are no longer taking pain medications -Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: -You should get up every day, get dressed and walk -You should gradually increase your activity -You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car -Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too much right away! -No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) until your post op visit -You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, rinse and pat dry -Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing over the area that is draining, as needed -Take all the medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed -Take one full strength (325mg) enteric coated aspirin daily, unless otherwise directed -Call and schedule an appointment to be seen in 2 weeks for staple/suture removal What to report to office: -Redness that extends away from your incision -A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain medication -A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the ability to feel your leg -Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours -Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOLLOWING TRANSMETATARSAL AMPUTATION . This information is designed as a guideline to assist you in a speedy recovery from your surgery. Please follow these guidelines unless your physician has specifically instructed you otherwise. Please call our office nurse if you have any questions. Dial 911 if you have any medical emergency. . ACTIVITY: . There are restrictions on activity. On the side of your transmetatarsal amputation you are non weight bearing for ___ weeks. You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever possible. . You may use the heel of your amputation site for transfer and pivots. But try not to exert to much pressure on the site when transferring and or pivoting. If possible avoid using the heel of your amputation site when transferring and pivoting. . No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. . PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS: . Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s). . New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toes. . Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR. . Exercise: . Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks. . Do not drive a car unless cleared by your Surgeon. . No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days. . Try to keep leg elevated when able. . BATHING/SHOWERING: . You may shower immediately upon coming home. No bathing. A dressing may cover youre amputation site and this should be left in place for three (3) days. Remove it after this time and wash your incision(s) gently with soap and water. You will have sutures, which are usually removed in 4 weeks. This will be done by the Surgeon on your ___ appointment. . WOUND CARE: . Sutures / Staples may be removed before discharge. If they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for staple removal. . When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm water and soap in the shower. . Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for four weeks after surgery. . MEDICATIONS: . Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the medications you were taking before surgery. You will be given a new prescription for pain medication, which can be taken every three (3) to four (4) hours only if necessary. . Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small balanced meals throughout the day. CAUTIONS: . NO SMOKING! We know you've heard this before, but it really is an important step to your recovery. Smoking causes narrowing of your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation. If you smoke you will need to stop as soon as possible. Ask your nurse or doctor for information on smoking cessation. . Avoid pressure to your amputation site. . No strenuous activity for 6 weeks after surgery. . DIET: . There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. Poor appetite is expected for several weeks and small, frequent meals may be preferred. . For people with vascular problems we would recommend a cholesterol lowering diet: Follow a diet low in total fat and low in saturated fat and in cholesterol to improve lipid profile in your blood. Additionally, some people see a reduction in serum cholesterol by reducing dietary cholesterol. Since a reduction in dietary cholesterol is not harmful, we suggest that most people reduce dietary fat, saturated fat and cholesterol to decrease total cholesterol and LDL (Low Density Lipoprotein-the bad cholesterol). Exercise will increase your HDL (High Density Lipoprotein-the good cholesterol) and with your doctor's permission, is typically recommended. You may be self-referred or get a referral from your doctor. . If you are overweight, you need to think about starting a weight management program. Your health and its improvement depend on it. We know that making changes in your lifestyle will not be easy, and it will require a whole new set of habits and a new attitude. If interested you can may be self-referred or can get a referral from your doctor. . If you have diabetes and would like additional guidance, you may request a referral from your doctor. ___ APPOINTMENT: . Be sure to keep your medical appointments. The key to your improving health will be to keep a tight reign on any of the chronic medical conditions that you have. Things like high blood pressure, diabetes, and high cholesterol are major villains to the blood vessels. Don't let them go untreated! . Please call the office on the first working day after your discharge from the hospital to schedule a ___ visit. This should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ through ___. . PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE.
target: Pt is a ___ y.o female with h.o 3V-CAD, s/p NSTEMI ___, HTN, HL, DM, asthma, TIA?stroke who was admitted to the podiatry service and underwent L.SFA stenting ___ post-operative course complicated by NSTEMI. . NSTEMI: Patient with known 3V CAD developed chest pain consistent with her typical anginal symptoms, dynamic EKG changes in multiple leads and elevated troponins. Echocardiogram demonstrated dysfunction with basal to mid inferior/inferolateral hypokinesis with no prior for comparison. She was amenable to interventional management and was taken to the cath lab on ___ for a RCA stent. Hydration protocol was performed due to level of renal dysfunction. She was continued on plavix, aspirin, and isosorbide. The atenolol as increased from 50 to 75mg daily. Kept on heparin post-cath for several days. Atenolol increased again to 100mg on ___. On ___ the patient had another episode of ___ chest pain. EKG wnl. Nitro SL given X1. VSS and Cardiology aware. No acute changes noted. . PERIPHERAL VASCULAR DISEASE: She underwent Left SFA stent by vascular surgery on ___. Post operative course was complicated by large right groin hematoma. There was no evidence of pseudoaneurysm on ultrasound. She was transfused 3 units of PRBC. She was continued on aspirin and plavix. On ___ had a Right Coronary Stent placed by Cardiology. On ___ she additionally had a Balloon angioplasty of the right external iliac artery and stenting of the right external iliac artery. This resulted on a dopperable DP signal which was a new finding. On ___ the patient underwent a left femoral to dorsalis pedis bypass using in situ saphenous vein with a left hallux amputation which was left open. Transfused 2 units of PRBC blood post-op for a HCT 25.8. 1 additional unit of PRBC ___ for blood loss related to surgical intervention. Left toes continued to deteriote and decision was made for a transmetarsal amputation of the left toes. Patient underwent TMA on ___ under MAC with foot block. Tolerated procedure without complications. She is nonweightbearing on the left foot. . #ACUTE RENAL FAILURE - Creatinine increased from 1.2 to 1.5 post-SFA stenting with likely differential being pre-renal due to dehydration vs. contrast induced nephropathy secondary to dye received during SFA procedure. Her lisinopril was held. Her medications were renally dosed. Post bypass surgery was diuresed and renal function returned to normal and home meds restarted. . #HTN. Her blood pressure was well controlled during the hospitalization. She was continued on her home medications. The atenolol was increased to 75mg daily. . #HYPERLIPIDEMIA. She was continued on atorvastatin 20mg daily. She reported abdominal pain at higher doses and was not amenable to up-titration. . #LEFT TOE ULCER. She was followed by the podiatry service during this hospitalization. # WOUND CARE:The patient has a Stage II pressure ulcer, partial thickness skin breakdown of the soft tissue of the right gluteal. Wound care nursing recommendations include pressure relief and miconazole to labia for fungal infection. PHYSICAL THERAPY: On ___ recommended home physical therapy which the patient refused. ___: Recs home with ___ ___: Reevaluation post-op- recommended Rehab. NUTRITION: Consult on ___ for low nutrition risk. Recommendations includes continuing Diabetic Consistent Diet and encouraging ensure supplementation. SOCIAL WORK: Consult and followed patient for coping support. PAIN MANAGEMENT: Tylenol and oxycodone controlling pain. Neurontin started ___ for neuropathic pain. Ok to titrate up at rehab. . CODE: DNR/DNI . Discharge plan: Patient was transferred to Rehab on ___. She is scheduled for a LLE angiogram on ___ and will return to the hospital at that time. Her staples and sutures should remain intact until then. She will continue dicloxacillin until her next admission. Continue ___, pain management, Wound care and emotional support.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Percocet / Ciprofloxacin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain & shortness of breath <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization with Drug eluting stents x2 to ostial and mid RCA. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with a complicated history including CAD s/p CABG in ___, PVD, systolic CHF (EF 45-50% in ___ w/ diastolic dysfunction, severe COPD, severe AS (0.8cm2) & AI who presents as a transfer from ___ for respiratory failure. Mr. ___ has been hospitalized multiple times in the last several months for respiratory failure and has been intubated 3 times over the past 3 months most recently in early ___ at ___. Following his most recent discharge, he was seen by his PCP, ___ on ___ for persistent upper respiratory symptoms and placed on a Z-pack. His symptoms improved, but the patient's wife called the patient's PCP 3 days prior to this admission stating that the patient had developed worsening cough productive of thick yellow-green sputum and worsening shortness of breath on his home 2L O2, as well as chest tightness that resolved after SL NTG x 2. At that time, his wife reported that he had no chest pain, nausea, sweating, fever, chills, vomiting or dizziness and he was directed to ___ for further evaluation. . For unclear reasons, he did not seek care until the day prior to admission when his breathing and chest pain symptoms worsened. He was taken to ___ by ambulance and found to be non-verbal in the ED. CXR was negative and pBNP was 3969. He was initially treated for presumed systolic CHF exacerbation and COPD with CPAP, IV Solumedrol, nebulizers, Lasix, and Nitrates. He was also given a dose of IV Levaquin out of concern for infection but his respiratory rate declined and his ABG's demonstrated severe respiratory acidosis so he was intubated in the ___ ED. In the ICU, EKG's demonstrated sinus tachycardia with left anterior fascicular block and ST depressions in II, V3, V4. CE's rose with CK's peaking at 229 and Troponin levels peaking at 0.45. He was placed on a Heparin gtt, ASA, beta-blocker, and a statin. The following morning, his respiratory status improved and he was extubated and placed on BIPAP before being transferred to the ___ at family request. . On arrival to the CCU, the patient was noted to be on BIPAP, but not in respiratory distress. He was able to speak with the health care team, but demonstrated a visible left hand tremor and was relative immobile. On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. he denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, +Dyslipidemia, +Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: -CABG: CABG ___ (LIMA -> LAD, SVG -> D2, OM2, RCA; stent to RCA graft ___. Has three vessel coronary disease -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: -PACING/ICD: 3. OTHER PMH: - severe AORTIC STENOSIS (mean gradient 47 mmHg) - h/o LLE Fem-pop (unclear when) - Hyperlipidemia - Obstructive sleep apnea - GERD - Anxiety - Colon cancer s/p sigmoid colectomy w/ colorectal anastomosis ___ and adjuvant Xeloda therapy - PVD - B12 deficiency anemia - Ascending aortic aneurysm (4.2x4.2 in ___ - Anterior wall abdominal hernia - COPD - HTN - Asthma <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Dad died of MI at ___. 2 brother had MI. One brother had emphysema. One other brother with brain tumor. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS on admission: T 97.3 BP 128/73 HR 89 RR 8 O2 sat 98% on BIPAP at 30% FiO2 GENERAL: Well-developed elderly man in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NC/AT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: JVD not able to be assessed ___ soft tissue obscuring anatomy CARDIAC: RRR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs audible. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NT/ND, large ventral hernia with multiple abdominal scars throughout the abdomen. No HSM. Abdominal aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominal bruits. Positive bowel sounds. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: DP 1+ Left: DP 1+ NEURO: CNII-CXII intact, able to follow commands, easily conversant, moving all extremities <PERTINENT RESULTS> 2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___: OSH, EF 45-50%, with aortic valve area of 0.8cm2 and ___ aortic insufficiency. . ___: The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild global left ventricular hypokinesis (LVEF = 45-50%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets are moderately thickened. There is severe aortic valve stenosis (valve area 0.8cm2). An eccentric jet of mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets and supporting structures are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad. IMPRESSION: Severe aortic valve stenosis. Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with mild global hypokinesis. Mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Mild aortic regurgitation. Compared with the report of the prior study (images unavailable for review) of ___, the severity of aortic stenosis has progressed, mild aortic regurgitation is now seen, left ventricular systolic function is less vigorous, and the estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is higher. . CARDIAC CATH ___: RIGHT ATRIUM {a/v/m} -/___ RIGHT VENTRICLE {s/ed} ___ PULMONARY ARTERY {s/d/m} ___ PULMONARY WEDGE {a/v/m} -/___ LEFT VENTRICLE {s/ed} 143/11 AORTA {s/d/m} ___ SYSTEMIC VASC. RESISTANCE 1604 PULMONARY VASC. RESISTANCE 214 . PROXIMAL LAD 40% stenosis MID-LAD 100% stenosis DIAGONAL-1 100% stenosis DIAGONAL-2 DIFFUSELY DISEASED OM-2 90% stenosis . Impressions: 1. Three vessel native coronary artery disease. 2. Known occlusion of all SVGs. 3. Patent LIMA-LAD graft. 4. Mild pulmonary arterial hypertension. 5. Severe, but noncritical aortic stenosis. 6. Normal biventricular diastolic function. CT Abd/pelvis Noncon ___ CT ABDOMEN WITHOUT IV CONTRAST: Lung bases are clear without consolidation or pleural effusion. The heart size is normal without pericardial effusion. Dense calcification of the coronary arteries is noted. In the abdomen, assessment of solid organs is limited in the absence of IV contrast. However, the liver is grossly unremarkable. A focal hypodensity anteriorly is unchanged and likely represents focal fatty infiltration. A small gallstone is present in a decompressed gallbladder. The pancreas, spleen, adrenal glands and kidneys are grossly unremarkable. There is no hydronephrosis in either kidney. Perinephric stranding size is unchanged. The stomach and duodenum are distended with fluid and small amount of ingested material. The esophagus also contains fluid. There is no free air or free fluid in the abdomen. The abdominal aorta demonstrates atherosclerotic calcification, but is normal in caliber. There is no mesenteric or retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy by size criteria. CT PELVIS WITHOUT IV CONTRAST: Large bowel demonstrates residual oral contrast material, possibly from the CT of ___ or from an outside hospital study. Loops of small bowel are distended, extending to the distal small bowel. Both small and large bowel extends into a large, wide-based ventral hernia. A transition in small bowel caliber is noted just adjacent to the ventral hernia, with a small segment of fecalization of contents of the dilated small bowel, measuring up to 4 cm. Distally, there is marked decompression of the distal and terminal ileum. The colon is relatively decompressed, although still retained a small amount of stool and contrast material. There is no extraluminal fluid or air. The sigmoid colon demonstrates scattered diverticulosis without diverticulitis. There is no free fluid layering dependently in the pelvis. The urinary bladder contains excrete contrast material. There is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy by size criteria. A fem-fem bypass graft is in place. The patient has undergone prior low anterior resection and surgical material is present at the rectosigmoid junction. OSSEOUS STRUCTURES: Degenerative changes are present throughout the lower spine, with no interval change. There is no new fracture. IMPRESSION: 1. High-grade small-bowel obstruction, with dilatation of proximal loops up to 4 cm, and complete decompression of the distal and terminal ileum. Obstruction may be early, as there is residual oral contrast and stool within the colon, which is minimally decompressed. No evidence of perforation. Obstruction occurs adjacent to the mouth of the large ventral hernia. However, both dilated and decompressed loops pass into and out of the hernia sac. Obstruction may be related to adhesions. 2. Cholelithiasis without cholecystitis. 3. Diverticulosis without diverticulitis. 4. No evidence of obstruction at the rectosigmoid anastomosis. 5. Atherosclerotic disease. ___ abd x-ray Single supine portable abdomen radiograph was obtained. The radiograph demonstrates focal mild dilatation of small bowel loops in the epigastric region measuring 3.2 cm, consistent with the small bowel loops seen within the ventral hernia on the prior CT scan. Air is seen within the descending colon and the rectum. The relative lack of air in the distal small bowel suggests likely partial or early small bowel obstruction. There is no intraperitoneal free air. The NG tube terminates at the gastroesophageal junction, and the sideholes likely are at the distal esophagus. Recommended advancement of the NG tube. IMPRESSION: 1. Findings suggestive of early/partial small bowel obstruction. 2. Recommended further advancement of the NG tube. Disp: *1 INH* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Acute on Chronic Systolic and Diastolic congestive Heart Failure Chronic Kidney Disease, Stage 2 Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Exacerbation Aortic Valve Stenosis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had trouble breathing and needed to be intubated at ___ ___. You were extubated and transferred to ___ ___ to evaluate your heart. You were treated with antibiotics for COPD (emphysema) and given prednisone and nebulizer treatments to help your oxygen level. A Cardiac catheterization showed blockages in your arteries which may have made your breathing worse. You had 2 stents placed in an artery in your heart. You will need to be on Plavix for one year and possibly longer. It is extremely important that you take Plavix and aspirin every day and not miss any doses. Missing doses could cause your stents to clot off and cause a heart attack or death While you were here some of your medications were changed. You should CONTINUE taking: -Imdur 120mg daily -Metoprolol 25mg three times a day -Tylenol ___ every 6 hours as needed for pain -Albuterol nebs four times a day and every 2 hours as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing - Amitriptyline 25mg nightly - Celexa 20 mg twice a dy - Advair 500/50 twice a day - multivitamin daily - trental 400mg three times a day - Seroquel 12.5mg twice a day - Spiriva 18 mcg daily - Fish oil - Vitamin B1 and B12 - Ativan 1mg every 8 hours as needed for anxiety. You should not drive with this medication. You should START taking: - Plavix 75 mg daily - take bactrim for PCP pneumonia prevention because of your steroids until your doctor tells you to stop it - You should stop smoking. Use the nicotine patch once a day to help. DO NOT smoke while using the patch since it can be even more dangerous for your heart. You should CHANGE: - INSTEAD of Aspirin 81 mg daily START spirin 325mg and your cardiologist will let you know when to come down to 81mg - Increase your Simvastatin to 80 mg daily - STOP Prilosec and INSTEAD START Ranitidine for reflux since Prilosec an interfere with your new heart stents. - You should increase your Prednisone to 30mg daily (one 20mg pill plus two 5mg pills) through ___. On ___, start taking a total of 25mg daily (one 20mg pill plus one 5mg pill) . Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 6 pounds in 3 days.
target: ___ year old man with a complicated history including CAD s/p CABG, PAD, systolic CHF (EF 45-50% in ___ w/ diastolic dysfunction, severe COPD, severe AS (0.8cm2) & AI and a severe ventral hernia who presents as a transfer from ___ ___ for respiratory failure. After rapid stabilization of his respiratory status, he went for a cath with PCI with DESx2 to the RCA on ___. He had intermittent abdominal pain that progressed to an SBO on ___. Patient made progressively less urine and was transferred to MICU through ___. He was sent to the cardiology service on ___ and the SBO subsequently resolved. # Small bowel obstruction Patient has history of severe ventral hernia s/p laparotomy for colon resection and intermittent abdominal pain, last on ___. He received a CT ABD with contrast that was negative for SBO at that time. On ___ he complained of abdominal pain that passed with ativan and simethicone. On ___ he had constipation, ___ he had obstipation, bilious emesis and acute renal failure. A NGT was placed. Surgery was consulted. All PO only medications were held except for Plavix which was given down the NGT. Surgery followed and his NGT drainage decreased and he started to have BMs on ___. On ___ the NGT was pulled. Mr. ___ then had intermittent nausea without vomiting which resolved with Ranitidine. He continue to have BMs and flatus. # ARF: On ___ he developed ARF in the setting of SBO. Patient made very little urine and was therefore transfered to a MICU for management of fluid status given ARF and Aortic stenosis. IVF were started and a foley catheter was placed which was subsequently removed with voiding prior to discharge. His creatinine at d/c was 1.2, at his baseline. # Respiratory failure/ COPD Patient with known history of COPD, Asthma, and OSA as well as an extensive smoking history. He is on 2L of continuous O2 as well as Albuterol, Advair, and Tiotropium at home and over the past 3 months has required multiple intubations for respiratory distress despite repeated courses of Prednisone & antibiotics, most recently approximately 2 weeks PTA. He was intubated on ___ at ___ for an ABG of 7.___/62/32 and was extubated on ___ AM to CPAP prior to transfer after improved respiratory status. Etiology likely obstructive lung disease with systolic CHF as patient did not demonstrate e/o infection. In the CCU, the patient was placed on BIPAP and eventually weaned to 2L of NC over approximately 24 hours. He received 40 mg of Prednisone daily and a course of levaquin. By ___, he was on 2 litres, saturating at 97%. He was able to tolerate room air with good saturations on day of discharge. He was discharged with a slow steroid taper. # Systolic Heart Failure Diasolic Heart Failure Aortic Stenosis, Severe Aortic Insufficiency Patient with known systolic heart failure, last EF in ___ demonstrated EF 45-50% with severe AS (mean gradient 47 mm Hg and area 0.8cm^2) and ___ AR. His EF is unchanged from echocardiograms, but as his AR has progressed significantly since his last echo one month prior, his true forward flow is likely more compromised than his EF would suggest. CXR's from OSH have not demonstrated e/o congestion or effusions and clinical exam does not support fluid overload, but pBNP was elevated at 3969. Patient possibly a candidate for percucanteous valve replacement vs valvuloplasty however this decision will be deferred to the outpatient setting. # CORONARIES: Patient s/p CABG ___ (LIMA -> LAD, SVG -> D2, OM2, RCA; stent to RCA graft ___. His last cardiac catheterization in ___ demonstrated three vessel coronary disease with a patent LIMA, but occlusion of all vein grafts. Patient with possible old inferior MI based on micro-Q waves in II, III, AvF, but EKG on admission does not demonstrate new ST changes. CE's trended down from OSH levels (peak CK 229) and patient was CP free. Patient initially on Heparin gtt, ASA, statin, beta-blocker. He did not receive Plavix at OSH as he has a history of GI bleed and thrombocytopenia while on Plavix. He was discharged with the addition of Plavix and high-dose statin with high-dose aspirin. # RHYTHM: Patient without known history of arrythmia, but micro-Q waves in II, III, and AvF suggest prior inferior infarct not seen on ECG from ___. # Hypertension: Patient takes Imdur SR 120 mg daily & Metoprolol Tartrate 25mg TID at home. Blood pressures at OSH and in CCU were well-controlled. Given h/o AS, patient likely pre-load dependent. Imdur and Metoprolol were restarted before discharge. # Hyperlipidemia: Patient takes Simvastatin 20mg qHS at home. Given question of ACS, high dose statin warranted. Fish oil was also continued. # Alcohol abuse: Patient with extensive EtOH history and an episode of DT in ___ requiring intubation. His EtOH screen on ___ at ___ was negative and his wife reported that his last drink was on ___. Patient was maintained on a CIWA scale and continued to get his home q8H prn Ativan for anxiety. # Anxiety: Patient with h/o anxiety, on Celexa 80mg daily, Lorazepam 1mg TID:PRN, and Seroquel 12.5mg BID at home. Per OMR records, patient preferred not to take Seroquel out of concern for side effects, so it is unlikely to be an active medication. Home medications were continued. # Peripheral vascular disease: Patient with known PAD s/p LLE Fem-Pop bypass (unclear when). He also has a known ascending aortic aneurysm last measured at 4.2cm x 4.2cm in ___. ASA 325 and Pentoxyfylline SR 400mg TID were continued. # Anemia: Patient with known Vitamin B-12 deficiency anemia for which he receives daily supplementation. Iron studies during this hospitalization were normal and he was continud on his home B-12 1,000 mcg daily. # GERD: Patient was continued on his home Omeprazole 20mg daily and then was switched to an H2B before discharge. Ranitidine worked better than Famotidine. # H/o recurrent C. difficile colitis: Patient has failed multiple Flagyl regimens in the past in the context of EtOH use, and was ultimately successfully treated with an extended course of Vancomycin. He did have an episode of diarrhea and abdominal pain during this hospitalization which resolved. He had multiple bowel movements after resolution of his SBO, likely thought to be due to just improved motility. # H/o Colon cancer: s/p sigmoid colectomy w/ colorectal anastomosis ___ and adjuvant Xeloda therapy with resulting post-surgical anterior wall abdominal hernia. Patient uses belt for hernia control, but this has exacerbated SOB in the past, so it was not utilized during this hospitalization. # Active smoking habit: Patient smokes ~ 1ppd with >150 pack year history. He was given a Nicotine TD during this hospitalization and provided an Rx and counseling prior to discharge. CODE: FULL CODE (confirmed with patient's wife) COMM: Patient & patient's wife ___ ___, ___

Secondary diagnosis: coronary artery disease type 2 diabetes mellitus hypertension hyperlipidemia anxiety post-traumatic stress disorder <DISCHARGE CONDITION> afebrile, hemodynamically stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital after you had a cardiac arrest at home. You were found to have a very serious arrhythmia (ventricular fibrillation), for which you received electric defibrillation shock before arriving to the hospital. At the hospital, you were evaluated and treated with cardiac catheterization and stenting for coronary artery disease. You were observed in the intensive care unit and were found to have a stroke most likely due to cholesterol-plaques dislodged from the electric shock during resuscitation. Your hospital course was also complicated by respiratory failure, for which you were intubated, aspiration pneumonia, which we treated with antibiotics. Because of the extremely high risk of developing a lethal arrhythmia again, an automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator was placed. . We recommend that you follow up with your physicians very closely (see below). We recommended that you go to rehabilitation after discharged from the hospital, however, you refused to go. Therefore, if you go home, you should restart your activities very carefully and have somebody with you at all times, given your severe medical conditions and very high risk of fall and injury. You should not drive and should not perform any major activity by yourself, unless you talk to a physician. . Your medications have been changed as follows: - we stopped your lamotrigine (lamictal) while you were in the hospital and we recommend that you talk to your psychiatrist before restarting it - started you on aspirin 325mg PO daily and clopidogrel 75mg PO daily, please do not stop taking these medications unless directed to do so by your cardiologist - started atorvastatin 80mg PO daily for your lipid control - started metoprolol succinate 25mg PO daily for your heart disease - started lisinopril 30mg PO daily for your blood pressure - started hctz 25mg PO daily for your blood pressure - continued metformin 850mg PO BID for your diabetes, please follw up with your physican on how to control your blood sugar optimally - started oxycodone and acetaminophen as needed for pain - started docusate for your bowel movements while on opioid pain killers - started thiamine and folic acid vitamins - started pantoprazole for heart burn - continued lorazepam as needed for anxiety - continued SLNTG as needed for chest pain, please call ___ immediately, if you your chest pain lasts after 3 tablets taken 15 minutes apart. - continued your prednisone taper through ___ - started cephalexin 500mg PO q6h for 3 days after AICD placement - started albuterol/ipratropium nebulizer treatment . Please stop smoking. Information on smoking cessation was given to you on admission. . Please call your physician immediately if you have fever, headache, new neurological deficits, chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, or any other symptoms that concern you.
target: In summary, Ms ___ is a ___ y/o F with DM2, HTN, 3vCAD (s/p MI s/p RCA stent in ___, EtOH and tobacco abuse, h/o depression/PTSD, transferred to the ___ on ___ from ___ ___ for VF arrest on ___ s/p electric shock in field. Pt was initially treated in the CCU, then transferred to the MICU for management of respiratory failure, hypertension and newly-diagnosed embolic strokes, and finally transferred to the medicine floor for observation and AICD device placement. . 1) Respiratory failure/Aspiration PNA: The pt initially was difficult to ventilate in the CCU. DDx of resp failure included PE (CTA negative, but did show diffuse b/l pulm infiltrates), COPD (baseline, med non-compliance, wheezes on exam), pneumonia (sputum Cx negative, on Abx), aspiration (pre-/post-cardioversion, radiographic findings suggestive). The pt was empirically treated with steroids out of concern for a COPD flair, as well as nebulizer treatments. In this setting, after several days, her respiratory status finally imporved and she was able to be extubated on ___. Post extubation the pt did very well with minimal oxygen requirements. Her RA O2 sat was 95-100%. Steroid taper was initiated, to be continued through ___. Pt was discharged on home albuterol/ipratropium nebs. . 2) Hypetertension: In the CCU, the pt was intermittently noted to be hypertensive into the 200s- reportedly alternating SBPs from 140s to 320. Alcohol withdrawal considered, as well as RAS (normal renal u/s) and pheochromocytoma (normal torso CT). Repeat CT today showed new embolic infarcts in L occipital lobe, L frontal lobe. Neuro consulted, pt started on nicardipine gtt, pt transferred to MICU for ongoing management of her newly diagnosed stroke, respiratory failure and hypertension. Given her recent CVAs, neuro advised a goal BP of the 140s-160s. In the ICU, the pt was managed with captopril and HCTZ; she briefly required a nicardipine gtt to control her BP. On the floor, her SBPs ranged in the 100-150s range, she was continued on HCTZ 25mg PO daily, lisinopril 30mg PO daily, Toprol XL 25mg PO daily. On discharge, she was normotensive. . 3) Embolic stroke: Head CT for evaluation of HTN on ___ revealed new embolic infarcts in L occipital lobe, L frontal lobe. The findings were confirmed with MRI/MRA. Pt had a h/o CEA in ___ and the neck MRA revealed some narrowing in the R carotid artery, however, the strokes seemed to be of embolic origin given the CAD, presentation, and distribution. They most likely happened in the context of her VFib and defibrillation, as their appearance in the CT scan points towards subacute events. Thus, pt was kept on ASA and clopidogrel, but no anticoagulation was started on discharge. Pt's neurological exam significant for R sided weakness and peripheral vision loss. Sensation grossly intact, ambulation is difficult (rehab was recommended, but pt refused). . 4) Leukocytosis: The pt was noted to have an elevated WBC count over the course of her hospital stay. Given concern for aspiration around the time of the pt's defibrillation in the field, and given radiographic findings consistent with this, the pt was treated with Zosyn for an 8 day course. Her initial treatment at time of presentation also included levofloxacin and vancomycin, however these were stopped based on negative culture results. On transfer to the medicine floor, her WBC count downtrended (31.8--> 15.3, 18.4 on discharge s/p AICD placement). . Note: B-Glucan positive 360 (>80), Galactomannan negative. Tests repeated with similar findings, however fungal blood cx remained negative. Zosyn could give a false positive for galactomannan (which was negative)(N ___ J Med. ___, but this has not been reported for B-glucan (Antimicrob Agents Chemother. ___ 50(10): ___). . 5) CAD/Ischemia: Patient has prior history of inferior MI, with 3VD (diffuse 50% stenosis) on cardiac catheterization performed on day of admission. Cardiac catheterization revealed non-occlusive disease, and picture felt not to be consistent with ACS. Stenting of OM1 undertaken (not felt to be culprit lesion). The pt was continued on ASA 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily. A beta blocker was held in the setting of bronchospams on exam, however low-dose metoprolol was started on ___ppeared to tolerate well. Pt discharged on aspirin, beta-blocker, ace-i, and statin. Given 3vCAD, CABG evaluation in the future is to be considered. Since the stroke seems to have occured in the setting of v-fib/electric defibrillation, it is not thought to be a contra-indication to possible CABG, once pt is medically stabilized and improved. . 6) Arrhythmia/V-fib: Pt was in sinus rhythm with occasional PVC and asymptomatica tachycardic episodes associated with movement. Given extensive CAD and recent episode of v-fib, pt is at very high risk for a recurrence, therefore an AICD (VVI) was placed on ___. Pt to be followed regularly by electrophysiology clinic. . 7) Acute systolic CHF: Pt had a LVEF of ___ on admission in the setting of acute MI, v-fib and cardioversion. LVEF improved to >55% by the time of discharge. . 8) DM2: The pt's metformin was held and she was managed with standing insulin and a sliding scale while in house. Her blood sugar ranged in the 150-300 range while on prednisone. On discharge she was restarted on metformin 850mg BID, to be optimized as an outpatient once prednisone entirely tapered and pt on her home diet. . 9) Depression/Anxiety/PTSD: Pt has an extensive history of substance use/abuse as well as depression/PTSD/anxiety. On transfer to the medicine floor from the ICU, she experienced several episodes of anxiety, which prompted her to refuse treatments at times and threaten to leave AMA. She was treated with reassurance and lorazepam. Her outpatient lamotrigine was not continued on discharge. Pt was instructed to follow up with her outpatient psychiatrist for optimal management. . #) Please contact husband, ___, ___ for collateral information.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It has been a pleasure caring for you at ___. After about 24 hours of chest pain, you went to ___ on ___, where you were diagnosed with an inferior heart attack with ST wave elevations. You were transferred to ___, where you had a cardiac catheterization, which diagnosed that your right coronary artery was blocked. You were given medication to thin your blood and a drug-eluding stent was placed to keep the vessel open. You spent the night in the intensive care unit for monitoring and you were transferred to the cardiac step down unit the next day (___), as you were doing very well. Your stay has been without fevers or other complications and you are ready to return home today. A number of medications have been added to your list, and you should continue to take these once you return home to protect your heart and prevent further cardiovascular complications. We have stopped your Amlopidine and instead started you on Lisinopril and Metoprolol Extended Release for blood pressure control, as these medications are recommended after a heart attack. We have also started you on Aspirin 325 mg daily following your stent placement, your cardiologist will decide how long you need this dose and when you may take Aspirin 81 mg. Clopidogrel (Plavix) is another blood-thinning medication and should be taken for one year to protect your stent. Please do not stop taking the Aspirin or Plavix for any reason unless directed to by your cardiologist. These medications are absolutely necessary to protect you from another heart attack. For cholesterol control, you have been started on Atorvastatin (Lipitor). Regarding your multiple supplements, we recommend that you stop the Niacin and Vitamin E, as they can interact with the Atorvastatin. Please speak with your PCP regarding the need/benefit of the other vitamins. You have a prescription for nitroglycerin to use for chest pain. Please call ___ if you still have chest pain after 2 tablets. Call Dr. ___ you use any nitroglycerin at all.

STEMI/CAD: The patient presented with STEMI of II, III, aVF and STD of V5-6, with q-waves in II,III, and aVF already present. He was taken to the cath and was found to have a complete thrombotic occlusion to the RCA, now s/p DES. The patient was not taking ASA or a statin even though he had a prior MI in ___. The patient received ASA, Plavix, heparin gtt prior to OSH transfer and was started on intergralin prior to cath. Post-cath echo with EF 45%. Pt. was stable without CP or SOB, VSS on d/c. We started ASA 325 mg PO daily, clopidogrel 75 mg PO daily, Lisinopril 2.5 mg po daily and Metoprolol Tartrate 6.25mg po BID. #. HTN- Patient reports baseline BP is 120-140 at home. Current BP 90-110's/50-70's and mentating well. We held home amlodipine and started Lisinopril and Metoprolol Tartrate. #. HLD- not on a statin at home, does take a number of supplements, including Vitamin E and Niacin. We started atorvastatin 80mg and suggested pt. stop taking his Niacin and Vitamin E d/t interactions. Suggested the pt. consider d/cing the other supplements, with the exception of Vitamin D and any others that were prescribed by his PCP #. esophagectomy for ? esophageal CA. performed in ___. The path report did not confirm a cancer, but pt. wanted the operation just in case Contact: Wife, ___ ___ CODE: full (confirmed with pt/family) DISPO: Home. Lives with his wife at home, is retired, but active with projects around the home. Has 5 grown children, some in the area.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and a cardiac catheterization to look for blockages in your heart arteries. We found several blockages and opened the blockage that was causing your heart attack and placed a drug eluting stent in the artery to keep it open. You still have two other arteries with less serious blockages. You will need to take Plavix (Clopidogrel) and aspirin every day for at least one year and possibly longer to keep the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. Do not stop taking this medicine or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ you it is OK. We have started you on other medicines that will help your heart recover from the heart attack. You will need to follow the instructions from the physical therapist here regarding activity level after you go home. You also should not return to work until after you see Dr. ___. . We started you on the following medicines: 1. Start taking aspirin and Plavix (Clopidogrel) to prevent the stent from clotting off 2. Start taking Metoprolol to lower your heart rate and help your heart recover from the heart attack 3. Start taking Lisinopril to lower your blood pressure and help your heart recover from the heart attack 4. Start using nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain. You can take up to 2 tablets 5 minutes apart under your tongue. Please call ___ if you have chest pain that does not go away after you take nitroglycerin. Call Dr. ___ you have any chest pain at all. 5. STart taking coumadin to prevent blood clots from forming in your heart. You will be on this medicine for ___ months until your heart function improves 6. Start taking Lovenox (enoxaparin) injections twice daily until your coumadin level (INR) is more than 2.0. Dr. ___ will tell you when to stop using the Lovenox. 7. Start taking atorvastatin (lipitor) to lower your cholesterol levels.
target: Patient is a ___ yo male with no significant PMH who presented to ___ with 1 hour with chest pain found to have STEMI and 100% proximal occlusion in LAD now s/p DES to mid LAD. 1. s/p STEMI: presented to ___ less than 1 hr after onset of symptoms and was rapidly started on ACS protocol (ASA, plavix load, heparin gtt) with emergent cardiac catheterization. EKG showed diffuse STE, predominantly in precordial leads suggesting a "wrap around LAD". During catheterization, had a DES placed in 100% occlusion in LAD, also noted to have significant CAD in other vessels which were not intervened upon given STEMI. Patient tolerated procedure well with no complications, with groin site appearring c/d/i and no post-procedural chest discomfort. Cardiac enzymes were trended and peaked with CK-MB of 392, trop 8.51. Transaminases were initially elevated thought ___ to acute MI and trended down by time of discharge. Hemoglobin A1C was within normal limits and ___ lipid panel revealed LDL of 111 with HDL of 153. Post-procedure, patient was maintained on ASA, plavix, atorvostatin, metoprolol and ACEI (titrated captopril which was changed to lisinopril prior to discharge). Echo revealed apical akinesis, severe hypokinesis of the distal half of the anterior septum and anterior wall with EF of 40%. Patient was started on coumadin with heparin bridge with plan for anticoagulation for 3 months. Of note, patient will need to remain on plavix for at least 12 months and ASA indefinitely. He should undergo stress test as an outpatient with targeted lesion in RCA if patient develops recurrent angina. 2. Systolic CHF: Following anterior MI, ECHO revealed EF 40% with severe hypokinesis of the distal half of the anterior septum and anterior wall. As above, patient was started on anticoagulation with plan to continue for three months. Also started on bblocker and ACEI. Spironolactone was deferred given low blood pressures and patient's clinical status (asymptomatic). Remained clinically euvolemic through hospital course. 3. Rhythm: Maintained on telemetry throughout hospitalization. Had short run of NSVT shortly after arrival to CCU, likely ___ reperfusion of myocardium during catheterization. Electrolytes were trended daily with repletion to maintain K> 4, Mg>2. As above, started on metoprolol per rountine post-STEMI care. #Code: Full Code (confirmed with patient)
