During CCU stay, hemodynamics were monitored with aortic ballon pump, arterial line, swan ganz catheter and urine output with goal MAP > 65, UOP 50cc/hr and CVP 12 -14 (higher goal ___ likely RV infarct). While on intra-aortic balloon pump, patient maintained on heparin gtt and monitored for complications. Of note, he did develop mild thrombocytopenia and symptoms worrying for progressive limb ischemia with decreased peripheral pulses and rising CK. As hemodynamics improved dopamine was discontinued and he was weaned off intra-aortic balloon pump. Echocardiogram on ___ while on intra-aortic balloon pump showed EF of 45%, mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, c/w inferoposterior infarction. Once hypotension had resolved, he was started on metoprolol and captopril and was discharged on ___. #. Coronaries: He presented to OSH with STEMI c/b vfib arrest ___ emergency department. Emergent catheterization at OSH showed severe 2 vessel disease with 100% occlusion ___ left circumflex, 40% mid-LAD disease, sequential 90% proximal 70% distal and 90% ostial RCA lesions. He received BMS x2 to left circumflex at OSH, and was transferred to ___ for possible intervention on RCA. Received ASA 325mg, plavix load of 600mg; and was subsequentially started on ASA 325mg, plavix 75mg, and atorvostatin 80mg. When cardiogenic shock resolved, patient was also started on metoprolol succinate 100mg daily and lisinopril 10mg daily. Patient will need further risk factor modification for secondary prevention with better BP and lipid control. # ___ Cramping/ poor peripheral pulses: On review of symptoms, patient complained of lower extremity cramping with exertion, poor dorsal pedial pulses, and symptoms concerning for lower extremity ischemia upon femoral artery vascular access. ABI showed severe flow deficit of right lower extremity and significant left tibial disease. This will need to followed as an outpatient and referral to vascular surgery may be appropriate. #. s/p endotracheal intubation: Patient was emergently intubated following post-arrest agitation for airway protection; requiring minimal ventilatory support. Following resolution of cardiogenic shock, patient was successfully extubated on ___. Immediately following extubation, patient transientally desaturated to mid ___ from mild pulmonary edema and mucus plugging with possible VAP. Treated successfully with lasix and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Respiratory status improved with lasix and by ___ he was no longer requiring supplemental O2. #. Elevated CK: Upon admission, patient had CK elevated to 2604 which trended up to 8716 during course of hospitalization. Etiology was multifactorial from myocardial infarction, muscle injury from cardiac resuscitation and early lower extremity ischemia during intra-aortic balloon pump placement. Myocardial ischemia was treated as above. CK trended down once balloon pump was removed. Renal function was trended and there was no evidence of myoglobinuria or renal injury associated with elevated CK. #. Fever: on ___, patient developed fever to 101.5. Infectious evaluation with blood culture, urinalysis/ culture, sputum culture and CXR was concerning for ventilator associated PNA. Groin lines (IABP, a-line) also may have been source of infection/ fever. Patient was started on broad spectrum antibiotics with vancomycin and cefepime for HAP/ possible line infection. Sputum culture was growing GNR and GPCs. Fever curve and WBC count was trended. #. Transaminitis: Likely shock liver ___ the setting of VF arrest with cardiogenic shock. LFTs trended down thoughout his hospitalization. Patient's underlying alcohol abuse may have also contributed to elevated LFTs.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Left hand numbness. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a history of HTN and CAD and longstading cervical arthralgia and possibly peripheral neuropathy. She presents with several complaints that began last night around 9pm, as well as symptoms that she noticed over the past week or so. First, following a couple days of vomiting and feeling ill (this past ___, 3d PTA), she developed a non-productive cough continuing through today. She felt much better ___ (yesterday, ___, so good in fact that she returned to an exercise program (___ "Life Study") she hadn't done in months. She was able to walk around a track for 30mins and perform their sit/stand exercises. Then, around 9pm in the evening (still ___, last night), she was sitting at home using her computer. She noticed several things at once: - headache: band-like, bifrontal, severe, constant (not throbbing), not positional - "off-balance" sensation: endorses lightheadedness, denies spinning. Says she felt like the table and chair were moving beneath her. Says this occurred while seated, then resolved shortly after. No falls. Mild nausea, not now. No vomiting. - Left hand/arm "heaviness": used the terms "numb" and "heavy" and weak. Endorses tingling. Denies pain. Said that she needed to lift the left arm with the (normal) Right arm. When she lifted the Left arm into position, she was able to type with the fingers with good control, but they never stopped feeling numb/tingly (continues through today). - chest pain: came on suddenly with other symptoms last night and did not resolve until just before my exam in ED today. She says she thought it was "indigestion" but did not eat anything unusual or large for dinner L/N. Her substernal chest felt "heavy." The pressure-like sensation moved to her left chest, and persisted today, until just recently ___ on ED arrival, now ___. She slept well, but on awakening she realized the LUE symptom had continued and possibly worsened. In bed, she felt like the arm was "hanging down" from the shoulder to the hand. When she got up to walk she was "stumbling" worse than she has recently and she felt "off-balance" (now only when walking). Again denies vertiginous sensation. Endorses LH with walking. Her neck feels "good" relative to her baseline, with stable restriction of ROM on the left moreso than the right. She says she had tingling in her toes when she puts her chin to her chest in the past, but not recently, and definitely not now. No symptoms in her arms or hands when she moves her neck. She called her daughter and PCP, who asked her to go to the ED. She was BIBA and arrived in NAD c/o ___ chest pain as above. She c/o left-sided weakness as above and the ED physicians consulted us (Neurology) for possible stroke. They ordered NCHCT and CT-chest with contrast to r/o aortic dissection (thought at that time was dissection + stroke). Review of Systems: negative except as above Denies current headache. No loss of vision at any time. No blurred vision or diplopia. Agrees voice may be hoarse, maybe for past week. Denies dysarthria, dysphagia. Repeatedly denies vertigo (but see above re. desk/table "moving" sensation last night). Has remote h/o vertiginous episodes, none recently. Denies tinnitus or hearing change. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae other than Left arm and possibly mild leg weakness. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Endorses difficulty with gait as above. On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. +cough as above, no shortness of breath. Denies palpitations. +chest pain as above. Denies current nausea (see above), no vomiting. No diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CAD -- "50% occlusion" of ?; denies stent. No h/o CABG. Denies h/o CHF or MI or angina. Unsure results of prior echo/stress tests. 3. Chronic neck pain s/p C-spine facet injections for Dx arthritis 3. ED visit here ___ for sudden-onset Left-sided neck stiffness and sharp ___ pain, exacerbated by mouth/facial movements and a/w headache (relieved by Aleve) as well as decreased appetite, generalized fatigue, photophobia, pain with chewing and pain with swallowing. Workup in the ED at that time -- including NCHCT and LP/CSF -- was negative except for ESR slight elevation at 38. She was reportedly neurologically intact at that time. She was observed overnight and discharged with Rx Percocet. 4. Hypertension on CCB; previously on atenolol; says home BPs recently up to 160s/100s; says PCP BPs usually 140s/x. 5. chronic arthritis and LBP s/p ?steroid injections 6. h/o vertiginous episodes, NOS 7. h/o painful paresthesias in soles of both feet, resolved per pt years ago (denies h/o DM, EtOHism); thinks she saw a Neurologist once before, but unsure who/when/Dx. 8. s/p hysterectomy 1990s 9. s/p SBO/laparatomy ___ 10. hyperlipidemia on statin 11. endorses h/o glaucoma < denies h/o stroke, seizure, or other Neurologic disease > 12. episode of lips/tongue numbness lasting about 10min ___ ago while on vacation in ___. Upon return, PCP ordered CT head and stress test (per pt), which were (per pt) normal. Around this time she started CCB and BB for HTN. Sx Never recurred. < denies h/o afib > <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Denies h/o neurologic diseases. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ON ADMISSION: ------------- Vital signs @ED triage: 97.3 108 162/84 16 100%5L (on my exam, HR was 90-100,reg; SBP low-140s; RR mid-teens; SaO2 94-100%RA) . General: Lying in bed in pants and Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: Normocephalic and atraumatic. No scleral icterus. Mucous membranes are DRY. No lesions noted in oropharynx. Neck: ~30% Limited range of motion (L>r) and significant discomfort with active or passive movement to the LEft. No nuchal rigidity. No bruits. No lymphadenopathy. No goiter. Pulmonary: Lungs good air movement at bilateral bases, but low-pitched inspiratory groan/whz bilaterally (no exp wheeze). Non-labored breathing. Cardiac: RRR, normal S1/S2 (loud S1), no M/R/G. Abdomen: Mildly overweight. Soft, non-tender, and non-distended, + normoactive bowel sounds. Extremities: Warm and well-perfused, no clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Micro-D5 on both feet. Skin: no gross rashes or lesions noted. . Neurologic examination: . Mental Status: Oriented to ___, BI-ED, ___, ___. Able to relate history without difficulty. Knows about "___ challenge in ___ court this week" and ___, ___ primaries. Attentive, and able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric, but voice sounds slightly hoarse to me (pt and daughter agree). Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension, normal prosody, and normal affect. There were no paraphasic errors. Able to read and write without difficulty. Naming is intact. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Memory - registers 3 objects and recalls ___ at 2 and 5 minutes. Calculation was intact. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect or ideomotor apraxia or left-right confusion. . -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: Pupils with bilateral (?Lt>rt) haziness, likely cataracts and slightly sluggish light reactivity, ~3.5 to 2mm. Visual fields are full. Cannot see fundi well with ophthalmascope at this time (?cataracts and pt eye movement). III, IV, VI: EOMs full and conjugate; no nystagmus; denies diplopia. ? intermittent saccadic intrusions. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact and subjectively symmetric to light touch V1-V2-V3, but with PINprick testing, she has "30%" reduction in pinprick intensity over the entire Left face (V1+2+3) and pinna, but not on the neck/entire shoulder. VII: Possibly slight lag on the Left with smile. Slight assymetry at rest, too. No ptosis. Brow elevation is symmetric. Eye closure is strong and symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact and subjectively equal to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Mild asymmetry of palate elevation with phonation (Left side weak). XI: Definite lag with Left trapezius elevation. XII: Tongue protrusion is midline, full strength bilaterally. . -Motor: No drift. ?pseudoathetotic movements of arms and R-D5 with eyes closed. No asterixis. No tremor. Grossly normal tone x4 extremities, although the Left ankle rests in slight eversion. . Sensory: - Significant subjective pinprick deficit in LEFT hand (everywhere up to the wrist) and LEFT foot (everywhere up to the ankle) and LEFT face (everywhere down to the jawline, but also including the pinna); no pinprick deficit anywhere in the torso or upper leg/thigh/forearm/arm. There was a slight pinprick gradient in the right ___ at the ankle, but pt says this is much less pronounced than on the Left. - Joint position sense is mildly impaired in both great toes (grossly intact, but makes errors with subtle movements), possibly worse on the Left. In the UEs, JPS is excellent in the distal D5 of both hands. Eyes-closed Finger-to-nose testing revealed no proprioceptive deficit (did not miss nose). - No agraphesthesia (discriminates ___ easily in both hands and at dorsum of both feet). - Vibratory sensation impaired distally, symmetrically (4sec at each great toe, 7sec at ankle, >10sec at knees, fingers). . -Reflexes (left; right): pathologically brisk in both UEs Pec/delt (+++;+++) Biceps (+++;+++) Triceps (+++;+++) Brachioradialis (+++;+++) Quadriceps / patellar (+++;++) ___ / achilles (0;0) Plantar response was MUTE bilaterally. . -Coordination: Finger-nose-finger testing and heel-knee-shin testing with no dysmetria or intention tremor. No dysdiadochokinesia noted on rapid-alternating movements (perhaps slight slowing of RAM on the Left relative to right, but not consistent). . -Gait: Stands without difficulty. Good initiation. Narrow-based, slightly hesitant stride (WITH EYES CLOSED, pt takes very short, more hesitant steps and seems ready to fall but does not). Pt says she is OK unless she takes her eyes off the ground and looks up. Turns normally. Able to walk on toes well, but unsteady on heels. NCHCT ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No acute intracranial process. 2. Likely chronic small vessel ischemic disease. . CTA CHEST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of aortic dissection. No pulmonary embolus. 2. Centrilobular emphysematous change in lungs, min b/l atelectasis. 3. Patulous, but thin-walled esophagus with small amount of fluid within. . MR HEAD, MRA BRAIN & NECK ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of acute infarct or hemorrhage. There are bilateral periventricular and subcortical T2/FLAIR hyperintensities representing microangiopathic chronic ischemic changes. 2. Atherosclerotic disease without evidence of significant stenosis or occlusion. The left vertebral artery is hypoplastic and arises directly from the aortic arch, a normal variant. There is a small infundibulum at the origin of the left Pcom. . ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___: The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF 70%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. Non-cardiac chest pain possibly musculoskeletal. Headache. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Ambulatory: requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). . NEURO EXAM PERTINENTS ON DISCHARGE: LLE > RLE weakness LEFT ___ > ___ weakness LEFT ankle inversion > eversion weakness <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to ___ with a 1 week history of facial asymmetry and an unsteady gait. You also reported 1 day of LEFT hand heaviness/numbness as well as left jaw/chest/arm pain. . We performed several blood and imaging tests to rule out serious problems such as a stroke or heart attack. You definitely did NOT have a heart attack, but with the description of your event paired with the imaging results of your head, we cannot say for sure that this was not a transient ischemic attack or TIA. A TIA is like a stroke, but its effects are not permanent, they resolve with time. . To prevent future events like this, we recommend continuing your daily aspirin. You were already taking Simvastatin 40mg and Amlodipine 5mg, but after discharge you should only continue taking the simvastatin as your blood pressure has been good on its own. All of your other home medications can also be continued as prior to admission. . We did a study called an echocardiogram to look in your heart to see if there was a source for the possible TIA there. We found no abnormalities. . Our physical therapists at the hospital evaluated you, and recommended that you be discharged to home, but with outpatient physical therapy visits to make sure that you are regaining your strength and balance.

The patient was d/c home w/ outpatient ___ and appointments for follow-up. Of note, her PCP can restart her Amlodipine in the future if the need arises, but she is not discharged on this medication as her blood pressure was within a normal range for the duration of her stay here off home anti-hypertensive medication.

Due to the eccentric nature of the regurgitant jet, its severity may be significantly underestimated (Coanda effect). There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Nicotine Lozenge 2 mg PO Q2H: PRN tobacco craving RX *nicotine (polacrilex) 2 mg take 1 as directed every 2 hours as needed Disp #*120 Gum Refills: *0 7. Prasugrel 10 mg PO DAILY Do not stop taking this drug without talking to your cardiologist. RX *prasugrel [Effient] 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*90 Tablet Refills: *3 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY - non-ST elevated myocardial infarction - ventricular fibrillation, cardiac arrest - cardiogenic shock - atrial fibrillation - hypertension - hypercholesterolemia - OSA - cardiomyopathy - mitral regurgitation - tobacco abuse <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___. You were admitted because you had a heart attack. You underwent cardiac catheterization which revealed some coronary artery disease. You had 2 stents placed. While you were having stents placed in your coronary arteries, your heart stopped pumping blood. This was fixed with defibrillation (electric shocks to the chest). Additionally, you had an episode of an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation ("A fib"), so we will send you home with a monitor to see if you have any further arrhythmias at home. You are now on aspirin. You need to take aspirin everyday. If you stop taking aspirin, you risk for having stent blockage and death. Do not stop taking aspirin unless you are told by your cardiologist. You are now on prasugrel. This medication helps keep your stent open. Do not stop taking this medication unless you are told by your cardiologist. You will need to take this for ___ year. It is critical that you not smoke cigarettes any longer. You will be discharge with nicotine lozenges, but you should talk to your primary care doctor about other options to quit smoking. We wish you all the best, Your ___ Cardiology team
target: ___ with history of HLD, HTN, tobacco abuse and sleep apnea who presented to ___ on ___ with chest pressure over a few days prior to admission. He was found to have an NSTEMI with inferior q-waves and T wave changes. He was transferred to ___. # CORONARIES: Angiography ___ showed distal RCA occlusion and thrombus in the LMCA, LAD, and 100% ostial LCx occlusion. Kissing drug eluting stents placed at bifurcation of left main coronary artery into LAD and LCX. Residual moderate mid-LAD disease, subtotal occlusion of OM2 and occlusion of distal RCA. RCA was not revascularized. # PUMP: LVEF 55% ___ TTE) > 35% ___ TTE) > 55% ___ TEE) with akinesis of the inferior segments and hypokinesis of the inferolateral segments. There was no ___ on TEE. # RHYTHM: Sinus rhythm on admission and discharge; had new atrial fibrillation during his PCI # 3-vessel coronary artery disease with non-ST elevation MI: The patient presented as a transfer from ___ ___ with biochemical evidence of NSTEMI with q-waves inferiorly and T wave changes inferiorly. He was placed on heparin ___ and went for left heart catheterization on ___. During the procedure the RCA was evaluated initially and showed total distal RCA occlusion. Before engaging the LCA, the patient had severe chest pain and started becoming hypotensive. He was started on inopressors and a balloon pump was placed. His left coronary system showed thrombus in the LMCA, LAD, and total ostial occlusion of the LCx. Given the thrombus location in all 3 vessels and cardiogenic shock, the major intervention was placement of "kissing" drug-eluting stents to the LMCA at the bifurcation into the LAD and LCx with subsequent improvement in flow. During the procedure the patient had brief atrial fibrillation and then developed VF twice that responded to defibrillation without CPR. It was unclear why he appeared to have active thrombus in all 3 coronary arteries with new thrombi likely occurring during the catheterization. This may have been due to thrombus formation on the catheter, hypercoaguable state, or cardiac thromboembolism to the coronary arteries. He was started on tirofiban given the thrombus burden and transferred to the CCU post-procedure on a balloon pump and off inopressors. He was continued on heparin gtt initially, which was switched to bivalriduin gtt (given c/f drug-related hypercoagulability given appearance of and extent of thrombus found on cath) which was continued for a total of 48hr. Overnight, blood was noted in his IABP line and so IABP was removed. The balloon pump did not appear to be augmenting his MAPs significantly and he did not have hemodynamic issues after removal. After removal of IABP, he continued to do well. And patient was loaded with and continued on ticagrelor. His troponin peaked at 10.8 and CKMB peaked at 387. Patient also had a post-NSTEMI TTE which showed LVEF 35% (no apical akinesis). However, post-catheterization TEE to evaluate for ___ showed EF of 55%. There were moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the inferior segments and hypokinesis of the inferolateral segments. Because TEE was negative for thrombus and patient's transient atrial fibrillation in the cath lab was thought related to catheterization and so decision was made to defer anticoagulation. Repeat TTE ___ showed 45-50% EF with more functional MR, which supported the decision to pursue a second cardiac catheterization. On ___ he had repeat coronary angiography with successful POBA of mid-distal LCX, successful DES 2x of mid & distal RCA. He had severe ostial stenosis of ramus artery at the trifurcation with the prior LMCA>LAD and LMCA>LCx kissing stents that was not intervened upon. He will need a repeat TTE in the next ___ weeks to reevaluate systolic function and mitral regurgitation following revascularization. At discharge, patient was in sinus rhythm and patient was sent home with a monitor to continue to assess for cardiac arrhythmia. Patient was evaluated by ___ and outpatient cardiac rehab was recommended. #sCHF: Post-NSTEMI TTE demonstrated LEVF 35% with moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction and akinesis of the inferior segments and hypokinesis of the inferolateral segments likely secondary to CAD. No ___. However, TEE showed improvement of EF to 55% one day later. Patient was started on low dose lisinopril of 2.5mg daily and metoprolol succinate 50mg daily for heart failure with plans to uptitrate as tolerated by BPs. #New AF: No prior history of AF. Occurred transiently in the setting of ischemia in the cath lab. He was otherwise in sinus rhythm. Most likely a result of extreme catecholaminergic tone during cath, especially given electrical and hemodynamic instability. No AF on telemetry after leaving cath lab. CHADS2=1. Decision made not to systemically anticoagulate. Patient was continued on metoprolol 12.5mg TID initially and transitioned to 50mg XL prior to discharge home. Patient was also discharged with an event monitor to assess for further dysrhythmias. #Cardiogenic shock: Required 2 pressors in the cath lab and IABP, but pressure improved after placement of stents to LMCA>LCx and LMCA>LAD. Initially arrived with IABP, which was removed shortly therafter ___ blood in the helium gas line (c/f balloon rupture). Patient continued to do well off the balloon pump and was able to be weaned off pressors within the next ___ hr. #VF arrest: Occurred x2 in the cath lab. Likely ischemic. TTE prior to cath had EF 55% with hypokinesis of the basal-mid inferior wall and basal inferoseptal walls suggestive of prior MI (q-waves on ECG). As his EF was normalized on discharge and he was considered low likelihood for subsequent sudden cardiac arrest after partial revascularization, no ICD/lifevest was indicated. Patient sent home with an event monitor to assess for dysrhythmia. ================= CHRONIC ISSUES: ================= #Tobacco abuse: Long-standing smoker, though had quit once in past and started smoking again during divorce. Patient is now very motivated to quit again. He was given nicotine gum and encouraged to quit smoking. ___ consider for varenicline or bupropion as outpatient. #HTN: Held HCTZ. He was started on metoprolol succinate and lisinopril. These should be up-titrated as hemodynamics allow. #HLD: Started atorvastatin 80mg daily. #OSA: continued CPAP at home setting of 13 cm H20 TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -DISCHARGE WEIGHT: 131.6 kg (discharged off diuretics) -Discharged with ___ of Hearts Event monitor to evaluate for atrial fibrillation (his original, transient post-arrest rhythm) -continue Prasugrel 10 mg PO DAILY minimum x12 months -continue aspirin for life -please uptitrate lisinopril as tolerated by BPs -patient needs referral for outpatient cardiac rehab -consider repeat TTE in ___ weeks to evaluate stability of EF -discharged off diuretics given stability/euvolemia while inpatient. Consider reevaluation for diuretic as an outpatient.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> adhesive tape / Plavix <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> CAD, HTN <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Cardiac catheterization with placement of bare-metal stent to the RCA <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o F with PMH of HTN, HLD, hypothyroidism, severe vascular disease (multiple femoral bypass procedures, L CEA, renal artery stenosis s/p stenting), lung Ca s/p R middle lobe resection (___) with recent recurrence on PET, CKD (baseline Cr high-2's), and GERD s/p ___, transferred to ___ for management of multivessel CAD. She initially presented on ___ to ___ with a chief complaint of epigastric pain. Per documentation there, she complained of ___ months of intermittent epigastric pain with a more significant episode that caused her to present to the hospital. During that episode ___ epigastric pain radiating to her neck and jaw with numbness with sweating, and the episode lasted longer than usual. Of note, she does have a history of reflux and had a laparoscopic fundoplication in the past and so was attributing her episodes of epigastric pain to GERD. EKG showed T wave inversions in V3 to V6 with ST depressions in V5 to V6, and her troponin I was found to be 0.14 with a CK-MB of 4.2. She was started on a heparin drip, aspirin, Lipitor, and continued on her home labetalol. She was medically managed on the floor with heparin and blood pressure control. On ___ she underwent pharmacologic stress testing during which she had chest pain with regadenoson infusion and became hypotensive. She had increasingly marked diffuse ischemic changes on the ECG and intermittent ___ then 3rd degree AV block. Reversed with Aminophylline. After administration of aminophylline, her HR recovered to 90 or so and her BP over-shot her baseline, going up to 180-190 systolic. She continued to have chest pain for a total of about 12 minutes before completely resolving. She was subsequently brought to Cath Lab and was found to have a LAD proximal 70% stenosis, ___ Diag Proximal 70% stenosis, ___ 70%, ___ RCA 70% stenosis with likely ruptured plaque (culprit lesion). No intervention was performed. She was transferred to the ICU and required nitroglycerin drip for control of her blood pressure. Plan was to transfer here for CABG evaluation and possible PCI. Of note, on recent f/u with her oncologist she was found to have recurrence of her lung adenocarcinoma in her RML on PET scan with mildly increased uptake in an enlarged R hilar LN, plan at that time was to do PFT to evaluate for further resection. There was also consideration for bronchoscopy with ultrasound guided biopsy of the mildly enlarged R hilar LN. Notable labs from ___: HbA1c 5.8 Cholesterol 206, LDL 106, HDL ___ labs on transfer: WBC 5.5 Hemoglobin 9.3 Platelets ___ 29 -------------< 79 5.4 20 2.45 On arrival to the CCU, patient reported feeling well this no CP, epigastric pain, SOB, DOE, orthopnea, PND, lightheadedness/dizziness or palpitations. ROS: Positive per HPI. Remaining 10 point ROS reviewed and negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Cardiac History: -Hypertension -Tobacco use -Hyperlipidemia -AAA Other PMH: -CKD stage IV with renal artery stenosis, atrophic R kidney -peripheral artery disease -Hypothyroidism -Lung adenocarcinoma status post right middle lobe lobectomy ___ with no adjuvant therapy -Past surgical history: Right middle lobe lung resection, laparoscopic fundoplication, cholecystectomy, hysterectomy, multiple bypass surgery is of leg, carotid endarterectomy, renal artery stent placement. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Aunt with possible ovarian cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: -======= VS: afebrile, BP 140/80, HR 97, O2 93% on RA GENERAL: Well developed, well nourished in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Sclera anicteric. PERRL. EOMI. NECK: Supple. no appreciable JVD CARDIAC: tachycardic, regular rhythm. ___ systolic murmur loudest at ___ LUNGS: CTAB, No wheezes/rales/rhonchi. normal work of breathing ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. EXTREMITIES: Warm, well perfused. No clubbing, cyanosis, or peripheral edema. SKIN: No significant lesions or rashes. PULSES: Distal pulses palpable and symmetric. NEURO: A&Ox3, moving all 4 extremities with purpose, face symmetric DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: -======= GENERAL: Well developed, well nourished in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: Atraumatic. Sclera anicteric. PERRL. EOMI. NECK: Supple. no appreciable JVD CARDIAC: tachycardic, regular rhythm. ___ systolic murmur loudest at ___ LUNGS: CTAB, No wheezes/rales/rhonchi. normal work of breathing ABDOMEN: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. EXTREMITIES: Warm, well perfused. No clubbing, cyanosis, or peripheral edema. SKIN: No significant lesions or rashes. PULSES: Distal pulses palpable and symmetric. NEURO: A&Ox3, moving all 4 extremities with purpose, face symmetric <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: -== ___ 11: 00PM BLOOD WBC-5.3 RBC-2.85* Hgb-8.6* Hct-27.9* MCV-98 MCH-30.2 MCHC-30.8* RDW-14.1 RDWSD-50.4* Plt ___ ___ 11: 00PM BLOOD Neuts-66.6 ___ Monos-12.0 Eos-0.0* Baso-1.0 Im ___ AbsNeut-3.51 AbsLymp-1.05* AbsMono-0.63 AbsEos-0.00* AbsBaso-0.05 ___ 11: 00PM BLOOD ___ PTT-63.3* ___ ___ 11: 00PM BLOOD Glucose-78 UreaN-29* Creat-2.2* Na-138 K-5.2 Cl-107 HCO3-19* AnGap-12 ___ 11: 00PM BLOOD Calcium-8.7 Phos-3.8 Mg-2.1 DISCHARGE LABS: -== ___ 07: 30AM BLOOD WBC-4.4 RBC-3.07* Hgb-9.2* Hct-29.9* MCV-97 MCH-30.0 MCHC-30.8* RDW-14.5 RDWSD-50.2* Plt ___ ___ 07: 30AM BLOOD Glucose-80 UreaN-27* Creat-2.7* Na-139 K-5.1 Cl-107 HCO3-20* AnGap-12 ___ 07: 30AM BLOOD Mg-1.8 IMAGING/STUDIES: -=== Cardiac cath with PCI (___) Access obtained in left radial artery using micropunture kit and ___ x 11 cm Terumo Slender sheath placed. At end of case this was removed and TR band placed with successful hemostasis. Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on a planned basis based on coronary angiographic findings documented on a prior angiogram (performed at ___. A 6 ___ JR4 guide was used to engage the RCA and provided adequate support. Angiography confirmed an irregular 80% ___ stenosis. There was diffuse 40% stenosis in the mid segment. Crossed with a Prowater wire into the distal RCA. Predilated with a 3.0 mm balloon and then IVUS performed using the ___ Eye catheter which was advanced to mid segment of the vessel. IVUS images showed extensive homogenous and mildly calcified plaques and vessel measurements were performed. A 4.5mm x 18mm Multilink Ultra stent (bare metal) was deployed at 14 atm. Repeat IVUS imaging showed that stent was midly malapposed in the proximal segment. Was therefore postdilated using a 5.0 mm NC balloon at high pressure. Final angiography revealed normal flow, no dissection and 0% residual stenosis. Complications: There were no clinically significant complications. Findings - Three vessel coronary artery disease. - Successful PCI with bare metal stent of the RCA. Recommendations - ASA 81mg per day indefinitely. - Ticagrelor 90mg BID for 1 month. - Only 15 cc of contrast used for the case. But still being hydrated ___ since high risk for contrast nephropathy. - Further management as per primary cardiology team. OSH IMAGING/STUDIES: -=== ___ Cardiac Cath Angiographic findings Cardiac Arteries and Lesion Findings LAD: Lesion on Dist LAD: Proximal subsection.70% stenosis 12 mm length. Lesion on ___ Diag: Proximal subsection.70% stenosis 6 mm length. ___: Lesion on ___ CX: Proximal subsection.70% stenosis 10 mm length. RCA: Lesion on ___ RCA: Proximal subsection.70% stenosis 15 mm length. Preprocedure TIMI III flow was noted. Good runoff was present. The lesion was diagnosed as Low Risk (A). Lesion plaque is ruptured. Culprit lesion. CONCLUSIONS Procedure Summary Severe three vessel CAD with probable rupture plaque in the proximal RCA. Recommendations Medical management and optimization of BP and fluid status (given single kidney and Cr 2.5) IVFs (genle) post cath CABG evaluation; if turned down can consider contrast "free" PCI (IVUS -guided). ___ TTE Summary: Normal LV size, wall thickness and systolic function. Calculated LVEF 69% by ___ biplane method with no regional wall motion abnormalities. NSR. Diastolic indices suggest grade 1 diastolic dysfunction. Normal left atrium. Normal right atrium. Normal RV size and systolic function. Aortic valve is mild to moderately calcified. Peak trans-aortic velocity 2.43 m/s with a mean gradient of 12 mm Hg. Using an LVOT diameter 20 mm, calculated ___ 1.29 cm2.trileaflet. Moderate (2+) aortic insufficiency present. AR VC width 0.5 cm. Normal mitral valve structure and function. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation. Normal tricuspid valve structure and function. Trace tricuspid regurgitation. Estimated PA systolic pressure 28 mmHg, assuming an RA pressure of 3 mmHg. Normal pulmonic valve structure and function. No evidence of pericardial effusion. The aortic root and ascending aorta are normal in size. Normal IVC size and respirophasic variation suggesting normal RA pressures. No Doppler evidence of ASD or PFO. ___ CT Abdomen/Pelvis IMPRESSION: 1. No acute findings are identified in the abdomen or pelvis. 2. There is chronic diverticulosis. ___ VQ Scan IMPRESSION: The examination is low probability for pulmonary embolus. ___ PET Scan Impression: 1. The enlarging right upper nodules are FDG avid and there is mild FDG avid mediastinal adenopathy, findings consistent with malignancy. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Esomeprazole 20 mg Other BID 2. Ezetimibe 10 mg PO DAILY 3. Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS 4. Labetalol 100 mg PO DAILY 5. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 6. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 7. Ondansetron 4 mg PO BID: PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 8. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Nitroglycerin SL 0.3 mg SL Q5MIN: PRN chest pain 2. TiCAGRELOR 90 mg PO BID to prevent stent thrombosis 3. Labetalol 300 mg PO BID 4. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 5. Esomeprazole 20 mg Other BID 6. Ezetimibe 10 mg PO DAILY 7. Gabapentin 300 mg PO QHS 8. Levothyroxine Sodium 75 mcg PO DAILY 9. Ondansetron 4 mg PO BID: PRN Nausea/Vomiting - First Line 10. HELD- Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY This medication was held. Do not restart Lisinopril until you see your nephrologist or PCP. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: NSTEMI SECONDARY DIAGNOSES: ___ on CKD stage IV, hypertension, RML lung adenocarcinoma <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear , Please see below for more information on your hospitalization. It was a pleasure taking part in your care here at ___! We wish you all the best! - Your ___ Care Team WHY WERE YOU ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? -You were admitted to the hospital because you had a heart attack (non-ST elevlation myocardial infarction) and needed to have a stent placed. WHAT WAS DONE WHILE YOU WERE IN THE HOSPITAL? -A procedure called a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) where xrays are used to look at the blood vessels around your heart was completed. A stent was placed in one of your arteries in order to open a blockage that was seen and to improve the blood flow to your heart. -You were started on a medication called ticagrelor which is essential to take for at least one month until you follow up with your cardiologist to make sure that the stent remains open. -Your home medication labetalol was increased to help better control your blood pressure. -You were given a prescription for a medication called nitroglycerin which can be taken on an as needed basis to help with chest pain. -We have asked that you temporarily stop taking your lisinopril until you see your nephrologist to make sure that your kidney function is back to where it was prior to the hospitalization. Please monitor your urine output and if it decreases please call your PCP as soon as possible to be evaluated. WHAT DO YOU NEED TO DO WHEN YOU LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? - Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below). It is very important that you take your aspirin and ticagrelor (Brilinta) EVERY DAY. - Follow up with your doctors as listed below - Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms or you develop chest pain, are unable to urinate, develop swelling in your legs, abdominal distention, or shortness of breath at night.
target: ___ y/o F with PMH of HTN, HLD, hypothyroidism, severe vascular disease (multiple femoral bypass procedures, L CEA, renal artery stenosis s/p stenting), lung Ca s/p R middle lobe resection (___) with recent recurrence on PET, CKD (baseline Cr high-2's), and GERD s/p ___, transferred to ___ for management of NSTEMI and multivessel CAD. #CORONARIES: LAD proximal 70% stenosis, ___ Diag Proximal 70% stenosis, ___ 70%, ___ RCA 70% stenosis #PUMP: 69% #RHYTHM: NSR ACUTE ISSUES: ============= #NSTEMI #multivessel CAD: Pt presented with epigastric discomfort, found to have EKG changes and elevated trop I (peaked at 0.14). Developed chest pain and ischemic changes during pharmacologic stress, and had cath done showing multivessel disease with rupture lesion plaque in proximal RCA. ECHO done with EF 69% and no wall motion abnl, mod AI and Grade I diastolic dysfunction. On admission she was maintained on a heparin gtt, aspirin 81mg daily, ezetimibe 10mg daily. On ___ she underwent repeat cardiac cath with placement of a 4.5mmx18mm Multilink ultra bare metal stent in the proximal RCA. She was started on ticagrelor 90mg BID (history of rash to Plavix) which she will require for 1 month for DAPT. She was not started on a statin due to history of GI intolerance and dizziness. She was discharged on ticagrelor 90 BID, ASA 81, ezetemibe 10 daily, and prn sublingual nitro. Her home lisinopril was held in the setting of ___ with plan to follow-up with nephrology within two weeks to discuss restarting. Initiation of a statin can be discussed within two weeks with her cardiologist and PCP (given her questionable allergy). Her home dose of labetalol was also uptitrated as described below. Transitional issue also to discuss if she should be switched to a cardioselective beta-blocker. #RML lung adenocarcinoma with recurrence s/p RML resection in ___. Plan at that time was to do PFT to evaluate for further resection, with possible LN biopsy. On communication with her outpatient pulmonologist scheduled to do her LN biopsy, Dr. ___ was determined that an MI within 4 weeks was a relative contraindication to bronchoscopy and decision was made to proceed with PCI prior to LN biopsy. Dr. ___ was updated of her discharge and will plan to contact the patient for scheduling of her biopsy. #Hypertension SBP to 200s following nuclear stress test at ___ - improved after starting nitro gtt. Has h/o renal artery stenosis with atrophic rt kidney and normal sized left kidney with stent in L renal artery in place. Received hydration post-cath at the OSH as well as post PCI. Cr on discharge was mildly elevated to 2.7 with good UOP. Her home lisinopril was held in the setting of mild ___ and recent contrast with PCI with plan to see her nephrologist within two weeks to discuss restarting. #Klebsiella UTI UCx from ___ growing Klebsiella, >100k. Sensitivities with resistance to ampicillin and nitrofurantoin, otherwise pan-sensitive. s/p 2 days of CTX at OSH, received an additional day of Bactrim on ___ to complete a 3 day course of antibiotics. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #GERD #Dysphagia/odynophagia: s/p laparoscopic fundoplication that required reoperation. Reports worsening dysphagia/odynophagia with greater solid food dysphagia. GI consult at ___ recommended EGD, although unclear at this time whether presenting symptoms are truly related to GI etiology vs angina. She was given pantoprazole daily and Maalox PRN. She should continue to have follow up with her outpatient GI provider to monitor her symptoms of dysphagia. #Hypothyroidism -Continued home synthroid 75mcg daily #constipation -Continue home daily miralax TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== []To continue ticagrelor 90mg BID x1 month for bare-metal stent. Should continue aspirin 81mg daily indefinitely []Ensure scheduling with interventional pulmonologist Dr. ___ ___ scheduling of her lung biopsy []Home lisinopril held in setting of ___. Consider restarting after f/u with nephrology and repeat creatinine []Home labetalol was increased from 100 mg daily to 300 mg twice daily. Recheck blood pressure to make sure she is tolerating the increase well/isn't still hypertensive []Hx statin intolerance: Was not started on a statin for her NSTEMI due to history of GI intolerance and dizziness. Consider challenging with statin. #CODE: FULL CODE confirmed #CONTACT/HCP: ___ (daughter) ___

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization with placement of Bare Metal Stent <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> I have reviewed the admission note and agree with all details. In brief this a ___ M with history of smoking, borderline diabetes, and little medical follow up who was transferred from ___ with substernal radiating chest pain, EKG changes, and elevated troponins. He was transferred to ___ for potential cardiac catheterization. . Currently, patient is chest pain free. . ROS: Denies fever, chills, night sweats, headache, vision changes, rhinorrhea, congestion, sore throat, cough, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, BRBPR, melena, hematochezia, dysuria, hematuria. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> The patient was told he had "Borderline diabetes" which he was attempting to control by diet <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of MI, CAD, DM, HL <PHYSICAL EXAM> On Admission: VS - 96.5, 118/72 68 18 95% on RA 98.8kg GENERAL - NAD, AAOx3 HEENT - PERRLA, EOMI, MMM, OP clear, no JVD LUNGS - CTA b/l, no w/r/r HEART - S1S2, RRR, no m/r/g ABDOMEN - soft, obese, ND, NT, +BS EXTREMITIES - no c/c/e, 2+ peripheral pulses NEURO - awake, A&Ox3, CNs II-XII grossly intact, muscle strength ___ throughout, sensation grossly intact throughout <PERTINENT RESULTS> OSH EKG: NSR @ 81 bpm, NA, NI, TWI in III and aVF ___ EKG: NSR @ 83 bpm, NA, NI, Q waves inferolateral leads . Other: ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD %HbA1c-11.0* eAG-269* ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD Triglyc-115 HDL-42 CHOL/HD-4.6 LDLcalc-129 . Cardiac Catheterization ___ (prelim report): 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated single vessel disease. The LMCA had ostial 25% stenosis. The LAD had ostial 30% stenosis with diffuse luminal irregularities to 20% involving origin of a large D2; modest caliber D1. The LCx had ostial diffuse plaquing in the AV groove Cx; modest high OM1 (nearly a ramus); modest OM2 with mild origin plaque; modest atrial branch; large slightly tortuous OM3 with 20% origin lesion; AV groove Cx mid 80% bifurcation stenosis involving modest OM4; small distal atrial branch; TIMI 2 slow flow into major LPL. The RCA had diffuse luminal irregularities to 20% with TIMI 2 flow; twin RPDA; modest RPL1 and RPL2. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed elevated left ventricular filling pressures with LVEDP 18 mmHg. There was no significant pressure gradient across the aortic valve on catheter pullback. There was systemic arterial normotension with SBP 110 mmHg. 3. Left ventriculography revealed mild focal anterobasal and posterobasal hypokinesis, 1+ non-ectopic mitral regurgitation, and estimated LVEF ~65%. 4. Successful PCI of the mid LCx with 2.5x12mm BMS post-dilated to 2.75mm (see ___ comments). FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One vessel coronary artery disease with diffuse atherosclerosis and diffuse slow flow consistent with microvascular dysfunction. 2. Mild mitral regurgitation. 3. Mild diastolic left ventricular dysfunction. 4. Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction managed by successful deployment of bare metal stent in the AV groove CX (see ___ comments). 5. Cycle CKMB and platelets. 6. Plavix (clopidogrel) 75 mg daily for 1 month minimum to prevent stent thrombosis; would favor 12 months for secondary prevention if tolerated. 7. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against CAD, NSTEMI, DM. 8. Importance of smoking cessatino reviewed with patient. 9. Outpatient cardiac rehabilitation referral. 10. Follow up with cardiologist at ___ Medicine Associates). . TTE ___: The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with mild hypokinesis of the basal inferior and inferolateral and mid inferolateral segments. Overall left ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 50-55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Mild focal LV systolic dysfunction. Mild mitral regurgitation. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> None <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO at bedtime. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 2. Call ___ when taking third dose. . Disp: *30 tablets* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary - NSTEMI Secondary - Type 2 Diabetes - Hyperlipidemia - Tobacco Abuse <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___, it was a pleasure taking care of you here at ___. You initially went to the hospital because you were having chest pain. This was found to be due to a heart attack, which is also called a myocardial infarction (MI). You were taken for cardiac catheterization where you had a blockage in one of the arteries in your heart. This blockage was opened using a stent. It is VERY important that you take a baby aspirin (81mg) EVERY day. This is to prevent you from having another heart attack. In addition you will need to take a medication called plavix for the next month. This medication is important for keeping the stent from closing off. You were started on several different medications during this hospitalization. You were started on a medication called metoprolol. This medication lowers you blood pressure and also helps protect your heart. You were started on a medication called atorvastatin which lowers your cholesterol and also helps protect your heart. In addition it was found that your diabetes has progressed and you will need medication in addition to improving your diet and exercise. Controlling your blood sugar is important for decreasing your risk of kidney disease and other complications. You will need to make an appointment with a primary care provider (PCP). This person will be a general doctor who will oversee your medical care. This person will help treat your diabetes. As we discussed, it is VERY important that you stop smoking. Quitting smoking decreases your risk of having another heart attack. Here is a summary of your new medications: START metoprolol succinate (Toprol XL) 25mg once daily START Atorvastatin (Lipitor) 80mg once daily before bed START Aspirin 81mg once daily START Clopidogrel (Plavix) 75mg once daily for 1 month START Nitrogylcerin 0.4mg beneath the tongue ONLY AS NEEDED for chest pain. If pain continues after 5 minutes you may take a ___ pill. If pain continues after 10 minutes you should take a third pill and call ___.
target: Primary Reason for Hospitalization: ___ M with h/o smoking and diabetes presents with NSTEMI . ACTIVE ISSUES: # NSTEMI (s/p BMS to LCX): BMS selected due to concern about compliance given lack of medical care to date. Risk factors in this patient were obesity, smoking, and uncontrolled diabetes. The patient was previously taking no medcations and he was started on the following - plavix 75mg X 1 month minimum. 12 months if tolerated. - ASA 81mg indefinitely - metoprolol succinate 25mg for now, uptitrate as tolerated - atorvastatin 80mg qhs - Sublingual nitroglycerin 0.4mg Over 20 minutes were spent counseling the patient and his wife about smoking cessation. It was also stressed how important it will be for him to have regular follow-up with both a PCP and cardiology. An appointment was set up with Dr. ___ at ___ ___ cardiology on ___. A TTE was performed which showed Mild focal LV systolic dysfunction (EF 50-55%). The patient did not have any clinical evidence of heart failure. . # DMII (HbA1c = 11%) Patient reported that he was just trying to control his DM with diet however this clearly has not been sufficient. He did not have a PCP that actively followed with and he did not check his blood sugars. The patient requested to have a PCP close to his home therefore he was given the phone number for the doctor's line to get established with a new PCP. The patient was told he needs to be seen within one week of discharge. He was told that if he cannot get follow-up within that time he should call Dr. ___ at ___ to help coordinate follow-up in the interim. Most likely the patient will require multiple oral medications to control his blood sugar if not insulin. No medications were initiated prior to discharge given that the patient was already being started on 4 new medications which appeared to be somewhat overwhelming. He will also need teaching on how to test his blood sugar at home. The patient was counseled on the signs and symptoms of high and low blood sugar. . # HLD: LDL 129. He was started on atorvastatin 80mg. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Studies pending at the time of discharge: Final Cath Report - Patient's new primary care provider should coordinate diabetes teaching and initiate diabetes therapy.

No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen. The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. ___ Stress test ___ yo woman with HL, HTN and DM, s/p NSTEMI and PCI to LCx in ___ was referred to evaluate an atypical chest discomfort and shortness of breath. The patient completed 10.5 minutes of a Gervino protocol representing a fair exercise tolerance; ~ 5.5 METS. The exercise test was stopped due to fatigue. No chest, back, neck or arm discomforts were reported by the patient during exercise. Immediately post-exercise, the patient reported anterior chest tightness which was reportedly absent 3 minutes post-exercise. At peak exercise, 0.5-1 mm slow upsloping ST segment depression was noted inferolaterally. Although these ST segment changes appeared to resolve early post-exercise, as recovery continued 0.5-1 mm horizontal ST segment depression was noted inferiorly, lead I and leads V4-V6. In addition, 0.5-1 mm ST segment elevation was noted in aVR. All ST segment changes were absent by 10 minutes post-exercise. The rhythm was sinus with no ectopy noted. Resting systolic hypertension with an exaggerated systolic blood pressure response noted with exercise. In the presence of beta blocker therapy, the peak exercise heart rate was blunted. IMPRESSION: Fair exercise tolerance. Probable anginal symptoms with ischemic ST segment changes noted post-exercise. Resting systolic hypertension with an exaggerated systolic blood pressure response noted with exercise. ___ Cardiac Catheterization Aorta 152/72/101 Coronary Anatomy Dominance: Right Left main normal LAD: 70% mid stenosis, dilated and stented with 0% residual and normal flow LCX: mild disease proximally with 80% distally proximal to stent, dilated-->20% residual RCA: patent Interventional Details We engaged the left main coronary artery with a JCL 4.0 guide catheter and it provided adequate support. We used heparin boluses to achieve the therapeutic ACT. We then used a Runthrough wire to cross the lesion with minimal difficulty. We then predilated the lesion with a 2.5 x 20 Emerge balloon. The lesion did not expand and we then used a 2.5 x 12 mm NC Emerge balloon to dilate the lesion again. We then deployed a 2.75 x24 mm Promus Premier DES in the mid to distal LAD and then deployed another 3.0 x16 mm Promus Premier DEs in the mid LAD. We post dilated the stent in the proximal portion with a 3.0 x20 mm NC emerge balloon. The final angiogram showed 0% residual stenosis and no dissections. We then diverted our attention to the left circumflex lesion and crossed the lesion with minimal difficulty with a Runthrough wire. We predilated the lesion proximal to the previous stent with a 2.0 x20 NC Emerge balloon. The final angiogram showed 20% residual stenosis and no dissection. Patient tolerated the procedure well and left the lab in stable condition. She was also loaded with Plavix 600 mg on the table at the conclusion of the procedure. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms ___, You were admitted to ___ after you had worsening chest pain at home after developing a likely upper respiratory viral illness. Your flu test was negative, and your EKG and cardiac enzymes were negative as well. However, your stress test showed some signs concerning for cardiac ischemia, and you went for a catheterization procedure which showed disease in your coronary arteries -- you had 2 stents placed in your "LAD" and they opened up your old stent in your "Left Circumflex" with a balloon. Please make sure to take aspirin and Plavix daily going forward for at least the next year. Please also make sure to weigh yourself every morning, and to call your doctor if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. Your weight here was 205 lbs upon discharge. It was a pleasure taking care of you! Your ___ Cardiology Team

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> aspirin / ibuprofen / Iodinated Contrast Media - IV Dye / red dye <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> FROM HISTORY AND PHYSICAL "Ms. ___ is a pleasant ___ y/o woman with PMH notable for HTN, HLP, prior TIA I/s/o left ICA as well as multiple L-MCA aneurysms noted on ___, presenting with chest discomfort. Per patient, she was in her normal state of health until the night prior to admission. She was lying in bed around 730 or 8pm, when she suddenly noted left-sided chest discomfort "behind the breast" with involvement of her left shoulder blade. She noted concurrent indigestion as well as sensation of needing to burp. She was able to "burp up" some "phlegm" without any emesis and felt better. This episode lasted for about 15 minutes. She denies any radiation of the pain, worsening with exertion, or relationship with position. She denies any shortness of breath, palpitations, lightheadedness, or abdominal discomfort. She has never had this before and she does remember eating a ham and cheese sandwich about an hour prior to this event. The next morning, she woke up without any issues. She took her morning multivitamin and then about an hour later, developed indigestion with nausea and no emesis. She again had an urge to "burp up phlegm" and had an associated bilateral anterior chest discomfort, non-radiating, slightly different from the symptoms she was having the night previously. This time, the pain lasted nearly 2 hours in duration. She took a Tylenol with no relief. She laid down in her bed to try and rest it off, but this did not help. She again denies any associated symptoms and her daughter, who was home with her decided to call an ambulance to take her to ___ for further evaluation. While in the ambulance, without any intervention, her pain resolved, about 5 minutes prior to arriving in the ED. Otherwise she denies any recent illnesses, fevers, chills, orthopnea, PND, ___ swelling, diarrhea (apart from her daily loose stools), or arm/jaw pain. She has no DOE or SOB. She has a baseline cough with some production of sputum and no recent changes from this. She Of note, the patient does carry a diagnosis of cerebral aneurysms, most recently imaged (detailed below) at ___ in ___ and ___. These include several left MCA aneurysms ranging from 2-5mm in diameter without any evidence of rupture. She also saw Dr. ___ ___ neurology) in ___ after her initial MRA in ___ and during that visit, he concluded that "[I]f an aneurysm would rupture, this could be a potentially fatal situation. On the other hand, if the patient's posterior circulation TIAs became a fixed stroke, at this time the area involves seems to be a small area and would not be potentially fatal. Therefore focusing upon the problem that potentially has more serious consequences, I would recommend that the patient be free of any type of anticoagulation. I would not recommend an antiplatelet therapy and in fact statin drugs have an anticoagulation effect, and I would even recommend doing away with statin drugs and using other types of drugs and diet therapy to address the cholesterol." Of note, shortly after this visit, in ___, she did have repeat MRA, which called into question whether her previously visualized aneurysms were truly aneurysms or whether they were atherosclerotic lesions. Since, then the patient has not received any aspirin or blood thinners, although she does not recall every being told not to take them. She also has not had any neurology follow-up since that visit with Dr. ___. In the ED, initial vitals: 96.6 80 156/82 18 99% RA Exam was notable for: nothing documented ECG per my read notable for sinus rhythm with ventricular rates of 81 bpm; physiologic left axis, inferior TWI and probable LVH with non-specific lateral ST-TW changes; with anterior Q waves, cannot rule out prior anterior infarct; compared with prior on ___, inferior TWI's and lateral ST-TW changes are new Labs were notable for: -CBC showing normal white count, Hgb 9.7 (baseline ___ -Chem10 notable for Bicarb 21, BUN/Cr 38/2.8 (baseline ___ -Trop 0.18 -> 0.26 -CK-MB negative x2 -U/A notable only for 30 protein, few bacteria -Urine culture pending Imaging notable for: CXR notable for: Subtle patchy right base opacity is most likely due to overlap of vascular structures and atelectasis, but pneumonia is difficult to exclude in the appropriate clinical setting. Patient was given: -Aspirin 324mg PO x1 -IV heparin (given with bolus) On the floor, the patient reports feeling well, endorsing the above story and asking to go home. She denies any recent sick contacts. When asked about her contrast allergy, the patient states that she is not sure what that is. She knows that she should not have it, but does not know if it is because of her kidneys or due to other reasons. She does not recall any prior history of anaphylactic reactions or severe hives to any medicines or to prior contrast exposures, but does not seem confident in her answer." <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> FROM HISTORY AND PHYSICAL 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS - Hypertension - Dyslipidemia - History of TIA - Left carotid stenosis - Cerebral aneurysms (MRI/MRA in ___ and ___ with multiple 2-5mm saccular aneurysms in L MCA and R meningoghypohyseal aneurysm) - no history of rupture or intervention - Stage 4 CKD (baseline Cr ___ complicated by frequent hyperkalemia 2. CARDIAC HISTORY - H/o grade I diastolic dysfunction on TTE in ___ 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY -Anemia -Gout -Thrombocytopenia (chronic - presumably ___ ETOH Abuse) -Ongoing ETOH abuse c/b prior withdrawal seizures -Ongoing tobacco abuse -Colonic adnoema -Complex renal cyst/pancreatic mass -Osteoporosis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FROM HISTORY AND PHYSICAL "___ notable for cerebral aneurysms in her daughter complicated by subarachnoid hemorrhage, diabetes in daughters, and no known heart disease." <PHYSICAL EXAM> VITALS: T 98.2, HR 71, BP 176/81, RR 17 GENERAL: no apparent distress, lying comfortably in bed HEENT: anicteric, oropharynx clear CV: RRR, S1/S2, harsh III/VI systolic murmur at RUSB with radiation to carotids versus bruit PULM: unlabored, CTAB ABD: soft, non-tender, non-distended EXT: warm, pulses palpable and symmetric, without edema NEURO: non-focal <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: - However, loss of signal at the site of narrowing indicates greater than 70% stenosis. 4. Mild-to-moderate narrowing of the right carotid bulb and proximal internal carotid artery. You were hospitalized because you had a small heart attack. The blood vessels around your heart were examined (cardiac catheterization or "cath"), which showed a blocked artery. You were given medications to prevent new blockages. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I LEAVE THE HOSPITAL? -It is very important that you continue to take aspirin and clopidogrel (also known as Plavix) every day. These two medications help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. -Take all of your other new medications as prescribed (see medication list). -Follow up with your primary doctor next week and your new cardiologist this month (see appointments below). -We would also like you to follow-up with neurosurgery for repeat pictures of your brain. -Refrain from aerobic exercise or heavy lifting for at least one week. It is safe for you to return to work after that. Talk to your new cardiologist before beginning an exercise routine. -Please quit smoking and reduce the amount of alcohol you drink. We are always available to assist you in your efforts to quit. -___ medical care if you develop chest pain or difficulty breathing. We wish you all the best. Sincerely, Your ___ care team
target: ___ female with array of risk factors for coronary atherosclerosis and remote history of left MCA aneurysm, left ICA aneurysm complicated by TIA, and chronic kidney disease stage IV admitted for NSTEMI. Coronary angiography revealed culprit RCA lesion. #) NSTEMI, type I: while features of her chest pain were atypical, rising cardiac enzymes and new T-wave inversions in anteroseptal precordial leads on background said risk factors were suggestive of true unstable plaque rupture in probable LAD distribution. She was empirically heparinized when cleared by neurosurgery. TTE was obtained, which instead demonstrated hypokinesis of the basal inferior and inferoseptal segments, but globally preserved biventricular systolic function. She thus proceeded with coronary angiography, which revealed 100% occluded RCA with well established left to right collateralization, which was not intervened upon, as well as non-obstructive LCx (50% stenosis) and D1 (40% stenosis) disease. She received periprocedural hydration as prophylaxis against contrast induced nephropathy. She was also pre-medicated for idoniated contrast allergy per ___ protocol. Heparin was later discontinued in favor of aspirin and clopidogrel. Metoprolol was converted to carvedilol 12.5 mg BID for better alpha antagonism in the absence of home lisinopril, which was held for renal insufficiency above baseline and impending contrast load. #) Cerebral aneurysm: once deemed an absolute contraindication to anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy. Surveillance head CT obtained after therapeutic PTT was unremarkable. MRA head revealed a single 3 mm left ICA aneurysm, which was considered at minimal, and thus, acceptable risk of hemorrhage. No intervention was warranted. Neurosurgery cleared patient for heparin and dual-antiplatelet therapy in that regard. ___ on chronic kidney disease, stage IV: presumably secondary to hypertensive nephropathy. Creatinine 2.8 on arrival from baseline creatinine 2.0-2.5. She received gentle hydration in anticipation of catheterization, which was then continued for low-normal LVEDP, albeit minor contrast load. Lisinopril was held at discharge for unchanged creatinine. #) Alcohol use disorder: notably, has history of withdrawal seizures. Last drink reportedly evening prior to admission. Monitored on CIWA without benzodiazepine needs. CHRONIC/STABLE ISSUES: #) Anemia: near-macrocytosis at baseline 10-range. Presume secondary to chronic kidney disease and alcohol myelotoxicity. #) Hypertension: home lisinopril 5 mg held, as above. Carvedilol 12.5 mg BID added for alpha antagonism. =================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== NEW MEDICATIONS -Aspirin 81 mg daily -Atorvastatin 80 mg daily -Carvedilol 12.5 mg BID -Clopidogrel 75 mg daily CHANGED MEDICATIONS: none. HELD MEDICATIONS: -Lisinopril 5 mg daily DISCONTINUED MEDICATIONS: -Pravastatin [ ]Ensure follow-up with cardiology and neurosurgery (see appointments above). [ ]At discharge, creatinine = 2.8; recommend repeat chem-10 at primary care follow-up on ___. [ ]Consider titrating carvedilol and/or resuming lisinopril, if renal function has returned to baseline. [ ]Facilitate smoking and alcohol cessation. #CODE: Full, presumed #CONTACT: ___, daughter (___)

PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 03: 55AM BLOOD WBC-5.6 RBC-3.94* Hgb-11.9*# Hct-35.5*# MCV-90 MCH-30.2 MCHC-33.5 RDW-15.6* Plt ___ ___ 03: 55AM BLOOD ___ PTT-66.9* ___ ___ 03: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-122* UreaN-47* Creat-2.1* Na-140 K-4.4 Cl-113* HCO3-19* AnGap-12 ___ 03: 55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.6 Mg-2.6 . . . CATH COMMENTS: 1. Coronary angiography in this right-dominant systemt demonstrated three-vessel nonobstructive disease. The LMCA had mild-moderate plaquing. The LAD was diffusely disease to 60% beginning inthe proximal vessel and spanning the origin of a moderately diffusely diseased (up to 40%) first diagonal branch. There were luminal irregularities in the mid-distal LAD. The LCx had an ostial bidurcation 60% stenosis involving a high first obtuse marginal branch. There were luminal irregularities in the third and fourth obtuse marginal branches. The proximal RCA stent was patent, but there was diffuse disese throughout the RCA to 50% proximally with some ulcerations and calcifications. There was a 50% stenosis in the distal AV groove RCA just after RPL2. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed elevated left-sided filling pressures with an LEVDP of 24 mm Hg. There was severe systemic arterial hypertension with an SBP of 180 mm Hg. There was no gradient upon pullback of the catheter from the left ventricle to the aorta. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three-vessel non-flow-limiting coronary artery disease with no obvious culprit lesion and essentially unchanged from prior angiography. 2. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 3. Severe systemic arterial hypertension. You had one drug coated stent placed in your right coronay artery (RCA). There are other arteries of your heart with less severe plaque buildup which will be managed with medication at this time. Medication changes: START Aspirin 81mg daily START Plavix 75mg daily START Atorvastatin 80mg daily START Toprol 50mg daily STOP Atenolol STOP Simvastatin STOP Amlodipine STOP Spironalactone You will be on Aspirin 81mg indefinitely and Plavix 75mg daily for at least one year. These medications make your platelets less sticky and prevent blood clots from forming inside your stent. Do not stop either of these medications unless instructed to do so by Dr. ___. Stopping either of these medications early COULD result in a blockage inside your stent and lead to a heart attack. You should switch your Simvastatin to Atorvastatin 80mg daily. This is a stronger cholesterol medication. You will need to have your cholesterol and liver function tests repeated in 6 weeks. You should aim for your LDL (bad cholesterol) to be less than 70 (it is currently 80). If you have chest pain at home, take Nitroglycerin under your tongue as directed. If the pain does not go away, call ___. You should switch your Atenolol to Toprol (Metoprolol) 50mg daily. This is a different drug in the same family (beta blocker). It will take some of the work load off your heart, it will lower your blood pressure and heart rate. Your blood pressure has been well controlled while you were in the hospital. For now, do not take your Amlodipine or Spironalactone. If your blood pressure is elevated when you see Dr. ___ in follow up he may start you back on these medications. You should have your INR checked on ___ as previously scheduled. If you have pain in your right wrist, fevers, chills or shortness of breath, call Dr. ___.

Inferior wall myocardial infarction with ST-T wave configuration consistent with acute/recent/in evolution process. Clinical correlation is suggested. No previous tracing available for comparison. ___: Normal sinus rhythm, rate 74. Inferior wall myocardial infarction of indeterimate age TTE: The left atrium is elongated. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with near akinesis of the basal inferior wall and hypokinesis of mid inferior wall. Overall left ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 55%). Doppler parameters are most consistent with normal left ventricular diastolic function. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Left ventricular regional systolic dysfunction consistent with coronary artery disease. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: One vessel coronary artery disease. Successful primary PCI of the RCA thrombotic occlusion with a CYpher DES <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with chest pain. An ECG and blood tests showed that you were having a heart attack. You were immediately transferred to the cath lab, where they opened a blocked artery and placed a stent to keep the artery open. You have been started on new medications to keep the stent open, to control your blood pressure, and to help your heart as it heals. An ultrasound of your heart showed that it was pumping well. You good cholesterol was low; this can be improved with diet and exercise. Your bad cholesterol was elevated, and should improve with one of your new medications. You did well after the catheterization. . The following changes were made to your medications: #. START Aspirin 325mg by mouth daily #. target: ___ year old male with h/o hyperlipidemia p/w chest pain ___ inferior STEMI, proximal RCA occlusion. . # CORONARIES: Pt presented with CP, found to have STEMI; now s/p cath which showed complete ___ occlusion of RCA. Most likely ___ ruptured atherosclerotic plaque, perhaps with partial occlusion last night with second rupture and complete occlusion this morning. Low suspicion for embolic phenomenom, vasospasm, or hypercoaguable state. Patient was started on Plavix, aspirin, statin, ACE, BB; Plavix was started at 150 mg daily for one week, to be decreased to 75 mg daily following discharge. Peak CK 950. Platelets were normal post-cath on Integrelin, Plavix, ASA. A1c was normal at 5.7. Lipid panel showed elevated total cholesterol, low HDL, and elevated LDL. The patient tolerated initiation of ACEi, beta blockade. Statin, ASA, plavix, metop, lisinopril, and NTG PRN were provided at discharge. . # PUMP: No systolic/diasolic failure on exam. TTE showed preserved LVEF and inferobasal hypokinesis/akinesis. ACEi and beta blockade were started and uptitrated as BP could tolerate, and continued upon discharge. . # RHYTHM: In sinus currently. At risk for sinus nodal dz given RCA occlusion. There was no evidence of arrhythmia post-MI. Beta blockade was continued on discharge. . # Hyperlipidemia- low HDL and elevated LDL on lipid panel. high dose atorvstatin was continued at discharge. . CODE: full . You had a cardiac catheterization which showed one occluded branch vessel. Medical management of your coronary artery disease is recommended, so optimal treatment of your diabetes, high blood pressure and high cholesterol/triglycerides is needed. . You were noted to have a hemoglobin A1C of 8.5. You should work with your primary care doctor to find a better way to control your diabetes. . Your triglycerides were elevated at 335, so we recommend Fish Oil to help. You can stop taking niacin. . Your LDL was noted to be 84. Goal LDL<70. You were started on Pravastatin 20 mg to help your cholesterol. Since you had problems with muscle aches while on cholesterol medications, we recommend taking Coenzyme Q10 to help minimize the muscle aches. . For your heart (anginal) pain, you were given nitroglycerin which you can take as needed. You were also given a prescription for Imdur, a long-acting form of nitroglycerin, which should help with your chest pain. . In addition, you were prescribed metoprolol, which will help with your heart and also decrease your blood pressure. . Since you had a heart attack, you were also given Plavix to prevent clot formation in your heart vessel. You should continue this medication until you see a cardiologist. . Since you have a cough with lisinopril, we will start you on another blood pressure medication called losartan. . Your medications have changed in the following way: -stop niacin -Start pravastatin (for your cholesterol) -start coenzyme Q10 (to decrease the risk of muscle aches while on pravastatin) -Start fish oil (to help lower your triglycerides, a type of fat) -Start nitroglycerin as needed (for chest pain) -Start imdur (for chest pain) -Start metoprolol (for your heart and blood pressure) -Start clopidogrel (for your heart vessels) -Stop lisinopril -Start losartan -change aspirin from 81 mg to 325 mg
target: Summary: ___ yo M with IDDM, HTN, HL presents with chest tightness found to have NSTEMI. . ASSESSMENT AND PLAN . # CORONARIES: The patient presented with intermittent non-exertional chest pain that has worsened over the last few days. Initially he thought his symptoms were due to reflux, however his most recent episode not relieved by antacids. In the ED pain improved with nitro and morphine. He had no ECG changes, however had increasing troponins with normal CKs. He was started on a heparin gtt. He was started on high dose aspirin, statin, beta blocker, plavix (loaded in the ER), and heparin gtt. The patient was taken for cardiac catheriterization and a small diagonal branch (2.0mm) with a 60% stenosis at the origin. There was no intervention and medical management was initiated. He was started on Imdur and continued on high dose aspirin, plavix (will continue until his cardiology appointment), beta blocker, and statin. In addition, he was given sublingual nitroglycerin for acute anginal pain. In order to ___ medical manage his coronary disease, he will need optimal control of his diabetes, dyslipidemia, and hypertension. . # Diabetes Mellitus II: The patient was found to have a hemoglobin A1C of 8.5. He currently takes Metformin and insulin. The patient was advised to hold his Metformin for one day after discharge (since he received contrast for cath). He was also advised to work with his primary care doctor to better control his blood sugar. . # Dyslipidemia: The patient was noted to have a calculated LDL of 84 (without treatment) and a triglycerides of 335 on admission. He was started on pravastatin 20 mg daily and fish oil (for triglyceridemia). Since he had associated myalgias with statin use in the past, he was advised to take Coenzyme Q10 to prevent the myalgias. . # Hypertension: The patient initially was hypertensive to 190/80 when he came to the floor, however, with his medications, he lowered to normal values. The patient complained of a persistent dry cough over months, so his lisinopril 30 mg was switched to Valsartan 50 mg. He was also started on metoprolol 12.5 mg BID on this admission. There were no issues with optimal blood pressure control. Outpatient followup: 1. Medication adherence 2. Optimal dyslipidemia, DM II, and HTN control 3. Check LFTs, Chem 7 on new medications
