You had a catheterization and a stent placed in one of the arteries of your heart. You were started on medications, Plavix and Aspirin, that will keep your stent open. You should take these medications EVERY DAY, without missing any doses. Do not stop taking Plavix and aspirin unless Dr. ___ you to. START: Aspirin 325 mg daily: to prevent your stent from clotting off START: Plavix 75 mg daily: to prevent your stent from clotting off START: Atorvastatin: to lower your bad cholesterol and increase your good cholesterol START: Metoprolol: to lower your heart rate and blood pressure and help your heart to heal. START: Lisinopril: to lower your blood pressure START: Nicotine patch: to help with symptoms of nicotine withdrawal. . It is extremely important that you stop smoking. Please use a nicotine patch to help with the cravings for nicotine. Look at "smoking-cessation.org" for a quit plan and helpful facts. . No lifting more than 10 pounds for 1 week. No pools or baths, you may take a shower. Please watch your right groin area for signs of increasing bruising, tenderness or lumps under the skin. . Please check your blood pressure at home and record the readings. Bring this to any doctor appt. Please come back to the hospital or call your primary care provider if you have fainting or near-fainting, dizziness, light-headedness, chest pain, jaw pain, arm pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, nausea, abdominal pain, gain of 3lbs in 1 day, leg swelling or any other concerning symptoms.
target: # Inferior Wall Myocardial Infarction: The patient was taken to the cath lab, a bare metal stent was placed in the RCA as he was found to have total occlusion of the RCA. He was then transfered to the CCU for close monitoring. He remained stable following PCI, with no significant drop in his blood pressure or arrhythmias. His hemodynamics in the cath lab suggested RV as well as LV dysfunction (elevated end RV pressure and elevated PCWP), but he was never in clear CHF. During his hospitalization a beta ___, plavix, statin were all initiated. He was also started on ACE therapy for remodeling as wall motion abnormalities on TTE although EF wnl and as blood pressure not at goal. The patient did not have any further chest pain during his hospitalization. ___ and clopidogrel will be continued for at least one month to be discussed with his outpatient cardiologist. The importance of continuing these medications was reinforced with him and his wife. The patient was encouraged about smoking cessation and was discharged with a nicotine patch. . # Hyperlipidemia: The patient did not have a history of hyperlipidemia prior to admission. He has xanthalesmas on exam. During his hospitalization, his HDL was found to be low, LDL was 99, however these may be depressed in the setting of an acute MI. Goal LDL < 70. Started on full dose Atorvastatin to continue as an outpatient. f/u repeat lipid panel in 6 weeks. . # Hypertension: The patient was not on any standing medications at home. He was started on metoprolol and lisinopril during the hospitalization, both will be continued as an outpatient. . # Tobacco Abuse: Nicotine patch applied during hospitalization. Discussed importance of cessation with the patient and wife on multiple ___. No evidence of nicotine withdrawal during hospitalization. . #FEN: Heart healthy diet # ACCESS: PIVs # PROPHYLAXIS: SC heparin, bowel regimen # CODE: full code

target: NON-ST ELEVATION MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION: The patient has significant cardiac risk factors for coronary artery disease including hyperlipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, and active smoking. She presented with ___ days of non-exertion chest pain, and was found to have a troponin elevation from 0.08 to 0.10 on admission. In the setting of cardiac biomarker elevation, patient mets criteria for NSTEMI. Other possibilities that were considered included myocarditis in the setting of recent viral illness, and less likely, vasospasm, Takatsubos, pericarditis, GERD. She was started on medical management for an NSTEMI with full-dose aspirin, increased dose of statin, beta-blocker, and angiotensin receptor blocker. She underwent cardiac catheterization on ___ that mild-moderate diffuse coronary atherosclerosis and chronic total occlusion of OM2 thought unlikely to be the source of her chest pain. As such, the Will continue medical management for NSTEMI. After this, she was started on clopidogrel and furosemide and continued on other oral medications as above. She was discharged on aspirin 81mg daily, atorvastatin 80mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25mg daily, clopidogrel 75mg daily, losartan 100mg daily, oral furosemide 20mg daily, and sublingual nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain. She was also counseled heavily to discontinue smoking, and discharged on a nicotine patch. HYPERTENSION: The patient was continued on a lower dose of her home losartan without complications, and restarted on her home dose at discharge. TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS: The patient recieved a dose of metformin and glipizide in the emergency room, after which her oral diabetic medications were held. The patient was on a basic insulin sliding scale without complications. ANXIETY/MOOD DISORDER: Continued on home Klonapin, escitalopram, diazepam without complications. ___: Held home primrose and vitex without complications. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES - No pending results - The patient remained full code throughout this hospitalization

She quickly notices when it comes on and will sit down for half an hour or so to watch TV and it will go away without any other complications. Patient says that she developed significantly worse chest pain starting on ___. She was out shopping for food in the market and while going down one aisle she felt slightly lightheaded. Thinking that she might be hypoglycemic, patient went to the candy aisle and got some gum drops. She then felt a little bit better and was able to get through the checkout and make her way home. Upon walking up seven stairs into her house, patient started to feel significant chest pressure. She went to her living room to sit down, noting that the pain quickly became ___ in severity. She asked her daughter to call the ambulance. When patient was putting on her shoes, the pain became "crushing" and ___ in severity. There was some radiation of the discomfort into her right arm (of note, patient says that her right ring finger had been numb the day prior). Patient was experiencing shortness of breath and diaphoresis at the time. No palpitations or persistent lightheadedness/dizziness. EMS gave patient a sublingual nitro, though she thinks that it was supplemental oxygen that made her feel much more comfortable (oxygen saturation was reportedly 70% and patient was placed on BiPAP). She was then brought to ___ for urgent evaluation/management. On arrival, patient was chest pain free and hemodynamically stable, quickly taken off of bipap. Carvedilol was increased to 12.5mg BID given mild hypertension and ranolazine was increased to 1000mg BID. Otherwise, she continued on isosorbide mononitrate 30mg qd in addition to losartan 25mg qd. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___! WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? -========= - You were admitted because you had a heart attack. You initially received some nitroglycerin and oxygen, which improved your chest pain. We contacted your cardiologist, Dr. ___ felt medical management of your heart attack with medications was most appropriate at this time. -We started you a on a medication called Plavix (clopidogrel) 75mg once daily. This is one of the medications used to help treat your heart attack. -We increased your blood pressure medication (Imdur) from 30mg once daily to 90mg once daily, as well as amlodipine 2.5mg once daily to 5mg once daily to lower your blood pressure. This is so your heart does not have to work as hard to pump blood through the body. - You were also admitted to the hospital because you had too much fluid in your body. This was felt to be due to a condition called heart failure, where your heart does not pump hard enough and fluid backs up in your body. You were given a diuretic medication to help get the fluid out. You improved considerably and were ready to leave the hospital. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? --== -Continue to take all of your medications as directed, including the new increased dose of the Imdur 90mg once daily, and the new medication, Plavix 75mg once daily. -Please follow up with your outpatient primary care doctor and cardiologist. -Your weight at discharge is 169.71 lbs (76.98 kg). Please weigh yourself every day in the morning. Call your doctor if your weight goes up by more than 3 lbs. Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish you all the best! Your ___ Healthcare Team

Pt reports that he has a known history of CAD with cardiac cath showing occluded RCA and 50% stenosis in the LAD and LCx back in ___ who comes in with worsening dyspnea on exertion that he was concerned about. Denies any orthopnea or pnd or peripheral edema. No cough, wheezing, fevers or sick contacts. Denies any associated nause or vomitng but does not that he has been somewhat dizzy on standing recently. The aortic knob is calcified. Mediastinal and hilar contours are unremarkable. Lungs are clear. Pulmonary vascularity is normal. No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is present. No acute osseous abnormalities are seen. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. Cardiac Cath Study Date of ___ ___ COMMENTS: Initial angiography demonstrated tandem mid LAD 70% stenoses. We planned to treat these with direct stenting. Bivalirudin was given prophylactically. A ___ XBLAD-3.5 guide catheter provided good support and the lesions were crossed easily with a Prowater wire. A 3.0x30mm Resolute Integrity RX drug-eluting stent was deployed at 20 atm and overlapped proximally with a 3.0x12mm Resolute Integrity RX drug-eluting stent at 20 atm. The overlap region was post-dilated with a 3.25x9mm NC Sprinter RX balloon at 22 atm. Final angiography demonstrated no residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection, and normal flow. Following limited groin angiography the right femoral arteriotomy site was closed with a ___ AngioSeal device. The patient left the cath lab angina-free and in stable condition. Anticoagulation: Heparin 0 units IV Other medication: Bivalirudin 100mg bolus and 242 mg/min drip COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated three vessel coronary disease. The LMCA had a 30% lesion at the ostium. The LAD had two 70% lesions mid-vessel. The LCX had a 30% lesion. The RCA was totally occluded. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normotension. 3. Successful PCI of the mid LAD with overlapping 3.0x20mm and 3.0x12mm drug-eluting stents, post-dilated to 3.25mm (see PTCA comments). 4. Successful right femoral arteriotomy closure with ___ AngioSeal device. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Successful PCI of the LAD with drug-eluting stents. ___ Cardiovascular ECHO The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Left ventricular systolic function is hyperdynamic (EF 80%). The right ventricular free wall is hypertrophied. Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with normal free wall contractility. There are focal calcifications in the aortic arch. The number of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. The aortic valve leaflets are moderately thickened. The aortic valve is not well seen. There is mild aortic valve stenosis. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired relaxation. There is a very small pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. You came to the hospital because you experienced some chest pain which was found to be due to a small heart attack, caused by a blockage of one of your blood vessels. target: ___ year old male with hx. CAD s/p cath in ___ (showed occluded RCA with collaterals, 50% ___ of LAD and LCx), HTN, obesity, PMR on prednisone, DM presenting with c/o chest pain and dyspnea on exertion, positive troponin concerning for NSTEMI. #NSTEMI: patient presented with worsening in baseline angina and positive troponins. Patient was heparinized overnight, made NPO for cath. He underwent cardiac cath on ___ that showed 3 vessel disease with 2 70% mid LAD lesions, s/p placement of DES x2. Post-cath day 1 patient was plavix loaded, started on a full dose aspirin, continued on his home beta blocker and lisinopril. His rosuvastatin was changed to atorvastatin 80 mg daily. He will be discharged on 75 mg plavix daily. Post cath ECHO demonstrated EF 80%, mild AS with mild symmetric LVH and possibly impaired LV relaxation. Patient had no further episodes of chest pain while in the hospital. Patient worked with ___ and was determined able to be discharged without ___ services. He has follow-up with his PCP for further management of his CAD. # Dyspnea on exertion: likely due to cardiac ischemia, which was treated as above. Other possibilities included worsening of patient's known AS versus CHF, however AS remained stable on ECHO in house and patient remained euvolemic on exam during hospitalization. # Hypertension: stable, continue home regimen of atenolol and lisinopril. # Hyperlipidemia: home rosuvastatin was switched to atorvastatin 80 mg given NSTEMI. # Polymyalgia rheumatica: has been treated with steroid taper. His prednisone was due to be tapered to 10 mg daily on day of admission, which he was continued on at discharge. # Insomnia: stable, continued home alprazolam TRANSITIONAL ISSUES 1. Patient needs continued monitoring and management of CAD and risk factors, was initiated on standard post-PCI antiplatelet regimen. 2. Patient remained full code.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Statins-Hmg-Coa Reductase Inhibitors <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Difficulty walking <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cerebral angiogram (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Ms. ___ is a ___ yo right-handed woman with h/o HTN, HLD, IDDM, CAD/MI s/p stent ___ ___, and h/o TIA ___, presented to OSH, MRI with no DWI abnormalities) who is transferred to ___ from an OSH ED for evaluation of multiple symptoms, including difficulty walking. Neurology was consulted in the ED for LLE weakness noted on ED resident evaluation. . When I initially attempted to discuss her neurologic complaint, she interrupted my questioning frequently with tangential comments about other symptoms. She said "ooh, ___ when attempting to sit up while we were talking. She complains of pain in her Left > right hip since yesterday morning. Hypothesized that her mattress is too hard. Seems slightly out of breath, tired. . Later, she agrees that her reason for ED presentation was "I was draggin my [left] leg." Also says her arms were moving "like I'm a puppet." But arms never moved on their own (no shaking or incoordination), and were never weak, she just felt like she couldn't control them as well as usual. On reconsideration, says it was not her left leg alone, it is both her legs, but the left is worse. Says today is the first time she has ever experienced such symptoms. Says last year she couldn't pick up the front of her feet (both feet), which is different from her gait difficulties last ___. She was able to navigate her stairs and walk without falling at home, but she is certain that her gait is off balance relative to usual. She spoke with neighbor, ___, and told him "I think I'm having a stroke." The neighbor said he thought she's alright. Speech comprehension/production was subjectively normal at that time. She decided she needed evaluation for stroke and came to the ED. Yesterday, she thinks she felt fine initially, but says "I'm gettin my days mixed up." She remembers taking her ___ year-old neighbor girl to play in a pool with her ___ year-old ___ who has "the same personality" (long tangent). She remembers telling them at the pool that she felt funny due to recent dizzy spells and migraine headaches. Dizzy spells for a month off and on, feeling "woozy" and "a little dizzy." She never passes out or feels like she will pass out, but just feels a "little wobbly" on her feet. She has felt like this intermittently for about a month, but never before that she can remember. Symptoms are worst when she stands from a seated position. Never triggered by moving head. Endorses a spinning sensation sometimes. Back of neck hurts sometimes, but not now. No recent trauma. No medicines for this symptom; takes aspirin for migraine. Yesterday a neighbor gave her two ibuprofen, which helped relieve her headache. Yesterday, she was supposed to see her PCP, but says she had to cancel because she didn't get her SS check in time to pay for the appointment. She had wanted to see her PCP ___. her increased headaches and dizzy sensation. Her headaches are "pounding," mostly R-sides, migrates slowly to the occiput. Sometimes lasts two days. Endorses photophobia, says sunlight causes awful headache. Napping provides the most relief. Used to take a different PRN medication that helped relieve the headaches (better than aspirin/NSAIDs), but Rx ran out (Rx from Dr. ___ at ___. Cannot remember name ___. ___ last presented to our hospital in ___ with what she calls a "stroke." Our records indicate that she presented with ?TIA (veering to the right when walking and slurred speech), with suspicion for small-vessel disease. Her MRI was negative for recent infarction (there was e/o Left-cerebellar lacune on CT and MRI, as well as several "dots and spots" white matter MVID, especially a focus in the right parietal white matter). Exam findings at that time were possible ataxia/slowing of R-sided movements, with a normal examination the following morning. She also had an episode a couple years before that (TIA vs. migraine) with a few minutes of word-finding difficulty. She continues smoking, says she tries to quit. Still 1 ppd. Last year, we re-started her aspirin at 325mg daily (she had stopped taking it). Her LDL at that time was 120, so she was started on Tricor -- she stopped taking this medication since then and is not taking any lipid-lowering medications. She says "I don't know why I stopped taking it" and confirms that she is allergic to statins. She was followed in clinic by Dr. ___, with no recurrence of her symptoms or change in exam findings. Dr. ___ a ___, which did not reveal any clot or vegetations or other abnormalities of concern. Review of Systems: On neuro ROS, the pt endorses headache (forehead), loss of vision; endorses blurred vision in both eyes, denies cataracts. Gets black & white spots when she has headaches sometimes, last was ___ days ago. Denies diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. Says her LUE was achy recently. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Urinates frequently (blames this on DM and furosemide); ~ almost every hour overnight. . On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss (~25 pounds since starting Victoza ___ ago). Denies cough, shortness of breath. Denies chest pain or tightness, palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain. Constipation last week, relieved by OTC stool softener. No dysuria, but urine has been darker yellow than usual recently. Denies arthralgias or myalgias except for hips (L>R) and neck. Denies rash except some "bumps from the sun" on her forehead. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - CAD cath ___ showed 2VD and moderate LV diastolic heart failure, s/p angioplasty (not sure if she has stent) - DM x ___ yrs, on insulin, Victoza. Does not know A1c - HTN, unsure which meds she is taking now besides atenolol - HL, unmedicated, statin allergy - ?TIA ?___, as above; white matter disease and L-Cb lacune on prior brain imaging - headaches ?migraines, as above - suspect medication non-compliance (see assessment, below) - tobacco abuse <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> strong h/o heart disease <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: -Vitals: 98.0 140/59 96 97% RA -General: Awake, cooperative. Smells of cigarettes. Hoarse smoker's voice (not dysarthric). Intermittently complains of pain in hip or head, but between complaints seems relaxed, comfortable. Obese. -HEENT: Normocephalic and atraumatic. No scleral icterus. Mucous membranes are moist. No lesions noted in oropharynx. Poor dentition, with small, dark aterior mandibular teeth. few papules at hairline on forehead (pointed out by pt). Neck: Supple. No lymphadenopathy. Pulmonary: Lungs CTA. Non-labored breathing. Cardiac: RRR, no loud M/R/G appreciated in loud ED environs. Abdomen: Obese, Soft, non-tender, and non-distended. Extremities: Warm and well-perfused, no clubbing, or edema. Feet are mildly purpuric (venous-stasis appearance). Intact distal pulses bilaterally. Skin: no gross rashes or lesions noted. ***************** Neurologic examination: Mental Status: Oriented to ___, ___ hospital ED. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive, and able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric (hoarse smoker's voice). Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension, normal prosody, and normal affect. There were no paraphasic errors. Able to read and write without difficulty. Naming is intact to both high and low frequency objects. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Memory - (all NIHSS objects; initially called glove a hand). Registers 3 objects and recalls ___ at 5 minutes. Good knowledge of recent and current events. Calculation was intact (answers seven quarters in $1.75). There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect or ideomotor apraxia; the patient was able to reproduce and recognize brushing teeth with both hands (uses finger as toothbrush). There was no evidence of left-right confusion as the patient was able to accurately follow the instruction to tough left ear with right hand. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: PERRL, 3 to 2mm and brisk. Slightly cloudy pupils (suspect cataracts). Visual fields are full. III, IV, VI: EOMs full and conjugate; no nystagmus. No saccadic intrusion during smooth pursuits. Normal saccades. Denies diplopia in all directions. V: Facial sensation intact and subjectively symmetric to light touch V1-V2-V3. VII: Very slight Left lid droop more than right; unchanged after ___ sustained up-gaze (uncertain significance). No flattening of either nasolabial fold. Normal, symmetric facial elevation with smile. Brow elevation is symmetric; possibly slight lag on the Left (ipsilateral to slight lid droop). Eye closure is strong and symmetric. VIII: Hearing intact and subjectively equal to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically with phonation. Mallampati III. XI: ___ equal strength in trapezii bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrusion is midline. -Motor: No drift. No asterixis. No tremor or fasciculations were observed. Normal muscle bulk and tone (except slightly decreased EDB bulk). No flaccidity, hypertonicity, or spasticity. Delt Bic Tri WE FF FE IO | IP Q Ham TA ___ L ___ ___ 5 4+* 5 5 5 5 5 R ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 * give-way of Left IP; patient gives good initial force, then c/o discomfort in hip. Can hold against gravity without drift >>10 sec. -Sensory: JPS moderate deficit in both great toes (normal at the ankles). No pinprick deficit and denies pin gradient over ankle/shin. Vibratory deficit, may be assymetric (Left great toe 4sec / Right 7sec ; Left ankle 13sec / Right 15sec). Possibly slight deficit of cortical sensation in the Left hand (cannot discriminate ___ from dime), but able to discriminate coins from glove from dollar ___. -Reflexes (left; right): Biceps (++;++) Triceps (++;++) Brachioradialis (++;++) Quadriceps / patellar (++;++) ___ / achilles (+;+) Plantar response was mute-to-flexor bilaterally. -Coordination: Finger-nose-finger testing and heel-knee-shin testing with no dysmetria or intention tremor. No dysdiadochokinesia noted on rapid-alternating movements. LEFT hand fine finger movements are impaired. -Gait: Stands without difficulty, but initially takes several stutter-steps to the Left and braces against the wall. Complains of hip pain, but not antalgic. Wobbly standing with eyes open, no change with eyes closed (Romberg absent). Takes Short steps and seems a bit unsteady, but does not stagger or fall. Points out an inability to lift the "ball of the foot" on the Left, which I cannot appreciate (the TA is again full-strength, and she dorsiflexes the foot when explaining to me that she cannot). Narrow-based. Turns normally. Does not walk on toes or tandem. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 11: 20AM URINE HOURS-RANDOM ___ 11: 20AM URINE bnzodzpn-NEG barbitrt-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-NEG amphetmn-NEG mthdone-NEG ___ 11: 20AM URINE COLOR-Straw APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 11: 20AM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-NEG GLUCOSE-NEG KETONE-NEG BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-NEG PH-5.0 LEUK-NEG ___ 11: 06AM CREAT-0.5 ___ 11: 06AM estGFR-Using this ___ 11: 06AM COMMENTS-GREEN TOP ___ 11: 06AM GLUCOSE-159* NA+-141 K+-4.3 CL--97 TCO2-30 ___ 11: 00AM UREA N-14 ___ 11: 00AM WBC-12.0* RBC-4.80 HGB-15.1 HCT-44.2 MCV-92 MCH-31.5 MCHC-34.2 RDW-12.7 ___ 11: 00AM ___ PTT-28.3 ___ ___ 11: 00AM PLT COUNT-283 NONCONTRAST HEAD CT (___): 1. Focal hypodensity in the right parietal lobe has increased in size since the prior study and may be due to chronic small vessel ischemic disease; however, evolving infarct is also possible. Additional smaller hypodense areas in the right parietal lobe have various levels of chronicity and are new since the prior study. Recommend MRI for further evaluation. An embolic process could be considered. 2. Old lacunar infarct in the left cerebellar hemisphere, stable. . MRI HEAD (___): Multiple small acute infarcts are seen in the right occipital lobe. A small subcortical infarct in the right centrum semiovale is also seen. No evidence of blood products. No evidence of mass effect or hydrocephalus. . ___ (___): The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect or patent foramen ovale is seen by 2D, color Doppler or saline contrast with maneuvers. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. An eccentric, posteriorly directed jet of mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: No intraatrial setpal defect or source of thromboembolism identified. . HIP X-RAY (___): Single AP view of the pelvis and two coned-down views of the left hip demonstrate no fracture or dislocation. Mild bilateral hip osteoarthritis is present with minimal joint space narrowing and acetabular roof spurring. The femoral heads remain well seated in the acetabular cups. No pubic symphyseal or SI joint diastasis. The bowel gas pattern is nonobstructive. IMPRESSION: No fracture or dislocation. If occult fracture is of persistent clinical concern, consider MRI. . CTA HEAD (___): 1. Possible laryngeal mass versus voluntary vocal cord adduction and secretions. Correlate with clinical evaluation. 2. Severe stenosis of the left vertebral origin and focal narrowing of the right vertebral artery at C5-6 level due to uncovertebral osteophyte. 3. Evolving right parietal infarcts as described. 4. Non specific mediastinal lymphadenopathy. Clinical correlation is advised. . VERTEBRAL/CAROTID ANGIOGRAM (___): 1. Fetal origin of the right posterior cerebral artery. 2. 45% focal stenosis at the origin of the left vertebral artery. 3. 55% short-segmental stenosis at the cavernous segment of the right internal carotid artery. 4. 50% focal stenosis at the ophthalmic segment of the left internal carotid artery. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> furosemide 20 daily atenolol 25 daily lisinopril 40 daily amlodipine 5 daily imdur XR 120 qAM +, 60 qPM metformin 1000mg daily lantus 70 units daily victoza 18mg/3mL ___ 1.2mg daily omeprazole 20mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY RX *clopidogrel 75 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Glargine 40 Units Breakfast 8. Isosorbide Mononitrate (Extended Release) 30 mg PO DAILY RX *isosorbide mononitrate [Imdur] 30 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 10. MetFORMIN XR (Glucophage XR) 1000 mg PO DAILY Do Not Crush 11. liraglutide *NF* 0.6 mg/0.1 mL (18 mg/3 mL) Subcutaneous daily Total dose is 1.2mg subcutaneously per day. 12. Outpatient Physical Therapy Patient needs outpatient physical therapy twice weekly. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> ACUTE ISSUES: 1. Right posterior cerebral hemisphere infarction and ischemia due to stenosis of the right internal carotid artery within the carotid siphon 2. Left intracranial carotid artery siphon stenosis CHRONIC ISSUES 1. Hypertension 2. Hyperlipidemia 3. Insulin-dependent type II diabetes 4. Coronary artery disease 5. History of TIA <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Confused - sometimes. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to the hospital with left leg weakness. You were found to have a stroke on the right side of your brain. You underwent several tests including an MRI, an angiogram, an echocardiogram and a CT scan to obtain the diagnosis. We believe your stroke was caused by narrowing of the carotid artery (a blood vessel supplying the brain), and also possibly by small blood clots (emboli) collecting in the brain. . You have several risk factors that put you at risk for stroke: smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and diabetes. We adjusted your medications in the hospital to treat the high blood pressure and high cholesterol. We also started you on a drug called Plavix (Clopidogrel) to prevent future strokes. It is VERY IMPORTANT that you take your meds EVERY DAY at home to prevent future strokes. You also made the excellent decision to quit smoking while in the hospital! We wish you the very best with that. . Please attend the follow up appointments with your PCP ___ ___ and with Neurology (___) listed below. . We made the following changes to your medications: 1. STARTED clopidogrel (Plavix) 75mg by mouth daily 2. STARTED pravastatin 40mg by mouth daily 3. STARTED nicotine patch 14mg: apply one patch daily 3. DECREASED aspirin to 81mg by mouth daily 4. DECREASED lisinopril from 40mg daily to 10mg daily 5. STOPPED amlodipime 5mg daily 6. DECREASED isosorbide mononitrate (Imdur) to 30mg by mouth daily
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ right-handed woman with a history of hypertension, hyprelipidemia, insulin-dependent diabetes, coronary artery disease/MI s/p stent (___), and TIA (___) who was transferred to the ___ ED due to difficulty walking and dizziness. . # STROKE: In the ED, a Neurology consult was called, which did not reveal any gait abnormality or lower extremity weakness, but did show some left hand clumsiness. CT head showed several hypodensities in the right parietal lobe and a stable old lacunar infarct in the left cerebellar hemisphere. The patient was admitted to the Neurology service for further evaluation. An MRI of the head showed multiple small acute infarcts in the right occipital lobe and a small subcortical infarct in the right centrum semiovale. An echocardiogram was performed but did not identify an intraatrial septal defect or source of thromboembolism. A CTA of the head and neck was performed to assess the cerebral vasculature and revealed a fetal PCA. Angiography was performed and revealed tight stenosis of her right carotid siphon. Thus it was hypothesized that the etiology of her stroke was watershed infarct of right fetal PCA, possibly also with embolic component as well. Her right carotid stenosis was evaluated and discussed by the ___ Radiology and Neurology teams, and the decision was made to medically manage the stenoses with anti-platelet therapy (clopidogrel). Her home ASA was decreased from 325mg daily to 81mg daily to reduce risk of bleeding. Her blood pressure medications were down-titrated, initially to allow autoregulation after her stroke and then, after discovery of the watershed infarct, to allow her to run slightly high as to better perfuse this territory. She was re-started on oral pravastatin 40 mg daily for management of her cholesterol (LDL 123), as she had not been taking her home dose of a statin. . # AGITATION: Upon transfer to the Neurology service, Ms. ___ was alert and oriented to person, place, and time. However, she became agitated, paranoid, disoriented to place, and hostile toward the staff on the night of hospital day 2, requiring urgent psychiatric consultation, sedation with haloperidol, and use of soft restraints. Over the following 2 days, she was no longer paranoid and her agitation decreased, but she maintained a persistent delusion that she was in her own home. On hospital day 4, she re-gained orientation to place and was amnestic to her prior agitation and delusional behavior. She was ruled out for all toxic-metabolic sources of delirium during hospitalization, and had no h/o EtOH abuse making withdrawal unlikely. It was felt that her agitated delirium was likely secondary to the occipito-parietal location of her stroke, as well as a possible superimposed component of nicotine withdrawal given her >1 PPD history. . # HIP PAIN: While on the Neurology service, Ms. ___ also complained of left hip pain. A hip X-ray revealed only mild osteoarthritis but no fracture or dislocation. The pain resolved on hospital day 2. . # SMOKING CESSATION: Ms. ___ was counselled extensively regarding the need for her to quit smoking. She maintained on a nicotine patch throughout her hospital stay. On discharge, she seemed committed to quitting smoking with the support of her family. . # QUESTION OF LARYNGEAL MASS AND MEDIASTINAL LYMPHADENOPATHY ON CT: CTA head incidentally found mediastinal lymphadenopathy and a question of vocal chord adduction + secretions vs. laryngeal mass. Ms. ___ denied any throat discomfort or change in her voice. She was counselled to follow-up with her PCP regarding further evaluation of these findings.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ with no significant PMHx who presented with chest pain, found to have inferior STEMI, now s/p PCI c/b RCA dissection with ___ 2 to RCA. She was at work at 6: 30am complaining of severe indigestion, SOB, and diaphoresis. Her boss called ___. Upon arrival EMS found her somnolent but with significant pain. She received Fentanyl, 325 ASA, and EKG showed inferior ST elevations. She was transferred to ___ ED and then directly to the cath lab. She received heparin bolus of 5000U, ticagrelor 180mg, and a tirofaban drip. Access was right radial. She was found to have a 100% proximal RCA occlusion. A DES was placed with subsequent distal dissection for which a second DES was placed with good results and resultant flow. During the case she became hypotensive and bradycardic, felt to be vagal, for which she received several doses of atropine without response so was started on dopamine. However she became tachcyardic and was symptomatic so was changed to levophed. Her SBP increased to the 180s on levophed, but off was in the ___, so she is only on a low dose levophed maintaining SBP in the 140s. On arrival to the ICU she feels well and does not have CP. She reports having burning chest pain at rest for the past few months - not associated with eating or exercise, sometimes improved with tums and cold water. Of note, her father had a CABG in his ___ and her uncle and grandfather died in their ___ from sudden death of unknown etiology. She has never had a MI or stroke, does not have a cardiologist, and has no known history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or diabetes, and has a 10 pack year smoking hx (quit ___ years ago). Her only medical problem is chronic back pain ___ to MVA for which she takes diclofenac. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: (+) per HPI Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. Denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - No history of CAD, CKD, HTN, HLD, or tobacco abuse - Chronic back pain secondary to motor vehicle accident - ?GERD - No past surgeries <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Uncle and grandfather died suddenly of unknown causes in their ___. Father had CABG. <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: afebrile HR 97 BP 107/66 98% in RA GEN: in NAD HEENT: NC/AT, PERRL, EOMI NECK: no JVD CV: RRR S1 S2, systolic ejection murmur loudest over right ___ intercostal space LUNGS: CTABL ABD: soft NT ND +BS EXT: warm and well perfused, no edema NEURO: CN II-XI in tact, moving all 4 extremities spontaneously DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM: GEN: in NAD HEENT: EOMI NECK: no JVD CV: RRR S1 S2, systolic ejection murmur loudest over right ___ intercostal space LUNGS: CTABL ABD: soft NT ND +BS EXT: warm and well perfused, no edema NEURO: CN II-XI in tact, moving all 4 extremities spontaneously <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS: ___ 08: 30AM BLOOD Neuts-65 Bands-0 ___ Monos-4* Eos-5 Baso-0 ___ Myelos-0 AbsNeut-10.27* AbsLymp-4.11* AbsMono-0.63 AbsEos-0.79* AbsBaso-0.00* ___ 08: 30AM BLOOD Plt Smr-NORMAL Plt ___ ___ 08: 30AM BLOOD Glucose-186* UreaN-22* Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-4.2 Cl-105 HCO3-24 AnGap-16 ___ 04: 00PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-471* ___ 08: 30AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.02* ___ 12: 17AM BLOOD Albumin-3.6 Calcium-8.9 Phos-3.7 Mg-1.8 PERTINENT INTERVAL LABS: ___ 04: 00PM BLOOD CK-MB-70* MB Indx-14.9* cTropnT-1.35* ___ 12: 17AM BLOOD CK-MB-55* MB Indx-11.9* cTropnT-0.95* ___ 12: 17AM BLOOD %HbA1c-6.6* eAG-143* ___ 12: 17AM BLOOD LDLmeas-76 ___ 12: 17AM BLOOD TSH-0.83 DISCHARGE LABS: ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD WBC-10.0 RBC-4.24 Hgb-13.2 Hct-40.2 MCV-95 MCH-31.1 MCHC-32.8 RDW-12.6 RDWSD-43.5 Plt ___ ___ 07: 10AM BLOOD Glucose-112* UreaN-16 Creat-1.0 Na-137 K-4.4 Cl-101 HCO3-24 AnGap-16 IMAGING/STUDIES: ___ TTE The left atrial volume index is mildly increased. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic function is mildly depressed (LVEF = 45%) secondary to hypokinesis of the inferior free wall. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. CXR ___ The lungs are clear without infiltrate. There is a small right-sided effusion. The heart is upper limits normal in size. The bony thorax appears normal CARDIAC CATH ___ - LCMA without significant disease - LAD is with 40% origin, 30% proximal, ___ diagonal without significant disease - LCx without significant disease, ___ marginal is small caliber, high-takeoff vessel, ___ marginal is a large branching vessel without significant disease - RCA 100% stenosis in the proximal RCA with thrombus. The lesion has a TIMI flow of 0 and has no noted calcification. An intervention was performed on the proximal RCA with a final stenosis of 0%. There were no lesion complications. Impression: acute ST elevation myocardial infarction due to proximal RCA occlusion. Successful PCI of the RCA with drug eluting stents. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY RX *aspirin 81 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care at ___! You were admitted to the hospital with a heart attack. We treated you with a cardiac catheterization which showed blockage in the arteries supplying your heart. We treated you with two stents with improvement in blood flow. After your catheterization, you were found to have some low blood pressure. This was likely related to your heart attack. We treated you with some medicine to improve your blood pressure and you improved. It is very important that you take all of your medications after discharge, particularly your aspirin and clopidogrel. You should follow up with your primary care physician and ___ cardiologist after discharge. We wish you the very best! - Your ___ Medicine Team
target: ___ with no significant past medical history presenting with inferior STEMI s/p PCI complicated by RCA dissection, now s/p ___ 2 to RCA. # ACUTE CORONARY SYNDROME: The patient presented with chest pain found to have inferior STEMI with 100% proximal RCA occlusion. She was treated with PCI and DES x1 to proximal RCA. PCI was complicated by RCA dissection so patient was treated with additional DES to mid-RCA. Pt had some hypotension post-procedure thought to be secondary to vagal response due to inferior STEMI, treated with brief course of levophed which was successfully weaned. The patient was started on ASA, ticagrelor, atorvastatin, metoprolol and lisinopril. TTE showed EF 45% with hypokinesis of inferior free wall. The patient should have follow-up electrolytes and BP check as outpatient for titration of BP medications. # TYPE 2 DIABETES: Patient noted to have A1c 6.6% incidentally as part of post-STEMI work-up, which meets criteria for diagnosis of diabetes. The patient should f/u with PCP for further management and consideration of medical therapy or lifestyle modification if needed. # BACK PAIN: Chronic, secondary to MVA, described as sharp pain radiating down leg. The patient's diclofenac was held on discharge due to concern for cardiac risk with NSAIDs. The patient should f/u with PCP after discharge for further management of pain. Transitional Issues - Lisinopril started on discharge. Will need to follow up electrolytes and bp as an outpatient and titrate accordingly - f/u with cardiology after discharge - f/u with PCP after discharge - f/u blood sugar management, consider monitoring blood sugar and possible starting oral agent - pt previously on diclofenac for back pain, held upon discharge due new cardiac diagnosis. Consider alternative regimen for pain control after discharge.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Codeine / Zocor <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Shortness of breath and cough <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization with no intervention <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ with a history of CAD, with 2VD not candidate for CABG s/p PCI with stent to ostial LAD ___ with residual known proximal 80% Lcx in addition to a history of systolic CHF, COPD and OSA who was transferred from the OSH after admission for NSTEMI complicated by VT/VF which resolved with shock on the day of transfer. . Mrs. ___ presented to OSH yesterday (___) due to worsening SOB, cough productive of whote phlegm and parasternal chest pain which was related to cough and deep breathing but not to exertion or rest without coughing. The cough had troubled her for the preceeding two weeks. This was also associated with some fatigue and chills but not with fever or night sweats. She denied nasal congestion, sinus pain, ear pain, throat pain, heartburn, diarrhea or urinary symptoms. . She reported orthopnea X 2 pillows, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, nocturia X ___. These have been stable in recent days prior to admission. She denied any lower extremity swelling. . On review of systems, she complained of chronic arthritic pains. Otherwise, she denied any nausea or vomiting, diaphoresis, fevers, prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, hemoptysis, bloody stools and fevers. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems was notable for absence of ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. . At the OSH, her admission vitals were as follows: BP 116/60 HR 79 RR 29 SaO2 89% on 2L. She exhibited signs of florid heart failure (CXR findings and a BNP 1300) and had positive cardiac enzymes (Trop 4.96). Impression was a NSTEMI. She got 2 units of blood as her Hct was 26. She was also diuresed overnight with Lasix 80mg bid. As there was suspicion of a GI bleed (Blood on per-rectal examination, guaiac positive), all anticoagulants and antiplatelets were stopped and she was admitted to the ICU. target: Ms ___ ___ with a history of CAD, with 2VD not candidate for CABG, s/p PCI with stent to ostial LAD (___) with residual known proximal 80% Lcx in addition to a history of systolic CHF, COPD and OSA who was transferred from an OSH after admission for NSTEMI + CHF exacerbation complicated by VT/VF which resolved with shock on the day of transfer. . # NSTEMI. Patient has a history of CAD with 2VD per cath in ___ patient is not a candidate for CABG due to high surgical risk in the setting of severe COPD. Patient underwent an elective PCI at that time with stent to ostial LAD ___ with residual known proximal 80% Lcx. Patient presented to OSH ___ with lateral and inferior EKG changes and raised troponins suggestive of a new NSTEMI compatible with LCx distribution. She was transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. She was continued on an IV Heparin gtt and started ASA 325 mg PO, clopidogrel 75 mg PO daily, atorvastatin 80mg daily. Patient underwent cardiac cath on ___ which demonstrated widely patent LAD stent, mild non-significant CAD and no culprit for NSTEMI. TTE demonstrated normal left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is mildly dilated. Overall left ventricular systolic function is low normal (LVEF 50%) secondary to mild hypokinesis of the inferior, posterior, and lateral walls (the anterior septum and anterior free wall are hyperdynamic). Patient remained chest pain free throughout remainder of her stay. . # Acute decompensated sytolic CHF (___ Class III): On presentation to OSH CXR showed florid pulmonary congestion. Patient was diuresed in OSH with IV lasix. BNP = 1300. Likely decompensated due to ischemia. On arrival patient with above baseline O2 requirement (nasal canula at 5L; 2L at home). Patient intermittently diuresised with Furosemide 20 mg IV. On HD3 patient creatinine elevated and decision made to hold to diuresis. Patient was started on ACEi and continued on beta blocker. . # RHYTHM. She developed an episode of VTach/VFib possibly as a complication of her recent NSTEMI. The downtime was <1 minute. This required CPR and defibrillation x1 which subsequently converted her to normal sinus rhythm. She was monitored on telemetry without further event. . # COPD: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease on home oxygen therapy (2L/min) and chronic respiratory failure. Last PFT's Moderate restrictive ventilatory defect with a marked gas exchange defect. FEV1/FVC actual = predicted = 0.65. Per pulmonary note: has severe COPD with superimposed restriction, severe emphysema by CT scan, obesity, probably OSA. Now presenting with worsening cough of 14 days productive of sputum. No fever. Has leukocytosis to 12.5. Dif is pending. No clear infiltrates on CXR except possible small infiltrate at left heart border. Given her prolonged cough with increased sputum in the setting of risk factors including chronic prednison, severe underlyting lung disease, diabetes, CHF and her age would tend to cover her with Abx for CAP organisms. She was started on PO Levofloxacin for likely 5day treatment course. She was continued on home Advair (500/50), ipratropium nebs as well as standing, chronic prednisone 5mg . # Anemia: Has baseline macrocytic anemia, with Hct ~ ___. In OSH noted to have PR bleeding per-rectal examination and was guiaic positive. Hct was 26 and she received PRBC X2, now Hct 31. B12, Folate were normal in ___. Patient continued on Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H in the setting of Plavix + Asprin. HCT stable in house. . # Chronic Kidney Disease (Stage III). Creatinine in ___ was 2.1. Creatinine did uptrend in setting of diuresis as well as contrast load during catheterization. Patient continued to make urine thoughout hospitalization. Creatinine at time of discharge was 2.2. . # Question of cirrhosis. Patient has history of fatty liver with recent CT demonstrating nodular liver. Has chronic macrocytosis, low albumin, borderline elevated INR and mild chronic thrombocytopenia. All suggesting chronic liver disease. Of note current elevated AST is likely of cardiac origin. - Out-patient hepatlogy f/u. . # HTN: Converted to Metoprolol succinate from tartrate and started on Lisinopril for her CHF instead of felodipine. Her blood pressure was well controlled during her hospital stay. Lisinopril should be uptitrated as creatinine allows. . # HLD. Patient was started on Atorvastatin 80mg daily for treatment of CAD. Her lipid panel was normal. . OUTPATIENT ISSUES: - Continue Atorvastatin 80mg daily . # DM. Her HbA1c was 5.2%. Her glypizide was held and she as put on an insulin sliding scale and a low carbohydrate diet. . OUTPATIENT ISSUES: - Restart glypizide . # Gout: She has some minor joint pain that was treated with Tramadol prn, No evidence of acute flare. - Continue Febuxostat 40 mg PO DAILY . # Rheumatoid Arthritis. Hydroxychloroquine was held in the context of recent arrythmias as well as ABx treatment with levofloxacin to avoid excess QT prolongation. This should be restarted as an outpt. . #Urinary Tract Infection. A UA was positive on ___, but she was asymptomatic. She was treated with PO levofloxacin for 5 days for her pneumonia, course was finished at the time of the postivie U/A. Urine cultures were sent. Rehab will be called if the results are positive. . OUTPATIENT ISSUES: - Urine culture results will need to be followed-up as an outpatient

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Coronary cath with angiogram followed by PTCA/stent of proximal LCX using DES, and POBA of OM2. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diverticulitis who presents with 3 weeks of chest pain worse evening prior to admission, found to have NSTEMI. He first had an episode of chest pain approximately 3 weeks ago described as a pinching sensation in the anterior chest for a minute or 2 occurring at random intervals. Also felt weak. He reported increasing sodium content in his diet at the time, accompanied by some lower extremity edema left greater than right (not new). His symptoms are worsened by exertion (unloads boxes as a ___). Since then he reports intermittent chest pain which occurs every other day. Last night, he reported more central chest discomfort, diaphoresis, mild palpitations ("fluttering pain") around 7 ___ which persisted until about ___ AM. This morning he reported improvement in symptoms, however went to urgent care for evaluation. There he was found to be hypertensive 155/106 and EKG showed lateral T wave inversions in 1 and aVL, hyperacute T wave in V3, nonspecific T wave abnormality/inversions V5 and V6. In the ED, he continued to have intermittent chest discomfort and mild hypertension to 140/150s. He was afebrile and satting 100% on room air. EKG showed resolution of T wave inversions in lateral leads. Chest x-ray was unremarkable, troponin came back positive at 1.98, declining to 1.79 with elevation of CK to 1389 with a CK-MB of 122. Lab work notable for leukocytosis of 15, unremarkable BMP. He received aspirin 325, atorvastatin 80 mg, 0.4 mg nitroglycerin. Due to elevated troponin in the setting of anginal symptoms patient was sent to the Cath Lab for coronary angiogram and possible PCI. Cardiovascular risk factors include remote tobacco history, no clear family history of early MI/sudden death. No history of stroke, diabetes, TIA. He does have a history of hyperlipidemia not on a statin (LDL 140s). Vitals on Transfer: afebrile BP 140/98, HR 83, RR 18, 100% RA. Cath lab: thrombotic appearing large bifurcating OM1/OM2 lesion, stent to OM2, with mild residual ostial OM1 occlusion, approx. 30%. Had a chronic distal lesion with R to L collaterals, attempted to balloon it given thought of some degree of thrombus but it didn't do much. Pain free, feeling well, good results from the stent. Loaded w/ aspirin in ED, ticagrelor, will continue ticag 90 bid, also atorva 80. Consider morning A1c. R radial access. On the floor, he is HDS and chest pain has resolved. Endorses mild headache and right wrist tenderness where cath access. IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic abnormality. No evidence of pneumonia. CORONARY ANGIOGRAM WITH PCI ___ Coronary Description The coronary circulation is right dominant. LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a large caliber vessel and is normal. This vessel bifurcates into the Left Anterior Descending and Left Circumflex systems. LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber vessel with minimal irregularities. The Diagonal, arising from the proximal segment, is a small caliber vessel. There is a 70% stenosis in the proximal and mid segments. Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 90% thrombotic stenosis in the proximal segment which extends across the origin of OM1. The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the proximal segment, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 30% stenosis in the ostium. The ___ Obtuse Marginal, arising from the mid segment, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 100% stenosis in the mid segment which is likely due to distal embolization. There are right to left collaterals to the distal vessel. The Inferior lateral of the 2ndOM, arising from the mid segment, is a small caliber vessel. RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 30% stenosis in the proximal segment. The Right Posterior Descending Artery, arising from the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. The Right Posterolateral Artery, arising from the distal segment, is a medium caliber vessel. Findings - Single vessel coronary artery disease. - Successful PTCA/stent of proximal LCX using DES, and POBA of OM2. Recommendations - ASA 81mg per day. - Ticagrelor 90mg BID for 12 months. - Secondary prevention of CAD TRANSTHORACIC ECHO ___ CONCLUSION: The left atrial volume index is normal. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with a normal cavity size. There is a moderate sized area of regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the inferolateral wall and anterolateral wall (see schematic). Quantitative biplane left ventricular ejection fraction is 39 % (normal 54-73%). There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Normal right ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. Tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) is normal. The mitral valve leaflets appear structurally normal with no mitral valve prolapse. There is mild [1+] mitral regurgitation. The pulmonic valve leaflets are normal. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is physiologic tricuspid regurgitation. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction c/ w CAD. Mild mitral regurgitation. Atenolol 50 mg PO DAILY 2. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY RX *aspirin 81 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*90 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime Disp #*90 Tablet Refills: *0 3. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY RX *lisinopril 10 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 4.
