TiCAGRELOR 90 mg PO BID RX *ticagrelor [Brilinta] 90 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY DIAGNOSES: #Type 1 NSTEMI SECONDARY DIAGNOSES: #HLD #HTN <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___. WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? - You were admitted to the hospital because of your chest pain. WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL? - In the hospital, we did blood tests and an EKG that were concerning for a heart attack given your chest pain. When we did a cardiac catheterization of your heart, imaging of the vessels confirmed narrowing of several including 90% occlusion of one, which was opened up with a stent. Imaging at the end of the procedure showed normal blood flow through that artery. Ultrasound imaging of the heart afterward demonstrated that its pumping ability is a little below normal, which is likely a result of the heart attack. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? - Please take all of your medications exactly as prescribed and attend all of your follow-up appointments listed below. We wish you the best! Your ___ Care Team
target: SUMMARY STATEMENT: ==================== Mr. ___ is a ___ man with hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diverticulitis who presents ___ with 3 weeks of chest pain that worsened evening prior to admission, found to have NSTEMI, sent to cath lab where notably found LCX 90% occluded and 100% occluded segment in OM2, successful PTCA/stent of proximal LCX using DES and POBA of OM2 with return of normal flow, patient now pain free, got TTE prior to discharge showing reduced EF 40-45 and anterolateral hypokinesis/inferolateral akinesis. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== - Patient needs outpatient cardiac rehab - Started on ASA 81mg per day - Started Ticagrelor 90mg BID - continue until ___ (if 12 month course) - Started on atorvastatin 80 mg daily - Home atenolol was switched to metoprolol succinate XL 25 - continue outpatient - Switched home hydrochlorothiazide to ACE inhibitor: lisinopril 10, titrate as tolerated ACTIVE ISSUES: ============== #NSTEMI #Chest pain Three weeks of anginal symptoms and found to have an NSTEMI here. EKG reflected possible ischemia in the lateral leads. Coronary angiogram with LCX 90% occluded, 100% occluded segment in OM2, 70% of the diag, and 30% of the RCA. Successful PTCA/stent of proximal LCX using DES, and POBA of OM2, with final angiogram showing return of circulation. TTE showed EF 40-45% and inferior/inferolateral hypokinesis. Pt symptom free on discharge. On medications as noted above/below with cardiology follow up scheduled and needing outpatient cardiac rehab. CHRONIC ISSUES: =============== #Hypertension - managed per above. #HLD - started on atorvastatin per above. CONTACT: Name of health care proxy: ___ Relationship: Wife Phone number: ___ CODE STATUS: Full confirmed with patient.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Codeine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain, abnormal stress test <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with multiple medical problems including HTN, HL, undifferentiated rheumatologic condition, depression, DJD spine admitted after abnormal stress test today. Per recent PCP and ___ notes: Ms ___ has CAD risk factors positive for HTN, HL, previous smoking history and strong family history. In ___, she underwent a stress ECHO which demonstrated normal LV function without evidence of wall motion dysfunction. In the last few months Ms ___ has been experiencing exertional substernal/left chest discomfort with some shoulder aches at times after stopping her atenolol. This usually happens when she does her daily walk around her cul de sac and is occuring with less and less exertion. If she pushes on, she has associated SOB. She notices it on walking up an incline and its relieved with rest. She denies ever having symptoms at rest. She denies any orthopnea, PND, ankle swelling, palpitation or dizziness. Plan was to undergo a stress MIBI test to help further risk stratify her symptoms. She continued aspirin, beta blocker and statin. She was given sublingual NTG and have advised her to contact EMS should her symptom does not improve after taking 3 NTG tablet. Per recent phone call, nitro worked well for patient. Today, she had her stress test during which she had had CP, her BP dropped, ECG changes noted. Symptoms resolved with rest, oxygen, and SLN x 1. She is being admitted. On the floor, pt feels tired and worn out but is comfortable. No chest pain or SOB. On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Cardiac Risk Factors: (-)Diabetes, (+)Dyslipidemia, (+)Hypertension Cardiac History: CABG: none Percutaneous coronary intervention: none Pacemaker/ICD: none # FIBROMYALGIA # HTN # HYPERLIPIDEMIA # GERD # HYPOTHYROIDISM # ATROPHIC VAGINITIS # OSTEOARTHRITIS # Iron deficiency anemia # Depression # DJD of spine # Lymphocytic colitis ___, treated with macrobiotic diet # H/o peritonitis ___ s/p experimental IUD # s/p R salpingo-ooprectomy ___ # s/p KNEE SURGERY ___ at ___ # h/o SHINGLES ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother is ___ with some OA and significant macular degeneration; otherwise doing okay. Father had CAD and a hip replacement, died of suicide. PGM had OA. She has seven siblings, many have OA of the hands. One brother has gout, DM type II and has had 3 strokes, one has CAD, one has T2 DM. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Exam on admission ___: VS - T 97.8 BP 140/72 HR 72 100% RA Ht 64 inches Wt 175 lbs Gen: WDWN middle aged female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Neck: Supple without JVD CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RRR, normal S1, S2. ___ systolic murmur at ___, no r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. Chest: CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. No chest wall deformities. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No c/c/e. 2+ ___ pulses b/l. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. Exam on discharge R groin with bruise, 2cm X 4cm hematoma. mild tenderness. No bruit <PERTINENT RESULTS> Labs on admission ___: WBC-5.5 RBC-4.19* Hgb-11.3* Hct-35.5* MCV-85 MCH-26.9* MCHC-31.7 RDW-14.9 Plt ___ PTT-26.6 ___ Glucose-118* UreaN-16 Creat-0.9 Na-144 K-4.7 Cl-106 HCO3-28 AnGap-15 Cardiac enzymes negative x3 HbA1c 5.9 Labs on discharge Hct HCT-33.3* Imaging: ETT performed ___ demonstrated: patient exercised for 7.5 minutes of a modified ___ protocol (~ ___ METS), representing an average exercise tolerance for her age. The test was terminated due to progressive anginal type symptoms in association with ST depression/elevation (AVR) and drop in systolic blood pressure. At minute 5 of exercise, the patient noted ___ substernal chest tightness, progressing to ___ at peak exercise. The discomfort resolved by minute 6.5 of recovery after administration of 0.3 mg of SL NTG and 4 L of O2. At peak exercise, there was 1-1.5 mm of horizontal/upsloping ST segment depression in the inferolateral leads and 1-___levation in lead AVR. During recovery, there was an additional 0.5 mm (1-2 mm total) of ST segment depression with ST segments becoming downsloping in the inferolateral leads. These changes returned to baseline by minute 8 of recovery. The rhythm was sinus with no ectopy throughout the study. There was a progressive drop in systolic blood pressure throughout exercise, rebounding in recovery. Heart rate response to exercise was appropriate. IMPRESSION: Ischemic EKG changes in the presence of progressive anginal type symptoms and drop in systolic blood pressure with exercise. Nuclear report sent separately. . MIBI: The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 64% at rest and 50% at stress. Large severe reversible perfusion defect in the proximal LAD territory accompanied by left ventricular hypokinesis during stress imaging. . Cardiac Catheterization: 1. Coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated single vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA was long with a distal 20% tapering. The LAD had a proximal 80% stenosis with TIMI2 flow, with moderate calcification. There was mild 30% plaquing before S1 and D1 just beyond the proximal LAD stenosis. The mid-LAD had 40% narrowing after D3. The LCx had minimal luminal irregularities and supplied an OM1, 2, and a larger OM3/LPL. The RCA had diffuse plaquing throughout to 30%. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated high-normal systemic arterial blood pressure (SBP 138 mm Hg) and mildly elevated left ventricular filling pressure (LVEDP 15 mm Hg). There was no gradient upon pullback of the catheter from the LV into the aorta. 3. Left ventriculography revealed normal left ventricular systolic function (calculated LVEF 57%) with normal wall motion and no mitral regurgitation. 4. Successful PCI of the proximal LAD with a 3.0x12mm Promus DES, post-dilated to 3.25mm. 5. Successful closure of the right femoral arteriotomy site with a ___ Perclose device. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> (all doses confirmed with pt on admission): -Atenolol 25 mg Tablet daily -Atorvastatin [Lipitor] 20 mg Tablet daily -Duloxetine [Cymbalta] 30 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) daily -Esomeprazole Magnesium [Nexium] 40mg daily -Estradiol [Estrace] 0.01 % Cream; apply 1 gram to vag area 2x weekly (___) -Hydroxychloroquine 200 mg Tablet BID -Levothyroxine 88 mcg Tablet daily -Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual PRN -Aspirin 81mg -Calcium-Mag-Vit B6-D3-Minerals [Calcium Citrate + D with Mag] 250 mg-40 mg-125 unit-5 mg Tablet - 3 tabs BID -Cetirizine [Zyrtec] PRN -Docusate Sodium 300 mg Capsule daily (recently increased due to -Glucosamine-Chondroitin 500 mg-400 mg Capsule BID -Ibuprofen 200 mg Tablet BID: PRN -Multivitamin Capsule (without iron) daily -Omega-3 Fatty Acids [Fish Oil] 300 mg-1,000 mg Capsule daily -Iron Sulfate 325mg TID (pt takes 45mg elemental iron) <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atenolol 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 3. Acetaminophen 500 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Q6H (every 6 hours). 4. Duloxetine 30 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Conjugated Estrogens 0.625 mg/g Cream Sig: One (1) gram Vaginal 2X/WEEK (___): apply 1 gram to vag area 2x weekly. 6. Hydroxychloroquine 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 7. Levothyroxine 88 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 8. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tablet Sublingual as directed: 1 Tablet(s) sublingually prn can take 1 tablet every five minutes up to 3 tablet and if persistent symptoms despite the above should contact EMS . 9. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 10. Calcium Citrate + D with Mag 250-40-5-125 mg-mg-mg-unit Tablet Sig: Three (3) Tablet PO twice a day. 11. Zyrtec 10 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day as needed for allergy symptoms. 12. Docusate Sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: Three (3) Capsule PO DAILY (Daily). 13. Ferrous Sulfate 300 mg (60 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO TID (3 times a day). 14. Multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 15. Omega-3 Fatty Acids Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY (Daily). 16. Glucosamine-Chondroitin 500-400 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). 17. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 18. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *90 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 19. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day: for heart burn. Disp: *30 Capsule(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Stable angina Coronary artery disease Hypertension Hyperlipidemia Secondary: Hypothyroidism Anemia Osteoarthritis Fibromyalgia GERD <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Ms. ___, you were admitted to ___ due to an abnormal outpatient stress test. You had a cardiac catheterization which showed an obstruction of your proximal left anterior descending artery and a drug eluting stent was placed to remove the obstruction. Dr. ___ and Dr. ___ were present at your catheterization. Changed to your medications: 1. INCREASE to aspirin 325mg daily , DO NOT STOP OR REDUCE until you speak to your cardiologist. 2. INCREASE to atorvastatin (lipitor) 40mg daily 3. STOP Ibuprofen until you speak to your cardiologist about when it is safe to restart this medication. 4. START tylenol ___ every six hours if needed for arthritis pain 5. START Clopidogrel (plavix) 75mg daily. DO NOT STOP this medication under any circumstance. 6. STOP Nexium, instead take Ranitidine for heartburn (reflux)
target: Pleasant ___ with cardiac risk factors of HTN, HL, smoking history, family history presenting to PCP and cardiologist with chest pain, underwent stress test which was abnormal, admitted for further evaluation. #. CAD - Pt's symptoms are concerning for stable angina given sx are with exertion and resolve with rest. Distribution of ST T changes concernign for L main disease. Chest pain is resolved with nitro. CE negative x3. Tele unremarkable. Plavix load and heparin were held prior to catheterization due to concern that surgical intervention may be necessary. She underwent catheterization which showed a proximal LAD lesion, underwent PCI with drug eluting stent. Pt was started on high dose aspirin, clopiogrel, atorvastatin was increased, and pt was continued on atenolol. LVEF was within normal range, and no ACEI was started. On the following day pt had an 4 point Hct drop, hematocrit was rechecked and stable. Pt was discharged with 3 week follow up with Dr. ___. During ___ hospitalization her HbA1C was checked which was 5.9%

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Iodine; Iodine Containing / Lipitor / Zocor / Codeine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate mitral regurgitation noted on perprocedure TTE and TEE with no disruption of subvalvular apparatus or frank rupture of the valve leaflets. 3. Pulmonary hypertension 4. Elevated right and left sided filling pressures. 5. Hemodynamic compromise necessitating IABP placement. 6. Successful PTCA and stenting of the LCX with two overlapping bare metal stents. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mrs. ___ is a ___ y oF with CAD s/p multiple PCIs, HTN, PVD, and DMt2 who presented to an OSH with severe chest pain on ___. She describes the pain as a "tightness" in the center of her chest that she rated as 10 out of 10 on a pain scale. Onset of pain was while watching television after attending a relatives funeral. Pain was associated with nausea and shortness of breath. She denies palpitations, dizziness, diaphoresis, syncope, recent illness, fever or chills. It is not associated with position or diet. She states this chest pain is similar to the chest pain she experienced with her heart attack in ___. While at home pt took three ntg tablets without relief so she called EMS. . At the OSH she received additional sublingual ntg without relief and was subsequently placed on ntg drip. EKG was read as bigeminy and trigeminy. She had Troponin I of 7.___epressions in V3-6. She given aspirin and started on heparin and integrillin drips. She was continued on home plavix and beta blocker. CXR showed evidence of congestive changes so she was gently diuresed with lasix. Pt was then transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. . On presentation to the floor, pt admits that her chest pain has never completely resolved but that it has been maintained at a level of 1 out of ten since admission. She denies current palpitations, shortness of breath, and nausea. On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. Cardiac review of systems is notable for abscence of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. She admits to exertional calf pain despite prior interventions. She also admits to increased dyspnea on exertion over the last year. . Patient was admitted to floor and the triggered for chest pain that was not controlled with nitroglycerin SL or drip. She was bolused for 500 ml IVF for low blood pressures. Shortly thereafter, she became acutely hypoxic, and was started on face make oxygen. She was given 40 mg lasix, 2 mg morphine, and increased nitroglycerin rate. She diuresed well with the lasix. . On arrival to the CCU, she was chest pain free and respiratory distress was resolved. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> CAD s/p MI in ___ with c. cath x 2 (see below) DMt2 PVD s/p bilateral ___ arterial stenting HTN s/p psoas abscess repair s/p cholecystectomy s/p appendectomy Cardiac Risk Factors: + Diabetes, +Hypertension, + tobacco <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No known family history of sudden cardiac death or premature cardiac disease. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: BP 102/39, HR 87 RR 18 SpO2 94% 2L fsbs 347 wt 108kg Gen: WDWN elderly female in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Neck: Supple; no masses, no LAD; JVP at angle of jaw CV: distant heart sounds, RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. Chest: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no wheezes or rhonchi, mild crackles at bases Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Ext: No c/c/e. Cool, capillary refill 3 seconds Skin: dry, no stasis dermatitis or ulcers . Pulses: Right: Carotid 2+ DP palpable ___ palpable Left: Carotid 2+ DP palpable ___ palpable <PERTINENT RESULTS> Cardiac ECHO (___) The right atrium is markedly dilated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is mildly depressed (LVEF= 40 %). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve is not well seen. There is no aortic valve stenosis. Mitral valve leaflets are not well seen. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen (may be underestimated due to poor technical quality). The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad. IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Mildly depressed left ventricular systolic function. Preserved right ventricular function. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the severity of mitral regurgitation appears to be reduced, but image quality is extremely suboptimal. If clinically indicated, a TEE would better assess the severity of regurgitation. . CARDIAC CATH: 1. Selective coronary angiogrpahy in this right dominant system revealed 2 vessel obstructive coronary disease. The LMCA had a distal taper. The LAD had an 80% proximal and 80% mid vessel stenosis. The LCX was subtotally occluded proximally with TIMI 2 flow. The RCA had ostial dampening with a filling defect in the proximal stent. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed low systemic blood pressure and shock physiology with SBP as low as 50 mmHg up to 118 mmHg with initiation of a dopamine IV gtt. There was moderate to severe pulmonary hypertension with PASP of 84 mmHg. There was elevated right and left sided filling pressures with RVEDP of 21 mmHg and mean PCWP of 60 (with giant V waves noted). The cardiac index was preserved at 3.40 l/min/m2 on IV dopamine. 3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the left circumflex with two overlapping bare metal stents a Microdriver (2.5x24mm) bare metal stent proximally and a MiniVision (2.5x28mm) bare metal stent distally. The stents were postdilated with a 2.5mm balloon. Final angiography demonstrated no angiograghically apparent dissection, no residual stenosis and TIMI III flow throughout the vessel (See ___ comments). 4. Successful placement of an intraortic balloon pump via the right femoral artery. Cardiac cath final diagnosis: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate mitral regurgitation noted on perprocedure TTE and TEE with no disruption of subvalvular apparatus or frank rupture of the valve leaflets. 3. Pulmonary hypertension 4. Elevated right and left sided filling pressures. 5. Hemodynamic compromise necessitating IABP placement. 6. Successful placement of a 30cc IABP via the right femoral artery. 7. Successful PTCA and stenting of the LCX with two overlapping bare metal stents. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> lisinopril 40mg po daily aspirin 81 mg daily HCTZ 25mg daily Plavix 75mg daily Lopressor 25 mg bid Crestor 2.5 mg bid Colace 100 mg bid NPH 36 u bid Novolog 4 u bid Advil 200 mg prn <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily): Take every day for one year. 2. Pravastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: Four (4) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 4. Senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for constipation. 5. Albuterol 90 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: One (1) Puff Inhalation Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed. 6. Ipratropium Bromide 17 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: Two (2) Puff Inhalation QID (4 times a day). 7. Bisacodyl 10 mg Suppository Sig: One (1) supp Rectal once a day as needed for constipation. 8. Metoprolol Succinate 50 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: 1.5 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hrs PO DAILY (Daily): Hold SBP<100, HR< 55. 9. Trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO at bedtime as needed for insomnia. 10. Insulin NPH Human Recomb 100 unit/mL Suspension Sig: Twenty Six (26) units Subcutaneous twice a day: before breakfast and dinner. Disp: *qs 1* Refills: *2* 11. Humalog 100 unit/mL Solution Sig: Four (4) units Subcutaneous twice a day: before breakfast and dinner. 12. Lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 13. Omeprazole 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO twice a day. 14. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day. 15. Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tab Sublingual q 5 minutes x3. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Non-ST elevation Myocardial Infarction Coronary Artery disease Cardiovascular Shock Acute blood Loss anemia Diabetes mellitus Type 2 Acute Renal failure Hypertension Peripheral Vascular Disease Positive MRSA screen Ventricular Bigeminy <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable BUN=35 Creat 1.1 K=4.4 hct=28.8 wbc=12.3 <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and received 2 bare metal stents in your left circumflex artery. You will need to continue Plavix (Clopodigrel) for the next month, do not miss any doses. You also had a bleed in your bowel that has resolved, you have been started on Omeprazole twice daily to treat this. Your kidneys were not working very well, they have normalized now. . Please stop smoking. Information was given to you on admission regarding smoking cessation. . Medication changes: 1. You are on NPH insulin at 30units twice daily, this is lower than the 36 units that you were taking on admission. 2. Omeprazole was started twice daily for blood in your stools. 3. Your Lisinopril was decreased to 10mg daily 4. Aspirin was increased to 325mg daily 5. Crestor was changed to Pravastatin 6. HCTZ was discontinued 7. Lopressor was changed to Toprol and increased to 75mg daily 8. Albuterol and Atrovent inhalers were added as needed. . Please follow up with your primary care provider after you leave the rehabilitation facility.
target: CARDIOGENIC SHOCK: Patient was admitted to CCU service for intractable chest pain without ST elevations. Shortly after admission to the CCU, she developed progressive hypotension and dyspnea. She was emergently intubated for hypoxia and was started on dopamine en route to cath lab on ___. In the cath lab, she had two vessel coronary artery disease, moderate mitral regurgitation, pulmonary hypertension, elevated right and left sided filling pressures and overall hemodynamic compromise necessitating IABP placement. She had successful PTCA and stenting of the left circumflex with two bare metal stents. She received prednisone due to a history of allergy to contrast dye. Following IABP placement, she was aggressively diuresed. She had ventricular ectopy that interfered with IABP function and required lidocaine and amiodorone for control. She was weaned off IABP on ___ and extubated on ___. She had significant blood loss following IABP removal secondary to a failure of hemostasis. She was transfused 2 U PRBC. Pressures improved and she was weaned off dopamine and able to be start antihypertensives. . CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: She had stenting of left circumflex but has residual disease. She was started on medical management for her coronoary artery disease including ASA, plavix, statin, beta-blocker, ACE-inhibitor. Cardiac surgery evaluated for CABG, but patient decided that she was not interested in further interventions at this time. . VENTRICULAR ECTOPY: Patient had intermittant bigeminal rhythm on admission that was thought to be reactive to ischemia. Because IABP was unable to expand during PVCs, this rhythm prevented IABP augmentation of cardiac output. She was started on lidocaine on ___, but developed tachyphylaxis and was changed to amiodorone on ___. She received prednisone due to the iodine moiety in amiodorone. Amiodorone was stopped on ___. . GI BLEED: Had episode of ___ with falling Hct on ___. She was transfused and started on a BID PPI. She was seen by GI consult, but refused endoscopy. She had no further episodes of bleeding. - Would recommend oupatient endoscopy if patient is amenable. . BACTERMIA: Coag (-) staph in isolated sample, very likely to be a contaminant. She had an echo without evidence of vegetation. Patient refused TEE. She was treated with Vanc ___. This was stopped following the results of the coagulase test. Surveilence cultures were negative. She was afebrile with a normalizing white blood count. . ENDOCRINE: She has a history of DM type 2 that resulted in marked hyperglycemia on prednisone. She was started on an insulin drip in the ICU. He insulin was reintroduced following call-out. She required 24 U NPH BID when eating minimally, and takes 36 U at home. On discharge, she was receiving 26 U insulin BID. - Uptitrate as necessary. . RENAL: Patient had acute renal failure secondary to cardiogenic shock and need for aggressive diuresis. Creatinine peaked at 1.9 but returned to baseline of 1.1 on discharge. . EPSTAXIS: Patient had nosebleed. She was seen by ENT who packed left nares. She was treated with 7 days of nafcillin. Packing was removed on ___.

Lipids showed HDL 36, LDL 54, Trig 130, cholesterol 116. HgA1C showed 6.0%. . #Atrial fibrillation - CHADS2 score is 1 (HTN) and he is anticoagulated with Pradaxa at home. He was recently diagnosed with AF within the past year and is s/p DCCV in ___, although he is currently in AF at admission. Rate control with metoprolol. . # Concern for Peripheral vascular disease: pt endorsed claudication, ABI was done and was pending at time of discharge. . # HLD - On simvastatin at home, LDL was 78 and HDL 40 in ___. Continued metoprolol as above for rate control and to reduce myocardial work. . # Alcohol abuse - Drinks ___ drinks per day and reports no prior withdrawal symptoms. target: ___ yo M with hx of HIV, DMII, HLD presented from OSH with sx of chest pain found to have lateral STEMI, now s/p cardiac catheterization with DES placed in RCA. . ACTIVE ISSUES: # STEMI - Pt presented with chest pain found to have ST elevations in II, III, avF, V3-V6 with reciprocal depression in I, aVL, V1 and V2. Cardiac enzymes intially showed CK-MB 71 and troponin 5.02. Cardiac catheterization showed large RCA thrombus which was treated with a DES to mid-distal RCA. While in the cath lab, he developed self-limited VT lasting 60 seconds. Post cath, ST inferiolateral segments remain elevated despite being pain free. Loaded with plavix, started integrilin, no antiarrythmics started. Angioseal was placed in right groin at 10AM. The patient was continued on integrillin for 18 hrs after cath, plavix, and ASA. He was started on metoprolol, captopril and atorvastatin. Nitro was held given that he had a large inferior MI. Post cath echo showed LVEF of 40-45 and inferior/inferolateral akinesis and inferoseptal akinesis/hypokinesis. Patient remained chest pain free through the remainder of admission. He was discharged on ASA, plavix, metoprolol, lisinopril, atorvastatin with plans to follow up with Dr. ___. . #thrombocytopenia - On the evening of cardiac catheterization, platelet count was 12, repeat 13 (initially 83 on presentation). A peripheral smear verified this finding and there was no evidence of schistocytes present. The drop in platelet count was attributed to integrillin side effect. No platelet transfusion was given as transfused platelets will not have been exposed to aspirin and plavix and did not want to risk thrombosing new stent. There was no evidence of active bleed. After the discontinuation of integrillin platelets trended up. At time of discharge platelet count was 75. . CHRONIC ISSUES: # DM type 2: stable. non insulin dependent, reports home sugars 130-180s Initially held home oral medications and was managed with SSI. On day 2, pt was restarted on home oral medications (metformin and glipizide). A1C was 9.3 on this admission. Will need follow up for tighter glucose control with his primary care physician. . # HIV: on ARV since ___. Unknown last CD4 count or viral load Home medications were verified with his pharmacy and continued . # GERD: stable given ranitidine 150 mg po BID during admission . # Hyperlipidemia: lipid panel completed (see results section). Pt started on atorvastatin 80 which was decreased from 80 to 40 given interaction risk of rhabdomyolysis. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # diabetes: Given elevated A1c on admission, patient needs tigher glucose control. He will need to follow up with his PCP for possible medication adjustments.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). mild left sided weakness <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear ___, ___ were hospitalized due to symptoms of left sided weakness resulting from an ACUTE ISCHEMIC STROKE, a condition where a blood vessel providing oxygen and nutrients to the brain is blocked by a clot. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. We saw on MRI that ___ had a small stroke (not a TIA) that caused your weakness. This was most likely caused by small vessel disease, which is from high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol. We stopped your aspirin, started Plavix, which is similar to aspirin, and increased your atorvastatin to decrease your risk of stroke in the future. ___ will have physical therapy at home per physical therapy recommendations. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed ___ for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: high blood pressure diabetes atherosclerosis of your blood vessels high cholesterol We are changing your medications as follows: stop aspirin start Plavix (clopidogrel) 75 mg daily increase atorvastatin to 80 mg nightly Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician. If ___ experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to ___ - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team
target: ___ woman with a history of HTN and DM presented with acute onset left-sided weakness and slurred speech that lasted for 2 hours before resolving spontaneously prior to presentation to the hospital. She was admitted to the stroke service. CT head showed hypodensity in the right basal ganglia. MRI brain w/o contrast confirmed small acute infarct in the right putamen and as well as the body of the right caudate nucleus. Her stroke was most likely secondary to small vessel disease given the location and her risk factors. We did consider this a failure of ASA. Her home aspirin was stopped, and she was started on Plavix 75 mg daily. She had mild weakness on the L side in an upper motor neuron pattern distribution. ___ assessed and felt that she was able to be discharged home with home ___. She passed her swallow evaluation. TTE not done as this was felt to be small vessel etiology. Her stroke risk factors include the following: 1) DM: A1c 5.5% 2) intra and extra cranial calcifications noted on CTA 3) Hyperlipidemia: LDL 173, started on atoravastatin 80 # CKD--Cr 1.4 on admission, 1.2 on discharge (baseline). TRANSITIONAL ISSUES stroke - follow up in stroke clinic in ___ months. Stopped aspirin, started Plavix 75 mg daily this admission. Increased atorvastatin to 80 mg qhs. DM - continue glycemic control HTN - continue blood pressure control Consider outpatient Echo Home ___ TSH pending at the time of discharge

target: ___ y/o man with H/O dilated cardiomyopathy with preserved overall LVEF, s/p PPM ___, chronic atrial fibrillation, hypertension, CAD s/p DES to right PDA ___ with no flow-limiting disease on repeat coronary angiography ___, now transferred from ___ with marker negative unstable angina. # Chest pain - Patient with H/O DES to right PDA in ___, with angina in ___ which prompted cardiac catheterization which showed no flow-limiting lesions. Recently, he developed chest pain while at rest which prompted admission to the OSH. He has not had chest pain for the last several months and only uses his nitroglycerin ___ times per year. No history of crescendo angina as patient was not having chest pain with exertion. Cardiac biomarkers negative for necrosis. Patient reportedly (per outside cardiologist) had a nuclear stress test showing inferior wall ischemia. Furthermore, given significant history of CAD, and numerous risk factors (diabetes mellitus, HTN, hyperlipidemia - and use of ASA in past week), patient was transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. EKG did also show new T wave inversions in anterolateral leads. Radial arterial access was attempted, however vasospasm there resulted in a femoral approach. Catheterization was technically very challenging as patient had tortuous vessels and large body habitus. Procedure showed no angiographically apparent flow limiting lesions on the left system, however, right coronary artery could not be engaged selectively, and only nonselective imaging was performed of the RCA. No obvious severe stenoses were appreciated. He remained completely chest-pain free throughout the entire duration of this hospitalization. On discharge, Plavix was stopped given apparently patent coronary arteries and ongoing systemic anticoagulation. It was felt that his chest pain was either related to his known GERD or some transient musculoskeletal pain vs. possibility of small clot which propagated distally or lysed spontaneously. Imdur was added to his home CAD regimen to control symptoms of chest pain should they be CAD related, see below. # CAD: Patient with H/O CAD s/p PCI of right PDA in ___, with patent coronaries on angiography ___. He was sent home on medical regimen of aspirin, metoprolol, fenofibrate, Crestor, and newly started Imdur. # ___ on CKD - Cr up to 1.9 on admission. His baseline was 1.5, likely due to diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His creatinine slowly trended down to 1.6 on discharge (arguing against contrast nephropathy). Unclear etiology ___ as patient denied any decrease in PO intake. # Cardiomyopathy: Reported history of dilated cardiomyopathy, unable to obtain TTE records. PMIBI ___ reportedly showed inferior wall hypokinesis. Patient did not have evidence of significant volume overload on exam, with LVEDP 17 mm Hg (consistent with mild diastolic dysfunction). Home dose Lasix was continued. # Atrial fibrillation - Patient with atrial fibrillation on Coumadin. On admission to ___ was 3.3. Coumadin had been held the day of transfer and patient was given PO vitamin K prior to transfer as well. The day after admission, INR remained at 3.2 and he was given another small dose of PO vitamin K. Following day, ___ INR was 1.8 and patient was taken to the cardiac catheterization laboratory, see chest pain above. Warfarin was restarted evening of ___ at 5 mg daily, and patient was instructed to follow up with his ___ clinic regarding INR levels and warfarin dosing. Home digoxin, diltiazem, and metoprolol were continued for rate control. Outpatient cardiologist was contacted regarding his rate control regimen as patient was paced the majority of the time, suggesting possibly excessive rate control. Last pacer interrogation showed pacing of >70%. It appeared that he has been very difficult to rate control in the past so his home regimen was not adjusted at this time. # Dyslipidemia - LDL 35. Triglycerides elevated. Home Crestor and fenofibrate were continued. # Diabetes mellitus - Patient not on medications at home but recent A1c 6.5. FSG monitored with SSI administered accordingly. He was instructed to follow with his PCP regarding blood glucose control. # GERD - omeprazole was continued. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: Patient was to follow with his PCP regarding blood glucose control.

The patient explains he was in his usual state of health until about one month ago. At that time, he went shopping at a familiar mall. While perusing in the aisles, he realized he did not know how to exit the building. Even with the help of directions, he had trouble finding his way. The episode lasted about 15 minutes before spontaneously resolving. Once outside he was able to drive himself home without difficulty. About two weeks later, he was walking along the beach when he experienced the sudden weakening of the knees bilaterally. The episode was transient (seconds) and he did not actually fall. The episode was not associated with any other symptoms. In the course of the month prior to evaluation, the patient has also experienced 10 to 15-minute episodes of sensory changes in the left lower extremity. He describes the sudden onset of "numbness" distal to the left knee; he indicates the sensation encompasses the entire lower limb and foot. He further elaborates that the leg transiently feels "like dead wood," as "if it does not belong to me." He cannot identify any reliable triggers; he recalls standing to do housework during the first event but also reports experiencing the sensation while supine in bed. He denies associated symptoms including right lower extremity and upper extremity weakness, sensory changes, and facial symptoms. The symptom spontaneously resolved. Episodes now occur weekly. Concerned, he sought the attention of his primary care doctor who ordered an MRI. The MRI was reported to show changes concerning for acute watershed infracts in the right premotor region, lentiform nucleus, and posterior parietal subcortical white matter in addition to the absence of flow in the right cavernous internal carotid artery and poor flow in the right middle cerebral and distal left vertebral arteries. At the suggestion of his PCP, the patient presented to the ___ for further evaluation and care. At the time of our initial evaluation, the patient denied active symptoms. In the course of the interview, however, he reported the onset of the left lower extremity symptoms. When asked to lie down, he reported the resolution of the syndrome. Motor: * Bulk: No evidence of atrophy. * Tone: Normal. No evidence of cogwheel rigidity or paratonia. * Drift: No pronator drift bilaterally. * Adventitious Movements: No tremor or asterixis noted. Strength: * Left Upper Extremity: 5 throughout Delt, Biceps, Triceps, Wrist Ext, Wrist Flex, Finger Ext, Finger Flex * Right Upper Extremity: 5 throughout Delt, Biceps, Triceps, Wrist Ext, Wrist Flex, Finger Ext, Finger Flex * Left Lower Extremity: 5 throughout Iliopsoas, Quad, Ham, Tib Ant, Gastroc, Ext Hollucis Longis * Right Lower Extremity: 5 throughout Iliopsoas, Quad, Ham, Tib Ant, Gastroc, Ext Hollucis Longis Reflexes: * Left: 2 Biceps, 2 Triceps, 2 Bracheoradialis, 2 Patellar, 1 Achilles * Right: 2 Biceps, 2 Triceps, 2 Brachiradialis, 2 Patellar, 1 Achilles * Babinski: flexor bilaterally Sensation: * Light Touch: intact bilaterally in upper extremities, lower extremities, trunk, face * Pinprick: intact but with increasing dullness distal to knee bilaterally * Temperature: intact to cold sensation bilaterally in lower extremities * Vibration: intact bilaterally at level of medial malleolus * Proprioception: intact bilaterally at level of great toe * Extinction: No extinction to double simultaneous stimulation of lower extremities Coordination * Tremor: No evidence of resting or intention tremors. * Finger-to-nose: intact bilaterally * Rapid Alternating Movements: intact, symmetric Gait: * Description: Good initiation. Narrow-based with normal stride and arm-swing * Tandem: Able to tandem walk * Romberg: Negative (although pt reported feeling subjectively unsteady) Exam at time of discharge: Right pupil fixed and ureactive (old retinal hemorrhage), Face symmetric, no dysarthria, no pronator drift, decreased pinprick sensation in a stocking distribution. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Labs on admission and discharge: ___ 09: 45PM BLOOD WBC-9.1 RBC-4.74 Hgb-13.9* Hct-41.6 MCV-88 MCH-29.3 MCHC-33.4 RDW-14.3 Plt ___ ___ 08: 00PM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.8 ___ ___ 08: 00PM BLOOD Glucose-167* UreaN-32* Creat-1.8* Na-140 K-4.7 Cl-105 HCO3-27 AnGap-13 ___ 08: 06AM BLOOD ALT-11 AST-16 CK(CPK)-86 AlkPhos-48 TotBili-0.5 ___ 08: 00PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-106 ___ 08: 06AM BLOOD CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 08: 00PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 08: 06AM BLOOD Calcium-9.8 Phos-2.9 Mg-1.8 Cholest-180 Modifiable risk factors: ___ 08: 06AM BLOOD Triglyc-150* HDL-36 CHOL/HD-5.0 LDLcalc-114 ___ 08: 06AM BLOOD %HbA1c-9.4* Urine studies: ___ 09: 31AM URINE RBC-2 WBC-1 Bacteri-FEW Yeast-NONE Epi-<1 ___ 09: 31AM URINE Blood-SM Nitrite-NEG Protein-100 Glucose-TR Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-NEG pH-5.5 Leuks-NEG Imaging: Carotid u.s: ___ IMPRESSION: 1. Known occlusion of the right internal carotid artery. 2. Less than 40% stenosis of the left internal carotid artery. CXR ___: IMPRESSION: No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary abnormalities. MRI/A head/neck ___ ___: FINDINGS: There is an approximately 1 cm area of restricted diffusion in the right premotor area of the cerebral hemisphere near its vertex, with two additional punctate areas of restricted diffusion, one within the right lentiform nucleus and the second in the right posterior parietal subcortical white matter. These findings are of concern for areas of acute brain ischemia. Relatively minor areas of T2 hyperintensity are seen largely in the periartrial white matter on the right side, consistent with chronic small vessel infarction. There is no hydrocephalus or shift of normally midline structures, nor susceptibility abnormality of the brain. There is an absence of flow void signal within the right cavernous internal carotid artery. MR angiography discloses essentially complete absence of flow in the intracranial right internal carotid artery, in keeping with the prior duplex ultrasound results. There is very poor flow within the right middle cerebral artery. There is also likely a moderate stenosis of the precavernous portion of the left internal carotid artery. There is minimal flow within the distal left vertebral artery, in keeping with the prior duplex ultrasound results. The right vertebral artery is patent and non-stenotic. There is probable moderate atherosclerotic stenosis of the P1 segment of the left posterior cerebral artery. target: ___ year-old man with history including DM, HTN, CAD s/p CABG, PAD s/p aorto-bifem bypass, and known right internal carotid artery occlusion presented to his PCP with ___ history of left lower extremity paresthesias, underwent MRI/A and was found to have evidence of acute watershed infarcts in: - right premotor region - right lentiform nucleus - right posterior parietal subcortical white matter with absence of flow in the right cavernous internal carotid artery and poor flow in the right middle cerebral and distal left vertebral arteries. His exam on admission was notable for a chronically dilated non-reactive right pupil secondary to retinal hemorrhage and decreased pinprick sensation in a stocking distribution. He was asymptomatic during evaluation with exception of one episode of recurrence of his left lower extremity symptoms with standing and resolution with recumbency. Given above findings and history, concerning etiologies included stump emboli from R ICA as well as hypoperfusion of right side due to worsening L ICA disease, as noted by recrudescence of symptoms with standing. Patient was admitted to stroke service for further evaluation. His antihypertensive regimen was adjusted as follows: Norvasc was discontinued, Lisinopril was decreased. BP goal was deemed to be < 150/80 mmHg rather than typical 130/80 mmHg goal. He underwent a carotid duplex study confirming ___ stenosis and showing that L ICA was < 40% stenosed. Given recurrent emboli he was started on Plavix 75mg. Due to prior history of R opth. vein occlusion and secondary neovascularization s/p laser ablation, the risks and benefits of this treatment were discussed with patient and his opthalmologist, Dr. ___. It was agreed that the risk of stroke and their disability outweighted the risks of possible intraoccular hemorrhage on the right. Patient's modifiable risk factor were LDL of 114 and A1C of 9.4%. This was discussed with the patient and PCP. No changes to the multiple lipid lowering agents were made, and an outpatient evaluation by a Lipid specialist was discussed. ___ adjustments were also discussed and will be follow up by PCP. A neurology follow up was arranged, with Dr. ___.

No cough, vomiting, diarrhea, fever or chills. No recent injury or trauma to his chest. No headache,neck pain or abdominal pain. He reports his chest pain lasted for about ___ minutes. Your ___ Healthcare Team

Pulses: Right: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: WBC-13.8* RBC-4.20* Hgb-12.9* Hct-38.9* MCV-93# MCH-30.7# MCHC-33.2 RDW-14.1 Plt ___ Neuts-87.1* Lymphs-9.9* Monos-2.9 Eos-0.1 Baso-0.1 Glucose-136* UreaN-32* Creat-1.4* Na-137 K-4.2 Cl-98 HCO3-30 ALT-24 AST-18 AlkPhos-74 TotBili-0.3 DirBili-0.1 IndBili-0.2 Calcium-9.3 Phos-3.7 Mg-2.3 Discharge Labs: WBC-7.1 RBC-3.82* Hgb-11.7* Hct-35.3* MCV-92 MCH-30.5 MCHC-33.0 RDW-14.1 Plt ___ PTT-27.3 ___ Glucose-97 UreaN-21* Creat-1.2 Na-138 K-4.1 Cl-97 HCO3-33* Calcium-8.4 Phos-3.3 Mg-2.2 CXR ___ No appreciable interval change. Patient has had right upper lung and chest wall resection. There is mild scarring in the left mid lung unchanged over ___ years, no pleural effusion or pulmonary consolidation noted. Heart size normal. Transvenous right atrial pacer and right ventricular pacer defibrillator leads follow their expected courses unchanged and continuous from the left pectoral pacemaker. ECG ___ 1: 46: 26 AM Sinus rhythm and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with ventricular rate 143 bpm. The limb leads are misattached. There is evidence for prior inferoposterior and lateral myocardial infarction. Right bundle-branch block. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ paroxysmal atrial fibrillation has appeared. Otherwise, no apparent diagnostic interim change. Cardiac catheterization ___ 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system revealed three vessel native coronary artery disease. The LMCA was heavily calicified with ostial 70% stenosis and distal 40% stenosis; there was some pressure dampening when the LMCA was engaged with the JL4 diagnostic catheter. The LAD had proximal diffuse disease, was heavily calcified, and had competitive flow in the mid-LAD; there were apical collaterals to the RCA. The LCX was moderately calcified with a hazy origin stenosis of at least mild-moderate severity. A high OM1 had diffuse severe disease after a proximal taper. There was a major patent OM2. The OM3/LPL was of modest caliber. The distal AV groove CX supplied an atrial branch and faint collaterals to the RCA. The RCA had a proximal total occlusion with faint filling of AMs. 2. Selective venous conduit angiography was not performed as the SVG's were known to be occluded. Selective conduit arteriography revealed a patent LIMA arising adjacent to the thyrocervical trunk. The proximal left subclavian artery stent was patent, with a 20 mnHg gradient in the subclavian distal to the LIMA origin. The LIMA had a mild kinking mid graft and a mild anastomotic lesion; there was retrograde filling of a large diagonal and aterograde filling of the apical LAD with collaterals to the RCA. There was a 50% lesion at the origin of the vertebral artery. 3. Abdominal aortography using an angled pigtail catheter just below the level of the renal arteries revealed no apparent renal artery stenosis. There was extensive distal abdominal aortic disease with plaque at the origin of the right iliac artery and a 60-70% stenosis at the origin of the left iliac artery. There was calcific atherosclerosis in both femoral arteries. The right femoral artery had been noted to be heavily calcified during arterial access. 4. Resting hemodynamics revealed normal systemic blood pressure with SBP of 101 mmHg, elevated right and left sided filling pressures with RVEDP of 13 mmHg and mean PCWP of 22 mmHg. There was pulmonary arterial hypertension with PASP of 45 mmHg. The cardiac index was preserved at 2.7 l/min/m2 (using an assumed oxygen consumption). Echocardiogram ___ The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 25 %) with akinesis to dyskinesis of thinned inferior and infero-lateral walls. The basal septum moves best and the remaining segments are hypokinetic. There is no ventricular septal defect. with normal free wall contractility. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The number of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. The aortic valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. An eccentric, posteriorly directed jet of moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is a trivial/physiologic pericardial effusion. PCI ___ 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated a severly diseased left main coronary artery extending into the proximal left circumflex and left main coronary artery. The mid to distal portion of the left anterior descending artery filled by a patent LIMA. The right coronary artery was not engaged. 2. Successful prophylactic placement of an IABP via the left femoral artery for cardiogenic support during PCI. 3. Successful stenting of the left main coronary artery extending into the proximal left circumflex artery with a Xience (3x23mm) drug eluting stent postdilated with a 3.5mm balloon. Final angiography demonstrated no angiographically apparent dissection, no residual stenosis and TIMI III flow throughout the vessel. 4. Successful closure of the right femoral arteritomy site with a ___ Mynx closure device. Right Knee X-rays ___ Right medial post-surgical clips projecting over the soft tissues. Extensive vascular calcifications. Subtle dot-like radiopaque particles projecting 6 cm caudal of the tibial head on the AP projection. Minimal linear calcifications projecting into the joint space. There is no evidence of traumatic bone injury. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Albuterol inhaler Flunisolide 250 mcg, two puffs bid Quinaglute 324 mg tid Flovent inhaler Foradil 12 mcg 1 inhaled bid Captopril 25 mg bid Crestor 40 mg daily Aspirin 325 mg daily Lasix 60 mg BID Spironolactone 25 mg daily Indomethacin 25 mg qid prn Metoprolol 25 mg bid Nasonex ___ mc 1 puff each nostril bid Nitro sublingual prn Verapamil 120 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 11. Albuterol 90 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: ___ Inhalation every six (6) hours as needed for shortness of breath or wheezing. 12. Flunisolide 250 mcg/Actuation Aerosol Sig: One (1) Inhalation twice a day. 13. Foradil Aerolizer 12 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device Sig: One (1) Inhalation twice a day. 14. Nasonex ___ mcg/Actuation Spray, Non-Aerosol Sig: One (1) Nasal twice a day. 15. Digoxin 125 mcg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 16. Oxygen 2L continuous 17. please provide tubing for oxygen <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnoses: Coronary artery disease, treated with Drug-eluting stent deployment in the left main and circumflex coronary arteries Acute on chronic left ventricular systolic and diastolic congestive heart failure Secondary Diagnoses: Gout Atrial fibrillation Supraventricular tachycardia Ventricular tachycardia Diabetes mellitus Prior lung cancer Asthma Hypoxemia Acute renal failure Mitral regurgitation <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable, afebrile, SBPs in ___, breathing comfortably on 2L O2. Desats to 84% on room air with ambulation. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for worsening shortness of breath. It was thought to be due to your heart. You had a catheterization that showed an artery that needed a stent. You had another catheterization in which the stent was placed, and then you were monitored in the intensive care unit while you had a balloon pump helping your blood pressure stay high. You continued to have low oxygen saturations while walking, dropping to 84% and will need to go home with oxygen. You did well post cath. You had a few arrhythmias, so the electrophysiologists saw you and helped us adjust your medicines. The following changes were made in your medications: your captopril was stopped and changed to a lower dose of a similar medication called lisinopril. Your metoprolol dose was increased to 100 mg daily. Your diuretic was doubled to 60 mg twice daily. Your quinidine was increased from three to four times daily (~ every 6 hours). You were also started on two new medications: clopidogrel 75 mg daily and digoxin 0.125 mg daily. You have been given prescriptions for these changes. You also developed knee pain which improved after a few doses of indomethacin. This may have been a gout attack, however, the indomethacin was stopped because it may interfere with aspirin. If your knee pain or other gout symptoms return, you should take a short course of a steroid medication called prednisone instead of indomethacin. You have been given a prescription for this should you need it. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight > 3 lbs. Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet. Please call your physician or return to the hospital if you develop worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, fevers, swelling in your feet, or other concerning symptoms.
target: ___ y/o man with H/O CAD, congestive systolic heart failure, and lung cancer with worsening dyspnea on exertion. History of numerous VT episodes on recent ICD interrogation. # CAD - Known severe coronary artery disease. Cardiac catheretizations this admission showed PCW 22 and LVEDP 26 mm Hg with preserved cardiac index. He had severe LMCA and three vessel disease with patent proximal left subclavian artery stent and patent LIMA-___. Abdominal aortography showed extensive aortic and iliac disease, precluding using of the Impella Assist Device. In consultation with Dr. ___ decision was made to proceed with high risk PCI of the protected LMCA with IABP support. This procedure was delayed for several hours due to arrhythmias (see below), but on ___, a Xience DES was placed in the LMCA into the circumflex artery with right femoral arteriotomy closure using the Mynx device and IABP secured in place in the left femoral artery. The patient was stable after the balloon pump was removed. He was continued on maximal medical management with aspirin, Plavix, metoprolol, and rosuvastatin. # Pump - Has severe chronic systolic and diastolic left ventricular heart failure with recent acute exacerabtion with recent EF of 25% and akinesis to dyskinesis of thinned inferior and infero-lateral walls with slightly dilated LV wall. Repeat echocardiogram here showed moderate eccentric mitral regurgitation, prompting the decision to revascularize the native circumflex in hopes of reducing papillary muscle ischemic dysfunction. His filling pressures were elevated at catheterization. Lasix and spironolactone were continued, and captopril was decreased then changed to low dose lisinopril due to hypotension. # Rhythm - Has a pacer and ICD. Patient did have VT upon interrogation of ICD prior to admission; unclear etiology for this, but likely secondary to ischemia. He had recurrent SVT during this admission with HRs into 160s, mostly asymptomatic with relatively low BPs which are now close to baseline. He was on an amiodarone drip for three days, but then switched back to quinidine, increased to QID instead of his prior dosing at TID. He triggered for atrial fibrillation with VR to 160 the night prior to discharge, however, he had not received his quinidine or metoprolol that evening. He was asymptomatic and his arrhythmia resolved after receiving these medications. He was evaluated by EP who felt that no further changes to his pacer/ICD settings were needed at this time. They may consider ablation in the future if recurrent VT is originating from a scar. He is not anticoagulated at this time. This can be considered in the future if atrial fibrillation returns. His dose of metoprolol was increased on this admission. # Dyspnea - The patient's dyspnea was likely multifactorial including past lobectomy, worsening heart failure, and asthma. He received ipratropium, fluticasone, salmeterol prn. The patient's dyspnea at rest resolved, however, he desaturated to 84% on room air with amublation the day prior to discharge and again on the of discharge, despite receiving extra Lasix. He was discharged to home with oxygen and pulmonary rehab. He has not previously had home oxygen. # Diabetes mellitus - The patient was placed on an insulin sliding scale with good blood sugar control. # Knee pain - A few days prior to discharge, the patient developed a painful right knee. The patient was afebrile and the knee was not warm. It was felt that his knee pain was most consistent with a gout flare. He was given indomethacin for 24 hours with resolution of his knee pain. This medication was discontinued due to its potential to interfere with the antiplatelet effects of aspirin. He was discharged with a prescription for a prednisone burst-taper in the event that his symptoms recur. # Mild Acute Renal Function - The patient had a creatinine elevated to 1.4 on admission, likely due to hypovolemia and poor foward flow from CHF. With pre-hydration prior to catheterization and judicious diuresis, his creatinine had returned to a baseline of 1.2 on the day of discharge.

target: ___ year old man with multiple CAD risk factors who presented to an OSH with his first episode of persistent chest pain with questionable unstable angina and a diffusely elevated PR interval throughout his ECG leads, but a normal ESR and CRP. He underwent a stress test ___ Protocol) which had some non-specific ST segment depression but no anginal symptoms. After the risk and benefits of a cardiac catheterization were discussed, he opted to forego a cath, and follow up with a cardiologist. Prior to discharge he was encouraged to stop drinking, and to quit smoking. He had a HgbA1c of 6.7 with an LDL of 85. Therefore, his statin dose was increased and he was placed on a beta blocker.

Secondary: CAD s/p CABG PAD renal artery stenosis, resolved stable ___ Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you. You were transferred to ___ with weakness, low blood pressure, and EKG changes. Given your history of coronary artery disease, this was concerning for a heart attack. Indeed, your bloodwork showed damage to you heart. We treated you with medications to optimize the management of your heart disease. However, you should followup with your cardiologist as you may need a repeat catheterization or stress test in the future. . You also presented to the hospital with new damage to your kidneys. A renal ultrasound did not show any obvious blockage or other damage. Your kidneys may have suffered damage when your blood pressure was low. This will take time to heal. . Finally, we discovered that your dose of thyroid medication, your dose of digoxin, and your dose of amiodarone needed to be adjusted. . We made several changes to your medication regimen: DECREASED amiodarone to 200mg daily (not twice daily) DECREASED levothyroxine to 12.5 mcg daily DECREASED digoxin to 0.125mg every M,W, and F HOLD Lisinopril until you see your doctor HOLD ___ until you see your doctor CHANGED omeprazole to pantoprazole (to minimize plavix interaction) CHANGED simvastatin to atorvastatin (to minimize amiodarone interaction) INCREASED Metoprolol to 50mg daily STARTED Metoclopramide . Please keep all of your followup appointments. Please take all of your medications as prescribed. If you experience any symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness, or other symptoms which concern you, please call your doctor or come to the ER.
target: ___ year old female with past medical history of CAD status-post CABG, mesenteric ischemia, duodenal ulcer, and ovarian cancer who presents with reported hypotension, nausea, vomiting, sharp abdominal pain and found to have new T wave inversions and elevated troponin, leukocytosis, renal insufficiency, and hyponatremia. # NSTEMI Troponin 0.64 on admission and trending down, CK flat, LDH (elevated at baseline) trending down. ECG showed new T-wave inversions. She was transferred on heparin and this was continued to complete 48 hours. She was angina-free on arrival here and throughout stay even with walking. She likely had MI prior even to admission to ___. Given that she was stable, angina-free, optimally medically managed and with renal insufficiency, we elected not to do catheterization. It may be worthwhile to pursue stress MIBI or cath in the future to determine if there are areas of myocardium that could be revascularized. # Leukocytosis: Likely reactive leukocytosis in setting of ischemia and no localizing symptoms and trended down. Cultures negative, no pneumonia on CXR and CDiff negative. It seems she also received a dose of salumedrol at ___ after a rash from Zosyn and this may have contributed though her WBC was 31 prior to this. Give baseline elevated LDH (could be from mesenteric ischemia but might expect elevated lactate) and high WBC count, would check WBC again as this could be MDS. # Acute kidney insufficiency: Unknown baseline. Did not improve significantly with hydration. Could be ATN from hypotension. Renal ultrasound negative for stent occlusion. Improving on discharge but will hold ACE. Would recommend restart once creatinine at baseline. # HTN: Held home lasix and ACE. Increased metoprolol to 100mg daily. # Hyponatremia: Likely hypovolemic hyponatremia and resolved with hydration. # Abdominal discomfort, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea: Chronic for her though worsened. Mesenteric ischemia vs dysmotility as s/p gastrectomy. Abdominal exam benign and pancreatic enzymes not elevated. Lactate not elevated. Much improved with metoclopramide and post-gastrectomy diet. # Suppressed TSH: Decreased levothyroxine to 12.5mcg. Recommend rechecking TFTs. # h/o atrial fibrillation. Patient in sinus rhythm throughout stay. Had been on amiodarone twice daily but decreased this to once daily. Digoxin level elevated on admission so this was held for several days and then restarted at 125mcg three times weekly. Continued metoprolol. # History of duodenal ulcer. GUIAIC negative. Continued BID PPI but switched to pantoprazole because of interaction with omeprazole. # Tobacco abuse. Patient was given nicotine patch # COPD: Stable. Continued spirvia # Anxiety: continued Ativan

RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. Normal interatrial septum. No ASD by 2D or color Doppler. No resting LVOT gradient. No VSD. RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion. AORTA: Normal aortic diameter at the sinus level. Normal ascending aorta diameter. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and global systolic function (LVEF>55%). The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *11* 2. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 3. lisinopril 10 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 4. metoprolol succinate 50 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet Extended Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *0* 5. fexofenadine 60 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day) as needed for allergy symptoms. 6. multivitamin Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 7. Ocuvite Oral 8. Crestor 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS ST elevation myocardial infarction . Secondary diagonosis: Hypertension Hyperlipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to the hospital because you were having chest pain. Your EKG and lab work showed that you had a heart attack, called myocardial infarction. You had 3 stents placed in the right artery of your heart to open this up and restore blood flow to your heart. You were started on new medications to help modify your risk for further heart disease. It is especially important for you to take aspirin and plavix daily for one year and possibly longer. Do not stop taking aspirin and plavix or miss any doses or the stent may clot off and cause another heart attack. You initially went to the ICU but you remained stable after the stents were placed and now you are ready to be discharged. You should follow-up with your doctors as ___ below. It is important to bring all your medications to each appointment so your doctors ___ update their records and adjust the doses as needed. The following changes were made to your medications: START TAKING THE FOLLOWING MEDS: - Aspirin 81 mg daily to keep the stent open and prevent another heart attack. - Plavix (clopidogrel) 75 mg daily to keep the stent open and prevent another heart attack. - Metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily to lower your heart rate - Increase rosuvastatin (Crestor) to 40 mg daily to lower your cholesterol . STOP TAKING THE FOLLOWING MEDS: -Celebrex- this medication is not good to take right after having a heart attack. If you need to take something for pain we recommend you take tylenol instead (maximum of 4g in one day) It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital!
target: PRINCIPLE REASON FOR ADMISSION Ms. ___ is a ___ year old female with hypertension (HTN), hyperlipidemia (HLD), osteoarthritis who presented with chest pressure found to be due to inferolateral ST elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), with persistent hypotension after balloon inflation requiring dopamine. She was weaned off the dopamine during the first 24 hours post-cath and remained stable hemodynamically and chest pain free. ACTIVE PROBLEMS # STEMI- ST elevation in III greater than II, with ST depression in I, aVL suggested that right coronary artery was the culprit lesion. The patient had 3 ___ placed in the RCA but still had LCx 80% ostial OM1, 80% mid circumflex which was not treated given her hypotension (see below). In the cath lab, she was started on intregrillin which was continued for 12 hours and then discontinued. Her post-intervention echo showed preserved LV ejection fraction (60%) and no focal wall motion abnormalities. -New Medications: -Aspirin 81mg qday -Plavix 75mg po qday -Atorvastatin 80mg po qday -F/u the patient continues to have stenosis of the LCx and need for intervention on this can be addressed at follow-up with Dr. ___ #Blood pressure control: While in the cath lab, the patient had hypotension after inflating the balloon in RCA. Her right heart cath had normal pressures so a temporary vagal response was the most likely etiology of her hypotension. She was started on dopamine drip in the cath lab. PCWP was 10, so slight hypovolemia may have contributed- patient received a total of 1200 cc normal saline and was able to wean off dopamine drip within the first 24 hours. She had no evidence of infection to suggest sepsis as an etiology of hypotension. Her blood pressure was stable on her home regimen: lisinopril 10 mg daily and metoprolol succinate 50 mg daily. # Hyperlipidemia-Changed rosuvastatin to atorvastatin 80 mg daily for better risk factor modification. Admission CK was 253, AST/ALT 36/20, lipid panel LDL 60, HDL 70, ___ 137. # Osteoarthritis- Used acetaminophen for pain control; held Celebrex due to possible interaction with coronary artery disease. # Right knee ___ cyst: She continued to have pain behind right knee and exam was consistent with ___ cyst. Ultrasound confirmed this. Advised her to use tylenol for pain control. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Will likely need intervention to left circumflex - monitor for side effects of medications including muscle aches from atorvastatin and bleeding - monitor symptoms of osteoarthritis and consider changing pain regimen as an outpatient

Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 5 ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 R 5 ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, temperature. no extinction to DSS. -DTRs: deferred -___: No dysmetria on FNF. -Gait: deferred <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 25AM BLOOD WBC-8.2 RBC-3.43* Hgb-10.1* Hct-31.1* MCV-91 MCH-29.4 MCHC-32.5 RDW-13.5 RDWSD-45.2 Plt ___ ___ 06: 35PM BLOOD WBC-11.3* RBC-3.37* Hgb-10.1* Hct-30.6* MCV-91 MCH-30.0 MCHC-33.0 RDW-13.7 RDWSD-45.4 Plt ___ ___ 06: 10AM BLOOD ___ PTT-24.9* ___ ___ 06: 35PM BLOOD ___ PTT-21.3* ___ ___ 06: 25AM BLOOD Glucose-127* UreaN-14 Creat-1.0 Na-137 K-3.7 Cl-99 HCO3-21* AnGap-17 ___ 06: 35PM BLOOD ALT-48* AST-81* AlkPhos-236* TotBili-1.1 ___ 06: 25AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-2.9 Mg-1.3* MRI head w/ w/o contrast ___ "IMPRESSION: 1. Early subacute infarct in the left posterior inferior cerebellar hemisphere, in the ___ territory, with central hemorrhagic transformation and thin peripheral contrast enhancement. 2. Stable left superior occipital/inferior parietal parenchymal hematoma demonstrates thin rim enhancement without nodularity and adjacent leptomeningeal hyperemia. Diagnostic considerations include another site of infarction with hemorrhagic transformation versus sequela of amyloid angiopathy, though no chronic hemorrhages related to amyloid angiopathy are identified. While no underlying mass is identified, evaluation for masses not definitive until the T1 hyperintense blood products resolve. RECOMMENDATION(S): Recommend follow up MRI after resolution of T1 hyperintense blood products to assess for expected evolution and resolution of contrast enhancement." CT head w/o contrast ___ "FINDINGS: There is an acute parietal occipital hematoma measuring approximately 3.5 cm in diameter. There is surrounding vasogenic edema. There is mass effect on the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle. There is likely an old left cerebellar hemispheric infarct, not well seen. Mucosal thickening is evident within the left maxillary sinus. Vascular calcification is noted. Mastoid air cells are clear.. The visualized portion of the orbits are unremarkable. IMPRESSION: 1. Parietal occipital hemorrhage compatible with the given clinical history. No prior studies are available for comparison. " CTA head neck ___ "IMPRESSION: 1. Left superior occipital/inferior parietal parenchymal hematoma with mild adjacent hyperemia, but no evidence for underlying arteriovenous malformation. Mild mass effect on the occipital horn of left lateral ventricle. No shift of midline structures. 2. Left posterior-inferior cerebellar territory infarct may be acute or subacute. 3. Mild atherosclerosis of the cervical carotid arteries without stenosis by NASCET criteria, and of the right vertebral artery origin without flow-limiting stenosis. 4. Mild narrowing of the proximal V4 segment of the left vertebral artery, and narrowing of bilateral distal V4 segments just proximal to the basilar origin, likely atherosclerotic. Left ___ is smaller than the right but patent. 5. Multiple pulmonary nodules ranging up to 8 mm in the right upper lobe partially visualized, relatively large left pleural effusion. 6. Fluid in the left maxillary sinus. Please correlate whether any infectious symptoms may be present. RECOMMENDATION(S): Consider dedicated chest imaging as clinically indicated. Smoking cessation counseling given? () Yes - (x) No [reason (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 4.
