(x) Yes - () No 5. Assessment for rehabilitation and/or rehab services considered? (x) Yes - () No <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Vitamin D 5000 UNIT PO DAILY 3. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 4. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 5. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO QPM 6. Warfarin 5 mg PO DAILY16 7. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 8. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO BID 9. traMADol 50 mg oral BID: PRN 10. Amiodarone 200 mg PO DAILY 11. Metoprolol Tartrate 75 mg PO TID <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS 1 TAB PO BID end date: ___ 2. Metoprolol Tartrate 50 mg PO TID 3. Amiodarone 200 mg PO DAILY 4. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 6. Gabapentin 300 mg PO TID 7. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY 8. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO BID 9. Rosuvastatin Calcium 10 mg PO QPM 10. Vitamin D 5000 UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> hemorrhagic stroke <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Confused - sometimes. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. With anomia, alexia, some agraphia as well. Possible R field cut. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of confusion, headache, speech change resulting from an ACUTE HEMORRHAGE, a condition where a bleed is found in the brain. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from irritation from blood can cause various symptoms. We think that the bleed you had may have been due to the fact you were on warfarin as well as aspirin and Plavix. There was also an ischemic stroke in your cerebellum, which could have been caused by a clot travelling from your heart. Because of your hemorrhagic stroke, you can no longer be on Coumadin for now, which you had been on for atrial fibrillation. This is because of the risk of further bleeding. This risk can be reassessed in the future. You need a repeat MRI in 2 months to assess how much the bleeding has reabsorbed and to look for an underlying lesion. Your stroke mainly affected your speech, specifically finding the right words for things and being able to read. Your ability to see the right side may also have been affected. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: high blood pressure coronary artery disease high cholesterol atrial fibrillation (for stroke) warfarin use (for hemorrhage) We are changing your medications as follows: stop warfarin stop Plavix temporarily (restart plavix on ___ Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please followup with Neurology and your primary care physician. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old man with HTN, HLD, and CAD as well as history of atrial fibrillation on Coumadin. On ___ he had been discharged from an OSH, on Plavix, lovenox bridge to warfarin following a BMS on ___ to the proximal circumflex artery. He presented to an OSH with headache, slurred speech, and confusion and was found to have a 3x3 cm left parietal intraparenchymal hemorrhage with surrounding edema but no midline shift and was transferred to ___ for further care. His examination is significant for an expressive aphasia, which improved while he was present. Initially his spontaneous speech was slow and sparse but improved. He continued to have anomia, which was improving, as well as alexia, and some degree of agraphia though not as pronounced as his degree of alexia. He may have had a R field cut. He also had right nasolabial fold flattening. Strength and coordination were normal. His MRI brain w/ and w/o contrast also showed a cerebellar ischemic infarct ___ territory). Etiology of bleed could be cardioembolic in the periprocedural setting, possibly during the procedure, as there were two areas in different vascular territories. It is possible that the L parietal IPH was hemorrhagic transformation of an ischemic infarct, in the setting of anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy for his afib and stent, although this less likely. It could also have been spontaneous in the setting of triple therapy, though that would not explain the cerebellar ischemic infarct, or a combination of the two. The IPH appears more likely to be primary. There was no evidence of microhemorrhages on gradient echo sequences to suggest CAA at this time. Cardiology was consulted for recommendations on antiplatelet therapy in the setting of IPH. They recommended that he be restarted on aspirin and then Plavix when safe from a neurological perspective. He was restarted on aspirin, as his bleed was felt to be stable. He can be restarted on Plavix 75 mg daily as well 7 days post bleed, on ___. He will need to be re-evaluated in the future before it can be determined if it is safe for systemic anticoagulation. Cardiology had suggested that he be switched to coumadin and Plavix in the future, if safe for anticoagulation. He was evaluated by ___ who recommended rehab, which he was discharged to. His IPH was stable on repeat imaging. An Echo was not done because it was not felt that it would change management. UOP was initially low but resolved with fluids. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES IPH: Can restart Plavix for stent on ___ from bleed perspective. Outpatient MRI brain in ___ months prior to stroke appointment. Follow up in stroke clinic. Determine need/safety for systemic anticoagulation in ___. CAD s/p BMS ___ at OSH: Continue aspirin 81 mg daily. RESTART Plavix 75 mg daily on ___. Should be on ASA/Plavix for at least 1 month. Switch to coumadin/Plavix in the future if safe for anticoagulation from IPH perspective, per cardiology. AFib - home metoprolol was reduced to 50 mg TID initially, this can be titrated up to 75 mg TID (which he had been on) as required by his heart rates Urinary retention, low urine output: he had a foley which was discontinued on the morning of discharge. He was undergoing void trial. The foley can be replaced and void trials continued as required by his clinical status. complicated UTI - he had an abnormal UA with 51 WBCs, moderate ___, and was started on Bactrim DS 1 tab BID. Urine culture did not grow anything, so this was discontinued. Multiple predominantly peripheral pulmonary nodules ranging up to 8 mm in diameter - incidentally seen on CTA h/n. Consider further evaluation with CT chest as clinically indicated as an outpatient. He did not have any pulmonary issues while hospitalized. Transaminitis--attributed to known history of cirrhosis CRP elevated in the setting of hemorrhage and infarct. Repeat as outpatient. PCP ___

Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Respirations were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No clubbing, cyanosis or edema. No femoral bruits. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. Median sternotomy wires are again seen. Cardiac and mediastinal contours appear relatively unchanged. No focal consolidations are seen within the lungs. Pulmonary vascularity appears within normal limits. No large effusion identified. Clips again seen projecting over the right abdomen suggesting prior cholecystectomy. No evidence of acute cardiopulmonary process. ECG ___: Sinus rhythm with intermittent atrial pacing. First degree A-V delay. Right bundle branch block. Early precordial QRS transition. Precordial lead ST-T wave changes may be in part primary. These findings are nonspecific but clinical correlation is suggested. Since previous tracing of ___, further ST-T wave changes present. Stress test ___: This ___ y/o man with a htx of CAD (s/p cabg X 4, 98, cath 99, pacer implant 05) was referred to the lab for evaluation of an atypical chest pain four weeks after his most recent Exercise MIBI. The patient exercised for 7 minutes of a Gervino protocol and was stopped for fatigue ___ METS). Limited functional capacity. The patient was asymptomatic throughout. Lungs were clear bilaterally to auscultation. The rhythm was AV paced with intermittent sinus beats, frequent isolated VPBS, episodic V. trigeminy and rare isolated APBS. In the setting of complete RBBB, with accompaning ST abnormalities and intermittent AV pacing, the EKG is rendered uninterpretable for myocardial ischemia. Appropriate hemodynamic response to physiologic stress in the setting of beta blockade therapy IMPRESSION: Uninterpretable EKG for myocardial ischemia. No anginal symptoms. Moderate grade VEA. Echo report sent separately. Imaging: Resting images were acquired at a heart rate of 52 bpm and a blood pressure of 138/72 mmHg. These demonstrated normal regional and global left ventricular systolic function (basal inferioir wall not well visualized). Doppler demonstrated mild aortic regurgitation with no aortic stenosis or significant mitral regurgitation or resting LVOT gradient. Echo images were acquired within 79 seconds after peak stress at heart rates of 90-71 bpm. These demonstrated appropriate augmentation of all left ventricular segments. IMPRESSION: Limited functional exercise capacity. No 2D echocardiographic evidence of inducible ischemia to achieved workload. Normal hemodynamic response to exercise. Mild aortic regurgitation at rest. Limited study - target HR not achieved and suboptimal post-stress images. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Toprol 25 mg daily ASA 81 mg daily Zantac 150 mg daily HCTZ 12.5 mg daily MVI <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 2. Toprol XL 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO once a day. 3. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 4. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO DAILY (Daily). 5. Multivitamin Injectable Sig: One (1) ML Intravenous ONCE (Once) for 1 doses. 6. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Sublingual prn as needed for chest pain. 7. Simethicone 60 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO every ___ hours as needed for gas pain. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> - Chest pain without biomarker evidence of infarction or evidence of ischemia on stress echocardiogram - Coronary artery disease, S/P coronary artery bypass surgery and prior infarcts - Second degree heart block, S/P permanent pacemaker - Abdominal aortic aneurysm, 5 cm, infrarenal s/p endovascular repair ___ - Hypertension - Dyslipidemia - Urinary incontinence <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Stable, without Chest Pain <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted into ___ for evaluation of your chest discomfort. You did not have a heart attack. You were taken for a Stress Echocardiogram for further evaluation given your history of heart disease. This test did not show major change to your heart function. Your chest pains may have been some angina but could also be related to stomach upset. Please continue with your Zantac 150mg daily for relief. You may also take Simethicone (GasX) over the counter tablets for gas relief. Please continue with your remaining medications as instructed. Please attend all follow up listed below. Please call your PCP or go to the emergency room if you have fevers >101, chills, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other symptoms which are concerning to you.
target: ___ year old male with PMH of CAD s/p CABG ___, IMI ___, NSTEMI ___, PPM ___, endovascular AAA repair ___ presenting with intermittent chest pain atypical for angina or cardiac source, most likely due to gas pains. # CAD - Patient has a history of severe CAD and now presents with atypical chest pain. Per ED report, patient had new TWI in V3-4. There was no biomarker evidence of infarction. He had a few episodes of chest pain two nights ago but is currently chest pain free with no subsequent episodes. Pain is likely from GI discomfort/gas pain. However, he was sent for stress echo for evaluation given his strong history of CAD. This showed no evidence of inducible ischemia. He is to continue on his ASA 325mg daily and Metoprolol 12.5mg BID for his CAD. He cannot take statins due to allergy. Mr. ___ was told to take Simethicone 60mg every ___ hours for treatment of his gas pain. He was also continued on his home Ranitidine. # Pump - Patient with no history of CHF, last ECHO per Dr. ___ at ___ showed LVEF of 60%. Stress ECHO here showed EF 55-60%. # Rhythm - Patient currently AV paced, s/p PPM in ___. # Hypertension - He is to continue on his home metoprolol, HCTZ. # Lupus Anticoagulant - patient with history of circulating Lupus Anticoagulant per Dr. ___. No signs of clotting on history or exam while in the hospital. He was kept on Heparin SQ during his stay. # AAA s/p Repair ___ - Mr. ___ has no signs of pulsatile mass on exam. # Incontinence - Patient with two year history of incontinence, wears a condom cath at home. Patient to continue with condom cath at home.

target: Patient is a ___ y/o male with a PMH significant for CAD, hyptension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia, A.fib on coumadin, who presents from ___ for cardiac catheterization after and episode of chest pain who ruled in for an NSTEMI. He was admitted to ___ on ___ and underwent cardiac catheterization on ___. His post-catheterization course was complicated by a R groin cellulitis and L groin hematoma. On ___ he was discharged to a rehab facility in good condition, ambulatory, with stable vital signs, with appropriate outpatient follow-up arranged. His hospital course was notable for: . #. CAD/NSTEMI: Patient with known CAD ruled in for an NSTEMI at ___ was transferred for cardiac catheterization. Patient is s/p cath on ___ where they were able to POBA a lesion in his circ but unable to place a stent. He reported that he continued to have daily chest pain, that was identical to his CP at home, that improves with ___ SL nitros. Recently Ranexa was added for increased anti-anginal effect. He was continued on atorvastatin, aspirin, and discharged with outpatient follow-up scheduled for ___ with his cardiologist Dr. ___. . #.Left Groin Hematoma: Pt was noted to have a L groin hematoma after catheterization. He underwent an u/s examination to rule out AV fistula, which was negative for AV fistula and pseudoanuerysm. . #. Pump: no echo in our system, BNP mildly elevated at 518 at ___, but with initial volume overload on exam that appeared consistent with acute diastolic heart failure, now volume status is improved, right heart cath with PCWP of 15, now appears consistent with chronic diastolic HF . #. Rhythm: patient with known A.fib on coumadin as an outpatient, currently rate controlled on outpatient regimen of metoprolol 50mg TID, on heparin gtt while not on coumadin --patient needs to be bridged in the setting of having a prior stroke while off coumadin, has taken lovenox in the past will look into outpatient lovenox bridge to coumadin --monitor on telemetry --continue coumadin . #. Right Groin Erythema: exam consistent with cellulitis, ultrasound shows 8.4cm hematoma which has decreased in size from prior. Started on vancomycin, has been afebrile with normal white count. Pt received a PICC line on ___. He is being discharged with prescriptions for Vancomycin and Ciprofloxacin and scheduled to complete a two week course. The last dose of each medicine will be administered on 750 mg q24h. . #. History of AVR: Pt was discharged on home outpatient Coumadin regimen . #. Diabetes: patient currently being managed on metformin as an outpatient, will hold metformin and continue prior insulin sliding scale . #. Hypertension: continue outpatient metoprolol and Imdur. Valsartan was d/c during this hospitalization. . #. Chronic Renal Insufficiency: creatinine increased to 1.7 during this hospitalization. At the time of discharge, creatinine had decreased to 1.6. His creatinine should be followed and trended as an outpatient. . On ___, the Pt was discharged to a rehab facility in good condition, ambulatory, with stable vital signs.

He said that beginning last night at 2am, he woke up and felt faint. He checked his BP which was 165/95. He said he was also bradycardic to 52-54, not in atrial fibrillation. He felt that he was becoming dehydrated. This morning he woke up at 7: 30 with a HA, and then while lying in bed developed ___ chest pressure. He did not take any nitroglycerin as he says this does not work for his pain. He drove to the ED, and walking from his car to the ED, he said he was SOB and had to stop and sit down. . The CP then resolved, but reoccured, and was given 2mg IV Morphine x1. CXR prelim read was normal. He was also given 1L NS. On transfer, VS were BP 147/78 HR 54 RR 11 O2 sat 100% RA. . On the floors, his chest pressure has resolved. He was having some abdominal discomfort, which he thought may be gas, in the mid-abdomen, dull, non-radiating. Denies nausea or vomiting. . target: ___ yo M w/ CAD (see below, multiple PCIs), HTN, HL, Afib not on coumadin, pericarditis and cardiac fibrosis, mitochondrial myopathy, orthostatic intolerance and multiple recent admission for weakness, nausea, dehydration, presents with chest pressure similar to prior MI. . # CORONARIES: Presenting with chest pressure similar to previous MI, concerning for UA vs. NSTEMI vs. demand angina ___ dehydration vs. arrhythmia vs. PE. EKG in ED reported as having showed ST depressions in V4-V6, apparently new (though unable to locate that ECG as did not come up in chart). Repeat EKG while patient was CP free was not checked in the ED. NSTEMI less likely given that first troponins negative. Repeat EKG on floors while chest pain free showed no ST depression in leads V4-V6, and was sinus. He has had multiple admissions for nausea, chest pressure with dehydration. Orthostatic on admission with BP drop of 60 pts systolic, making dehydration and demand angina more likely. PE thought to be unlikely given no tachycardia, no pleuritic CP, no hypoxia, and no evidence on EKG. Arrhythmia associated with CP also possible, but in sinus bradycardia to high 50's, without events on telemetry. Troponins were negative x3. His repeat EKG was sinus bradycardia, unchanged. He was continued on home dose of ASA 325mg daily, Plavix 75mg daily. Lipids checked with LDL 61, TSH was 1.3, and A1c of 5.8. He was given aggressive fluid of 5L and symptoms completely resolved. He was continued on valsartan 80 bid, metoprolol succ 25 mg bid. Continued on antianginal Ranexa 500mg po bid (pt stated that Imdur previously has cause hypotension). On the day of discharge, his chest pressure had completely resolved. He was instructed to ___ with his cardiologist, Dr. ___ as an outpatient. He was also encouraged to increase his po intake and liberalize his salt diet given orthostasis. He was encouraged to use compression stockings as well. . # PUMP: Last Echo from ___ here shows EF of 55-60%. Stress from ___ showed EF 52%. Pt appeared dry on admission exam. No evidence of fluid overload. Continued on home regimen of Metoprolol succinate 25mg bid and Valsartan 80mg bid. . # RHYTHM: Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, on ASA 162mg bid and plavix. CHADS score 1 for HTN. Has been considered by ___ in ___ for Reveal device. No events on telemetry, and remained in sinus. Continued on metoprolol succ as above, ASA 325mg daily and Plavix. . #Orthostatic hypotension: As above, was quite orthostatic during this admission. He has been seen by neurology previously in the autonomics department. We spoke with his autonomics physicians, who were very helpful stating that he will always be orthostatic given his dysautonomia. On the day of discharge, he was orthostatic, but asymptomatic without lightheadedness and ambulating well. As above, advised to increase his po intake and liberalize his salt diet given orthostasis. He was encouraged to use compression stockings as well. He was scheduled to ___ with autonomics as an outpatient. . # Abdominal pain: Differential included appendicitis vs. diverticulitis vs. hepatitis. LFT's, lipase were normal, pt remained afebrile, and exam was benign after passed gas. Treated with home Nexium, maalox and simethicone. He stated that he had abdominal pain in RLQ previously for several months and had CT that showed diverticulosis but no other findings (did not have these records). He was afebrile, and pain resolved on its own without further intervention. He was completely pain free on the day of discharge. . # CKD, renal cysts: Baseline Cr 1.3-1.4; Admitted at baseline with Cr 1.4 on admission. He was given IVF as above, and his creatinine was 1.4 on day of discharge. . # HTN: Hypertensive on admission but orthostatic. Per outside hospital records and per outside cardiologist, is frequently hypertensive, but always orthostatic and borderline bradycardic, limiting his regimen. His BP improved, and his medications were unchanged. He was normotensive on the day of discharge. . # Hyperlipidemia: Lipids last documented here in ___ with LDL 52. Rechecked with LDL 61, continued on home Lipitor 20mg daily and ezetimibe 10mg daily. . # GERD: Continued on Nexium. . # CODE: FULL . LABS/STUDIES PENDING ON DAY OF DISCHARGE: none . ___: 1. Dr. ___ for ___. 2. Dr. ___ Dr. ___ autonomics ___ in 1 month from previous visit. Spoke with Dr. ___ stated that she had spoken with him at her previous visit on ___ and outlined a plan including increased water and salt intake, BP monitoring, and to schedule ___ in one month. 3. PCP, ___. Currently scheduled for ___, with no openings per HCA at the time of discharge. Dr. ___ was emailed, and we will attempt to get an earlier appt given the patient's frequent admissions.

The patient presented with complaints of three hours of ___ chest pain with radiation to his left arm. He had associated nausea and SOB. He called his PCP who instructed him to go to the ED. His previous presentation prior to his last cath was of increasing dyspena on exertion. He denied having a history of chest pain. . In the ED, initial vitals were T 96.4, HR 96, BP 199/117, RR 20, O2 98%. ECG demonstrated ST elevations I, II, AVL, V2-V6 with ST depressions AVR. He was given Clopidogrel 600mg, Metoprolol 5mg IV, Nitroglycerin SL and gtt started, ASA 81mg, Morphine 2mg IV and Eptifibatide gtt was started. CK 302 with troponin 0.14. He was taken emergently to the cardiac cath lab. . At cath he was found to have 100% proximal stent thrombosis of the LAD. LCx and RCA were normal. He underent thrombectomy and PTCA of the stent with good result except for a residual cutoff to the distal diagnoal. He was given a loading dose of plavix 600 mg and continued on the eptifibatide gtt and nitro gtts. He was also given 3 200 mcg boluses of nicardipine. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He admits to awakening occasionally with about an hour of subjective fevers/chills, but has had no persistent fevers. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Anterolateral myocardial infarction with ST-T wave configuration consistent with acute process. ___ CCATH: COMMENTS: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated single vessel coronary disease. The LMCA, LCx, and RCA were without angiographically apparent disease. The LAD had 100% proximal in-stent thrombosis. 2. Limited resting hemodyanmics revealed systemic arterial normotension. 3. Sucecssful percutaneous thrombectomy (utilizing the Export catheter), and serial PTCA of the proximal LAD thrombotic occlusion with 3.5, 4.0 and 4.5 mm balloons. Final angiography showed an excellent result in the treated lesion with no residual stenoses, residual thrombus or flow-limiting dissection. TIMI 3 flow was evident throughout the LAD system with a cut off (emboli) to the distal diagonal branch. 4. IVUS of the proximal LAD (including the old stent and the whole segment), showed an MLD of 4.___pposed stent without residual thrombus or dissection. 5. Successful deployment of a ___ Angioseal to the RCFA. 6. Due to the patient's body habitus, access was moderately difficult advancing the J wire retrogradely, requiring Magic Torque wire. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Single vessel coronary artery disease with ST elevation MI from acute thrombotic occlusion of the proximal LAD consistent with very-late stent thrombosis. 2. Percutaneous thrombectomy of the thrombotic proximal LAD lesion with Export catheter. 3. Sucecssful PTCA of the proximal LAD lesion (including the stent) with 3.5, 4.0, and 4.5 mm balloons with excellent final result. 4. IVUS of the proximal LAD showed excellent PTCA result. 5. Successful closure of the RCFA with ___ Angioseal. 6. Embolic occlusion of the distal diagonal . Monitor renal function and switch to renal dose if GFR < 50. 7. Prasugrel (Not Plavix) starting in AM with 60 mg bolus then 10 mg daily. 8. Complete smoking cessation, weight loss (minimum of 10% of current weight), and best medical management for secondary prevention (target BP < 130/80, LDL <70, HDL>45, ___. ___ TTE: The left atrium is elongated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the anterior wall, septum and apex. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = ___. Anterior wall and septum appear slightly edematous, suggesting a recent MI. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is a very small pericardial effusion. The effusion appears circumferential. IMPRESSION: Severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, c/w recent LAD-territory myocardial infaction. The clot was removed and there is now good blood flow through the stent. You will need to restart your plavix to protect your heart. Your heart is also weak after the heart attack. this increases your risk of blood clots. You will need to inject lovenox twice daily to keep your blood thin and take couamdin for at least a few months until your heart function improves. Dr. ___ will monitor your labs and tell you when you can stop taking the injections. You are also at risk for fluid retention because of your heart fucntion. This is the most important thing you can do for your health.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year-old male with pmh of hypertension, HL, CAD s/p bare metal stent in ___ admitted with a STEMI secondary to an instent thrombosis s/p thrombectomy. #. CORONARIES/STEMI: The patient presented with chest pain and STE in V2-V6, I, II, aVL. Cardiac catheterization showed instent thrombosis of the proximal LAD bare metal stent (previously placed around ___ years prior). He had the thrombosis removed and was admitted to the CCU. The patient was initially plavix loaded and was given integrillin and was continued on aspirin, simvastatin, nitroglycerin gtt. The patient was soon started on metoprolol tartrate for blood pressure and heart rate control. Initially the plan was to start prasugrel, however, the patient was unable to attain the medication at a pharmacy near his house. Thus, he was started on plavix 150mg daily. An ACE inhibitor was also added. The patient had a TTE which showed apical akinesis and a depressed ejection fraction. He was started on warfarin and lovenox ___ BID. He was counselled on smoking cessation. He was discharged with follow up with Dr. ___. #. Decrease ejection fraction: The patient was started on ACE inhibitor and metoprolol tartrate as described above. The patient will follow up with Dr. ___ as an outpatient. #. Hypertension: The patient was continued on lisinopril 20mg BID and started on metoprolol succinate 50mg daily. He had good blood pressure control as an inpatient. #. Diabetes Type II: The patient was started on an insulin sliding scale. He was switched back to his oral medications as an outpatient. #. Anxiety: The patient presented and was very anxious. He denies history of alcohol abuse. It is likely related to nicotine withdrawal. He was given nicotine patch and nicorette gum prn for withdrawal sypmtoms.

Moderate-to-severe canal stenosis between C3 and C6 (severe at C5-C6) due to a combination of disc herniation and posterior longitudinal ligament thickening. Cord demonstrates associated myelomalacia, without superimposed acute abnormalities. 3. Multilevel neural foraminal narrowing, particularly on the left. Echo ___: Mild spontaneous echo contrast is seen in the body of the left atrium. No mass/thrombus is seen in the left atrium or left atrial appendage. Mild spontaneous echo contrast is present in the left atrial appendage. The left atrial appendage emptying velocity is depressed (<0.2m/s). Mild spontaneous echo contrast is seen in the body of the right atrium. No mass or thrombus is seen in the right atrium or right atrial appendage. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Global left ventricular systolic function appears groslly preserved There are complex (>4mm) atheroma in the descending thoracic aorta and aortic arch. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present and appears well-seated. The prosthetic aortic valve leaflets appear normal The aortic valve prosthesis leaflets appear to move normally. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: No intracardiac thrombus. Mild spontaneous echo contrast and left and right atrium. Normally functioning bioprosthetic aortic valve. Mild mitral regurgitation. Complex, non-mobile plaque in the thoracic aorta. Echo ___: The left atrium is mildly dilated. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior and infero-lateral akinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The diameters of aorta at the sinus, ascending and arch levels are normal. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present. The aortic valve prosthesis appears well seated, with normal leaflet/disc motion and transvalvular gradients. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the LVEF has decreased. The RV is probably similar. If indicated, a cardiac MRI may more accurately assess LVEF. EKG on admission ___: Underlying atrial mechanism not certain with differential diagnosis including atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter variant versus atrial tachycardia with variable block. Right bundle-branch block with left axis deviation consistent with left anterior fascicular block. Underlying inferior Q wave myocardial infarction. Single ventricular premature beat is also present. Non-specific ST-T wave change with slight QTc interval prolongation. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ atrial tachy-arrhythmia is new. Clinical correlation is suggested. EKG ___: Sinus rhythm. Right bundle-branch block with left anterior fascicular block. Prior inferior myocardial infarction. Outpatient Lab Work Please check Chem-7 and CBC on ___ and call results to Dr. ___ at ___ thanks <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Acute on chronic Systolic congestive Heart Failure Atrial Fibrillation Non ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction Upper and Lower GI Bleed Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had chest pain and was admitted to ___ with a heart attack. You were transferred to ___ and had a fainting episode in the bathroom. You were in an irregular heart rhythm, atrial fibillation, that was converted to a normal rhythm with an electrical cardioversion. You will need to have your heart rhythm checked regularly now. We started an anticoagulation pill called coumadin to prevent strokes from the atrial fibrillation and you developed a bleed somewhere in your GI tract. We were unable to localize the bleeding using a scope in your stomach and lower colon. It is very important that you follow a diabetic and low salt diet. This will prevent your blood sugars from being high and prevent the fluid from reaccumulating. Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ if weight goes up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days. Your weight at discharge is 184 pounds. Please make an appt with your diabetes doctor soon to review your diet and insulin requirements. We were unable to perform a cardiac catheterization during this hospital stay because of your kidney function worsened. . We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. Increase Metoprolol to 150 mg daily 2. Increase Omeprazole to 40 mg twice daily 3. Increase aspirin to 325 mg daily
target: ___ male with history of CAD s/p CABG x 2 who presents from OSH with NSTEMI. Transferred to the CCU s/p syncopal event. . # Syncope: His transfer to the CCU was initiated because of a syncopal episode. Possible etiologies included vasovagal episode (he was baring down in the bathroom at the time), arrhythmia given his a-flutter/a-fib and sigificant cardiac history. He was not on tele at the time of the event, and he was found down, pulseless in the bathroom. Compressions were initiated and he quickly regained consciousness, and was lucid. He was not confused, and had no evidence of seizure activity. In the CCU, tele showed a-fib with RVR and was uptitrated to 75 TID of metoprolol tartrate and then initiated on a diltiazem drip. His rate slowed, but he remained in a-fib. He was put on a heparin drip and started on coumadin for a CHADS2 score of 3. He was DC cardioverted and remained in NSR through discharge. Of note, his anticoagulation was stopped in-house in the setting of developing LGIB (see below), and was discharged on beta blocker but no coumadin. He will require follow up for reassessment of his need for coumadin given his recent bleed. . # NSTEMI: Pt was first seen at ___ with 2 days of chest pain and was noted to have a positive troponin-I of 2.92. His troponin-T in the ___ ED was 1.05, prior troponins in ___ ranged from 0.05->0.23 in the setting of his renal dysfunction. His troponins remained elevated in the 1's but his CK decreased and his CK-MB were normal. He also had renal dysfunction, likely contributing to his poor clearance of troponins. In the setting of his renal function, cath was deferred, but may be considered in the future. He was d/c'd on beta blocker (metoprolol succinate increased to 150mg daily from home dose of 100mg), asa, satin. . #LGIB: Pt noted to have Guaiac positive stools and occasional BRBPR. His Hct was noted to drop from 33.5-->26.5 over the course of 1 day and received a total of 1 U PRBC with good response. Pt had both upper endoscopy and colonoscopy which was only significant for antral erosisons but no obvious source of bleed. His anticoagulation was held and he was continued on PPI which was increased to BID on discharge. After endoscopy, he had no further signs of bleeding and hct stable at ___. H pylori was negative. He was set up with GI follow up. . #Acute on chronic systolic Congestive Heart Failure: Pt with echo in-house showing worsening LVEF to 40% compared to prior echo. He was noted to be volume overloaded in house requiring diuresis with metolazone and toresemide, along with home dose of spironalactone. Over the course of his CCU and floor stay he diuresed well and became more euvolemic after transfer back to the floor. He was discharged on a regimen of torsemide 60 mg daily, with instructions to take an additional 40mg as needed, as well as home spironalactone of 25 mg daily. He was told to follow up with Dr. ___ in heart failure clinic. . # Fever/leukocytosis: He spiked a fever overnight on the night of his transfer to the CCU to ___. He had pan cultures taken (blood, urine, sputum) and a chest x-ray was done, but no focal source was identified. Antibiotics were initially held in the setting of a lack of source/bug, and given his hemodynamic stability. Given the presentation of malaise and myalgias it was thought that he had a viral syndrome. . # Hypoxia: He was hypoxic to the the high 80's on NRB initially on transfer to the CCU, and was able to be weaned without intervention to 2L NC and maintained sats in the low to mid ___. PE was considered as well as CHF exacerbation, ACS, hypoventilation, methemoglobinemia, and COPD. Because of his normal ABG and his normal methemoglobin, as well as his downtrending CK-MBs he was thought to be overloaded. He had been in a-fib with RVR, with likely poor forward flow. He had increased crackles on exam and required diuresis with good improvement in his respiratory status. . # CKD: Patient has stage III CKD thought to be secondary to CHF. He is followed by Dr. ___ as an outpatient. Creatinine at baseline on arrival (1.7) and increased likely secondary to poor forward flow to as high as 2.3. He was continued on home spironalactone, torsemide, and metolazone, and his Cr improved to 1.8 on discharge . # DM II: He was continued on his home regimen of Lantus BID (40qAM, 50qPM) and ISS. . # Hypothyroidism: Continued on Levothyroxine 280mcg qAM. TSH was WNL. . # Depression: Continued on home sertraline

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> Crestor / atorvastatin <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Bilateral lower extremity weakness, slurred speech and confusion <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ RHM who presents to the ED with resolving bilateral lower extremity weakness, slurred speech and confusion on a background of stroke, severe vasculopathy, poorly treated DM, HTN, HL, right CEA, paroxysmal afib. He was recently admitted to ___ (___) for chest pain and shortness of breath and underwent Cardiac cath that showed extensive and worsening coronary disease. CABG was considered but he was not thought to be a good candidate for either CABG or "high-risk stenting". It was decided that he would be managed medically with aspirin/plavix and statin. Since discharge he has continued to require sublingual nitro every ___ days for chest pain (he reports good and prompt benefit). Otherwise he has been roughly at his baseline with intermittent and fluctuating swelling in his legs. He does report increased tremors in his hands. Perhaps 2 days ago, he noted weakness in both legs but mostly on the right. He states that he sometimes notices swelling and tingling in his lower extremities but that his legs have never felt weak like this beforehand. He felt weak in his proximal lower extremities but NOT the feet and noted that he had significant difficulty walking and needed to brace himself on stationary objects. He denies vertigo or imbalance or lightheadedness. He denies falls or increased back pain. He denies sensory changes (other than mild chronic tingling associated with leg swelling) He acknowledges some degree of discomfort in the legs during this time but is adamant (despite documented call-in to cardiology on ___ in ___) that he did NOT have leg cramps or pain and that he stopped the statin because of GI upset. His narrative at this point is slightly inconsistent as he at times both denies pain but also states that he stopped the medication (simvastatin) because of pain and stiffness in his legs. At any rate, the next day he continued to have difficulty ambulating and spent most of the day on the couch hoping he would improve after stopping the statin. Despite his disability, he was able to make it to the bathroom on his own without walker/cane or assistance from family members. He denies changes in urinary/bowel function during this time or saddle anesthesia. He has a prior history of adverse side-effects from statins (crestor ,lipitor), noting significant myalgias (back pain and stiffness). He reports that these myalgias were different than his current discomfort. He denies any symptoms whatsoever in his upper extremities. Earlier today, his daughter called him at 1pm to visit and he appeared to exhibit strange behavior over the phone. She noted that he was repeating himself and seemed slightly confused and "slow" with notable latency in answering her questions. He also appeared to have slurred speech -but no paraphasic errors noted and he was generally able to understand her. He apparently had not had anything to eat at this point in the day day and, given that he is a diabetic on insulin, there was some concern that his sugar might be low (he did not use his glucometer at this point). She told him to eat and went over to see him and by this point he had had 3 packets of cheese and crackers and his confusion/slurred speech seemed to have improved. His BG at this point was >300mg/dl. However he continued to exhibit difficulty walking on his own and there was concern for stroke and he was brought in to the ED. By the time of his arrival at ___, his confusion had improved and his cognitive abilities had pretty much returned to baseline. His lower extremity weakness had also improved to some degree but his gait remained, by his account, quite impaired. He has a history of a stroke/"TIA" ___ years prior which presented as left facial droop (could not remember if arm was involved as well) he reports no lingering deficits from this one event (only known stroke). Of note, he also was told to hold his aspirin/plavix for several days last week in the setting of a dental appointment after which he restarted both these medications. He has otherwise been compliant and there were no other changes to his medication (other than stopping the statin). On ROS, he states that he has had fluctuating facial numbness on the left side of his face "on and off for the past few years". He also endorses relatively frequent headaches that have increased in frequency over the last few weeks. He does not report any fever, chills or other signs/symptoms of infection. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: +Dyslipidemia, +Hypertension, +Diabetes (A1c 9.60 on ___ 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - CABG: None - PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: None - PACING/ICD: None 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: CVA ___ years ago CAD (per report): In terms of his coronary artery disease, he underwent cardiac catheterization, I believe, at ___ ___ in ___, which showed moderate left main disease, significant circumflex disease and an occluded right coronary artery with an ejection fraction of 45%. They recommended bypass surgery in addition to the carotid endarterectomy, but after consultation with us, he eventually just underwent carotid endarterectomy and continued on medical therapy for his coronary disease. ?___: Per report ejection fraction of 45% but no evidence of echo that I can find. PVD s/p back surgery s/p resection of aortic aneurysm ___ s/p left subclavian stenting ___ s/p bifemoral bypass surgery ___ s/p right CEA ___ s/p mesenteric stenting in ___ s/p renal artery stenting ___ Significant PAD of right upper extremity Appendectomy 1970s Cholecystectomy 1970s <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Unclear of his parents medical history -- he has children who are alive and well - no CAD, no hypertension, no hyperlipidemia <PHYSICAL EXAM> Discharge <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 97.5 152/76 63 18 96%RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: CTABL Cardiac: RRR, no murmurs Abdomen: soft, nontender, nondistended Extremities: no edema, pulses palpated Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x 3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Normal prosody. There were no paraphasic errors. Pt. was able to name both high and low frequency objects. Able to read without difficulty. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Pt. was able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 5 minutes. The pt. had good knowledge of current events. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: I: Olfaction not tested. II: PERRL 3 to 2mm, both directly and consentually; brisk bilaterally. VFF to finger counting. III, IV, VI: EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch, pinprick in all distributions, and ___ strength noted bilateral in masseter VII: No facial droop, facial musculature symmetric and ___ strength in upper and lower distributions, bilaterally VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline, and is equal ___ strength bilaterally as evidenced by tongue-in-cheek testing. -Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. Postural tremor worse on the left than right (chronic) No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L ___ ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 R ___ ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 -DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2 2 2 1 0 R 2 2 2 1 0 Toes: withdrawal bilaterally -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation, vibratory sense, proprioception throughout. except for mild patchy pinprick loss over the lateral right lower ext. No extinction to DSS. -Coordination: intention tremor but no dysdiadochokinesia or clear dysmetria on FNF or HTS or dysrhythmia noted on rapid tapping. -Gait: Romberg negative, Slightly wide-based, tentative steps with stiff lower extremities with decreased arm swing. Able to stand on toes and heels, able to squat down and hold that position and come back up under his own power. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 04: 50PM ___ PTT-36.5 ___ ___ 04: 50PM PLT COUNT-177 ___ 04: 50PM WBC-6.3 RBC-4.03* HGB-12.7* HCT-38.3* MCV-95 MCH-31.5 MCHC-33.1 RDW-13.9 ___ 04: 50PM UREA N-29* ___ 05: 00PM GLUCOSE-232* NA+-144 K+-4.0 CL--100 TCO2-26 ___ 05: 02PM estGFR-Using this ___ 05: 02PM CREAT-2.0* ___ 08: 02PM URINE MUCOUS-RARE ___ 08: 02PM URINE HYALINE-1* ___ 08: 02PM URINE RBC-1 WBC-0 BACTERIA-NONE YEAST-NONE EPI-<1 ___ 08: 02PM URINE BLOOD-NEG NITRITE-NEG PROTEIN-100 GLUCOSE-300 KETONE-TR BILIRUBIN-NEG UROBILNGN-2* PH-6.5 LEUK-NEG ___ 08: 02PM URINE COLOR-Yellow APPEAR-Clear SP ___ ___ 08: 02PM URINE UHOLD-HOLD ___ 08: 02PM URINE HOURS-RANDOM . Discharge Labs: ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Glucose-187* UreaN-28* Creat-2.0* Na-144 K-3.9 Cl-103 HCO3-28 AnGap-17 ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Calcium-9.1 Phos-3.6 Mg-2.2 Cholest-184 ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Triglyc-123 HDL-31 CHOL/HD-5.9 LDLcalc-128 . Microbiology: # Blood Culture (___): Pending. # Urine Culture (___): Pending. . Pathology: None. . Imaging/Studies: # CT Head Without Contrast (___): 1. Hypodensities in the right occipital lobe (601b image 94) without definite volume loss could be subacute infarts. No other acute intracranial abnormality. MR is more sensitive for detection of acute infarction and dating of these findings. 2. Old right frontal infarct. 3. Well-circumscribed hypodensity with a central area of parenchymal density in the right cerebellar hemisphere most likely represents infarcts with preserved adjacent parenchyma. There is no mass effect or remodeling of the underlying bone. Further evaluation with MRI on a non-emergent basis is recommended. # CXR (___): No evidence of an acute cardiopulmonary process. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Amlodipine 10 mg PO DAILY 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 3. Humalog 3 Units Breakfast Humalog 3 Units Lunch Humalog 9 Units Dinner NPH 12 Units Breakfast NPH 12 Units Bedtime 4. Labetalol 300 mg PO BID 5. losartan-hydrochlorothiazide 100-12.5 mg oral daily 6. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 7. Simvastatin 20 mg PO DAILY 8. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN angina 9. Nicotine Patch 21 mg TD DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 3. Humalog 3 Units Breakfast Humalog 3 Units Lunch Humalog 9 Units Dinner NPH 12 Units Breakfast NPH 12 Units Bedtime 4. Labetalol 300 mg PO BID 5. Amlodipine 10 mg PO DAILY 6. losartan-hydrochlorothiazide 100-12.5 mg oral daily 7. Nicotine Patch 21 mg TD DAILY 8. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL PRN angina <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ ___: Leg weakness/cramps, possible statin reaction Multiple prior strokes <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, You were admitted to ___ on ___ due to leg weakness. Your symptoms resolved shortly after you arrived but your CT scan showed multiple areas concerning for strokes so you were admitted to the neurology service for further evaluation. We were unable to obtain an MRI as we could not determine whether all of your stents are MRI compatible. Your strokes have likely happened over time and are unlikely to explain your leg weakness. However you do have multiple risk factors for stroke including high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and diabetes. You should follow up with your cardiologist as scheduled and with neurology (see below). We did not change any of your medications. If you experience any of the below listed danger signs, please call your doctor or go to the nearest Emergency Department. It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospital stay.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ RHM with a past medical history significant for coronary artery disease, vasculopathy s/p right carotid enarterectomy, hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia who presented to the ED with resolving bilateral lower extremity weakness, slurred speech and confusion. # NEURO: He claims that his right lower extremity was weaker than his left. A couple of days prior to this admission, he stopped taking his statin because he had worsening leg cramps and GI symptoms like diarrhea and constipation. He has had difficulty tolerating statins in the past. He was recently hospitalized in ___ of this year for chest pain. During that admission, he had a cardiac catheterization that revealed severe and worsening coronary artery disease. He was not considered a good candidate for CABG or "high risk" stenting. In the emergency room, head CT revealed hypodensities in the right occipital lobe that could represent subacute infarcts. MRI could not be performed because records from his previous vascular surgeries regarding the type of stents that were implanted in his subclavian and femoral artery bypass surgeries could not be obtained. His stroke risk factors were assessed and his HbA1c was 9.0% and LDL was 128. He had a recent transthoracic echocardiogram which showed no ASD or thrombus. His left ventricular ejection fraction was found to be 40%. His home Aspirin and Plavix were resumed. His outpatient cardiologist was contacted. His cardiologist confirmed that he does not have a history of atrial fibrillation. He recommended against starting anticoagulation in addition to Aspirin and Plavix. He will not be restarted on a statin given his history of adverse reactions. Also, he had a recent (1month ago) carotid ultrasound, revealing <40% stenosis on the right, and 40-59% on the left). His exam was essentially non focal and he was able to walk without difficulty. AHA/ASA Core Measures for Ischemic Stroke and Transient Ischemic Attack 1. Dysphagia screening before any PO intake? (x) Yes [performed and documented by admitting resident]  () No 2. DVT Prophylaxis administered by the end of hospital day 2? (x) Yes - () No 3. Antithrombotic therapy administered by end of hospital day 2? (x) Yes - () No 4. LDL documented (required for all patients)? (x) Yes (LDL = 128) - () No 5. Intensive statin therapy administered? () Yes - (x) No [if LDL >= 100, reason not given: adverse reaction to several statins in the past ] (intensive statin therapy = simvastatin 80mg, simvastatin 80mg/ezetemibe 10mg, atorvastatin 40mg or 80 mg, rosuvastatin 20mg or 40mg, for LDL >= 100) 6. Smoking cessation counseling given? () Yes - (x) No [if no, reason: (x) non-smoker - () unable to participate] 7. Stroke education given (written form in the discharge worksheet)? (x) Yes - () No (stroke education = personal modifiable risk factors, how to activate EMS for stroke, stroke warning signs and symptoms, prescribed medications, need for followup) 8. Assessment for rehabilitation or rehab services considered? (x) Yes - () No [if no, reason not assessed: ____ ] 9. Discharged on statin therapy? () Yes - (x) No [if LDL >= 100 or on a statin prior to hospitalization, reason not discharged on statin: adverse reaction to several statins in the past ] 10. Discharged on antithrombotic therapy? (x) Yes [Type: (x) Antiplatelet - () Anticoagulation] - () No 11. Discharged on oral anticoagulation for patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter? () Yes - () No [if no, reason not discharge on anticoagulation: ____ ] - (x) N/A # CARDIOVASCULAR: He was continued on his home dose of labetalol. His home dose of Asprin and Plavix were continued. # TRASITIONAL ISSUES: 1. He will follow up with is cardiologist on ___ and with the neurology clinic on ___.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Percocet <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ cardiac catheterization with drug-eluding stent placed in the OM1 graft and with 80% occlusion of the PDA graft not intervened on <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of CAD s/p 4V CABG ___ years ago who presents with chest pain x 1.5 weeks related to exertion, getting more intense. He describes the pain as pressure-like/burning and with radiation to his jaw last night, and it felt like his past MI. He also had one episode of awakening in the middle of the night diaphoretic but has never had nausea or vomiting with his chest pain. He also denies shortness of breath. . In the ED, a cardiology consult was called and the patient was given aspirin 81 mg, plavix loaded with 300 mg, and nitro SL x 1 with resolution of CP. He was also started on a heparin gtt for unstable angina. Vitals on transfer were 98.7 64 109/71 16 99% RA. . On arrival to the floor, patient is chest pain free. He originally refused cath in the ED but is now considering it, he would like to think about this over the weekend and talk about it with his wife. He also describes about 3 months of exertional calf pain which occured with very predictable amount of activity. . REVIEW OF SYSTEMS On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, cough, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. + for exertional calf pain . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Hypertension CABG times four on ___ LIMA to LAD, SVG to ramus, SVG to OM-1, SVG to PDA with EF of 66% at catheterization. <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> + father died with MI at age ___, + diabetes, + HLD, + stroke in mother in her ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM: VS: T 97.8, BP 112/64, HR 60, RR 8, O2 sat 98% RA GENERAL: WDWN M in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, normal oropharynx No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP of 6-7 cm. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. IMAGING: ___ CXR: FINDINGS: Single AP portable view of the chest was obtained. Again seen is marked thoracic scoliosis convex to the right. The patient is status post median sternotomy and CABG. No definite focal consolidation is seen. No large pleural effusion or pneumothorax. The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are stable. IMPRESSION: Marked thoracic scoliosis without evidence of acute cardiopulmonary process. . ___ CARDIAC CATH: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated native three vessel disease. The LMCA had an 80% distal stenosis. The LAD was totally occluded in the mid vessel. The LCx had a 100% proximal occlusion. The RCA had an 100% mid vessel occlusion. 2. Venous conduit arteriography demonstrated a patent vein graft to the ramus, SVG to the OM2 with a 95% proximal stenosis, and SVG to the PDA with a complex thrombotic 95% stenosis at the distal anastamosis. 3. Arterial conduit arteriography demonstrated a patent LIMA-LAD with 40% stenosis at the anastamosis. 4. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed normal central aortic pressures 108/58 with a mean of 78 mmHg. 5. Successful PCI to the SVG-OM2 95% stenosis in the proximal segment of the body of the graft with deployemnt of a 4.0 x 20 mm Promus element drug-eluting stent. 6. A 95% complex, thrombotic stenosis in the SVG-PDA at the distal anastomotic site was not treated due to extremely prohibitive technical factors( described previously). 7. Successful closure of teh left common femoral arteriotomy with Perclose proglide suture-mediated closure device. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. SVG-OM2 stenosis, SVG-PDA stenosis 3. Patent LIMA-LAD 4. Successful PCI to SVG-OM2 95% stenosis with a 4.0 x 20 mm Promus element drug-eluting stent. 5. If patient has recurrent angina, PCI to SVG-PDA could be considered with high risk of procedural complications and limited possibility of technical success. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> aspirin 81 mg daily atenolol 25 mg daily valsartan 80 mg daily protonix 40 mg daily multivitamins (B complex) vitamin D <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. metoprolol succinate 25 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO once a day. SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS hypertension hyperlipidemia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, . You were admitted to the hospital because you were having chest pain which was concerning for blockage within your previous bypass grafts. You were evaluated with a cardiac catheterization which found 90% blockage of one of your grafts and 80% blockage of another graft. . The 90% blockage was stented, and you will need to take plavix for ___ year to keep the stent open. The other 80% blockage could not be stented because the vessel was too small. We cannot be sure which of these blockages was causing your symptoms, so it is possible that you will still have chest pain. You started a new medication to help with the chest pain, called Imdur. . The following changes were made to your medications: - CHANGE valsartan to losartan 25 mg daily - CHANGE atenolol to metoprolol succinate (Toprol XL) 25 mg daily for blood pressure and heart rate - START clopidogrel (plavix) 75 mg daily to keep your stent from clotting - CONTINUE aspirin 81 mg (full dose) daily - START atorvastatin 80 mg daily for high cholesterol - START isosorbide mononitrate (Imdur) 30 mg daily for chest pain and your blood pressure . It is also very important that you keep all of the follow-up appointments listed below. Bring your medications to each appointment so that your outpatient doctors ___ update their records and make adjustments if necessary. . It was a pleasure taking care of you in the hospital!
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with history of coronary artery disease (CAD) status post 4Vessel bypass (CABG) ___ years ago who presented with exertional chest pain x 1.5 weeks, concerning for unstable angina. He underwent cardiac cath and recieved a DES in his OM1 graft with a second 80% occlusion found in his PDA graft that could not be intervened upon. . # CAD: Had CABG ___ years ago. He has a story which was concerning for unstable angina and he was evaluated by cardiology in the ED who recommended aspirin 325 mg daily, clopidogrel loading with 300 mg x 1 and then 75 mg daily, as well as a heparin drip. He was able to become chest pain free after nitro SL. He remained without ischemic changes on his EKG and with 2 troponins negative. He underwent cardiac cath on ___ which showed 90% occlusion of his OM1 graft, which was stented. He also had 80% occlusion of his PDA graft which could not be intervened on because it was too small of a vessel and with oganized thrombus. He continued to have chest pressure with radiation to his jaw after the cath and because PDA vessel could not be intervened on, he was started on isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg daily for symptomatic relief. His last echo was ___ years ago with a normal EF (60%) and no valvular disease and he did not have symptoms or signs of failure so this was not repeated. His home blood pressure medication, valsartan 80 mg daily was decreased to losartan 25 mg daily in favor of symptomatic anginal control and blood pressure management with the Imdur. Also, atenolol was changed to metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily. These changes achieved goal blood pressure less than 130s and heart rate less than ___. He was also started on atorvastatin because his lipid panel showed LDL 91, HDL 39 and his AST/ALT were mildly elevated to ___ with normal CK. His discharge medications were: aspirin 81 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg daily, metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily, atorvastatin 80 mg daily, losartan 25 mg daily, and isosorbide mononitrate 30 mg daily. . CHRONIC ISSUES BY PROBLEM: # Hypertension: Well controlled during admission. Continued home valsartan 80 mg daily and changed home atenolol to metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily. When we started Imdur 30 mg daily he had symptomatic hypotension with systolic blood pressures in the ___. Thus, his valsartan was decreased to losartan 25 mg daily in favor of using the imdur to control blood pressure 100s-130s while also achieving anginal symptom relief. . # Gastroesophageal reflux disease: no symptoms, continued protonix 40 mg daily. . EMERGENCY CONTACT: wife and HCP: ___, ___ h . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Please make sure that he continues to take his atorvastatin for risk factor modification - Please uptitrate his isosorbide mononitrate as needed for persistent anginal symptoms and as his blood pressure will tolerate

target: The patient is a ___ year old female with a history of premature CAD and a prior STEMI in ___ with a 99% mid RCA lesion and Cypher stent placement. Since then, she has had several admissions for chest pain in the setting significant stressors that were found to be non-cardiac in nature. She presented today with chest pain shortly after the funeral of a close childhood friend who was murdered. Cardiac enzymes were negative and EKG showed no evidence of new ischemia. Stress testing with perfusion imaging showed limited functional capacity and findings consistent with her prior MI in ___. . # Chest Pain: History of prior RCA lesion and recent symptoms are concerning for ACS, but EKG showed no new ischemic changes and several sets of cardiac enzymes were negative. Given her past presentations and the association of her current symptoms with significant stress at home, panic attack is another reasonable diagnosis to consider, though the persistence of the chest pain for hours would be atypical. Her clinical stability, imaging, and labs argue against other possible causes of chest pain such as PE, aortic dissection, pleurisy, and pneumothorax. Musculoskeletal pain was also considered, and her chest pain did respond to warm packs, Toradol, and Percocet. She has Percocet at home for fibromyalgia symptoms, so no new prescription was given at discharge. . # CAD: Significant cardiac history and presentation concerning for ACS, but cardiac enzymes and EKG were negative. An exercise stress test on ___ showed no ischemic ECG changes and non-anginal symptoms were reported. Her functional capacity during the test was limited. Perfusion imaging showed an LVEF of 45% and a moderate size minimally reversible defect in the inferolateral wall with no other defects noted. The findings likely represented sequelae of her prior MI in ___. Medical management was continued with her home regimen as below except that she was switched to Aspirin 81 mg daily from 325 mg daily. -- Aspirin 81 mg PO daily -- Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY -- Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg PO BID -- Lisinopril 2.5 mg PO DAILY -- Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY . # HLD: Continued home Lipitor 80 mg PO daily . # Depression / Anxiety: History of depression and anxiety with recent severe stress including the murder of a close friend, daughter leaving for college, and fiance leaving her. A social work evaluation was ordered while an inpatient, and close followup with her outpatient therapist was recommended. Her outpatient medication regimen was continued including Fluoxetine 60 mg PO DAILY and Alprazolam 0.5 mg PO TID PRN anxiety. . # Asthma: She has a history of asthma treated with an Albuterol inhaler, but also reports prior evaluation for possible COPD. No such records were found from ___ reports, however. Starting an inhaled steroid was discussed with the patient, but she reported poor tolerance of inhaled steroids in the past and prefered Albuterol. . # Breast Rash: The patient had an pruritic, erythematous rash under her left breast consistent with a fungal skin infection. She was started on a topical antifungal regimen on ___. A prescription for Miconazole 2% Powder One Applicator TP BID was provided at discharge. . # Smoking Cessation: The patient smokes approximately ___ packs of cigarettes per day and requested a Nicotine patch while in the hospital. Smoking cessation health benefits and options were discussed and she was provided a prescription for Nicotine patches upon discharge. .

CARDIAC RISK FACTORS ___ 08: 55PM BLOOD Triglyc-66 HDL-63 CHOL/HD-2.4 LDLcalc-75 . PERTINENT STUDIES CARDIAC CATH (___) COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography demonstrated in this left dominant system demonstrated one vessel disease. The LMCA had 40% ostial stenosis. The LAD had a mid 30% stenosis. The LCX had a mid 70%, 95% major OM1. The RCA was small non dominant. 2. Resting hemodynamics demonstrated right and left elevated filling pressures with RVEDP 15mmHg and LVEDP 22 mmHg. The PCWP was elevated at baseline 16 mmHg. There was moderate pulmonary arterial hypertension at rest, with PASP 45 mmHg. the cardiac output was low, with CI 1.79 L/min/m2. There was severe aortic stenosis with peak gradient of 60 mmHg and a calculated aortic valve of 0.4 cm2. 3. Left ventriculography was deferred. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate pulmonary hypertension. 3. Severe aortic stenosis. . CXR (___) AP chest reviewed in the absence of prior chest radiographs: Hyperinflation reflects COPD. No focal pulmonary abnormality. Technical artifact produces misregistration at the lung bases not to be mistaken for pneumothorax or other abnormality. There is no pleural effusion. Cardiomediastinal and hilar silhouettes are normal aside from atherosclerotic calcification of the aorta. . ECHO (___) Conclusions The left atrium is normal in size. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Regional left ventricular wall motion is normal. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). The number of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. The aortic valve leaflets are severely thickened/deformed. There is significant aortic valve stenosis. Peak and mean gradients place AS in the moderate range, though precise calculation of valve area is limited by technically-suboptimal LVOT jet velocity measurement. The mitral valve leaflets are not well seen. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Very limited study. Normal global biventricular systolic function. Aortic stenosis, probably moderate. . CHEST CT (___) IMPRESSION: 1. Several bilateral pulmonary nodules, including dominant 8 and 10 mm right apical nodules. In the setting of apical scarring, the apical nodules could potentially be due to nodular scarring. However, in the setting of emphysema, PET-CT should be considered for further evaluation in order to exclude a primary lung cancer. 2. Mild-to-moderate centrilobular emphysema in the upper lobes. Apparent coexisting panlobular emphysema in lower lobes. Considering coexisting moderate bronchiectasis, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency should be considered. 3. Severe aortic valve and coronary artery calcifications. 4. Bilateral hypodense adrenal nodules, most consistent with adenomas. 5. Anterior wedge compression fracture of vertebral body T12, age indeterminate, as no priors are available for comparison. . ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___ Suboptimal image quality. Significant aortic stensosis. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the peak transaortic velocity has increased from 2.8 m/s to 3.9 m/s and the peak transaortic pressure gradient has increased from 32 mmHg to 60 mmHg. These findings are more consistent with the visual appearance of the aortic valve with severely thickened leaflets and limited leaflet mobility (at least severe aortic stenosis visually and by velocities/transvalvular gradients), however in the absence of a measurement of the LVOT ___ and a peak LVOT velocity tracing a definitive measurement of the aortic valve area cannot be made. . CARDIAC CATHETERISATION ___ 1. Severe aortic stenosis 2. Successful balloon valvuloplasty of aortic valve with 22mm Tyshak II balloon with improvement in SBP and gradient 3. Successful LFA angioseal. 4. Plan for PCI LCx later in week. . CAROTID ULTRASOUNDS ___ Study: Carotid Series Complete Findings: Duplex evaluation was performed of bilateral carotid arteries. On the right there is moderate heterogeneous plaque seen in the ICA . On the left there is mild heterogeneous plaque seen in the ICA. On the right systolic/end diastolic velocities of the ICA proximal, mid and distal respectively are 120/24, 95/27, 106/16, cm/sec. CCA peak systolic velocity is 106 cm/sec. ECA peak systolic velocity is 196 cm/sec. The ICA/CCA ratio is 1.1 . These findings are consistent with 40-59% stenosis. On the left systolic/end diastolic velocities of the ICA proximal, mid and distal respectively are 68/15, 85/22, 76/28, cm/sec. CCA peak systolic velocity is 100 cm/sec. ECA peak systolic velocity is 108 cm/sec. The ICA/CCA ratio is .85 . These findings are consistent with <40% stenosis. There is antegrade right vertebral artery flow. There is antegrade left vertebral artery flow. Impression: Right ICA 40-59% stenosis. Left ICA <40% stenosis. . <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> simvastatin, nifedipine, advair, spiriva (does not know dosages). <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 2. senna 8.6 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO HS (at bedtime) as needed for constipation. 3. fluticasone-salmeterol 250-50 mcg/dose Disk with Device Sig: One (1) puff Inhalation twice a day. 4. warfarin 3 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 5. atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 6. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. 7. trazodone 50 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO HS (at bedtime) as needed for insomnia. 8. tiotropium bromide 18 mcg Capsule, w/Inhalation Device Sig: One (1) Cap Inhalation DAILY (Daily). 9. albuterol sulfate 2.5 mg /3 mL (0.083 %) Solution for Nebulization Sig: One (1) vial Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for wheezing. 10. ipratropium bromide 0.02 % Solution Sig: One (1) vial Inhalation Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for wheezing. 11. tamsulosin 0.4 mg Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Capsule, Ext Release 24 hr PO HS (at bedtime) for 1 weeks. 12. aspirin 81 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s) <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ ___ Diagnosis: Acute on Chronic Diastolic congestive heart failure Critical aortic stenosis s/p valvuloplasty Non ST elevation myocardial infarction New Aflutter Urinary retention Coronary artery disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and was taken to ___ for evaluation. A catheterization showed a very tight aortic valve and multiple blockages in your heart arteries. A valvuloplasty was done to open the valve and two bare metal stents were placed in one of your heart arteries which was thought to be the artery responsible for your heart attack. You are on many new medicines to prevent another heart attack and a stroke. It is extremely important for you to take these medicines every day. You had some fluid overload because of the heart attack that was treated with a diuretic to remove the extra fluid. Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days. You were found to be in an irregular heart rhythm called atrial flutter, amiodarone was started to help regulate the rhythm and warfarin was started to prevent a stroke from the rhythm. . You had trouble urinating and a catheter was replaced in your bladder. It will stay in a week and then be removed again. You will need to see a urologist if you are still having trouble after one week. We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. STOP taking nifedipine and simvastatin 2. START aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) to keep the stent open. Do not miss any doses or stop taking clopidogrel for any reason unless Dr. ___ you it is OK 3. START taking atrovastatin to lower your cholesterol 4. START taking tamsulosin to decrease the swelling in your prostate 5. START taking amiodarone to regulate your heart rhythm 6. START taking senna and colace to prevent constipation 7. START taking warfarin to prevent a stroke from the aflutter 8. START taking albuterol and ipratroprium as needed for wheezing. 9. START taking trazadone as needed for sleep.
target: ___ hx COPD, HTN, HLP who presented to OSH after ___ hours of chest pressure, found with NSTEMI with trop of 22, transferred for cath. Here found 95% likely culprit major OM1 lesion and critical AS. . # NSTEMI/low CI: He had no further chest pain during his hospitalisation here. CK-MB was flat at 5. He underwent cardiac catheterisation which showed critical AS and OM1 stenosis, and underwent spaced aortic valvuloplasty and bare metal stenting of his OM1 during this hospitalisation. These procedures were successful. He was started on aspirin, plavix, atorvastatinno further chest pain. Plan for PCI to OM1 on today. On ASA, plavix, statin. Beta blocker was not started due to starting amiodarone for rate/rhythm control of atrial fibrillation. He was also started on a heparin drip and transitioned to warfarin. . # Critical AS: Cardiac catheterisation revealed critical aoritc stenosis. He was evaluated by cardiothoracic surgery for possible valve replacement, but felt not to be an operative candidate on account of porcelain aorta and significant COPD/ emphysema. The patient underwent valvuloplasty with 50% reduction in gradient. He tolerated the procedure well and has been stable since. . # Atrial fibrillation/flutter: Patient was noted to have atrial fibrillation/ atrial flutter, and was started on amiodarone, which he will receive TID until ___. Subsequently, please decrease his amiodarone dose to 200 daily. He was also started on a heparin drip and transitioned to warfarin, which he will continue following discharge. . # COPD: On spiriva/advair at home. O2 sat >95% on RA here. He had occasional wheeze but no dyspnea or cough. He was continued on albuterol and ipratropium nebulisers and treated with advair and spiriva during his hospitalisation. . # Pulmonary nodules: found on CT concerning for malignancy. This finding was discussed with patient and family. He will need to followup with a PET-CT as an outpatient. . # Hyperlipidemia: was on simvastatin at home, this was changed to atorvastatin 80 mg post-MI. . # Urinary obstruction: Patient had poor urine output, but had >800 cc residual urine in his bladder. Foley catheter was placed; when removal was attempted, he failed a voiding trial. Foley catheter was therefor replaced and he will have a furtehr voiding trial in rehab. Tamsulosin was started to treat BPH. . # Psychosocial: he was seen by social work and provided with support regarding coping following his new diagnosis. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: 1. Patient is starting warfarin for atrial fibrillation and will need INR monitoring and appropriate warfarin dose titration following discharge. 2. During his hospitalisation, he was ntoed to have urinary retention and foley catheter was placed. Please perform a voiding trial in ___ days and remove foley catheter as tolerated. 3. CT chest revealed a pulmonary mass and other nodules. Please schedule a PET-CT for further evaluation for possible malignancy.
