Branching echogenic pattern in the liver, concerning for possible tubular gas. The configuration is most consistent with hepatic venous gas (conceivably from central venous line), although considerations include pneumobilia and portal venous gas. Correlation to history, physical examination and lactate value is recommended. This finding might be further evaluated with a CT. 2. 6cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. 3. No Budd-Chiari syndrome and limited evaluation of the hepatic artery, secondary to poor patient tolerance. 4. Cholelithiasis. . CT A/P ___ IMPRESSION: 1. No portal venous gas or pneumobilia. 2. Extensive atherosclerotic disease with an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm, measuring 60 x 56 mm. 3. Cholelithiasis. . TTE ___ The left atrium is mildly elongated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is moderate global left ventricular hypokinesis with more severe hypokinesis of the basal half of the inferior and inferolateral walls (LVEF = 30%). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Mild to moderate (___) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. . IMPRESSION: Moderate global left ventricular hypokinesis with some regionality suggestive of multivessel CAD or other diffuse process. Right ventricular cavity enlargement with free wall hypokinesis. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. . Cardiac Cath ___ COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed three vessel coronary artery disease. The ___ had no angiographically apparent disease. The previous LAD stent was patent and the LAD had diffuse calcification with distal 50-60% stenosis. The Lcx was calcified and occluded. The distal Lcx filled via collaterals from the diagonal. The RCA had diffuse disease with serial 90% stenosis and distally filled via collaterals from the LAD. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed an elevated left sided filling pressure with an LVEDP of 35 mmHg. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. . Art Ext Studies: pending . DISCHARGE LABS <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> On transfer: per discharge summary heparin aspirin IV lopressor IV ACEI . Your heart had some damage around that time (a heart attack) and the pumping function of your heart has worsened. A cardiac catheterization showed severe blockages in your arteries that we were unable to fix. In addition, we could not fix your aneurysm. target: ___ yo F w/ h/o ESRD on HD, CAD s/p 2 stents, PVD, HTN, AAA and COPD presents as OSH transfer with hypercarbic respiratory failure, isolated elevated troponin, and new hepatic dysfunction # CAD - The patient has a h/o 2 prior stents. Positive troponin in setting of flat CKs and h/o ?arrest/unresponsiveness likely ___ initial hypotensive episode causing demand ischemia. TTE this admission showed newly depressed EF compared to ___ years ago. LHC showed diffuse 3VD. The patient and her family were unwilling to pursue CABG at this time. The patient was treated medically with ASA, BB, ACEi. Statin was held in the setting of acute liver injury. The patient was also provided with materials regarding tobacco cessation. # Chronic systolic congestive Heart Failure: TTE shows EF of 30%. No sx of heart failure on exam, no oxygen requirement or crackles on exam. The patient was continued on ASA, BB, ACEi, as above. # AAA - 6.5cm with plan at OSH for elective repair. Given severe CAD, felt that percutaneous repair could not be done. Per VSurg, obtained ABI/venous mapping and will be followed up by Vascular Surgery as an outpatient in 2 wks. # RHYTHM: Sinus Rhythm with no history of atrial or ventricular arrhythmias. # Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: Has history of COPD, continues to smoke with recent dry cough raising suspicion for COPD exacerbation. S/p BiPAP at the OSH with improvement in PCO2. Currently appears comfortable on RA. Discussed smoking with pt and offered nicotine replacement systems, she has refused and wants to quit on her own. Of note, daughter is a current smoker and is the only venue for pt to obtain cigarettes. Will focus information about quitting to her. The patient was treated with ipratropium/albuterol nebs while hospitalized. # Hepatic Failure: Most likely etiology is shock liver (ischemic hepatitis) given history and significantly elevated LDH, although no clear documentation of hypotension at OSH and has not been observed here, vascular obstructive disease, acute viral/toxic injury, infiltrate process. AST/ALT decreased quickly. CT abd/pelvis showed no acute change, pos cholelethiasis. Hepatitis serologies negative. Statin was held ___ to increase in LFTs. # GI Bleed: Guaiac positive stools with maroon mucous tinged on heparin gtt as transfer. No prior history per family. HCt 40 at OSH, down trending to 33 on admission and 29 here. Stable during the rest of the hospitalization. The patient was treated with PPI. # Altered Mental Status - Waxing and waning in setting of normal PCO2, dramatic LFT abnormality. She is more confused at night per daughter and tends to wake frequently. MS improved during hospitalization, although the patient continued to be confused at times. She was started on low dose Seroquel at hs. # ESRD on HD: On regular ___ schedule. The patient's line clotted on ___. Instillation of tPA failed to open line, and patient was sent for tunneled cath placement on ___. # Unilateral Peripheral Edema: resolved. # PVD - Mottled ___ at baseline, but improved during hospitalization. No open areas were noted. The patient had vein studies, as per Vsurg and will f/u as an outpatient.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Lisinopril / Norvasc / Cipro <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Cardiac catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ yo woman with H/O CAD s/p CABG ___ years ago at ___ ___ (anatomy and clinical course not known at the time of presentation) who presented to ___ with pain in the left lateral chest wall that did not radiate per patient (although per ___ records, she also had suprascapular and left scapular discomfort). The pain was present for the last 5 days prior to admission. It was random in occurrence and was not exacerbated with activity; she noticed it primarily at rest. She described it as a pressure in the upper left lateral chest that did not radiate and lasts for around 10 seconds then goes away. It was associated with a dry cough, but no nausea, diaphoresis, or jaw pain. She saw her PCP late last week and was diagnosed with a musculoskeletal condition of her upper back and neck and prescribed Vitamin D. She states that after taking it, her back and neck pain resolved. She was also diagnosed with a UTI and prescribed a 5 day course of doxycycline that she had not started using yet. She denied dysuria, hematuria, or polyuria. She recalled that when she had an MI prior to CABG, she "just felt sick" and stated that she didn't have any specific symptoms. She stated that the reason she came into the hospital was that her PCP mentioned that she should see a cardiologist as an outpatient given her fleeting chest discomfort. This morning at home, the patient took her aspirin 325 mg and metoprolol succinate 100 mg along with her other medications. Upon arrival to ___, EKG showed inferior Q waves and ST elevation with T wave inversion consistent with evolving late presentation of a STEMI. Labs notable for CK-MB 37 and TropT 0.32 -> 0.52. The patient was started on a heaprin gtt and transferred to ___ for cardiac catheterization. She endorsed a H/O an ischemic stroke in ___, now S/P left CEA in ___. She had a DVT of her Left arm during CABG hospitalization. In the ___ ED, initial vitals were: T 98.3 HR 70 BP 133/76 RR 16 SaO2 96% on RA. Mild mitral regurgitation with normal valve morphology. ___ Stress echocardiogram ___ yo woman with HTN, HL and remote tobacco use, s/p CABG in ___, s/p MI on ___ and cardiac catheterization revealing significant RCA and LCx was referred for evaluation. The patient completed 9 minutes of a Gervino protocol representing a fair exercise tolerance for her age; ~ ___ METS. The exercise test was stopped due to fatigue. No chest, back, neck or arm discomforts were reported by the patient during the procedure. At peak exercise, and in the presence of small inferior q-waves, 0.5-1 mm of additional ST segment elevation was noted inferiorly; more so in leads III and aVF vs lead II. These ST segment changes were absent 1 minute post-exercise. As recovery continued, 0.5-1 mm horizontal ST segment depression was noted in leads I, aVL and V2. The rhythm was sinus with one isolated VPB. The heart rate and blood pressure response to exercise was appropriate. IMPRESSION: Fair exercise tolerance. No anginal symptoms with nonspecific ST segment changes; see above. Appropriate hemodynamic response to exercise. Imaging: Resting images were acquired at a heart rate of 67 bpm and a blood pressure of 98/76 mmHg. These demonstrated regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inferior hypokinesis. Your graft of your right coronary artery is occluded. Today, ___, you had a stress test during which you had no chest pain and there were no concerning echo changes. Please make sure you continue to take your aspirin and plavix every day. This is very important to protect the stents you have in your heart vessels. Please enroll in cardiac rehab. Please follow-up with your cardiologist in one week and with your PCP in two weeks.
target: ___ yo woman with H/O CAD s/p urgent CABG ___ ___, SVG-D1, and poor flow into SVG-RPDA) following primary PCI for late presentation of an inferior STEMI ___ and 3 vessel CAD with culprit thrombotic occlusion of the RCA, with attempted aspiration thrombectomy of the RCA complicated by guiding catheter dissection of the RCA extending from the coronary sinus down to the distal vessel treated with 5 bare metal stents and definitive CABG 2 days later) and post-operative DVT who presented to ___ with pain in the left lateral chest wall and inferior Q waves and ST elevation with T wave inversion suggestive of inferior STEMI. Patient had tropT elevations 0.32->0.52->0.53->0.6 and initial (and peak) CK-MB 23. Her NT-pro-BNP was elevated, but throughout the hospital stay she appeared euvolemic (LVEDP 7 at time of cardiac catheterization) and was breathing and saturating well on room air. She was clinically and hemodynamically stable throughout hospitalization. # Acute Coronary Syndrome/STEMI, CAD: Patient with unknown anatomy at the time of presentation. Admission EKG revealed inferior Q waves and ST elevation with T wave inversion (new since ___ consistent with recent evolving inferior STEMI (vs. inferior aneurysm, but no aneurysm was seen on echocardiogram). Peak troponin-T 0.60, with peak/initial CK-MB 23. Her EKG and troponin-T were unchanged, and she associated the pain with musculoskeletal pain. Cardiac catheterization on ___ demonstrated LVEDP 7 and native three vessel CAD with patent ___, patent SVG-D1 and occluded SVG-RPDA. Her PCI and CABG records from ___ were obtained, as well as a DICOM CD copy of her ___ angiogram. Review of these records showed interval likely fresh thrombotic occlusion of the distal native RCA with extensive RCA native (restenotic) disease with mid total occlusion and occluded SVG-RCA (likely not acute). Her native CX was severely and diffusely diseased and did not appear that different from her pre-CABG angiogram. Neither the CX nor the native RCA were appealing for PCI. Patient had one episode of chest pain early in the morning of ___ described as left axillary pain extending to her left upper chest and muscular in quality with shortness of breath, not decreased with movement, non-tender, relieved with 2 sl TNG. She subsequently underwent a stress echocardiogram to ___ METs without provoking her presenting symptoms and without echocardiographic or ECG evidence of inducible ischemia. The resting images on her stress echocardiogram were consistent with prior inferobasal infarct, but her full TTE images suggested normal wall motion abnormality. (In fact, the patient actually ran on the treadmill twice due to problems with image acquisition and had no symptoms and no ischemic ECG both times). Medical management was deemed the treatment of choice, especially as the patient was anxious to go home. She was discharged on low dose aspirin, clopidogrel (for secondary prevention after medically treated MI), metoprolol, atorvastatin, losartan, and SL nitro PRN. Patient and outpatient providers advised to enroll patient in cardiac rehabilitation program. # Hypertension: Blood pressures stable during admission. Patient was kept on metoprolol and losartan. # Hyperlipidemia: Patient kept on atorvastatin 80 mg # Hypothyroidism: asymptomatic while inpatient. Kept on home levothyroxine Transitional issues: - Aspirin daily for life, clopidogrel for one year if tolerated - Please enroll patient in cardiac rehabilitation program at ___ ___ - ___ care proxy: ___, friend, ___ - Code status: FULL

target: ___ yo M with PMH of borderline hyperlipidemia and 3 months of CP presents with CP at rest found to have inferior STEMI now s/p 3 DES to RCA with residual lesion at bifurcation of OM1, stented on return to cath. # STEMI: Pt brought to cath lab, where culprit lesion in RCA was stented. Post cath, pt had asymptomatic bradycardic preventing the use of beta blockers, and was also hypertensive, requiring the use of nitroglycerin drip. As bradycardia resolved, NTG was transitioned to beta-blocker and pt was managed with aspirin, Plavix, high dose statin, ACE-inhibitor and betablocker titrated up as tolerated. Pt received 18 hours of integrillin without complication, and had a normal post cath check. Post-MI echo showed "LVEF 50% secondary to akinesis of the basal inferior and posterior walls and hypokinesis of the midventricular segments of the inferior and posterior walls." 2 days after admission, pt returned for an elective catherization of the stenosis at OM1, which was without complications. Pt was then monitored overnight and discharged on titrated doses of the above mentioned meds. # TOBACCO: Pt and family counseled on tobacco cessation

target: ___ with h/o CAD s/p DES to RCA, diabetes mellitus, hypertension presents with chest pain that starts at rest and has been worsened with exertion. # Chest pain: patient's CAD risk factors include diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, hypertension, and ongoing smoking. Unlike her previous exertional angina, her chest pain has been persistent and occurring at rest. Troponin x 2 was negative and with no acute ischemic changes in EKG. TIMI risk score was 5 (for age, 3 risk factors, known CAD, severe angina, ASA for 7 days). Last nuclear stress test was in ___ and showed moderate, mostly reversible perfusion defect in the inferolateral wall and apex. Given her symptoms and risk factors, we recommended coronary angiography. This showed RCA diffusely diseased with 60% proximal stenosis followed by chronic total occlusion in its mid segment and LCx with known chronic total occlusion in its mid portion; collaterals were present. Given chronicity of these lesions, optimization of medical management was recommended. Her metoprolol succinate was titrated up to 100 mg daily. She was continued on her home ASA, atorvastatin, plavix, isosorbide mononitrate, and lisinopril. Post-procedure check was unremarkable. She remained asymptomatic since arrival to floor through discharge. CHRONIC ISSUES # Type II diabetes mellitus: HbA1c was 6.9% in ___. She is on metformin at home. Patient was kept on a sliding scale while hospitalized. # Tobacco abuse/? COPD: Patient was interested in quitting and using a nicotoine patch. This was begun with plan to continue at home. Her last PFTs on ___ were within normal limits. However, compared to prior from ___, there had been a decline in FEV1 by about 240 mL, which may represent interval worsening obstruction. She was continued on her home ipratropium bromide and albuterol. # Multiple pulmonary nodules: Nodules have been stable for about ___ years (most recent scan ___ and will need to be reevaluated again in ___. # GERD/hiatal hernia: continued on home rabeprazole #TRANSITIONAL ISSUES -metoprolol succinate uptitrated to 100 mg daily -please continue to optimize medical management of CAD as needed -please continue to encourage smoking cessation CODE: full CONTACT: ___ (daughter) ___

On ___, his daughter realized that he had chest pressure and discomfort so he was brought to the ED at ___. At ___, patient was found to have a subacute STEMI with Q waves and ST elevation/T wave inversion in leads II. III, aVF. Troponin was up to 15.1, then peaked to 17 and decreased to 15.5. He was started on a heparin drip and was loaded with full dose aspirin. Cardiac cath was done on ___ which showed 90% stenosis in LAD anterior diagonal branches, 100% stenosis in RCA. Plavix was held for possible CABG. He was continued on aspirin, heparin, atorvastatin. His blood pressure was soft in the ___. TTE showed EF 60%. He received Lasix 20 mg IV x1 on ___. CT chest was positive for trace to small bilateral pleural effusions, bilateral interstitial patchy opacities. He was also found to have biapical consolidative opacities, right greater than left which may have been present in previous x-rays from ___. This was thought to be scarring/fibrosis versus neoplasm. CT surgery thought patient to be at high risk of mortality at 26.8% so he was a poor candidate for CABG. He was thought to be confused on ___ overnight. He was noted to be alert and oriented the next morning per medicine. Daughter thought he was last normal on ___ morning. On ___ at 10: 45 AM, daughter noted that pt was more confused, less responsive, and had slight worsening of his baseline L sided weakness. He said nonsensical things and seemed to be moving his left arm less than usual. On ___ at 10: 55 AM, a code stroke was called. CT ___ did not show acute hemorrhage or infarct. CTA ___ and neck showed extensive atherosclerosis with critical stenosis of the right ICA and 70% stenosis of the left ICA. Neurology assessed patient and noted decreased alertness, pronator drift of LUE/LLE and right gaze preference but it was unclear whether it was a partially residual deficit from prior stroke in ___. NIHSS was 6 (1 pt for lethargy, 1 pt for incorrect age, 1 pt for R gaze preference, 2 pts for LUE/LLE drift, 1 pt for tactile extinction to DSS). His confusion was thought to be delirium versus TIA. ___ tele-stroke was notified and patient was transferred to ___ for closer monitoring and possible intervention if exam worsens. Currently, patient says he feels well and denies any pain. He is unable to say whether he feels weaker. Continued enlargement of the cardiac silhouette with diffuse bilateral pulmonary opacifications, more prominent on the right, consistent with pulmonary edema as suggested in the clinical history. Poor definition of the hemidiaphragms with basilar opacification is consistent with layering pleural effusion and compressive atelectasis at the bases. Given the extensive changes described above, it would be impossible to exclude superimposed aspiration/pneumonia in the appropriate clinical setting. ___: MR ___ Involving the right frontal lobe, right basal ganglia, right temporal lobe adjacent to the posterior aspect of the temporal horn and within the right occipital lobe adjacent to the occipital horn of the right lateral ventricle. Additional tiny infarcts are noted within the genu of the corpus callosum, the right greater than left high posterior frontal lobes and high right parietal lobe. There is both cortical and white matter involvement. Some of the infarcts in the right cerebral hemisphere are compatible with watershed etiology, and others appear embolic. There is no evidence of acute intracranial hemorrhage. No significant mass effect. No shift of midline structures. Additional periventricular, deep, and subcortical T2 and FLAIR hyperintensities which do not restrict diffusion are nonspecific but likely represent small vessel ischemic changes. There is prominence of the ventricles and sulci suggestive of involutional changes. Major vascular flow voids are grossly preserved. There is mild mucosal thickening in bilateral ethmoid air cells and right maxillary sinus. Status post lens replacement bilaterally. IMPRESSION: Numerous small acute infarcts, predominantly involving the right hemispheric watershed distributions, but also with an embolic component in the right cerebral hemisphere and left frontal lobe. No associated mass effect or blood products. ___: Carotid artery ultrasound Right ICA 40-59% stenosis. Left ICA 70-79% stenosis. ___: Left cardiac catheterization Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on a planned basis based on coronary angiographic findings documented on a prior angiogram. A 6 ___ EBU3.5 guide provided adequate support. Crossed with a Sion Blue into D1 and Prowater wire in D2 and Runthrough wire into the distal LAD. Predilated with a 2.0 am 2.5 mm balloons and then deployed a mm 2.5 x mm 24 DES. There was significant difficulty post-dilating as the patient moved his wrist several times prolapsing all of the equipment out several times. As such the stents needed to be recrossed several times and NS balloons would not cross. Eventually, using a Guideliner and an inchworm technique, a 3.0 mm balloon was used to postdilate. Final angiography revealed normal flow, no dissection and 0% residual stenosis. There was slow flow in the apex without wire passage into this area likely due to distal embolization. Findings: Successful PCI with drug-eluting stent of the LAD coronary artery. ___: Portable CXR In comparison with the study of ___, there is increasing opacification in the upper zones bilaterally, consistent with multifocal pneumonia. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is stable and there is increasing pulmonary edema. Acetaminophen 650 mg PO Q6H: PRN Pain - Mild/Fever 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 3. Bisacodyl 10 mg PR QHS: PRN Constipation - Second Line 4. Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID 5. Alendronate Sodium 10 mg PO DAILY 8. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth once a day Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 9. Cetirizine 10 mg PO DAILY 10. Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol (vitamin D3)) 400 unit oral DAILY: PRN <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic right carotid stenosis. Unstable angina with ECG changes concerning for STEMI <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___, You were admitted to the hospital after being diagnosis with inferior STEMI and worsening left side weakness in the setting of carotid stenosis at an outside hospital. You had a stent placed in your LAD for your unstable angina in the setting of a STEMI. A transcarotid artery revascularization was also performed to help with your carotid stenosis. The stent placed in your carotid artery will help keep the artery open so that blood can flow to the brain. To perform the procedure, a small incision was made in your neckline and it will continue to heal on its own. Discharge Information Preventing a Blood Clot in the Stent -After getting a stent, you need to take aspirin and Ticagrelor medicines that work to prevent blood clots from forming on the carotid and LAD stent. -Important: Do not stop taking aspirin and Ticagrelor without discussing it with the doctor who did your carotid stent procedure. Incision Site Care For one week: -Do not take a tub bath, go swimming or use a Jacuzzi or hot tub if your incision in submerged -Use only mild soap and water to gently clean the area around the puncture site. -Gently pat the puncture site dry after showering. -Do not use powders, lotions, or ointments in the area of the puncture site. You may have a small bruise around the incision site. This is normal and will go away one-two weeks. Call your doctor right away if you have swelling, bleeding, drainage or discomfort at the incision site that is new or increasing. Call if you feel increasing swelling, erythema, or any discharge or drainage from the wound or if you have a temperature of 101 or more. Activity For the first 48 hours: -Do not drive for 48 hours after the procedure For the first week: -Do not lift, push , pull or carry anything heavier than 10 pounds -Do not do any exercises or activity that causes you to hold your breath or bear down with abdominal muscles. Take care not to put strain on your abdominal muscles when coughing, sneezing, or moving your bowels. After one week: -You may go back to all your regular activities, including sexual activity. We suggest you begin your exercise program at half of your usual routine for the first few days. You may then gradually work back to your full routine.

Patient to be evaluated by interventional cardiology today with possible intervention tomorrow. Plan discussed with vascular, with likely intervention after cardiac cath on ___ or ___. **Patient to be made n.p.o. for possible cardiac stent tomorrow final decision to be made during ___ multidisciplinary rounds.. Patient with chest pain at rest at 15:10, EKG without significant changes, to trend trops, reviewed EKG with cardiac interventional fellow. To try SL nitro, if no improvement, to try morphine, if no improvement to consider cardiac cath for unstable angina. Patient blood pressure dropped to MAP of 59 after nitro sublingual. PHENYLEPHrine started. s/p sublingual nitro *5, and morphine 2mg IV, Patient being transferred to Cardiac ICU for management of unstable Angina = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = ================================================================ CCU Course In setting of unstable angina, PCI of 90% mid lesion in LAD at complex trifurcation was performed on ___, originally planned for ___ but team was unable to get ___ interpreter; patient was not a candidate for CABG. Patient remained euvolemic preop and given metoprolol, ASA 81mg, ticagrelor 90mg, and atorvastatin along with a heparin drip. The procedure was complicated by difficulty with the device delivery requiring multiple re-wiring of the distal tortuous vessel; this however resulted in successful PCI with drug-eluting stent of the LAD coronary artery. Troponin levels continued to trend down after CCU transfer. First day after PCI patient was hypotensive with MAPs in the high ___ to low ___ and metoprolol was held. Repeat EKG showed improving ST elevations anteriorly and inferiorly and CXR obtained on ___ was suspicious for RUL pneumonia in the setting of no leukocytosis and remaining afebrile during admission, antibiotics were held. MRSA and UATs negative. Post-myocardial infarction secondary prevention medications were titrated. Repeat TTE on ___ evaluating for wall motion abnormalities in the LAD territory revealed EF of 47% and mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction most c/w multivessel CAD. Upon stabilization of cardiac status, patient was scheduled by vascular surgery for TCAR to be done on ___ concerning the right carotid stenosis. He was then transferred to vascular surgery for post-operative management of his TCAR. _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ ________________________________________________________________ On ___ patient underwent Right transcervical carotid artery stenting with flow reversal. The operation went as expected and after a short stay in the PACU the patient arrived to the floor. Postoperative check was unremarkable with no new neurological deficits. The incision site was c/d/I with no noticeable hematoma. He continued to do well except for intermittent episodes of hypotension that were asymptomatic and responded to fluid bolus. On POD 1 he continued to do well, with slight improvement in his left extremity weakness, and remained hemodynamically stable. Staples were removed, and wound redressed. Throughout the rest of his hospitalization Mr. ___ continued to do well with intact neurological exam except for the residual left extremity weakness that continued to improve. He remained hemodynamically stable, tolerating a regular diet, and ambulating with a walked and assistance. ___ recommended rehab, and continued to work with Mr. ___ until his discharge to rehab facility. Of note the daughter brought up a concern for a lung opacity that was originally seen on chest imaging from an outside hospital. The images appear to be stable, but we recommended an outpatient follow up with pulmonary clinic for evaluation. An appointment was made for him prior to discharge. He continued to be on SQ heparin for DVT prophylaxis and was started on aspirin and ticagrelor in the hospital on which he was sent home with. Ideally he would continue to take the ticagrelor for 12 months per cardiology, but should be on it for at least 6 months. He will be follow as an outpatient by cardiology as well as vascular surgery for continue postop optimization. At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating with assistance, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.

Recent TTE with LVEF 55-60%, and on exam there were no signs of volume overload. Now s/p cardiac cath on ___ demonstrating 2-vessel disease (however w/o warranting PCI). The night prior to discharge, Mr. ___ had another episode of chest pain while he was sleeping - with no acute EKG changes or elevated troponins/CKMB. As a result, he had a exercise MIBI test on ___ which did not show any reversible perfusion defects or angina symptoms with exercise. He was continued on ASA 81mg. His Metoprolol xl dose was reduced to 12.5 mg daily due to low HR. He was increased to Atorvastatin 80mg PO daily prior to discharge. He was started on imdur 30 mg daily. ================ CHRONIC ISSUES: ================ #HLD: Increased to Atorvastatin 80mg PO daily prior to discharge #HTN: His Metoprolol xl dose was reduced to 12.5 mg daily due to low HR. Held HCTZ 25mg PO daily given cath, and it was restarted on discharge. #Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis: Recent CT Chest in ___ demonstrating improvement in pleural opacities. Throughout his hospitalization, he had oxygen saturations in the mid-high ___ while on RA. #Hypothyroidism: Continued home Levothyroxine Sodium 112 mcg PO DAILY #Open Angle Glaucoma: Continued home Latanoprost and Timolol eye drops for glaucoma. Given he recently had R eye surgery, he was continued on home Prednisolone and Ketorolac eye drops (reports that he was no longer taking Ofloxacin eye drops). #Allergic Rhinitis: Continued home Cetirizine and Fluticasone ==================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ==================== - DECREASED metop xl to 12.5 mg daily due to low HR - INCREASED atorvastatin to 80 mg daily - STARTED imdur 30 mg daily for angina - Please follow-up with Dr. ___ in 1 week.

This is in the context of two recent admissions, one with nausea and vomting found secondary to diverticulitis and another with similar nausea and vomiting that was found to relate to a myocardial infarction. This time she presents with similar nausea and vomiting and, as with the two previous admission, there was no chest pain. Last night, Mrs. ___ went out for dinner with a friend. They went to '___' in ___. She had two glasses of wine - the first time that she has had anything to drink since her heart attack. She does not know if her friend is unwell but plans to call. She did not sleep well last night and awoke feeling nauseous at about 5: 30 a.m. She drank some Coke and took an Ativan and two of her other regular BID medications (she was not specific). Her nausea did not relent. She vomited the Coke (and presumably the pills). Vomitus was non-bloody and non-bilious. It was very similar to her last presentation that was attributed to myocardial ischemia, which also, as now, appeared in the absence of chest pain. This time she also has had some mild shortness of breath. She decided that she would not wait but come straight to the ED in case this was another MI. She took 325 mg aspirin prior to calling the EMS. She presented with hypotension (98/71) but otherwise unremarkable vitals, 1 mm elevation in V2 and new T-wave inversion in V2, V3, and V4. Troponin was 0.65. She was given aspirin 325 mg, clopidogrel 600 mg, and started on a heparin drip. She was also given ondansetron and lorazepam for nausea, to good effect. She went directly to the cath lab and a Xience stent was placed in the RCA. She bled from her groin afterward. Echocardiogram revealed a LVEF of ___ and findings suggestive of ___ (versus myocarditis). She did not tolerate atorvastatin (myalgia) and was started on pravastatin. She developed a hematoma post-cath with stable hematocrit. Knee pain was treated with oxycodone 10 mg TID. Nausea was further investigated. She described her discomfort as "stomach spasms" and not real pain. GI was later consulted, and she underwent EGD. The EGD showed diffuse mild esophagitis, gastritis and duodenitis. She was started on pantoprazole 40mg bid. On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery. She recently had a fevers when she had diverticulitis. She denies cough, dysuria, diarrhea. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations. Given that this was the presentation of your recent cardiac event, we took this seriously and you were admitted to Cardiology. While you were here we investigated your cardiac function and found it to be improved. This suggests that your cardiac event in ___ was ___ Cardiomyopathy. This means that your heart muscle was stunned by stress hormones. This disorder has an excellent prognosis, with cardiac function typically recovering over a four to six week period. IT IS VERY IMPORTANT TO STOP TAKING WELLBUTRIN (BUPROPRION - from at least a theoretical perspective, this medication may agrevate the neurotransmitter excess that led to ___. This, however, does not most likely explain your nausea and vomiting. For your nausea we considered coeliac disease, which you do not have, helicobacter pylori reflux disease, for which tests were also negative. You bled a little, most likely from your esophagus, while vomting, but this stopped quickly. This can sometimes occur with vigorous vomiting. Recent endoscopy showed that you have some inflammation of the lining of your esophagus, stomach and duodenum. Therefore we changed your aspirin to the enteric coated version, as this may contribute to gastritis. In addition, it would be advisable to take spicy food and alcohol only in small amounts. We feel that anxiety may have played some role in your nausea and vomiting, but feel that follow up with Gastroenterology is also warranted. We took an x-ray of your knees and found that they are healing well. Please take your medications as outlined below. Please attend all follow-up appointments as list below. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight > 3 lbs. Adhere to 2 gm of sodium per day diet. This will help you not retain extra fluid while your heart is recovering. Fluid Restriction: Please restrict fluids to thirst - do not drink large volumes of fluid.
target: Impression Mrs. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with diverticulitis and coronary artery disease presenting with nausea and vomiting that replicates both of her recent presentations, one for diverticulitis and the other with myocardial infarction. Acute Heart Failure On the basis of rapidly recovered myocardial function on echo, we now think that this may have actually been ___ cardiomyopathy at her last presentation. This fits with her EKG changes, moderate cardiac enzymes and emotional or psychiatric context. Her brother had passed away just a couple of weeks earlier, about which she felt guilty, and she presented to the hospital with this acute cardiac event on her birthday. ___ has a favorable prognosis with good recovery over four to six weeks. It is interesting to consider her tandem use of buproprion with an SSRI. We speculate that this may have contributed to her development of ___ cardiomyopathy, and stopped buproprion after consulting psychiatry. Normetanephrins were elevated, not to pheochromocytoma ranges, and likely due to psychotropics. This diagnosis might also explain why her coronary pathology did not correlate well with EKG changes or territories of reduced contractility. The coronary artery stenosis and possibly her colonic diverticula may have been incidental findings. Nausea and Vomiting Work-up for myocardial infarction was negative. This may have been related to gastritis or erosions from aspirin (we changed to enteric-coated and to ranitidine given Plavix). Gliadin and H. pylori tests were negative. However, her nausea largely resolved, particularly after increasing her anxiolytic medication, Ativan. She also seemed comforted by seeing psychiatry as an inpatient, with whom she will follow-up as an outpatient. There has been no recent vomiting. We now think, given the absence of any positive workup, that this may be exacerbated by anxiety. This also fits with her diagnosis of ___ cardiomyopathy. Nonetheless, she will follow-up with gastroenterology, possibly for gastric emptying studies as suggested in their last note. See also hematemesis below. Hypotensive episode Likely due to hypovolemia (tachycardia with postural drop today) along with vagal activation as affective response. Resolved with fluids and increased oral intake. Depression and anxiety Initially continued high-dose duloxetine and buproprion, given that the patient has been stable on these doses for some time. However, reviewed, as above, with diagnosis of ___. Anxiety and inappropriate affect continued throughout the admission. These medications, in the context of aspirin and Plavix further reduce platelet function. Bruising Aspirin + Plavix + SSRIs --> platelet dysfunction (SSRIs by blocking transport of 5-HT into platelets, which otherwise acts as clotting co-factor). This is the likely reason for increased bruising and decreased threshold for hematemesis when vomiting. Hematemesis See comments above. Resolved spontaneously. UGIB RR with aspirin/Plavix elevated by SSRIs (about 5 to 13 RR). Knee pain Concern for osteo given recovery after surgery and pain appearing about three weeks after implant. X-rays clear - no signs osteomyelitis. Physical exam not consistent with infection. Continued home analgesia and encouraged to continue with ___ Low-Grade Fever Resolved without identification of cause. Constipation Resolved with bowel regimen. Contribution by opioids for knee pain. Tobacco Use Mrs. ___ was counseled numerous times and offered adjuvants for cessation.

Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated two vessel disease. The LMCA was patent. The LAD had less than 30% lumen irregularities. Underlying infectious process might be obscured, in particular in the right lower lung. Evaluation of the patient after diuresis is recommended. No evidence of pneumothorax is seen. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROLOGY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Right arm and eye numbness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The pt is a ___ RH male w/ history of CAD s/p PCI x3 (most recently DES to LAD in ___ on aspirin/Plavix, left renal cell carcinoma w/ bony mets s/p nephrectomy/XRT in remission, who presents today with sudden onset numbness in the right arm, face, and dysarthria, which lasted for 30 minutes. The patient was in his usual state of health and watching football on TV when around 1: 30pm, developed sudden onset sensory change described as feeling "hard" and "numb", which began at the shoulder and over a few minutes traveled down to his hand and fingertips. After a few minutes, this subsided and he subsequently developed the same feeling of numbness in a small patch along his right upper eyelid on the nasal side extending into the nasofacial angle. He endorses a vague sensation of blurry vision in the right eye, but cannot say for sure as he did not cover each eye individually. He also endorses dysarthria, stating that some of his speech sounded "garbled" and not clear, although other words were clear. He endorses a few word-finding difficulties, but denies focal weakness, diplopia, visual obscurations, or photopsias. He called his wife from the other room who came in and told him his speech sounded unclear and that he may have had a mild right eyelid droop. He called ___ himself and was taken by ambulance to ___, at which time about 30 minutes later from onset, the symptoms all resolved completely. At ___, he underwent CT head noncontrast which was negative except for chronic bilateral basal ganglion infarcts, and had unremarkable CBC, BMP, LFTs, troponin. He was subsequently transferred to ___ for further workup. Of note, the patient presented with similar symptoms of right facial and arm numbness, speech disturbance lasting for ___ minutes 3 months ago in ___, for which he was admitted to ___ and had a workup for presumed TIA including MRI/MRA negative for acute infarct and showing 50-60% right ICA stenosis. He had an otherwise negative workup with LDL 86, negative TTE, telemetry, although he has not had outpatient cardiac monitoring done. On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait or weakness. He does endorses chronic right upper extremity tingling and paresthesias (different from above symptoms), for which he received outpatient cervical spine MRI from his PCP, showing degenerative changes. On general review of systems, the pt denies recent fever or chills. No night sweats or recent weight loss or gain. Denies cough, shortness of breath. Endorses stable angina. Denies palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. Denies arthralgias or myalgias. Denies rash. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> CAD s/p PCI DES x3 (LAD ___, RCA ___, LAD ___ Carotid stenosis: L ICA <50%, R ICA 50-60% Left renal cell carcinoma s/p nephrectomy ___, XRT to bony mets, in remission Hypertension Hyperlipidemia GERD Bladder cancer, s/p local excision ___ <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> No family history of strokes. Numerous cancers in family (brother pancreatic, sister colon, mother unknown). <PHYSICAL EXAM> -====== ADMISSION PHYSICAL EXAM -======= <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: T 97.8 HR 66 BP 153/78 RR 18 spO2 99% RA General: Awake, cooperative, NAD. HEENT: NC/AT, no scleral icterus noted, MMM, no lesions noted in oropharynx Neck: Supple, no carotid bruits appreciated. No nuchal rigidity Pulmonary: Lungs CTA bilaterally without R/R/W Cardiac: RRR, nl. S1S2, no M/R/G noted Abdomen: soft, NT/ND, normoactive bowel sounds, no masses or organomegaly noted. Extremities: No C/C/E bilaterally, 2+ radial, DP pulses bilaterally. Skin: no rashes or lesions noted. Neurologic: -Mental Status: Alert, oriented x3. Able to relate history without difficulty. Attentive, able to name ___ backward without difficulty. Language is fluent with intact repetition and comprehension. Normal prosody. There were few paraphasic errors such as naming "hassock" for "hammock" on stroke cards and stating "___" for current president. He was otherwise able to name both high and low frequency objects including "cuticle" and "stethoscope", and name all other objects on stroke cards. Speech was not dysarthric. Able to follow both midline and appendicular commands. Pt was able to register 3 objects and recall ___ at 5 minutes. There was no evidence of apraxia or neglect. -Cranial Nerves: II, III, IV, VI: PERRL 3 to 2mm and brisk. EOMI without nystagmus. Normal saccades. VFF to confrontation. Visual acuity ___ bilaterally. Fundoscopic exam revealed no papilledema, exudates, or hemorrhages. V: Facial sensation intact to light touch. VII: Possible subtle right upper eyelid ptosis, but symmetric activation of all other facial musculature. VIII: Hearing intact to finger-rub bilaterally. IX, X: Palate elevates symmetrically. XI: ___ strength in trapezii and SCM bilaterally. XII: Tongue protrudes in midline. -Motor: Normal bulk, tone throughout. No pronator drift bilaterally. No adventitious movements, such as tremor, noted. No asterixis noted. Delt Bic Tri WrE FFl FE IO IP Quad Ham TA ___ L 4 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 R 4 ___ ___ 5 5 5 5 5 5 5 -Sensory: No deficits to light touch, pinprick, cold sensation, vibratory sense, proprioception throughout. No extinction to DSS. -DTRs: Bi Tri ___ Pat Ach L 2+ 2+ 2+ 2 1 R 2+ 2+ 2+ 2 1 Plantar response was flexor bilaterally. -Coordination: No intention tremor, no dysdiadochokinesia noted. No dysmetria on FNF or HKS bilaterally. -Gait: Deferred. . -======== DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM -========= Neurological exam Mental status - Alert, oriented x3, able to answer questions appropriately Cranial Nerves - Face symmetric, EOMI, PERRL, palate elevates symmetrically Motor - 4+/5 b/l deltoids with give way and 4+/5 for IO bilaterally. Sensory - Upper extremity proprioception intact, light touch sensation intact in all four extremities Coordination - Left greater than right action tremor vs mild intention tremor. <PERTINENT RESULTS> -= PERTINENT LABS -= ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD WBC-7.2 RBC-4.62 Hgb-14.3 Hct-42.8 MCV-93 MCH-31.0 MCHC-33.4 RDW-13.9 RDWSD-47.5* Plt ___ ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD Neuts-62.4 ___ Monos-8.6 Eos-2.4 Baso-0.8 Im ___ AbsNeut-4.51 AbsLymp-1.82 AbsMono-0.62 AbsEos-0.17 AbsBaso-0.06 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD ___ PTT-27.4 ___ ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD Glucose-153* UreaN-14 Creat-1.0 Na-137 K-3.6 Cl-104 HCO3-23 AnGap-14 ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD ALT-17 AST-17 AlkPhos-62 TotBili-0.8 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD Calcium-9.9 Phos-3.0 Mg-1.8 Cholest-187 ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD Albumin-3.8 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD %HbA1c-5.9 eAG-123 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD Triglyc-234* HDL-40 CHOL/HD-4.7 LDLcalc-100 ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD TSH-6.7* ___ 06: 05AM BLOOD Free T4-1.1 ___ 02: 07AM BLOOD ASA-NEG Ethanol-NEG Acetmnp-NEG Bnzodzp-NEG Barbitr-NEG Tricycl-NEG ___ 06: 45PM URINE Color-Yellow Appear-Clear Sp ___ ___ 06: 45PM URINE Blood-NEG Nitrite-NEG Protein-TR Glucose-70 Ketone-NEG Bilirub-NEG Urobiln-2* pH-6.0 Leuks-NEG ___ 06: 45PM URINE RBC-0 WBC-1 Bacteri-NONE Yeast-NONE Epi-0 ___ 06: 45PM URINE Mucous-RARE ___ 10: 40AM URINE bnzodzp-NEG barbitr-NEG opiates-NEG cocaine-NEG amphetm-NEG oxycodn-NEG mthdone-NEG . --= ___ PRIOR STUDIES --= CT head noncontrast ___ at ___: No acute intracranial process. Modest atrophy, old bilateral basal ganglia lacunar infarcts and diffuse microvascular angiopathy stable from prior study. . CT head noncontrast ___: Conclusion: 1. Age-related involution and small vessel ischemic leukoencephalopathy. Small chronic left basal ganglia lacunar infarct. Otherwise, normal noncontrast CT scan of the head. 2. No acute hemorrhage, acute infarction, edema, mass, mass effect, or fracture. 3. Minimal chronic left ethmoid sinusitis. . MRI ___: Findings: Correlated with CT performed earlier today. Mild generalized age related involution. Mild patchy periventricular, scattered pontine, external capsular T2 hyperintensity compatible with small vessel ischemic leukoencephalopathy. There is no focal abnormally increased DWI signal identified to suggest recent or acute infarct. Small chronic lacunar infarct noted in the left anterior putamen, as on the CT earlier. No acute intraparenchymal hemorrhage, no edema mass or mass effect. No definite discrete cortical encephalomalacia. There is no abnormal gadolinium enhancement of the brain or its linings. There are small prominent perivascular spaces symmetrically in the basal ganglia regions both sides. Pituitary fossa and its contents appear unremarkable.The major intracranial flow-voids are preserved. Cervical cord/medullary and craniocervical junctions are unremarkable. No significant abnormality of the globes, orbits, skull, petromastoids or sinuses is seen. Upper cervical facet arthropathy noted on the sagittal T1 both sides. Conclusion: 1. Age-related involution, small vessel ischemic leukoencephalopathy. Small chronic lacune of the left anterior putamen. 2. No acute infarct, no acute hemorrhage. No enhancing lesion. No edema, mass or mass effect. 3. Other incidental findings as noted. . MRA neck with contrast ___, 1720 Findings: The innominate artery and left common carotid artery origins from the arch are normal. The left subclavian artery origin is normal. The vertebral arteries are normal in the neck. The right innominate bifurcation and common carotid artery are normal. The right carotid bifurcation shows mild to moderate plaque formation deforming, constricting the lumen. There is approximately 50-59% right proximal ICA stenosis. Moderate to marked tortuosity of right cervical ICA. The left common carotid artery origin and cervical course are normal. The left carotid bifurcation is normal. There is no left bifurcation plaque or ICA stenosis.Mild left cervical ICA tortuosity. The left internal carotid artery diameter is 4 mm. The right internal carotid artery diameter is 3.8 mm. Conclusion: 1. Mild to Moderate plaque of the right internal carotid artery origin, carotid bifurcation, causing moderate 50-59% right proximal ICA stenosis. 2. No appreciable left carotid bifurcation plaque, no significant left ICA stenosis, less than 40%. 3. Tortuosity of cervical ICAs, R > L. 4. Otherwise Normal MRA of the neck with gadolinium. On neuro ROS, the pt denies headache, loss of vision, blurred vision, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, lightheadedness, vertigo, tinnitus or hearing difficulty. Denies difficulties producing or comprehending speech. Denies focal weakness, numbness, parasthesiae. No bowel or bladder incontinence or retention. Denies difficulty with gait. . TTE ___: 2 - D FINDINGS: Left ventricle is not dilated. Concentric LVH. Normal LV wall motion. The aortic valve was sclerotic. The aortic root was normal. The ascending aorta is dilated to 40 mm. The mitral valve, left atrium normal. The RV, RA and tricuspid normal. No pericardial fluid. Doppler reveals trace AI. There is no AS. There is trace MR. ___ is no pulmonary hypertension. CONCLUSION: 1. Thickened aortic valve without stenosis, trace AI. 2. Normal mitral valve, no MR. 3. Concentric LVH. 4. Dilated ascending aorta at 40 mm. 5. Normal RV systolic function . 6. Normal left ventricular wall motion, estimated ejection fraction 60%. . . -======= BI IMAGING STUDIES -======= PATIENT REFUSED MRI (ATTEMPTED) . EEG ___ IMPRESSION: This is an abnormal routine EEG in the awake and asleep states as it showed (i) mild continuous background slowing with a slowed posterior dominant rhythm (7 Hz), as well as (ii) bursts of superimposed left temporal delta frequency slowing during drowsiness. These findings indicate the presence of a mild encephalopathy that is not specific as to etiology, as well as simultaneous focal cerebral dysfunction in the left temporal region. There were no electrographic seizures or epileptiform discharges. Note is made of occasional premature ventricular contractions on simultaneous single channel EKG monitoring. . . ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___ The left atrium is normal in size. No left atrial mass/thrombus seen (best excluded by transesophageal echocardiography). No atrial septal defect or patent foramen ovale is seen by 2D, color Doppler or saline contrast with maneuvers (saline contrast images highly suboptimal). The estimated right atrial pressure is ___ mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Suboptimal apical image quality limits utilty of saline contrast study, but no significant shunt seen. No LV mass. Mild symmetric left ventricular hypetrophy with normal cavity size and normal biventricular systolic function. Mildly dilated aortic root with mild functional aortic regurgitation. . . Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr ___, You were admitted with transient symptoms of right arm numbness and right face numbness that were concerning for transient ischemic attack. We attempted an MRI which you did not tolerate and refused. Because it would be unlikely to see an infarct with your short duration of symptoms, we opted to get ultrasound imaging of your brain vessels which showed some stenosis of the right artery in your neck but there was not left sided stenosis. This will need to be followed by another ultrasound in ___ year. The vessels in your brain appeared to be open by ultrasound. Echocardiogram showed some consequences of high blood pressure but no clot in your heart or connection between two chambers. There was a leaky valve that should be followed by your cardiologist. You also had an EEG or brain wave study to assess for possible increased risk of seizure that did not preliminarily show seizures. The final read for this will need to be followed as an outpatient. Regarding your risk factors for stroke, your diabetes risk factor labs were within normal limits, your cholesterol was high and your thyroid function tests showed that you have subclinical hypothyroidism. You should get repeat thyroid function tests in around 1 month. You were ordered for ___ monitor to evaluate for an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation that puts you at increased risk for strokes. If you have this arrhythmia, that would be an indication to treat you with a stronger blood thinner. This will be followed by Dr ___. Therefore your medications were changed: Started Fenofibrate 48mg daily Tried Atorvastatin but you reported myalgias in the past. You would benefit from being on a cholesterol lowering medication - Your primary care provider or cardiologist can consider starting simvastatin as an outpatient. Please follow up with Neurology as below.
target: ___ M w/ hx CAD s/p PCIx3, renal cell carcinoma w/ bony mets s/p nephrectomy/XRT in remission, prior TIA 3 mos ago, presenting with symptoms of right arm followed by upper right eyelid, nasal numbness and dysarthria, resolved after 30 minutes. This is a similar presentation from 3 months ago but slightly prolonged. He was admitted for a TIA/stroke workup given his vascular risk factors and his recent TIA - to evaluate for possible stroke and eval for possible progression of his arterial disease. . Originally, an MRI Brain and MRA head and neck were planned to evaluate for possible ischemia and atherosclerotic disease. However, when the patient was sent down, he refused the MRI and any further attempts. Since his symptoms only lasted 30 minutes, we felt that it was unlikely that he had suffered a stroke. He therefore underwent carotid ultrasound and TCD's to evaluate for severe stenosis of his carotids and large intracranial vessels respectively. His carotid ultrasound showed R ICA 60-69% stenosis and <40% stenosis on the L ICA. He will need a f/u carotid US in ___ year. Transcranial dopplers were negative for intracranial artery stenosis. . Regarding his other risk factors, his fasting lipid panel showed Chol 187, LDL 100, ___ 234. We tried to start atorvastatin for his hypercholesterolemia but he refused to try any statin due to history of myalgias with atorvastatin. This will need to be discussed as an outpatient as it is our formal recommendation that he be initiated on a statin. He was started on fenofibrate for hypertriglyceridemia. HBA1c 5.9%. His thyroid studies did reveal subclinical hypothyroidism with TSH 6.7 and free T4 within normal limits. He will need to get follow up TFTs in 1 month. . He was continued on aspirin and Plavix on discharge. . Trans-thoracic echo w/ bubble study showed no source of intracardiac clot, PFO or ASD. He had a mildly dilated aortic root with aortic regurgitation that will be followed by his cardiologist. . He was sent home with ___ of hearts monitor for 2 weeks to evaluate for atrial fibrillation as an additional risk factor. . Given the slow evolution of symptoms, the possibility of ictal etiology was considered though acknowledged to be low. He underwent extended routine EEG that was negative for epileptiform activity but did show generalized slowing and left focal temporal slowly. We thought this may be related to his prior infarct in the left basal ganglia. . . ================================ TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ================================ - Follow up Carotid US in ___ year - Repeat thyroid function tests in 1 month. Subclinical hypothyroidism. - ___ of hearts monitor for 2 weeks. - Attempted to restart atorvastatin 20mg but patient refused due to myalgias in the past - this will need to addressed by cardiology as an outpatient - Started on fenofibrate for hypertriglyceridemia - Follow up with outpatient neurology . . You had a temporary aortic balloon pump to help your heart. You also developed kidney failure. You have a mass on your kidney, that will need to have another imaging study in the future and may need to be removed once your kidney function improves. If the urologist decides to operate on your kidney, you will need to have another procedure to stent the artery in your heart before that happens. You are being discharged to rehab. Please take your medications as instructed. Weigh yourself every day. Call you doctor if the weight increases by more than 3 pounds or if you develop trouble breathing. If you have chest pain, shortness of breath, groin pain, or other concernig symptoms please seek medical attention.
target: Mr ___ is an ___ man with history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, chronic renal insufficiency, presenting with syncope and found to have STEMI. . # Sycope: The cause of his sycope on presentation was thought to be most likely orthostatic hypotension with cerebral hypoperfusion given his cerebrovascular disease. Carotid ultrasound showed 40-59% stenosis of the internal carotid arteries bilaterally. He had no further syncopal episodes while in house. . # STEMI: Patient initially had positive enyzmes and ST elevations v2-v6. He was given ASA, Plavix, Beta blocker, heparin gtt. He was prehydrated for catheterization. . On ___, repeat EKG showed STE in lateral leads. Enzymes were trended and flat. Pt did not have symptoms. Decision was made to send pt to cardiac cath on ___, demonstrating severe 3 vessel disease. At that point, cardiac surg was consulted for CABG. However, during the morning of ___, pt complained of back pain and STE returned in his lateral leads. Patient was sent again to the cath lab for balloon pump and then transfer to the CCU. . In the ccu, the decision was made not to pursue CABG given multiple medical comorbidities. The patient remained free of chest pain. Medical management including clopidogrel, full dose aspirin, beta blocker, and high dose statin were undertaken. He was weaned off the intra-aortic balloon pump and it was removed. He had a femoral bruit, so US was done which showed no evidence of pseudoaneurysm. . Regarding his coronary disease, the plan was to wait until renal failure resolved and then consider repeat catheterization for revascularization of his LAD. He would need to have this done before any urologic procedure (as below). . # Acute on chronic renal insufficiency: Creatinine on admission was near baseline of 2. After catheterizations, creatinine rose to a high of 5.4. The most likely cause was contrast-induced ATN. He was hydrated, and renal function improved slowly. Creatinine on discharge was 3.2. . # GI bleed: In the CCU, the patient had guaiac positive stools and reported a history of melena. He was given pRBC to maintain Hct >28. GI did an upper endoscopy that showeed erosive gastritis and duodenitis, likely the source of bleeding. He was given BID PPI. Per GI, this would not preclude heparinization for cardiac procedure if needed. . # Renal mass: On non-contrast abdominal CT, patient was found to have a 4 cm L renal mass that was confirmed by ultrasound to be solid. The urology team evaluated the patient and recommended outpatient follow-up for MR with gadolinium after renal function improves. After speaking with his nephrologist (Dr. ___ at ___, he should NOT get MR with gadolinium at any point but should instead have a contrast CT after kidney function improves. He could potentially undergo resection, after LAD is revascularized, if the disease is localized. . # Mild Chronic Systolic heart Failure: Echo from outside hospital showed overall mildly depressed EF of 40-45% but with focal wall motion abnormality. He was on lasix as an outpatient which was held because of acute renal failure. On discharge, he will need to have daily weights and reinstitution of diuretics as needed. . # Hypertension: The patient had a history of chronic hypertension, likely exacerbated by not taking his clonidine the morning of admission. He initially received a nitro drip, transitioning to hydralazine and later to home medications including beta blocker, amlodipine, and clonidine (changed from tablet to patch). Lisinopril was held for renal failure. He was normotensive on this regimen. . # Left orbital edema: The patient had left orbital edema on admission. Head CT at ___ negative for fracture, no point tenderness on exam. The edema resolved within days. . # Leukocytosis: The patient briefly developed leukocytosis. CXR showed a possible L lower lobe infiltrate. He was afebrile and asymptomatic, and the leukocytosis resolved within days. The most likely cause was aspiration pneumonitis. He should be observed while eating until his mental status improves to baseline. . # Hypernatremia: Sodium the day of discharge was slightly elevated at 148. This will need to be followed at the rehab facility.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Codeine / Hydrocodone / Morphine <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> transfer from OSH for cardiogenic shock <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Inta Aortic Balloon Pump Placement <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o F w/ prior CABG (SVG to the OM, SVG to PDA/LPL, SVG to Diag/LAD), multiple peripheral interventions, prior VF arrest and ICD placement, who is transferred from an OSH for cardiogenic shock. . Patient initially presented on ___ with chest pain. She reported that she developed increasing episodes of chest discomfort with walking in the ___ weeks prior to presenation. On the night prior to presentation, she developed chest discomfort at 9pm. She felt this to be GERD and so went to sleep, but woke up all night with chest pain. She described the pain as radiating to her right shoulder and right arm (but not left arm). She took some out of date nitro she had available w/o improvement. The following morning she attempted to get a new nitro prescription at the pharmacy which rapidly helped her pain improve, but it quickly returned and was never completely pain free. She presented to the ED approximately 12 hours after the onset of her pain the night before. . In the OSH ED she was reported to have ST elevation in V2 2mm and ST elevation in V1/V3. Bedside Echo demonstrated hypokinetic/akinetic mid-distal anterior septum, basal and distal anterior wall, and entire apex. EF 35% (previous EF in ___ - 60%). Patient was started on metoprolol, integrilin, nitroglycerin, and heparin gtt and was never chest pain free. Patient was transfered to ___ for emergent catheterization. . On arrival at ___, patient was cath'd but no intervention was performed(report not available - images not yet reviewed). On cath found VG to OM with stent, unchanged from previous, VG to PDA patent with collaterals to distal LAD, VG to LAD occluded with proximal thrombus (previously patent in ___. Patient was managed medically. . After presentation patient was on the medical floor, and developed what was reportedly completed heart block and cardiogenic shock. Repeat Echo showed extension of her infarct with EF ___, and new RV dysfunction. She was intubated, started on dopamine and placed on IABP. She was taken back to the lab where gain no intervenable lesion was identified (report unavailable - images not yet reviewed). No apparent change on cath but will need to review images. She was then taken back to the ICU on pressors. Over next ___ days where she was weaned of pressors but could not be weaned off dopamine and IABP. She was then transferred to ___ for mgmt. . ICU course was otherwise notable for poor ___ pulses with intermittent loss of pulses. Patient was treated for strep pneumonia with ceftriaxone (unclear how many days of therapy). . ROS: n/a <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> -CABG in ___ (SVG to the OM, SVG to PDA/LPL, SVG to Diag/LAD) -Subclavian stenosis, s/p ___ right brachiocephalic/subclavian stenting (___) -R-Brachiocephalic artery stenosis s/p stent ___ -___ s/p cardiac arrest, s/p ICD -Prior cocaine abuse, stopped ___ years ago -Prior ETOH abuse, stopped ___ years ago -C-section -Tobacco abuse ___ up until last month -Pneumonia ___ -non-compliant with medications -h/o R-carotid bruit. -Possible h/o COPD . Cardiac Risk Factors: Dyslipidemia PVD Asymptomatic hypotensive episodes <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> (+) ___ CAD. Father and grandfather both with MI's in their ___. Father with a stroke at age ___. <PHYSICAL EXAM> Gen: WDWN middle aged male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Neck: Supple with JVD of cm. CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. Abd: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 09: 20PM WBC-6.9 RBC-2.71*# HGB-8.1*# HCT-23.7*# MCV-87 MCH-29.8 MCHC-34.1 RDW-14.4 ___ 09: 20PM NEUTS-75.8* ___ MONOS-2.5 EOS-3.1 BASOS-0.4 ___ 09: 20PM PLT COUNT-262 ___ 09: 20PM ___ PTT-40.3* ___ ___ 09: 20PM GLUCOSE-99 UREA N-9 CREAT-0.6 SODIUM-141 POTASSIUM-4.0 CHLORIDE-114* TOTAL CO2-19* ANION GAP-12 ___ 09: 20PM ALT(SGPT)-66* AST(SGOT)-73* LD(LDH)-587* CK(CPK)-760* ALK PHOS-119* TOT BILI-0.3 ___ 09: 20PM CK-MB-7 cTropnT-2.52* proBNP-2510* ___ 09: 20PM ALBUMIN-2.7* CALCIUM-7.8* PHOSPHATE-4.0 MAGNESIUM-2.1 . CXR ___ There is interval slight progression of the opacification of both lung bases that might be consistent with aspiration versus the underdevelopment of infectious process. Bilateral pleural effusions are most likely present, small-to-moderate. No evidence of overt pulmonary edema is seen. The patient is in mild interstitial engorgement. The right subclavian line tip is in mid SVC. No pneumothorax is present. Bilateral stents in the most likely subclavian and brachiocephalic arteries are present. . ECG: Sinus rhythm ST segment elevation in leads V1-V4 with poor R wave progression - suggest anterior myocardial infarction - possibly acute Lateral ST-T changes are nonspecific Since previous tracing of ___, faster rate present . Rest thallium ___: IMPRESSION: Severe fixed perfusion defects in the distal anterior, and apical walls and a moderate defect of the septum, with no evidence of redistribution on the 4 and 24 hr scans to suggest an area of hibernating myocardium. . ECHO ___: The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. LV systolic function is depressed (ejection fraction 40-50 percent) secondary to extensive severe apical akinesis with focal dyskinesis. The anterior septum and anterior free wall are severely hypokinetic/akinetic. The rest of the left ventricle is hyperdynamic. Tissue Doppler imaging suggests an increased left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP>18mmHg). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with borderline normal free wall function. [Intrinsic right ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the severity of tricuspid regurgitation.] The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. Moderate [2+] tricuspid regurgitation is seen. However, due to extensive acoustic artifact from the right heart wire/catheter, the amount of tricuspid regurgitation may be inaccurately quantitated by color-flow imaging. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. Compared with the findings of the prior report (images unavailable for review) of ___, extensive left ventricular contractile dysfunction now present. A wire/catheter is seen crossing the tricuspid valve, and there is now significant tricuspid regurgitation, possibly related to the wire/catheter. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> CURRENT MEDICATIONS: (Medications on initial presentation) Aspirin 325 Plavix 75 Lipitor 40 Reportedly non-compliant with meds in the past, but taking aspirin/plavix. . (Medications on transfer) Albuterol PRN Colace 100mg BID Aspirin 325mg daily Protonix 40mg IV daily heparin gtt ceftriaxone 2gm q24 dopamine gtt propofol gtt <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 3. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Carvedilol 3.125 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 5. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. Warfarin 2 mg Tablet Sig: 2.5 Tablets PO once a day. Disp: *150 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 7. Lovenox 80 mg/0.8 mL Syringe Sig: One (1) syringe Subcutaneous twice a day. Disp: *6 syringes* Refills: *2* 8. Outpatient Lab Work Please check your INR on ___ and call results to Dr. ___ at ___ <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> ST Elevation Myocardial Infarction Cardiogenic shock Pneumonia <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and was in shock requiring an intra aortic balloon pump and medicine to help your heart work better. You have recovered well but an echocardiogram showed an ejection fraction of 35% (normal is 55%) and a large area of your heart that is not functioning well. You will need another echocardiogram in about a month to look at the heart function again. You will need to be on coumadin for now to prevent blood clots that could lead to a stroke. Coumadin interferes with the production of Vitamin K in your liver. You will need to check a coumadin level (INR) frequently at first, the desired level is 2.0-3.0. It takes about 3 days for coumadin to work so once your dose is changed, you will need to check your INR in about 3 days. Because your heart is weak, you could start to retain fluid. Please note any increasing shortness of breath, swelliing in your legs, nausea, cough or inability to lie flat to sleep. If you notice these symptoms, call Dr. ___. Weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight > 3 lbs in 1 day or 6 pounds in 3 days. Adhere to 2 gm sodium diet and a low fat diet. Do not take Ibuprofen (Motrin) type medicines for pain as they can interfere with your medicine. Take 1000mg of tylenol or talk to Dr. ___ a stronger pain medicine. . Please talk to Dr. ___ starting cardiac rehabilitation in about a month. Congratulations on quitting smoking. It is of upmost importance that you stay a non-smoker. Information was given to you about smoking cessation. . New medicines: 1.Carvedilol: a beta blocker that helps your heart pump better 2.Lisinopril: to lower your blood pressure and help your heart pump better 3. Lovenox: an injection to take twice daily to prevent blood clots and strokes. You will stop taking the Lovenox when your coumadin level is > 2.0. 4. Coumadin: a pill to take every day to prevent blood clots and strokes.
target: Patient is a ___ y/o F w/ h/o CAD s/p CABG (SVG to OM, SVG to PDA/LPL, SVG to diag/LAD), multiple peripheral interventions, prior VF arrest and ICD placement who was transferred from OSH for cardiogenic shock secondary to STEMI. She presented with chest pain at OSH where she was cathed prior to transfer with no intervention. She subsequently developed complete heart block and cardiogenic shock and was found to have extension of her infarct and new RV dysfunction. She was intubated, IABP placed, started on pressors and recathed without intervention. #. Cardiogenic Shock: ___ to MI. Likely some component of RV infarct given echo findings from ___, severe hypotension, and heartblock/bradycardia on presentation. She required balloon pump and dopamine. EF 35%. No further CP or signs of ischemia, VS at goal. Pt has ICD in place from arrest in ___, has not fired here. S/P viability study that showed no tissue that would benefit from reperfusion. Has apical AK with low EF s/p MI so will need warfarin, with Lovenox bridge, goal INR ___. Pt will need stress in ___ weeks. Pt saw ___ while in house who gave activity prescription and recommended cardiac rehabilitation. Extensive teaching done re: diet, exercise, new medicines and post MI course. Pt has an appt with her outpt cardiologist. Dr. ___ updated by phone on day of discharge. ___ take warfarin over the weekend and check her INR on ___ at ___ office. . #. CAD: Severe multivessel disease with prior CABG, now s/p STEMI. She was continued on aspirin 325, plavix 75mg, lipitor 80. See above for viability study results. She was started on Captopril and Carvedilol during her stay and transitioned to Lisinopril and Carvedilol at discharge. Pt will need repeat stress in ___ weeks with cardiac rehab. . #. Respiratory Failure/Presumed Pneumonia: Intubated on arrival, she was extubated on ___ without incident. Rec'd 5 day course of levofloxacin PO. No fevers or cough at discharge. . #. PVD: Had transient loss of pulses s/p IABP at outside hospital. Pt has dopplerable pulses and warm extremeties throughout her hospital stay. . # Transaminitis: Presumably ischemic, normalized before discharge. . #. Anemia: normocytic, hemolysis w/u negative. Not addressed in OSH records. Hct was 35 and stable at discharge. . #. Cocaine Use: Not actively using, no active issues while inpatient. Pt seems quite non-compliant by her own account at baseline. Has expressed that she is interested in becoming more compliant with diet and exercise after discharge.
