Disp: *14 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Gangrene of right lower extremity PMH: Coronary artery disease CHF (EF <30%) Hypertension Dyslipidemia IDDM <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. ___ is primary language <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS FOLLOWING BELOW OR ABOVE KNEE AMPUTATION . This information is designed as a guideline to assist you in a speedy recovery from your surgery. Please follow these guidelines unless your physician has specifically instructed you otherwise. Please call our office nurse if you have any questions. Dial 911 if you have any medical emergency. . ACTIVITY: . There are restrictions on activity. On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing until cleared by your Surgeon. You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever possible. . You may use the other leg to assist in transferring and pivots. But try not to exert to much pressure on the amputation site when transferring and or pivoting. Please keep knee immobilizer on at all times to help keep the amputation site straight. . No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. . PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS: . Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s) . . Watch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR. . Exercise: . Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks. . Do not drive a car unless cleared by your Surgeon. . Try to keep leg elevated when able. . BATHING/SHOWERING: . You may shower immediately upon coming home. No bathing. A dressing may cover youre amputation site and this should be left in place for three (3) days. Remove it after this time and wash your incision(s) gently with soap and water. You will have sutures, which are usually removed in 4 weeks. This will be done by the Surgeon on your follow-up appointment. . WOUND CARE: . Sutures / Staples may be removed before discharge. If they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for staple removal. . When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm water and soap in the shower. . Avoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for four weeks after surgery. . MEDICATIONS: . Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the medications you were taking before surgery. You will be given a new prescription for pain medication, which can be taken every three (3) to four (4) hours only if necessary. . Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small balanced meals throughout the day. . CAUTIONS: . NO SMOKING! We know you've heard this before, but it really is an important step to your recovery. Smoking causes narrowing of your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation. If you smoke you will need to stop as soon as possible. Ask your nurse or doctor for information on smoking cessation. . Avoid pressure to your amputation site. . No strenuous activity for 6 weeks after surgery. . DIET : . There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. Poor appetite is expected for several weeks and small, frequent meals may be preferred. . For people with vascular problems we would recommend a cholesterol lowering diet: Follow a diet low in total fat and low in saturated fat and in cholesterol to improve lipid profile in your blood. Additionally, some people see a reduction in serum cholesterol by reducing dietary cholesterol. Since a reduction in dietary cholesterol is not harmful, we suggest that most people reduce dietary fat, saturated fat and cholesterol to decrease total cholesterol and LDL (Low Density Lipoprotein-the bad cholesterol). Exercise will increase your HDL (High Density Lipoprotein-the good cholesterol) and with your doctor's permission, is typically recommended. You may be self-referred or get a referral from your doctor. . If you are overweight, you need to think about starting a weight management program. Your health and its improvement depend on it. We know that making changes in your lifestyle will not be easy, and it will require a whole new set of habits and a new attitude. If interested you can may be self-referred or can get a referral from your doctor. . If you have diabetes and would like additional guidance, you may request a referral from your doctor. . FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENT: . Be sure to keep your medical appointments. The key to your improving health will be to keep a tight reign on any of the chronic medical conditions that you have. Things like high blood pressure, diabetes, and high cholesterol are major villains to the blood vessels. Don't let them go untreated! . Please call the office on the first working day after your discharge from the hospital to schedule a follow-up visit. This should be scheduled on the calendar for seven to fourteen days after discharge. Normal office hours are ___ through ___. . PLEASE FEEL FREE TO CALL THE OFFICE WITH ANY OTHER CONCERNS OR QUESTIONS THAT MIGHT ARISE Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

There was a small blister noted on the dorsal aspect of the stump, this was dressed wtih adaptik and an antibiotic was started for 7 days. Mr. ___ was deemed stable to discharge back to his rehab facility on ___. He will follow up in clinic for wound check and staple removal in 4 weeks.

She was continued on aspirin 81mg qd, clopidogrel 75 mg, atorvastatin 80mg, and metoprolol succinate 25 mg daily # Hematoma: Patient developed a hematoma after cardiac cath. input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Iodine <ATTENDING> ___ <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Shortness of breath for elective cardiac catheterization. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization with bare metal stent placement ___ <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This ___ year old woman with extensive cardiovascular disease, including CAD S/P CABG ___ (LIMA-LAD)+bioprosthetic AVR (21 mm ___ root repair (24 mm graft) and multiple PCIs (including pre-CABG RCA DES and post-CABG LMCA-LCX DES), who had a positive stress test is now referred for cardiac catheterization. Shortness of breath on exertion was her presentation for her catheterization ___ which resulted in stenting of left main into left circumflex. She does not have chest pain. She has had some mild ankle edema after her Lasix dose was decreased because of syncope. Her lisinopril was also discontinued at that time. The Lasix was increased back to 40 mg, and the edema has improved. She had a positive Cardiolite stress test ___ (LVEF 27%, fixed inferior and basal lateral defect with mild reversibility) and is now scheduled for cardiac catheterization. This showed PCW 34, for which she received furosemide 40 mg IV during the procedure with 500 cc urine output. The LIMA was patent, but she had mild stenosis at the ostium of the circumflex artery (treated with balloon angioplasty) and a new focal mid LCX lesion that was treated with a 3.0x8 mm bare metal stent (had significant GI bleeding on Plavix). Post-procedure, she had no complications. Of note, the patient has dysarthric speech which has been since she had CABG/AVR in ___, as this appeared suddenly post-operatively. The cause was unclear per patient's husband. On review of systems, she denies deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery (did have GI Bleeding on Plavix); has myalgias in hands with arthritis, suffers from back pain, some cough; no hemoptysis; has black stools but is on Slow Fe. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. She has some dyspnea on exertion and gets "tired" but not painful legs. She has had some ankle edema, although not presently. She had one episode of syncope in the bathroom two months ago. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. She denies a fever >100.0 in the last week, flu like symptoms or contact with anyone having H1N1 or any other flu. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CAD - ___ DES to RCA - ___ CABG, AVR (for aortic stenosis), and Aortic root replacement for ascending aortic aneurysm - MI ___ cardiac cath: severe ostial circumflex disease and in-stent restenotic tocal occlusion of RCA. Drug eluting stenting of the left main into ostial circumflex 2. Hypertension 3. CHF, chronic systolic - Per echo stress test: LVEF 27 % 4. Anemia in past now resolving 5. COPD 6. Diabetes mellitus Type II 7. Bilateral carotid endarterectomy 8. S/p cholecystectomy 9. GERD 10. Anxiety/Depression 11. Arthritis-hands 12. Active smoker <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Mother died of acute MI at ___, father died of cancer at ___ years - lung, former smoker. Oldest brother with stroke at ___; Youngest with prostate cancer. <PHYSICAL EXAM> GENERAL: Elderly Caucasian woman, alert and oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate; reporting some back pain. VS: T 96.8 BP 157/78 HR 99 RR 18 O2 Sat 97% on 2 L/min O2 Height: 5 2 Weight: 117 lbs. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. Dentures top and bottom in place. NECK: JVP not yet evaluated - patient lying flat after cath. CARDIAC: RRR, rough systolic murmur radiates to neck, loudest ___ at left superior sternal edge, normal S2. No rubs. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4 appreciated. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB at sides and front - posterior examination deferred, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi appreciated. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. No abdominal bruits. Bowel sounds present. EXTREMITIES: No clubbing, cyanosis or edema. Right groin sheath in place. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. Visible veins in feet. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ DP 1+ ___ 1+ Left: Carotid 2+ DP 1+ ___ 1+ NEURO: Dysarthria with slowed speech, A&Ox3, CNII-XII grossly intact, gait movement and sensation not fully assessed post-cath. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD WBC-5.0 RBC-4.49# Hgb-13.2# Hct-41.4# MCV-92 MCH-29.4 MCHC-31.9 RDW-14.1 Plt ___ ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD ___ ___ 06: 30AM BLOOD WBC-7.1 RBC-4.57 Hgb-13.5 Hct-41.8 MCV-92 MCH-29.5 MCHC-32.3 RDW-14.0 Plt ___ ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-164* UreaN-28* Creat-0.7 Na-143 K-4.2 Cl-106 HCO3-27 AnGap-14 ___ 06: 30AM BLOOD Glucose-103 UreaN-34* Creat-0.9 Na-141 K-3.6 Cl-96 HCO3-34* AnGap-15 ___ 08: 05PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-29 CK-MB-NotDone ___ 06: 15AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-25* CK-MB-NotDone cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 05: 25PM BLOOD Albumin-4.1 Calcium-9.8 Phos-5.5*# Mg-1.9 ___ 06: 30AM BLOOD Calcium-10.0 Phos-4.3 Mg-1.9 ECG ___ 7: 40: 28 AM Sinus rhythm. Left atrial abnormality. Right axis deviation. Right bundle branch block. Consider left posterior hemiblock. Since the previous tracing of ___ the axis is now rightward and right bundle-branch block is new. Clinical correlation is suggested. 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated 3 vessel disease. The LMCA stent was widely patent. The LAD was occluded in the mid segment with competitive flow from the arterial graft observed. The LCx had a patent stent with mild-to-moderate narrowing at the ostial region. The RCA was known to be totally occluded and therefore was not engaged. 2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed the LIMA to be widely patent. 3. Resting hemodynamics revealed elevated right and left sided filling pressures with RVEDP of 19 mm Hg and PCWP of 34 mm Hg. There was severe pulmonary artery hypertension with PASP of 74 mm Hg. The cardiac index was preserved at 2.8 L/min/m2. There was moderate systemic arterial systolic hypertension with SBP of 168 mm Hg. 4. Successful PCI of the ostial LCx with a 3.0x8mm Vision BMS. FEMORAL VASCULAR US RIGHT ___ Targeted ultrasound examination was performed in the right groin over the region of the femoral puncture site. No pseudoaneurysm or subcutaneous fluid collections are identified. The right common femoral artery and vein are patent with normal directional flow and waveforms. Echocardiogram ___ The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrial pressure is indeterminate. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. There is severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with near akinesis of the inferior wall and mild inferior aneurysm. The basal half of the anterior wall is moderately hypokinetic. The remaining segments are mildly hypokinetic (LVEF = ___ %). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the severity of valvular regurgitation.] Right ventricular chamber size is normal. with mild global free wall hypokinesis. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present. The transaortic gradient is normal for this prosthesis. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Moderate to severe (3+) mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. Compared with the report of the prior study (images unavailable for review) of ___, the aortic valve has been replaced, the left ventricular cavity enlargement and regional systolic dysfunction is new. The severity of mitral regurgitation has increased, and pulmonary artery systolic hypertension is now identified. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Prilosec 20 mg daily Aspirin 81 mg daily Slow Fe 325 mg daily Lipitor 80 mg daily Furosimide 40 mg daily Coreg 3.125 mg daily Mirtazapine 15mg at Bedtime <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Metoprolol Succinate 25 mg Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr Sig: 0.5 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *15 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* 2. Lisinopril 5 mg Tablet Sig: 0.5 Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *15 Tablet(s)* Refills: *4* 3. Ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) for 1 months. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 5. Atorvastatin 80 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 6. Ferrous Sulfate 325 mg (65 mg Iron) Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 7. Mirtazapine 15 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO HS (at bedtime). 8. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: One (1) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). 9. nicotine patch Sig: One (1) once a day. Disp: *24 patches* Refills: *1* 10. Lasix 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day. Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ ___: Primary diagnoses: 1) Coronary artery disease with prior coronary artery bypass grafting and coronary artery stent deployment, with additional bare metal stent deployment this admission 2) Acute on chronic left ventricular systolic and diastolic heart failure. 3) Ventricular tachycardia 4) Asymptomatic hypotension Secondary diagnoses: 5) Diabetes mellitus 6) Hypertension 7) Dyslipidemia 8) Tobacco abuse 9) Iodinated contrast allergy 10) Steroid-induced leukocytosis 11) Cerebrovascular disease with prior bilateral carotid endarterectomies 12) Prior bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement and aortic root repair 13) Peripheral arterial disease with right femoral arterial bruit 14) Gastroesophageal reflux disease 15) Arthritis 16) Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease 17) Dysarthria <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mrs. ___ is hemodynamically stable, has improved cardiac function, improved fluid status, is taking a full diet, is able to walk and well enough to engage in some of the tasks of daily living. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital for elective catheterization and stenting of a coronary vessel. During this procedure it was found that there was a higher than normal pressure within the vessels of your lungs. This indicates fluid excess. During your admission we gently removed much of this excess volume. It is important that you maintain a low salt diet (maximum 2 g sodium per day) and drink to thirst, but not more. We are happy to note that you are weighed daily and this information is followed by your physician. It is particularly important to call your physician if your weight changes by around three pounds. IT IS VERY IMPORTANT THAT YOU CONTINUE TO ABSTAIN FROM SMOKING, as this will worsen your heart disease and increases your risk of cancer. During this admission, your medications have changed. Please take all medications as directed below. It is especially important that you take your aspirin daily. This will markedly reduce the chance of your new stent clotting. Please ___ with the physicians listed below. This will be very important in maintaining your health. If you experience increased shortness of breath during activity, increasing weight, ankle or low back swelling, shortness of breath on lying flat or during the night, the control of your heart failure may be worsening. If these symptoms are mild, you should contact your physician ___. If you experience any of the above symptoms are troublesome, or if you experience chest pain, fever, lightheadedness, fatigue, sensations of your heart racing, or any other concerning symptom, you should return to the hospital. Thank you for staying with us at ___, it was a great pleasure to look after you. Information for your physician: 1. LVEF was assessed during the visit with echocardiography and was found to be ___ %. 2. Lisinopril is to be continued after discharge, in keeping with recommendations for ACEI use in patients with heart failure. 3. A beta blocker is also to be continued. 4. Mrs. ___ was counseling regarding smoking cessation and additional help was suggested including nicotine patch. 5. Counseling given regarding: a) Diet and fluid restriction b) Activity level c) Medications d) Weight monitoring e) Heart Failure symptoms f) ___ MD ___ plan 6. Please check electrolytes given adjustment of loop diuretic.
target: Patient is a ___ yo woman with severe CAD, hypertension, diabetes mellitus and h/o CABG+bioprosthetic AVR+aortic aneurysm repair with ? post-operative neurological event resulting in dysarthria and bilateral carotid endartectomies with symptoms of exertional dyspnea and pedal edema with a recent positive stress test. Elective cardiac catheterization today showed a patent LIMA-LAD and patent LMCA stent but a new severe mid circumflex lesion that was treated with a bare metal stent (along with balloon angioplasty of the proximal circumflex). She was also found to have severely elevated filling pressures with PCW 34 and severe pulmonary artery hypertension (PASP 74), in the setting of LVEF ___ in ___ (decreased compared to a year ago) and a recent syncopal event for which her ACE-inhibitor and diuretics were stopped. # Coronary artery disease. Her mid circumflex lesion was treated with a bare metal stent (given history of prior GI bleeding on clopidogrel). She was treated with ASA, clopidogrel, beta-blocker and high dose statin. She was noted to have a right femoral bruit post-procedure, but femoral ultrasound showed no arterial pathology, suggesting a bruit from chronic peripheral arterial disease. # Acute on chronic left ventricular systolic and diastolic heart failure with LVEF ___ recently (but ___ on echocardiogram this admission). She was diuresed (limited by asymptomatic hypotension to SBP 70-80 mm Hg twice, so placed on furosemide infusion for the ___ triggered episode; treated with further dose reduction in her diuretics and beta-blocker for the ___ triggered episode) and put on an long-acting beta-blocker for heart failure as well as an ACE-inhibitor at low doses (as blood pressure would permit). She received heart failure teaching. Her beta-blocker was changed from carvedilol to metoprolol in hopes of lessening the hypotension, allowing more diuresis and afterload reduction with ACE-inhibition, and to avoid using minute fractions of a pill at each dosing interval (for carvedilol 1.562 mg BID). # Ventricular arrhythmia. Telemetry showed a 24 beat run of ventricular tachycardia. The patient notes that about 2 months ago, she was walking into the bathroom and suddenly blacked out. She does not recall any lightheadedness, dizziness, palpitations, SOB, chest pain, nausea or sweating prior to passing out. She did not hit her head. She thinks she was out for a minute or two and felt fine upon awakening. She called her husband to pick her up and continued about her day. Given this history of syncope, documented ventricular tachycardia (although in the post-PCI settting) and LV systolic heart failure, an electrophysiology consultation was obtained. Re-evaluation on an outpatient basis by her primary cardiologist for ICD was recommended. # Diabetes mellitus. Treated with insulin sliding scale, ACE-inhibitor. # Hypertension. Restarted beta-blocker, with addition of daily furosemide and ACE-inhibitor. # Leukocytosis. WBC to 13.5 on post-procedure day one. No evidence of infection. This leukocystosis was likely secondary to steroids given for contrast allergy pre-medications. # Dyslipidemia. High dose atorvastatin continued. # GERD. Her PPI was discontinued in favor of a H2 blocker to avoid negative interactions with the activation of clopidogrel. # Tobacco abuse. The important of smoking cessation was discussed repeatedly with the patient, and she was prescribed a nicotine patch. # Dysarthria. Stable during the admission. # Iodinated contrast allergy. Aside from the leukocytosis caused by steroid pre-medications, she had no problems related to use of iodinated contrast.

We performed a cardiac catheterization, which showed that the stent placed in your graft did not have any clot or blockage. As we discussed, have your primary care doctor check your CBC count when you meet with him in ___ days. When you leave the hospital: - CHANGE your dose of Aspirin to 325 mg Daily (previously you had been taking 81 mg Daily) - START Labetalol 100 mg twice a day - START Lisinopril 10 mg Daily (previously you had been taking 5 mg) - STOP taking Nadolol 40 mg Daily
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ man with a history of OSA on CPAP, dyslipidemia, former tobacco use, PAF, and known CAD s/p CABG x2 in ___ @ ___ (LIMA to LAD and SVG to RCA), with recent cath and stenting to the SVG-PDA on ___ who presents with chest pain. # CORONARIES: The patient presented to the hospital with chest pain which was not typical of his anginal chest pain after having lunch with his friends. His EKG as described in HPI was concerning for ST-T abnormalities in V3-V4, small inferior q waves, and TWI in III, avF. Given that the patient's pain had not fully resolved upon his admission to the ED, and given that his tropinin was elevated at 0.51 (subsequently trending down to 0.4), he underwent cardiac catheterization, which did not show any stent thrombosis in the SVG-PDA. Additionally, the pateint's CK-MB and CK were not elevated during his admission. The patient did not have any reoccurred of his chest pain post catheterization, and was continued on his home regimen of ASA, Plavix, and ROSUVASTATIN 40 mg ___. On the day of discharge, his EKG was repeated, and the ST abnormalities seen before were lessened in their size, although had not disappeared entirely. On discharge, his Nadolol was discontinued, and replaced Labetalol 100 mg BID. In addition, ___ was instructed to start taking a full dose of aspirin, as opposed to a baby dose. He was also instructed to start taking Lisinopril 10 mg daily, as his physician had previously prescribed. # ANEMIA: HCT on discharge was slightly at 34 than baseline of 38. This could represent a drop secondary to procedure, and the patient does not endorse vomiting blood or having any bowel movements with blood. Nevertheless given his history of bleeding post-cath last time, it will be important to monitor his cath site on the L to see if there is any evidence of hematoma formation. He was instructed to follow-up with his PCP to have ___ repeat HCT check.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization with stent ___. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman with h/o HTN and ___ transferred from ___ with NSTEMI. . He experienced chest pain on ___ evening when he was sitting and resting. The pain was substernal and radiated across his chest. It was associated with shortness of breath but no nausea or diaphoresis. It was present for several hours, at which point he went to bed. When he woke up, the pain was gone. He contacted his PCP, who advised he go to the hospital, but he did not do so until this evening. He does not have a clear answer for why he changed his mind and came in, but he states he has not had chest pain since ___. . At the ___, he ruled in by enzymes (CK 77 with trop 0.176 and then 0.211 4 hours later). He was given ASA 325mg and started on a heparin gtt at 00: 20. He also had duonebs x 2 for wheezing. . In the ___ ___, initial VS were: No temp recorded 156/93 91 18 96% RA. Guaiac was noted to be negative. He received plavix 300mg x 1 and was sent to the floor. . He notes some ankle edema that is chronic, other ROS negative. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HTN Dyslipidemia s/p partial amputation of right middle finger <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father had MI in his ___. <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 97.6 124/96 82 20 99% 2L 143.3kg GENERAL: Obese man, sleeping, easily roused. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: +1 pitting ___ edema. No femoral bruits. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PERTINENT LABS/STUDIES: . WBC: 11.9 -> 12.5 Hct: 42.2 -> 41.0 Cr: 0.9 Troponin: 0.2 Triglycerides: 160 Total Cholesterol: 185 LDL: 111 . EKG: NSR at 82 with normal axis and intervals. Wavy baseline, but good R wave progression and ? T wave flattening in I and aVL. EKG from ___ is better quality, shows TWI in aVL and flattening in I. . ECHO (___): The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF 60-70%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. . Cardiac Catheterization (___): 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 3. Normal systemic arterial blood pressure . CXR (___): Portable AP chest radiograph was reviewed with no prior studies available for comparison. Heart size is top normal, but it may be exaggerated by lordotic projection of this portable AP radiograph. Lungs are essentially clear. Note is made that the left costophrenic angle was not included in the field of view. . CT Abdomen (___): Mild stranding at the right femoral catheterization site secondary to some hematoma, but no evidence for large hemorrhage. . . DISCHARGE LABS: . ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD WBC-12.5* RBC-4.62 Hgb-13.6* Hct-41.0 MCV-89 MCH-29.4 MCHC-33.2 RDW-12.9 Plt ___ ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD Plt ___ ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-119* UreaN-13 Creat-0.9 Na-140 K-5.1 Cl-101 HCO3-33* AnGap-11 ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD CK-MB-3 ___ 08: 00AM BLOOD Mg-2.2 ___ 03: 10AM BLOOD Cholest-185 <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Lisinopril 20mg daily Statin--does not know which one, 20mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily) for 1 months: and then 81mg after taking 1 month of 325mg . Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 3. Lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Disp: *30 Tablet Sustained Release 24 hr(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: Coronary Artery Disease Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Good. Patient's vital signs are stable, and he is able to ambulate without difficulty. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain. We discovered that you had a heart attack on ___ night. You were transferred to ___ for a cardiac catheterization, which showed that you had blockages in two of your vessels. We stented these vessels, and you have not had any more chest pain since admission. While you were here, we made the following changes to your medications: 1. We started you on Plavix, 75 mg daily. You must take this medication every day. If you do not, your stents may block off again, and you may die. 2. We started you on Aspirin 325mg for one month and then 81mg daily after that. 3. We started you on Atorvastatin daily 4. We started you on Toprol 50mg daily Please take all medications as prescribed. Please keep all previously scheduled appointments. Please return to the ___ or your healthcare provider if you experience shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, confusion, fevers, chills, or any other concerning symptoms.
target: Patient is a ___ yo man with h/o hypertension and dyslipidemia who was transferred from OSH with NSTEMI. . # NSTEMI: The patient presented with chest pain four days prior to admission. He had significant risk factors for coronary artery disease, his troponin was elevated on admission, and his ECG showed dynamic T waves. The patient had a cardiac catheterization performed on ___ showed two-vessel coronary artery disease. He had two stents placed to the LAD and the RCA. The patient was started on Plavix and high-dose aspirin, and his Atorvastatin was increased to 80 mg daily. He was also continued on his home dose of Metoprolol and Nitroglycerine. The patient did not have any further chest pain during this admission. . # Lower extremity edema: The patient presented with ___ edema, which he stated was chronic. It was uncertain whether or not this edema was secondary to a cardiac etiology, so he had an Echo performed on admission. His TTE showed grossly preserved cardiac function. He was continued on his home dose of Metoprolol during this admission and did not have any acute events. . # Hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension, and he was on Lisinopril at home. The patient was placed back on his home doses of Lisinopril and Metoprolol on admission and did not have any acute events.

He was discharged to home with plans for EP follow-up. He presents today for chest pressure x two weeks. Mr. ___ describes the recent presentation to ___ one week ago. He says that he was sitting at his desk for work and got up and down going to the printer several times throughout the day. On one of these occasions, he woke up on the ground. He denies preceding symptoms such as chest pain, lightheadedness, headache, chest pain, chest pressure, or palpitations. He reports that when he awoke from the syncopal episode he had a headache behind his eyes as well as tingling in his left arm. He waited for the first responders to come prior to getting up. He says that his blood pressure at this time was 190/90, which was quite high for him. He denies other abnormal vital signs at that time, and his glucose was normal. He recalls being lightheaded when he did stand up. He was taken to the ED and was found to have unremarkable laboratory evaluation and an electrocardiogram with frequent VPBs per outside documentation. He was admitted for observation and underwent an echocardiogram which was unremarkable. He was evaluated by cardiology who recommended follow-up with EP and started metoprolol tartrate 25 mg BID, which he did not start. Of note, he has a history of palpitations that are intermittent extra or a skipped beat. These have never bothered him now or in the past. He did not have any episodes of syncope or pre-syncope after this episode last week. Of note, he had a syncopal episode in the 1980s when staying awake all night after getting out of the shower. He presented to the ED today because of chest pressure. He tells me that the chest pressure has been intermittent over the past two weeks. He said that he did have episodes prior to his syncopal episode. He described the discomfort as pressure on his chest which comes and goes. He has not noticed if it worsens with walking around. He was has been active, but he has not been as active lately due to switching jobs roughly a month ago. The last time he was active was 6 weeks ago on a trip to ___ when he walked up to 4 miles at a brisk pace with incline without symptoms and good tolerance. Before that, he and wife would do walks of similar intensity. He has not done that since this discomfort started. He denies radiation. He denies associated symptoms such as shortness of breath, palpitations, lightheadedness. Symptoms are not associated with eating. He had a stress test in ___ for dyspnea when shoveling snow which he believes was likely related to his asthma. He reports that this was negative. He has hypertension for which he takes his medications as prescribed. He has a family history of CAD in his father who had an MI and CABG in his ___ and died of infectious complications. His mother and brother have afib. He has healthy children. He is a never smoker and drinks socially. A full 10 point review of systems was reviewed and is otherwise negative in detail. No fevers, chills, no cough. No weight loss or gain. No swelling, orthopnea. Lost 50+ lbs a few years ago intentionally and has kept the weight off. No changes in his appetite. Stress Echo ___: Modified ___ protocol for 7 min 45 sec ___ METS) representing a poor exercise capacity for age and gender. Patient was given: - Amlodipine 5mg - Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5mg Vitals on transfer: T 99 HR 85 BP 132/85 RR 18 Sat 96% RA On the floor... He confirms the above history with additional details: His chest pressure that started 2 weeks ago was always localized in his mid chest w/o radiation, at worst ___ but recent reached ___ (what brought him in), comes and goes ~2x/day, lasts 45min-1hr, not associated with activity or food, and not worsened by deep breathing or palpation. However, the onset of the chest pressure was correlated with new stress at work with new responsibilities. The chest pressure is worsened by stress and relieved by 'walking away' and relaxing. There is no consolidation, effusion, or edema. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits. Hypertrophic changes noted in the spine. IMPRESSION: No acute cardiopulmonary process. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old with HTN, asthma, history of PMR, and a syncopal episode one week ago who presents for atypical chest pressure and risk factors for CAD with a negative ischemic workup but concerning run of VT during stress test. ACTIVE ISSUES: =============== #Chest pressure: His chest pressure was atypical given that it is not worsened with exertion and no associated symptoms nor radiation. The association of the chest pressure with emotional/psychological stress and relief with relaxation methods suggests anxiety. TTE at ___ showed normal EF and normal LV function early ___. Risk factors for CAD include hypertension and family history. Negative trops x 3. An ECHO stress test revealed no EKG changes concerning for ischemia or hypo/dyskinesis on ECHO. He did have a short run (4 beat) of VT with no other events. He was admitted for observation overnight. Other risk factors for CAD were explored, including diabetes and hyperlipidemia but A1c is 5% but lipids were Tchol 225/ HDL 65/ LDL 141/ ___ 95. Atorvastatin 80mg qd and ASA 81mg qd were started. Due to a relatively negative ischemic workup he was observed overnight without event on telemetry and discharge the next day. #Syncope: Occurred one week ago with no preceding symptoms and associated with chest pressure. No postictal state or abnormal blood glucose. Family history of arrhythmias (AFib) but none observed on telemetry. Orthostatic vital signs negative. Chest pressure episodes started before (2wks ago) syncope and have happened since without syncope. No symptoms or events on telemetry were ever observed during this short admission. Will require further workup in outpatient setting. #Trigeminity: In regards to his trigeminy, these rarely cause severe symptoms and have no known independent prognostic importance. They represent only a repeating pattern of VPBs. Occasionally, patient's may have symptoms from VPBs including palpitations, dizziness, lightheadedness. Chest pain and syncope would be atypical presentations for VPBs although syncope could reflect another arrhythmic etiology rather than VPBs and may warrant further evaluation with monitor on discharge. CHRONIC ISSUES: ================ #Hypertension: He continued his home Amlodipine and HCTZ during this admission with adequate control. #Asthma: The patient was diffusely wheezy on admission but did not take Advair on day of presentation. He had a ___ episode of bronchitis treated with steroids x 5 days. He continued his home Advair during this admission with improvement in wheezing. No asthma attacks were observed and he needed no Albuterol rescue. # CODE STATUS: Full confirmed # CONTACT: ___ (wife and HCP) Phone TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== - No episodes of syncope or telemetry events during this admission and orthostatic vital signs negative, therefore, further workup in outpatient is recommended. - Consider an event(___) monitor as part of syncope workup.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Ampicillin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___ Left heart cath: XB 3.5 LAD guide provided good support. A Prowater wire crossed easily into OM. Export aspiration catheter for 1 run restoring flow. The lesion was then dilated with 2.5 x 12 balloon at 6 ATM. A 3.0 x 16 Promus drug-eluting stent was deployed at 14 ATM and post-dilated in proximal segment with 3.5 x 12 NC balloon at 14 ATM. A distal area of narrowing near the wire tip improved after IC NTG. Final angio = 0% in stent; distal 30%, TIMI 3 flow. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ M with PMH of untreated hypertension and anxiety who presented to the ED with substernal chest discomfort for the previous 16hours. Patient characterized the discomfort as a tightness that did not radiate to neck, jaw, arm or back. Did note associated sweats and clamminess as well as tingling in his distal fingers bilaterally. Discomfort started in the middle of the night, but did not keep him from sleeping. Worsened throughout the day at work and when on the T on the way home he got off and took a cab to ___ for worsening symptoms. He states he was concerned about a heart attack but delayed coming in due to concerns about finances and health care associated costs. Came in when he parents stated they would help pay the bills. Denies lightheadedness, SOB, DOE, palpitations, orthopnea, PND. Does note that he has GERD, worse at night, which he intermittently takes Prilosec for, as well as anxiety attacks which he says feels similar today's episode with the exception of decreased chest discomfort associated with the attacks. Of note, patient does not see a physician regularly and cannot remember when his last doctor's visit was. In the ED an EKG was done which showed rate 86, STE in V5, V6, I and AVL, depressions in V1-V3. Code STEMI was called. Patient was given ASA 325mg, Heparin Sodium 5000units, Nitroglycerin SL 0.3mg SL, and plavix 300mg. He was taken to the cath lab and given prasugrel 60mg. In cath, findings included: severe single vessel CAD with acute thrombotic occlusion for which successful thrombectomy and drug-eluting stent to the left circumflex/OM was performed with good result. Patient was transferred to the CCU for monoring and presents pain free, though shortly after identified ___ substernal chest pain relieved with burping. Patient states he is concerned about the health care costs and feels anxious. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___. You were admitted for a heart attack. A bare metal stent was placed in one of the arteries in your heart (called the Left Circumflex Artery) to restore blood flow to your heart muscle. To prevent another blood clot from forming on this stent and causing another heart attack, it is crucially important that you take your aspirin and prasugrel every day for the next ___ days, and then continue taking your aspirin and plavix every day for at least ___ year beyond that. You are being discharged on several medications that will help to protect your heart from further damage and so taking this medicaion regimen as prescribed is important for you. An echocardiogram (imaging of your heart) was performed after your heart attack and showed that some damaged had been done to your heart muscle, but that this was limited thanks to your cardiac intervention and stenting of the clotted vessel. You will need to have close follow up with a cardiologist (see the appointment below), for continued care of your heart. You have also been diagnosed with diabetes, high cholesterol and high blood pressure, three conditions that are important for the health of your heart and for life span and quality of life moving forward. You have been started on medications for these medical problems and will need close follow up with a primary care physician (see appointment below) to ensure these conditions are appropriately managed. It is very important you take your medications every day!
target: ___ M with PMH of untreated hypertension and anxiety who presented to the ED with an anterolateral STEMI, now s/p thrombectomy and DES to OM1. Active issues: # STEMI: Patient presented with substernal chest pain and an ECG consistent with an anteriolateral STEMI. He is now s/p cath showing severe single vessel CAD (Circ) with acute thrombotic occlusion. He is now s/p successful thrombectomy of left circumflex and 3.0 X 16mm DES to OM1. He received ASA 325, plavix 300, and prasugrel 60. He was maintained on Aspirin 81mg daily, prasugrel 10mg daily x 1 month (and then may change to Plavix 75 mg daily for minimum of ___ year of dual antiplatelet therapy). Additionally, patient was started on atorvastatin, metoprolol and lisinopril. ECHO showed symmetric LVH with mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction, c/w CAD. Patient was monitored in the CCU but as was stable was soon moved to the floor. On the floor pt was stable and no longer had CP or SOB. Repeat echo showed EF was lower at 45% which may be seen in post MI patients as heart is stunned. Will need repeat echo as outpatient. Discussed w/ pt about importance of life style changes. # Uncontrolled hypertension: Patient states that he was told years ago he had hypertension when his blood pressure was taken prior to a dental procedure, which resulted in cancellation of the procedure. Patient started on metoprolol and lisinopril with good control during this admission. Patient educated on the importance of taking his medications and following up with his physicians. # Diabetes: New diagnosis this admission. The diagnosis should be confirmed with a repeat A1C. Patient maintained on ISS while admitted. Patient started on metformin at discharge. Patient counselled regarding diet and weight loss and will follow up with new PCP. Chronic issues: # Psoriasis: Isolated to dorsal aspect of right foot. Patient given Betamethasone Valerate 0.1% Cream 1 Appl TP BID during admission. # Social: Patient is not seeking medical care due to costs associated with care. Pt receiving free care bc no health insurance. Transitional issues: -Appt made with Dr. ___ who ___ be pt's new PCP (pt did not have a PCP prior to admission) -Patient will follow-up with Dr. ___ as pt does not have established cardiologist -Patient may need additional support at home for med adherence, education on discharge -Metformin started on discharge -pt will need repeat echo

There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated. There is severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the mid to distal septum and inferior wall, distal anterior wall, and apex. There is severe hypokinesis of the remaining segments, with the lateral wall relatively less hypokinetic in comparison with other segments (LVEF = 15 %). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). The apex is trabeculated. No apical thrombi are seen, but a small mural thrombus cannot be excluded. There is no ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened without aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with moderately dilated left ventricular cavity. Severely depressed systolic function due to severe wall motion abnormalities indicative of coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction, as described. Mildly dilated right ventricle with normal free wall systolic function. Mildly dilated aortic root. CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION ___: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated severe native three vessel disease. The LMCA was patent. The LAD had a 60% proximal stenosis with a 70% major diagonal stenosis at the origin, and a 100% occlusion mid-LAD. The LCX had a 40% stenosis in OM1. There was a diffusely diseased ramus. The RCA was known 100% occluded with left ot right collaterals to distal vessel with diffuse disease in the PDA. 2. Selective venous conduit angiography demonstrated new total occlusion of the origin of the previously stented LAD graft. All other grafts were known to be occluded and were not engaged, including the LIMA-LAD. 3. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed systemic arterial hypotension. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. New occlusion of the previously stented SVG-LAD graft. 3. No clear targets for repeat CABG, recommend medical management. CTA CHEST ___: IMPRESSION: 1. No evidence of acute aortic syndrome or pulmonary embolus. 2. Thickened interlobular septations and small opacities, likely reflect pulmonary edema. Superimposed infection is possible. The above findings appear progressed since ___ exam. Follow-up CT exam is recommended following treatment for pulmonary edema to exclude superimposed infection. 3. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or wheelchair. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Mr. ___, it was a pleasure to participate in your care while you were at ___. You were transferred to ___ from an outside hospital because you were having chest pain due to a heart attack. You had a cardiac catheterization on ___ but unfortunately the cardiologist were not able to open up any of the blockages in your heart. This means that your Coronary Artery Disease can only be managed with medicines and risk factor management. You should therefore stop smoking. You were started on a blood thinner called coumadin while you were in the hospital. This medication is being used to thin your blood so that you do not have another stroke given that you have heart failure and a certain part of your heart is not moving as it normally should. You will be discharged to a rehabilitation facility where you can work with physical therapy. You will also require ongoing monitoring of your blood (by measuring INR) to ensure the coumadin is at the right dose.
target: REASON FOR ADMISSION: ___ yo male with long-standing, multi-vessel CAD presenting with pleuritic chest pain & troponin elevation; found to have non-intervenable NSTEMI. ACUTE DIAGNOSES: # NSTEMI: The patient was admitted with substernal chest pain and burning for a couple of days prior to admission. His EKG revealed evidence of anterior ischemia and his cardiac biomarkers were positive. He was taken to the cath lab on ___ which revealed an occlusion of the previously stented SVG-LAD graft. There were no clear targets for repeat CABG or PCI. The patient was managed medically on the cardiology floor. His medications were optimized; metoprolol and isosorbide mononitrate were up-titrated. He was started on a high dose statin as well as an ACE-inhibitor. He was chest pain free for many days at the time of discharge. He will continue on plavix, low-dose aspirin, & coumadin (see below) for high-risk CAD. # ACUTE ON CHRONIC SYSTOLIC CHF: The patient's post-MI TTE showed an EF 15% with apical akinesis. Given the stroke risk associated with apical akinesis, the paitent was started on a heparin bridge to coumadin. Goal INR ___. He will continue on aspirin, plavix, & coumadin. His heart failure regimen was optimized and he was started on an ACE-inhibitor, spironolactone, and lasix. His I&O balance was relatively even on this dose of lasix; he appears euvolemic on discharge (slighy bibasilar crackles are likely atelectatic). His potassium was stable between 4.7-5.1 at the time of discharge. He should have his potassium rechecked on ___ to ensure it stays below 5.3 on his current medications (otherwise his dose of spironolactone may need to be decreased to 12.5 mg QD). He should be maintained on a 2 gm sodium restricted diet, as well as a 1200 mL fluid restriction. CHRONIC ISSUES: # DM: A1c = 6.1 on admission. Complicated by peripheral neuropathy. He was discharged on his home regimen of metformin & sitagliptin. Continued pregabalin for peripheral neuropathy # HLD: Lipids at goal on admission. The patient was started on atorvastatin 80 mg QD on admission. His LFTs should be checked within 5 weeks to ensure they are normal. His home niacin & fibrate were discontinued. # HTN: Continue metoprolol as above. # DJD: Continue home pain regimen. A prescription for Vicodin was provided for his rehab center. # CKD: Baseline creatinine reportedly 1.3-1.4. Now 1.3 on discharge. His creatinine should be checked on ___ to ensure it continues to be stable on his current regimen of medications. # PVD: Continue aspirin & plavix as above. # COPD: Last PFTs were not suggestive of emphysema. Pt not on any COPD meds. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # LABWORK: The patietn needs the following labwork checked while he is at rehab. - INR should be checked daily for the next couple of days to ensure he remains stably therapeutic on his initiation dose of 5 mg coumadin daily - A basic metabolic metabolic should be checked on ___ to ensure that the patient's creatinine is stable and not uptrending on his new medications. Also, his potassium should be checked to ensure it is less than 5.3. Further labs should be rechecked at the discretion of a physician at rehab. # VOIDING TRIAL: The patient's Foley catheter was discontinued on ___. He will be due to void at roughly 4:30 ___. If he has not passed urine at that time, he should be bladder scanned and evaluated by a physician for possible reinsertion of a Foley catheter. # FOLLOW UP: The patient will need to arrange for a follow up with his cardiologist upon leaving rehab.

Midline sternotomy wires and mediastinal clips are compatible with prior CABG. A dual-lead pacer device is noted overlying the left chest wall with lead tips in the expected location of the right atrium and right ventricle. The lungs appear clear bilaterally and demonstrate no evidence of pneumonia or CHF. There is widening of the AP diameter of the chest which is seen with flattened diaphragms suggesting underlying emphysema. There is no evidence of pneumonia or CHF. The aorta is unfolded with atherosclerotic calcifications along the knob noted. Bony structures appear intact with degenerative changes in the mid thoracic spine. IMPRESSION: No acute intrathoracic process. Likely underlying COPD. . Head CT (___): FINDINGS: There is no acute intra-axial hemorrhage, major vascular territory infarction, mass effect or edema. There is preservation of the gray-white matter differentiation. Periventricular white matter hypodensity is likely related to chronic small vessel ischemic disease. In addition a more rounded hypodensity in the left basal ganglia (2: 13) may represent a chronic lacunar infarct. Age-appropriate prominence of ventricles and sulci is consistent with a moderate degree of diffuse parenchymal volume loss. The visualized paranasal sinuses and mastoid air cells are well aerated. No osseous abnormality is identified. IMPRESSION: 1. No acute intracranial abnormality. 2. Probable chronic lacunar infarct in the left basal ganglia. 3. No chest, back, neck or arm discomforts were reported by the patient during the procedure. The ECG is unintepretable for ischemia in the presence of ventricular pacing. The rhythm was atrial fibrillation with occasional isolated VPDs noted in exercise. More frequent VPDs were noted mid- to late post-exercise. The heart rate response to exercise was appropriate. The blood pressure response to exercise was flat. IMPRESSION: Average exercise tolerance. No anginal symptoms with an ECG that is uninterpretable for ischemia in the presence of ventricular pacing. Appropriate heart rate response. Blood pressure response to exercise was flat. Nuclear report sent separately. Nuclear report: Left ventricular cavity is dilated at stress greater than the rest. Resting and stress perfusion images reveal small-sized moderate severity reversible perfusion defect in the basal lateral ventricular wall. dditionally, there is a mild to moderate small fixed apical perfusion defect. There are no studies available for comparison. IMPRESSION: 1. Moderate severity small reversible lateral basal perfusion defect. 2. Mild to moderate small fixed apical perfusion defect. 3. transient left ventricular cavity dilatation, can be seen in multivessel disease. <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure to be involved in your care, Mr. ___. After talking to your cardiologist Dr. ___ your family, we decided to continue medical management instead of cardiac catheterization. Your medications have changed: Your INR was high, so we discontinued your coumadin while you were hospitalized. Please have your INR re-checked tomorrow, and discuss the result with Dr. ___ when you see him. A new medication, isosorbide mononitrate, was added to control your symptoms. If you develop recurrent chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, dizziness, leg swelling, or any other symptom that concerns you, please call your doctor or come back to the Emergency Department immediately.

The proximal LAD was noted to have an 80-90% stenosis. It was notable for a cuff adequate for endovascular treatment of this lesion without necessarily involving the LMCA. It was noted to be very heavily calcified, and would thus consider rotablation. The LCx had a proximal 60-70% lesion. The RCA had a thrombotic occlusion of the distal RCA. You should take Aspirin 325mg daily indefinitely and Plavix 75mg daily for a minimum of ___ months. Do not stop either of these medications unless instructed to do so by Dr. ___. target: ___ with HTN, macular degeneration, without known CAD with new RCA STEMI s/p BMS x2. . # CAD/RCA STEMI: Presented with RCA STEMI. SHe was treated with aspirin plavix and taken to the cath lab with succesful PTCA and BMSx2 placement with resolution of CP. Post catheterization EKG demonstrated resolution of the STE but new Q waves in II and AVF. Echo the following day demonstrated LVEF 35% and depressed RV function. She was placed on atorvastatin 80mg, metoprolol, lisinopril and imdur. Her cardiac cath also showed significant CAD of the LAD and circumflex artetries but no intervention was performed. These lesions will be treated medically for now. . #HTN: Had HTN prior to admission treated with diltiazem. After her MI she was started on metoprolol, lisinopril, and imdur, and her diltiazem was discontinued. Blood pressure was well controlled at discharge. #Acute Systolic Dysfunction: Has been on lasix 40 mg for lower extremity edema. Her LVEF is 35% on recent echo thought to be depressed from baseline. She looked mildly hypervolemic but was not actively diuresed as she is likely preload dependent in setting of her RV infarct. Her home lasix was retarted prior to discharge. . #Hyperlipidemia: had history of HLD and was on pravastatin 20 mg daily. This was changed to atorvastatin 80mg after her MI . #Macular degeneration: Stable . #Urinary tract infection: Multiple episodes of urinary incontinance in past 24h since foley removed. Pt denies incontinence at home. U/A positive, started on ceftriaxone empirically and culture grew klebsiella in urine, sensitive to ciprofloxacin. She will finish a 7 day course of antibiotics with cipro for 4 days. . # Dementia. Baseline at present, possible additional component of delirium. Pt much clearer today, A+Ox3, following commands, conversant, pleasant. . Transitional issues: 1. consider repeating u/a once antibiotics are finished 2. consider stress test in the future to assess for ischemia given known occlusions 3. Chem-7 to be drawn in 3 days at rehabilitation as pt is newly on lisinopril 4. BP and HR monitoring on new medicines 5. Repeat ECHO in 6 weeks to assess EF.

You were transferred to ___ from the ___ emergency room. While you were in the hospital we sought to determine the cause of this pain by doing both blood work and diagnostic testing. We found that you were not having a heart attack, but because of a history of heart disease and a heart attack in ___, we did a cardiac catheterization to better evaluate the arteries that provide your heart with blood. We found that you have 40% blockage of your "left main coronary artery" and slow flow through your other coronary arteries. These findings may explain your chest pain, although other causes such as anxiety, muscle strain, or acid reflux are other possibilities. After discharge from the hospital it will be very important to see a cardiologist regularly along with a primary care physician. We are changing some of your medications, and it will be important to ensure you follow the instructions below on exactly which medicines to take. These medicines will protect your heart, lower your blood pressure and reduce the chance of further blockage of your coronary arteries that supply the heart with blood. This will reduce your chance of a heart attack. It has been a pleasure caring for you during your time at ___. We wish you all the best in your recovery! Kind regards, ___ Cardiology
target: ___ y/o woman with H/O hypertension and MI in ___, presenting with ___ chest pain radiating to left arm, consistent with wide differential including cardiac (unstable angina/acute coronary syndrome), GI (GERD, esophageal spasm, PUD, pancreatitis) or musculoskeletal pain. # Chest Pain - Idiopathic at this time, likely does not represent ACS given normal EKG, TnT <0.01 twice. However, given atherosclerotic history (MI in ___, 70% left carotid stenosis, along with prior angiography at ___ showing 50% stenosis of LM and 40% stenosis of RCA), she was sent for coronary angiography. On ___, she was found to have 40% left main coronary artery stenosis (with normal pressure wire study) and slow flow consistent with microvascular disease. Other possibilities remain including gastrointestinal (GERD, gastritis), musculoskeletal causes such as costochondritis, anxiety, or idiopathic. There was no rash to suggest herpes zoster. During her hospitalization, telemetry showed no abnormal cardiac rhythms. She had one <10 minute episode of chest pain while in the hospital that resolved without treatment. Her troponins remained <0.01. Her vital signs remained stable throughout her hospital stay. At no time during her episodes of chest pain either before or during her hospitalization did she report any associated symptoms such as dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea, weakness. She was discharged on ___ with a regimen including ASA 81 mg, atorvastatin 80 mg (raised from home dose of 10 mg given LMCA disease), isosorbide mononitrate ER 60 mg, and metoprolol succinate 25 mg PO daily. She will need outpatient follow up with her cardiologist. # Hypertension: Managed with metoprolol. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Medication changes including raising dose of atorvastatin will require regular monitoring by PCP - ___ need to see both a primary care physician and ___ cardiologist as an outpatient

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Ms. ___, During this admission you were noticed to have right sided weakness and found to have a stroke on the left side of the brain. Unfortunately, this stroke has left you with weakness in your right face, arm, and leg. We anticipate that you will regain some function over time. To maximize potential gain in function we have discharged you to rehabilitation. We believe that your stroke occurred because of a possible blockage in one of the vessels that provides blood to the left side of your brain. We want to reduce your risk of having another stroke so therefore have started you on a medication called warfarin which acts to thin your blood. You will be discharged with a monitor to ensure that there is no abnormal rhythm in your heart leading to increased stroke risk and we will schedule you for an appointment with one of our stroke physicians. Please immediately come to the hospital next time you have sudden onset of weakness or other symptoms. Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to ___ with stroke and infection. WHAT HAPPENED: - You were admitted to the neurology service given that you had weakness on your right side. Imaging found that you had a stroke. - You have narrowing of one of the blood vessels in the neck and brain. We think this is what caused the stroke. You are on a medication to prevent further narrowing of those blood vessels. - You also have narrowing of the blood vessel in the right leg preventing good blood flow to your feet causing the ulcer and pain. - We think the narrowing of these blood vessels is due to atherosclerosis from abnormal cholesterol. - Additionally, you were treated for a fever with antibiotics. When the antibiotics were stopped, your fevers went away - You had other testing to looking for causes of your stroke, these tests were normal IMPORTANT MEDICATIONS - You are on a new anti-clotting drug. You should stop your plavix until you are told to restart this medication by your neurologist - Continue to take your medications for lupus as you were at home. No changes were made to these medications. - Continue to take your atorvastatin 80 mg daily - Start warfarin 2mg daily. This medication causing easy bleeding. This medication needs to be monitored by frequent lab draws to measure INR (goal ___. You will take this medication for one month last day ___. Discuss with your neurologist before stopped. You should restart your plavix at this time. ****Warfarin causes easy bleeding. If you notice gum bleeding, nose bleeding, easy bruising call your doctor. If you start or stop any medications most importantly antibiotics call your doctor, these medications will effect your warfarin level*****If you notice blood in your stool, fall, hit/bump your head report to the emergency department****** - We started a new medication called Cilostazol 50 mg once in the morning and once in the evening. This will help the pain in your legs. During this hospitalization, you were diagnosed with a TIA or Stroke. You received materials and information about strokes and TIAs. This includes information on: understanding what a stroke is, warning signs of another stroke, calling 911 if warning signs occur, risk factors for stroke, and care options that may be available after you leave the hospital. It also includes tips on steps you can take to lower the chance of another stroke, including taking prescribed medications, stopping smoking, lowering sodium and fat in your diet, and having a mobility/exercise plan. Ensure you follow up with your the doctors listed below Thank you for allowing us to care for you ___ care team

She was now directly admitted to the vascular surgery service overnight for a fem-pop bypass surgery. On presentation she was found to have a right hemiparesis and dysphagia. The patient related on presentation that she had experienced right-sided weakness for more than a week. Our Neurology service was consulted. A CTA of head and neck on admission was read overnight as showing a hypodensity in the left occipital lobe concerning for an acute infarct as well as a hypodensity in the posterior left frontal lobe concerning for a subacute infarct. During a second read by Neuroradiology a high grade stenosis of the proximal left cavernous ICA was noted as well as a query left-sided carotid artery dissection was noticed. # Atherosclerotic disease Athroscelortic changes seen throughout the aorta on MRI/MRA abd/pelvis with patent portal, splenic, super mesenteric, and renal veins. Celiac axis, SMA origins, renal arteries, and bilateral common iliac arteries are unremarkable. Occlusion of the left ICA seen on carotid duplex ultrasound 10.3 and R SFA occlusion on diagnostic angiogram on ___. Significant coronary artery disease s/p BMS to LAD in ___. Total cholesterol 58 with HDL <10 and LDL 9 this admission; previous ___ LDL 110 with HDL 30. Given her very low HDL she as increased risk for atherosclerotic disease. She was continued on atorvastatin 80 mg, anticoagulation with lovenox bridge to heparin with cardiology/vascular surgery/neurosurgery/stroke neurology following and will follow up with ___ clinic on discharge. # Subacute left sided frontal/parietal/occipital infractions Patient was admitted to the neurology service on ___ and a stroke workup was conducted. Patient has high grade stenosis of the left cavernous ICA. Patient was anti coagulated with heparin with plans to bridge to warfarin. The plan is for her to be on warfarin for one month just in case the left ICA stenosis is secondary to a fresh thrombus or plaque. Patient after she completes warfarin for one month will be transitioned to plavix 75 mg daily. Patient continues on home atorvastatin 80 mg. Patient had TTE/TEE and no thrombus of PFO was identified. Patient was on telemetry throughout admission and there was no noted atrial fibrillation. Patient will need to be discharged with ___ and ___ need stroke followup in clinic. # FUO On admission the patient had fever, tachycardia, and leukocytosis concerning for sepsis on admission. Neurology team stopped minocycline, started cefepime vancomycin (___) for a 7 day course with no fevers. On admission, given the concern for infection in an immunosuppressed patient, MMF was held, hydrochloquine/predinosone was continued and ID was consulted. ID recommended MRI/MRA to look for aortitis which was negative, TEE negative for vegation, BCx neg, UCx negative, CXR negative, HIV/HCV negative, fungal markers beta glucan/aspergillus negative. Foot ulcer and dry gangrene do not appear as an infectious source. Last recorded fever ___ F on ___ and leukocytosis resolved on discharge with WBC 9.1. She was restarted on MMF on ___ and received a total of 7 days cefepime/vancomycin. # Left ICA occlusion Patient with total occlusion of the left ICA seen on carotid duplex ultrasound on ___ which was new finding from CTA head/neck upon admission. Neurosurgery was consulted who recommended repeat CTA head/neck for direct comparison which was completed on ___ that demonstrated ICA occulsion new from the CTA head/neck completed on admission ___. Neurosurgery deemed no interventions were necessary inpatient and will follow up with the patient in ___ wks after discharge. # High grade stenosis of cavernous internal carotid artery Patient has high grade stenosis of the left cavernous ICA and plan per neurology to continuen warfarin for one month given left ICA stenosis secondary to a fresh thrombus or plaque. Patient discharged on a lovenox bridge to warfarin with INR on discharge 1.5. Last doses warfarin (3 mg, 2 mg, 2 mg INR 1.5) last dose 3 mg on ___ # Transaminitis: Patient presented with traminitis with ALT/AST 50/57 with normal Alk phos 90-100 and normal Tbili 0.3-0.7 in post stroke setting. target: ___ year-old male with a past medical history of NSTEMI in ___ s/p POBA to the culprit occluded ramus and DES to the LAD, hyperlipidemia, depression presenting with acute onset chest pain this morning, symptoms indicative of unstable angina, new RBBB, J point elevations on ECG, now s/p BMS to mid LAD lesion. . ACTIVE DIAGNOES: . # NSTEMI S/P BMS to LAD: Pt presented same day with acute severe anginal chest pain, ECG showed NSR, new RBBB, right asix deviation, ___epressions V2/V3 with a deep S wave in V4/V5, 1-2 mm STE in v3/v4. Code STEMI was called, patient started on ASA 325mg, heparin drip, loading dose of Plavix, started on an integrillin drip, and taken to the cath lab. Cath showed aneurysm formation within the DES to the LAD, with stents widely patent except for a 70-80% stenosis in the mid LAD. This lesion was ballooned and a BMS (Integrity) placed to mid LAD. His pain rapidly improved and follow-up EKG's showed resolution of his RBBB and normal sinus rhythm. TTE showed LVEF of 60% but the midventricular segment of the anterior and lateral walls appear hypokinetic. He was discharged on 325 aspirin daily, 75mg plavix, 25 metoprolol tartrate BID, and re-started on his prior home crestor with follow-up arranged with his outpt PCP and cardiologist. He was instructed to to stop his niacin and ibuprofen. . CHRONIC DIAGNOSES: . # HLD: Stable. Total Chol 135, Trigs 150, HDL 38, LDL 79. He was re-started on his home crestor 5mg PO 3 days weekly. He did not previously tolerate atorvaststain (developed weakness and abdominal pain) and has had trouble with other statins previously. . # Depression: Stable. Continued on his home citalopram. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: . 1)Pt has new BMS to mid LAD, on plavix and ASA 325mg. Follow-up set up with his home cardiologist who will manage his cardiac meds. 2)Pt has history of poor medication compliance especially with statin drugs. His LDL was 79 here, would likely benefit from aggressive lowering to <70. He is on the largest dose of crestor that we think he will presently tolerate. Would attempt to uptitrate as an outpatient.

The tightness was generally present all day, waxing and waning, with no clear precipitants. It was not related to exertion, rest, or food intake. TELEMETRY: No events 2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM (___): The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). Transmitral and tissue Doppler imaging suggests normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Your symptoms were probably due to heartburn. . We started you on a higher dose of an acid-reducing medication (Protonix, pantoprazole) to help control the heartburn. target: A/P: ___ yo M with known CAD s/p recent placement of 3 stents (2 distal RCA, 1 mid-LAD) who presents with acute onset chest discomfort 2 days ago. . #. Chest discomfort: His symptoms are most likely GERD associated. There may have been an irritative component from the stent placement to the RCA that was transmitted to the diaphram. There was concern for cardiac etiology of his chest discomfort (ie ACS) given his recent catherization 4 days ago -- however, it was deemed unlikely to be instent restenosis (EKG without ST elevations, cardiac enzymes negative x3.) Because he has known CAD with multiple stents and some components of his symptoms were similar to his anginal equivalent, a nuclear stress test was ordered. It showed a fixed inferior defect similar to one seen in a previous stress test from ___. He was chest pain free throughout his admission, except during exertion from his stress test. Because of the negative enzymes, the unchanged EKG, the similarity of the two stress tests, the decision was made not to re-catheterize. He was continue on his home doses of aspirin, plavix, statin, Beta Blocker, and ACEI was increased. He was also restarted on protonix 40 PO BID, and maalox as needed. . #. Pump: euvolemic. continued Beta Blocker, ACE Inhibitor. . #. Rhythm: normal sinus rhythm. continued telemetry. . #. Hypertension: Patient noted to be hypertensive in ED, likely ___ discomfort and anxiety. His pressures were slightly elevated on the floor to 130s/70s. His Valsartan was doubled to 160 PO daily. . #. Hyperlipidemia: continued ezetimibe/atorvastatin.

Imaging: CHEST, AP: Lung volumes are low, with crowding of bronchovascular markings and bibasilar atelectasis. There is no focal consolidation. Median sternotomy wires and mediastinal clips are present from prior coronary artery bypass grafting. Mild cardiomegaly is unchanged. There are no significant pleural effusions or pneumothorax. The bones are diffusely demineralized. Cholecystectomy clips are noted in the right upper quadrant. IMPRESSION: Stable mild cardiomegaly. . Stress Test: INTERPRETATION: ___ yo woman with HTN, HL, type II DM requiring insulin, s/p PCI in ___, CABG in ___ and NSTEMI in ___ resulting in BMS of SVG-RCA was referred to evaluate an atypical chest discomfort. The patient was administered 0.142 mg/kg/min of Persantine over 4 minutes. No chest, back, neck or arm discomforts were reported by the patient during the procedure. No significant ST segment changes were noted from baseline. The rhythm was sinus with no ectopy noted. Systolic hypertension at baseline with an appropriate heart rate and blood pressure response to the Persantine infusion. Post-infusion, the patient was administered 125 mg Aminophylline IV. IMPRESSION: No anginal symptoms or additional ST-T wave changes from baseline. Baseline systolic hypertension with appropriate hemodynamic response to the Persantine infusion. Nuclear report sent separately. Imaging: SUMMARY FROM THE EXERCISE LAB: Dipyridamole was infused intravenously for 4 minutes at a dose of 0.142 mg/kg/min. IMAGING METHOD: Resting perfusion images were obtained with Tc-99m sestamibi. Tracer was injected approximately 45 minutes prior to obtaining the resting images. Following resting images and two minutes following intravenous dipyridamole, approximately three times the resting dose of Tc-99m sestamibi was administered intravenously. Stress images were obtained approximately 30 minutes following tracer injection. Imaging protocol: Gated SPECT. This study was interpreted using the 17-segment myocardial perfusion model. During stress test: No anginal symptoms or additional ST-T wave changes from baseline. INTERPRETATION: The image quality is appropriate. Left ventricular cavity size is 85cc. Rest and stress perfusion images reveal small reversible inferolateral defect at the apex, new since the studies from ___ and ___. Gated images reveal normal wall motion. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 59%.
