target: Assessment and Plan: ___ y/o female with recent NSTEMI and atypical chest pain admitted with chest pain with probable costochondritis, and negative cardiac enzymes and a negative stress test, but with an elevated ESR. . # Costochondritis. The patient presented to the ED with hypertensive emergency with an elevated blood pressure. She had chest pain at that time and was started on a nitro gtt, but she was not bolused with heparin. Her cardiac enzymes were negative and her ECG did not demonstrate ST segment or T wave changes suggestive of an ACS. She was ruled out for ACS with two negative enzymes and she underwent a stress test, which did not reproduce any anginal symptoms. Of note, her exam was consistent with costochondritis, and she had very point tenderness across the L side of the precordium. This tenderness diminished significantly prior to discharge. She did not have ECG changes or PE findings consistent with pericarditis. She was discharged with an ACE inhibiter, Beta-blocker, and Imdur as well as sublingual nitroglycerin. She has a follow up with her cardiologist in early ___. - Day Care: Please make sure Ms. ___ has transportation to her cardiology appointment. . # Elevated ESR/CRP: She had a markedly elevated ESR and CRP. She has had chronic headaches, and had a complaint of blurry vision associated with these headaches. These headaches however have been going on for the past year. She did not have any temporal tenderness, in addition to the absence of any focal neurological findings. She will need outpatient follow up to determine the etiology of the elevated enzymes. - Day Care: Please transport patient to her next PCP appointment with ___ on ___. . # Constipation: Upon admission she was passing gas and had a recent bowel movement. There was palpable stool in the transverse colon. She was given Mag Citrate and had several bowel movements. She was discharged home on daily MiraLax in addition to senna and Colace. . # Diabetes: Her blood sugar remains elevated despite an insulin sliding scale. Her metformin was held while she was admitted due to concern she may require a cardiac catheterization. - She will resume her home medications for her Diabetes. - Day Care: Please call ___ to schedule a diabetes appointment the ___ is listed in her page 1. . # Dyslipidemia: Her cholesterol and triglyceride levels are not at goal. Her statin was increased, she was started on fish oil, and her niacin was discontinued. . # Asthma: No acute exacerbation while she was admitted. She was continued on her home medications. . # Benign Essential Hypertension: She was hypertensive while she was admitted and she presented with hypertensive emergency. Her metoprolol was increased in addition to her amlodipine. . # Chronic Medical Problems: Depression/Anxiety, Anemia and GERD were all treated with his home medications. . CODE: Full (discussed with interpreter) . Important Phone Numbers: PCP ___: ___ Day Care Phone ___ : ___ Day Care Fax: ___ Pharmacy Phone ___: ___ Fax ___

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest Pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization (___) <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is a ___ with a PMHx of HTN presenting for chest pain. He reports this morning while helping his wife fold laundry he developed sharp, sub-sternal chest pain that radiated to his right arm and elbow. He notes that his wife gave him an 81mg ASA to take for this pain. Given persistent pain for approximately one hour, this prompted him to present to BI-N. He notes that his pain resolved spontaneously as he was traveling to the hospital. He denies ever having pain like this. He reports no exertional chest pains, but does note some exertional dyspnea with heavy activity recently, but he is unsure if this is just from being out of shape. Initially at OSH, trop was negative. Plan was for second set and stress, but second trop returned positive at 0.03 and given his story and concerning cardiac history, he was transferred for further evaluation. At ___- troponin noted to be negative initially then 0.042. EKG there noted NSR 98 bpm without STE/STD. In the ED initial vitals were: Temp. 97.7, HR 90, BP 130/69, RR 16, 96% RA EKG: Sinus rhythm with T wave flattening in lateral leads. Patient was given: IV Heparin 4000 UNIT IV Heparin Started 1000 units/hr PO/NG Atorvastatin 80 mg On the floor the patient reports his chest pain has not recurred, and that he feels overall well currently. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope, or presyncope. On further review of systems, denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Denies exertional buttock or calf pain. Denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthelasma. NECK: Supple without JVD CARDIAC: RR, normal S1, S2. No murmurs/rubs/gallops. No thrills, lifts. Radial pulses equal and 2+. LUNGS: CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Obese, soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. EXTREMITIES: 1+ pitting peripheral edema, wwp. ETT ___ "Conclusion: 1. Negative ETT for ischemia but note abnormal baseline EKG. 2. No chest pain. 3. No palpitations. 4. Fair exercise tolerance for age. 5. Patient achieved 86% of age predicted maximal rate." CXR "In comparison with the study of ___, the cardiac silhouette remains at the upper limits of normal in size. Prominence of interstitial markings is again seen. Some of this could represent elevated pulmonary venous pressure, though chronic interstitial lung disease cannot be excluded. If this is a serious clinical concern, CT could be obtained. Prominence of central pulmonary arteries, raising the possibility of pulmonary artery hypertension. No evidence of acute focal pneumonia. Cardiac Cath (___): Impressions: 1. Diffuse coronary atherosclerosis consistent with diabetic disease with 2 vessel angiographicallyapparent flow-limiting coronary artery disease with subtotally occlusive calcified bifurcation of the mid LAD into D3 with apical cut-off consistent with recent embolization of thrombus or atheroma and moderate branch CX disease. 2. Normal average left ventricular end diastolic pressure. 3. Successful deployment of 2 drug eluting stents into the mid LAD with rescue of the jailed D3 with maintained TIMI 2 flow but recoil of the origin of the D3. Angiograms reviewed with Dr. ___ decision made not to attempt Culotte bifurcation stenting into D3 given reasonable flow. Reperfusion of the apical LAD also achieved with maintained perfusion of jailed D2 and septal branches. TTE (___): The left atrial volume index is normal. Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size, and regional/global systolic function (3D LVEF = 63 %). Doppler parameters are most consistent with Grade I (mild) left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The number of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: 1) Mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal biventricular regional/global systolic function. 2) Grade I LV diastolic dysfunction. Pulmonary pressure could not be determined. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY 2. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth at bedtime Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. TiCAGRELOR 90 mg PO BID RX *ticagrelor [Brilinta] 90 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth twice a day Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 100 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> PRIMARY: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction Coronary Artery Disease SECONDARY: Obesity Pre-diabetes Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you. Why you were admitted - You were admitted because you had chest pain. What we did for you - You received a cardiac catheterization which revealed blockage in one of your coronary arteries, and they placed 2 stents to help open up the artery. What you should do when you go home? - Please be sure to take your ticagrelor twice a day. Even missing one dose has the risk of clogging your stents and causing a major heart attack. - Please take all your medications and go to your follow up appointments We wish you the best, Your ___ team
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ with a PMHx of HTN, obesity, active smoker presenting for severe sudden substernal chest pain found to have NSTEMI. Patient had mild troponinemia to 0.03 with T-wave flattening in lateral leads in EKG, although similar to prior. Due to extensive cardiac risk factors, he had a left heart cath which revealed diffuse coronary atherosclerosis with subtotal occlusive plaque in the mid-LAD, in which 2 drug eluting stents were placed. He was loaded with ticagrelor. Course was complicated by an episode of dyspnea with normal VS and O2 sats. CXR clear. ___ be related to ticagrelor, but unclear. TTE revealed EF of 63% with no wall motion abnormalities. He was screened by ___ and stable for discharge. # NSTEMI: Pt with substernal chest pain radiating to arm occurring at rest now resolved without intervention with evidence of mild troponinemia of 0.03. He has extensive cardiac risk factors including HTN, obesity, active smoker, and family history. He was initially started on heparin gtt, metoprolol, atorvastatin, and aspirin. He underwent LHC which revealed diffuse coronary atherosclerosis with subtotal occlusive plaque in the mid-LAD, in which 2 drug eluting stents were placed. He was loaded with ticagrelor. He had elevated troponin up to 0.07 after procedure without EKG changes and was chest pain free. On discharge, his cardiac medications were metoprolol succinate, atorvastatin, aspirin, and ticagrelor. #Hypertension - Continued metoprolol as above #Prediabetes A1c of 6.4. Nutrition was consulted and recommended lifestyle modifications #Tobacco use: Counseled on importance of cessation. Offered nicotine patch, but patient declined TRANSITIONAL ISSUES ====================== []recommend outpatient sleep study given obesity and snoring []cont counseling for smoking cessation []A1c of 6.4. Repeat A1c in 3 months New medications: ticagrelor 90mg BID, atorvastatin 80mg # CODE: Full, confirmed # E-contact: ___ (Wife) ___

She denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She received plavix 75mg and was started on a heparin drip but refused Aspirin. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Diabetes, Dyslipidemia, Hypertension CARDIAC HISTORY: - C.Cath ___ was done d/t inferolateral ST depressions in stress test. Suboptimal study. Target HR not achieved. . OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: 1. Degenerative arthritis 2. Parathyroid adenoma - s/p excision (___) 3. Uterine fibroid 4. target: ___ yo F h/o CAD (40-50% RCA/PDA in ___, h/o atypical CP who presented with chest pain and SOB. . # Chest pain and SOB: Mrs. ___ complained of ___ days of intermitient left lateral chest pain in mid-axillary line which was affected by arm-movement and position and accompanied by shortness of breath. She was started on Heparin in the ED under impression of ACS but on reassessment on the floor chest pain was not thought to be suggestive of angina-type symptoms and she had 3 sets of negative CE and no dynamic changes on repeated ekgs. PE was ruled out per low clinical probability (no desaturation, no tachycardia)and negative d-dimer. IV heparin was discontinued. The above chest pain in this ___ y/o woman with chronic musculoskeletal complaints was thought to be most consistent with musculoskeletal chest pain. Mrs. ___ is also known to have LVH and may have mild diastolic heart failure. She was found to have + 2 bilateral tibial edema on admission. She was well saturated on room air and did not have clinical or radiological signs of pulmonary congestion but her breathing did seem to improve somewhat after duresis with a single IV dose of Furosamide 20 mg. She subsequently saw a physiotherapist and was able to ambulate comfortably without drops in her O2 saturation. . # Leukocytosis: Mrs. ___ was found to have mild leukocytosis of 11.4 on admission to 11.7 on discharge with 81% PMN. She had recent URTI as well as recent steroid injections to her joints. Mrs. ___ was afebrile throughout her admission. Her UA was neg and no infiltrates were seen on CXR. No clinical symptoms or signs of bacterial sinusitis, skin infection or other bacterial infections were apparent. She will continue follow up including repeat CBC with her PCP. . # Hyperlipidemia: Mrs. ___ dyslipidemia is not well controlled on home regimen of Simvastatin 20mg. We recommended increasing dosage to 40mg daily and continuing follow up with her PCP. . # EKG findings: Mrs. ___ was found to have marginally short PR 0.1-0.12sec, with a wide deflection on her QRS downstroke. These findings are unchanged from base line. She has had some episodes of syncope in the past but these were always in circumstances of high ambient temperatures and poor fluid intake rather than sudden losses of concsiousnes and thus are likely secondary to dehydration and/or vagal reactions rather than tachycardia epsiodes. No further workup was deemed neccessary for these findings at this point. Continued follow up with her cardiologist was recommended at discharge. . # HTN - Mrs. ___ blood pressures were well controlled throught her hospital stay. Her home amlodipine and atenolol were continued. Inlight of diabetes and in the presence of frequent ankle edema and possible diastolic heart failure switching amlodipine to an ACE-I and possibly addition of a duretic may be considered in the out-patient setting. . # CAD - As discussed above Mrs. ___ current presentation does not seem to be related to her coronary artery disease. Medication for control of her CAD including atenolol and simvastatin were continued during this admission. Of note although Aspirin is indicated for secondary prevention Mrs. ___ refuses to take it due to associated gastric bloating in the past.

STRESS TEST INTERPRETATION: ___ yo man s/p IMI in ___ and CABG in ___, multiple PCIs with most recent performed in ___ with stent of mid-RCA was referred to evaluate an atypical chest discomfort. The patient was administered 0.142 mg/kg/min of Persantine over 4 minutes. No chest, back, neck or arm discomforts were reported by the patient during the procedure. No significant ST segment changes were noted from baseline. The rhythm was sinus with rare isolated VPBs. The heart rate and blood pressure response to the Persantine infusion was appropriate. Post-infusion, the patient was administered 125 mg Aminophylline IV. IMPRESSION: No anginal symptoms or ischemic ST segment changes to pharmacologic stress. Appropriate hemodynamic response to the Persantine infusion. Nuclear report sent separately MIBI INTERPRETATION: Left ventricular cavity size is moderately enlarged. Rest and stress perfusion images reveal a severe, partially reversible inferior and inferolateral wall perfusion defect. Gated images reveal hypokinesis of the inferior wall. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 40%. IMPRESSION: 1. Partially reversible, severe perfusion defect of inferior and inferolateral walls. 2. Moderate left ventricular dilatation. input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Patient recorded as having No Known Allergies to Drugs <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> SOB/Dizziness <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> None <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old male with h/o CAD s/p PCI with DESx2 to RCA in ___, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and who is POD 5 from lap chole who presented to the ED with SOB, dizziness and palpitations. He was found in triage to have a heart rate in the 180's accompanied by SOB and dizziness. By the time he was moved back to a room in the ED, his heart rate had decreased to the 80's. He reported that he began to have multiple episodes of palpitations this morning. He had dizziness that started in his chest and progressed superiorly to his head. He also endorsed shortness of breath but no syncope. He also endorses fevers to 100.3 in the afternoons since his recent lap chole. He is followed by Dr. ___ as ___ for paroxysmal Afib and he was initially diagnosed in the setting of heavy alcohol consumption. He now avoids alcohol, caffeine, and tobacco. He continues to have palpitations approximately once per month but his episodes usually last seconds. He was treated with a beta blocker in ___ but this was discontinued due to his lack of symptoms. He was restarted on his beta blocker after his NSTEMI earlier this year, but this was discontinued due to hypotension. In the ED, he had a CTA chest negative for PE, and a RLE ultrasound negative for DVT (on ED eval, there was some concern for RLE swelling). He was evaluated by surgery who felt there was no acute surgical issue but recommended a RUQ ultrasound to evaluate for biloma. On review of systems, s/he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. S/he denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> CARDIAC PAST MEDICAL HISTORY 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, + Dyslipidemia, + Hypertension 2. CARDIAC HISTORY: - NSTEMI in ___ s/p DES to RCA x 2, 60% mid LAD, LCX gives high OM1 wiht mild diffuse disease, RCA 70% of diffuse distal disease with focal 90% distal RCA - ___ MIBI without signs of ischemia - History of cardiac arrhythmia (patient's wife reports he gets yearly f/u at ___ Ctr) -CABG: None -PERCUTANEOUS CORONARY INTERVENTIONS: Cath ___: Coronary angiography in this right-dominant system revealed: --the LMCA had no angiographically apparent disease. --the LAD had a 60% mid-vessel stenosis after a large diagonal branch --the LCX had a moderately sized RI and a high OM1 with mild diffuse disease --the RCA had diffuse ectasia, with a proximal hazy 70% lesion and diffuse distal disease with a focal 90% stenosis in the distal RCA. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed elevated left-sided filling pressures, with LVEDP 18 mmHg. Systemic arterial systolic pressures were normal with SBP 135 mmHg. There was no gradient across the aortic valve upon pullback of the angled pigtail catheter from LV to ascending aorta. 3. Left ventriculography revealed inferobasal and mid-inferior hypokinesis, no significant mitral regurgitation, and measured LVEF 50%. 4. Stenting of distal RCA with Xience 2.75x28 posted to 3mm 5. Stenting of proximal RCA with Xience 3.5x18. -PACING/ICD: None Stress Test ___: ___ protocol, went 10.3 minutes on treadmill, 97% maximum predicted HR, no symptoms, had 0.5mm upsloping ST depression noted inferolaterally at maximal exercise that resolved post exercise. Interpretation: Left ventricular cavity size is normal. Resting and stress perfusion images reveal uniform tracer uptake throughout the left ventricular myocardium. Gated images reveal normal wall motion. The calculated left ventricular ejection fraction is 67%. Last Echo ___: The left atrium is normal in size. Left ventricular wall thicknesses and cavity size are normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with basal inferior hypokinesis. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 50%). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is moderately dilated at the sinus level. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: Choledocholithasis - s/p biliary stent in ___ and lap cholecystectomy 5 days ago HLD HTN <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father with MI at age ___. Three brothers with CABG and MI's in ___, ___, and ___. Son has had ablation for SVT in the past <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: 98.0 130/73 84 18 97%RA GENERAL: Awake, alert, in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. NECK: Supple with JVP of 7cm. CARDIAC: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. Regular rate, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. No thrills, lifts. No S3 or S4. LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, slightly tender to palpation diffusely. Well-healing laparatomy scars. No HSM or tenderness. Abd aorta not enlarged by palpation. No abdominial bruits. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. No peripheral edema and legs look about the same diameter. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 2+ ___ 2+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 08: 30AM WBC-8.5# RBC-4.11* HGB-12.6* HCT-37.9* MCV-92 MCH-30.6 MCHC-33.2 RDW-13.8 ___ 08: 30AM PLT COUNT-284 ___ 08: 30AM ___ PTT-31.2 ___ ___ 08: 30AM GLUCOSE-102 UREA N-10 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-141 POTASSIUM-4.2 CHLORIDE-102 TOTAL CO2-30 ANION GAP-13 ___ 08: 30AM CK-MB-NotDone ___ 08: 30AM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 05: 44PM TSH-0.21* ___ 06: 00AM BLOOD T4-5.7 T3-80 Free T4-1.1 ___ 08: 30AM ALT(SGPT)-81* AST(SGOT)-57* CK(CPK)-21* TOT BILI-0.7 DIR BILI-0.2 INDIR BIL-0.5 ___ ECG Normal sinus rhythm, normal axis, no ST changes ___ Chest Xray 1. Moderate amount of free air under the bilateral hemidiaphragms which could be attributed to recent abdominal surgery, although seems large in amount for 5 days post laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Clinical correlation is recommended. 2. Linear basilar atelectasis. Otherwise, no acute intrathoracic process. ___ CTA Chest 1. No pulmonary embolus or acute aortic abnormality. 2. Clear lungs. 3. Moderate amount of free intraperitoneal air, small amount of pneumobilia, and post-operative changes (including Surgicel) in the right upper quadrant, consistent with recent post-operative state. No overt abscess in the gallbladder fossa. ___ No right lower extremity DVT. ___ Liver and Gallbladder Ultrasound 1. Small, poorly defined aerosolized fluid in the gallbladder fossa, likely post-operative sequela, although developing abscess cannot be completely excluded. 2. Small amount of perihepatic fluid along the anterior margin of the liver. 3. Small amount of pneumobilia without biliary ductal dilatation. 4. Trace right pleural effusion. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Aspirin 325 mg PO DAILY Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY (Previously on atorvastatin but stopped due to increased LFTs) Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet prn <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Metoprolol Tartrate 25 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* 4. Nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tablet Sublingual as needed as needed for chest pain. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Diagnosis: Supraventricular Tachycardia Secondary Diagnosis: Coronary artery disease <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Good, vital signs stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with a fast heart rate which was thought to be a supraventricular tachycardia (such as atrial tachycardia or AVNRT). You were started on a medication called metoprolol to control your heart rate. You were seen by the electrophysiology team who felt that this was not concerning at this time and that metoprolol is the medicaiton of choice to treat your symptoms. You did not have a heart attack. You should follow-up with Dr. ___ as previously scheduled on ___. We have contacted Dr. ___ to let him know what has occurred during this admission. Additionally, as you were several days out from your cholecystectomy, the surgery team followed you during admission. You had an ultrasound of your surgical area which showed normal post-surgical changes. Check your blood pressure at home if you feel lightheaded or dizzy on your new medication. If your pressure is low, you should hold the medication or take a half dose until you see your cardiologist on ___. If you develop any chest pain, worsening palpitations, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, weakness, fevers, chills or other concerning symptoms, please go to the Emergency Room immediately.
target: ___ year old male with history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, CAD s/p PCI with DESx2 to RCA in ___, and recent laparoscopic cholecystectomy (on admission, he was post-op day 5) who presented to the ED with SOB and dizziness, found to have tachycardia on evaluation. #. Supraventricular Tachycardia: He has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation in the past and was not on any AV nodal blocking agent on admission. He had multiple episodes of tachycardia during this hospitalization, typically during exercise. He was monitored on telemetry during this episodes. He was seen by the electrophysiology team who felt that his tachycardia was supraventricular tachycardia. It was felt that the most likely rhythms were AVNRT vs. atrial tachycardia. He was started on metoprolol and this was uptitrated to 25mg po twice daily. His heart rate and blood pressure tolerated this medication without issue. After uptitrating this medication, he had no further episodes of SVT. If his episodes recur, he will likely need an EP study. #. Status post laparoscopic cholecystectomy: He had a laparoscopic cholecystecomy five days prior to admission. He had been having low grade fevers at home, and had temperatures to 99.5 degrees in the afternoons during hospitalization. He was evaluated by surgery who felt he was recovering well from his recent surgery. He had a right upper quadrant ultrasound which was consistent with post-operative changes. He had a negative urinalysis, RLE ultrasound negative for DVT, and he was encouraged to use incentive spirometry. #. Coronary Artery Disease: Patient is status post NSTEMI with DESx2 to the RCA in ___. He was started on a beta blocker as above, and continued on aspirin and Plavix. He was ruled out for MI as well. #. DVT prophylaxis: He was given pneumoboots for DVT prophylaxis, as the patient declined to have subcutaneous heparin. # Code Status: He was FULL CODE during this hospitalization.

History is obtained per son. She was recently admitted to ___ for a 1.5 week stay for pneumonia. She was discharged on ___ back to rehab. During the hospital stay, she was started on steroids, 40 mg daily, which has been tapered down to 17 mg daily per son, with a taper to a goal of 10 mg daily. At her baseline she is conversant, at times she is tangential. She is oriented to her location and to her year but may have difficulty with dates or months. She is at times forgetful and may be concerned that different family members are sick when they are not. She was seen by her son this morning at 7 or 8 AM and she was in her usual state of health. She had a bad dream and was concerned that her daughter was ill, but he reassured her that she was fine. He then went to work. he then received a phone call at around 9 AM that she had been slumped over to one side. He went to the ___ emergency room. She said he said when he saw her there she had no speech output, she had a right facial droop and had no movement on her left side. He noted that she was not regarding him. However after she received the TPA her speech and put increased and so did the movement on the left side. She then started looking and tracking him. She continues to improve but she is not yet at her baseline per son. Per outside hospital records, she was working in physical therapy this morning when she had a syncopal event and slumped over against the wall. She did not have a head strike, but she was noted to be nonverbal with left-sided weakness. So she was transferred to the emergency room. Telemetry stroke was called, and she was noted to have an ___ stroke scale of 9. She was initially somnolent with bilateral eyelid closure, however over the course of the exam she became more arousable, such that she would open her eyes to loud voice, and then complete 1 step commands with prompting. She initially was nonverbal but was able to later generate up to 2 word output. She was noted to have a right facial droop. She had negative Noncon head CT. Do not restart TraMADol until speak with your primary care doctor. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Extended Care Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Transient ischemic attack versus vasovagal syncope <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Confused - always. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were hospitalized due to symptoms of difficulty speaking, right facial droop, and inability to move your left side resulting possibly from a TRANSIENT ISCHEMIC ATTACK (TIA). This occurs when there is decreased blood flow to your brain. TIAs are temporary and resolve. The brain is the part of your body that controls and directs all the other parts of your body, so damage to the brain from being deprived of its blood supply can result in a variety of symptoms. It is worth noting that possible loss of consciousness while seated on the toilet can cause a separate syndrome called vasovagal syncope, and this also remains a possibility. The MRI did not show any evidence of stroke. Stroke can have many different causes, so we assessed you for medical conditions that might raise your risk of having stroke. In order to prevent future strokes, we plan to modify those risk factors. Your risk factors are: - High lipids in your blood (cholesterol and triglycerides) - High blood pressure We are changing your medications as follows: - We are holding pramipexole due to family concerns, but you could consider resuming half your home dose (0.125mg) in the future. - Reduced Memantine from 7mg to 5mg, a needed adjustment due to current renal function - Held Tramadol as there is a reaction between this medication and Trazadone, please continue to hold until you follow up with your primary care doctor. - Added Trazadone 37.5mg at bedtime to help you sleep. - Added Sulfameth/Trimethoprim DS (Bactrim) 1 tab twice daily for your urinary tract infection. - Added Miconazole powder 2% 1 application three times daily to treat your skin rash. - Added Plavix 75mg daily to help prevent future strokes. - Added Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime for high cholesterol. Please take your other medications as prescribed. Please follow up with Neurology and your primary care physician as listed below. If you experience any of the symptoms below, please seek emergency medical attention by calling Emergency Medical Services (dialing 911). In particular, since stroke can recur, please pay attention to the sudden onset and persistence of these symptoms: - Sudden partial or complete loss of vision - Sudden loss of the ability to speak words from your mouth - Sudden loss of the ability to understand others speaking to you - Sudden weakness of one side of the body - Sudden drooping of one side of the face - Sudden loss of sensation of one side of the body Sincerely, Your ___ Neurology Team
target: ___ is an ___ y/o F with a PMHx of HTN, ___ dementia, MI, CAD, TIA, rheumatoid arthritis, and PMR who was transferred from ___ for tPA care in the setting of R facial droop, left sided weakness, and aphasia concerning for stroke. She was last known well on ___ at 0900 and her NIHSS score was 9. She was given tPA at 1155. She had a negative NCHCT and was transferred to ___. On arrival, her NIHSS score was 7. Her exam here was notable for improvement in mental status and speech output as well as improved movement of LUE and LLE and with residual R nasolabial fold flattening. Her CTA showed a heavily calcified plaque at the L ICA origin causing lumenal narrowing. Given her elevated white count, likely due to recent pneumonia and/or prednisone taper, she had a CXR and U/A which initially showed no infectious process (see UTI below). She subsequently had an MR brain which showed no evidence of acute infarct or hemorrhage. Etiology of episode is unknown but thought to likely be anTIA vs. vasovagal syncope. She had a TTE which revealed mild dilation of the left atrium and hypokinesis of the inferior and posterior basal and mid walls without evidence of thrombus. Her EKG and troponin did not reveal concern for acute ischemia. Although an aberrant heart rhythm was not observed during this admission, it cannot be ruled out as the primary etiology. Her cardiovascular risk factors include mild hyperglycemia (A1c 6.6%) and significant hyperlipidemia (LDL 109 and ___ 673). She was started on Atorvastatin 20 mg (not a higher dose due to Zocor allergy), and Plavix was reinitiated. During her admission, she continued to have labile affect, paranoia, and encephalopathy. Due to concerns for a continued reduction in her baseline cognitive function, investigation into reversible causes of delirium were explored. Pramipexole was held initially (per OMR, held due to nightmares; per family, held because they wondered if it could cause paranoia); the initial plan was to restart at half the dose on discharge, but her family declined this. Infection screen revealed a urinary tract infection pan-sensitive enterobacter. She was started on Ceftriaxone and transitioned to Bactrim by discharge (to which the enterobacter was susceptible). Her sleep was very poor while inpatient and disruption of sleep/wake cycle likely contributed to her delirium. Therefore, trazadone was started to help her sleep at night. Her son reported that he observed an episode of bilateral hand/forearm shaking that lasted minutes during this admission. Therefore, an extended routine EEG was performed and then expanded to an overnight continuous EEG to better define anomolies observed. Her son reported that he observed an episode of bilateral hand/forearm shaking that lasted minutes during this admission. Overnight continuous EEG demonstrated generalized slowing and bifrontal and L to R frontal slowing; the latter could be due to subcortical disease. There was no epileptiform activity. By discharge, she was following simple commands intermittently, strength in all extremities were at least antigravity, there was paucity of speech but no dysarthria, she was still not oriented to person/place/time, but her acute confusional state had improved. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES [ ] F/u with PCP ___ ___ weeks after discharge, appointment still needs to be scheduled. [ ] F/u with cardiologist, appointment has been scheduled. [ ] F/u with neurologist, appointment has been scheduled. Call to get on cancellation list for earlier appointment. [ ] Continue prednisone taper. [ ] Pramipexole was held initially. A plan was made to restart at half of home dose (0.125mg) due to intolerable side effects, but her family declined. Will need to evaluate this medication effectiveness vs side effect profile. [ ] Memantine home dose was decreased to 5mg in the setting of a Cr 1.3, will need to readjust to current renal function [ ] Finish Bactrim course for uncomplicated UTI (started ___. Urine has speciated with sensitivities as above. [ ] Triglycerides were measured at 1079 and repeated measurement at 673. Atorvastatin 20mg was started (did not start higher dose due to prior reported Zocor allergy). Effectiveness will need to be evaluated and uptitration or augmentation as needed. [ ] Due to the unknown etiology of the symptoms leading to this admission, a cardiac ___ of Hearts monitor was ordered to investigate for episodes of Afib. Tel: ___ to arrange obtaining the monitor. (Has mild ___ on Echo). [ ] We started Trazadone to help her sleep. Therefore, her home Tramadol was held. Ramelteon can be initiated if she continues to have trouble sleeping [ ] Encourage PO intake given Cr of 1.3. Recheck Cr. [ ] TTE with hypokinesis (per discussion with cardiology, this is likely chronic). No trop elevation or ischemic changes on EKG. [ ] Vaginal yeast culture pending [ ] miconazole for rash beneath breast initiated. [ ] Monitor for improvement in MS with PO intake, Bactrim course, and improved sleep/wake cycle 1. target: Mr. ___ is a ___ M with history of HTN, HLD, and gout who is presenting with acute onset of chest pain that started the day of admission, found to have STE in inferior leads and proximal RCA occlusion s/p DES. . # CAD s/p STEMI: Pt was found to have inferior infarct on EKG, found to have proximal RCA occlusion on cath. On presentation, bradycardic and possible that SA node was involved. He is now s/p DES x1. The patient was maintained on integrillin drop for 18 hours post procedure. He was also started on ASA 325 daily, Plavix 75 mg daily, Atorvastatin 80 mg. He was continued on his home quinapril 20 mg daily and we started metoprolol 12.5 mg twice daily, which was later converted to metoprolol succinate 37.5 mg daily. The patient's lipid panel and A1c were normal. His home fibrate was also discontinued because the patient was started on atorvastatin. The patient had a TTE done post cath, which showed normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). There was borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, with no pericardial effusion. Overall, the echo showed mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global and regional biventricular systolic function. The patient was monitored on tele, which did not show any arrythmias, and set up with outpatient cardiology follow up. . # HTN: The patient was continued on his home quinapril, and was also started on Metoprolol during this hospitalization to optimize heart function. . # HLD: The patient was started on atorvastatin 80 mg daily and his home fibrate was discontinued. . # Gout: The patient was continued on his home dose of allopurinol ___ mg daily. .. Transitional Issues: - it is very important that the patient continue to take his aspirin/plavix - the patient has scheduled follow up with cardiology

target: ___ female with a history of multiple medical problems including type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and peripheral vascular disease was admitted with STEMI and had a bare metal stent placed to the left circumflex. . #. CAD now s/pSTMEI: Has multiple risks for CAD as detailed above. Her history of multiple episodes of epigastric pain appears most consistent with unstable angina. Patient had STE in inferior region but has left dominant system. Patient had BMS to LCx and now is chest pain free. She was continued on aspirin. Although patient was concerned about starting statin because of prior myopathy on different formulations, she agreed to try Crestor which she tolerated without adverse reaction. Fasting lipid panel showed LDL at goal. Started ACEI at low dose and no adverse reaction so increased to 5mg PO qday. Also started metoprolol at 12.5 mg PO BID which she tolerated well. . #Hematoma: Patient developed a 6x4 inch hematoma in right groin s/p cath. Her hematocrit droped initially and required 3 units of blood. Throughout this she was hemodynamically stable. Her hematocrit stabilized and hematocrit checks were done only daily. . #. Pump: Patient appears mildly hypervolemic on admission but difficult to assess secondary to body habitus and post cath flat positioning. Patient was previously on multiple anti-hypertensive agents at her rehab facility, including hydralazine, CCB, and nitrate. Patient was transitioned to ACEI and beta blocker regimen given that she was post STEMI. She had an echocardiogram that showed preserved EF and inferior/infero-lateral hypokinesis. Slowly resumed home furosemide after she was stabilized. . #. Rhythm: Patient remains slightly bradycardic but in normal sinus rhythm. Her heart rate improved after MI to be normocardic. She was monitored on telemetry via cardiology protocol without events. . #. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: A1C on admission was 6% which was at goal. Continued home insulin which was long acting Lantus in house, 20U at night. Did not require any insulin on sliding scale. Discontinued actos as it was not needed based on in house blood sugars. #. Vitamin D deficiency:Stable, continue vitamin D supplementation . #. GERD:Stable-continue prevacid . #. Glaucoma- continue xalatan eye drops and genteal eye drops . #. COPD: on 2L oxygen at baseline- continue xopenex, flovent, and atrovent . #. Anxiety: Continued 0.25mg PO prn alprazolam as patient was stable on home regimen. . #. Pain: c/o back pain chronically worsened with lying flat post cath, continue gabapentin 100mg PO ___, percocet prn pain. . #. Right ankle fracture: Seen by ___ and walking boot applied. Pt states this feels heavy but is able to participate in ___. She has WBAT on this ankle and pain is well controll with percocet prn.

target: ___ yo female with hx of CAD s/p PCI to RCA and OM who presents with exertional angina: # Chest pain: Patient admitted with recurrent chest discomfort, similar to previous anginal episodes with story classic for cardiac etiology ie stable angina. She denies any cough or fevers to suggest other etiology. EKG with some T wave flattening, cardiac enzymes neg x3. Her isosorbide dinitrate dose was increased to 120mg daily and was continued on atenolol and losartan, along with ASA and plavix. She underwent a treadmill stress test, that showed ischemic changes and anginal symptoms at maximal exertion ___ METS). She subsequently underwent cardiac catheterization, that per report did not show significant coronary artery disease and showed a patent RCA stent. # Pump: Patient appeared euvolemic with no concerning symptoms for CHF exacerbation. Most recent stress echo showed EF 62-69%. We continued home lasix 20 mg daily and monitored I/O on a sodium restricted diet. # HTN: Was well controlled on losartan, atenolol, lasix and was able to tolerate increased dose of isosorbide as noted above. # Hyperlipidemia: From admission lipids elevated, LDL 186. Given CAD, goal LDL would be less than 70, though pt has not tolerated statins due to myalgias and has not tolerated other agents such as omega 3 due to constipation. No anti lipid agent was started given difficulty in the past. # COPD: Continued Advair and PRN albuterol IH. # GERD: continue lanzoprazole TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== -Likely needs anti lipid agent as noted above

Active issues: # CAD: Patient has 3VD on cardiac cath but LCx occlusion was thought to be lesion responsible for inferior STEMI. Now s/p DES to LCx. No intervention to occlusion of RCA stent as appeared to be chronic. She also had lesion in LAD. Given 3VD, may benefit from CABG. Patient accessed via right radial artery. She was maintained on integrillin drip for 18 hours and was loaded with prasugrel. She continued on prasugrel 10mg daily and ASA 81mg daily. She was also continued on a statin. Patient will require outpatient work-up/discussion for CABG vs PCI for remaining CAD. # STEMI: See CAD above for additional details. Patient was taken to cath lab and LCx was stented with DES as it was thought to be cause of STEMI. Her cardiac enzymes were trended and peaked at 6.68. She was on an integrillin drip for 18 hours, loaded with prasugrel and maintained on prasugrel 10mg PO daily and ASA 81mg daily. She had no adverse events. # COPD: Hx of reduced RV function on echo in ___. No known CHF but with significant dyspnea which was thought to be related COPD. Repeat ECHO showed mildly depressed LV function with EF 40%. Dyspnea attributed to COPD. Continued home flovent and ipratropium nebs PRN. Continued to encourage/educate regarding smoking cessation. Patient initially reported smoking only 1 cigarette/day, then 3 cigs/day then admitted to continuing to smoke 2 ppd. Patient given nicotine patch Rx to facilitate quitting. # DM2: Patient was on significant amount of insulin at home. HgbA1C was 9.0 on admission. As patient was on an unusual regimen, ___ was consulted to facilitate appropriate adjustment and transition to improved regimen as an outpatient. We held home regimen and metformin and maintained patient on standing and ISS. In conjunction with ___, this was transitioned to a standing regimen for outpatient use (not sliding scale). Patient was restarted on home metformin at discharge. Chronic issues: # Hyperlipidemia: On simvastatin at home. Started on atorvastatin 80 mg po daily during this admission. # Hypertension: Normotensive. Patient initially on nitro drip. Restarted home metoprolol and added ACEi to regimen. # Neuropathy: Stable, but with significant symptoms. Nerontin increased from 300mg qhs to 600mg qhs. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr ___, You were admitted to the hospital for chest pressure. You were also found to have high blood pressure. During your stay, we closely monitored your heart with numerous ECGs and with lab tests. These tests indicated that you were NOT having a heart attack and that there was no permanent heart damage. In addition, we managed your pain with a medication called nitroglycerine through the IV. This medication also helped us to control your blood pressure. You underwent an exercise test to help see how much you can exercise without chest pain, and this test failed to show active heart damage, although you were not able to exercise intensely and you did have chest discomfort during the test. You also underwent an echocardiogram, or an ultrasound picture of your heart, which showed normal heart function and some expected changes due to your high blood pressure. Finally, you underwent cardiac catheterization, which showed no new blockages in your heart arteries as compared to the one you had in ___. All of the stents you have previously had placed are still open. In terms of your cardiac medicines, we changed some and kept others the same. We changed your isosorbide mononitrate (also called Imdur) to a dose of 150 mg every morning and none in the evening. We started a new blood pressure medication called hydralazine at a dose of 20 mg three times per day. We made no changes to your aspirin (still 81 mg every day), clopidogrel (also called Plavix, still at a dose of 75 mg every day), rosuvastatin (also called Crestor, still at a dose of 40 mg every evening), ezetimibe (also called Zetia, still at a dose of 10 mg every evening), fenofibrate (reduced from 160 mg to 145 mg every day), lisinopril (still at a dose of 40 mg every day), amlodipine (still at a dose of 10 mg every day) or spironolactone (still at a dose of 25 mg every day). We also contacted your regular, outpatient Cardiologist, Dr ___, to let him know how you were doing during this hospital stay. In addition, you tested positive for a minor, reversible kidney injury. We believe this was due to your high blood pressure. As your blood pressure was controlled, your kidney function returned to normal. During your cardiac catheterization, the blood flow to the kidneys was evaluated and determined to be normal. It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___ ___. Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish you all the best! - Your ___ Healthcare Team
target: Mr ___ is a ___ man with history of CAD s/p multiple stents (4 stents in all 3 major epicardial arteries, most recently to LAD in ___, diabetes mellitus on insulin, hypertension, dyslipidemia, HIV on HAART, GERD, and anxiety now presenting with a several day history of chest pain on exertion concerning for unstable angina. He experienced several episodes of similar chest pressure both on exertion and at rest, relieved by rest, with no ischemic ECG changes and negative cardiac biomarkers. He was also noted to be hypertensive on presentation with SBP = 190 mmHg. He was started on a nitroglycerine drip with resolution of chest pressure and reduction of SBP to the 130s mmHg range. He was also started on a heparin drip, which was maintained for 48 hours. Telemetry was without ventricular tachyarrhythmias or concerning events. He underwent an exercise stress test achieving ___ METS, without ischemic ECG changes, though he did experience ___ chest discomfort. Echocardiogram demonstrated symmetric left ventricular hypertrtophy, ___ ___, preserved biventricular systolic function with LVEF > 55 %, and no evidence of valvular disease. Coronary angiography on ___ showed no change from previous in ___ (Right dominance, mild LMCA irregularities, patent proximal and mid-vessel LAD stents with 50% D1 ostial disease, mild LCx irregularities with patent proximal stent and 40-50 % diffuse proximal RCA disease). Non selective renal angiography to evaluate for renal artery stenosis to account for his difficult to treat hypertension demonstrated no evidence of renovascular disease. No interventions were performed. Mr ___ was continued on his home cardiac regimen, including aspirin 81 mg PO daily, clopidogrel 75 mg PO daily, rosuvastatin 40 mg PO daily, ezetimibe 10 mg PO QDdailyfenofibrate (reduced from 160 mg PO dailyto 145 mg PO daily), carvedilol 50 mg PO BID, lisinopril 40 mg PO daily, amlodipine 10 mg PO daily and spironolactone 25 mg PO QDdailywhich he tolerated well. Isosorbide mononitrate was changed to 150 mg PO daily. Hydralazine 20 mg PO TID was started for goal SBP = 140 mmHg in this diabetic patient (ACCORD BP trial). # Acute Kidney Injury: Mr ___ presented with ___ = 1.2 uptrending to 1.5 on ___ (baseline 1.0). This was likely in the setting of hypertensive emergency (presented with SBP = 190 mmHg). Cr improved throughout hospitalization and he was discharged with Cr = 1.1. # Hypertension: Patient has history of difficult to manage hypertension despite numerous medications. Evaluation of renovascular with abdominal aortogram showed no angiographically apparent renovascular disease. We made modifications to his home regimen as detailed above. Chronic issues: # HIV - Continued home regimen during hospitalization, consisting of lamivudine-zidovudine 150 mg-300 mg PO BID, tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 300 mg PO daily, fosamprenavir 1400 mg PO BID and raltegravir 400 mg PO BID # Diabetes Mellitus - held home metformin (resumed on discharge) and continued home insulin glargine with lispro sliding scale # Hyperlipidemia - continued home regimen, consisting of rosuvastatin 40 mg PO QHS, ezetimibe 10 mg PO QHS. Fenofibrate 160 mg PO daily was reduced to 145 mg daily # GERD - continued home pantoprazole 40 mg PO BID # BPH - continued home tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO BID # Anemia - continued home ferrous sulfate 325 mg PO BID # OSA - Mr ___ used his home CPAP during hospitalization # Major Depressive Disorder, PTSD - continued home regimen, including venlafaxine XR 300 mg PO daily, mirtazapine 22.5 mg PO QHS and lamotrigine 200 mg QPM # Hypothyroidism - continued home levothyroxine 50 mcg PO QD # Anxiety - continued home lorazepam 1 mg PO QD PRN TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - New Medications: hydralazine ___ g po TID - Medication changes: isosorbide mononitrate 150 mg po QAM, fenofibrate 145 mg daily - Uptitrating hydralazine to 20mg TID for blood pressure control - Ranolazine not started during this admission due to drug-drug interaction with Venlafaxine XR and Fosamprenavir with risk for prolonged QTc # CODE: Full (presumed) # CONTACT: ___ (partner) ___

target: ___ with hx of CAD/NSTEMI (IMI, TPA ___ NSTEMI RCA BMS ___, last echo ___ showed EF 47%, PD with ___ Body Dementia was transferred from ___ with CP. Atypical sounding with clusters of CP lasting only les than a second with longest cluster ___ mins in duration without other cardiac sounding features and not similar to previous heart attack. Patient presented to ___ where they found ECG unchanged and was CE negative x2 and was discharged home. Patient had a further cluster and re-presented to ___ and was given nitro paste and was transferred to ___ for a second opinion with the possibility of cath. Here, ECG was unchanged and CEs were negative with flat MB. Was initially treated with nitro paste and latterly with IV heparin infusion which was stopped. Still having chest pain episodes but not distressed by these. Patient was still having similar chest pain episodes but not distressed by these and at much reduced frequency. Given concern of relatives despite having explained that symptoms were not cardiac in origin patient went on to an exercise MIBI which showed a moderate fixed inferior perfusion defect without evidence of reversibility. Patient was started on a trial of Imdur and was discharged on ___ with PCP ___ to address his atypical symptoms. . # CORONARIES/CP: Patient with history of CAD/NSTEMI (IMI, TPA ___ NSTEMI RCA BMS ___ and presents with very atypical chest pain which has been more frequent lately. Patient describes very transient episodes of "zings" of pain he has had since his first MI but only very rarely but now increased in frequency and having clusters. Very atypical sounding with clusters of CP episodes individually lasting less than a second with longest cluster of ___ mins in duration (with c20 episodes) without other cardiac sounding features and not similar to previous heart attack pain which was very different and classical. Of note, on the day of presentation, he had no chest pain when he was exerting himself doing yard work. Patient presented to ___ ___ where they found ECG unchanged and was CE negative x2 and was discharged home. Patient had a further cluster and re-presented and was given nitro paste and was transferred to ___ for a second opinion with the possibility of cath. Here he was started on a nitro drip and was pain free until am of ___. ECG was unremarkable and cardiac enzymes were negative here with flat MB. Patient had no rib or chest wall tenderness although given his odd history, these could be musculoskeletal. Patient was still having similar chest pain episodes but not distressed by these and at much reduced frequency. It is unclear as to the etiology of these pains but given the short duration this may be related to nerve irritability from his previous shoulder injury and subsequent infection. The pain sounds potentially neuropathic, and in this light gabapentin may be a possible consideration. Given concern of relatives despite having explained that symptoms were not cardiac in origin patient went on to an exercise MIBI which showed a moderate fixed inferior perfusion defect without evidence of reversibility and akinesis of the inferior wall and otherwise normal wall motion. Patient was therefore deemed safe for discharge from a cardiology standpoint. He was continued on aspirin, pravastatin at increased dose and metoprolol. Patient was started on a trial of Imdur for his symptoms and was discharged on ___ with PCP/cardiology ___ on ___. . # PUMP: Last echo ___ showed mild LVH and EF 47%. Calculated LVEF on myocardial perfusion scan ___ was 49%. Patient had no murmurs on exam or stigmata of CHF. PCP can consider starting ACEI in the community. PCP to consider repeat echocardiogram. . # RHYTHM: NSR. No new changes. . # ___ Disease with ___ Body Dementia: Patient followed by D ___. Mild clinical findings with R>L bradykinesia and cogwheeling. Continues to be active but more cognitive difficulty and occasional visual hallucinations recently per note. Last sinemet dose increase in ___. We continued home Carbidopa-Levodopa CR daily (although per Dr ___ had recommended increasing to bid but patient not taking this) and regular sinemet ___ 1.5 tabs 5x/day. We continued home pramipexole 1.5 mg tid. Patient had mild symptoms and managed on the treadmill well. Patient will be seen by Dr ___ on ___ where his PD medication dose will be addressed. . # HLD: Lipids were TGCs 37 HDL 55 LDL 83. We increased pravastatin to 40mg daily. . # HTN: BP was controlled in house. We continued home metoprolol tartrate at 25mg bid. PCP to consider starting ACEI as was stopped between ___ and ___ with no allergy reported. . # Hypothyroidism: We continued home levothyroxine.

He was working in his garden all day prior to admission and was sore and tired that night. He denied any chest pressure or shortness of breath, but was lightheaded and fell to his knees 2x. No LOC, no trauma. Later that night he awoke with "heart burn" which is his anginal equivalent. He also had chest pressure, shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He checked his FSBG and it was >400. He tried to treat his symptoms with Maalox without releif, but SL NTG gave him releif. He slept a while longer, again awoke with chest pressure, took SL NTG and went to ___. He was hemodynamically stable. He was given an inch of nitropaste with good releif of symptoms and was started on Heparin GTT. . Had cath in ___ with 3VD and decision was to medically manage. He does have a history of falls in setting of hypoglycemia, and as noted by Dr. ___ in his most recent note, he is mildly orthostatic with ~10 point BP drop from sitting to standing. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, and palpitations. . In the ED, initial vitals were 97.0, 87, 110/60, 18, 98% RA. ECG reassuring without ST elevations or depressions, inferior q-waves unchanged. Basic labs were measured and he was admitted for unstable angina. . <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: + Diabetes, + Dyslipidemia, + Hypertension 2. EKG: NSR, rate 90, LAD, inferior q-waves, T-wave flattening in lateral leads, no other ST or T-wave changes. Unchanged from prior . CARDIAC CATH: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated 3 vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA had 40% stenosis. The LAD had a long 90% proximal stenosis as well as focal 70% distal stenosis and a 60% stenosis of the major diagonal branch. The LCX had 90% stenosis in its origin. The RCA had diffuse disease with 50% proximal, 50% distal and 90% posterolateral stenoses. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics were performed. The systemic arterial pressure was elevated measuring 161/63mmHg. FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Elevated systemic arterial pressures. . CAROTID DUPLEX ___ Impression: Right ICA stenosis 40-59%. Left ICA stenosis <40%. . ECHOCARDIOGRAM ___ The left atrium is normal in size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior hypokinesis. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. Blood test show you did not have a major heart attack. Your pain is due to unstable angina. You underwent cardiac catheterization which showed that you have blocks in the arteries. Cardiac surgoens evaluated you and plan on having you return on ___ for CABG after the plavix washes out of your system. . Medication changes: - DO NO TAKE PLAVIX ANY LONGER - YOur metoprolol was increased to 75 mg per day - Please start taking lisinopril 5 mg daily for blood pressure and kidney protection. - Continue your other medications as prescribed . Call your doctor if you have recurrent chest pressure, shortness of breath, sweating, fevers, chills, dizzyness, lightheadedness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or other concerns.

Patient states that when he woke up this morning, that he just wasn't feeling right. He stated that he was mildly short of breath when laying down, but this improved when he sat up at the edge of the bed. He got up to go to the bathroom, and while he was walking there, developed chest pain that was located on the left side radiating to the right, ___, that was described as pressure-like and similar to other episodes he's had in the past with his stable angina, only now he had associated palpitations. The pain did not go away, even after taking 2 NTG and aspirin, which usually abates the pain. Nothing in particular makes the pain worse. The patient also noted associated nausea and some diaphoresis associated with the pain. The patient was still able to get up and drove to obtain a CXR at ___ that his doctor requested. The patient was worried about the pain, however, which was still present, and called his son, who met him at ___, and talked to his doctor, who called an ambulance. EKG before transfer showed atrial fibrillation with flipped T waves in V2, V3. He received ASA and NTG x 2 from EMS. . In the ED, VS were: 95.6 67 133/80 100%. EKG showed AFib ST depressions and TWI in V2-V5, which was new. Chest pain was ___, but got better with nitro and morphine. His initial Trop was negative and subsequently rose to 0.25, with MB rising from 75 to 190, MB 18, and MBI 9.5. He was given given 10 IV Dilt with some improvement in rate and ST depressions, given 30 mg PO Dilt, and came out of AFib. He was also started on Hep gtt, got Morphine IV x1, SL NTG tablet x1. Patient also had an aortic ultrasound which showed diameter 2 cm. Stool guaiac was negative. . On the floor, patient feels much better at this time. He no longer has chest pain or shortness of breath, and states that he is feeling back to his baseline. The patient notes some ankle edema that is chronic. He reports no recent travel or long car or plane trips. He has not been immobilized recently and has no history of malignancy. He reports no increased swelling, pain or redness of his legs. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. Prior inferior myocardial infarction. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ there are global ischemic appearing ST segment changes with ST segment depression and T wave inversion and ST segment elevation in leads III and aVF. Rule out active ischemic process and/or myocardial infarction. Followup and clinical correlation are suggested. CXR on admission: Stable small right pleural effusion and peripheral right lower lobe opacity. If the patient has no clinical evidence of sepsis or cardiac failure, pulmonary embolism could provide an alternative explanation for the radiographic appearance. This could be confirmed or excluded with a pulmonary CTA. Echo on ___: The left atrium is mildly dilated. The estimated right atrial pressure is ___. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with near akinesis of the inferior septum, inferior, and inferolateral walls and apex. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = ___ %). [Intrinsic left ventricular systolic function is likely more depressed given the severity of valvular regurgitation.] The estimated cardiac index is depressed (<2.0L/min/m2). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with moderate global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. Trace aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Moderate (2+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. The end-diastolic pulmonic regurgitation velocity is increased suggesting pulmonary artery diastolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. IMPRESSION: Left ventricular cavity enlargement with extensive regional biventricular systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD or other diffuse process. Pulmonary artery hypertension. Moderate mitral regurgitation. Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, regional left and right ventricular systolic function is now more depressed and the estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is now higher. CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS: The left ventricular ejection fraction is <40%, a threshold for which the patient may benefit from a beta blocker and an ACE inhibitor or ___. Based on ___ AHA endocarditis prophylaxis recommendations, the echo findings indicate prophylaxis is NOT recommended. Clinical decisions regarding the need for prophylaxis should be based on clinical and echocardiographic data. ECG ___: Sinus rhythm. Non-specific inferior conduction defect. Lateral ST-T wave changes raise concern for myocardial ischemia. Possible prior inferior myocardial infarction of indeterminate age. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ the findings are similar. CXR ___: As compared to the previous radiograph, there is no relevant change. Minimal right pleural effusion. Borderline size of the cardiac silhouette. Moderate tortuosity of the thoracic aorta. No evidence of pulmonary edema. No focal parenchymal opacity suggesting pneumonia. Two small rounded dense lesions at the level of the azygos arch could represent calcified mediastinal lymph nodes. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> ASA 325 mg PO qdaily Captopril 12.5 mg PO BID Furosemide 40 mg PO qdaily Imdur 120 mg PO qdaily Metoprolol succinate 100 mg PO qdaily Prilosec 20 mg PO qdaily Simvastatin 40 mg PO qdaily Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL PRN pain <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. PO once a day. 8. Simvastatin 40 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 9. Warfarin 2 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO Once Daily at 4 ___. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *3* 10. Amiodarone 200 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO once a day. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *3* 11. Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Tablet, Sublingual Sublingual PRN (as needed) as needed for chest pain: Take one every five minutes up to maximum 3 doses and call ambulance if pain not relieved. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary diagnoses this admission: 1. NSTEMI: Likely result of demand ischemia in the setting of AFib 2. Atrial fibrillation, started Coumadin, currently sinus rhythm on discharge <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ with chest pain and found to have damage to your heart due to a fast heart rate called atrial fibrillation. You were monitored and improved with slowing of your heart rate. You were started on a couple new medications to help prevent this rapid heart rate (Amiodarone) and also Coumadin, a blood thinner to prevent you from having a stroke as a result of the rapid heart rate. The following changes were made to your medication regimen: 1. START Coumadin 2 mg daily--a blood thinner to prevent strokes. You will need to have frequent INR (Coumadin level) checks and are being set up with a home visiting nurse to facilitate this. The results will be faxed to Dr. ___ ___ for any necessary adjustments. 2. START Amiodarone 200 mg daily. This is to keep you from going into atrial fibrillation. 3. CHANGE Captopril 12.5 mg PO bid to Lisinopril 2.5 mg daily, to reduce the number of pills you have to take daily. This may need to be increased over time depending on your blood pressure. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.
target: Patient is a ___ yo male with h/o CAD s/p MI, CABG and PCI in ___, systolic CHF 35%, AAA s/p repair presents with shortness of breath and CP that started this morning. Symptoms are concerning for ACS and PE primarily. Patient has low probability of PE based on history and physical, although he was tachycardic and short of breath. CXR was suspicious for PE if appearance could not be explained by CHF and other alternative diagnoses. Patient has apparent atrial fibrillation w/ RVR, which could make demand ischemia a possible cause of the patient's chest pain. NSTEMI is possible, but EKG changes resolved with rate control. Ultrasound of aorta was done and does not suggest aortic dissection. . #. Chest pain/shortness of breath: The main differential in this patient included acute coronary syndrome vs. demand ischemia from new atrial fibrillation vs. pulmonary embolus vs. atypical chest pain. Patient most likely had poor perfusion of his coronaries due to tachycardia, resulting in demand ischemia. TIMI risk score was 5. History and clinical exam suggested that pulmonary embolus was not likely. Troponin levels and CK-MB levels were elevated with T wave inversions and ST depressions evident on ECG, making NSTEMI likely. The patient was started on heparin drip, and patient was given aspirin, and started on his home regimens of statin, metoprolol, captopril and Imdur. The patient was not plavix loaded on admission. He was monitored on telemetry throughout hospital course. The changes on ECG and chest pain were found to resolve with rate control in the ED via diltiazem drip and nitroglycerin and morphine. His cardiologist, Dr. ___, was contacted, and said that he felt that catheterization would likely be non-revealing and that such a procedure should be avoided unless the patient developed chest pain again. Upon reaching the floor, the patient was chest pain free and remained so throughout hospitalization. He was weaned off the heparin drip within 36 hours of presentation. He occasionally got short of breath when ambulating, but this resolved upon resting, and improved throughout the hospital stay. Cardiac biomarker levels were found to resolve over the course of admission, after elevating originally. The patient was scheduled outpatient follow-up with his primary care provider upon discharge. . #. Atrial fibrillation: the patient presented with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and palpitations and shortness of breath, which was controlled with PO and IV diltiazem in the ED. After reaching the floor, the patient was started on his home dose of metoprolol and was maintained on a heparin drip originally. After heparin drip was stopped, it was discussed with the patient about starting anticoagulation as well as antiarrhythmic therapy. Risks and benefits of both treatments were discussed, and the patient and his son agreed that they would like to start treatment with coumadin and amiodarone. Patient was started on these two medications in the hospital, with monitoring of INR, which showed the level to be subtherapeutic on discharge. He was discharged on these two medications, with follow-up scheduled with his primary care provider on ___. The patient was scheduled to have a ___ check his INR level after returning home, with the results to be faxed to his PCP. Amidoarone was started at 400 mg TID in the hospital, then decreased to 200 mg daily upon discharge, in order to simplify the patient's home regimen. These checks will be continued indefinitely in the future, with management by the patient's primary care provider. The patient was in sinus rhythm on discharge, and without symptoms of palpitations. . #.Coronary artery disease: the patient was continued on his home regimen of Imdur, metoprolol, statin and captopril during hospitalization. His captopril was discontinued on discharge, and changed to lisinopril in order to simplify his home medication regimen, and for better control of his congestive heart failure. . #.Chronic systolic congestive heart failure: on admission, the patient was not started on his home dose of lasix, because his creatinine level was elevated from baseline. The patient was given gentle fluids, and creatinine improved, upon which the patient was restarted on his home lasix regimen. Daily weight and ins and outs were recorded, and BUN, creatinine and electrolytes were trended. The patient was on captopril BID upon admission. Echocardiogram was obtained while in the hospital, and showed worsening of the patient's ejection fraction. Chest x-ray showed improved pleural effusions from previous admission. It was decided to switch the patient from captopril BID to lisinopril qdaily to simplify home medication regimen and for better control of the patient's heart failure. . #.Hyperlipidemia: the patient was continued on his home statin dose during admission. . #. Chronic kidney disease: the patient's creatinine level was increased from baseline on admission, from 1.3 to 1.5. Gentle fluids were given, and the patient's creatinine decreased back to baseline. Levels were trended throughout hospitalization. . #.GERD: the patient was administered his home dose of omeprazole throughout admission. . #.Nausea: the patient reported feeling nauseous throughout the course of admission, and was discharged with ondanestron for control of this symptom. . #.Chest x-ray abnormality: X-ray taken before discharge showed possible calcified mediastinal lymph nodes, which may need to be followed up upon discharge with the patient's primary care provider.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> versed / fentanyl <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Abdominal pain, Dyspnea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old female with PMH significant for of CAD s/p NSTEMI in setting of HTNsive emergency (no history of PCI), Afib not anticoagulated, HFpEF, ESRD on HD, HTN, and severe COP2 on 2L who presented to OSH on ___ with epigastric abdominal discomfort, which radiated to her back. She did not have associated nausea, vomiting, melena, or diarrhea. She did not take any medications, including anti-hypertensives due to the pain. Upon arrival to the ED, her blood pressure was 200s/100s. She underwent a CT abd/pelvis with contrast. After the CT, she became acutely shortn of breath, hypoxic, and in Afib with RVR. She was placed on BiPAP, nitro gtt, and transfered to the ICU for close monitoring. The patient's clinical status improved quickly with these interventions. Labs were notable for troponin 0.03 and peaked at 0.41. EKG showed lateral ST depressions. The patient reported one instance of substernal chest discomfort during dialysis on ___, which lasted for "a long time". Cardiac cath showed mLAD 80%, pLCx 60%, mLCx 100%, diffuse irregularity of RCA with poor collateral flow from RPDA to dLCx. The patient was started on a heparin gtt and transferred to ___ for PCI. In terms of her abdominal pain, CT abd/pelvis showed dilation of the pancreatic duct without evidence of obstruction. MRCP revealed chronic biliary dilatation with air in the duct indicating previous sphinceterotomy. C difficile returned positive and the patient was started on PO vanc. Upon arrival to ___, the patient reports feeling anxious and scared. She denies any shortness of breath, orthopnea, peripheral edema, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Her chest pain resolved. She denies history of chest pain. In terms of her history of NSTEMI, she presented with feeling generally unwell. She denies prior cardiac catheterizations. Review of sytems: (+) Per HPI, all other ROS negative <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> - Coronary artery disease s/p NSTEMI in setting of HTNsive emergency, no cath done - Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation - ESRD on HD via Lt fistula (___) - Heart failure with preserved EF - Hypertension - Hyperlipidemia - Tobacco abuse - Severe COPD on 2L home O2 - Peripheral vascular disease - AAA - Cholelithiasis and choledocholithiasis s/p ERCP with stent placement - H/o C difficile in ___ - H/o pancreatitis - S/p cholecystectomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Parents with history of smoking <PHYSICAL EXAM> ADMISSION EXAM VS: 98.1 144/83 93 18 99% 2L. General: Appears comfortable, extremely thin, A+Ox ___ (not oriented to month), no acute distress. HEENT: NCAT, PERRL, EOMI Neck: Supple, JVD 7cm at 45 degrees. CV: Irregularly irregular. Normal S1, S2. SEM at LUSB. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally without wheezes, crackles, or rhonchi. Abdomen: +BS, soft, nondistended, nontender to palpation. Ext: Warm and well perfused. Left UE AV fistula with thrill and bruit. Pulses 2+. No peripheral edema. Neuro: CN II-XII grossly intact. Moving all extremities grossly DISCHARGE EXAM VS: 97.5 BP= 110s-140s/ 70s-80s HR ___ RR= ___ O2 sat= 96-97% Weight: 47.3<--46.3<--48.9<--47.4 <--46.3 (47.1) Is/Os - 0/anuric 8HR, 570/anuric Tele - Afib GENERAL: Frail appearing, thin elderly caucasian female, agitated, Oriented x3. HEENT: Sclera anicteric. MMM.
