Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, You were admitted to ___ because there was concern you were having a heart attack (called an NSTEMI). While you were here, we did a cardiac catheterization to look at the arteries around your heart. This showed that you had blockages in one of the arteries and we put two stents in to keep the artery open. It is crucial that you continue to take aspirin and Plavix (clopidogrel) to prevent your stents from clotting, which would cause another heart attack. You were continued on hemodialysis while in the hospital and this was used to manage your fluids and prevent you from going into heart failure. You completed a course of antibiotics (vancomycin) for a C. diff infection of your colon. We did CT scans of your chest because there was concern that you might have had some bleeding. It showed signs that your aorta bled a little because of its enlargement, but then stopped and contained itself. It did not show any signs of active bleeding but you should follow up with a vascular surgeon to make sure that everything looks good. We discussed the value of anticoagulation (blood thinners) given that you have atrial fibrillation and are at increased risk of stroke. You were very clear that you did not want to start warfarin. Unfortunately, no other blood thinners are safe given your kidney disease. We also made several changes to the medications used to control your heart rate and blood pressure. Your updated medications are detailed in your discharge medication list. You should review this carefully and take it with you to any follow up appointments. You will have follow up appointments with your cardiologist and a vascular surgeon for your aorta. After you finish rehabilitation, you will also be set up with an appointment with your primary care doctor. We expect your stay at the ___ to be less than 30 days. It was a pleasure taking care of you and we wish you all the best. Sincerely, Your ___ Care Team

She reports she manages her medications and has been compliant, though did initially present to ___ with systolic in 200's. Her medications were altered throughout admission due to the tachycardia and her pressures were well controlled on discharge. - Labetolol 300 mg TID as above - Isosorbide 10 mg TID - Verapamil 40 mg Q8H # ESRD: Likely secondary to poorly controlled hypertension. Nonspecific 7 mm right lower lobe nodule as detailed above, for which six-month follow-up CT chest is recommended. 2. He awoke in the morning feeling well, and worked on his car (changed a bulb, which involved laying under the car). Afterward he was returning to his house and he climbed up 10 steps when he had sudden onset of substernal chest pain. It was ___ severity, constant. He took SL nitroglycerin x 4 or 5 doses with no significant relief. He also took Tylenol and Maalox without improvement. He began to feel diaphoretic and uncomfortable, so called his family, who called EMS to bring him to ED. . Of note, he has generally been feeling well for the past few months. He feels his CHF has been under good control, with minimal edema, orthopnea or PND. However, he does report increasingly frequent exertional angina (typically with carrying groceries or walking longer distances) over the past few weeks for which he has taken SLNG a few times per week. . In the ED, his initial vitals were T 97, HR 104, BP 84/50, RR 16, O2 100% 2L NC. An EKG was performed and showed LBBB which met Sgarbossa criteria for evolving myocardial infarction. He was given full-dose aspirin and plavix-loaded and taken to the cardiac cath lab. There, cath revealed complete stenosis of his RCA graft (felt likely to be old, as wire could not be passed) and 99% proximal stenosis of his LAD graft. A drug-eluting stent was placed in this location with subsequent good flow noted. Given hypotension to SBP in ___ during the procedure, a balloon pump was placed. . On arrival to the floor, he reports feeling significantly better than earlier in the day and is chest-pain free. He is on 2L O2 by NC but denies SOB at rest. Cannot urinate from the supine position, but otherwise no complaints at this time. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. No dysuria. No paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. All of the other review of systems were negative. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: - Diabetes, + Dyslipidemia, +Hypertension 2. SVG to OM known occluded. 3. OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: - CAD s/p MI, CABG, PCI as above. - AAA s/p repair - Chronic systolic CHF (EF ___ - Hyperlipidemia - Chronic kidney disease (baseline creatinine 1.6-2.2) - s/p L carotid endarterectomy ___ - s/p cholecystectomy - GERD - hearing loss - Nephrolithiasis - Mesenteric ischemia (celiac artery stenosis, occluded ___ - Dizziness - Chronic pleural effusion s/p talc pleuridesis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father died of MI in ___ <PHYSICAL EXAM> On Admission: PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: HR: 63 BP: 112/50 O2: 100% 3L NC RR: 18 Gen: AxO x3 HEENT: no JVP, no carotid bruits, CEA scar on left CV: distant heart sounds, balloon pump Resp: CTAB anteriorly Abd: soft, NT/ND Ext: cool feet, 1+ DP pulses, no edema bilaterally Groin: L+R with no signs of ecchymosis or hematoma, slight oozing . On Discharge: afebrile HR: 56-65 BP: 102-117/51-59 ___ O2sat: 96-100%RA Gen: pleasant elderly man, AOx3 HEENT: no JVP CV: distant heart sounds but nl S1, S2, no murmurs Lungs: CTAB, no wheezes or rales Abd: soft, NT/ND Ext: cool feet, 1+ DP pulses b/l, no edema Groin: R-sided bruising and ecchymoses with small hematoma, L-side no hematoma or bruising <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 01: 30PM BLOOD WBC-8.3# RBC-3.84* Hgb-12.5* Hct-37.1* MCV-97 MCH-32.5* MCHC-33.6 RDW-15.0 Plt ___ ___ 01: 30PM BLOOD ___ PTT-22.2 ___ ___ 01: 30PM BLOOD Glucose-141* UreaN-63* Creat-2.9* Na-139 K-4.3 Cl-103 HCO3-22 AnGap-18 ___ 05: 35PM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.1 Mg-2.4 . Cardiac Enzymes: ___ 05: 35PM BLOOD CK-MB-22* MB Indx-10.4* cTropnT-0.52* proBNP-3678* ___ 02: 52AM BLOOD CK-MB-41* MB Indx-10.5* cTropnT-1.03* (PEAK) . Discharge Labs: ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD WBC-4.7 RBC-3.45* Hgb-11.0* Hct-32.6* MCV-95 MCH-31.8 MCHC-33.6 RDW-15.2 Plt Ct-95* ___ 05: 04AM BLOOD ___ PTT-25.6 ___ ___ 07: 00AM BLOOD Glucose-94 UreaN-44* Creat-1.9* Na-141 K-4.3 Cl-105 HCO3-27 AnGap-13 . Other Results: EKG ___ wide complex tachycardia - possibly idioventricular rhythm. Compared to the previous tracing of ___ wide complex tachycardia is now present. . Cardiac Cath (___) 1. Native three-vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Occluded SVG-RCA with possible stent fracture. 3. 95% ostial stenosis of SVG-LAD with 40% mid-stent ISR. 4. Successful IABP placement. 5. Successful PCI of the SVG-LAD with a 3.5 x 15 mm Promus DES. . TTE (___) EF 30%. Left ventricular cavity dilatation with moderate regional and global systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. Compared to the prior study dated ___, the left ventricular systolic function is similar. The right ventricle was not well visualized on this study. . Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> ST-elevation myocardial infarction corrected by a drug-eluting stent to the left anterior descending artery <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted for a heart attack and underwent a procedure in which they re-opened a blocked vessel in your heart. Your blood pressures were a bit low during the procedure so you were initially monitored in the cardiac intensive care unit while a balloon pump temporarily supported your pressures but that was successfully removed. You recovered from your procedure well enough to be sent to the regular hospital floor. . The following medications were changed during your hospitalization: 1. Stop taking your Pravastatin 40mg daily and instead start taking Atorvastatin 80mg daily to lower your cholesterol. 2. Please start taking Plavix 75mg daily. 3. While you were in the hospital, you were on Furosemide 80mg daily which is lower than your typical home dose. We would like for you to weigh yourself tomorrow morning after you urinate and write down the weight, this will be your baseline weight. Continue to weigh yourself on the same scale everyday. If you gain 3lbs in one day a) call Dr. ___ b) please take an additional 40mg of Furosemide (Lasix) that evening. 4. While you were in the hospital, we did not give you your daily Spironolactone 25mg because your blood pressures were low. Please do not resume taking your spironolactone until you have discussed this with Dr. ___. 5. Please stop taking your omeprazole and start taking ranitidine 150mg daily for your heartburn. . Please continue taking all of your other home medications.
target: Pt is a ___ with CAD s/p CABG and prior PCI who presented with chest pain and EKG changes consistent with inferior wall STEMI. . # Inferior Wall STEMI - Pt presented with chest pain and EKG changes consistent with inferior wall MI with peak CKMB of 41 and troponin of 1.03. Pt underwent urgent cardiac catheterization for revascularization. In the cath lab, initial angiography revealed an occluded SVG-RCA. Attempts were made to cross the occlusion with multiple wires. At this point, the patient's blood pressures dropped, so an IABP was inserted via the right femoral artery. They then accessed the left femoral artery, and repeat angiography of the SVG-LAD revealed a 95% stenosis at its ostium. They treated this lesion with PTCA and one drug-eluting stent. Final angiography revealed no residual stenosis, no evidence of dissection and TIMI 3 flow. Patient was transferred to the CCU for close monitoring. He was stable enough to be transferred to the floor. Post-procedure Echo showed EF of 30%, which was similar to his previous baseline. He was discharged home on an appropriate post-MI regimen including plavix, aspirin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Patient was trialed on a low-dose beta-blocker but he became quite bradycardic so it had to be discontinued. . # Hypotension - Patient became hypotensive during the procedure requiring placement of IABP. On arrival to the CCU, pt's pressures were quite stable, so pt was successfully weaned off the IABP on ___. Pt's blood pressures remained in the low 100s until the time of discharge, which is likely his baseline as he was mentating appropriately and clinically quite stable. . CHRONIC ISSUES . # Congestive Heart Failure: Repeat Echo on this admission showed essentially no change in pt's EF post-STEMI - it remained depressed at ___. Pt remained euvolemic throughout his stay, complaining only of some minor shortness of breath when lying flat. His blood pressures remained in the low 100s, so he could not be fully re-started on all of his home medications prior to discharge. His spironolactone was held and his lasix dose was decreased to 80mg daily at the time of discharge. He was advised to follow-up with his primary doctor to re-add/titrate these medications appropriately. . # Chronic Renal Failure: Pt's creatinine was initially elevated post-procedure likely from the contrast load he received, but it gradually returned to baseline without any further intervention. . # Atrial Fibrillation: Pt was consistently bradycardic and in sinus rhythm post-procedure. His bradycardia prevented us from successfully starting a beta-blocker on him. He was continued on amiodarone. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES . Pt needs to follow-up with his outpatient cardiologist regarding the appropriate doses of lasix and spironolactone he needs to be on given his low blood pressures. A beta-blocker should be started in him as well if his heart rate can tolerate it.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization with insertion of drug-eluting stent <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ yo M with PMHx sig. for PAD s/p aortofemoral bypass, CAD s/p 2 stents, stable angina, HTN, HL who presents after an episode of chest pain that started around 1 am this morning in the setting of an argument with the patient's girlfriend. The patient reports that the pain was sudden onset sharp substernal and left side, radiating to both arms, ___ in intensity. It was associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis and was reminiscent of prior episodes of CP from MI in ___. The patient call ___. He reports that the pain improved to ___fter 1 NTG. At that time the patient also experiened some nausea. . In the ED, initial VS were: 98.7 66 140/85 16 100. ___ set of CEs were negative. CXR showed no infiltrate. Pt received 2 mg of IV morphine and 1 more NTG SL. His pain resolved after morphine administration. Vitals on transfer were 76, 119/61, 14, 100RA. . Of note, the patient reports that he has been having anginal symptoms with exertion for some time. States he can walk several flights of stairs without getting short of breath. Notes that he has been completely non-compliant with his medications (Aspirin, Benicar, Lipitor) for ~9 months. . On evaluation on the floor, pt was alert, responsive and comfortable. target: The pt. is a ___ yo M with PMHx sig. for PAD s/p aortofemoral bypass, CAD s/p 2 stents, stable angina, HTN, HL who p/w CP. . # CORONARIES: Given multiple risk factors (HTN, HLD, smoking, family history), prior history of CAD. MI s/p stenting of LCx and RCA, non-compliance with medications concern for ACS or stent re-stenosis despite atypical pain. EKG with no acute ischemic changes. The patient was monitored on Telemetry, given ASA 325mg and Atrovastatin 80mg daily as well as Metroprolol tartate. Ruled out for MI by negative cardiac biomarkers. Stress MIBI revealed a reversible inferior defect concerning for a new lesion or stent re-stenosis. Cardiac catheterization was performed and revealed a two vessel coronary artery disease of the RCA and LAD, moderate systemic arterial hypertension. A drug eluting stent was placed in the mid LAD. Throughout hospitalization, the patient was maintained on heart healhthy diet. Extensive discussion with the patient about the critical improtance of being compliant with his medications was held by several individuals. . # PSYCHIATRIC CONDITION: The patient became agitated after he was not allowed to eat during the completion of MI rule out. He was convinced at that time not to sign out against medical advice due to the high risk of irreversible heart damage and death due to MI. The patient became again extremely agitated almost immediately upon leaving cardiac cathteterization lab in the setting of his belongings being moved to another room by staff member "without his permission." He was demanding to leave right away and to sign out AMA. However, as he just received a large dose of sedating medications, he was deemed not to have decision-making capacity to sign out against medical advice that time. Code purple was called and the patient had to be restrained. Upon further questioning, the patient reported that he has been diagnosed with schizophrenia in the past during his military service, but that he hasn't been on antipsychotic medications for many years and has not followed up with a psychiatrist. By the following morning, the patient was not longer agitated. He expressed understanding of the critical importance of being compliant with his medications including Plavix and Aspirin, and the risk of death that may result as a consequence of non-compliance. He was given contact information by Dr. ___ follow up closely with him. It was also recommended to the patient to follow up with a psychiatrist for management of his psychiatric condition. . # PUMP: The patient with history of prior MI, but no Echo on file. LVEF of 48% on stress MIBI. . # RHYTHM: the patient remained in normal sinus rhythm throughout on Telemetry. . # Hypertension - the patient was normotensive. He was maintained on Metoprolol tartate 25mg bid and was prescribed Metoprolol succinate 50mg daily upon discharge. . # Hyperlipidemia: the patient was prescribed Lipitor 80mg daily. . # PAD - s/p aortofemoral bypass, currently stable. Aspirin, Plavix and Lipitor were prescribed as above. .

target: ___ year old ___ female with HTN, PAD, PAF, severe CAD and h/o stable angina status post MI in ___, CABG in ___ (LIMA-LAD, SVG-OM-OM, SVG-RPDA), PCI to native RCA ___, severe right femoral artery pseudoaneurysm following cardiac catheterization in ___ presenting with "throat burning/jaw pain" similar to anginal equivalent. . #. CAD: Pt presented with throat burning/jaw pain consistent with anginal equivalent. At baseline, pt has chronic stable angina but reported that this episode was not alleviated by 3 sublingual nitroglycerin tabs. ACS was unlikely given EKG and negative cardiac enzymes x 3. EKG was unchanged from prior (LVH with secondary repolarization changes, no ST-T wave changes). We discussed with the patient that our recommendation would be to undergo a stress test. However, pt adamantly refused stress test even after risks and benefits were thorougly explained. She was continued on medical management with beta blocker, aspirin, statin, imdur, and ranolazine. She was discharged home with close ___ with her cardiologist. . #. CHF: Prior cath from ___ showed LVEF: > 65%. Patient appeared euvolemic on exam. CXR showed no evidence of CHF. Home dose of lasix was continued without any complications. . #. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation: Pt was found to be in sinus rhythm with rate in the ___ throughout hospital stay. She was continued on her beta blocker. Her coumadin was held because INR was elevated to 4.7 on admission. By discharge, it was 3.8. At discharge, she was instructed to have her INR rechecked on the day after discharged. Orders were written for this INR result to be faxed to the patient's PCP. Additionally, she was instructed to resume her coumadin two days after discharge (___) at a lower dose (2 mg daily, down from 3 mg daily). Her primary care physician's office was made aware of this plan. . #. UTI: Urinanalysis showed ___ WBC, small leuks, and many bacteria. She was started on a total 3 day course of ciprofloxacin for presumed UTI. Urine culture was still pending on discharge and should be followed-up after discharge.. . #. Acute on chronic renal failure: On admission, Cr was elevated to 2.3 (up from baseline ~1.7). Appeared to be pre-renal given BUN/Cr ratio. Cr improved to 2.0 on discharge with improved fluid intake. She was instructed to see her PCP soon to have her creatinine rechecked.

However, after comaprison with previous CXR, opacity was thought most likely ___ CHF. Therefore she was started on a nitro drip. EKG showed sinus tach normal axis QTC 510, no STEMI. The patient describes intermittent dyspnea on exertion, i.e. climbing up and down the stairs or when feeling anxious. She recalls one isolated episode of chest discomfort that occurred at rest several weeks ago, described as a burning substernally, lasting several minutes before resolving spontaneously. Uses mutiple pillows at baseline. . Recently in the beginning of ___, the patient was hospitalized for flash pulmonary edema at ___. At that time, she was ruled out for ACS and was provided with lasix and bipap, which greatly helped her symptoms. At that time, BP's were noted to be in the 160-220 range. BNP was 5314. As part of her evaluation she underwent an echo which revealed normal LV function. Stress testing was completed where she was only able to exercise 2.5 minutes, stopping due to dyspnea and wheezing. Imaging revealed possible anterior ischemia. She went home on her usual atenolol dose of 150 mg qd and with the addition of lisinopril 10 mg qd. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had trouble breathing and was transferred to ___ for a cardiac catheterization. The catheterization found one severe blockage in your left circumflex artery and a drug eluting stent was placed to keep the artery open. There was another less severe blockage that was not treated but your new medicines will help to keep it open. It is extremely important that you take a full dose aspirin and Clopidogrel (Plavix) every day for at least one year. Do not stop taking aspirin and plavix or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ that it is OK to do so. The shortness of breath that you experienced in the last month seems to be because of a stiff heart that is called diastolic congestive heart failure. This is caused by your high blood pressure and can be prevented with the medicines you are taking. It is very important to watch for signs of fluid retention in your hands, feet and trouble breathing with exercise. You will also need to weigh yourself every morning, call Dr. ___ weight goes up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 5 pounds in 3 days. . We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. INCREASE the Lisinopril to 40 mg daily to lower your blood pressure 2. START taking Amlodipine to lower your blood pressure 3. STOP taking Atenolol, take Metoprolol instead to lower your heart rate 4. START taking clopidogrel (plavix) every day to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing a heart attack. Continue to take 4 baby aspirin every day with the clopidogrel for the same reason. 5. START taking nitroglycerin as needed if you have chest pain at home or if you become short of breath suddenly. Take one tablet under your tongue, wait 5 minutes, then take another tablet. Call Dr. ___ the nitroglycerin helps the chest pain or trouble breathing, call ___ if you feel it is worsening. 6. START taking Atorvastatin to lower your cholesterol and prevent the blockages in your arteries from getting worse. 7. START taking Furosemide daily to prevent fluid retention.
target: ___ yo F with h/o HTN, COPD, nicotine/EtOH abuse admitted with acute dyspnea found to have pulmonary edema, now clinically stable s/p cardiac cath with DES placed to LCx. . # CORONARY ARTERY DISEASE: Patient has h/o angina, HTN, and smoking. On admission she had no EKG changes or significantly elevated cardiac enzymes. She is now s/p cardiac cath which showed 70-80% LCx occlusion at OM bifurcation, and ___ proximal LCx occlusion. DES was placed to LCx. Patient also found to have elevated left-sided pressures (LVEDP 30) during cath. Patient was treated with ASA 325mg PO daily, lisinopril 30mg PO daily, atorvastatin 20mg PO daily, clopidogrel 75mg PO daily, and metoprolol tartrate. She was initially on NTG gtt on admission to CCU which was tapered. Patient did complain of mild chest/neck discomfort on evening of ___, with EKG showing diffuse TWI but negative cardiac enzymes x2. Most likely noncardiac chest pain. She remained clinically stable and was called out to the floor on ___. She was discharged the next day on ___ after BP control was achieved. . # DYSPNEA: multifactorial etiology. Patient has pulmonary edema and elevated BNP, with cardiac cath showing LVEDP 30. Pulmonary edema may have occurred in the setting of hypertension and myocardiac ischemia causing diastolic dysfunction. She does not have any wall motion abnormalities on echo so myocardial infarction less likely etiology. In addition, patient has underlying COPD which may be contributing. Because she received IV contrast in the cath lab, patient given slow IV fluids in CCU, and was also given Lasix 20mg IV to start diuresis. She diuresed >2L to this, and was then started on Lasix 10mg PO daily. Pt also treated with lisinopril and metoprolol. . # COPD - does have poor air entry but no significant wheezes on exam, so no need for systemic therapy. Treated with albuterol and tiotropium nebs. . # Metabolic Acidosis - On admission pt had gap acidosis with pH 7.3 with lactate of 4. Acidosis has now resolved, with pH 7.42 and lactate 1.2. Possible that in the setting of flash pulmonary edema, she had tachycardia with underlying diastolic dysfunction and consequent low cardiac output state, resulting in lactic acidosis; this seems to have resolved. . # HTN - treated with lisinopril + metoprolol. Also on NTG gtt while in CCU. Upon transfer to the floor, BP was still elevated to SBPs in the 170s and amlodipine was added. . # Depression - continued home fluoxetine and ativan PRN . # Alcohol abuse - did not score on CIWA.

Incidental 5 mm sub solid nodule in the right lower lobe, see recommendations below. RECOMMENDATION(S): For an incidentally detected single ground-glass nodule smaller than 6mm, no CT follow-up is recommended. See the ___ ___ Guidelines for the Management of Pulmonary Nodules Incidentally Detected on CT" for comments and reference: ___ CARDIAC CATH ___ 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease with subtotal vs. recanalized chronic total occlusion of the mid RCA and acute thrombosis of the mid LAD resulting in her acute myocardial infarction. 2. Normal systemic arterial pressure. 3. Successful primary percutaneous coronary intervention for acute anterior myocardial infarction with deployment of a drug-eluting stent in the mid LAD. 4. The patient had transient supraventricular tachycardia and ventricular tachycardia (? Wire/catheter related) during the procedure. 5. Findings discussed in person with the ___ Attending and Fellow. Recommendations 1. Routine post-TR Band care. 2. ASA 81 mg daily for life. Daily dose of ASA should not exceed 100 mg while on ticagrelor. Patient advised to avoid higher dose ASA or NSAIDs. 3. Ticagrelor 90 mg BID for ___ year for post-MI secondary prevention and to prevent stent thrombosis. 4. Tirofiban infusion until the current bag/bottle runs out (~4 hours). 5. Cycle troponin-T, CK-MB and platelets (given use of a GP IIb/IIIa inhibitor). 6. Echocardiogram to assess LVEF and need for oral anticoagulation and/or ACE-inhibitor if large anterior MI with anterior and apical akinesis. 7. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against CAD and acute myocardial infarction, including high dose statin, beta-blocker, and 8. Smoking cessation. 9. Referral to outpatient cardiac rehabilitation. 10. Arrange for cardiology follow-up through the Partners system. 11. ___ medical therapy with option for CTO PCI of the RCA if objective evidence of residual inferior ischemia despite good ___ medical regimen. ___ TTE The left atrial volume index is normal. There is normal left ventricular wall thickness with a normal cavity size. A left ventricular thrombus/mass cannot be excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is moderatelymdepressed secondary to extensive apical hypokinesis with focal apical akinesis. The visually estimated leftmventricular ejection fraction is 35%. There is no resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient. Normal right ventricular cavity size with normal free wall motion. The aortic sinus diameter is normal for gender with normal ascending aorta diameter for gender. The aortic arch diameter is normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear structurally normal. There is no aortic valve stenosis. There is no aortic regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets appear structurally normal with no mitral valve prolapse. There is trivial mitral regurgitation. The tricuspid valve leaflets appear structurally normal. There is trivial tricuspid regurgitation. There is no pericardial effusion. RECOMMEND: If clinically indicated, a follow-up TTE with an endocardial border definition agent (e.g.Lumason) is suggested for definitive exclusion of apical thrombus. ___ TTE Focused study using echo contrast to evaluate apical aneurysm for thrombus. No thrombus or mass is seen in the left ventricle. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list may be inaccurate and requires futher investigation. 1. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM RX *atorvastatin 80 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 2. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY RX *clopidogrel 75 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 3. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO BID RX *metoprolol succinate 25 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth every 12 hours Disp #*60 Tablet Refills: *0 4. Nicotine Patch 21 mg TD DAILY RX *nicotine 21 mg/24 hour (28)-14 mg/24 hour (14)-7 mg/24 hour (14) please apply 1 patch daily as directed daily Disp #*1 Package Refills: *0 5. Nitroglycerin SL 0.3 mg SL Q5MIN: PRN chest pain RX *nitroglycerin 0.3 mg 1 tablet(s) sublingually every 5 minutes as needed for chest pain Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 6. Rivaroxaban 20 mg PO DAILY RX *rivaroxaban [Xarelto] 20 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY 8. Multivitamins 1 TAB PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> # ST elevation Myocardial infarction # Coronary artery disease # Ischemic cardiomyopathy: LVEF 35% # Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia # Apical Hypokinesis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___! WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? -========= - You were admitted because you had a heart attack WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL? -- - You were admitted to the hospital because you had chest pain. You were found to have had a heart attack. Your heart arteries were examined (cardiac catheterization) which showed a blockage of one of the arteries. This was opened by placing a tube called a stent in the artery. You were given medications to prevent future blockages. - It is very important to take your aspirin and Clopidogrel (also known as Plavix) every day. - These two medications keep the stents in the vessels of the heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. - If you stop these medications or miss ___ dose, you risk causing a blood clot forming in your heart stents and having another heart attack - Please do not stop taking either medication without taking to your heart doctor. - You are also on other new medications to help your heart, such as atorvastatin and metoprolol. - You are also being started on a medication to protect you from stroke since you had a heart attack affecting the motion of your heart, Xarelto (Rivaroxaban), which you should take every day at the same time with your largest meal - You are being discharged with a Life Vest (wearable defibrillator). It is important that you wear it every day as it can detect and treat fatal arrhythmias. You need to wear this for at least three months. Do not remove until instructed to do so by a cardiologist. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? --== - Follow up with your doctors as below - PLEASE MAKE AN APPOINTMENT WITH A CARDIOLOGIST OR ASK YOUR PCP FOR ___ REFERRAL - If you cannot find a cardiologist within 2 business days, please call ___ for an appointment with ___ ___ - Take all of your medications as prescribed - Return to the hospital if you have chest pain, shortness of breath and if your Life Vest alerts you. Thank you for allowing us to be involved in your care, we wish you all the best! Your ___ Healthcare Team
target: Ms. ___ is a ___ with PMHx notable for tobacco abuse, with current use, who presented with STEMI found to have two vessel coronary artery disease with acute thrombosis of the mid LAD s/p DES and chronic total occlusion of the mid RCA with recannulized/collateral flow. Her hospital course was complicated by paroxysmal SVT and a newly depressed EF with apical hypokinesis in the setting of her acute anterior MI. # STEMI: # CAD: Patient presented with STE in leads I, aVL, V2-4 and initial troponin elevation to 0.05. CTA chest was negative for pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection. Patient was bolused and maintained on a heparin gtt, given SL nitroglycerin x 2 and was started on a nitroglycerin gtt with relief in symptoms. She was taken from the ED directly to the cath lab. She underwent LHC via right radial access and was found to have a complete occlusion of the LAD (culprit lesion) and a chronic total occlusion of the RCA with recannulized flow. A DES was placed in the LAD and patient was continued on tirofaban. The procedure was well tolerated however was complicated by self limited atrial tachycardia. She was subsequently started on DAPT aspirin and ticagrelor. TTE showed a newly depressed EF of 35% and apical hypokinesis. Patient was subsequently initiated on triple therapy as prophylaxis against LV thrombus. Due to elevated bleeding risk with ticagrelor in addition to systemic AC, patient was switched to aspirin, Clopidogrel (loaded ___ and rivaroxaban. To treat her CAD, she was continued on aspirin, atorvastatin and metoprolol succinate. Troponins peaked at 3.76 and MB at 243. Patient will follow up with new cardiologist in ___ system or ___ if she cannot find a cardiologist. # Apical Hypokinesis: Lumason TTE without evidence of apical thrombus/mass. However given apical hypokinesis with focal akinesis, and low risk of bleeding, patient was started on systemic anticoagulation in addition to DAPT as prophylaxis against LV thrombus. She also had an episode on telemetry that was suspicious for Atrial Fibrillation, which was thought to be another indication for anticoagulation. Patient was switched from ticagrelor to clopidogrel to decrease bleeding risk on triple therapy. She was continued on rivaroxaban 20mg daily, clopidogrel 75mg daily, and aspirin 81mg. Systemic anticoagulation, in addition to DAPT, should be continued for a minimum of 1 month after that she can considered to have aspirin discontinued although continuing triple therapy for up to 3 months is reasonable if she is tolerating well. At 3 months, she should have repeat transthoracic echocardiogram and evaluation of any arrhythmia on the lifevest. If no arrhythmia is documented, and there is no LV thrombus, she can remain on DAPT (i.e. discontinue rivaroxaban). If there is need for ongoing anticoagulation, aspirin can be discontinued at that time and she can continue double therapy with ticagrelor (switch from clopidogrel) and rivaroxaban. # HFrEF: Newly depressed EF 35%. TTE notable for apical hypokinesis with focal apical akinesis, however no thrombus/mass on Lumason TTE. RV had normal free wall function. Given EF 35%, young age, and large anterior wall MI patient was given a Life Vest wearable defibrillator. She was continued on metoprolol to control SVT however due to low normal systolic blood pressures, ACEinh/spironolactone could not be started prior to discharge. # SVT: Hospital course complicated by SVT with heart rates in the 120-150s. Rhythm was suspicious for AVNRT. This resolved with beta blocker therapy that was ulitimately uptitrated to metoprolol succinate 25mg BID. There was concern for short burst of atrial fibrillation and patient will be monitored with the Life Vest for arrhythmias. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== [ ] ___ revealed a chronically occluded RCA with recanalized and collateral flow that was not intervened upon. Following revasculariztion of the LAD, it appears that collateral flow to RCA is also improved. Given residual CAD this can be considered for intervention pending follow-up TTE and consideration of an outpatient stress test to evaluate for residual ischemia. [ ] Discharged on triple therapy for new DES and LV thrombus prophylaxis in the setting of apical hypokinesis with potential paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Patient should have at least one month of triple therapy with DAPT (asa, Clopidogrel) + DoAC given her significant infarct and residual disease with an overall low bleeding risk. After one month then may consider stopping aspirin. If aspirin is stopped could consider switching back to ticagrelor with rivaroxaban given large territory anterior MI. Systemic anticoagulation should be continued for three months for LV thrombus prophylaxis. Continuing beyond three months may depend on Afib diagnosis/burden and bleeding risk. [ ] Newly depressed EF of 35%. Given young age and large anterior MI, patient was discharged with Life Vest wearable defibrillator. She should have a repeat TTE in ___ weeks to reassess EF and subsequent TTE in 90 days to evaluate for need for ICD unless patient satisfies indication for an ICD prior to that. [ ] Patient noted to have multiple episodes of SVT during and following her coronary intervention. Following adequate beta blockade these episodes resolved. Of note telemetry review revealed an interval that appeared consistent with atrial fibrillation. Patient will be discharged with life vest that can be reviewed for further interrogation of rhythm. She was discharged on metoprolol succinate 25MG BID daily and on systemic anticoagulation. [ ] Patient was counseled on smoking cessation. She was prescribed a nicotine patch during her hospitalization and at time of discharge. She may benefit from additional resources as an outpatient. [ ] Outpatient cardiac rehabilitation when cleared by Cardiologist

No orthopnea, leg edema, or cough. Lost 55 lbs in past year (intentionally, and also ___ decreased appetite from depression). No fevers, chills, night sweats, pre-syncope, dysuria, diarrhea. Successful direct stenting of ostium of ___ (overlapping distally with graftmaster) with 4.0x15mm Vision bare metal stent postdilated to 4.5mm. 3. EXTREMITIES: No edema, no femoral bruits ___. pulses Right: DP 1, ___ 1 Left: DP 1+, ___ 1+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION ___ 03: 33PM WBC-11.1* RBC-5.15 HGB-16.5 HCT-46.4 MCV-90 MCH-32.0 MCHC-35.4* RDW-13.3 ___ 03: 33PM NEUTS-71.0* ___ MONOS-4.5 EOS-1.8 BASOS-0.4 ___ 03: 33PM ___ PTT-21.4* ___ ___ 03: 33PM GLUCOSE-100 UREA N-14 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-136 POTASSIUM-3.6 CHLORIDE-103 TOTAL CO2-17* ANION GAP-20 ___ 03: 33PM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 09: 30PM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 05: 45AM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 06: 35AM BLOOD Triglyc-193* HDL-48 CHOL/HD-4.0 LDLcalc-107 . DISCHARGE LABS ___ 06: 15AM BLOOD WBC-8.0 RBC-4.82 Hgb-15.3 Hct-44.2 MCV-92 MCH-31.7 MCHC-34.6 RDW-12.9 Plt ___ ___ 06: 15AM BLOOD Glucose-109* UreaN-18 Creat-0.8 Na-139 K-4.0 Cl-103 HCO3-29 AnGap-11 ___ 06: 15AM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-4.4 Mg-2.1 . . ................................................................ IMAGING Cardiac perfusion scan IMPRESSION: 1. Large left ventricle in rest and stress with calculated EF of 37%. 2. Fixed perfusion defect in the inferior wall. ......................................................... Coronary CT angiogram ___ CTA CHEST: The opacification of the pulmonary arteries is uniform with no evidence of pulmonary embolism till the subsegmental level bilaterally. Note is made that the very apices of the lungs were not included in the field of view. . Several mediastinal lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged. The imaged portion of the airways is patent. There is no pericardial or pleural effusion. The aorta is normal in diameter with minimal calcification and some degree of atherosclerosis at the level of the aortic arch. The imaged portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable. . The imaged portion of the lungs demonstrates no evidence of abnormalities except for bilateral subpleural basal areas of atelectasis. . There are no bone lesions worrisome for infection or neoplasm. . The post-sternotomy changes are unremarkable. Stranding of the anterior mediastinum related to prior surgery is unremarkable with no evidence of collections or current infectious process within the limitations of the study technique evaluation. . CTA CORONARY ARTERIES: . The native coronary arteries demonstrate extensive areas of calcification and atherosclerosis. . LM/LAD: Left main coronary artery bifurcates into LAD and circumflex. Proximal and mid portion of native LAD are heavily calcified and occluded. LIMA bypass graft is creating anastomosis with distal LAD that appears to be patent with some distal calcifications that do not cause significant narrowing. . D1 - The proximal portion of the first diagonal brunch is occluded. The artery bifucates into two large brunches that are both supplyied at the bifucation by a patent saphenous graft. At the anastomosis the graft shows narrowing with both origins of the diagional brunches being narrowed at least by 50%, but with appropriate opacification of both diagonal brunches that show no evidence of occlusion distal to anastomosis. The graft is stented in it's proximal and distal portions, patent. . LCX: The proximal Left circumflex is calcified. There is a stent in the proximal circumflex that appears to be patent. Distal to the stent, there is no evidence of significant disease/vessel narrowing . . OM1: small , heavily calcified. OM2: small, patent OM2: large artery. There is proximal area of mixed plaque with focal area of narrowing that does not exceed 50% at the proximal OM3. Additional area of narrowing of more than 50% is noted at the level of mid portion of OM3. . RCA: Right coronary artery is extensively calcified and occluded in its mid distal portion. Posterior lateral branch is patent and most likely retrogradely filled from collateral supply. . Bypass to the distal right coronary artery/PDA: is completely occluded at its proximal and mid portion with retrograde filling at the distal portion and at the level of the PDA. . Bypass grafts originating from the anterior aspect of the aorta most likely was connecting to a second diagonal artery - occluded. . IMPRESSION: . 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism 2. Known extensive three vessel disease as descibed in details in the body of the report. ................................... Exercise stress test ___ INTERPRETATION: This ___ year old man s/p CABG ___, MI ___ and PCI ___ and ___ was referred to the lab for evaluation of chest discomfort. The patient exercised for 10.5 minutes of a modified ___ protocol and stopped for fatigue. The estimated peak MET capacity was 8.7 which represents an average functional capacity for his age. During exercise, he developed a progressive left sided chest tightness that radiated to his sternal area. The peak intensity of the discomfort was ___. The discomfort abated through recovery with 2 L/min of oxygen via nasal canula and resolved by minute 12 of recovery. There was no significant ST segment changes during exercise with biphasic T waves noted in V1 and V2 during exercise. The rhythm was sinus with 1 apb. Appropriate increase in systolic BP with a blunted HR response to exercise on high dose beta blocker. IMPRESSION: Anginal type symptoms with non-specific EKG changes. Nuclear report sent separately. .................. ECHO ___ The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and regional/global systolic function (LVEF>55%). Transmitral and tissue Doppler imaging suggests normal diastolic function, and a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). There is no ventricular septal defect. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic arch is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. The mitral valve appears structurally normal with trivial mitral regurgitation. There is no mitral valve prolapse. The estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal. There is no pericardial effusion. . Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, the ascending aorta findings are similar. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> citalopram 40 daily clopidogrel [Plavix] 75 daily colchicine 0.6mg daily gabapentin 300 mg Capsule TID isosorbide mononitrate 60 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr lisinopril 20 mg Tablet lorazepam 1mg TID metoprolol succinate 100 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual ranitidine HCl 300 mg Capsule daily rosuvastatin [Crestor] 40 mg Tablet aspirin 325 mg Tablet nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. citalopram 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 2. clopidogrel 75 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 3. gabapentin 300 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO TID (3 times a day). 4. colchicine 0.6 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 5. lisinopril 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 6. metoprolol succinate 100 mg Tablet Extended Release 24 hr Sig: One (1) Tablet Extended Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily). 7. nitroglycerin 0.3 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) Tablet, Sublingual Sublingual PRN (as needed) as needed for chest pain. 8. ranitidine HCl 150 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO BID (2 times a day). 9. rosuvastatin 20 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 10. aspirin 325 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 11. lorazepam 1 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO three times a day as needed for anxiety. 12. cholestyramine-sucrose 4 gram Packet Sig: One (1) Packet PO BID (2 times a day). Electrocardiogram and blood tests did not show anything concerning for damage to your heart. A nuclear imaging test of blood flow to the heart did not show anything concerning. A CT scan of the veins in your heart did not show any new blockages. You were taken for cardiac cathterization which did not show any new blockages. . target: ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: ___ y/o male w/ PMHx of CAD s/p 4v CABG (___) and MI s/p DES to ___ in ___ and BMS of ___ aneurysm (9mm in ___ who presents with chest pain with no ECG changes, negative cardiac enzymes, stress with imaging limited by chest pain, . ACTIVE ISSUES: ============== # CORONARIES: CAD s/p 4v CABG (___) and MI s/p DES to ___ in ___ and BMS of ___ aneurysm (9mm in ___. He has had several recent admissions for chest pain, which is likely related to anxiety though given significant underlying cardiac disease may be cardiac in nature. He was ruled out for ACS on admission with negative cardiac enzymes and no ischemic ECG changes. No evidence of pneumonia on admitting CXR. CTA was done to assess for endoleak or expansion of aneurysm, which showed did not identify the aneurysm and showed no new occlusions. A stress test with imaging was done. He achieved 8.7 mets after 10.5 minutes on a modified ___ protocol. A fixed defect in the inferior wall was seen, however the exam was limited by chest pain, no ischemic changes were seen on EKG. He was continued on aspirin and plavix, beta blocker, ACE-i, and statin. Imdur was increased from 60 to 90mg daily. Cholestyramine was added to regimen to improve hyperlipidemia (last LDL 130s and goal <70). He was counselled on smoking cessation and given a nictoine patch in house and a prescription for nicotine gum. . # PUMP: last TTE in ___ showed EF>55% with normal regional global function. No clinical symptoms of progressive CHF and no evidence of volume overload on exam. Pt was continued on beta blocker and ACE-i. ECHO was repeated in this admission showing stable EF and normal wall motion. . # RHYTHM: Pt was in NSR with stable RBBB, no acute ischemic changes on admitting ECG. He was monitored on telemetry and no significant arrythmias were identified. . INACTIVE ISSUES: ================ # Hypertension - he was well controlled on home lisinopril, metoprolol XL, and Imdur with SBP 110s. . # Hyperlipidemia- on crestor 40mg at home, last LDL 130s with goal <70. Cholestyramine was started for improved control. . TRANSITION OF CARE: =================== # Depression - pt with significant emotional stressors and recent disability. Weight loss and sleep disturbance likely ___ depression. Pt follows with a psychologist (and recently a psychiatrist) at ___. No active SI. - continue citalopram 40mg daily - social work consult - ativan prn anxiety

No lower extremity edema. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission labs: ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD WBC-7.8 RBC-4.25* Hgb-12.1* Hct-37.5* MCV-88 MCH-28.5 MCHC-32.3 RDW-13.6 RDWSD-43.5 Plt ___ ___ 09: 30PM BLOOD UreaN-17 Creat-1.3* Na-137 K-4.6 ___ 09: 30PM BLOOD Mg-2.4 ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD Triglyc-161* HDL-29* CHOL/HD-2.6 LDLcalc-15 ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD %HbA1c-9.9* eAG-237* Discharge labs: ___ 06: 23AM BLOOD WBC-7.4 RBC-3.69* Hgb-10.6* Hct-33.0* MCV-89 MCH-28.7 MCHC-32.1 RDW-13.4 RDWSD-43.8 Plt ___ ___ 06: 23AM BLOOD Glucose-202* UreaN-19 Creat-1.5* Na-132* K-4.4 Cl-98 HCO3-22 AnGap-12 ___ 01: 00PM BLOOD WBC-7.5 RBC-3.84* Hgb-11.1* Hct-34.2* MCV-89 MCH-28.9 MCHC-32.5 RDW-13.5 RDWSD-44.0 Plt ___ Cardiac catheterization on ___: Coronary Description The coronary circulation is right dominant. LM: The Left Main, arising from the left cusp, is a large caliber vessel. This vessel bifurcates into the Left Anterior Descending and Left Circumflex systems. LAD: The Left Anterior Descending artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 70% stenosis in the proximal segment. Cx: The Circumflex artery, which arises from the LM, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 90% stenosis in the proximal segment. RCA: The Right Coronary Artery, arising from the right cusp, is a large caliber vessel. There is a 95% stenosis in the proximal and mid segments. Interventional Details Percutaneous Coronary Intervention: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed on an ad hoc basis based on the coronary angiographic findings from the diagnostic portion of this procedure. It was unclear if the LCx or the RCA were the culprit. ECG was not helpful in localizing. There was TIMI 2 flow in the RCA and thus we decided to fix first. heparin boluses were given prophylactically for an ACT >250s and the patient was pre-loaded with 180 mg of Ticagrelor. A ___ Fr AL0.75 guide provided good support for the procedure. A short Sion Blue wire crossed easily into the distal RPL. We pre-dilated with a 2.5*15 mm balloon at 14 ATM for ___ x3. We then delivered a 2.75*38 mm Promus Elite DES at 14 ATM for ___ and then an overlapping 3.0*20 mm Promus Elite at 16 ATM for ___. We then post-dilated with a 3.0 mm NC balloon distally and with a 4.0 mm NC balloon proximally at 20 ATM for ___ x6. Final angiogram showed no residual and TIMI 3 flow without any visible evidence of dissection or rupture. We now turned our attention to the LCx. A ___ Fr. EBU 3.5 guide provided poor support for the procedure. A short Sion Blue crossed the lesion easily into the OM and we then predilated with a 2.5 mm balloon at 14 ATM and then delivered a 2.75*20 mm Promus Elite DES at 14 ATM for ___ and post-dilated with a 3.0 mm NC balloon at 20 ATM fro ___ and then with a 3.5 mm NC balloon at 20 ATM for ___. Final angiogram revealed no residual and TIMI 3 flow without any visible evidence of dissection or rupture. Complications: There were no clinically significant complications. Findings ---- - Three vessel coronary artery disease. ------------- Recommendations - DAPT for 12 months minimum. Consider 30 months if patient tolerates with no issues. Routine post-stemi care. TTE. F/u with me in 1 month. Outpatient stress test to assess for anterior ischemia. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide ___ mg oral DAILY 2. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 3. Rosuvastatin Calcium 20 mg PO QPM 4. Humalog 10 Units Breakfast Humalog 10 Units Lunch Humalog 10 Units Dinner NPH 40 Units Breakfast 5. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Apixaban 5 mg PO BID 2. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM This replaces rosuvastatin 3. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY 4. Lisinopril 5 mg PO DAILY This replaces your previous medication of lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide 5. Metoprolol Succinate XL 37.5 mg PO DAILY 6. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL Q5MIN: PRN chest pain Lying down before taking this medication. Call ___ for onset of chest pain 7. HumuLIN N NPH Insulin KwikPen (insulin NPH isoph U-100 human) 100 unit/mL (3 mL) subcutaneous 40 units at breakfast and 10units before dinner Take 40 units of NPH with breakfast Take 10units of NPH before dinner <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Coronary Artery Disease STEMI Diabetes Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ ___! WHY WAS I IN THE HOSPITAL? -========= - You went to ___ because you were having chest pain. You had abnormal cardiac testing indicating you were having a heart attack, ST elevation myocardial infarction, (STEMI). You were transferred to ___ for further care. WHAT HAPPENED IN THE HOSPITAL? -- - You had a cardiac catheterization procedure. This showed significant coronary artery disease. - You had 2 stents placed to the right coronary artery (RCA) and on stent placed in the left circumflex coronary artery (LCx). You also have a 70% blockage of the left anterior descending coronary artery (LAD). You had an episode of atrial fibrillation, irregular heart rhythm which requires an anticoagulation medication, apixaban (Eliquis), to decrease your risk for stroke. - You were started on new medications to best treat your heart disease. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? --== - Instructions regarding care of the access site are included with your discharge information. - Take all of your medications as prescribed (listed below). There are a lot of new medication changes. STOP Humalog insulin STOP Aspirin STOP Lisinopril-hydrochlorothiazide STOP Amlodipine STOP Rosuvastatin Start NPH insulin take 40 units daily with breakfast, 10 units before dinner daily. Please take Atorvastatin 80mg, daily (best absorbed when taken in the evening), this medication not only reduces cholesterol, but has been shown to help decrease risk of heart attack in the future for people who have coronary artery (heart) disease. NITRO Nitroglycerin is a medication that can be used as needed for chest pain. If you develop chest pain, place 1 tablet under the tongue and allow it to dissolve. If after 5 minutes you are still having chest pain, you can repeat this every 5 minutes for UP TO 3 doses. If chest pain persists after 3 doses, call ___. You should always lie down if you need to take this medication, because it can cause a drop in your blood pressure which can lead to lightheadedness or possibly cause someone to pass out if blood pressure drops too low. Even if your chest pain resolves, you should contact your cardiologist METOPROLOL 37.5mg daily. This medication belongs to a class of medications known as Beta Blockers. Beta blockers slow the heart down and can lower blood pressure. They help reduce the amount of work the heart has to do, and can help to reduce risk of future heart attack. LISINOPRIL 5mg daily. This medication belongs to a class of medications known as Ace Inhibitors. Ace Inhibitors help to reduce blood pressure and decrease the amount of resistance that the heart needs to pump against, which decreases strain on the heart muscle. It can also help to protect/improve kidney function in some individuals Plavix (clopidogel) 75mg daily - It is very important to take all of your heart healthy medications. In particular, Plavix (clopidogrel) help keep the stents in the vessels of the heart open and help reduce your risk of having a future heart attack. If you stop this medication or miss ___ dose, a blood clot could form in your heart stent which could cause a life threatening heart attack. Please do not stop taking either medication without taking to your heart doctor, even if another doctor tells you to stop the medications. - We have ordered a cardiac monitor for you to wear to monitor your heart rate and rhythm at home. The information will be sent to the cardiologist, Dr. ___. - It is strongly recommended that you attend a cardiac rehab program in the near future. A referral form was provided to you that lists the locations of these programs. Please bring this with you to your follow up visit with your cardiologist, and they will inform you when it is safe to begin a program. - Follow up with your doctors as listed below. - An Appointment for ___ was requested, they should contact you with a 1 to 2 week follow up appointment time next week. We have arranged visiting nursing to come to your home to help with education for your new medications, to assess your recovery after this hospitalization. It was a pleasure participating in your care. If you have any urgent questions that are related to your recovery from your hospitalization or are experiencing any symptoms that are concerning to you and you think you may need to return to the hospital, you may call the ___ HeartLine at ___ to speak to a cardiologist or cardiac nurse practitioner. -Your ___ Care Team

He reports that he awoke from sleep at midnight with left sided chest pain the radiated down his left arm and into jaw and also had slight shortness of breath. Patient called ___. EMS provided sl ntg x 1 that improved his chest pain. He also received ASA on EMS arrival. An EKG obtained by EMS did not reveal ST elevations. On arrival to the ED, an EKG was obtained that revealed ST elevations in the inferior leads II>III and code STEMI was activated. He was transiently noted to be bardycardic in the ED and received atropine with subsequent improvement. He was take to the cath lab where the culprit mid-distal left circumflex lesion was identified and two DES were placed. On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. Exam otherwise unchanged. <PERTINENT RESULTS> Admission Labs: ___ 01: 25AM WBC-12.7* RBC-4.60 HGB-13.5* HCT-38.0* MCV-83 MCH-29.3 MCHC-35.4* RDW-13.4 ___ 01: 25AM NEUTS-47.7* LYMPHS-43.4* MONOS-5.2 EOS-2.9 BASOS-0.9 ___ 01: 25AM PLT COUNT-209 ___ 01: 25AM GLUCOSE-141* UREA N-18 CREAT-0.8 SODIUM-142 POTASSIUM-4.1 CHLORIDE-109* TOTAL CO2-22 ANION GAP-15 ___ 01: 25AM cTropnT-<0.01 Cardiac Enzymes: ___ 01: 25AM cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 03: 24AM CK(CPK)-330* CK-MB-5 cTropnT-0.03* ___ 12: 17PM CK(CPK)-331* CK-MB-19* MB INDX-5.7 cTropnT-0.11* Cardiac Catheterization Report ___ 1. The LCx had a 99% mid-distal stenosis. The RCA had diffuse, mild disease. 2. Successful PCI with Promus DES to mid to distal LCx with 0% residual stenosis. 3. Successful AngioSeal of the RFA sheath site. 4. No complications. TTE ___: The left atrium is dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with mild hypokinesis of the basal to mid inferior and inferolateral segments. There is no ventricular septal defect. The right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free wall contractility. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and needed a cardiac catheterization. The catheterization showed a severe blockage in your left circumflex artery that was cleared and a drug eluting stent was placed. You will need to take Clopidogrel (Plavix) and aspirin every day for at least one year to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. You had some damage to your heart but we think this will get better over the next month. In the meantime, you have been started on medicines that will help your heart muscle recover. If you have chest pain at home that is similar to the chest pain you had previously, you can take nitroglycerin but call ___. If the chest pain only lasts a few seconds or if it goes away with nitroglycerin, please call Dr. ___ to discuss this. . We made the following changes to your medicines: 1. Start aspirin and clopidogrel to prevent the stent from clotting off 2. Stop taking simvastatin, take atorvastatin instead to lower your cholesterol. 3. Start taking lisinopril to lower your blood pressure and help your heart recover from the heart attack. 4. Start taking metoprolol to lower your heart rate and help your heart recover from the heart attack. 5. Start taking nitroglycerin as directed under your tongue for chest pain that does not go away. 6. Stop taking omeprazole, take ranitidine instead for your hearburn. If the rantidine is not sufficient, you can try to take the Pantoprazole instead. 7. Use a nicotine patch daily for 6 weeks to prevent cravings for cigarettes. You can switch to a 14mg patch after that. You can use nicotine gum as needed for cravings.
target: Primary Reason for Hospitalization: ___ smoker with HLD p/w inferior STEMI, s/p DES to LCx. Active Issues: #Inferior STEMI: Patient was taken to cath lab and noted to have 99% occlusion of Left Circumflex artery. Had two drug eluting stents placed in L circumflex with restoration of flow. TTE showed mild impairment of systolic function (EF of 45%-50%). He was started on ASA, plavix, high dose atorvastatin, captopril, and metoprolol. Cardiac enzymes trended downward from a peak CK of 339 to 284. Chronic Issues: #HLD: His simvastatin was discontinued and he was started on high dose atorvastatin in the setting of STEMI, as above. #Current Smoking: Patient was counseled about benefits of smoking cessation and received a nicotine patch, titrated to 2 ppd use. #Anxiety: Stable. He was continued on his home Wellbutrin and Celexa. #GERD: Stable. He was continued on his home omeprazole. Transitional Issues: - Patient maintained full code status throughout hospitalization. - He should continue Plavix for at least one year and continue ASA indefinitely. - F/u echo in 3 months

Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg Tablet, Sublingual Sig: One (1) tablet Sublingual every 5 mintues for total of 2 doses: If you still have chest pain after 2 doses, call ___. Disp: *1 bottle* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> ST elevation Myocardial Infarction Cerebral Palsy Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> stable <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and a drug eluting stent was placed in your right coronary artery. You will need to take Clopodigrel (Plavix) every day for at least one year to prevent the stent from clotting off. Do not miss any doses or stop taking Plavix unless Dr. ___ you to. No lifting more than 10 pounds for 5 days. Please follow your right groin site carefully. You may shower but no baths or swimming for 5 days. If you notice increased bruising, tenderness or redness at the site, call Dr. ___ at ___ for further instructions. Please follow the activity recommendations that physical therapy discussed with you. You should start cardiac rehabilitation but you will need to see your new cardiologist and have a stress test before you exercise. . Medication changes: 1. START Clopodigrel (Plavix) every day 2. Increase your aspirin to 325 mg every day for one month, then decrease to 162 mg daily (2 baby aspirin) 3. START Atorvastatin to lower your cholesterol 4. START Lisinopril to lower your blood pressure and help your heart pump better. 5. Start nitroglycerin is you have chest pain. 6. STOP taking your hydrochorothiazide . Please call your primary care doctor if you develop any fevers, chest pain, trouble breathing, vomiting or severe heartburn. If you have chest pain that is similar to the pain you had with your heart attack, please take nitroglycerin under your tongue as directed.
target: ___ year old male with a history of cerebral palsy and hypertension presented with inferior STEMI treated with PCI with drug eluting stent to the mid RCA. . # CORONARIES: Patient presented with acute ST elevation myocardial infarction, and underwent cardiac catheterization with a drug-eluting stent to the mid-RCA. In addition, the cath revealed another lesion of 50% in the mid LAD lesion. Symptom to balloon time was approximately 2.5 hours and door to ballon time was approximately 1.5 hours. Maximal enzyme excursion was TnT 1.75 CKMB 95. The patient received Integrilin perioperatively. In addition, he was treated with Aspirin 325 daily, Plavix 75 daily, Atenolol 75 daily, Atorvastatin 80 daily, Lisinopril 5 daily. Hydrochlorothiazide was discontinued. The patient will have follow-up with a cardiologist close to his home, Dr. ___. He will require a stress thallium as an outpatient to evaluate the LAD lesion. . # PUMP: LV gram showed LVEF 50%, mild inferior hypokinesis, no MR. ___ on discharge showed LVEF 60% with no definite wall motion abnormality, 1+ MR. . # RHYTHM: No rhythm abnormalities on telemetry. . # ECCHYMOSIS at catheter site. Femoral ultrasound showed no hematoma or pseudoaneurysm. . # HYPERTENSION: Discharged on Atenolol and Lisinopril. . # DIET: Cardiac heart healthy diet. . # CODE: Full Code

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Ms. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ ___. WHY WAS I ADMITTED TO THE HOSPITAL? - You were admitted to the hospital because you had a heart attack which exacerbated your heart failure, as well as a COPD flare WHAT HAPPENED WHILE I WAS IN THE HOSPITAL? - You had an echocardiogram (or ultrasound of your heart) to assess your heart function. This showed that your heart is not able to pump as well as it should. - You had a coronary angiogram test to look at the vessels in your heart. This showed that 3 of your coronary arteries had coronary artery disease with blockage. - You were seen by the cardiac surgeons who initially thought you would benefit from a heart surgery. However, after your lung function was assessed, it was determined that you would not be a good surgical candidate. - You had lung function tests and a CT of your chest. These showed that you have severe COPD. You were seen by the ___ (lung doctors) team and they are planning to see you again once you leave the hospital. - You had a coronary catheterization with placement of a stent in one of the vessels in your heart to allow for more blood flow. - You developed a large hematoma, or bruise, on your right forearm near the area of the catheterization entry. This was monitored closely during your stay and it was determined that no intervention was needed for your bruise. - You had a TIA, or mini stroke, shortly after your cardiac catheterization, which caused you to lose strength in your left forearm and hand. You were seen by the neurology team and you had a CT scan and MRI of your brain which suggested you had a TIA. You are scheduled to see the neurology team again for follow up when you leave the hospital. - You were seen by the physical therapy team after your TIA. They suggested that you continue to work with physical therapy and occupational therapy upon discharge from the hospital to help you regain your strength. WHAT SHOULD I DO WHEN I GO HOME? - You should continue to take your medications as prescribed. - You should attend the appointments listed below. - Your discharge weight: 123.02 lb. You should use this as your baseline after you leave the hospital. - Weigh yourself every morning, and call your doctor if your weight goes up more than 3 lbs. - Seek medical attention if you have new or concerning symptoms or you develop swelling in your legs, abdominal distention, or shortness of breath at night. We wish you the best! Your ___ Care Team
target: ==================== PATIENT SUMMARY: ==================== ___ w/ PMH HTN, HLD, CAD s/p PCI to RCA presented with worsening SOB found to have NSTEMI with likely mixed CHF/COPD exacerbation. s/p cor angio with 3 vessel disease. There was an initial recommendation for CABG, however given poor pulmonary function, she was deemed to be not a good surgical candidate. s/p PCI with DES to mid LAD. Her hospital course was complicated by R ulnar hematoma, TIA with R hemispheric infarcts. She was diuresed with IV Lasix until she was clinically euvolemic. ==================== ACUTE ISSUES: ==================== #NSTEMI #Three-vessel coronary artery disease: Patient presented to ___ with several weeks of dyspnea on exertion, lower extremity edema, abdominal distention, and orthopnea. Troponin I 1.52. She was transferred to ___ where coronary angiography on ___ showed triple-vessel coronary artery disease. She was started on atorvastsatin 80mg, ASA 81mg, and metoprolol tartrate. She was initially evaluated by cardiac surgery for CABG , however on pre-operative evaluation, she had poor pulmonary function tests and CT chest showing nearly entirely collapsed RML. It was deemed that the patient was not a good surgical candidate and subsequently underwent PCI on ___ with right ulnar access with DES to mid LAD. Her course was complicated by the development of a right ulnar hematoma shortly after the procedure and a TIA (see below). She will be discharged on ASA 81mg, Plavix 75mg, Metoprolol, lisinopril, and atorvastatin 80. #Acute HFrEF Exacerbation: Ms ___ presented with SOB of likely multifactorial etiology. She was clinically volume overloaded with signs of pulmonary vascular congestion on CXR and pro-BNP 16480. She had a TTE on ___ that showed an EF of 39% and mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with mild to moderate global hypokinesis. Elevated PCWP was suggested. She was diuresed with IV Lasix, which was held briefly in preparation for surgery. She was transitioned to PO Lasix at discharge when she was euvolemic. #COPD: The patient's dyspnea was also contributed to by severe COPD. She has a strong smoking history and is a current smoker. She was started on 2LNC oxygen, duonebs, and levalbuterol (since albuterol made her anxious) as well as Advair. As part of her surgery work up she had a CT Chest w/o contrast on ___ which showed centrilobular emphysema, and a mostly collapsed RML with probably inflammatory thickening of RML airways. Her PFTs also showed diminished FEV1/FVC. She is scheduled to follow up as an outpatient with pulmonology. She will be discharged on Spiriva, Advair, and levalbuterol. #TIA: On ___, shortly after her cardiac cath, patient reported LUE weakness with some diminished sensation. She had significant distal>proximal left upper extremity weakness with sensory changes not in dermatomal distribution. CTA head/neck ___ significant for aortic arch atherosclerotic disease and moderate to severe stenosis L carotid bifurcation. MRI ___ significant for small right hemispheric infarcts causing her left arm weakness. Neurology evaluated and she was not candidate for advanced therapies. Her symptoms improved within 1 hr of code stroke activation, although still with residual left upper extremity hemiparesis. Most likely etiology of infarctions is atheroembolic in setting of cardiac cath and aortic arch atherosclerotic plaques. She will be on DAPT x ___ year given stent placement. Her motor function improved throughout her hospitalization. Neurology follow up was recommended within ___ months. #Right ulnar hematoma: She developed a large right ulnar hematoma s/p cardiac cath on ___. No concern for pseudo-aneurysm, nerve impingement given intact sensation and motor function. Clinically improved throughout her hospitalization. ___: Baseline Cr 1.1. Cr bumped from 1.0 (___) to 1.5 (___) after 80mg IV Lasix. Likely pre-renal etiology from diuresis. After holding IV Lasix, her Cr improved to 1.2 at discharge. ==================== CHRONIC ISSUES: ==================== #Diabetes mellitus type 2: A1c 6.8. Maintained on insulin sliding scale while in house. #Hypertension: Patient was not take any home antihypertensives, prior to discharge she was started on metoprolol and lisinopril. #Hyperlipidemia: Patient not on home medications, given coronary disease patient was started on high-dose atorvastatin. ==================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== [ ]Post-Discharge Follow-up Labs Needed: Please recheck BMP in 1 week after discharge. Please recheck LFTs given mild transaminitis (likely ___ congestion) [ ]Please continue to monitor weights regularly and adjust diuretics as [ ]Discharge weight: 123.02 lbs [ ]Discharge creatinine: 1.2 [ ]Please ensure follow up with neurology for TIA in ___ months. Encouraged patient to call ___ [ ]FYI on CT: 2 mm left upper lobe pulmonary nodule. For incidentally detected single solid pulmonary nodule smaller than 6 mm, no CT follow-up is recommended in a low-risk patient, and an optional CT in 12 months is recommended in a high-risk patient. [ ]FYI on CT: Thyroid isthmus approximately 1 cm and approximately 5 mm right thyroid lobe nodules. [ ]FYI patient has residual weakness of LUE after TIA. continue to monitor and encourage ___ [ ]The patient is on many new medications. Please encourage medication compliance # CODE: presumed FULL # CONTACT: ___ (Daughter) cell: ___ work ___

She has had an ongoing cough productive of clear-white sputum without hemoptysis. She experienced one episode of chest thightness/sharp chest pain roughly 3 weeks ago. This pain was non-radiation; it was not associated with diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting. . She was seen by her PCP and started on inhalers for concern regarding possible URI. CARDIAC: RRR, normal S1, S2. No m/r/g. Distant heart sounds. LUNGS: Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. Decreased breath sounds with bibasilar crackles, no wheezing or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Bowel sounds present, soft, non-tender, non-distended, no organomegaly, no guarding or rebound tenderness. HEENT: NCAT. NECK: No JVD COR: +S1S2, RRR, no m/g/r. PULM: Crackles at bases, do not clear with cough. ___: +NABS in 4Q. Soft, NTND. EXT: WWP, no leg edema. R groin with hematoma stable. NEURO: MAEE, weak. <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS & STUDIES: ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD ___ PTT-VERIFIED B ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD WBC-9.4 RBC-3.95* Hgb-11.8* Hct-33.9* MCV-86 MCH-29.9 MCHC-34.8 RDW-14.2 Plt ___ ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Glucose-100 UreaN-23* Creat-1.3* Na-140 K-3.6 Cl-100 HCO3-26 AnGap-18 ___ 12: 34AM BLOOD CK-MB-9 cTropnT-0.33* ___ 06: 55AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-5.8*# Mg-2.1 CXR (___): FINDINGS: Comparison is made with the most recent study at this institution of ___. The cardiac silhouette remains somewhat enlarged and there is increased opacification at the bases consistent with small pleural effusions and associated compressive atelectasis. There is engorgement of ill-defined pulmonary vessels, consistent with elevated pulmonary venous pressure, as suggested in the clinical history CT ABDOMEN & PELVIS (___): IMPRESSION: 1. Total occlusion of the LAD 2. successful primary PCI of the LAD with restoration of TIMI 3 flow Echo ___: Conclusions The left atrium and right atrium are normal in cavity size. No atrial septal defect is seen by 2D or color Doppler. The estimated right atrial pressure is at least 15 mmHg. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild (non-obstructive) focal hypertrophy of the basal septum. There is moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis to akinesis of the anteroseptal, anterior, and anterolateral walls as well as distal septal and inferior hypokinesis and dyskinesis of the true apex. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 35%). No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Doppler parameters are indeterminate for left ventricular diastolic function. Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The diameters of the aortic sinus and ascending aorta are normal. The aortic valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened but aortic stenosis is not present. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Regional left ventricular dysfunction c/w CAD (LAD distribution), with moderately depressed overall systolic function. Normal right ventricular size and free wall systolic function. Deep T wave inversions in the anterior leads remain concerning for acute or recent ischemic process or myocardial infarction in evolution. Clinical correlation is suggested. There are some streaky linear opacities in the left costophrenic sulcus which may reflect subsegmental atelectasis or post-inflammatory scarring. There is no evidence of pulmonary edema. More focal nodular appearance to the right hilum may reflect vascularity and overlapping shadows, but this can be better assessed on followup imaging. The cardiac contour is within normal limits. No acute bony abnormality appreciated. ECG ___: Sinus rhythm with left bundle-branch block with secondary repolarization abnormalities. The remaining left ventricular segments contract normally. LVEF 35%). No left ventricular apical aneurysm is seen. No masses or thrombi are seen in the left ventricle. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___. You were admitted with chest pain and a heart attack. A cardiac catheterization showed a total occlusion of your left anterior descending artery that was opened with three bare metal stents. You will need to take aspirin and clopidogrel (Plavix) every day without fail to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. Do not stop taking aspirin and clopidogrel for any reason or miss any doses unless your cardiologist tells you it it OK to do so. Your heart is weak after the heart attack and we have started you on many medications to help the heart heal. Because the heart is weak, there is an increased risk of blood clots so you will be started on warfarin, a blood thinner, to prevent blood clots until the heart is stronger. Warfarin takes about 3 days to start to work so you will take an enoxaparin injection twice daily to prevent blood clots. Dr. ___ will tell you when the warfarin level is high enough so that you can stop the injections.
