input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Diovan / Lipitor <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Shortness of breath <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization ___ with balloon angioplasty of the proximal RPL1; no stents placed <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ year old male with complete heart block s/p pacemaker (___), coronary artery disease s/p stenting, gout, arthritis, GERD with ___, iron deficiency anemia, chronic kidney disease, depression/PTSD, BPH, severe OSA on CPAP, seizure disorder who presents with progressive dyspnea on exertion. The patient states his dyspnea on exertion has been ongoing for a year but became much worse after a recent trip to ___ (___). Today, he was unable to walk from the ___ main entrance to the ___ Building without having to sit down near the ___ ER entrance. He felt very short of breath, with lightheadedness but no chest pain/palpitations or sore throat. In general, he is unable to walk more than ___ feet. He did, however, have chest tightness. He also feels "bloated" in the last few weeks and has noticed a ten pound weight gain (from 193 --> 203) within the month. He does not use home oxygen, denies PND, orthopnea, lower extremity edema, needing more pillows at night. He has had some mild nasal congestion but no cough. He has generally felt very fatigued, with significant muscle cramping at night and feels his symptoms coincide with when his medications are due. . ___ year old male with chief complaint of marked increase of DOE, and new onset orthopnea. Eval for unstable angina/new onset chf. Lisnopril had been stopped ___. Off diuretics x1 month for Cr improvement. Myalgias but still on statin. Had been taking red yeast rice for years per accupuncturist and myalgias improved off of it. Still on crestor. Restarted on ___ today. . In the ED, initial vs were: T 99.0 P 61 BP 154/87 R 18 O2 99% on RA. The patient underwent a CXR that was within normal limits (no volume overload), labs showed a negative troponin, INR 1.1. His BNP was 3723 with no priors and his anemia was very slightly below baseline at 34.7 (Hct ___. His chronic renal failure was stable but improved from priors at Cr 1.8 (baseline 2.0-2.4). The patient's D-Dimer was 655. In consideration of his creatinine, CTA was deferred. V/Q scan could not be performed as the tech could not come in from home in the snow. Thus, the patient was started on heparin gtt and admitted to the floor for further work-up and V/Q scan in the morning. . On the floor, the patient was resting comfortably in bed, chatty and lying flat in bed. . Review of systems: (+) Per HPI (-) Denies fever, chills, headache, sinus tenderness, rhinorrhea or congestion. Denies cough, chest pain or palpitations. Denies nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation or abdominal pain. No recent change in bowel or bladder habits. No dysuria. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Cardiac Risk Factors: (-)Diabetes, (+)Dyslipidemia, (+)Hypertension, (-) Smoking, (-) FH early MI or sudden cardiac death . Cardiac History: -CAD, s/p PCI -Complete heart block s/p pacer ___ -AF non-sustained post-cath . Coronary Artery Bypass Grafts: None . Percutaneous Coronary Interventions: -___: Inferior MI -> RCA intervention -___: No intervention -___: Mid-LAD intervention -___: No intervention . ___: No intervention, stable RCA, mild LAD ISR 1. Selective coronary arteriography of this right dominant system demonstrated branch vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA was patent. **The previously stented proximal LAD had mild in-stent restenosis.** The previously jailed diagonal was totally occluded and was noted to fill late via collaterals. There appeared to be diffuse proximal disease and the distal vessel was of small caliber. The origin was not clearly visualized. The LCX had a small OM1, and a larger OM2 had a 30% proximal stenosis. The previously placed RCA stent was widely patent. The distal RCA had a 40% stenosis and the R-PDA had a 50% stenosis. 2. Limited resting hemodynamics demonstrated moderate hypertension and an elevated LVEDP of 23 mmHg. 3. Left ventriculography demonstrated normal systolic function with a calculated ejection fraction of 65%. There was no mitral regurgitation. 4. The right femoral arteriotomy was successfully closed with a ___ Angioseal device. . FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Branch vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate diastolic ventricular dysfunction. 3. Successful right femoral Angioseal closure. . ___: mid-LAD stent 1. Coronary angiography of this right dominant system revealed significant obstructive single vessel disease. The left main was normal. The LAD exhibited a discrete proximal 90% lesion, with a small first diagonal branch that was subtotally occluded proximally. The LCx was normal. The RCA revealed a patent stent with minimal luminal irregularities throughout the remainder of the vessel. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed a normal systemic blood and mildly elevated left ventricular filling pressures. 3. Left ventriculography revealed preserved systolic function with an ejection fraction of 59%. 4. The mid LAD was treated with successful PTCA and stenting using a 3.5 x 23 mm Bx Velocity stent, which yielded 0% residual stenosis, no angiographically-apparent dissection, and normal flow (see ___ comments). 5. Successful right femoral arteriotomy closure with Angioseal. . FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Mild diastolic ventricular dysfunction. 3. Successful PTCA and stenting of the LAD. . ___: No intervention COMMENTS: 1. Angiography of this right dominant system demonstrated non-obstructive disease only. The LMT was normal. The LAD had a 40% mid vessel stenosis with a normal appearing distal vessel. The first diagonal had diffuse 50% proximal stenosis. The CX was normal. The RCA had a widely patent stent and distal vessel. There was a 15% articulation defect seen in the ___ view only. 2. Systemic Hypertension. . FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Coronary arteries have no significant stenoses. 2. The RCA stent site is widely patent. . ___: RCA intervention 1. Coronary angiography reveals 2 vessel disease in this right dominant system. The left main coronary artery is free of hemodynamically significant disease. The mid LAD has a 50% stenosis. The LCX is without significant stenosis. The mid RCA has a discrete 95% stenosis. 2. Resting hemodynamics reveals mildly elevated left heart filling pressures. 3. Left ventriculography reveals focal posterobasal hypokinesis. The ejection fraction is normal. There is mild mitral regurgitation. 4. The mid RCA was successfully treated with placement of a 4.0 x 20 mm biliary stent, leaving no residual stenosis. . FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Focal left ventricular systolic dysfunction. **3. Successful stenting of the RCA for 95% stenosis with a biliary stent.** . There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal (LVEF>55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal (>=2.5L/min/m2). There is a mild resting left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. The right ventricular cavity is dilated with mild global free wall hypokinesis. The aortic valve leaflets are mildly thickened (?#). There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve prolapse. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. The tricuspid valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. The pulmonary vascularity appears more prominent than on the previous study, though some of this may reflect the AP rather than PA projection. Prilosec 20 mg Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) Sig: One (1) Capsule, Delayed Release(E.C.) PO twice a day. <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary: -Non-ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (Heart attack) -Hypertension -Acute kidney injury -Diastolic congestive heart failure <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It has been a privilege to take care of you at ___ ___. You were hospitalized because you had a heart attack - the symptom of your heart attack was shortness of breath. Heart attacks are caused by blockages in the coronary arteries that supply the heart muscle, whose pumping function depends on a constant supply of oxygen delivered by the blood supplied by these arteries. Severe blockages in the coronary arteries can cause the symptoms that you experienced because they deprive your heart of oxygen. . During this hospitalization, the blockage in your posterior lateral coronary artery that was causing your symptoms was opened during a procedure called a cardiac catheterization. During this procedure, a balloon was inflated to open the blocked, restore blood flow through the artery and, in turn, restore oxygen supply to your heart muscle. This procedure should help to improve your symptoms. . The catheterization, however, is only one part of your treatment; the other part of your treatment is your new medication regimen. It is very important that you take all of the medications prescribed to you because they will help to prevent you from having future heart attacks and help ensure that your pre-existing stents remains open. . Your new heart medications are: # CONTINUE: Aspirin 81mg daily - will need to take lifelong # START: Plavix (clopidogrel) 75mg daily - will need to take for at least one year # CONTINUE: Crestor 40mg daily # START: Carvedilol 50mg twice daily, STOP labetalol # START: Lisinopril 20mg daily # CONTINUE: Sublingual Nitroglycerin **Take 1 tab if you experience chest pain. If the pain persists, take a ___ tab 5 minutes after taking the first. If the pain still persists, take a ___ tab 5 minutes after taking the ___. If the pain still persists, call ___ and call your cardiologist.** . Your blood pressure was very high while you were here, and we made several changes to your blood pressure medications. Your new blood pressure regimen is as follows: # START carvedilol 50mg twice daily (STOP labetalol) # CONTINUE guanfacine 2mg daily # INCREASE hydralazine to 50mg three times daily # INCREASE Nifedpine to 60mg twice daily # START lisinopril 20mg daily # START furosemide 20mg daily . Please continue to take all of your other medications as previously prescribed. . It is also very important that you attend all of the follow-up appointments detailed below. Moreover, if you ever have chest pain associated with sweating, nausea or vomiting, or shortness of breath that does not resolve with sublingual nitroglycerin after 3 doses, please call ___ and call your cardiologist immediately because you may be having another heart attack. . You were also hospitalized because you had an acute worsening of your pre-existing heart failure - your symptoms were lower extremity swelling and shortness of breath. . You have diastolic congestive heart failure, which is a condition in which the filling function of your heart is impaired. As a result of your heart's impaired filling function, you are prone to accumulating excess fluid in parts of the body where fluid should not normally be; fluid that accumulates in the lower extremities causes swelling, and fluid that accumulates in the lungs causes shortness of breath. Your heart behaves like the water pumping stations that pump water out of a reservoir constantly being filled by an upstream river. If the pump is not filling properly, water flowing in from the river does not get pumped out of the reservoir and instead overflows onto the surrounding land. Similarly, if your heart is not pumping properly, fluid can overflow into your lungs and legs. . During this hospitalization, you were given medicines that removed the exess fluid from your body and your heart medicines were optimized; however, what we have done for you in the hospital is not the end of your treatment. . It is very important that you adhere to the fluid restrictions prescribed and that you refrain from consuming salt; failure to do so may result in you accumulating excess fluid and requiring re-hospitalization. You must also take all of the medications prescribed. Your current heart regimen is as follows: # Weigh yourself daily; call your cardiologist if you gain more than 3 lbs over your current weight, which is 175 lbs. # Lisinopril 20mg daily # Lasix 20mg daily # Potassium 10 mg twice daily # Carvedilol 50mg twice daily . During this hospitalization, your kidney function worsened slightly, but it normalized toward your baseline prior to your discharge. You should follow-up with your nephrologist after your discharge.
target: ___ gentleman with 2VD CAD s/p RCA stent and LAD stent with known mild ISR in ___, complete heart block s/p pacemaker in ___, CKD, severe OSA on CPAP, HTN, and seizure disorder, who initially presented to his nephrologist for SOB concerning for PE, who ruled out for PE but was found to have NSTEMI, and underwent cardiac catheterization with balloon angioplasty of the RPL1 on ___. . ACTIVE ISSUES: . # NSTEMI/CAD: Patient's anginal equivalent was shortness of breath; EKG showed A-V sequential pacing and was similar to prior tracings. CK/MB was 188/6 and Trop was <0.01 on admission; peak CK/MB was 6 and peak troponin was 0.10. The patient was chest pain free during this time. He had previously been started on a heparin gtt given concern for PE. Was also on started on aspirin 325mg, and continued on home regimen of Labetalol 600mg BID and Rosuvastatin 40mg daily. He underwent cardiac catheterization on ___ via the right femoral artery. Initial angiography revealed RPL1 with diffuse disease throughout to 80% proximally and 45% mid stenoses, and patient underwent successful balloon angioplasty of the proximal RPL1 (was felt to be too small to stent). Angioseal was placed. The patient tolerated the procedure well and there was no evidence of hematoma or aneurysm at the insertion site post-procedure. The patient had been on labetalol 600mg BID; this was changed to carvedilol 50mg BID for better blood pressure control. He was started on lisinporil 20mg daily. The patient was discharged chest pain free on 81mg aspirin daily, as well as Plavix 75mg daily for secondary prevention. He should be on aspirin life-long, and Plavix for at least 12 months. His regimen also includes carvedilol, lisinopril, and rosuvastatin, as well as hydralazine. . # ___ Decompensation: The patient's shortness of breath was likely multifactorial in setting NSTEMI and dCHF exacerbation. Patient has normal LV systolic function, demonstrated on TTE ___, and cardiac cath ___ revealed severe LV diastolic heart failure. The patient received lasix initially, then was diuresed with torsemide. At time of discharge, the patient was felt to be euvolemic, without cardiac wheezing, JVD, or lower extremity edema. The patient was discharged on a heart failure regimen of carvedilol, lisinopril, fluid restriction of 1500 mL, and a low Na diet. He will start on furosemide 20mg daily as an outpatient. . # HTN: The patient has a history of difficult to control blood pressure, and had persistent hypertension during much of his hospital course, with occasional SBPs in 190s-low 200s. Patient was asymptomatic during these episodes, denying any headache, dizziness, blurred vision, chest pain, or worsening dyspena. His anti-hypertensive regimen was changed as follows: Labetalol switched to carvedilol 50mg PO BID. Hydralazine was increased to 50mg TID. Nifedpine was increased to 60mg BID. Lisinopril 20mg daily was added back to regimen. Guanfacine was continued at 2mg daily. On morning of discharge, BP control had significantly improved, with SBP generally ranging 120s-150s. . # ___ CKD: Patient's recent baseline Cr around 1.8-2.0. Cr peaked at 2.3 this admission, and ___ was likely secondary to pre-renal etiology. Cr was closely monitored in setting of aggressive diuresis and dye load from cardiac catheterization. The patient's Cr had trended back to baseline prior to discharge. . # OSA: Maintained on home CPAP. . INACTIVE/CHRONIC ISSUES: . # h/o Seizure: Maintained on home regimen of Trileptal 300mg twice daily. . # Gout: Maintained on home regimen of Allopurinol ___ twice daily. . # GERD: Maintained on home regimen of Prilosec 20mg twice daily. . # Iron deficiency anemia: Maintained on home regimen of Iron 65mg daily. . # PTSD/Depression: Maintained on home regimen of Celexa 40mg daily. . # BPH: Maintained on home regimen of Terazosin 10mg daily. . # Supplementation: Maintained on home regimen of Fish Oil 2400mg daily, Vitamin D 1000mg daily, Resveratrol 200mg daily (supplement), Vitamin B12 1000mg daily. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -Patient will follow-up with his cardiologist Dr. ___ will need cardiac rehab. -His blood pressure will be closely monitoring in outpatient setting, and patient was discharged home with ___ and telemonitoring services. -Code status: Patient was full code during this admission.

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Penicillins / Tetracycline / Detrol / Nitrofurantoin <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Coronary catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> The patient is a ___ y.o.f. with diverticulitis and IBS who p/w inferior STEMI. Last night at approximately 10 p.m. she developed right sided chest discomfort that radiated to the underside of her right arm. This occurred on and off throughout the night and was accompanied by diaphoresis. "Breathes fast" at baseline (improved now with weight loss), but no increasing SOB, orthopnea, PND, palpitations, or prior episodes of chest pain. She was able to sleep, but when she awoke this a.m. she continued to have the chest discomfort and when getting up felt faint, lightheaded, and nauseated, so she caller her daughter who is a ___ at ___. EMS was called and BP on the scene was 96/60, HR 52, 99% RA. She was brought to ___ where EKG showed ST elevations in II, III, aVF, V6, ST depressions in I, avL, V2-V5. STEMI protocol was initiated, she was given ASA 324mg, heparin started, atorvastatin 80mg x 1, plavix 600 mg x 1, 500cc NS, 0.5 mg ativan, and she was sent to ___ for cardiac catheterization. . Cardiac catheterization showed right dominant system with 95% lesions in RCA with slow flow, no obstructive disease in LMCA, LAD, Lcx. She underwent BMS if RCA with temporary pacer placement. During stent deployment became hypotensive to SBP 60's, given atropine 1 mg IV x 2, and BP responded. Pacer d/c'd at end of case. . Of note her recent history is remarkable for a cough/flu in mid ___. She then had a precancerous lesion removed and tooth pulled on ___. Subsequent to that she developed loose stools for the next 2 weeks. Yesterday she was seen at her GI doctor's office and placed on a brat diet and was prescribed lomotil, which she took at 3pm and 9pm. . On review of symptoms, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. She denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. She denies exertional buttock or calf pain. She has chronic upper back discomfort x 2 months, felt by her to be d/t water aerobics, which comes and goes, not worsening. +urinates frequently. All of the other review of systems were negative. +recent intentional weight loss of 36 pounds in one year. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain currently (see above), dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, palpitations, syncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Diverticulitis - no surgeries IBS Radical hysterectomy UTI's (uretheral narrowing) PNA Sciatica HTN ? CHF - per patient, was in ___ in ___ and developed SOB and found to have mild CHF, 'd/t stress' - prompted stress test which was not optimal per patient, but never but on cardiac meds and never told that she had an MI . Cardiac Risk Factors: Hypertension, remote minimal tobacco . Cardiac History: Stress test in ___ - could not reach capacity d/t obesity <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Social history is significant for the absence of current tobacco use (very occasional ___ yrs ago, 'didn't inhale', 1 pack would last 2 weeks). There is no history of alcohol abuse. There is no immediate family history of premature coronary artery disease or sudden death. Maternal uncle died of MI at ___, brother with CAD recently in ___. Mother with ___, father deceased at ___. . <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: T 96.4 , BP 143/80 , HR 72 , RR 18, O2 100% on 2L Gen: WDWN middle aged male in NAD, resp or otherwise. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. Pleasant. Obese. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. Neck: Supple without JVD. CV: PMI located in ___ intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR, normal S1, S2. No S4, no S3. Chest: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. No crackles, wheeze, rhonchi. Abd: Obese, soft, NTND, No HSM or tenderness. No abdominial bruits. Ext: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits bilaterally. Fresh blood around groin lines, no hematoma. Skin: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. Pulses: Right: Carotid 2+ without bruit; Femoral 2+ without bruit; 2+ DP Left: Carotid 2+ without bruit; Femoral 2+ without bruit; 2+ DP <PERTINENT RESULTS> COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system revealed single vessel coronary artery disease. The LMCA had no obstructive disease. The LAD had no obstructive disease. The LCx had no obstructive disease. The RCA had a 95% focal lesion in the mid vessel. 2. Left ventriculography was not performed. 3. Central aortic pressure was normal at 120/66 (systolic/diastolic in mmHg). 4. Successful direct stenting of the mid RCA with a 3.0x18mm vision stent which was postdilated to 3.5mm. Successful temporary venous pacing wire insertion which was subsequently removed. Final angiography revealed 0% residual stenosis, no angiographically apparent dissection and timi 3 flow. The patient left the lab with persistent st elevation but pain free and hemodynamically stable and was transfered to the CCU service for further care. (see ___ comments) FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. One vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Normal ventricular function. 3. Acute inferior myocardial infarction, managed by acute ptca. PTCA of vessel <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ with an ST elevation myocardial infarction. Please take your previous medications as prescribed. The following changes has been made to your medications: - Please start taking aspirin 325 mg daily for secondary cardiovascular prevention (to prevent another heart attack) - Please start taking atorvastatin 80mg daily for your heart and for your cholesterol - Please continue taking Atenolol but change the dosing to 25mg daily (split the 50mg tablet in half) for your heart and blood pressure (prevents remodelling of the heart) - Please start taking clopidogrel (Plavix) 75 mg daily to keep stents open - Do NOT take the estrogen patch, this may increase risk of heart attack - You have follow scheduled with Dr. ___ on ___ at 130PM If you develop chest pain, jaw pain, or chest pressure with pain radiating into arm, or if you for any reason become concerned about your medical condition please call ___ or present to nearest ED. - We also gave you Nitroglycerin tablets to take if you experience chest pain, please call ___ or your doctor if chest pain recurs even if it dissapears with nitroglycerine. **DO NOT STOP TAKING THE ASPIRIN OR PLAVIX UNLESS INSTRUCTED TO DO SO BY YOUR CARDIOLOGIST EVEN IF ANOTHER DOCTOR TELLS YOU TO** We strongly recommend you stop smoking as discussed.

He was in normal healthy until the am of ___ when he experienced ___ substernal CP which was "squeezing" while watching TV. It lasted for 30 minutes without associated radiation, SOB, nausea, diaphoresis, palpitations or lightheadedness. He did not take medications for this incident. After dinner he lies down normally for approx ___ hour but has noticed SOB when supine over the past week. He has gained 30 lbs over the last year. He has had CP approximately 1X/year for which he usually takes Nitro. Patient's history is currently more variable. He reports CP the night prior to presentation for which he took SL Nitro X3. He had chest pain the next am which did not respond to Nitro. He had assocaited nausea. Patient notes that he had seizures during these episodes- as he gets seizures the more he drinks. target: ___ year-old male with history of CABG, DM, EtOH abuse, transfered for cardiac catheterization s/p stent to DES to LIMA-LAD, course complicated by respiratory failure requiring intubation. #. Coronary artery disease: The patient had symptoms concerning for unstable angina and presented to an OSH. At that time he had a slight increase in cardiac enzymes. There were no EKGs from the outside hospital. The patient was maintained on aspirin, heparin gtt, high-dose atorvastatin, plavix and metoprolol tartrate. He had a cardiac catheterization the morning of admission finding in-stent restenosis of ostial SVG->OM stent and LIMA->LAD. The patient had a DES in the SVG-OM. The patient developed agitation in the cath suite and was transfered to the cardiac ICU for further monitoring. It was thought to be secondary to a paradoxical effect of the benzos he was given during the procedure. He was resent to the Cath lab and had a successful PCI of the LIMA-LAD with DES. The patient was discharged on metoprolol tartrate, lisinopril, atorvastatin, aspirin and plavix. He had one episode of chest pain without EKG changes or cardiac enzyme elevations. He received 1mg of morphine which relieved his pain. He was hemodynamically stable at discharge. He should follow up with an outpatient cardiologist within 2 weeks of discharge. #. Acute on chronic systolic heart failure and respiratory failure: A TTE was done which showed decreased EF of ___. The patient was intubated for hypoxemic respiratory failure. He was diuresed and quickly extubated to a BiPAP. He was quickly weaned to face mask and then 3L NC. He receieved an 8 day course of vancomycin and cefepime for ventilator associated pneumonia. He was weaned slowly off of oxygen and had no oxygen requirement upon discharge. The patient was discharged on diuretics with torsemide 30 mg daily. #. Delirium: The patient initially had both hypoactive and hyperactive delirium; hypoactive delirium resolved, but hyperactive delirium at night persisted for weeks with gradual resolution. Initially it was thought to be secondary to paradoxical effect of benzos. Usual precautions were done including minimizing lines, frequent orientation, etc. The patient was started on large standing doses of seroquel in the evening with an additional smaller morning doses. His QTc was not prolonged. He was followed by both geriatrics and psychiatry throughout his hospitalization. Despite an improvement in delirium the patient had persistent difficulty with behavioral control. Despite aggressive medical management the patient had continued difficulty. He was started on trazadone and seroquel with some improvement. His dose was changed to seroquel 25mg qAM, 100mg qHS and 25mg given at midday to attempt to prevent increased agitation in the late afternoon. He continues on trazodone 50mg qHS. Per psychiatry, pt should be wslowly weaned off the Seroquel but discontinuing the day time dose in about 2 weeks, then decrease the bedtime dose by 25 mg per week until off. . #. Sinus tachycardia: The patient had sinus tachycardia. He was evaluated for potential pathological causes and none were found. The likely etiology was volume depletion and agitation. As the patient's delirium improved the tachycardia improved. #. Nutrition: The patient required an NG tube for medications and tube feeds while in the ICU. The tube was removed and he was able to eat and take medications by mouth. Speech and swallow evaluated the patient was cleared for a full diet with supervision. #. Diabetes mellitus: The patient was continued on insulin NPH at bedtime and in the morning as well as an insulin sliding scale. #. EtOH abuse: He was initially monitored on valium per CIWA scale. A social work consult was ordered. The patient showed no signs of withdrawal. #. Hyperlipidemia: continued statin per above. #. Hypertension: continued medications per above. #. GERD: changed to H2 blocker from PPI as patient is now on plavix. #. Code: full code for this hospitalization.

target: ___ female with history of CAD s/p MI in ___, angina, history of stents to LAD in ___, HTN, HL, PVD, AAA s/p repair, CEA, CKD (Cr 2.5), severe pulmonary hypertension, HIT, history of PE, oxygen-dependent COPD presents in setting of increasing dyspnea and chest discomfort to CCU for successful aspirin desensitization in setting of history of aspirin sensitive asthma and pre-cath hydration. C. cath showed three vessel disease, with critical Left main disease with evaluation for CABG deferred. # Aspirin-sensitive asthma Patient reporting asthma attack ___ years ago from taking aspirin. She was admitted to CCU for aspirin desensitization in setting of aspirin-sensitive asthma per ___ AERD protocol. Her baseline FEV1 was 61 % predicted. Her baseline peak flow was 250 mL on admission. She tolerated the protocol with peak flow not dropping below 200 and symptoms such as wheezing, hives, dyspnea, rhinitis. She was subsequently continued on aspirin 325 mg PO qD and should take this medication indefinitely. If she should stop aspirin for greater than 48 hours, the protocol must be repeated. # Coronary artery disease Patient admitted for c. cath in setting of 6 month history of increasing dyspnea associated with central chest discomfort relieved by rest and nitroglycerin. Patient has multiple cardiac risk factors and CAD equivalent given PVD. She presents with several month history of increased frequency of anginal symptoms that appears consistent with angina despite increased medical therapy. No episodes of chest discomfort in hospital. No active signs/symptoms to indicate acute ischemia including admission ECG similiar to prior. She underwent cardiac cath with pre-hydration/mucomyst showing three vessel coronary artery disease (see c. cath report for full details). Cardiac surgery evaluated patient and discussed high risk candidacy for revascularization. The patient and her family discussed the option and deferred surgery at this time. She was discharged on atorvastatin instead of home simvastatin in addition to plavix/aspirin. Her metoprolol succinate was uptitrated from 150 to 200 mg PO qD. She will follow-up with Dr. ___). # PUMP: Patient has history of coronary artery disease. Last ECHO in ___ showing LVEF 50-55 %. No active signs or symptoms to suggest heart failure # RHYTHM: Patient was in NSR with ectopy # COPD Patient has no active signs/symptoms of COPD exacerbation. Patient is not on ___ or steroids as "seem to bother her voice and mouth too much." She was continued on spiriva and home oxygen (2 L/min at night, 3 L/min with activity) with goal pOx of 88-95 %. . # History of PE Patient has history of PE (unknown if segmental/subsegmental/other) and unknown setting. She is anti-coagulated for life with target INR ___. Warfarin was held during the ___ period and re-started upon discharge at warfarin 1 mg PO qD. INR at discharge was 1.4. There was a plan for follow up in her ___ clinic on ___. . # Hypercholesterolemia Her lipid panel was checked during hospitalization with Cholesterol 142, ___ 114, HDL 44, and LDL 75. She was discharged on atorvastatin instead of home simvastatin . # Hypertension She was continued on metoprolol and furosemide. Her lasix was held on the day of and after her cath to avoid exacerbating possible contrast induced nephropathy. . # Questionable history of HIT: It is uncertain if the patient has true heparin-induced thrombocytopenia as records are not available and the circumstances surrounding this allergy are unclear. She was assumed to have a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, and all heparin products were avoided. # Chronic kidney disease: Patient has a baseline Cr of 2.5 - 2.9. Her creatinine at discharge was 2.2. Her CIN risk scored indicated that she had approximately a 20 % chance of developing CIN with minimal risk of requiring dialysis. # Iron deficiency anemia: Labs did not indicate anemia. She was continued on iron and will follow-up with her PCP for further discussion. # Thrombocytopenia: Patient had thrombocytopenia on admission that was stable at 150s throughout hospitalization. The etiology is of unclear origin, and outpatient work-up is advised. # Pulmonary hypertension: The patient had ___ ECHO performed on ___ which showed peak TR velocity of 45-75. Uncertain WHO classification given prior PE, COPD. No severe valvular disease per last ECHO except mild MR. ___ outpatient work-up was advised to further evaluate her pulmonary hypertension. # MRSA screen: Patient had a prior history of MRSA, and she was placed on MRSA precautions. # Transitions of care anticoag, Cr,

Approximately at 8: 30 ___ on the evening of presentation, he developed gradual onset of achy chest pain associated with diaphoresis. He denied palpitations, SOB. EMS was called and enroute he received SL nitroglycerin without improvement in chest pain and induction of hypotension. . In the ED, initial vitals were 96.7 156 123/87 16 99%RA. He was noted to have signficant ST depressions with tachycardia and without tachycadia. Troponin trended up to 0.18 and CK to 404 and echo done in ED by the fellow showed no segmental wall motion abnormalities, but EF decreased from prior at ___. Integrellin gtt, heparin gtt, asa 325mg , plavix 600mg were initiated and he was taken to the cath lab. . In the cath lab, he received 60mg IV lasix and heparin was discontinued. He received 25mcg fentanyl, 0.5mg versed, 185cc contrast, and 200cc NSb during the procedure. A swan was placed which induced ectopy and broke the SVT. LCx had 90% ISR and pt received PCI w/ a DES. He was noted to be presistently hypotensive (SBP 80-90s) and a balloon pump was placed prior to admission to the CCU. . In the CCU, he was chest pain free and his only complaint was his chronic neck and back pain. . On review of systems, he reports recent rhinnitis and non-productive cough not associated with fevers or chills. He denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. He underwent a CABG x4 with LIMA to LAD, VG to D1, VG to OM and VG to PDA . -___: Cardiac cath for recurrent angina. Patent LIMA to LAD and patent VG to RCA, occluded vein grafts to D1 and OM, 80% LM lesion, attempt at PTCRA of LM, unable to pass wire successfully, PTCA performed. . -___: PTCA and stent to LM. Echo done at that time showed significant aortic stenosis with an ___ of 1.0cm2. . -___: cath for atypical chest discomfort and cath revealed patent LM with 40% restenosis. . -___: Cath: 90% SVG to PDA and instent restenosis of the stent to the left main. S/P stent placement to the svg to pda and s/p rota and stent to LM. . -___ cath for continued pain/pre surgery: patent LIMA and SVG to PDA, mild AS. . -___ cath/MI: SVG to PDA totally occluded, high thrombus burden. S/p thrombectomy and 4 stents to PDA graft. . -___: cath: native CAD with occluded RCA and LAD and 90% LCX. BMS to mid Cx lesion, patent SVG-PDA and LIMA-LAD . -PACING/ICD: ___ ICD OTHER PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: CHF with EF 30% s/p ICD nephrolithiasis gout DM II w/peripheral neuropathy OSA CKD - baseline creatinine 1.5 <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> Father - ___ in his ___ Mother - "enlarged" heart <PHYSICAL EXAM> VS: afebrile BP=112/43 HR=79 RR= 18 O2 sat= 99% on 5L NC GENERAL: WDWN, obese male in NAD. Oriented x3. Mood, affect appropriate. HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva were pink, no pallor or cyanosis of the oral mucosa. No xanthalesma. SKIN: No stasis dermatitis, ulcers, scars, or xanthomas. PULSES: Right: Carotid 2+ Femoral groin sheath in place Popliteal 2+ DP 1+ ___ 1+ Left: Carotid 2+ Femoral 2+ Popliteal 2+ DP 1+ ___ 1+ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD WBC-7.9 RBC-3.60* Hgb-9.9* Hct-29.7* MCV-83 MCH-27.5 MCHC-33.4 RDW-15.0 Plt ___ ___ 06: 07AM BLOOD ___ PTT-50.3* ___ ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD Glucose-135* UreaN-35* Creat-2.2* Na-136 K-4.1 Cl-105 HCO3-20* AnGap-15 ___ 09: 45PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-200* ___ 09: 45PM BLOOD cTropnT-0.02* ___ 12: 50AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-404* ___ 12: 50AM BLOOD CK-MB-21* MB Indx-5.2 ___ 12: 50AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.18* ___ 06: 07AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-770* ___ 06: 07AM BLOOD CK-MB-94* MB Indx-12.2* cTropnT-2.08* ___ 01: 41PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1388* ___ 01: 41PM BLOOD CK-MB-197* MB Indx-14.2* ___ 08: 27PM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1221* ___ 08: 27PM BLOOD CK-MB-152* MB Indx-12.4* cTropnT-3.50* ___ 04: 13AM BLOOD ALT-30 AST-106* CK(CPK)-879* AlkPhos-123* TotBili-0.7 ___ 04: 13AM BLOOD CK-MB-88* MB Indx-10.0* cTropnT-3.14* ___ 06: 40AM BLOOD ALT-21 AST-48* LD(LDH)-427* AlkPhos-123* TotBili-0.6 ___ 06: 07AM BLOOD %HbA1c-7.9* ___ 06: 07AM BLOOD Triglyc-178* HDL-27 CHOL/HD-4.6 LDLcalc-60 EKG ___: Probable atrial tachycardia with variable block. Borderline intraventricular conduction delay. Inferior lead QRS configuration raises consideration of prior inferior myocardial infarction, although it is non-diagnostic. Delayed R wave progression with late precordial QRS transition. ST-T wave abnormalities. Findings are non-specific. Clinical correlation is suggested. Since the previous tracing of the same date ventricular response is now irregular and slower, precordial lead QRS configuration shows delayed R wave progression but is less suggestive of anterior myocardial infarction and further precordial lead ST-T wave changes are present. . TTE ___: The left atrium is dilated. The right atrium is moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is severe regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with akinesis of the inferior and inferolateral walls, hypokinesis of the anterior wall and septum. The lateral wall has relatively preserved function. Overall left ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= ___ %). with borderline normal free wall function. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. A bioprosthetic aortic valve prosthesis is present. The prosthetic aortic valve leaflets are thickened. No masses or vegetations are seen on the aortic valve. The mitral valve leaflets are mildly thickened. Trivial mitral regurgitation is seen. There is mild pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion. . Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, image quality is better. The aortic prosthesis can be seen and appears to work well. Wall motion can be adequately assessd on the current study. . CTA chest ___: 1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or acute aortic pathology. . 2. Coronary artery disease with prior coronary bypass surgery and aortic valve replacement. . CXR ___: No acute cardiopulmonary process. Stable moderate cardiomegaly. . LHC/RHC ___: COMMENTS: 1. Selective coronary angiography in this right dominant system demonstrated three vessel disease. The LMCA had mild plaquing throughout. The LAD had a proximal/ ostial occlusion. The Cx had a 90% in stent restenosis in the mid portion of the vessel. The RCA was known to be totally occluded and was not visualized. 2. Arterial conduit angiography revealed the LIMA to be widely patent. The SVG to the R-PDA was widely patent. The SVGs from the patients previous CABG were known to be occluded and not visualized. 3. Limited resting hemodynamics revealed elevated left and right sided filling pressures. The LVEDP was 33 mmHg and the RA A wave was 28 mmHg. The PASP was moderately elevated at 49 mmHg. There was systemic hypotension with an central aortic pressure of 81/50 mmHg. The cardiac index was low at 1.7 l/min/m2. . FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Three vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate left ventricular diastolic dysfunction. 3. Moderate pulmonary hypertension. 4. Decreased cardic index. 5. Systemic Hypotension <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You had a heart attack and required a drug eluting stent be placed in your left Circumflex artery. You will need to take Plavix every day for at least one year, do not stop taking Plavix or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ you to. This is to prevent the stent from clotting off again and causing another heart attack. You also had trouble urinating after we took out the Foley catheter. The catheter was put back in and you will need to keep it in until you see Dr. ___, in 10 days. New Medicines: 1. Flomax: to help shrink the prostate so you can urinate without the catheter. 2. Plavix: to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. 3. continue to take Aspirin daily along with the Plavix. 4. STOP taking Ibuprofen and Nabumetome 5. START taking Flonase to stop your runny nose 6. Start Imdur, a long acting nitroglycerin to prevent chest pain 7. Take Metoprolol succinate 1 tablet per day and titrate up as tolerated. 8. Start taking Furosemide to prevent fluid build up. 9. restarted lisinopril at 2.5 mg po daily . Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs in 1 day or 6 pounds in 3 days. Follow a low sodium diet.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Chest pain of sudden onset. <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac catheterization and placement of drug-eluting stent to RCA <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> Mr. ___ is an ___ M with history of HTN, questionable dyslipidemia and OSA, admitted to 6-CCU on ___ via ED, w/ complaint of one hour episode of substernal chest pressure/tightness radiating up into the neck awaking him from sleep. The pain was associated with diaphoresis but no shortness of breath. His wife gave him a full aspirin and the pain went away. She called EMS, and he was chest pain free upon available to the ER. . In the ER, initial vitals were 97.5, 84, 162/80, 16, 97% 2L NC. Initital EKG showed first degree AV block and ST elevations in the inferior leads. While in the ED, his CP recurred, and he was sent to the cath lab as a STEMI. He was plavix loaded with 600mg, started on heparin drip and given morphine. Patient was hemodynamically stable the whole time with heart rates in the ___ and blood pressures 150s-160s/80s. . In the cath lab, he had a subtotal ostium PL branch RCA lesion and DES was placed. He developed increased respiratory distress with some coughing and questionable SVT with cough. Patient received lasix 20mg IV for this and was transiently on NRB. His PCW on cath was 33. . On review of systems, he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. He denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. He denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of current chest pain, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. Upon reflection, he has felt more fatigued that usual with exertion but denies frank dyspnea. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> 1. CARDIAC RISK FACTORS: Hypertension, questionable dyslipidemia 2. Resp were unlabored, no accessory muscle use. CTAB anteriorly, no crackles, wheezes or rhonchi. ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. No HSM or tenderness. EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits. IMAGING ___ CARDIAC CATH: 1. Coronary angiography in this right dominat system demonstrated single vessel disease. The LMCA was patent. The LAD had <50% proximal stenosis, and diffuse irregularities. The LCX had no angiographically apparent disease. The RCA had a subtotal ostium occlusion posterolateral branch. 2. Resting hemodynamics revealed elevated right and left sided filling pressures with RVEDP of 16 mmHg and PCW of 33 mm Hg. There was moderate pulmonary arterial systolic hypertension with PASP 54 mm Hg. The cardiac index was low at 2.2 L/min/min2. There was normal arterial systolic and mildly elevated diastolic pressures at the aortic level with sBP 136 mmHg and DBP of 94 mmHg. 3. Left Ventriculography was differed. 4. Successful PTCA and stenting of the distal RCA into the PL branch with a 3.0 x 18 mm Promus DES (see ___ comments). 5. Successful LFA AngioSeal (see ___ comments). FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Single vessel coronary artery disease. 2. Moderate biventricular diastolic dysfunction. 3. Moderate pulmonary arterial hypertension. 4. Successful PCI of the distal RCA into the RPL with a 3.0 x 18 mm Promus DES. 5. Successful LFA AngioSeal. . ___ ECG: Sinus rhythm. A-V conduction delay. ST segment elevations in leads II, III and aVF with ST segment depressions in leads V2-V3 and V5-V6 and leads I and aVL consistent with acute transmural ischemia in the inferoposterior distribution. Relatively flat ST segment in lead V1 raises suspicion for acute right ventricular infarction. Compared to the previous tracing ST segment changes are new. . ___ Trans-thoracic Echocardiography The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. There is mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal inferior and inferolateral walls. The remaining segments contract normally (LVEF = 45-50 %). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear Mr. ___, It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization at ___. You were admitted because you had a heart attack. Images of your heart showed that critical vessels that supply blood to your heart were blocked, and so a stent was placed in order to keep the blood vessel open. it is extremely important that you take aspirin and plavix every day for one year to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. Do not stop taking aspirin and plavix or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ it is OK. You developed a very common irregular heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. You have tolerated this well but you now have an increased risk of stroke. Therefore, we have started ___ blood thinner called Dabigitran or Pradaxa to prevent a stroke. This medicine can cause easy bleeding so you may bruise easily or your gums could bleed with vigorous brushing. However, you also could have bleeding in your bowel that will give you dark or bloody stools, lightheadedness and dizziness. Call Dr. ___ away if you experience these symptoms. Please START taking the following medications in addition to your home medications: 1. Metoprolol succinate to lower your heart rate and help you heart recover from the heart attack 2. Rosuvastatin (Crestor) to lower your cholesterol 3. Plavix to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. 4. Aspirin to prevent the stent from clotting off and causing another heart attack. 5. Lisinopril to lower your blood pressure and help your heart recover 6. Pradaxa: to prevent a stroke from your atrial fibrillation Please STOP taking the following medications: 1. Amlodipine (the Lisinipril will replace Amlodipine) 2. Atenolol (the Metoprolol will replace Atenolol)
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ M with history of HTN and OSA, who was admitted with an inferior STEMI. . ACUTE # Inferior STEMI - Pt taken to cath and shown to have a subtotal ostium occlusion in the posterolateral branch of the RCA. There was successful PTCA and stenting of the distal RCA into the posterolateral branch with a 3.0 x 18 mm Promus drug-eluting stent. He was continued on aspirin and started on plavix, ACEI, statin, and switched to metoprolol from his home atenolol. . # CHF: No history of CHF but has not had an echo since stress echo in ___. ECHO showed EF 45-50% with mild to moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal inferior and inferolateral walls, Mild-moderate aortic and mitral regurgitation, and dilated thoracic aorta. . # RHYTHM: Evidence of first degree AV block on EKG back in ___ ___s now. He was monitored on telemetry and found to be in paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. He was anticoagulated with heparin drip and bridged to Pradaxa for long-term anticoagulation. . CHRONIC # Hypertension: His home amlodipine was held in favor of starting ACEI, and he was switched from his home atenolol to metoprolol for better cardioprotection. He was slowly titrated up to 50 mg metoprolol BID, which was equivalent to his home atenolol dose. He was also put on lisinopril 5mg. . # Hyperlipidemia: Per notes, he has history of hyperlipidemia,but patient reports good cholesterol levels. Lipid panel showed HDL 43, CHOL/HDL 4.0, LDL 104. He was started on atorvastatin 80mg daily for cardioprotection. . # Obstructive Sleep Apnea: He was continued on CPAP. . # BPH: He was continued on home tamulosin and finasteride. . # Low testosterone: Wife reports pt takes 200mg every 2 weeks. He was put on testosterone patch while in-house. . TRANSITIONAL # Pt will have follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___. . # Pt will have follow-up with Dr. ___ on ___.

EKG reveals ST elevations in leads 2,3, aVF and reciprocal changes in precordial leads. Troponin was 2.05. Cardiology was consulted for concern of ST elevation MI. Given the patient also had neurologic symptoms a stat head CT was performed which did not demonstrate any intercranial abnormality. The patient was given 325 mg of aspirin prior to head CT. Once head CT did not demonstrate any abnormalities the patient was brought immediately to the catheter lab for angiography. The patient remained hemodynamically stable while in the emergency department. Cardiac catheterization via R femoral access revealed total occlusion of proximal RCA with tracking in the mid RCA, mid-LAD with ?recanalized total occlusion vs subtotal occlusion. CATHETERIZATION REPORT: ESTIMATED blood loss: 30 mL Hemodynamics (see above): Preserved aortic pressure at baseline. Post-angiography, the PCW was moderately elevated at 19 mm Hg with RV ___ and PA 35/___ mm Hg. There was no oxygen step-up from the SVC to the PA post-PCI. The calculated cardiac index was lightly decreased at 2.3 L/min/m2 using an assumed oxygen consumption. Coronary angiography: right dominant LMCA: The LMCA was long with likely moderate diffuse disease, as it appeared smaller than expected with mild plaquing mid vessel. LAD: A long S1 had a 70% origin stenosis. The LAD was severely diseased after S1 with a recanalized total vs. subtotal occlusion after a small caliber/diffusely diseased D2. There was modest filling of the mid-distal LAD and a large D2 beyond the functional total occlusion. There were septal and apical collaterals filling the RPDA and D2 collaterals supplying the RPL. LCX: The CX gave off two high large and modest caliber OM branches. OM3 was small. OM4 was of modest caliber. OM5/LPL was long with minimal luminal irregularities. The distal AV groove CX continued beyond the LPL. RCA: The RCA was calcified with a proximal total occlusion with railroad tracking beyond in the mid RCA suggesting a large thrombus burden. There was faint filling of the RCA beyond the total occlusion (TIMI 0 flow). Assessment & Recommendations 1. Two vessel coronary artery disease with likely functional chronic total occlusion (? recanalized total occlusion vs. subtotal occlusion) of the mid LAD with collaterals connecting the distal LAD and major D2 with the RPDA and RPL respectively and likely acute thrombotic occlusion of the diffusely diseased RCA. 2. Moderate elevation of PCW consistent with moderate left ventricular diastolic heart failure. 3. No evidence of significant intra-cardiac shunting. 4. Successful deployment of 3 drug-eluting stent to the proximal, mid and distal RCA as primary reperfusion strategy for acute inferolateral STEMI. 5. Successful right femoral artery Perclose Closure. 6. RFV sheath to be removed subsequently. 7. Bivalirudin infusion for 6 hours. 8. ASA indefinitely. 9. Clopidogrel 75 mg daily for at least ___ year to prevent stent thrombosis. 10. Echocardiogram to assess LVEF. 11. Admit to ___ under CCU Team's Care. 12. Reinforce secondary preventative measures against CAD and STEMI. 13. Neurological evaluation for ? acute neurological event/symptoms. 14. Serial ECGs. 15. Cycle CKMB and platelets. . . There are no echocardiographic signs of tamponade. IMPRESSION: Moderate regional and global left ventricular systolic dysfunction c/w multivessel CAD. No intra-cardiac shunt identified. target: PRIMARY REASON FOR ADMISSION: ___ p/w chest pain, dizziness, R-sided weakness, slurred speech, found to have inferior STEMI and left posterior midbrain CVA. . . LEAVING AMA: The patient left AMA on ___. She had been evaluated by ___ and OT who all felt she required rehab services. Her primary team felt she was at signficant risk for falls given her ataxia and vision problems, as she had fallen and hit her head earlier in the day. The patient understood the risks of her decisions and was competent to make the decision to leave the hospital and go home rather than to an extended care facility. She was given her medications and will have ___ and ___ at home in addition to close follow-up with her PCP. . . ACTIVE ISSUES: ----------------- #) ACS: On presentation to the ED, the patient denied any chest discomfort but was found to have ST segment elevation in the inferolateral leads along with ST segment depression in leads I, aVL, and V1-V2. Coronary angiography showed a right dominant system. The LCMA was long with likely moderate diffuse disease. The LAD was signficant for a long S1 with 70% origin stenosis and otherwise severely diseased after S1 with a recanalized total vs. subtotal occlusion after a small caliber/diffusely diseased D2. There was modest filling of the mid-distal LAD and a large D2 beyond the functional total occlusion. There were septal and apical collaterals filling the RPDA and D2 collaterals supplying the RPL. The CX gave off two high large and modest caliber OM branches. OM3 was small. OM4 was of modest caliber. OM5/LPL was long with minimal luminal irregularities. The distal AV groove CX continued beyond the LPL. The RCA was calcified with a proximal total occlusion with railroad tracking beyond in the mid RCA suggesting a large thrombus burden. There was faint filling of the RCA beyond the total occlusion (TIMI 0 flow). In the cath lab, 3 DES were placed in the ___, mid and distal RCA. She received bivalirudin infusion post-procedure and started on asa and plavix TTE on ___ was signficant for moderate regional and global left ventricular systolic dysfunction (EF= 30%) c/w multivessel CAD. No LV thrombus seen but imaging of the LV apex was suboptimal. Mild-moderate mitral regurgitation. She was initially treated with heparin with a plan to bridge to coumadin; however given her extremely high fall risk, the decision was made to hold further anticoagulation with those agents. This issue can be revisited as an outpatient. She was discharged on asa (to be taken indefinitely), plavix (one year), atorvastatin, lisinopril, metoprolol. . #) CVA: Per the patient and the friend who initially found her, she had multiple falls immediately prior to admission and her "eyes looked wrong." CT Head was negative for bleed and given her EKG findings she was immediately taken to the cath lab (please see above). After arriving to the ICU, her examination was notable for nystagmus in the right eye on rightward gaze and an inability to adduct her left eye (past midline) as well as posturing of her right arm and dysarthria and possible word finding difficulties. She was evaluated by the Stroke service and MRI showed an acute infarct in the left posterior midbrain. This may have been embolic from her akinetic LV (given her wall motion abnormalities found on echo after her cath), secondary to to emoblism from posterior circulation or small vessel disease given her known hypertension. Per the Stroke neurology service, the stroke likely affected the left MLF resulting in the left INO syndrome. She may also have affected her cerebellar inflow or outflow tracks (causing ataxia and dysarthria). Prior to discharge, an MRA of the neck was performed that was limited by motion artifact. She may benefit from further workup with carotid ultrasounds and CTA neck. Because of her mental status and her recurrent falls, she was not started on coumadin during this admission. . #) Mental status changes: The patient demanded to leave AMA multiple times throughout the admission but had limited judgement or insight. She was unable to recognize the severity of her medical problems or recognize that she was unable to walk or care for herself alone. She also had visual and auditory hallucinations. Psychiatry felt this was delirium and unrelated to her stroke. . #) UTI: Patient had complained of suprapubic tenderness. UA was positive for large leuks and >182 WBC. Bactrim DS x 3 days (day ___ . #) Falls/Instability: Patient reported falling prior to admission. She was evaluated by ___ who felt she remained unstable on her feet and would benefit from rehab prior to returning home. On ___, she fell after urinating on the commode without LOC after feeling a "rush" suggestive of vasovagal. She had some external bleeding. ___ showed no evidence of acute intracranial process. . #) Social issues: The patient reported poor adherence to medications secondary to limited finances (taking pills every other or every few days to save money). She met with Social Work and will likely need continued support around this issue. As she left AMA on ___, she was given her medications in hand and educated about the importance of medication adherence. . . CHRONIC ISSUES: ------------------ #) DM-II: Hemoglobin A1c was 7.7. Her oral agents were held and she was kept on a sliding scale and placed on a diabetic diet. She will be discharged on her home medications. . #) HLD: LDL was 101. Her atorvastatin was increased to 80mg. . #) HTN: Blood pressures were monitored (goal <160) and her medications adjusted. She was discharged on lisinopril and metoprolol. . #) GERD: Maintained on home omeprazole. . #) SMOKING: Patient received nicotine patch while admitted and was given counseling about smoking cessation. She will benefit from continued support around this issue. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - The patient left AMA on ___. She would greatly benefit from rehab and physical therapy. She was competent to make this decision and despite the primary team's attempts to convince her otherwise, she left AMA to go home. She will receive ___ and ___ at home and was given her medications in addition to education about the importance of taking them as prescribed. - The patient was found to have apical akinesis on her echocadiogram. Given this and her CHADS2 score of 4, she would likely benefit from further anticoagulation. However, given her mental status and falls, she was not started on coumadin and instead discharged only on asa and plavix. This issue may be re-evalated in the outpatient setting. She may also benefit from carotid ultrasounds and/or CTA neck to futher assess her neck vasculature. - During this admission, she did not identify family members or designate a health care proxy. This may be helpful in the future. - Her medications were adjusted while inpatient. It is unclear how compliant she has been and will likely benefit from close follow-up and further titrating/modification as necessary. - During admission she reported also having a history of possible DVT. This plus her CVA and STEMI may suggest an underlying hypercoaguable disorder that could be further worked up in the outpatient setting. - Code status: full

Further optimization of regimen advised on outpatient basis. # Hypertension - continue cardiac medications as above # Aortic Stenosis s/p vavuloplasty in ___ ECHO showing grossly stable aortic stenosis. # Rhythm: Patient remained in NSR throughout hospitalization . # Steroid-dependent COPD with home O2 requirement of 1 L NC Patient has had multiple exacerbations requiring admission in ___ with last on ___ requiring ICU admission secondary to hypercarbic respiratory failure and intubation with discharge on ___. Per patient and wife, he does not take his medications on a regular basis secondary to financial issues specifically with advair diskus and tiotropium. On discharge, he was continued on a prednisone taper as outlined, tiotropium, standing duonebs, and budesonide nebs intended to replace his advair diskus given cost issues. Health Care Associates was also contacted for prescription assistance. Discussion with both patient and wife that smoking cessation would be imperative if patient wants to continue to have decent quality of life without multiple hospitalizations. He was continued on his baseline home oxygen at 1 L NC. He was also advised that adherence to prescribed regimen was also imperative as well. Consideration of changing SSRI to buproprion to assist with smoking cessation may be helpful. Patient's pulmonary appointment with pulmonary medicine was moved to ___ given recent instability. # Depression/Anxiety Patient appeared euthymic and in good spirits. He was continued on citalopram, lorazepam, and amitriptyline. . # Alkalosis Patient had HCO3 elevation from 28 to 36 with contraction alkalosis favored in setting of lasix dosage for sluggish urine output s/p cath. Although the patient has had hypercarbic respiratory failure in the past, it was less favored that renal compensation for a developing respiratory acidosis was the case given the elevation did not occur over ___ days. Patient will have labs drawn by ___ to trend before follow-up with PCP. # Anemia Patient with Hgb of 10.9 per recent OSH labs, appears at baseline per ___ labs in ___. Likely multifactorial etiology with CKD. Advise routine health maintenance screening. No evidence of acute blood loss. # Thrombocytopenia: Per last discharge summary at ___, patient has baseline thrombocytopenia. Previous work-up including HIT antibody testing at OSH was overall negative. Given concomitant anemia, cannot rule out marrow process. # Dyslipidemia The patient was continued on the aforementioned statin. - continue statin as above # Peripheral vascular disease with left carotid stenosis Patient had bilateral claudication with non-invasive vascular exam on ___ showing ABI 0.46 on right and on left 0.35 consistent with severe peripheral arterial disease at infrapopliteal level on right and on left disease at both iliacs and infrapopliteal vessels. He is advised to discuss this issue further on an outpatient basis. A1c to screen for diabetes was not suggestive of such. # Obstructive sleep apnea Patient reportedly has sleep apnea and intolerant of CPAP secondary to nausea/vomiting per OSH reports. No notable apnea observed by staff during hospitalization. Advise outpatient sleep study. # GERD Patient takes ranitidine at home. He was continued on this medication especially in setting of steroid usage. # Chronic kidney disease, Stage 2 Patient had creatinine of 0.9 in past with labs at ___ and ___ showing Cr 1.1. Given concern for CIN in setting of contrast load from c. cath and CTA chest at OSH, patient will have labs to monitor for renal dysfunction performed by ___. ##################################### Imaging incidentals ##################################### Patient noted on OSH CT Chest dated ___ to have 3 mm pulmonary nodule within left upper lobe. Radiology advised 6 month follow-up CT examination to assess stability. Patient informed in written discharge instructions about this finding. # CODE: Full # Communication: Case was discussed with patient and wife/HCP ___ (___) # ___ Lab Draw Patient is scheduled to have labs drawn by ___ on ___ with report faxed to Dr. ___. Key elements are monitoring Cr given recent contrast load and HCO3 given recent elevation as discussed above. K/Mg should also be monitored in setting of lasix and albuterol nebs.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> "Heartburn" <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Cardiac Catheterization <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS: This is a ___ year old man with a history of HLD, HTN, current smoker who had an episode of chest pain while at work that lasted 30 min, improve on its own. Then, tonight around midnight he noted a burning sensation on his chest that did not improve, radiating towards left shoulder. In the ED, initial vitals were Temp: 97.7 HR: 77 BP: 162/98 Resp: 16 O(2)Sat: 98. An ECG showed an acute inferoposterior infarct. He was hemodynamically stable and 100% on room air. No beta blocker or SL nitro was given. He was given a heparin bolus 5000U, ASA 324 and transfered to ___ for PCI. His catheterization showed a distal RCA occlusion. Two DES were places in the RCA. Final angio showed TIMI 3 flow, no dissection and 0% residual. Procedure was only remarkable for bradycardia to a rate of ___ which responded to 1mg of atropine. Upon arrival to the floor, he was stable without complaints. No chest pain. REVIEW OF SYSTEMS: On review of systems, s/he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools. S/he denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative. Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> HLD HTN Substance abuse H/o Lyme disease <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> High cholesterol, otherwise no family history of cardiac disorders. <PHYSICAL EXAM> PHYSICAL EXAM ON ADMISSION: --= PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VS: T97.8 87 124/75 18 100% General: alert and oriented, well-appearing HEENT: NCAT, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: supple, JVD 1cm above clavicle CV: distant heart sounds, regular rate and normal rhythm, no MRG Lungs: CTAB Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended Ext: warm, well-perfused; TR band on right wrist with minimal blood Neuro: grossly intact Skin: no rashes Pulses: 2+ DP bilaterally PHYSICAL EXAM ON DISCHARGE: --== PHYSICAL EXAMINATION: VS: T 98.2 66-70 ___ 18 100%RA General: alert and oriented, well-appearing HEENT: NCAT, MMM, oropharynx clear Neck: no JVD CV: distant heart sounds, regular rate and normal rhythm, no MRG Lungs: CTAB Abdomen: soft, non-tender, non-distended Ext: warm, well-perfused; right radial without Neuro: grossly intact Skin: no rashes Pulses: 2+ DP bilaterally <PERTINENT RESULTS> LABS ON ADMISSION: -== ___ 04: 07AM BLOOD Triglyc-259* HDL-27 CHOL/HD-9.6 LDLcalc-181* ___ 04: 07AM BLOOD Calcium-9.4 Phos-3.9 Mg-2.0 Cholest-260* ___ 02: 25AM BLOOD cTropnT-0.04* ___ 04: 07AM BLOOD CK-MB-123* MB Indx-11.6* cTropnT-1.40* ___ 04: 07AM BLOOD CK(CPK)-1062* ___ 02: 25AM BLOOD Glucose-113* UreaN-4* Creat-0.6 Na-133 K-4.0 Cl-97 HCO3-21* AnGap-19 ___ 06: 24AM BLOOD ___ PTT-29.1 ___ ___ 02: 25AM BLOOD Neuts-68.7 ___ Monos-5.0 Eos-1.1 Baso-0.3 ___ 02: 25AM BLOOD WBC-8.3 RBC-5.03 Hgb-15.4 Hct-45.8 MCV-91 MCH-30.5 MCHC-33.5 RDW-14.0 Plt ___ LABS ON DISCHARGE: -=== ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD WBC-6.2 RBC-5.06 Hgb-15.3 Hct-46.7 MCV-92 MCH-30.3 MCHC-32.8 RDW-14.1 Plt ___ ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD ___ PTT-28.7 ___ ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Glucose-95 UreaN-14 Creat-0.8 Na-137 K-4.7 Cl-99 HCO3-31 AnGap-12 ___ 06: 15AM BLOOD CK-MB-4 cTropnT-2.61* ___ 06: 50AM BLOOD Calcium-9.5 Phos-4.1 Mg-2.2 STUDIES: ============ Cardiac Cathterization ___: The lesion was crossed with Prowater wire revealing thrombotic subtotal occlusion and large posterior circulation. The lesion was predilated with 2.5 x 15 balloon at ___ ATM. Bradycardia to rate of ___ responded to 1 mg atropine. A 2.25 x 24 mm Promus drug-eluting stent was deployed in distal extent of lesion beyond the crux at 14 ATM and a 3.0 x 12 mm Promus drug-eluting stent was deployed overlapping more proximally. The distal stent was post-dilated with 2.5 x 20 NC ballon at 16 ATM and the proximal stent and overlap was post-dilated with 3.5 x 8 NC balloon at ___ ATM. Final angio showed TIMI 3 flow, no dissection and 0% residual. Echocardiogram ___: LEFT ATRIUM: Mild ___. RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Normal RA size. LEFT VENTRICLE: Mild symmetric LVH with normal cavity size. Mildly depressed LVEF. TDI E/e' < 8, suggesting normal PCWP (<12mmHg). No resting LVOT gradient. RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion. AORTA: Mildy dilated aortic root. Mildly dilated ascending aorta. No 2D or Doppler evidence of distal arch coarctation. AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (?#). No AS. No AR. MITRAL VALVE: Normal mitral valve leaflets. Mild (1+) MR. ___ VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial TR. Indeterminate PA systolic pressure. PULMONIC VALVE/PULMONARY ARTERY: Pulmonic valve not visualized. No PS. Physiologic PR. PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a fat pad, though a loculated anterior pericardial effusion cannot be excluded. GENERAL COMMENTS: Suboptimal image quality - poor parasternal views. Conclusions The left atrium is mildly dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size. Overall left ventricular systolic function is mildly depressed with hypokinesis of the basal and mid inferoseptal and inferior segments (LVEF= 50 %). Tissue Doppler imaging suggests a normal left ventricular filling pressure (PCWP<12mmHg). Right ventricular chamber size and free wall motion are normal. The aortic root is mildly dilated at the sinus level. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic valve leaflets (?#) appear structurally normal with good leaflet excursion. There is no aortic valve stenosis. No aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally normal. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. The pulmonary artery systolic pressure could not be determined. There is no pericardial effusion. There is an anterior space which most likely represents a prominent fat pad. IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Mildly reduced left ventricular systolic function with hypokinesis of the basal and mid inferoseptal and inferior segments consistent with coronary artery disease. Mildly dilated aortic root and ascending aorta. Mild mitral regurgitation. Indeterminate pulmonary artery systolic pressure. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete. 1. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 2. Simvastatin 40 mg PO DAILY 3. Adderall (dextroamphetamine-amphetamine) 25 mg oral QAM 4. Adderall (dextroamphetamine-amphetamine) 5 mg oral BID 5. Buprenorphine-Naloxone (2mg-0.5mg) 2 mg SL DAILY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Buprenorphine-Naloxone (2mg-0.5mg) 2 mg SL DAILY 2. Lisinopril 10 mg PO DAILY 3. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY RX *aspirin 81 mg one tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 4. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO DAILY RX *atorvastatin 80 mg one tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 5. Nicotine Patch 14 mg TD DAILY RX *nicotine 14 mg/24 hour one patch daily Disp #*30 Patch Refills: *2 6. Nitroglycerin SL 0.4 mg SL Q5MIN: PRN chest pain call Dr. ___ have any chest pain RX *nitroglycerin [Nitrostat] 0.4 mg one tablet(s) sublingually as needed for chest pain Disp #*25 Tablet Refills: *0 7. Metoprolol Succinate XL 150 mg PO DAILY RX *metoprolol succinate 100 mg 1.5 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*45 Tablet Refills: *2 8. Prasugrel 10 mg PO DAILY PCI RX *prasugrel [Effient] 10 mg one tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 9. Thiamine 100 mg PO DAILY RX *thiamine HCl 100 mg one tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet Refills: *2 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Primary Inferior ST segment elevation myocardial infarction Ventricular tachycardia Secondary Hyperlipidemia Hypertension <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> It was a pleasure caring for ___ at ___. ___ were admitted with chest pain and left shoulder pain and was found to be having a heart attack. A cardiac catheterization showed a blockage in your right coronary artery and two drug eluting stents were placed to open the artery. ___ will need to take prasugrel or Effient every day without fail to prevent the stents from clotting off and causing another heart attack. Do not stop taking prasugrel for any reason or miss any doses unless Dr. ___ it is OK to do so. An echocardiogram after the heart attack showed that your heart is only mildly weaker than before and ___ should have a good recovery of function. Please consider going to cardiac rehabilitation once Dr. ___. ___ had a dangerous heart rhythm called ventricular tachycardia in the setting of the heart attack. Your monitor did not show reoccurance of this rhythm and medications have been adjusted to prevent the rhythm from returning.
target: ___ year old man with HLD, HTN and current smoker who presented with chest pain found to have inferior STEMI now s/p placement of two drug eluting stents. #) INFERIOR STEMI s/p ___ c/b VTACH. The patient was found to have inferior STEMI on admission and was taken for cardiac catheterization requiring 2 drug eluding stents. Integrilin was continued for 2 hours post-procedure. (for full details please refer to results section) In addition the patient was continued on aspirin 81 mg daily, prasugrel 10 mg daily, atorvostatin 80 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily. Serial biomarkers were checked and down-trended prior to discharge. In addition echocardiogram post-MI showed mildly reduced left ventricular systolic function with hypokinesis of the basal and mid inferoseptal and inferior segments consistent with coronary artery disease. Mildly dilated aortic root and ascending aorta. Mild mitral regurgitation. Indeterminate pulmonary artery systolic pressure. (please see studies section for full details). On the afternoon of ___, a code blue was called when the patient was found to have monomorphic ventricular tachycardia with LOC thought to be due to reperfusion. He was shocked x1, loaded with lidocaine and started on a drip. ST elevations were noted in inferior leads, so the patient was taken back to the cath lab. No new lesions or stent thrombosis were seen. He continued on lidocaine drip for 24 hours, which was discontinued on ___. He was then transitioned to metorpolol. He will require dual antiplatelet therapy for ___ year (aspirin 81mg and prasugrel 10mg daily). #) HLD The patient was changes to atorvastatin 80 mg. #) HTN Lisinopril 10 mg daily continued. #) Substance abuse The patient was extensively counseled on the importance of smoking cessation during his hospital course and given nicotine patch prior to discharge. Suboxone was continued throughout hospital course. ================================== TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ================================== [] Will need aspirin 81mg and prasugrel 10mg daily for ___ year from ___ [] Was on Adderral prior to admission. This was stopped due to cardiac arrest/MI. [] Consider B12 given peripheral neuropathy sx [] consider rheum, ortho hand, or neuro follow up regarding hand weakness

input: <SEX> F <SERVICE> MEDICINE <ALLERGIES> Latex / Neurontin / Morphine / Percocet / Augmentin / Shellfish / Iodine / Red Dye / Dilaudid (PF) <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> broken insulin pump <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> none <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> ___ y/o F w/ h/o DMI, CAD s/p CABG, recent discharge from ___ for DKA c/b "vagal" cardiac arrest ___ p/w tx from OSH (___) for DKA. LYMPH: no cervical, axillary, or inguinal LAD SKIN: dry, no rash DISCHARGE PHYSICAL EXAM <PERTINENT RESULTS> ADMISSION LABS ___ 02: 50PM BLOOD Neuts-78.3* Lymphs-16.4* Monos-2.5 Eos-1.9 Baso-0.9 ___ 08: 15AM BLOOD ___ PTT-150* ___ ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD Glucose-343* UreaN-33* Creat-1.5* Na-142 K-4.8 Cl-110* HCO3-11* AnGap-26* ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD WBC-20.9*# RBC-3.76* Hgb-11.4* Hct-34.7* MCV-92 MCH-30.4 MCHC-32.9 RDW-12.0 Plt ___ ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD ALT-30 AST-54* LD(LDH)-245 CK(CPK)-160 AlkPhos-111* Amylase-39 TotBili-0.8 ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD Albumin-3.7 Calcium-8.6 Phos-3.9 Mg-1.7 Cholest-198 ___ 04: 58AM BLOOD %HbA1c-10.2* eAG-246* ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD Triglyc-136 HDL-69 CHOL/HD-2.9 LDLcalc-102 ___ 03: 11AM BLOOD Type-ART pO2-79* pCO2-25* pH-7.23* calTCO2-11* Base XS--15 ___ 03: 02PM BLOOD Lactate-1.6 CARDIAC ENZYME TREND ___ 02: 50PM BLOOD cTropnT-<0.01 ___ 12: 38AM BLOOD CK-MB-16* MB Indx-10.0* cTropnT-0.52* ___ 08: 15AM BLOOD CK-MB-94* MB Indx-11.9* cTropnT-2.85* ___ 12: 59PM BLOOD CK-MB-91* MB Indx-11.3* cTropnT-3.10* ___ 05: 58AM BLOOD CK-MB-21* MB Indx-7.0* cTropnT-2.22* DISCHARGE LABS MICRO: ___ URINE CULTURE NEGATIVE FINAL ___ BLOOD CULTURE __________ IMAGING: ___ CXR; FINDINGS: Two views were obtained of the chest. The lungs are well expanded and clear. There is no pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Post-CABG changes are seen with normal heart size and mediastinal contours. There is moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with hypokinesis of the septum and anterior wall. The remaining segments contract normally. Quantitative (3D) LVEF = 36%. Insulin Pump SC (Self Administering Medication)Insulin Aspart (Novolog) (non-formulary) Target glucose: 80-180 4. Levothyroxine Sodium 175 mcg PO DAILY 5.
